PUB-DATE: July 20, 1997

SECTION: Section 2; Page 1; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk 

LENGTH: 2539 words

HEADLINE: A Music Mecca Loved but Reluctantly

BYLINE: By BERNARD HOLLAND 

 BODY:
IF ARCHITECTS HAVE VISIONS AND MUSICIANS have needs, why did so much go wrong in the building of Lincoln Center? Momentous decisions of design and financing attend the birth of any arts center, but they are eventually reducible to one: the needs of the arts versus the art of the possible. I suggest that the first has been sacrificed in the name of the second.
In so many ways, Lincoln Center, now immersed in the second season of its namesake summer festival, has been an enormous success over its 35 years of life. The location is central; the address is prestigious; the publicity flows endlessly. The surrounding neighborhood has flowered. The four main theaters have elbowed their way to the center of New York's, and thus the country's, musical life. Carnegie Hall may have the patina of tradition, but Lincoln Center has the television cameras. 
 Are Lincoln Center's tenants happy? Are their customers? Are the needs of both parties met? You may find adaptability and resignation, but true contentment? Rarely. In one way or another, the buildings have let their inhabitants down, but with little hope of significant change, we have gotten used to them. I wonder how many of us, in our heart of hearts, really like Lincoln Center, yet we go there anyway. It is where things happen.
The New York State Theater, the Metropolitan Opera House, Avery Fisher Hall and Alice Tully Hall (reading the map of Lincoln Center's musical buildings from south to north) emerged between 1962 and 1969. The real-life neighborhoods of "West Side Story" were swept aside to make room for them, and more than five million patrons drop in every year, buying tickets to operas, plays, dance programs, concerts and recitals.
The city owns the land; a nonprofit corporation, the buildings. Crassly put, Lincoln Center is New York's shopping mall for the performing arts. If you can't get into "Carmen" at the Met, Bruckner at the New York Philharmonic is a few hundred feet away.
Arnold Toynbee told us that civilizations thrive more readily in harsh climates than in ecological paradises. For the making of music, Lincoln Center has certainly challenged rather than welcomed. Artists struggle daily with bad decisions made years ago, and these struggles, waged against conditions now inscribed in stone, may actually represent the most gripping theater Lincoln Center has to offer.
Lincoln Center has 11 constituents -- dance, film, theater, libraries, schools -- but music is the topic here, so first of all, how do these theaters let us hear? Not terribly well, in most cases. Acousticians wax long-winded about the science of sound, but the brief history of Lincoln Center demonstrates the crapshoot that is acoustics. Why else have the State Theater and Fisher Hall (originally Philharmonic Hall) been continually tinkered with and on several major occasions completely overhauled? Repairmen dominate the acoustical trade today. Indeed, rejiggering the mistakes of colleagues is big business for firms, any one of which might consider Hindsight Inc. as an appropriate trade name.
Another subject to think about is fit. Are the various artists of Lincoln Center operating in the right places? Wynton Marsalis seems happy to be heading up Lincoln Center's jazz division, but he still hasn't found a hall in it where jazz really belongs. (A contemplated theatrical space across Broadway on 64th Street may be helpful.)
 
New York State Theater
For Emerging Voices, A Dilemma in a Paradox
 The State Theater gets in opera's way. A good place for dance, say those who know, it does not serve the New York City Opera well. Backstage areas are small for operatic purposes, the wings even more claustrophobic. While operating areas are cramped, the State Theater's towering audience space is the opposite, reducing any hope of intimacy. Putting on Broadway musicals as part of its season is one of the City Opera's brighter ideas in recent years, but these entertainments are lost in the State Theater. The need for significant amplification makes the productions seem artificial; the distances make them cold.
Acoustically, the State Theater is certainly better than it was: that is, after several significant makeovers in the last 15 years. Its stage floor was designed to muffle the sound of dancing feet. Over the years, that floor has done much the same for singing voices. The City Opera is caught in paradox: being an important way station for emerging American voices yet presenting an environment that can strain young techniques.
The devisers of Lincoln Center and of the City Opera never wanted each other in the first place. The New York City Ballet was desirable -- indeed, necessary -- to the center, but the City Opera's cut-rate fare would undermine competing activities of other constituents, all offered at higher prices. The City Opera feared the inevitable comparisons with its huge, international next-door neighbor and was right to do so. But it also knew that if it stayed at the City Center, the Met would create its own budget opera at the State Theater and squeeze the City Opera out of business. Accepting the City Opera made Lincoln Center's job of dealing with the city easier, so it did.
Moving this brave if helter-skelter company to a smaller, more opera-friendly house -- perhaps a Broadway theater -- has been talked about for years. Money is a problem. With little or no endowment of its own, the City Opera badly needs its yearly slice of the Lila Acheson and DeWitt Wallace Fund for Lincoln Center, which in recent years has averaged $3.4 million. Independence, a heady thought, makes board members understandably queasy, for the Wallace money would not go with them.
 
Met Opera House
Wanted: Singers Built Like Defensive Tackles
 A few yards to the northwest is the Metropolitan Opera House. Seating 3,800 patrons, the Met is the King Kong of opera houses. The new Opera de la Bastille in Paris, at 2,700 seats, is already vastly larger than the old Palais Garnier (1,900 seats); it seems small beside its New York colleague. Typical European houses -- Geneva (1,500 seats), Cologne (1,350 seats) or Stockholm (1,100 seats) -- are midgets in comparison. Many of the bel canto pieces regularly produced at the Met were conceived for Italian houses of 1,000 seats or less; one thinks of the Teatro del Giglio in Lucca, where a stage whisper is perfectly audible in the balcony's last row. The Met is twice too big for its own good, and that is not hyperbole.
Forget, for yet another while, a Mini-Met in that proposed new theater across the street. People inside the Met point to the high union and production costs for first-rate productions in a small house and shake their heads.
Given its intractable problems, size being one, the Met shows admirable resolve and intelligence. Acoustics that are relatively good, considering the gargantuan dimensions, help a lot. The Met has also developed the most sophisticated and smoothly operating backstage in the world. Foreign directors, who don't necessarily like the space, come here because things work. Under James Levine, the Met has built a pit orchestra of uncontested superiority.
But the Met can't make its stage any smaller; nor can it propagate intimacy in a setting that screams of bigness. It tries, and with intermittent luck: pushing sets closer to the edge of the stage ("Cosi Fan Tutte"), focusing the eye on central points ("Queen of Spades"), repeatedly framing smaller stages within the given one. Exploiting the Met's grandiosity can backfire, as it did this year in the distant, scattered setting for "Eugene Onegin." Franco Zeffirelli's bloated Puccini extravaganzas are huge audience successes, even if Puccini is lost among the towering columns and gold-leaf decor.
The Met's major artistic challenge is finding voices that can be heard in it. Some were always there, but a new generation of consistent heft and brilliance is beginning to arrive. Think of football: the 200-pound lineman of 30 years ago looks puny on the field today; a changing athletic world has bred athletes nearly twice his size. It may not be an exaggeration to suggest that the Met is nudging us toward a whole new operatic culture. Singing teachers, impresarios and agents around the world now scout big voices and discourage smaller ones. The Met is a major part of any international career, and every singer knows it.
With gain there is loss. Finer, smaller voices are lost to Met audiences. The heldentenor Siegfried Jerusalem, by all accounts a splendid Tristan at Bayreuth and Vienna, could not do it here. Newly arrived, on the other hand, is Ben Heppner, with a big tenor sound of quality, seemingly engineered with the Met in mind. Jane Eaglen will thrive in this house. Voices with presence, Deborah Voigt's or Karita Mattila's, will also succeed.
As these singers enter, another culture, nearly extinct already, exits. I remember seven years ago, at the Opera Theater of St. Louis, a young tenor named Stanford Olsen singing Donizetti exquisitely before a sold-out audience of 950 at the Loretto-Hilton Theater. Mr. Olsen's subsequent career at the Met has been less happy. Four times bigger, the New York house has not only smothered his singing but may have damaged his voice as well.
The Metropolitan Opera House's bigness signals American exuberance, but it also has to do with money. Surrounded in the world by subsidized opera houses, the Met has gone it virtually alone and done remarkably well. Seats must be sold, lots of them, every night.
 
Avery Fisher Hall
By Any Name, A Chronic Head Case
 The building just to the northeast of the Met is Lincoln Center's resident manic-depressive. Limping from disappointment to disappointment since it opened as Philharmonic Hall in 1962, the home of the New York Philharmonic finally had to be closed, excavated and rebuilt as Avery Fisher Hall in the mid-70's. Dull and dead-sounding in early life, it became garish and top-heavy.
Helping not at all was the Philharmonic's choice as music director for the 1980's. Zubin Mehta's relish of loudness and brilliance, often expressed in superficial terms, compounded the felony of Fisher's new acoustics while playing on the worst instincts of a virtuoso urban orchestra. Yet another revision five years ago, featuring new ceiling panels and tumorlike protrusions along both sides of the stage, has done much to bring Fisher's sound to an acceptable medium ground.
Yet none of the recent changes recognize that listeners hear with their eyes as well as their ears. Fisher gives off a glare, a brightness, an unpleasant impression of heat. Listeners and musicians feel its effects. The new appurtenances, helpful as they are, add more hideousness to what was already an antimusical atmosphere. Great performances overcome adversity, and they happen at Fisher Hall. The most recent to my knowledge was in the spring: the Verdi Requiem conducted by Sir Colin Davis, a remarkable evening.
 
Alice Tully Hall
To Be or Not To Be A Chamber Hall
 Across the street to the north is Alice Tully Hall. Hamlet-like, it never made up its mind. Lurking in Tully's design is an element of greed, a desire to have it both ways. For here a theater that claims to be a home for chamber music ends up seating almost 1,100 patrons, not the 400 or 600 one would await. The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center is the titular resident here, but Tully's tall, fan-shaped space makes string quartet performances, not to mention duos, trios and quintets, too remote for comfort. Hearing a solo pianist from Tully's balcony, unless the artist has a truly extraordinary presence, is really no different from listening at the back of the much larger Carnegie and Fisher Halls.
Full orchestras can crowd themselves on stage at Tully, and the acoustical space handles them acceptably. But in the end, the hall is too big for the small and too small for the big. Its wood panels are not ugly. The seats are nicely spaced for leg room. Doors close silently. Gone, unfortunately, are the lobby's marvelous purple carpets, now replaced by play-it-safe green.
Some things work in Tully Hall: smaller orchestras like the New York Chamber Symphony, pianists like Garrick Ohlsson. Concert performances of smaller-scale operas come across well. The Lincoln Center vocal series, an excellent enterprise, features Met-size voices in recital, and they have been a good fit. But Lincoln Center has no truly appropriate chamber music hall. The Walter Reade Theater is the right size, but the dullness of the sound reflects its purpose as a place for movies, not music.
 
Juilliard Theater
The Little Auditorium That Could
 Is there a Lincoln Center hall that works as it should? One, but constituents will never get their hands on it. Buried in the bowels of the Juilliard School behind Tully Hall is the Juilliard Theater. It is a treasure, an oasis. The size, capacity 900, is sane for most of the opera repertory. The amphitheater design offers good sound and sight lines. It, like Carnegie Hall, is a place listeners feel good to be in.
Juilliard has fended off outsiders and kept it for school purposes, which are many. There is another problem: The Juilliard Theater does not employ union stagehands, and the other crews at Lincoln Center would not respond kindly to its use by the center at large.
WHAT TO DO? NOTHING, really. The buildings won't go away. They do big business. The tinkering will go on, and one hopes for the best. There are lessons for the future, perhaps, one being not to entrust artistic decisions to committees consisting primarily of lawyers and politicians. It also might be a good idea to find architects with a bolder, more selfish vision, people less ready to mollify the moneymen and city planners.
Somehow, America's best qualities, the ones that fuel our social, economic and political engines, never work with art. Killing the National Endowment for the Arts, for example, makes perfect sense to a lot of good people raised on American ideas of self-reliance and private enterprise. The isolated, inexperienced capitalist mind finds it hard indeed to fathom the ways art lives and works, so it is little wonder that lawmakers and businessmen remain bewildered if not hostile.
Artistic vision requires a certain totalitarianism. Consensus succeeds in much of America, but consensus in the arts produces Lincoln Centers. The Europeans have a lot of bad ideas about how to run a country, but they have a knack for finding the right person for a job and then letting the job be done. An example is the architect Frank Gehry, who has more or less had his way in the building of a new Guggenheim Museum in Bilbao, Spain. A similar design, the Disney Concert Hall in Mr. Gehry's hometown, Los Angeles, remains a mighty struggle, pushed and pulled by politicians and money-raisers.
I doubt that many of us would trade our passports for Spanish ones, but at moments one feels a certain wistfulness. Then again, maybe Toynbee was right. Maybe all the things wrong with Lincoln Center are meant to test us, provoke us to listen harder, play better and sing like angels. Roll up your sleeves.

HEADLINE: In the Region/Long Island;
The Advantages of a 2-Family Start With Purchasing Power

BYLINE: By DIANA SHAMAN 

 BODY:
RECENTLY, Allen and Linda Sinowitz signed a contract on their first home, a two-family house under construction in Long Beach, where they are renting an apartment for $1,200 a month.
Mrs. Sinowitz's aunt, Marianne Veitt, a retired teacher, will move into the downstairs rental apartment and help with the mortgage payments, said Mr. Sinowitz, who works as a nursing-home administrator in Brooklyn. Mrs. Sinowitz is the director of social work at a local nursing home.
"We have two children and since we both work, this will also be a perfect opportunity for someone to be there for the kids when they get home from school," Mr. Sinowitz added. "So it works out well for both of us." 
 Whether for family reasons or for economic ones, many families are discovering the advantages of purchasing legal two-family houses. They are also discovering that few such opportunities are available, especially in Suffolk County.
In Nassau, the inventory of legal two-family dwellings consists mostly of older homes converted before zoning rules took effect. New construction, though permitted in some areas of the county, is limited because of restrictive zoning. And in Suffolk, two-family houses have only been built under pilot programs sponsored by nonprofit groups.
"There's a bias against two-family houses because of the inherent prejudice on Long Island against anything that seems to smack of New York City," said Jim Morgo, president of the Long Island Housing Partnership, a nonprofit housing group in Hauppauge.
Yet one of the Partnership's most successful projects was an enclave of eight two-family houses built in Bay Shore two years ago on land donated by the Town of Islip. The $116,500 price was made possible by a $50,000 New York State grant for each house. The houses were designed by Burton Behrandt Smith of Patchogue.
The rental income -- tenants have to be over 60 and rents are capped at 75 percent of fair-market rents in the area -- allowed buyers like Karen Commander, who is single, to qualify for a mortgage. She occupies the three-bedroom upper apartment, and rents out the one-bedroom lower unit for $750 a month.
"I never thought I'd be able to buy a house," said Ms. Commander, who works in the public relations department of a local hospital.
She had been paying $550 a month for a studio rental. Now she pays $1,200 monthly for her $110,500 mortgage, but the rental income brings the cost down to $450, plus utitilities.
"And besides, it's nice to know there is someone downstairs," Ms. Commander added.
Even in much higher price ranges two-family houses are "a very good housing option because you pay less for your own apartment than you would pay in rent," said Abraham Shokrian, one of the principles of Charman Construction of Long Beach, which is building the Sinowitzes' house.
The five houses still available that Charman has under construction in Long Beach are priced from $300,000 to $350,000 depending on lot size and location. Each has two three-bedroom, two-bath apartments and a one-car garage. Upper units, usually occupied by the homeowner, are 1,600 square feet in size. The lower, 1,300-square-foot units typically command rentals of $1,400.
If a buyer were to make a 20 percent down payment on a $330,000 house, the $2,700 monthly mortgage payment on the $264,000 mortgage, which would include $500 in taxes, would be partially offset by a rental income of $1,400, Mr. Shokrian pointed out. The $1,300 difference, he added, would be less than the homeowner would pay to rent a comparable apartment in the community. In addition, the homeowner benefits from tax deductions that include a depreciation allowance for the rental unit.
EDWARD MAYOURIAN of Old Westbury builds two-family houses in Glen Cove and Port Washington, communities that also permit two-family house construction in some sections. The problem is not demand, but finding land to build on, Mr. Mayourian said. Prices for his houses, which have two- or three-bedroom side-by-side apartments, range from from $275,000 to $370,000.
Prices for existing two-family houses in Williston Park, Mineola and Port Washington start at $220,000, but the rental income puts them within reach of first-time buyers, said Evelyn Atanas, owner of the Atanas Realty agency in Williston Park.
"It's a wonderful way to get a start in homeownership," she said. Mortgage payments, including taxes, on a $220,000 house typically average $1,800, but with one-bedroom apartments commanding rents of $900 and in strong demand, a buyer could cut monthly expenses in half, she noted.
"The rule of thumb is that $1,000 of rental income is enough to pay for $130,000 in mortgage debt based on an 8 percent interest rate," said Wayne McCann the owner of the Harmonious Homes brokerage in Sea Cliff, another area where older two-family houses are available.
PRICES for two-family houses in Sea Cliff generally start at $160,000 and go up to $250,000, Mr. McCann said. The rental market is extremely strong, he added, with only a 2 percent vacancy rate. Harmonious Homes also has a rental department -- the tenant pays the fee -- and runs credit checks on tenants for the homeowner.
Mr. McCann pointed out, however, that buying a two-family house means sacrificing some privacy and adapting to being a landlord. "It's not for everyone," he warned.
Nevertheless, Andrew Lapinksy, who with his wife, Lisa, purchased a 60-year-old former carriage house in Sea Cliff three years ago through Harmonious Homes, said they made the right decision.
They paid $183,000 for the property, putting down 10 percent. The downstairs one-bedroom apartment brings in an $850 monthly income, which reduces their monthly mortgage payment of $1,250 to $400. However, they are responsible for heating the house, which adds about $200 to their monthly cost.
Their own one-bedroom apartment, which has a finished attic, would rent for at least $1,000, said Mr. Lapinsky, who works as a sales representative for an oil company. "And here we can own our own house at a cost of only $400 plus utilities," he said.
Manor Haven, an incorporated village just south of Sands Point, is another area where two-family houses are available, said Dorothy Waxman, owner of the Sandsport real estate agency in Port Washington. The community has a private beach, a muncipal pool and tennis courts and is within the highly rated Port Washington School District.
The rental income allows buyers who might not be able to afford a single-family house in the village to buy a home there, Mrs. Waxman said.
Her current listings range in price from $220,000 for a 53-year-old house with two one-bedroom apartments to a 3-year-old dwelling with 2 side-by-side 3-bedroom apartments with dining rooms, priced at $439,000.
Mortgage interest rates for two-family houses are competitive with those of single-family homes, said Neil Krumper, vice president of Sterling National Mortgage in Great Neck,a mortgage broker.
When qualifying buyers for a mortgage, banks normally take 75 percent of rental income and add it to a buyer's income. Under the standard formula, a buyer can spend no more than 28 percent of income on housing costs, and no more than 33 percent of income on all monthly debt.
But the Federal National Mortgage Association (Fannie Mae), which purchases mortgages that banks originate, has a more liberal program for purchasers of two-family houses. To qualify for the program, Fannie Mae allows buyers to factor in 75 percent of their rental income in calculating their monthly mortgage outlay, thereby letting them fall within the 28 percent and 33 percent debt limits.
Down payments under the program can be as low as 5 percent, but the mortgage amount cannot exceed $274,550. Although there are no income restrictions, buyers who want to participate in the program must attend a counseling session, and must make at least $1,000 more in gross monthly income than their housing expenses.
A pamphlet, "Becoming a Landlord," is available by writing Fannie Mae at 3900 Wisconsin Avenue, NW, Washington, D.C. 20016- 2899. Information on counseling sessions is available by calling (800) 7-FANNIE.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Allen and Linda Sinowitz, with children, at Long Beach 2-family home. (Richard Lee for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
New Uses for Old Sites in Clifton and Nutley

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
FOR decades they stood as familiar, and largely empty, landmarks along the stretches of Route 3 and the Garden State Parkway that run through Clifton and Nutley. Now plans are advancing to turn the commercial complexes, or their sites, to new uses, ranging from housing to retail and office space.
Most of the properties are in the Passaic County city of Clifton. There, the former Shulton Industries site, where men's soaps and toiletries once were produced, is being targeted for housing. The old ITT and Automatic Data Processing (ADP) sites are planned to become a retail/enterainment center. And the former research building used by the BASF Corporation, the chemical conglomerate, is being recycled into a Class A office structure. 
 In neighboring Nutley Township in Essex County, another ITT property is to become a town-house community. The site, now vacant, once housed the company's avionics and military and electronics division, including its 325-foot research tower.
In nearly all cases, developers are responding to rezoning of the industrially zoned parcels for new uses. They are also trying to take advantage of the state's improving economy -- 250,900 of the 262,200 jobs lost during the recession have been regained, figures from the Labor Department show. Well-positioned former manufacturing sites are considered candidates for re-use.
The Nutley and Clifton sites are rarities in northern New Jersey: large development sites near highways and job centers, including Manhattan, 15 minutes away.
But the re-use of such tracts poses a delicate balancing act for the towns as they seek ways to expand their tax bases while preserving quality of life of their residents. A main concern, within and across town boundaries, is that the new developments do not strain municipal services, particularly roads and schools.
In Clifton and Nutley the opportunity for redevelopment comes from the loss of industry, which has dominated the highways since they cut through those towns earlier this century.
For over the last decade companies like Shulton shut down and others like ITT, which split into three companies in 1995, reconfigured its space needs, providing the towns with space to redevelop for the first time in many years.
New Jersey, like the nation, has seen its manufacturing base erode. As of 1996 there were 610,600 manufacturing jobs in the state, down from 915,500 in 1979, according to data from the state's Department of Labor.
"We cannot wait for a single industrial user to fill the empty sites we have," said Mayor James Anzaldi of Clifton. "By rezoning them we took a pro-active stance that will serve the land with multi new uses."
City Manager Robert P. Hammer said the redevelopment also would help Clifton, which still has a substantial industrial base, to retain its position of having one of the lowest tax rates in the county. "We are exploring the options brought on by market trends and will select what is best for and has the least impact on the city," he said.
FOR the 205,000-square-foot former BASF site, at the intersection of Route 3 and Exit 153 of the Garden State Parkway, the answer is for Reckson Associates Realty Corporation to turn it into offices.
"The are no large blocks of space along Route 3 west of the Meadowlands or along the Parkway south of Paramus and north of Cranford," said Mark D. Schaevitz, senior vice president of the real estate investment trust, which is based in Melville, L.I.
Reckson is demolishing 25,000 square feet of the building for parking space. The remaining 180,000 square feet is being stripped to its skeleton and will be reclad with glass and aluminium. The new building, to be completed by next spring, will be leased to one tenant or could be divided into 10,000- to 15,000-square-foot blocks, said Mr. Schaevitz
The former 42-acre Shulton site, which has been closed since 1991 and is off Exit 154 of the Garden State Parkway, at Colfax Avenue, is expected to be sold soon and converted to housing. The seller is American Home Products, based in Madison, which acquired the site as part of its acquisition of American Cyanamid in 1995, and wants to "dispose of the property as quickly as possible," said Peter D. Blanchard. He is senior vice president of the Garibaldi Group, the Chatham-based real estate brokerage marketing the site for American Home Products, a manufacturer of pharmaceuticals and medical equipment.
The buyer, industry sources said, is Town and Country Developer, a division of Whiteweld, Barrister & Brown, a real estate investment company with offices in Woodcliff Lake and Manhattan. Town and Country is also advancing plans to redevelop the former ITT property in Nutley into housing. No one involved in the deal would comment.
The site is part of a 130-tract, which also includes the vacant Athena Steel property as well as a parcel occupied by Parkway Iron, that the city has rezoned for a mix of uses. The Shulton parcel is closest to existing neighborhoods, and as such works best as housing, said Mr. Blanchard.
He said the plan being advanced called for 800 for-sale town houses, of which 200 would be reserved for active adults age 55 and over. The sale is contingent on the plan's gaining approvals from the city's planning board.
Mr. Hammer said Clifton wanted a variety of houses, particularly those that will meet the needs of its older residents. That, in turn, will also temper the impact additional housing would have on city schools, he said.
ON July 10 the city approved plans to turn part of the old ITT and ADP sites along Route 3 into a 285,000-square-foot retail-entertainment center, comprising a 16-screen movie theater, a 70,000 square foot supermarket, 130,000 square feet of stores and two restaurants. The developer is Related Clifton Corporation, an affiliate of the Related Companies, a large Manhattan development company.
It bought the 62-acre ITT site and the 11-acre ADP parcel last year because "whatever the market, finding 73 acres this close to Manhattan is an irreplaceable opportunity," said James M. Jarosik, executive vice president at Related.
The complex, called Clifton Commons, is the initial phase of a larger mixed-use development that eventually will occupy the combined sites and include up to 750,000 square feet of hotel, office, housing and additional retail uses said Mr. Jarosik.
The first phase, scheduled for completion by next spring, will rise on 22 vacant westerly acres of the ITT site and the entire ADP site, which borders Nutley. Mr. Jarosik said the location supported the retail-entertainment concept because 236,000 people with an average household income of $55,000 live within three miles of it and the closest moviehouse is six miles away. The remaining 40 acres is home to a 950,000-square-foot building the avionics division of ITT Industries has leased back from Related until 2002.
Nutley has concerns about the project's first phase, mainly its density and its having an entrance off Kingsland Avenue. A second entrance from the avenue was recently eliminated, but Nutley residents are still worried that traffic from the project will spill onto their local streets.
Mayor Garry J. Furnari of Nutley called the project an example of overdevelopment. "They are trying to squeeze a gallon-sized project on a pint-size parcel of land," said Mr. Furnari, adding that his community would consider appealing the approval.
Meanwhile, Nutley, which rezoned the former 65-acre former ITT site within its borders for housing, is reviewing Town and Country's plan to build 582 town houses and 33 detached homes there. The company is under contract to buy the site contingent upon approvals, which Joseph L. DiBernardo, its senior vice president said he hoped to get next month.
Mr. DiBernardo said prices for the 1,400- to 1,800-square-foot town houses would be in the low $130,000's to $220,000 range. Construction is expected to start in September.

HEADLINE: In the Region/Connecticut;
Pfizer Adding 100 Labs to Its Groton Complex

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON 

DATELINE: GROTON

 BODY:
JUST a few hundred feet from Pfizer's laboratories here, where scientists are carrying out delicate experiments, construction workers are blasting a three-acre hole into solid granite, removing 2,000 cubic yards of rock a day to make way for 550,000 square feet of new research space.
It is the latest round of expansion for the pharmaceutical company that has enjoyed phenomenal growth in southeastern Connecticut. Pfizer's Central Research Division, which is based here, will add 700 workers when the new, 100-laboratory building opens in 1999, bringing its total to 3,400. 
 Dr. Nicholas A. Saccomano, a vice president of Pfizer in charge of medicinal chemistry in the neuroscience section, said the new building would bring a variety of disciplines under one roof. The expectation is that by bringing them together, new perspectives and new discoveries will be generated.
"In some places people are still building separate chemistry and biology buildings," Dr. Saccomano said. "If you're going to build a car, are you going to have the people who put the front wheels on in one building, and the people who put the back wheels on in another? It wouldn't make sense. It's inefficient. This one building will house all the disciplines we need to turn ideas into products."
In a region that has been hard hit by cuts in military spending, Pfizer's expansion has been greeted warmly.
"I think we're the envy of every community in the country," said Bette J. Giesing, Groton's Mayor. "It's every community's dream to have this kind of campus-like setting generating a lot of good jobs and taxes and helping our community flourish."
Years ago, there were some complaints about the manufacturing part of the operation, across Eastern Point Road from the research site. But the company has invested millions of dollars in pollution-, noise- and odor-control equipment. The last time she received a complaint was two years ago, said Mayor Giesing. "Within two weeks they were changing their manufacturing process and the smells went away," she addded.
"That makes a real good neighbor," she said, "when they respond so quickly."
Pfizer executives have suggested the expansion might only be the start. Dr. John L. LaMattina, vice president for discovery, said that in 1988 Pfizer constructed a 260,000-square-foot laboratory that led to discoveries that are now moving into the trials in a new clinical building opened this year. Financial analysts have said Pfizer's pipeline of products awaiting final Food and Drug Administration approval is among the strongest in the industry.
"The decision was made that we need to discover more, to maintain our pipeline over the years to come," Dr. LaMattina said. "So we're building discovery space. And in a few years time, if we're as successful as I expect we will be, we will have to expand in the development and clinical areas. This is kind of like a tsunami -- it just keeps rolling along and picking up momentum."
Business leaders in the region have said Pfizer's decision to increase the size of its Groton research site sends a strong signal to other high-technology companies.
"It shows the state's business climate is starting to improve," said William D. Moore, president of the Southeastern Connecticut Chamber of Commerce. "They're good, high-paying jobs that Pfizer is bringing to the region, and other companies are going to take notice."
John C. Markowicz, the director of the Southeastern Area Regional Economic Development Corporation in New London, said Pfizer could prove to be a magnet for other, smaller drug companies that might be looking to collaborate with the pharmaceutical giant, or some vendors.
"One biotechnology company has just decided to move into the Norwich Industrial Park, and one of their primary customers is going to be Pfizer," Mr. Markowicz said. "That's a sign that it's already starting to happen."
Others expect an impact on the residential market as well. John P. Read, president of Atlantic Financial Services, a mortgage broker in Groton, said the expansion will mean an influx of well-educated, affluent consumers who he predicts will look for houses in the $200,000 and up price range, double the median house price in New London County.
"They're going to be buying better houses, they're going to be buying better cars, they're going to be spending more money in the local retail stores," Mr. Read said. "There's going to be a tremendous impact on the local economy."
Gary D. Smith, the developer of the 41-unit cluster development called Peppermint Ridge on 100 acres in nearby Old Lyme, said that about two-thirds of his buyers were Pfizer employees from previous expansions.
"Most of them are looking for an upscale community to live in, and Old Lyme fits that bill," Mr. Smith said. "In the past, a lot of them looked at Mystic and Stonington. But with the tourism expanding in that area, we're seeing more of the Pfizer people come this way."
THE new research building will be five levels, including two below ground, said Michael J. Mirabito, the senior project engineer. Visitors will enter into an atrium that looks up three stories into glass-walled laboratories. Conference space, coffee nooks, and other building amenities will be designed to get people from different labs to mingle. "We're going to get people out of their labs, talking with each other, and the hope is that it will foster quicker discoveries," Mr. Mirabito said.
He said one difficulty had been trying to shoehorn the building onto a 137-acre campus that is already crowded with more than 75 buildings. Because of the constraints the construction is going down two floors, into solid granite, and up three floors.
"Logistically, it's a very tight site," Mr. Mirabito said. "You've got roads, railroad tracks, the parking garage, and other buildings all around it -- there is no flexibility in any of the boundaries,"
And there are the problems singular to laboratory construction, he said, most of them a result of the air-flow requirements. Chemistry labs generally need a flow hood that can remove any harmful vapors.
"There's ductwork in there that you could drive a car through, that we need to deliver the volumes of air that we need," Mr. Mirabito said. All counter and floor surfaces must be durable to chemical spills, and easy to clean, he said. And labs require a lot of services -- compressed air, vacuum, nitrogen, a drainage system for chemical waste and a separate system for sanitary waste. "It's almost like building two buildings."
Dr. Saccomano said Pfizer was in the middle of an international expansion of research capacity, with projects under way in England and Japan. But the Groton expansion is by far the largest, and reflects the fact that most of the company's drug discoveries already come out of that site. "We know we've got a good engine -- why not run it a little bit faster?" Dr. Saccomano said.

LENGTH: 1006 words

HEADLINE: The Bronx Is Named an 'All-America' City

BYLINE: By F. ROMALL SMALLS 

DATELINE: THE BRONX

 BODY:
A RECENTLY restored 11-story limestone building here in this busy neighborhood, the Morrisania section of the South Bronx, stands prominently as a striking example of urban renewal in America.
And as a result of ambitious projects like this one, which is called Urban Horizons and is housed in the former Morrisania Hospital, the borough was named an "All-America City" by the National Civic League last month. 
 New York City's only mainland borough has for years been considered a prime example of urban blight. But within the last 10 years, community leaders, along with various government agencies and philanthropic groups, began the task of redeveloping the area.
To many Westchester County residents, the nearby Bronx has often seemed to be the converse image of the suburban prosperity.
The Bronx and Westchester were one community 300 years ago. But after the consolidation of New York City into five boroughs in 1898, the two communities have had a tacit affiliation.
Much of the isolation, negative perceptions and dilemmas that have scourged the Bronx for more than three decades, however, will become a distant memory if its recent national recognition and the desire of community groups and city officials are any indication.
Hy Frankel, chief of staff of the Bronx Borough President's Office said he had suggested that the Bronx apply for the National Civic League "All-America City" award because he felt that the story about the revitalization of the Bronx was largely untold. "Winning this award was an extremely significant moment as far as telling the story of the Bronx's resurrection," he said. "You don't think of the big cities and the Bronx as 'All-American.' New York City and the Federal Government had given up on the Bronx. But changes have occurred from the bottom up, and what a story about the human spirit to fight."
Mr. Frankel was part of the 15-member delegation representing the borough at the competition in Kansas City, Mo. He, along with community leaders and other officials, presented the record of development in the Bronx for the last 10 years.
There were 1,400 communities vying for the award and the field was narrowed to 30 finalists.
The "All-America City" award is based on a community's application and presentation, which includes questions relating to community challenges and concerns and citizen participation. Applicants were also responsible for corroborating the degree of success in realizing community goals, by describing in detail three recent community-driven projects that made a difference in the last three years.
The award is given to 10 cities each year, and each of the winners receives a $10,000 grant. This year's "All-America City" awards were underwritten by the Allstate Foundation. Bronx officials and civic leaders said that the urban renewal accomplishments in the borough represent a definite change, which illustrates the significance of grass-roots problem solving.
The three Bronx projects highlighted in the award-winning application were the Mid-Bronx Senior Citizen Council, one of many nonprofit community development corporations in the borough, which have worked at rebuilding the housing stock throughout the region; the Undercliff/Sedgwick Neighborhood Safety Service Council, which, with residents of this western area of the borough and city officials, worked to rid the community of blight and crime, and the Women's Housing and Economic Development Corporation, which has addressed the issues of women living in the Morrisania section of the Bronx by obtaining $23 million in state, Federal and private funds to create Urban Horizons, a collaborative effort to provide affordable housing, child care, health care and economic development.
"People are really stunned when they walk through our neighborhoods and they don't see the textbook definition of devastation," Fernando Ferrer, the Borough President, said.
Mr. Ferrer, who called the Civic League award the "Super Bowl for cities" is most proud of his administration's ability to forge partnerships with local community organizations to help solve problems in the borough.
"Our partnerships have got their hands around these vexing problems, that is amazing," he said. "All the people of the Federal Government claim they know the answers to urban problems. But we are carrying out these solutions right under their noses."
Mr. Ferrer also said that the Bronx has built or refurbished 30,000 housing units, carried out community-based policing that has contributed to a 25 percent reduction in crime and, with the aid of state and federally financed Economic Empowerment Zones, has attracted 522 new businesses to the area and increased construction in the borough by $2.6 billion.
Bernd Zimmermann, president of the Bronx Economic Development Corporation, said the "All-America City" award indicated that urban areas are regaining civic stature.
He said closer ties between suburban and urban communities are needed to compete in the world market. "We have to understand ourselves as an economic region competing with the world," Mr. Zimmermann said, adding that the isolation of inner cities adversely affects all of society.
To help develop a regional economic philosophy between the Bronx and Westchester, a joint transportation center, which will connect Bronx bus lines with the Metro-North Commuter Railroad in the South Bronx, is expected to be completed this summer.
For 48 years, the National Civic League, based in Denver, has awarded the "All-America City Award" to to cities and communities in recognition of their civic achievements and grass-roots approach to solving problems.
Michael F. McGrath, communication director of the National Civic League, said: "The Bronx is an example of a community 20 years ago that was an example of urban blight. What we look for in an 'All-America City' is not perfection. It is a city with a strong civic infrastructure where people do really creative things to address these challenges."

HEADLINE: Public Housing's New Design

BYLINE: By R.L. FELSON 

 BODY:
IT looks like a scene from a wealthy suburban school: children in after-school programs, designing their own Web pages, developing photographs in a darkroom, learning computer skills, taking drum lessons or working on creative writing or video projects. Some children are outdoors playing basketball or soccer or running laps as part of a track club.
But the scene is from a Hartford housing project, where some of the poorest residents in the city live, and Hartford Housing Authority officials say it represents just one dramatic change underway within the 4,500 units of public housing in Connecticut's capital. 
 Within three years, the agency intends to "dramatically improve the quality of life for every family within public housing," said the authority's executive director, John D. Wardlaw.
Most visible will be the renovation, reconfiguration or demolition of every unit in the city's dilapidated public housing, which is scattered in high-density projects throughout the city. According to Paul Capra, an assistant to Mr. Wardlaw, the number of public housing units in Hartford will be reduced in density by a third or a half. Demographics could also change as officials build new units and neighborhoods, requiring residents who return to be employed or in training for employment.
As demolition continues through the summer -- the first section of Charter Oak Terrace in the southwest part of Hartford was razed more than a year ago -- displaced residents are being relocated to market-rate private rental units under the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development's Section 8 subsidy program.
The dispersal of residents who for generations lived in housing projects is not only making the once-crowded housing complexes safer, authorities said, but is also having a ripple effect on neighborhoods and schools throughout Hartford and some of its suburbs as they adjust to their new neighbors, many of whom never lived in private housing before.
"It's a historical moment in the life of Hartford," Mr. Wardlaw said. "This is a test case, a laboratory. If we can make it work here, we can make it work around the country."
To date, 1,000 of the 4,500 families in public housing projects have moved into private units under the Section 8 program, in which landlords' rent is guaranteed by the Federal government.
Ninety percent of those residents are moved to housing within Hartford; the remaining 10 percent have moved to suburbs including West Hartford, East Hartford, Bloomfield, Manchester and New Britain.
The most dramatic project underway is at Charter Oak Terrace, where $41 million in Federal financing is being spent on what was once a haven for gangs and drug dealers.
From a peak of 1,000 units, the complex will be replaced with just 280 units by 2001, more than a three-quarters reduction. The first new homes, 50 in number, is scheduled for completion in December.
But Mr. Wardlaw said the reconstruction is more than one of bricks and wood. Unlike traditional housing projects that were islands unto themselves, the new development on 22.5 acres will blend into the adjoining neighborhood.
Existing neighborhood streets, for example, will be extended and joined to streets in the housing project, and the new single-family houses will be built on 6,000-square-foot lots, not unlike typical suburban developments.
The reconstruction also means the end of barracks-style buildings, which were originally put up as cheap housing for factory workers.
Besides rebuilding the community, the agency has embraced a economic development study by the Capitol Region Growth Council, and paid for by Aetna. The study calls for the creation of 500 jobs and a business park on 25 acres at Charter Oak now free of housing. The office and factory park would straddle the Hartford and West Hartford town lines.
"It's not just housing. It's jobs. It's education. It's everything a neighborhood should have," said Mr. Wardlaw.
Plans also include new training programs for children and their parents in what has been called "a campus of learners."
The program, run by a five-year-old New Haven-based mentoring program called Leadership in Education and Athletics in Partnership, or LEAP, aims to turn Charter Oak into a campus of self- sufficient, employable residents who may eventually own the homes they live in, one of the other goals of the public housing transformation.
An after-school program includes Web sites where students can post their work. They can use E-mail to communicate with their teachers about homework assignments.
"We're an additional support network in partnership with parents," said Mercedes Soto, who runs the program.
The Southern New England Telephone Company gave the city $15,000 to set up a system to access the Internet quickly and Trinity College has donated part of its Internet server to allow the Housing Authority to create its own Web site for the families who live in public housing.
Getting the children to feel comfortable with computers, Mr. Capra said, not only allows them to get what many suburban children are getting as a matter of course, but also will give them important skills they will need to enter the work force.
The Housing Authority has similarly ambitious plans at nearly all its other projects. One example is at Bellevue Square, a 309-unit complex in the North End of Hartford. With $15 million in Federal funds, it will be rebuilt and reduced in density to a 130-unit complex. Gone will be common entryways and common doors. Instead, each unit will have its own private entrance and a sense of private space.
Creating neighborhoods where residents are given a greater sense of privacy and responsibility, Housing Authority officials said, is seen as one tool to combat crime and drug abuse.
Mr. Wardlaw said many of the changes reflect the realization by officials that the public housing structure of the past no longer works. Twenty years ago, those in public housing may have been "poor in the pocketbook, but they were families," he said. "They didn't have the welfare system like today."
Over the years, as many families the very poor were left in increasing isolation, without a neighborhood to help them seek a way out.
Hartford's new public housing plan is meant to make sure it is not housing "for criminals . . . or ill-adjusted individuals," but housing "for poor people who need assistance and no longer want to be poor."

GRAPHIC: Photo: A prototype single-family dwelling in the Charter Oak area, part of what is replacing the old high-density housing. (George Ruhe for The New York Times)(pg. 8)

HEADLINE: Paying the V.A.T.

 BODY:

To the Editor: It was too bad that I did not read Betsy Wade's column "Getting V.A.T. Back, at a Price" (June 22) before a recent trip to Europe. But I have a warning to add.
A pitfall exists for those who are not leaving for the United States from the country where they made their purchase. The V.A.T. refund office will not process a refund request unless one shows a ticket for a direct flight out of the European Union. In my case, I was going from Vienna to London and then New York. My purchase at a Vienna stationery store was rejected at the Vienna airport. I was told to resubmit it at Heathrow, which I did. However the staff at Heathrow seemed at a loss. They finally handed me a pre-addressed envelope and told me to drop it into a designated box. Naturally, there was relatively little time, but I believe I followed their instructions. You guessed it: The form never arrived and the merchant has refused a refund. So I imagine that the economy of Austria will receive an added infusion of my funds. 
 My conclusion is that there are no bargains in Europe.
 
ELLIS A. HURWITZ
New York, N.Y.

HEADLINE: Enlarging the Preservation Band

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP 

 BODY:
IN her three-year stewardship of New York City landmarks, Jennifer J. Raab has developed some untraditional ideas about who belongs to the preservation community. Like Bernard H. Mendik, chairman of the Real Estate Board of New York. And the ever-expanding Gap apparel empire.
"We've broadened the constituency of preservation," said Ms. Raab, who was named chairwoman of the Landmarks Preservation Commission in July 1994 by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. "It's not about the battles any more." 
 The battles were fought against what preservationists saw as development plans that destroyed or compromised New York's heritage. While the commission was not exactly in their thrall, groups like the Municipal Art Society and even individuals like Margot Gayle, a champion of cast-iron architecture, had considerable access and influence.
Preservationists still have access. But Ms. Raab has made it plain that the days of Us vs. Them are over. "I don't see anyone as the enemy," she said. "Property owners are by nature potential preservationists. If they're going to invest in their buildings, they're going to make a tremendous contribution."
She believes that the preservation impulse is so widespread that it has exceeded the purview of traditional advocacy groups; that owners will gravitate toward restoration and renovation of historic properties if they are not unduly burdened by the government.
Her critics wonder whether Ms. Raab may be diluting the commission's authority -- and therefore the integrity of the city's landmarks and historic districts -- as she makes it into a "user-friendly" agency that is more of a partner in the economic development process.
They fear that the commission will become an instrument of city policy rather than a semi-autonomous deliberative body that can, if necessary, stand up to City Hall.
Overdue or overdone, the changes could probably have been made only by an outsider. And Ms. Raab was just that at the time of her appointment: a 38-year-old litigation associate at Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison who had served as issues director in Mr. Giuliani's first mayoral campaign.
Although she once successfully defended a landmark designation on the Upper East Side from a legal challenge by its owner, Ms. Raab arrived at the landmarks commission with little experience in preservation.
She learned quickly. Between individual landmarks and historic districts, the 11-member commission regulates some 20,000 buildings, roughly 2.5 percent of all the properties in New York. It received nearly 6,000 work applications in the fiscal year that ended last month, an increase of more than 50 percent from 1990.
While other members work part-time without pay, the chairwoman receives $117,370 a year for a full-time job that includes heading an agency with 50 employees, a $2.7 million annual budget and its own landmark headquarters, the former First Precinct Police Station, an 86-year-old limestone palazzo at Old Slip and South Street.
"The commission has survived the awful budget-cutting that has gone on," said Anthony C. Wood, a private preservationist who worked for the agency in 1980 and has watched it closely ever since. "That is a real tribute to Jennifer Raab. Her good working relationship with the Mayor has been extremely helpful in keeping the commission an independent agency."
Not only has the commission survived but it has gained enforcement muscle, said Jack Taylor, a preservation advocate who frequently appears on items involving Gramercy Park, Union Square and Ladies' Mile. He said Ms. Raab had "come down very definitely on the subject of violations, far more than her predecessors."
Pushing to increase compliance with the landmarks law, Ms. Raab has created a new position in the agency, director of enforcement. She deals sharply with violators when they appear before the commission.
Perhaps her most important initiative is a bill that was introduced Tuesday in the City Council, at the Mayor's request, authorizing the commission to seek civil penalties, up to $5,000 a day, from owners or tenants who destroy or significantly alter the architectural features of a landmark.
Ms. Raab uses carrots as well as sticks. She gave a Preservation Achievement Award last year to Mr. Mendik for restoring the exquisite Art Deco lobby of the former General Electric Building, 570 Lexington Avenue, at 51st Street. She gave an award to the Gap Inc. for its "sensitive design" of stores in historic properties, particularly the Old Navy outlet in the Price Building on the Avenue of the Americas and 18th Street, in the Ladies' Mile Historic District.
"Why not recognize and reward that effort?" Ms. Raab asked. "Why not say to the Gap -- the 'big, bad corporation' -- that you're a preservationist?"
Under the preservationist rubric, Ms. Raab also includes neighborhood organizations like the Douglaston-Little Neck Historical Society and Jackson Heights Beautification Committee in Queens.
"There's an emphasis on community group input," said Vicki Match Suna, an architect and one of two commissioners remaining from the Dinkins administration. (The other is the Rev. Thomas F. Pike.)
Ms. Match Suna also noted a "cooperative spirit" on the commission, as did Pablo Vengoechea, an architect and city planner who was appointed vice chairman in February. "Opinions are formed almost by consensus as they go around the table," he said.
THIS is in sharp contrast to the contentiousness in which previous commissions were sometimes embroiled. Some preservationists worry that an emphasis on comity may come at the expense of rigorous give-and-take over esthetic and cultural issues. But those involved in hearings can now depend on the agenda proceeding at a steady clip and ending before dinner time, rather than dragging to midnight or beyond.
"Even her critics would agree that she's made a lot of progress in trying to expedite internal procedures," said Brendan Sexton, president of the Municipal Art Society.
The question in many minds, Mr. Sexton said, is whether Ms. Raab would choose development over preservation when push came to shove. That, critics say, seems to be happening at the Cottages, a modestly detailed but lushly landscaped two-story building on Third Avenue, between 77th and 78th Streets. It was developed by Robert Goelet in 1937 to designs by Edward Faile.
Above the ground-floor stores, which front on the avenue, is a row of eight one-bedroom apartments -- the Cottages -- which face a terraced courtyard and garden, hidden from view behind overhanging sycamore and apple trees. On this site, the developers Trevor Davis and Aby Rosen are planning to build a high-rise condominium.
A coalition called Save the Cottages and Gardens hopes to get the building designated as a landmark and counts among its supporters eight elected officials, the Municipal Art Society, the New York chapter of the American Institute of Architects and some 5,000 to 6,000 neighbors.
However, the Landmarks Commission has already declined four times to consider the Cottages for designation; once in 1988, twice in 1993 and most recently in May, based on its assessment of the property's architectural and historical qualities. That, as far as Ms. Raab is concerned, is that.
"I've made my decision on the Cottages," she said during a four-hour interview in her office on July 11. She noted that many of those who had written in favor of landmark designation spoke of the loss of light and air. "It's very important for people to understand that preservation is not a tool to stop development," Ms. Raab said.
Neighborhood opposition also confronted a plan by the American Museum of Natural History to raze the 62-year-old Hayden Planetarium, designed by Trowbridge & Livingston. It is to be replaced by the Frederick Phineas and Sandra Priest Rose Center for Earth and Space. Permitting the demolition was not easy, Ms. Raab said, but "allowed what everybody considered a new landmark to be built." The new structure, designed by Polshek and Partners, is a glass cube enclosing a 90-foot sphere.
Though the current commission will rarely designate a property in the face of owner opposition, it has nonetheless kept busy under Ms. Raab. "Designations are coming fast and furious," said her immediate predecessor, Laurie Beckelman, now the vice president for external affairs of the World Monuments Fund, based in New York.
Under Ms. Raab, the commission has designated 57 exterior or interior landmarks, 20 of which apply to office towers in lower Manhattan, once considered off limits to the Landmarks Commission.
On Tuesday, the commission began a concerted look at potential Modernist landmarks, placing three buildings on its September agenda: both the exterior and the atrium lobby of the Ford Foundation headquarters, 320 East 42d Street, just now reaching its 30th year, a requisite for landmark status; the CBS Building, known as "Black Rock," 51 West 52d Street and the former Manufacturers Trust Company branch at 510 Fifth Avenue, at 43d Street.
In Ms. Raab's term, the commission has created four historic districts: part of Governors Island, Stone Street in lower Manhattan, Vinegar Hill in Brooklyn, Douglaston in Queens. It is expected to consider a Morningside Heights district and to expand the Mount Morris Park district in Harlem. It may also take a look at the possibility of a NoHo district in Manhattan.
"Areas are getting attention that did not in the past," said Eric William Allison, president of the Historic Districts Council, an advocacy group. "The downside is that in areas where there's opposition -- especially political opposition -- we get nothing."
Councilman Kenneth K. Fisher of Brooklyn, a Democrat who heads the landmarks subcommittee, said it might not be as much a philosophical stretch as it would first appear for a Republican administration to support wide-scale property regulation.
"There's a recognition on the part of the Giuliani administration that historic districts are an important tool for preserving a housing stock that's attractive to the middle class," Mr. Fisher said.
And Ms. Raab readily concedes that she seeks homeowners' cooperation. "Designation doesn't work if there's not local support for what we're doing," she said. "There's a science to preservation but the way it is applied needs to be discussed with the people who are affected by it."
Her interactions with applicants were on view at a public hearing July 1. The first major item was a proposal by the Brighton Heights Reformed Church in St. George, Staten Island, to build a new building on the site of its wooden Gothic Revival landmark, which burned down last year.
The new structure, designed by Diffendale & Kubec, is not a copy. For one thing, it would be built of brick. As Les Neuhalfen, one of the architects, explained, "They've had their experience with wood."
A landmarks commission of another day might have objected to a Fiberglas cornice or the mixture of Gothic and Colonial architectural details. But this commission seemed most impressed by the fact that the church chose to build a steeple again. "What was there before was a very important icon," said Mr. Vengoechea, who lives and works about six blocks away.
In less than 15 minutes, the commission unanimously approved the project. "All of us feel very proud of the church," Ms. Raab told the applicants, "and I'm really touched by the gesture of replicating the steeple."
THERE were no such kind words for the owners of an apartment building on Christopher Street, in the Greenwich Village Historic District. To keep loiterers off the stoop, they installed a gate without permission and were seeking retroactive legalization. Ms. Raab admonished them for their failure to obtain a permit and said the gate could remain only until they presented a more appropriate design.
She was even tougher with representatives of the Kmart Corporation who appeared with a proposal for new signage and shop windows at the underground entrance to the Astor Place Kmart. The entrance, from the west platform of the landmark Astor Place subway station, originally led to Wanamaker's department store.
Ms. Raab said angrily that Kmart had failed to carry out earlier work along the lines specified by the commission, having substituted metal panels for glass panels in the transoms over the doorway. "We were really extremely cooperative in getting you open for Christmas," she said. "Now we expect the same degree of cooperation."
Frank Gabeletto, project representative for Kmart, apologized for what he called a miscommunication. And a lawyer for the corporation, Caroline G. Harris of Stadtmauer Bailkin, assured the commission that the glass panels were being installed.
Later in the day, the commission wrestled with the future of Wildflower, the rambling Tudor-style mansion begun in 1924 for Arthur Hammerstein on the waterfront in Beechhurst, Queens. Long abandoned, it has suffered two devastating fires.
Kiska Developers has proposed to renovate the mansion as part of a 32-unit residential development on the site. Hammerstein's house would be turned into six separate dwellings. The project is designed by Faruk Yorgancioglu of Bridgehampton, L.I.
Mr. Yorgancioglu said he wanted to soften a roadway between the mansion and water by paving it with concrete blocks spaced widely enough for grass to grow between them. The problem, he said, was that the Fire Department insisted on an asphalt strip to bear the weight of fire trucks.
Ms. Raab volunteered to intervene on behalf of the unconventional paving. "I'll take it on myself to make a couple of phone calls," she said. Two weeks later, the Fire Department went along with the plan.
Running interference with other agency heads is a way to encourage owners, Ms. Raab believes. "I've now made it easier for an applicant to do preservation," she said. "I'm your partner."
Of that, she convinced Alan T. Kessler, president and chief executive of Commerical Developments International, a subsidiary of Kajima International. Until May, Kajima owned 55 Wall Street, the former Merchants Exchange and the National City Bank headquarters. Acting as asset manager, Commercial Developments tried to interest CompUSA or Barnes & Noble in the enormous former banking hall.
It was clear that the existing loading dock was inadequate. The owners told the commission they might have to demolish part of the five-foot-thick granite facade along Exchange Place to enlarge the opening.
"Ten years ago, if you went and said something like to them, they would have thrown you out," Mr. Kessler said. "I was shocked -- happily so -- to discover that their concerns at this point had become similar to our concerns, which was how do we get an obsolete building into the mainstream so it becomes economically viable and attracts tenants.
"I think they've become much more attuned to the needs of the business world," Mr. Kessler said, "and the fact that it's nice to own landmark structures but it's nice to make money, too."
Not long ago, the discussion of economics was anathema at the commission. While five-foot-thick granite walls are a rarity, the commission constantly faces applicants who want to know why they cannot replace wood windows with aluminum frames, or slate with asphalt shingles.
"I immediately reversed the policy that we're not allowed to consider cost," Ms. Raab said. "Our standard remains appropriateness. However, we are not precluded from finding a less burdensome approach appropriate. If you give someone the opportunity to present an argument as to why a new material will work as well as the replacement of old material in kind, we can all learn together."
Another change made under Ms. Raab gives the landmarks staff the discretion to approve a close but inexact restoration of certain architectural details when no archival photographic evidence exists, based on buildings of similar style and age. Cases like this would previously have come to the full commission for review.
"Are you losing the opportunity to find the just-right detail?" she said. "Maybe yes. But what you're gaining is that more people will invest in their historic properties because the process is friendlier and easier."
AS part of his development in the TriBeCa West Historic District, the restaurateur David Bouley planned to tear down a 153-year-old, four-story building at 161 Duane Street, whose floors did not align with an adjacent structure, 36 Hudson Street, which he is renovating. Ms. Raab said she would not support demolition but suggested the problem might be solved through an alteration of the facade. The result was a plan to add several courses of brick to No. 161. "Sometimes, in order to get buildings restored, you have to be creative," Ms Raab said.
Appealing as it may sound, this approach raises questions about the commission's rigor. "They are appropriately concerned with being user-friendly," Mr. Wood said. "But at some point, if you're playing a regulatory role, somebody's not going to be happy."
Like Mr. Sexton, Mr. Wood asked: "Does this commission really have a preservation backbone? The jury is still out. This commission has not faced that difficult test yet."
One test mentioned by several preservationists involves the plans for an apartment tower at 250 Water Street, in the South Street Seaport Historic District.
Another potential controversy involves a bill introduced earlier this month by Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver requiring that state and local laws do not "substantially burden the free exercise of religion without compelling justification."
The bill is modeled on the national Religious Freedom Restoration Act, which was used to challenge landmark regulations, among other laws, before it was declared unconstitutional by the United States Supreme Court last month. Mr. Silver said his bill "is not a property-rights measure" but generally involved "personal rights to observe and practice religion."
Nevertheless, based on the way the Federal law was applied, Ms. Raab said she is "concerned about the potential impact it could have on historic preservation."
There is also likely to be a fight over the legislation in the City Council, which includes civil sanctions for the failure to keep a landmark in good repair, which Ms. Raab refers to as "demolition by neglect."
"We're not talking about removing a gargoyle," she said. "We're talking about the Biltmore Theater sitting there without a roof. We're talking about historic properties facing extinction." The abandoned landmark theater at 261 West 47th Street has been allowed by a series of owners to fall victim to vandals and the elements.
If the bill were passed, penalties for cases brought before an administrative tribunal would run up to $5,000 for the first offense and $250 a day for violations that continue after a respondent has been found liable or pled guilty. In the more unusual case brought before civil court, penalties can reach $5,000 a day.
But Ms. Raab emphasized that the goal was to improve compliance, not collect money. "I don't want $500," she said. "I want them to put up the right awning."
About her own future, Ms. Raab said, "I love this job and look forward to continuing in it." She said she would not play a role in Mr. Giuliani's re-election campaign because of time constraints, family commitments and the fact that her husband, Michael Goodwin, is the editorial page editor of The Daily News.
She is certain to stay in the spotlight as long as she is chairwoman of the commission. The panel gets a disproportionate share of press coverage compared to the planning commission and Board of Standards and Appeals, which arguably exercise greater influence over land use.
The commission has existed 35 years but was not given real power until 1965, after the demolition of Pennsylvania Station and the Brokaw Mansion at Fifth Avenue and 79th Street. Geoffrey Platt, an architect, was the first chairman. His nephew, Charles A. Platt, later served on the commission.
In its infancy, the commission picked its fights with care. It did not interfere with plans to raze the 19th-century Metropolitan Opera House at Broadway and 39th Street or the Singer Building on lower Broadway.
"They were terribly, overly conservative in their approach," Charles Platt recalled. "They were so worried about the vessel they were piloting through the channel, that there were so many rocks out there that could wreck it.
"The idea that the landmarks commission has been politicized under Jennifer is nonsense. The commission was politicized before it began."

HEADLINE: COPING;
In a 'Haven,' No Rap, Cola or Long Nails

BYLINE: By ROBERT LIPSYTE 

 BODY:
"I BELIEVE in inoculating my students with both creationism and evolution," Trenton Hamidan, a seventh-grade science teacher, said last week. "Of course, my bias toward creationism comes out. But since both are philosophies that cannot be proved, there is a faith factor at work. Faith in creationism leads us to respect for God and to a frame of reference our children can fall back on when they are out of this haven and must make decisions."
Mr. Hamidan's "haven" is the Hanson Place Seventh-day Adventist School for kindergarten through eighth grade in Fort Greene. It began 33 years ago with 40 pupils in two rooms of the grand Hanson Place Seventh-day Adventist church, once Baptist. As more West Indians immigrated to Brooklyn, the church began buying properties. The school moved two blocks to a former coffin factory on Lafayette Avenue. 
 "This building says middle-class to me," said my friend and guide, Joel Millman, gesturing up at the concrete box. "This says we will build something for ourselves and our kids. Most people write about immigration as melting pot versus mosaic. I see it as a market. Instead of saving up to flee the city, we stay to invest in our own community."
Such investments have revitalized many neighborhoods, as Mr. Millman points out in his important new book, "The Other Americans: How Immigrants Renew Our Country, Our Economy and Our Values" (Viking). His title is his take on the controversial subject. But by digging in and creating communities, groups have also created ethnic and religious islands in the city. At Hanson Place, this is considered an advantage, especially for black Caribbean children whose parents and teachers want them sheltered from a perceived American black culture of "dog eat dog" and of sex, drugs and rap.
"It is easier to live with rules," said Mr. Hamidan, a 44-year-old from Guyana, who said he dropped out of medical school in Mexico for financial reasons.
"Even when the hormones are raging and there is a lack of immediate reinforcement. For example, we teach that violence is not the answer, and we use the Bible. We interpret the word 'meek' by discussing the domesticated lion. This is a symbol of pride, not timidity. This is a lion who chooses not to use his strength. He has the courage to walk away. On these streets, what is the alternative?"
Boys wear blue blazers and ties, girls white blouses and green jumpers. Caps, earrings, long nails and makeup are not allowed. School lunches may not contain pork, shellfish or cola drinks. Junk food and "flesh food" (red meat and chicken) are discouraged. Tuition is $1,425 a year for Hanson Place church members, $1,855 for other Seventh-day Adventists, and $2,170 for those outside the faith. About half the 300 students are not Seventh-day Adventists.
School was out last week, although about 100 children were attending an all-day seven-week summer program that costs $450. The director of the program, Gloria Nelson, who came from Jamaica almost 40 years ago to attend Brooklyn College, paused in my tour to try to talk to a 5-year-old Pakistani boy, who did not speak English. He could seem to communicate -- in a private language -- only with a little Chinese boy and a Trinidadian. Ms. Nelson shrugged expressively, as if a case had been made, even for creationism. Isn't this the answer, she seemed to ask.
"When you go to public school it's a battle," said Edison McPherson, a 36-year-old science teacher from Tobago. "You mix with others who don't share your same beliefs and children want to be like everyone else. But if we have done our job here they will see that the dysfunctions of the society around them are the result of not following God-given principles."
There are 15 Seventh-day Adventist elementary and middle schools in the Northeast. The only high school is the 75-year-old Northeastern Academy in Inwood, which reports that 95 percent of its graduates go on to college. The middle schools also feed three Brooklyn high schools, Midwood and Clara Barton, which have strong health science programs, and East New York Transit Tech, which sends many graduates to the buses and subways.
The West Indian success in New York has a touchy side, which the teachers approached carefully. West Indians often display a certain contempt for "American blacks" and at Hanson Place the word "multiculturalism" often includes the rub between contemporary black immigrants and the descendants of Africans who were kidnapped.
"We remind our students," Mr. Hamidan said, "that we inherited a legacy. We were not part of the civil rights movement. We owe them something for their struggles. In developing our own self-esteem, we must walk that line close to arrogance. We need to understand and be tolerant."
