HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BEDFORD-STUYVESANT;
Right Place, Right Time: Neighborhood Advocate's Victory

BYLINE: By AMY WALDMAN 

 BODY:
The routine is familiar: politicians visit a blighted neighborhood, make speeches deploring poverty and promising change, and then vanish, leaving only dashed hopes.
Occasionally, however, such a visit creates a tangible, lasting legacy, as it did in Bedford-Stuyvesant. In 1966, New York's two Senators, Robert F. Kennedy and Jacob K. Javits, toured the neighborhood, talked to community residents and promised to help. 
 Their visit led to Bedford-Stuyvesant's designation as a Federal Model Cities demonstration project, which in turn brought new housing, businesses and community resources to the area. Their visit also led to the creation of the Bedford-Stuyvesant Restoration Corporation, the nation's first community development corporation, which marks its 30th anniversary this year.
But were it not for the willingness of Elsie Richardson, a community advocate, to open her mouth, the Senators' visit might have led simply to one more study of Bedford-Stuyvesant's problems. A study was exactly what Senator Kennedy proposed when he met with community leaders at the Bedford Avenue Y.M.C.A. at the end of his visit. Mrs. Richardson, chairwoman of the Urban Planning Committee of the Central Brooklyn Coordinating Council, who had accompanied the Senators on their rounds, rejected that proposal. "I said: 'No, no. No more surveys. We've been surveyed to death,' " she said in an interview last week.
Senator Kennedy agreed, and he soon had people at work, acting on plans that Ronald Shiffman of Pratt Institute and others had drawn up to revitalize the area.
But Mrs. Richardson has never just urged others to action. An entire wall of the house on Prospect Plaza where she has lived for 42 years is covered with plaques and certificates thanking her for community service, whether helping to bring the first black-owned McDonald's to the area or raising money for Medgar Evers College. "A lot of work, a lot of work," she said of the commendations.
Now 75, she is acting chairwoman of the Coordinating Council and secretary of her block association. Her phone rings constantly.
She said she was pleased by the improvements in Bedford-Stuyvesant, proudly pointing out housing projects and community centers.
But Mrs. Richardson also sees too many young people being sent to prison, too many babies bringing babies into the world, as she describes it, too many aimless youths without jobs on street corners. She worries about big stores squeezing out mom-and-pop shops, and a city that pours money into Times Square while stinting on social services for poor areas.
She is most disappointed, she said, by the absence of strong and vocal political leadership in her community. She recalled that when Senator Kennedy was alive, "There was such a fervor. Lots of people were going into politics, getting into office.
"Now people get into positions and feel so satisfied," she said, "that they move away from the man on the street." AMY WALDMAN

GRAPHIC: Photos: In the 70's, rebuilding started on the Fulton Street block (Bedford-Stuyvesant Restoration Corporation); that became Restoration Plaza, including an interior courtyard. (Rebecca Cooney for The New York Times)
 
Chart: "URBANOLOGY: A Hardy Chyild of the 60's"
The Bedford-Stuyvesant Restoration Corporation was born from the belief that government could revitalize inner cities. With Federal aid, the corporation built and restored houseing, made loans, developed community programs, promoted culture and otherwise wove itself deep into the community fabric. The corporation turned the block of Fulton Street between New York and Brooklyn Avenues into a linchpin of local economic and cultural life, with the Restoration Plaza mall and the billie Holiday Theater. A few of the other commercial and housing complexes it has developed are below.
 
The corporation is turning its effots to providing loans and equity to small businesses, which can provide both jobs and badly needed services. "We are not looking at trying to create Silicon Valley," said Roderick Mithell, the corporation's president. "We just want people to invest in homes and businesses here."
 
Map of Brooklyn showing the location of Bedford-Stuyvesant.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BEDFORD-STUYVESANT;
Strip Mall Is Next Step for an Area of Weeds and Thieves

BYLINE: By AMY WALDMAN 

 BODY:
Weeds grow by the bushel on the lot at the southeast corner of Fulton Street and Ralph Avenue, but for local consumers, there are slim pickings. Throughout the neighborhood, empty buildings adjoin empty lots; stores, in contrast, are sparse.
That may soon change. In September, developers are scheduled to break ground on the lot for Partnership Plaza, a 19,000-square-foot retail complex that is to include a Rite Aid drugstore and State Farm insurance office, as well as local businesses. Alan Bell, a partner in the Hudson Companies, the plaza's developer, said the strip mall will employ more than 100 local residents when it is finished in about a year. 
 The plaza is part of the Giuliani administration's attempt to revive once-healthy business corridors, many of which have been moribund since the blackout 20 years ago. The eastern portion of Fulton Street has already benefited from the Saratoga Square project, a public-private urban renewal effort to enable about 1,250 families to buy homes in a 28-acre area bounded by Atlantic Avenue and Bainbridge Street and Ralph and Rockaway Avenues.
Providing shops is the next step. The city, state and Federal governments are providing approximately 30 percent of the $3.3 million for Partnership Plaza in the form of loans, grants, land and tax abatements. The New York City Investment Fund, which was set up by local business executives to aid distressed areas, is providing $290,000 in equity.
"Retail is now hot for New York City," said Richard Roberts, Commissioner of the City Department of Housing Preservation and Development. "We'd like these neighborhoods to be part of that phenomenon."
Waiting for a bus at the corner of Fulton and Ralph, Veronica Clark, 36, who owns a local shipping company, said she has to travel to the western end of Fulton or to downtown Brooklyn for "just about everything." She and other residents said the most pressing need was for a supermarket -- the nearest one closed after a fire several months ago. By then the city was too far into negotiations with other prospective tenants to change plans. But Kathryn Wylde, president of the Investment Fund, said officials hoped to attract a supermarket to the corner of Fulton Street and Saratoga Avenue.
Still, residents were hopeful that the new development would bring not just goods and services, but greater safety too. Louis S. Scarborough, 69, who has lived in eastern Bedford-Stuyvesant for 33 years, said thieves had been so emboldened by the general desolation that they had even stolen his phone cables. "I've seen the neighborhood die," Mr. Scarborough said. "I hope to see it revive." AMY WALDMAN

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS;
Despite Consolidations, There's Room for Many Funds

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
BIG institutions with big money are doing a lot of talking about getting into the mutual fund business. Among the recent spate of splashy, headline-grabbing deals was last month's agreement by the Zurich Group, Switzerland's biggest insurance company, to purchase Scudder, Stevens & Clark, the old-line fund management company. Other deals are also in the works, as big banks like J. P. Morgan negotiate to buy stakes in fund companies like American Century Investments of Kansas City, Mo.
Nevertheless, the pace of consolidation in the mutual fund business is about the same as it was last year, industry analysts say. And despite the stock market's sharp rise in the last 12 months, the prices being paid for firms are only marginally higher than in 1996. 
 So while economies of scale suggest that big companies operating in a wide variety of markets will dominate the fund business, widely publicized predictions that small firms will wither have not yet been borne out.
In fact, it appears that there is room in the fund industry for several different kinds of companies, according to Putnam, Lovell & Thornton, an investment bank that specializes in the asset management business. "A multi-tiered industry organization is evolving," the firm's analysts wrote recently in a research report, "in which asset flows and growth dynamics sustain organizations with wholly different strategies."
And that may be good news for fund investors who value the innovative management and hot performance associated with small companies over the marketing muscle and shareholder services big companies can provide.
In the first six months of this year, 23 money management firms that together managed more than $316 billion were bought, mostly by large financial institutions. Excluding Scudder -- which alone manages about $120 billion and is being acquired in a deal valued at $1.67 billion -- this year's activity is very similar to last year's, when 22 deals involving just over $200 billion in assets were announced in the first six months.
"The upward trend has not been very dramatic," said Neal M. Epstein, Putnam Lovell's director of research. "Rather, it is high and constant."
There is no single motive for the deals this year, analysts said. Some buyers are looking for new ways to sell their funds; some "are making a strategic acquisition or seeking to expand their basic product mix," said Geoff H. Bobroff, a mutual fund industry consultant based in East Greenwich, R.I.
"A lot of sellers have reached the age where they are looking for liquidity," he added, referring to the founders of companies who are interested in retiring or are planning their estates.
In general, fund companies are no more valuable this year than last year, based on the prices they are fetching, with one exception. "Prices have escalated for recognizable properties," said A. Michael Lipper, president of Lipper Analytical Services and a longtime analyst of the fund industry.
Consider the deal announced last Tuesday, when the John Nuveen Company said it had agreed to buy Rittenhouse Financial Services for $145 million in cash -- about three times as much as Rittenhouse was offered just two years ago by Corestates Financial, in a deal that ultimately fell through.
Of course, the amount of assets Rittenhouse manages has more than doubled in that time, to $9 billion from about $4 billion, noted Burton Greenwald, who runs a consulting firm in Philadelphia.
Analysts were reluctant to predict which firms might be the next takeover candidates. But Mr. Bobroff said rumors continued to swirl around Neuberger & Berman Management of New York and Columbia Funds Management of Portland, Ore., two private firms.
EVEN though the fund industry has been in something of a consolidation phase for five or six years, the 30 largest firms in the business have only a smidgen more of the overall market than they did in 1991: 72.1 percent at the end of March, versus 71.8 percent at the end of 1991, Mr. Bobroff said. A number of fund managers, meanwhile, "came out of nowhere" and grabbed important shares of the fund market, according to Putnam Lovell. The investment bank identified 10 firms that, from 1991 to 1996, saw assets under management grow at a compound annual rate of more than 40 percent and now manage at least $5 billion apiece. They include Warburg, Pincus; Janus Capital, and Pilgrim Baxter, all of which prospered through strong fund performance.
"Even as firms merge, there are lots of managers and investment professionals going off on their own and forming new firms, which blurs the consolidation trend," said Kathryn Steele, a research analyst at Investment Counseling Inc., a consultant in West Conshohocken, Pa. In 1989, 450 firms had more than $1 billion in assets under management, Ms. Steele said; by last year, that number had more than doubled, to 960.
Much of that growth must be attributed to the bull market, which has experienced few missteps in the last decade and which has helped increase the assets of even less-than-stellar fund companies. Some of those firms may be wiped out in a prolonged market downturn, analysts note, leaving the biggest and strongest as survivors.
Even if the stock market tumbles, big American and European institutions will remain interested in buying fund managers.
"There is no question you will see new deals, and I don't think demand will change if the Dow Jones is at 8,000 or at 6,000," said Mr. Epstein of Putnam, Lovell. "People see market opportunities developing and competitors getting into position, and are faced with the choice of either building the business or buying it before they have lost the race."

HEADLINE: NOTICED;
Are These Seats in a Club or on the Exchange?

BYLINE: By DAVIDSON GOLDIN 

DATELINE: SOUTHAMPTON, N.Y.

 BODY:
MOST Saturday nights, Matt Handler and seven friends from his summer house reserve a table adjoining the buzzing dance floor at Jet East, the newest place to see and be seen in the Hamptons.
Mr. Handler, who is 27 and a natural-gas broker, thinks it's a nifty idea. "You go on the dance floor, come back and the alcohol is still sitting there waiting for you," he said. But here in the region's toniest resort area, that table has a price: with tax and tip, Mr. Handler's party coughs up $1,000 on their Saturday night jaunts. 
 With a booming Wall Street just 100 miles away, many young clubgoers don't seem to blink at the latest extreme in a place known for extremes.
This summer, popular nightclubs in Southampton, the heart of East End night life, have added lounge areas -- complete with banquettes and tables and seats in the form of king-size beds -- to spaces otherwise stingy with places to rest your pups. But the tables come with a pricey minimum charge, which covers equally pricey libations sold only by the bottle.
Charges vary, depending on the night and the number of people in a party. For example, at Jet East, which opened this season, two people would pay a $300 minimum; a table for eight carries an $800 minimum.
The Tavern, another popular late-night spot in Southampton that introduced a lounge area this year, charges $500 for a table for two or more, and M80 wants $200 for the first four people (add $200 for the next one to four).
"Truly, I never thought it would get like this out here," said Terrence Cassidy, 52, the chairman of National Wireless, a communications company, who was a guest of friends in the Tavern's privileged perch. He shook his head, scanning the 20- and 30-something crowd.
Club owners are well aware that they have the economy to thank for what has turned into a booming business of their own.
"People are making more money and feeling better than the last couple of years, and they're going out and spending more money," said Gordon Von Brock, an owner of the Tavern.
"As opposed to a traditional cocktail-waitress bar, we make it feel like your own living room," he added.
And the club owners say it was just a matter a time before bottle-only service made its way from Manhattan to the beach.
The concept of serving full bottles of liquor instead of individual cocktails originated some 20 years ago in St.-Tropez and quickly spread to other European resorts, including Cannes and Ibiza. City and beach club owners say that the idea was popularized in New York City with the opening of the midtown club Au Bar in 1987 and spread to the South Beach section of Miami Beach. Then last fall, several new Manhattan clubs, including Jet Lounge, Chaos and Cheetah, began offering bottle service at tables.
But unlike the beach, most Manhattan clubs don't have minimum charges based on the number of people at a table; instead, they require each table to order at least one bottle, whether for 2 or 12.
With bottles at the Southampton clubs costing from about $200 for a basic vodka or gin to $600 for a high-end Scotch or Cognac, it is not hard to reach minimum charges. On a recent Saturday night at Jet East, the popular combination seemed to be a $250 bottle of Ketel One vodka, which retails for $20, mixed with orange juice or cranberry juice. Mixers are complimentary.
For those not willing or able to buy a seat, the typical $20 cover charge provides access to the dance floor and standing room only at the bar. But there's a catch: clubgoers without table reservations -- or their names on a "guest list," showing they are known to the owners or promoters -- usually spend much of the night waiting outside on line.
"It's hard as hell to get into this place, so the minimums are definitely worth it," said Brian Abramson, 33, a Manhattan equity trader, who paid $125 on a Saturday night for his share of a table at Jet East. "Just look at all the girls."
But not everyone is comfortable with what it all represents.
"It's a little bizarre and excessive," said Shreve Hicks, 28, a Columbia Records employee on her first visit to Jet East. She could not imagine paying the table minimum.
"This is very Roman," she said.

High Cost Of Fun
 
Want to take a load off? Here are minimum table charges at some popular nightspots; prices can vary depending on the night.
 
AU BAR -- (41 East 58th Street, Manhattan): $60 a person.
 
CHAOS -- (23 Watts Street, Manhattan): no minimum, but the table must order one bottle ($175 and up).
 
CHEETAH -- (12 West 21st Street, Manhattan): $200 a table.
 
JET EAST -- (1181 North Sea Road, Southampton, N.Y.): $300 for a table that can accommodate up to four people, $800 for a table for eight.
 
JET LOUNGE -- (286 Spring Street, Manhattan): No minimum, but each table must order either a bottle of wine ($60 and up) or alcohol ($200 and up).
 
LIQUID -- (opening in September in Chelsea): $200 for up to five people.
 
M80 -- (1976 North Sea Road, Southampton): $200 for first four people, $200 extra for one to four more people.
 
TAVERN -- (125 Tuckahoe Lane, Southampton): $500 a table, accommodating up to eight people.

HEADLINE: OFF THE RACK;
Sounding an Alarm From the Newsstand

BYLINE: By FRED BROCK 

 BODY:
THE dog days of summer should be a time for hammock-swinging and lemonade-sipping, but the gyrations of the stock market haven't exactly been cooperating in this idyll. And the August issues of personal-finance magazines aren't helping, either.
The theme of the month is that stocks are overvalued, risks are rising and now may be the time to take some profits and run because the market is headed for a correction in coming months. Money magazine cuts to the chase: "Sell Stock Now!" screams its cover headline in giant red letters -- advice we've heard from various quarters almost every time the Dow has hit a new high in the last year or so. And Fortune, on its July 21 cover, asks, "Time to Cash In Your Blue Chips?" 
 Of course, plenty of analysts say that history is no guide to this bull market and that the Dow Jones industrial average may climb to 10,000 and beyond. Maybe all this conflicting expertise helped drive Jonathan Steinberg's Individual Investor magazine to run a column on Crawford Perspectives, a monthly newsletter by Arch Crawford that uses astrology to predict the market. Mr. Crawford sees a 35 percent to 50 percent drop in the next 30 months.
And Smart Money could be onto something -- relief, maybe? -- in its so-called Real Life Index. Among other things, the index tracks the price of a month's supply of Prozac around the country, from $64.53 in Tucson, Ariz., to $74.69 in Philadelphia.
 
WHAT TO DO? Money's Michael Sivy says the long-term outlook for stocks remains good, but he contends that share prices have risen too fast since 1994. A result, he argues, is that today's stocks are overpriced by 15 to 20 percent. He recommends trimming stock holdings by 20 percent, to about 60 percent of a portfolio.
Mr. Sivy, who cites one investment strategist's prediction that the Dow will dip to 6,200 in a sharp correction lasting six months or so, also offers this advice:
* Don't expect blue-chip shares to hold up in a market slump.
* Consider selling growth stocks with price-earnings ratios above 22.
* Add to bond holdings if yields on long-term Treasury bonds bounce back above 7 percent.
* Bolster cash reserves to as much as 25 percent of your portfolio.
In his column, Frank Lalli, Money's managing editor, reminds readers that in 1994, his magazine urged readers to buy stock when the Dow stood near 3,700, and that those who followed the advice have fared well. Sell some stocks now, he advises, and have cash to invest when the market becomes the bargain it was three years ago.
"Whatever you do, don't just sit there," he says.
Mr. Sivy, in his separate monthly forecast, says that if you are buying stocks, he recommends shares of natural-resource companies because of rising population, economic growth and a long-term likelihood of revived inflation. His picks: Newmont Mining, Georgia-Pacific, Alcoa, Phelps Dodge and Exxon.
Fortune takes a tack similar to Money's and cites specific companies whose share prices it sees as overvalued for various reasons: Coca-Cola, Procter & Gamble, Philip Morris, Merck and Motorola.
 
SHORT-TERM PLAN Smart Money's cover article, by Ken Brown, a senior editor, examines ways to invest money you know you will need within three to five years. Buying individual stocks for such a short time is unwise, he argues, pointing to 1990, when the Dow plunged 21.2 percent in just 12 weeks.
If you are very safety-minded, Mr. Brown recommends sticking with tried-and-true certificates of deposit and zero-coupon Treasury bonds. If your risk tolerance is higher, he likes loan-participation funds, which invest in bank loans to companies with less-than-perfect credit; these funds have been yielding 6.8 percent to 8.5 percent. They pay bond-like yields, but their returns increase when rates rise. But first, you might want to research this option a bit. The writer points out that cashing out can be tricky because the bank loans the funds hold are illiquid, most funds charge an early exit fee and investors can usually sell only once a quarter. The article recommends two such funds: Van Kampen American Capital Prime Rate Income Trust and Eaton Vance Classic Senior Floating-Rate.
For those with even higher risk tolerances, stock and bond funds are next. Four are recommended: The Janus Fund, which has never lost money over any 36-month period in its history; T. Rowe Price Capital Appreciation; AARP Growth and Income, and Invesco Industrial Income.
 
GOODBYE, PRIVACY Kiplinger's and Money have articles on threats to privacy posed by electronic data bases and other widely available sources of information. Kiplinger's concentrates on the danger that your Social Security number could fall into the wrong hands. Money looks at specific practices -- including workplace snooping and improper use of medical information -- that can prove especially harmful. The bottom line is that many people have less privacy than they think.
 
HOME ALONE Smart Money offers a good explanation of the circumstances under which you can deduct the costs of a home office. It also points out that the latest Republican tax plan would allow deductions for home offices that are used for essential business functions when no other suitable space is available. This is an effort to deal with a 1993 Supreme Court decision that a home office must pass a tough "principal place of business" test.
 
COMING BACK? Kiplinger's takes a look at the efforts of Fidelity Investments to regain its performance edge in the mutual fund industry. Mutual Funds magazine examines the competition between Fidelity and its main rival, the Vanguard Group.
 
BITS AND PIECES Worth, which had a combined July-August issue, has a special issue for August on investing in technology; it will go only to subscribers. . . . Smart Money rates 10 market gurus, with Abby Joseph Cohen of Goldman, Sachs winning the top spot.. . . . Kiplinger's reports that if you earn $50,000 a year in Chicago and want to duplicate your life style in New York, you'll need $96,382; in St. Louis you will need only $37,263.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 15; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 1784 words

HEADLINE: The Beltway Talks Back;
Wake Up, America: Apathy Can Be Dangerous

 BODY:
Unless the heat has warped our memory, it was only a couple of years ago that Americans were so mad at Washington there could have been a new Congressional election every month. Today, the cry of "throw the bums out" is seldom heard, and the people storming the ramparts of the Capitol are mostly the usual suspects looking to cut the usual deals.
John Huang had ties to a company with ties to the Chinese Government while raising millions of dollars for the Democrats? The loyalists whom Newt Gingrich had taken to his bosom tried to ace him out? What does any of this have to do with the price of a double-decaf iced mocha latte? 
 The reason for this complacency, according to the polls, is that most Americans believe the country as a whole and they themselves are better off than at any time since who knows when. But boredom with government is a threat to the people's long-term interests, including people who make a living saying things like "boredom with government is a threat to the people's long-term interests" -- the experts, pundits, gurus and others known collectively as the Beltway insiders.
A few leading commentators and others were asked to explain once again just why all good citizens must get serious. Here are their responses:
 
Ralph Nader is the author of "No Contest: Corporate Lawyers and the Perversion of Justice in America."
Strange, isn't it, that thousands of corporate lobbyists are actually excited about what is going on in Washington. For they are pushing legislation to limit or eliminate their liability for their corporate crime, fraud and abuse against citizens and investors whom they injure. These corporate interests use Orwellian language to call their bills "tort reform," "securities reform," "regulatory reform" and "banking reform."
Should these measures pass, you will pay more and have less recourse to justice, and health and safety standards will be weaker and less vigorously enforced.
On another front, more of your tax dollars will go to huge corporate welfare programs and giveaways ($70 billion worth of public airwaves to existing TV broadcasters, for instance) if people do not back the politicians -- both liberals and conservatives -- who are fighting in Congress to end these boondoggles.
Stay bored and government becomes more of an instrument of the rich and powerful against the rest of America. Get active with your fellow citizens and you might just see more government of, by and for the people.

Norman J. Ornstein is resident scholar at the American Enterprise Institute.
Peace and prosperity: great developments for the country, but tough going for politicians and pundits. Good times mean complacency among voters; combine that feeling with the underlying cynicism about politics, and it is no wonder that, outside the Beltway, events in Washington are even less compelling than they were in the halcyon days of cold war tension and economic turmoil.
The benign neglect of Washington has been fed by a sense that President Clinton, Speaker Newt Gingrich and the Senate majority leader, Trent Lott, have found ways to cut deals to make modest changes that steer the nation in the right direction.
Their ability to keep the process on track has been admirable, but it is plenty tenuous. The very lack of outside threat or internal crisis leaves a vacuum that has been filled by often vicious partisan bickering and ideological warfare that could, if unchecked, poison the atmosphere enough to make further compromise and action impossible.
"So what?" you ask. Times will not always be good. If we continue to make small but tangible progress in areas from Medicare reform to expanding free trade to campaign finance reform, we can prevent pain and dislocation down the road when we can least afford it.
 
David Gergen is editor at large of U.S. News & World Report.
People are so bored with Washington, says my friend Mark Shields, that they are turning off C-SPAN in favor of the Weather Channel. True enough, but there's much about our long-term future that needs attention.
Beyond the obvious lack of nerve in reforming Social Security and cleaning up campaign finance, we seem unable to figure out what can be done to rebuild American families. The past 40 years have witnessed the largest collapse of family life in recorded history -- and it won't be repaired with V-chips and $500 tax credits.
Meanwhile, much of Washington is also strangely silent on the disasters unfolding in public universities in California and Texas -- and soon to appear elsewhere -- as affirmative action is thrown out. Racial preferences are no longer sustainable politically, but a return to segregation would be even worse. Clearly, we need to pursue much stronger efforts at remediation in secondary school.
On a wholly different front, we are shortchanging one of our most vital long-term investments: basic scientific research. Federal spending has dropped four years in a row and is still heading down. To allow a continued deterioration would compromise prospects for our security, economy and quality of life.
 
Marian Wright Edelman is president of the Children's Defense Fund.
Congress and President Clinton have a historic opportunity to address a shameful and solvable problem shared by 10 million uninsured children, most of whom live with working parents. The House-Senate conference committee will soon decide whether to adopt a Senate plan to insure at least six million children with good benefits.
The Senate plan is partly financed by a 20-cent tobacco tax that would curb teen-age smoking and save hundreds of thousands of lives. The inferior House plan leaves the door open for special interests to raid the child health fund and gives no assurance that a single child will actually receive coverage.
Every American must speak out for our children's health so that special interests like Big Tobacco are not the only voices our lawmakers hear.
 
Lynne Cheney is former chairwoman of the National Endowment for the Humanities.
One reason that people outside the Beltway should care about what's going on there is that Washington can render state efforts moot. Consider "whole math" instruction, which has been making its way into schools for several years. The idea is that mathematics is a natural activity that students will invent procedures for if only they are given mathematically rich problems to solve.
Parents concerned that this idea will prove destructive are working to be sure that states require instruction in basic skills. They've made headway, but the Administration could reverse it. The national math test for eighth graders being planned for 1999 could easily overwhelm state efforts, and it is being shaped entirely by advocates of the "whole math" approach.
 
Arianna Huffington is chairwoman of the Center for Effective Compassion.
A very important piece of legislation -- the charitable tax credit -- is getting scant attention in Washington. The proposal would allow families to give up to $1,000 of what they owe in taxes to a poverty-fighting charity of their choice. Not only would it provide billions of dollars for effective grass-roots groups but it would also strengthen the frail bonds of community.
In the course of deciding what group to support, citizens would have the opportunity to become more involved in the lives of those in need. And the charitable tax credit would establish a hierarchy of charitable priorities at a time when both political parties have tragically neglected the crisis of poverty and violence in our inner cities.
 
Kevin Phillips is editor and publisher of American Political Report and author, most recently, of "Arrogant Capital."
For voters to ignore Washington's corruption hearings because Congress won't pass meaningful reform anyway is sagacity, not apathy.
Besides, Washington is never the nation's prime focus near the peak of a financial boom and stock market bubble -- not in the early 1890's, not in the late 1920's and not now. That's true even though money's corruption of politics often tops out close to other peaks of the money culture -- the record-setting Dow and the economists' announcement of the end of the business cycle. When (and if) the bubble pops, voters will get involved with a vengeance.
 
Michael Mandelbaum is the author of "NATO Expansion: A Bridge to the Nineteenth Century."
As Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic received invitations to enter NATO, and American officials assured Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania that they, too, could join, one feature of NATO expansion received less attention than it deserves: the price tag for Americans.
Upgrading the military establishments of the new members and sending Western troops to the territories of the three Baltic countries to protect them from their huge neighbor, Russia, could cost hundreds of billions of dollars. The new members cannot pay; the Western Europeans will not pay.
So Americans would foot the bill, requiring higher taxes, less social spending, abandoning a balanced budget, or all three. All Americans should care about that.
 
Zbigniew Brzezinski was national security adviser to President Jimmy Carter.
Three issues deserve public attention; each, if mismanaged, could affect every American's pocketbook and even cost American lives.
The first involves Europe. By widening NATO, we can reduce the chances of new intra-European conflicts. Otherwise, Americans could soon find themselves again engaged in European bloodshed.
The Middle East cries for more engagement by the United States in the stalemated Israeli-Palestinian peace process. Renewed conflict could quickly ignite a major energy crisis.
Last but not least, a more powerful China is emerging, while America's relationship with that awakening giant is in a state of drift. By portraying China already as our enemy, some commentators are engaging in a self-fulfulling prophesy.
In brief, ignorance is not bliss.
 
Vinnie Rosario is a bartender at The Capital Grille.
As the economy has heated up, Washington has seen a revival of 80's indulgence with a 50's retro twist, demonstrated by the unusual number of martinis, cigars and steaks being ordered at The Capital Grille when Congress is in session.
And over the hustle and bustle of bar interaction, the old jokes can be heard, like, "How many politicians does it take to screw in a light bulb?" The most timely response these days, though, is, "They'd immediately form a committee to determine the most effective way to meet the challenges of this great task."
What does all this mean for the rest of America? Hey, a bartender never reveals his secrets.

GRAPHIC: Drawing (J.D. King)

SECTION: Section 4; Page 14; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 680 words

HEADLINE: Editorial Notebook;
The World Resurrects Che

BYLINE: By TINA ROSENBERG 

 BODY:
Thirty years after his assassination in the Bolivian mountains, Ernesto (Che) Guevara has captured the public fancy in ways he never intended. At least three biographies and several movies about Che will come out this year. The silk-screen Che icon with beard and beret now hawks compact discs, beer, Swatch watches, skis, designer dresses and a host of other products not traditionally associated with international Communism. Scientists have now found his body, one of seven skeletons in a pit in Bolivia, and brought it to Cuba.
What would a Che alive today make of all this? He might not approve of the more crass commercialization of his name and image, but if the ideological migrations of his comrades are any indication, he would be firmly in the capitalist camp. Unlike his body, Che's politics remain entombed. Armed, leftist revolution is today found only in Cuba, and in a few violent but tiny bands in Colombia, Peru and now Mexico. 
 In Europe and the United States, Che's image owes its commercial appeal to the absence of political content. Yuppies who would never have worn a Che T-shirt when it could have been taken seriously now find Commie-kitsch hip and ironic. In Latin America, many still admire what they see as Che's idealism. While he was capable of great brutality, to them he was also uncorrupted by power, happier suffering in his disastrous attempts to foment revolution in the jungles of the Congo or Bolivia than as a bureaucrat in Havana.
But his politics are long gone. The old leftist revolutionaries are now closer to European-style capitalism than anything Che ever preached. Chileans reacted with amusement a few years ago when Carlos Ominami, Economy Minister of the democratic Government that came to power in 1990, proudly announced a record year of foreign investment. Foreign capital was Mr. Ominami's enemy when he was a guerrilla of the Leftist Revolutionary Movement two decades earlier. Chile's revolutionaries are now largely social democrats, as are the vast majority of Latin America's former guerrillas.
In Colombia, Venezuela, Guatemala and El Salvador, to name a few countries, guerrillas have come down from the mountains to found reformist political parties, some of which are now indistinguishable from the competition. The Sandinistas in Nicaragua ran in last year's elections on a free-market platform. In Argentina and Uruguay, survivors of guerrilla groups decimated by death squads now support social democratic political movements. All these groups advocate a version of what Jorge Casteneda, a Mexican political scientist, calls "Rhineland capitalism" -- the welfare state, strong unions and high tax burden of Germany today.
The guerrillas have been transformed by time. Middle-class kids are revolutionaries at 20. Middle-class men of 50 are anything but. There is no new generation to succeed them because Latin America, too, has changed. The military dictatorships most of the guerrillas battled gave way to nominal democracy in the 1980's. Even before the Soviet Union collapsed, depriving the armed left of weapons, cash and ideological backing, revolution had proved unsustainable except through the intense repression of Cuba, a model that gave many leftists pause. Since the 1960's, both left and right in Latin America have converged on the goal of what revolutionaries once scornfully derided as bourgeois democracy.
That goal is not yet within sight. While the left's solutions to Latin American poverty and injustice have changed, by many measures the problems are worse today than when Che died. Although the poor form a smaller percentage of the population of Latin America than they did, there are 50 million more Latins living in poverty now than in 1965. The Mexican minimum wage, earned by 17 million people, buys a quarter of what it bought 20 years ago. All that Western Europeans enjoy -- like a living wage, the rule of law, access to justice, schools and hospitals -- seems as fantastical to most Latins as any revolution Che Guevara ever dreamed up. TINA ROSENBERG

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

SECTION: Section 8; Page 6; Column 1; Sports Desk 

LENGTH: 1436 words

HEADLINE: BASEBALL: NOTEBOOK;
The Angels Are Proving to Be More Than the Sum of Their Stats

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
If anyone had suggested before the season began the possibility of a Freeway Series, the West Coast version of a Subway Series, most people would probably have wondered along which freeway the Los Angeles Dodgers would find an American League opponent.
Try I-5. 
 The Anaheim Angels live there, and they are threatening to reside in first place in the American League West, too. A 10-game winning streak, the league's longest this season, took them from six and a half games behind Seattle to half a game back entering the weekend. But don't insult Bill Bavasi, the general manager, by calling the Angels a "surprise."
"We get written up as a surprise, and I don't feel it's that surprising," Bavasi said. "It's a team we put together prior to spring training that we felt pretty good about. There are some good players in our clubhouse. We are where we are, and we don't have one guy having a career year."
Indeed, the Angels don't stand out in any phase of the game. They are fourth in hitting, seventh in pitching and eighth in fielding, and have barely any players among the leaders in hitting and pitching categories.
They do not frighten opposing pitchers with the threat of long balls (they are 10th in homers and slugging percentage), but they do give up a lot of long balls (their pitchers are third in most home runs allowed).
Mark McGwire and Tino Martinez each have more than twice as many home runs as the Angels' leading sluggers (Jim Edmonds and Tim Salmon with 16 each). Two of their starting pitchers have earned run averages above 5.00, and their leader in victories and e.r.a. is a rookie (Jason Dickson, 10-4, 3.26).
What do the Angels have? They have a team that can sustain long winning streaks (they won seven straight in May and six straight last month before this month), and long winning streaks have a way of catapulting teams into division races. "We're chasing the Mariners, so we have to take care of ourselves," Bavasi said. "We have to play as well as we can and put them in a position where they have to play their best."
The Angels do not have the glamour players the Mariners have -- Ken Griffey Jr., Alex Rodriguez and Randy Johnson. But Edmonds, their center fielder, has made himself almost a household name with his spectacular catches, and players such as Salmon, Garret Anderson, Jim Leyritz, Darin Erstad and Dave Hollins have played steadily and productively.
Eddie Murray, on the disabled list for more than five weeks with a wrist ailment, has not been missed, but that is because of Tony Phillips, the unpredictable but productive leadoff hitter and player of many positions. Phillips, who played for the Angels in 1995, returned in a May 18 trade with the Chicago White Sox and has done his usual good job of getting on base and hitting with some power.
The Angels also have overcome losses more critical than Murray's:
Troy Percival, the closer, missed six weeks early in the season with a shoulder problem; Mark Langston, their top starting pitcher, had elbow surgery in May; Mark Gubicza, another starter, has been on the disabled list since April 12 with a troublesome shoulder, and Randy Velarde, the second baseman, has been out all season following elbow surgery.
The most intriguing aspect of the Angels' current strategy is the decision of Manager Terry Collins to go with a four-man pitching rotation. Dickson; Allen Watson, the New York native; Chuck Finley, at 34 years old the senior member, and Dennis Springer, the knuckleballer, are in their third round of working as a four-man corps.
"We don't plan on going with it forever," Bavasi said. "We'll go with it as long as they feel good. We felt better with the bullpen we had than a fifth starter. We just felt we could go with four guys and figured it would make them more consistent."
Entering the weekend, the pitchers each had made one start with three days' rest, and the Angels had won all the games. When the Angels make up two rainouts with doubleheaders on a road trip that begins in New York on Tuesday night, Collins will insert Kevin Gross in one of the extra games and Matt Perisho in the other.
 
Parting With McGwire
 As the July 31 deadline for trading players without waivers approaches, the Oakland Athletics are faced with a dilemma unique even for these agonizing economic times. Going nowhere, they would like to trade Mark McGwire rather than lose him as a free agent after the season and get nothing for him. But how can they trade him, then watch him attack the home run record in another uniform?
"No club has talked to us, so no trade is imminent," said Bob Cohen, the agent for McGwire, who must approve any trade. "You hear all the rumblings, but you don't know how much is fact."
He said he has spoken to Sandy Alderson, the Athletics' president, and understands the team's dilemma. "Sandy hasn't said it directly," Cohen said, "but I sense they realize they have to trade him because he will be a free agent. But Sandy himself has said on numerous occasions it's a very difficult decision. He's almost in the ironic position that he wants to trade him but doesn't want him to do too well."
Widespread speculation has had the Angels as the leading contender to get McGwire, perhaps for Jim Edmonds, but the Angels don't look as if they are going to make a deal. The St. Louis Cardinals are another team often mentioned.
But Cohen said: "Mark wants to play for a contender in southern California. That's his first choice. And his second choice and his third choice. But does everybody get their first choice in life?"
The Athletics will not give him the kind of contract he can get as a free agent. But assuming they would pay him the going rate, Cohen said, raising the question himself, would McGwire re-sign with them?
"It's not a closed issue," the lawyer said. "But it does not appear likely."
 
Nieves Vvs. Gwynn
 Tony Gwynn, it is no secret, is the best hitter in baseball. But Gwynn, who is flirting with .400 this season, is hitting well below Melvin Nieves when they each hits the ball.
Nieves, a young outfielder with the Detroit Tigers, has struck out 113 times, the most in the majors and 100 more times than Gwynn. San Diego's perennial batting champion has been the toughest to strike out, only once every 28 at-bats (Nieves is striking out once every 2.35 at-bats).
But when they make contact, Gwynn is hitting .412, Nieves .454. Over all, Gwynn is hitting .395, Nieves .260.
 
Williams Cheers the Giants
 In his last seven seasons with the San Francisco Giants, Matt Williams suffered through five years with losing records and a season in which the team won 103 games but missed the playoffs. Now in his first season away, the Giants have been in first place for the past 10 weeks.
"I'm happy for Dusty and Rod and Barry and all the guys I played with," Williams said, mentioning the manager and a couple of former teammates. "It was tough on all of us the last couple of years, so it's nice to see them do well."
But doesn't he miss being there, being able to enjoy the winning and possibly the division championship? "No. We're in first place and playing well," he said of his new team, the Cleveland Indians.
When the trade was made last November, Williams was as stunned as Giants fans. "Unfortunately, sometimes you don't have any say in the matter," he said. "It took some time to get over wondering why, things like that. But it's baseball. You don't know what's going to happen the next day. I'm good with that."
The arrival of Williams and some other newcomers, notably David Justice and Marquis Grissom, represented a major change in the team that won the A.L. Central the past two seasons. The Indians' play on the field reflected that turnover.
Unlike the 1995-96 teams, these Indians struggled. They have been in first place for all but one day the past nine weeks, but only in the last couple of weeks have they begun exhibiting the ability to pull away.
The Indians gave Chicago every chance to stake their claim to the division lead, but the White Sox sputtered even more. When Albert Belle's new team finally put together a winning streak -- seven straight -- before and after the All-Star Game break, they gained only one game on the Indians, from three and a half to two and a half behind.
Then the White Sox lost four in a row leading to the weekend and tumbled five and a half back, only half a game from their largest deficit of the season.
"A lot of people expected them to be way out in front of us because they signed Belle," Hargrove said, "but I never agreed with that theory."

HEADLINE: Housing Drives Service Members to Poverty

BYLINE: By IAN FISHER 

DATELINE: TIJUANA, Mexico

 BODY:
On a recent morning, Casey Williams fell in with the tide as tens of thousands of Mexicans crossed the border here on their way to jobs in San Diego. He carried a green duffel bag, standard United States military issue, which advertised clear as the desert sky who he was: an American sailor on his daily commute to work from his home in Mexico.
There are no rules about where sailors can live. But the main reason Airman Williams, 26, a native of South Carolina, moved to Tijuana more than a year ago is something the Navy worries about: he thinks his employer, the Federal Government, does not pay him enough to allow him to live in the country he has vowed to serve and protect. 
 Many San Diego sailors who live in Mexico have ties there. Petty Officer 2d Class Cesar Deciga, 24, a son of Mexican immigrants, lives in Tijuana because it is inexpensive. As a result, he said, his life has become a curious circle.
"My family migrated to America to live the American dream," he said. "To have to come back and live over here -- I don't know. I never thought it would be like this."
In part, the situation faced by the San Diego sailors grew out of the surrounding geography and economy -- the proximity to Mexico, with its low cost of living, and the high real estate prices and falling apartment vacancy rates near the bases. But these sailors' lives also offer a glimpse into the wider question of how well service members live at many bases nationwide, especially in high-cost urban areas. Many military advocates in Congress and the Pentagon worry that economic survival has become harder for military personnel and that morale, and, therefore, the nation's overall fitness for war or defense, is hurt.
The strains are evident around the nation, especially in expensive areas like San Diego, Hawaii and Washington, where housing prices have outstripped military cost-of-living increases in the last several years. The Pentagon considers about two-thirds of the housing it administers around the country to be unacceptable because it is too small, too old or too rundown.
About 12,000 military personnel are on food stamps (more would qualify but wince at the idea of taking them). At many bases, service members live in rundown neighborhoods or trailer parks, sometimes in crowded squalor. Many take second jobs to keep their families afloat, and, in a few sad cases, marry people they do not love to get extra pay and benefits.
These problems afflict young enlisted personnel worst, particularly those with families, something the Pentagon does not encourage among its younger members. But it seems clear that those who serve in the military at all ranks and ages make sacrifices in things like pay, housing and time away from their families that the Pentagon calls "quality of life" issues.
For example, just after 5 A.M. one day earlier this month, at a mall parking lot in Temecula, Calif., four sleepy sailors, three of them with high rank, piled into a van for a drive more than an hour south to the North Island Naval Air Station in Coronado, outside San Diego. Chief Petty Officer Dave Whitefield had already commuted 30 miles to get to the van, for a daily round trip of 184 miles.
Behind the wheel, Master Chief Petty Officer Jack Napier, 42, who is at the Navy's highest enlisted rank, which pays more than $3,000 a month, said that commutes of an hour or longer were common among the sailors. He said he had been forced to move far away so he could buy a decent house.
"I'd rather be closer," he said, as the sun began to glow over the desert mountains. "I'd rather be asleep another 30 minutes than drive."
No one is certain how many sailors live in Mexico and cross the border each day to work at the mammoth San Diego Navy Base. The Navy itself has no idea. Guesses from officials and sailors living there run from several dozen to a few hundred.
Questions about the quality of life in the military have raged around Congress and the Pentagon for several years, especially since the cold war ended, the number of personnel was slashed, and more became expected of fewer people. Those concerns have spurred initiatives to improve housing and raise pay.
This year, at the Pentagon's request, Congress is debating a proposal to fix some of the worst deficiencies in off-base housing by providing allowances closer to what housing actually costs in various areas of the country. A Defense Department official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said the proposal would allow people to live closer to their bases and in better conditions than they do now, particularly in high-cost areas.
But most efforts to address the problem have been piecemeal, as the military struggles to balance competing demands: saving money, upgrading expensive weapons programs and taking care of the troops. James A. Martin, a former Army colonel who is now an associate professor at Bryn Mawr College, said there was wide agreement in the Pentagon and in Congress that the quality of life in the military was at a low, but that the costs of large-scale improvements were prohibitive.
He contends, though, that the price of dismissing the issue is high: in the Persian Gulf war, he said, the soldiers with the greatest problems were families in bad housing or in some way unsettled.
"They were preoccupied with worrying about their families," said Mr. Martin, who is part of a group studying housing issues for the Pentagon. "If the buddy next to you -- who you may depend on for your life -- is preoccupied with things back home, you are at risk."
But as politicians debate what to do, members of the armed forces are finding their own solutions, like living in Mexico -- which, it turns out, can raise their standard of living considerably, even to include the trappings of luxury.
Petty Officer 2d Class Oscar Moreno, 22, grew up in Los Angeles but has lived in Tijuana the entire five years he has been in the Navy, which enables him to afford many extras. Mr. Moreno, now married and with a 3-year-old son, said that he would not want to move back to the United States.
"Here I'm upper middle class," he said on a recent night in his kitchen. In the United States, he said, his family would be "probably lower middle class -- low, low, low. It would change dramatically."
As if to underscore the point, he heard a knock on the door a few minutes later and let in a woman with her teen-age daughter. "This is the lady who cleans my house," said Mr. Moreno, who also has a gardener and a baby sitter and sends their son to private school in Tijuana so he can learn English.
Not all sailors who live in Mexico do so with such comforts, but a striking theme emerged in almost every interview: since the draft ended in 1973, the armed forces have become more a career choice than a patriotic obligation -- and it has become a career chosen often by people from low-income families trying to find economic security. Because of the high-priced areas around San Diego, sailors said, living in Mexico is a way to keep that tenuous grasp on the middle class.
"I could live up there, and I could afford it," said one sailor, a 37-year-old native of Wisconsin, speaking on the condition of anonymity, who pays $300 a month rent in Tijuana with his wife, a Mexican medical student.
"But then I couldn't afford to buy other things."
And because the military has become a career for more of its members, the percentage of service members who are married has risen -- to 61 percent today, compared with 42 percent in 1955 -- and that has created even greater financial strains, both for the Pentagon and the individual service members.
Even though the Navy takes no position on sailors' decisions to live in Mexico, it appears to be uneasy about the issue. Master Chief Petty Officer Keith Goosby, the senior enlisted sailor in San Diego, said that about three years ago the Navy began hearing that high rents were pushing sailors into Mexico.
He said an informal survey then -- and a second one last winter -- had ended with the conclusion that money was not the primary reason sailors based in San Diego moved south of the border. Most of those sailors, he said, had family ties, like a Mexican wife or fiancee.
Master Chief Goosby said he would like to talk to any sailor who thought he had to live in Mexico. "I want to know: what is it we're not doing?" he said. "If a sailor has to choose to live in Mexico because of the cost of living, it's a problem very embarrassing to us. You mean we can't do any better than that?"
Navy officials in San Diego -- where roughly 67,000 sailors are stationed -- have worked to ease the hardships. They have started programs to build military housing, to renovate old apartments and houses and to help sailors find affordable private housing.
But roughly 38,000 Navy families are eligible for 8,700 units of military housing, which are free but vary greatly in quality. The average wait for military housing is 18 months, though it can be as long as several years, said Capt. Jill R. Usher, who is in charge of Navy housing in the San Diego area.
Captain Usher said private housing that was comparable to military housing cost roughly $1,000 a month, which is above the housing allowances for even the highest ranking enlisted sailors. The average one- or two-bedroom apartment in San Diego costs about $700, above the means of many sailors, especially young ones with children or whose spouses do not work outside the home.
While it is possible to find affordable housing, Captain Usher said, "it's a challenge."
Petty Officer 3d Class John Seymour, 23, and his wife, Melissa, 22, looked at apartments in Tijuana as they considered ways to save money. But in the end, Mr. Seymour said, national pride got in the way.
"I'm not going to enlist myself in the military and live in TJ," he said, referring to Tijuana. "It's my country, and I'm going to stay in it."
Still, the Seymours said it was hard living in the $700-a-month, two-bedroom house they rent in Imperial Beach, a small city south of San Diego, where they had a drug dealer for a neighbor. Mr. Seymour brings home $1,500 a month, which also has to cover about $200 for utilities, $400 for two car payments and $200 for insurance.
In Mexico, sailors say, they pay around $160 a month for small apartments and $500 to $600 for entire houses, sometimes within blocks of the beach. Nearly all of them said money had been a factor in their decision to move to Mexico. For some -- like Mr. Deciga, the immigrants' son from Tamaulipas, across from Brownsville, Tex. -- it was the most important one. His two-bedroom apartment near downtown Tijuana costs $300 a month.
But Mr. Deciga gets tired of the commute, which requires him to wake up at 4:15 A.M. and sometimes takes two hours -- a long trip, but not an unusual one for sailors living in Mexico. His neighborhood, too, is not the safest.
"I love San Diego," he said. "It's one of the most beautiful cities in the country. But the cost of living -- I just can't afford to live there."

HEADLINE: About New York;
For Some Hispanic Immigrants, a Sense of Kinship With the Silent Laborers

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ 

 BODY:
THEY come from dust-blown villages and jam-packed cities, young men barely old enough to work up a decent lather on their wispy mustaches, all drawn by the lure of the American dollar. They blend into neighborhoods like Jackson Heights, where waves of Latin immigration have made the commercial strips look like an entrepreneurial outpost of the Organization of American States.
The siren song of opportunity is so loud that it resonates even in the bodies of those who cannot hear. Yesterday's discovery of 62 mostly deaf and mute Mexican immigrants who the police said were being held virtually captive in two Queens homes underscored for some young immigrants just how desperately some of their compatriots want to get ahead. 
 The police said the immigrants in the two homes earned their keep, and possibly paid off their passage, by selling key chains and pens on the subway and at airports. It is humbling work, long days of being shunned by commuters and pedestrians who sometimes wave them off with a dismissive glare. But it is work, even for los muditos, the mute ones.
"All Latin America is poor," said Juan Martinez, a 20-year-old from Puebla, Mexico, who lives down the block from one of the houses on 93d Street. "Mexicans and the other Latin Americans want to come here, any way they can, to make a little money and a little progress. Los muditos cannot talk. But they have hands and feet."
THEY are all gears in the hidden machinery of the city's service economy -- nameless delivery boys for delis, quiet caretakers at corner flower stands, faceless dishwashers in restaurants. They barely make an impression on the public, as long as they labor.
"You know, in this country, the immigrant sustains it," said Mr. Martinez, who sells fruits and vegetables from a van. "Whatever restaurant you go to in New York, you will find Latins working in it. You could not eat if they left."
In a city that has long been a magnet for Hispanic immigrants and migrants, the Mexicans began heading here in sizable numbers during the 1980's. They moved into blocks that already were home to Puerto Ricans, Dominicans, Colombians and Ecuadoreans. Such are their numbers that in places like Spanish Harlem, the number of Mexican bakeries and taquerias rivals that of longstanding cuchifrito joints.
The mix is even more striking along 37th Avenue in Jackson Heights. A restaurant sign in bold yellow, blue and red -- the Colombian national colors -- faces its Mexican counterpart, where the awning is festooned with tiny banners for Tecate beer and a sign that announces, "Hoy, mariachis." Nearby, a phone-calling and money-transfer business -- a booming industry providing immigrant lifelines -- proudly displays the flags of Mexico and Colombia.
"Cocos!" shouted a coconut vendor outside a Dominican bodega. "From my corner to your refrigerator!"
The less welcome northern cold is a hard adjustment but a small concession for people like Mr. Martinez and his friend, Ruben Colmenares, both of whom paid coyotes -- smugglers -- to come to New York. Unlike cities in the Southwest, they said that la migra -- immigration authorities -- rarely bothered them here.
"In California, la migra is hard on you," Mr. Martinez said. "In this city, there's no problem because they let us work."
Mr. Colmenares, who makes deliveries for a midtown deli, agreed.
"For every 5,000 that are sent out of New York, 20,000 arrive each day," he said grandly.
"It's easy for us," Mr. Martinez said. "Even if la migra got me, I would be back here in a week."
MR. MARTINEZ said he paid a smuggler $1,200 to bring him here last year. Mr. Colmenares, who arrived five years ago, paid $650. In both cases, they paid half in Mexico and half here. They doubted that the immigrants discovered in the house on their block could have been still paying off their passage.
"Here, you pay the coyote first," Mr. Martinez said. "He would not bring you if not."
The real exploitation, the two men said, came at the hands of others who hired them in this city. In a way, they felt a certain kinship of silence with their less fortunate neighbors.
"In the delis and restaurants, they abuse us," said Mr. Martinez, who until last week worked 60 hours a week as a dishwasher in a restaurant for $130 in cash. "When I wanted to tell the owner something, it was either be quiet or go. Since I would have no money for food or rent, I stayed."
Why don't the police go after the business owners who paid low-ball wages, he asked. He looked across the street, to the house where los muditos had lived. A police officer on guard sat in a chair on the shaded stoop.
"He gets paid to sit," Mr. Martinez said. "I'd like a job like that."

HEADLINE: Mission to Mars Gives New Life to Space Program

BYLINE: By WILLIAM J. BROAD 

 BODY:
After decades in which the space program drew more yawns than cheers, the heavens are suddenly alive with the tragicomedy of the Russian space station Mir and the triumph of Mars Pathfinder's roving exploration of the red planet.
Policy analysts say the burst of activity hints at things to come. The drama, they say, will continue or even rise in years ahead as astronauts take on risky new jobs and waves of low-cost robots explore other worlds. 
 The public has been largely apathetic about the space shuttle since the excitement of the early launchings and missions, which began 16 years ago. The shuttle's job of hauling payloads to orbit is often seen as dull.
In contrast, the emerging phase of the American space program is characterized by new promise and peril.
Dozens of probes are to head for comets and asteroids, moons and planets, deep space and beyond, analyzing the fabric of the heavens, searching for signs of extraterrestrial life and hunting for Earth-like worlds around distant stars.
Closer to home, astronauts are to build, service and repair an international space station the size of a football field -- an endeavor steeped in the danger of sudden death.
"There's going to be thrills, chills and spills," said John E. Pike, director of space policy at the Federation of American Scientists, a private group in Washington. "All this stuff is exciting in a way the space program hasn't been for a long time."
Dr. Louis D. Friedman, executive director of the Planetary Society, a group in Pasadena, Calif., that advocates space exploration, said the program was entering a vigorous new phase.
"We're coming out of a slump," he said in an interview. "The 1980's were dark and lost. They were dark because we sent back no images from other worlds, and lost because we forgot why we were in space. 'Routine access' was the mantra, when what people really wanted was to explore new worlds."
"There's a sense of real vitality now," Dr. Friedman added. "The excitement has returned for the first time in decades."
The pace of activity is to pick up in the years ahead for robots and astronauts alike, which is already creating a major challenge for people who are trying to keep track of the new undertakings.
"There are so many missions," said Donald Savage, a spokesman at the headquarters of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration in Washington. "It's difficult to keep up."
Experts agree that the high point of the American space program occurred as men landed on the Moon in the late 1960's and as the first wave of deep planetary probes swept the solar system in the 1970's.
After that, the program became bogged down in increasingly costly programs and spectacular failures like the 1986 explosion of the space shuttle Challenger, which killed seven astronauts. The Hubble Space Telescope was launched into orbit in 1990, only to have scientists learn that its main mirror was distorted by a serious flaw that astronauts later repaired.
The new era of revitalization is partly attributed by analysts to the influence of Daniel S. Goldin, who became the NASA administrator in early 1992 and started a vigorous campaign to make the agency's projects smaller, cheaper, faster and better, as he put it. He is still pushing that agenda hard.
The other rejuvenating factor is President Clinton, who, after taking office in 1993, ordered NASA to abandon its long rivalry with Moscow and join its Russian counterparts in creating a new East-West program of piloted exploration of the heavens.
It was the first time that the White House had paid close attention to the space program since the Moon landings. Its political goals were to strengthen the shaky Russia economy and engage Moscow in constructive space work in exchange for ending practices like exporting advanced rocket gear to developing countries.
To date, five American astronauts have lived and worked aboard Russia's Mir outpost. The East-West collaboration is to culminate in the international space station, a 470-ton, 356-foot behemoth that is to hold as many as seven people studying heaven and Earth, and things like human physiology, while moving through space at more than 17,000 miles an hour.
The cascade of accidents that has shaken the 11-year-old Mir has raised questions about whether the station should be set aside in favor of the new one, which is viewed as safer. But many analysts say that logic is flawed, that the new outpost will have its own accidents and dangers, some of which could be major.
"All the things that have happened could happen in the future," said Jerry Grey, policy director of the American Institute of Astronautics and Aeronautics in Washington, a professional group of aerospace engineers. "If we planned the use of Mir in the most effective way, we would have had all these accidents. It's invaluable experience."
The new outpost is to be assembled in space by astronauts. Just sending all the parts and crews into orbit will require 42 launchings, which are to begin next year. Construction is to be finished in 2003.
"There will be a fair amount of excitement" as astronauts work as orbital builders and mechanics, said Dr. John M. Logsdon, director of the Space Policy Institute at George Washington University. He added that the drama would center on "fixing problems" and avoiding the risk of "killing people."
Danger is rooted in the size, which makes the station an easy target for speeding asteroids and space debris. In January, the National Academy of Sciences in Washington called on the station team to pay more attention to shielding the station and developing repair techniques.
Another risk is age. The station is designed for a life of 10 years and will cost some $50 billion to build and run. But given the expense, analysts say, its life will undoubtedly be extended to 20 or 30 years by astronauts' repairs.
So the aging patchwork that is Mir is likely to be repeated in the new outpost, only over a longer period.
"Mir has had two fires and one depressurization in 11 years," said George Cleghorn, a former aerospace executive who was chairman of the National Academy of Sciences panel on the outpost. "You can extrapolate that" to a higher number of tribulations over three decades for the new station, he said, adding that it could also be safer in many respects.
The robotic part of the American space program is also entering a new phase, which, in stark contrast to the costly station venture, involves large numbers of low-cost missions.
The new approach was on display at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Pasadena, Calif., on July 4 as joyous controllers oversaw the first landing of an American craft on Mars in 21 years and the first exploration of any planet by an itinerant robot. The effort was success on a shoestring, costing less than one-tenth what the Viking landings did two decades ago.
Experts say a whirlwind of new missions is planned or already winging its way toward distant targets. The highlights include the Lunar Prospector, which is set for launching in September to orbit the Moon in search of minerals and ice deposits; Stardust, to be launched in February 1999 on a mission to catch part of a comet's tail and take it back to Earth, and the Planet Finder, a cluster of four infrared telescopes tentatively set for launching in 2005, that is to orbit beyond Jupiter while hunting for Earth-like planets around distant stars.
Not all the missions are very likely to have the same degree of public interest that has typified the Mars Pathfinder success, in which a plucky little robot is traversing and analyzing Martian soil and rocks.
"They'll be taking different forms of scientific measurements that will not always translate into arresting images," said Dr. Logsdon of George Washington University.
But the rising quantity and intensity of space exploration, experts say, is sure to expand greatly the opportunities for success and failure, giving the program new lift and drama.
"The space program is always fragile," said Dr. Friedman of the Planetary Society. "But all the things being accomplished now are a preview of things to come. They're setting a new standard, and that's good. We need high standards" in the exploration of new worlds.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "COMING UP: Space Sampler: Previews of Exploration"
Some highlights of the dozens of planned unmanned space exploration missions:
 
Lunar Prospector, set for launching in September, is to orbit the Moon in search of minerals and ice deposits.
 
Mars Global Surveyor is to reach the red planet in September, orbiting and analyzing it.
 
Mars Surveyor 1998 Orbiter is to be launched in December 1998.
 
Mars Surveyor 1998 Lander it to blast off in January 1999. During descent, the lander spacecraft is to drop a separate payload that deeply penetrates the Martian soil, investigating its makeup.
 
Near Earth Asteroid Rendezvous is to reach the rocky asteroid Eros in February 1999, going into orbit for detailed analyses.
 
Stardust is to be launched in February 1999 on a mission to catch part of a comet's tail and bring it back to Earth.
 
The Comet Nucleus Tour, to be launched in 2002, is to investigate a trio of icy comets.
 
The Planet Finder, tentatively set for launching in 2005, is a cluster of four infrared telescopes that is to orbit out beyond Jupiter and hunt for Earth-like planets around distant stars.

HEADLINE: The July of Loren Easton;
Not All at Horace Mann Are From Upper East Side

 BODY:

To the Editor:
I read the article with interest since my own daughter graduated from high school this June. 
 Hannah began her education at P.S. 173 in Fresh Meadows, Queens (no aptitude test required, thank you). When we moved to Douglaston, she transferred to P.S. 98, entering a third-grade class with 34 children, a teacher-student ratio that I'm sure would horrify any Horace Mann parent or faculty member. Her middle school was M.S. 67, and in ninth grade she began her high school career at St. Francis Preparatory School.
Like so many parochial schools in our city, St. Francis has students from a wide range of economic, racial, ethnic and religious backgrounds. It gives its students an excellent education, yet I'm sure the good brothers and sisters and other dedicated faculty members of St. Francis would not be comfortable with the label "elite." Certainly no one would mistake the large brick building and surrounding parking lot for a small college campus. The tuition, less than $4,000, is bargain-basement, compared with the schools in your article.
Having then received this education that the privileged students of New York's 70 independent schools would no doubt find unremarkable, perhaps even inferior, what is my daughter to do with her future? Actually, she's going to Penn. See you there, Loren!
 
CLAIRE GOLDSTEIN
Douglaston, Queens
