HEADLINE: Coup Halts Lifeline to Cambodia Poor

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS 

DATELINE: KVET, Cambodia, July 19

 BODY:
It costs a full day's wages here $1.70 -- to take a motorcycle taxi through the rice fields to the marketplace seven miles away. Yet the people are so poor and isolated that social service groups say it is useless to offer them credit programs.
This tiny village, like thousands of others around the country, depends for its welfare on a wide range of international assistance that substitutes throughout Cambodia for Government services. The four-room schoolhouse was built with foreign aid. So was the narrow, rutted dirt road that links it to the outside world. 
 Health education and a literacy program, as well as information about AIDS, are provided by foreign aid groups. The village's economy now depends on an internationally financed "cow bank" that has lent 32 cows to the subsistence farmers here.
The village of Kvet, with its 520 people -- including 63 war widows -- is one of many examples of the success of a broad and idealistic program of international aid that is helping this broken country to begin to heal. It also offers a glimpse of the ways in which the withdrawal of aid -- now being discussed in the United States and other nations -- would affect the lives of the poor villagers who make up the overwhelming majority of Cambodians.
Ten days ago, after the violent seizure of power by Hun Sen, the Second Prime Minister, the United States suspended its aid programs to Cambodia for 30 days. These programs include $35 million in direct assistance as well as about $7 million in Defense Department money, most of it for the removal of land mines.
Other countries and organizations have also cut off aid or said they were considering similar moves. Japan suspended its program of about $150 million a year. The World Bank is considering whether to continue a $54.3 million program that includes $1.4 million for disease prevention and eradication and $20 million to improve agriculture. All told, the amount of foreign aid that has been coming in is equal to the national budget.
When its suspension ends on Aug. 9, the United States must decide whether, or to what extent, to resume its aid. The difficult decision faced by donors is how to punish or influence Mr. Hun Sen without hurting people like the villagers in Kvet.
"Teach a lesson to Hun Sen?" said Kien Serey Phal, who heads the Cambodian Women's Development Association, an aid group that uses money from the United States and other countries to help villagers. "But the poorest will suffer as a result of that lesson, not Hun Sen."
Few countries are as dependent on foreign assistance as Cambodia. From 1975 to 1979, more than a million people died when the radical Communist Government of the Khmer Rouge launched a campaign to kill the country's educated people and destroy its culture, industry and civil institutions.
When Vietnam ousted the Khmer Rouge and installed a new Communist Government, almost no doctors, lawyers, teachers or trained civil servants were left. A civil war ensued, during which few institutions were rebuilt, as the country remained isolated from most of the world.
A $2 billion effort coordinated by the United Nations established democratic forms of government in 1993 and huge amounts of foreign aid began flowing in. More than 100 non-governmental organizations now work in Cambodia, using foreign funds to provide everything from legal aid to irrigation projects to immunization programs.
But relatively little of the country's official budget reaches the people. In a statement last month, the United Nations complained that much of the budget was being drained off by military spending; much of the rest was disappearing into the pockets of Government officials.
Aid workers say their programs fill an additional, perhaps even more important need: training Cambodians in the basic skills and principles of administering a democratic society.
Indeed, the Cambodians they are training represent the foundation of what could become a genuine democratic opposition. An immediate fear among these workers after the coup was that it would be Mr. Hun Sen himself -- not foreign governments -- who would shut their agencies down.
"To the extent that non-governmental organizations represent a segment of civil society that is not controlled by the Government -- an alternative voice within the country -- their disappearance is not something the Government would be upset about," said an American aid worker, speaking on condition of anonymity.
The people of Kvet live much as they have for generations, and the Government plays little role in their lives.
Two years ago, the Government built a small clinic to serve seven neighboring villages, but it has no medicine. The Government also provided those villages with four water pumps, but the people here say they cannot afford the gasoline to run them.
Few people here have ever visited the capital, Phnom Penh, though it is less than an hour's drive away. But they could hear the big guns of Mr. Hun Sen's coup two weeks ago.
"We heard the sounds, boom, boom, boom," said Tith Sam On, who helps run literacy and health care programs here for Ms. Serey Phal's organization. "We were afraid it was war again."
Since then, villagers said, the political upheaval in Phnom Penh has had no effect on their lives. But they seemed terrified today by the prospect that aid could be halted.
"Please continue the aid!" cried a group of old women who were gathered for a ceremony at a local temple, when a foreign visitor arrived. "Don't stop the aid! Have pity on the people!"
Cheoun Pheap, 37, said the cow she had received from the Cambodian Women's Development Association offered hope that her five children could live a better life than she and her husband, who works as a laborer for $1.70 a day.
Her 10-year-old daughter, Net, who cares for her younger siblings when her parents are working in the fields, said she wanted to be the first in her family to finish all seven years of school.
"I want to be a nurse," she said, "and help the people of the village."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Cheoun Pheap, a villager from Kvet, stood with her children and the cow she received from an international aid agency. That animal, she said, provides the chance for her children to have a better life than she did. (Seth Mydans/The New York Times)
 
Map showing the location of Kvet, Cambodia: Kvet feels little effect from the strife in the capital nearby.

HEADLINE: As Leaders Bicker, Haiti Stagnates and Its People Fret

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, July 18

 BODY:
Nearly three years after American troops and aid began pouring into this country in an effort to build democracy and a working economy, the Haitian Government is all but paralyzed by internal squabbling that has left the economy moribund and the populace irate.
The latest crisis began early in June when Prime Minister Rosny Smarth resigned after intense criticism by allies of former President Jean-Bertrand Aristide. Six weeks later, no replacement has been found, $100 million in vital foreign aid is still bottled up in Parliament, and a runoff election seen as the first step to resolving the stalemate has been indefinitely postponed. 
 The dispute has eroded the prestige of President Rene Preval, a disciple of Mr. Aristide, who now finds himself advocating policies the former President has publicly attacked and sought to undermine.
"Preval doesn't know what to do," said Jean-Claude Bajeux, who was Mr. Aristide's Minister of Culture and is now critical of the former President. "He is torn between his fidelity to Aristide and his duties as chief of state."
As the stalemate drags on, people's impatience and frustration are growing. Prices are rising, jobs are scarce, electricity blackouts are more frequent, and the quality of other public services is declining.
By law, the caretaker Government now in place is prohibited from introducing new legislation, which might ease these pressures. But Parliament cannot even assemble a quorum to vote on several bills already introduced, whose passage is a requirement for release of the foreign aid that makes up 60 percent of the Government's budget.
"The political class is wasting time playing stupid games," said Monfort Jean-Jacques, 25, who was playing dominoes with a friend at a downtown street corner here because, they said, neither could find work. "In the meantime, all the rest of us are struggling to survive."
For the most part, such discontent has not yet led to violence. But several weeks ago, teachers, some of whom had not been paid in more than a year, went on strike just as final exams were to be held, provoking street protests by students that turned into rock-throwing, tire-burning and clashes with the police.
In an interview here, Mr. Preval pointed to several Government commissions or agencies he said were continuing normal activities. But with very little money in the pipeline, he has been reduced to promoting a school uniform program as if it were a major initiative and pleading with Haitians to give him more time to assemble a new Government that can function properly.
"Today, the car is in the repair shop, and they are checking the spark plugs and other parts," Mr. Preval said at a news conference this week with Bill Richardson, the American delegate to the United Nations, which has a peacekeeping mission here whose mandate expires July 31. "I don't want to start the car in Port-au-Prince and get stuck on the road. I want to be able to drive it all the way to Cap-Haitien."
One of the two quarreling factions in the coalition that American troops restored to power in September 1994 supports Mr. Preval and controls the largest bloc of seats in Parliament. It favors a program to sell off money-losing state companies and talks of building a political system based on parties, not personalities. The other faction, loyal to Mr. Aristide, who may run for President again, argues that the Government's privatization plan betrays the country's impoverished majority.
Tensions between the groups erupted after balloting in April for the Senate and local councils. Mr. Aristide's new party came out ahead in that vote, which attracted less than 10 percent of the electorate and has been widely criticized by international monitoring groups for widespread irregularities. The faction supporting Mr. Preval is demanding that those results be annulled and the election commission overhauled.
In an interview, William L. Swing, the American Ambassador, said he viewed the impasse as "prima facie evidence that democracy is working." He said it was "just a question of how long it is going to take them to put a package together," an assessment that other diplomats repeated.
"We've seen this type of situation before -- the country comes close to the brink and a solution is achieved," said Enrique ter Horst, director of the United Nations mission here. "I am confident it will also happen this time."
In public, the President has been careful not to criticize Mr. Aristide for behavior that most diplomats here, and many of his countrymen, regard as obstructionist.
Asked this week whether he regarded Mr. Aristide as a supporter of his Government or the leader of the opposition, Mr. Preval would not respond. "I think it would be better for you to ask the person concerned, not myself," he said in an interview at the National Palace. "It is dangerous to speak on behalf of someone else."
Mr. Aristide himself has been vague and elusive. At a news conference on Tuesday that coincided with his 44th birthday, he spoke of the need to "engage in a national dialogue with all sectors" in order to "reach a political equilibrium," but also said the results of the April vote should be ratified.
The United States faces a quandary. Having made a large political and economic investment in the restoration of democracy here, the Clinton Administration does not want to see the Government collapse in squabbling that would discredit the international effort or encourage Haitians once again to set sail for Florida.
Mr. Preval "ought to be given the opportunity and diplomatic space to govern," Nicholas Burns, a State Department spokesman, said last month. "It is very difficult to succeed someone as charismatic and popular as President Aristide."
But Mr. Aristide, whom Haitians and foreigners alike regard as likely to return to office when elections are held in 2000, if not before, must also be taken into account. That approach, though, only feeds speculation that Mr. Aristide is the country's real center of power.
Mr. Preval's first choice as the new Prime Minister is said to be Eric Pierre, who is Haiti's delegate to the Inter-American Development Bank in Washington. But diplomats and Haitian leaders say Mr. Pierre is just the kind of figure who would be anathema to the Aristide camp: a technocrat committed to a program of reduced spending and privatization of state companies.
"Whether he comes from abroad, from heaven, or a political party is of no interest to me," Mr. Preval said when asked what qualities he was seeking in a nominee. Then, with a rueful laugh, he added, "I just hope he doesn't come from hell."

HEADLINE: Item in Tax Bill Poses Threat to Job Benefits

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
In Congress and in thousands of workplaces, the nation's business community is seeking to change longstanding rules and practices to turn many people classified as employees into independent contractors -- a move that could cause many Americans to lose health insurance and pension and unemployment insurance benefits.
In a little-noticed provision in its tax bill, the House of Representatives has approved a new -- and, many experts say, more inclusive -- test to determine who is an independent contractor. The Clinton Administration is fighting the provision, asserting that it would strip millions of workers of their basic benefits. But business groups say the legislation is needed to clarify the often fuzzy definition of who is an independent contractor. 
 Outside Capitol Hill, employers from small construction companies to giants like Microsoft and Pacific Bell are increasingly hiring new workers as independent contractors rather than as traditional employees -- a not entirely new practice that is expanding rapidly as employers strain to cut costs. Such a strategy not only gives employers more flexibility to shrink their work forces, but it saves them thousands of dollars per worker because companies do not have to make Social Security, Medicare, unemployment insurance or workers' compensation contributions for independent contractors.
"What's clear is employers are seeking increasingly to have more flexible arrangements," said Sara Horowitz, the executive director of Working Today, an advocacy group on workplace issues. "But what that means in reality is people are working increasingly without benefits. They're working not only without health coverage but without the protections of the major labor legislation of this century: pensions, minimum wage, occupational safety, unemployment insurance, age discrimination. The list goes on."
Opponents of this practice say companies are wrongly lumping people usually considered employees, like truck drivers and middle-level managers, into the independent contractor category, which traditionally referred to people in business for themselves.
At last year's Olympic Games in Atlanta, for example, several hundred broadcast technicians hired by the Atlanta Committee for the Olympic Games had to sign contracts saying they were freelance independent contractors rather than employees, who are protected by overtime and unemployment insurance laws. A Maryland catering company that books 1,000 events a year insists that the 75 waiters it hires on average for each event are independent contractors, not employees. Texas A & M University recently hired 400 low-wage farm workers for its 18 agricultural extension programs and classified them as independent contractors rather than employees -- a move the Internal Revenue Service found to be illegal. Pacific Bell laid off hundreds of experienced middle managers several years ago and has hired many of them back as independent contractors, but without the health insurance, pension plan and unemployment coverage they used to have.
Corporate America defends the trend toward hiring independent contractors, saying it gives companies the flexibility to cut back easily during downturns. Business groups also assert that because this is an age when Americans are becoming more entrepreneurial and are increasingly working at home thanks to computers, it only makes sense to classify more workers as contractors.
The corporate groups that have persuaded the House and are pushing the Senate to rewrite the definition of who is an independent contractor contend that the legislation is needed because the common-law definition is arcane and vague. They say that because many companies fear harsh I.R.S. punishment, existing law pushes employers to classify workers as employees when they should be considered independent contractors.
Nelson Litterst, manager of legislative affairs for the National Federation of Independent Business, a small-business group that is pushing hard for the legislation, said: "The interest of small business has never been to find loopholes in the law to create wholesale switches of workers to independent contractors. Our intention is to clarify the definition so there is less of a gray area."
But a senior Treasury Department official argued that the provision passed by the House appeared intended to greatly increase the number of independent contractors, currently 8.3 million. "The number of employees who will be shifted will be in the millions," said the official, who characterized the House legislation as far broader than traditional definitions of independent contractor. "I'm not even sure if I would characterize this provision as a sieve. A sieve at least strains things out."
Martin Regalia, chief economist for the United States Chamber of Commerce, interprets the House language far more restrictively, saying it merely defines borders instead of opening up new territory. "To allege there will be wholesale expansion of independent contractors and that thousands of individuals will lose their benefits is pure rhetoric," he said.
The A.F.L.-C.I.O. is working to torpedo the House provision on independent contractors, insisting that it would eliminate basic protections for millions of workers, creating a cost advantage for many employers that would in turn push their competitors to transform their workers into independent contractors. That trend is especially worrisome for organized labor, which is struggling to increase its ebbing numbers, because independent contractors are not allowed to form or join unions under Federal labor law.
"What you have here is another window into the Republican leadership's view of the role of government," said Peggy Taylor, the labor federation's director of legislative affairs. "In this instance, they're trying to put government on the side of those corporations and employers who want to get away from any responsibilities for the people who work for them."
Because the House included the independent contractor provision in its tax bill, but the Senate inserted no such language in its tax bill, Administration officials and members of Congress say it is hard to predict whether conferees will keep the provision in the final tax bill.
The House language, introduced by Jon Christensen, Republican of Nebraska, sets up three tests to determine who is an independent contractor:
First, there should be a written contract between the worker and the company.
Second, the worker has a principal place of business that is not the company's, does not work primarily at the company's place of business or rents an office at the company. An alternative second test is whether the worker is not required to work exclusively for the company and whether the worker performed a significant amount of work for other companies the previous year.
If a worker meets the first and second tests, satisfying any of the following criteria makes a worker an independent contractor: The worker has "a significant investment in assets and/or training," the worker is primarily paid on commission, the worker has significant unreimbursed expenses or the worker's service is for a specific amount of time to complete a specific task.
Mr. Regalia, the Chamber of Commerce economist, said these criteria would create far more certainty than the common-law test, which turns on whether the employer controls not just the results of a worker's service but the means a worker uses, such as the route a worker drives or how a worker dresses.
But analyses prepared by the Clinton Administration and the A.F.L.-C.I.O. indicate that the new test will sweep many more workers into the independent contractor category. Pizza deliverers could easily become independent contractors because they do not work primarily on their company's place of business, they own their cars (a significant investment in assets), and they obtain most earnings from tips (primarily paid by commissions). Similarly, carpenters and painters might overwhelmingly be considered independent contractors because they own their tools (a significant investment in assets), they do no work on their companies' premises and they might sign a contract to do a specific job over a specific period.
According to the Treasury, many secretaries could become independent contractors if companies pay them a little extra and then require them to buy their own computers and pay a modest rent for their offices.
"We're heading into a two-tiered economy," said Ms. Horowitz of Working Today, the advocacy group. "The first tier has a New Deal safety net, protected by all the different labor laws. Then there is a second tier that's short term, flexible, many of them independent contractors. That tier doesn't receive benefits or labor law protections.
"The labor law and social protections are completely out of sync with this work force. If the rules of the game are changing and people are going to become independent contractors, then we have to have a new safety net that serves these people, too."

HEADLINE: Under the World's Eye, Postwar Liberia Goes to the Polls

BYLINE: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr. 

DATELINE: MONROVIA, Liberia, July 19

 BODY:
Under the unusually attentive eyes of a world that normally ignores it, this African nation founded by American slaves went to the polls today in what is hoped will be its first free and fair election.
Former President Jimmy Carter is here to watch, along with a White House special envoy and delegations from the United Nations, the European Union, the Organization of African Unity and other organizations. About 500 outside monitors are in the country to keep an eye on about 2,000 polling places. 
 And in a capital that normally has only two FM radio stations, there are now temporarily eight, one set up by the United States and one by the Roman Catholic Church, which both want access to more objective news coverage. Three of the others are controlled by former faction leaders. To make sure that rural Liberians hear the news, the United Nations has handed out 5,500 wind-up radios, to avoid the need for electricity, which is scarce, or batteries, which are expensive.
By early afternoon in Monrovia, there appeared to be a large turnout at the polls, and voting was proceeding without incident.
With no reliable opinion polls, the outcome is anybody's guess. Among the 13 candidates are 2 leading antagonists, each boasting with absolute certainty that he or she will collect the 51 percent needed to win on the first ballot.
The first is Charles Taylor, 49, who was both a student and a prison escapee in Massachusetts before returning to Liberia in 1989 to lead a coup. That led to occupation by troops from other West African countries, seven years of civil war in the countryside and the destruction of much of Monrovia last year.
The second is Ellen Johnson-Sirleaf, 58, a Harvard-educated former Citibank vice president and United Nations official in charge of African development. She once supported Mr. Taylor in his coup against the dictator Samuel K. Doe, but changed her mind as the ensuing war became increasingly vicious.
Several diplomats have predicted that neither will win a majority, and that in a runoff two weeks from now most other candidates will back Mrs. Johnson-Sirleaf.
The worry is that Mr. Taylor will prove a sore loser. Even though the militias that sacked Monrovia last spring have nominally been disbanded, everyone thinks Mr. Taylor could rearm his soldiers, many of whom are youths. But in his final campaign speech, on Thursday, he assured a crowd, "To those of you who are worried about violence -- you have nothing to fear from me."
A Nigerian-led peacekeeping force now controls the country. There are soldiers at every border post, in every village of more than 500 people and at checkpoints throughout the capital. On a 10-minute drive through downtown, a car may easily be stopped 5 times, and the trunk checked for weapons.
The force's jocular but tough-talking commander, Maj. Gen. Victor Malu, has warned that his troops will "go after" any losing candidate who tries to resort to violence, and the response, he has said, will be "heavy and decisive."
During the campaign, when candidates were threatened in rural areas, General Malu assigned each a military escort and gathered party leaders to warn against violence.
In the last six months, former militia members have turned in 20,000 weapons. General Malu said his troops had not been confronted by armed men since February, even during arms raids of houses.
But the 10-nation peacekeeping force's mission ends in 6 months, and Nigeria and Ghana, the largest contributors, are said to be eager to drop the expense.
The United States, which has helped finance the mission, has also spent $7.5 million to help assure that the election goes well today. Its chief interest is in seeing democracy succeed, said William B. Malim, the American Ambassador.
The United States is deeply entangled in the history of Liberia, which was settled by freed slaves in 1822 and declared independent in 1847. English here is spoken in the antebellum accents of rural Carolina counties, and many Liberians have studied in the United States, have relatives there and wonder why the average American is not more concerned with the fate of this country. The United States used to have important C.I.A. listening posts and military stores here, and Firestone has the world's largest rubber plantation.
Diplomats from the United Nations and other agencies said they were pleased with the preparations for the election. About 750,000 out of an estimated million voting-age Liberians have been registered, although all figures are a bit shaky. The civil war is believed to have killed 150,000 of the 2.4 million population and driven 1.5 million from their homes, many into exile in neighboring countries.
Ballot boxes have been delivered to rural areas. The elections commission has agreed to report all the tallies as they come in, which cuts down the possibility of fraud. And wild rumors that spread during the campaign -- like one that the ballot lines for Mr. Taylor's party were printed in disappearing ink -- have been quickly denied.
Voters are also being asked today to choose a vice president and a legislature comprising 26 senators and 64 representatives.
The campaigning between Mr. Taylor and Mrs. Johnson-Sirleaf has been personal and ugly. He has called her candidacy "an insult to traditional Liberian women," who he said do not think women should hold office. He has put himself forward as the only candidate strong enough to insure peace.
She calls herself the only candidate without blood on her hands and the best qualified to fix the country's economy. She has called Mr. Taylor a "desperate man, grabbing at straws," and has accused him of telling rural voters that he had already won and inviting them to the victory party.
On the street, people profess love for their candidates, though it is often unquestioning love.
"Charles Taylor spoiled this country, so he's the best man to fix it," insisted Carro Kannah, 19. "I'm going to sleep at the voting place tonight to be the first to vote for Charles Ghankay Taylor."
A 25-year-old supporter of Mrs. Johnson-Sirleaf who spoke on condition of anonymity said: "God is never unjust. Everyone who votes for Charles Taylor tomorrow will be punished." The woman described seeing Mr. Taylor's boy soldiers hack her stepfather to death with a cutlass for being a former policeman. Her two young children died of malnutrition in the civil war, she said.
While Mrs. Johnson-Sirleaf has borrowed against her United Nations pension and does her campaigning in old cars, Mr. Taylor has a fleet of four-wheel-drive vehicles and even a helicopter, and can afford to feed and give T-shirts to voters who attend his rallies.
Poor as Liberia is, it exports diamonds, gold, hardwoods and rubber, and Mr. Taylor's party has held official posts that have allowed it to collect fees on exports.
In 1985, according to the newsletter Africa Confidential, Mr. Taylor escaped from Plymouth County jail in Massachusetts, where he had been held for 15 months on an extradition request filed by the Liberian Government of Mr. Doe. That Government accused Mr. Taylor, its former General Services Agency director, of embezzling $1 million. Mr. Taylor's lawyer, Ramsey Clark, said the charge was trumped up.
Asked earlier this month how the United States would react to a Taylor presidency, Nicholas Burns, the State Department spokesman, said: "Lots of people with checkered pasts participate in elections. Redemption is an important theological element in diplomacy."

HEADLINE: A Year Later, Some Atlantans Are Asking: What Olympic Legacy?

BYLINE: By RICK BRAGG 

DATELINE: ATLANTA, July 19

 BODY:
For two weeks last summer, even the sky seemed bluer.
Many Atlanta residents, frightened of rumors of huge traffic jams during the 1996 Summer Olympic Games, left their polluting cars at home. The commuters rode public transportation, car-pooled, worked at home or went on vacation. The sky, usually shrouded in a dingy, grayish-brown haze from the freeway system that surrounds the city, was bright and clear. 
 Freakishly, even the weather was less humid and cooler than normal, as if the Atlanta Committee for the Olympic Games, which organized the event, had bought off God. Former Mayor Andrew Young had, indeed, prayed hard for a cool spell.
Today, one year after the Games began, the traffic and haze are back, the heat and humidity are again at a stifling norm, and Atlantans are asking if the Olympics left any significant legacy, or if it was all just an interesting break in routine.
The consensus, even from some who worked to make the Games a success, seems to be that the lasting effect of this event fell short of expectations in most ways. The Olympics left Atlanta with a grand new baseball field and an assortment of other new and renovated sports venues, but the Games do not seem to have become a seminal moment in history, not in economics, not in the city's character and certainly not as a boon for poor neighborhoods.
And no one seems very surprised. Expectations, many here said, were just too ridiculously high.
The impact was "less than many people would like to think it would have been," said Lyn May, former director of communications for the Atlanta Committee for the Olympic Games, now vice president of the Georgia Foundation for Independent Colleges. "There was always an overestimation of what the Games were supposed to be."
She added: "Any time you set your expectations too high, you're going to be disappointed. People did, and people are."
It is not so hard to find the worst legacy of the Games, the bombing in Centennial Olympic Park that killed an Albany, Ga., woman. That crime, which resulted in the bizarre investigation and later exoneration of Richard Jewell, a security guard, is still unsolved, and investigators seem no closer now than in 1996.
It is also not difficult to find the lasting changes in the city's infrastructure. But most of the new construction the Olympics ushered in -- like the Olympic Stadium that is now home to the Atlanta Braves, the Olympic Village, now student housing, and the Olympic Natatorium, a spot for the Georgia Institute of Technology's community to cool off -- was work that had to be done simply to accommodate the events. Some had hoped that the Olympics would quickly spark construction of other new business and housing.
While there has been a sprinkling of new housing in poor neighborhoods, more or less linked to the Games, the building has been less than expected.
"The biggest impact it had was on the construction industry and the infrastructure improvements that were made, the biggest part of that before the Olympics," said Kenneth L. Bernhardt, professor of marketing at Georgia State University.
Construction unrelated to the Games was deferred a year or so by the frenzy of the pre-Olympic building. "That prevented a major recession," Mr. Bernhardt said. "That helped even out things post-Olympics."
"We got a boost that put us on a higher plateau than we otherwise would have been on," Mr. Bernhardt said, "but there's very little legacy in terms of its long-term economic impact. People don't invest their capital because a city has the Olympics. That was part of the hype."
There was plenty of hype.
Billy Payne, the chief executive officer of the Atlanta committee, had predicted "the greatest peacetime event in the 20th century."
That, as people like to say down here, was a tough row to hoe. But Mr. Payne stands by his predictions of an economic windfall.
"I laugh about folks who are impatient about it," said Mr. Payne, now a vice president at Nationsbank in Atlanta. "We've created a location which has overnight seen sellers of land literally licking their chops. We have not yet seen the forces of supply and demand meet."
Mayor Bill Campbell agreed. "The economy is poised for success in the future," he said.
But others are less optimistic.
When the Games were over, Atlantans and Georgians and Southerners in general would describe the Olympics as one of the most exciting times of their lives, and say that just being part of the event -- however small a part -- was a treasured memory.
But Atlanta reached for much more than that, in a flare of chest-thumping civic pride that some visitors tried to douse early with criticism, contending that Atlanta fell short of Barcelona, the host in 1992. Then, when the Olympic Committee president, Juan Antonio Samaranch, refused to proclaim Atlanta "the best Olympics ever," as is the custom -- the latest one is always supposed to be the best -- it hurt.
Of the international press -- much of which criticized Atlanta for problems in everything from transportation to computers -- Ms. May said, "That was colored by their self-centered need to be coddled. As a result, Atlanta ended up with a less glowing image than we would have hoped."
But most people, "who saw wonderful events, who saw records broken, most of those people will tell you they'd come back to Atlanta," she said.
What they have not seen is a city that followed through on its grand promises. A year later, Centennial Olympic Park is still under construction. While Mr. Campbell says the downtown is more vibrant than ever before, nightfall still chases away most people except the homeless. The Olympic Games were supposed to create an atmosphere that would draw people to this sterile area of high-rise buildings.
The poor neighborhoods that were supposed to see major redevelopment were mostly disappointed. Of the 16 downtown neighborhoods targeted for redevelopment, only two areas, Summerhill and Techwood, saw new housing and other improvements, said Steven P. French, director of city planning at Georgia Tech.
But Atlanta, an image-conscious city that seems to be forever striving for bigger and bigger conventions and recognition as a true international city, will ultimately, like any good public relations firm, discard the bad and talk up the good.
"Atlanta had a pretty good self-image and sense of itself, even before the Games," Ms. May said. "Atlanta was full of itself even before the Games. Atlanta is like an egotistical guy. His pants may be a little shorter than they should be, and he may be balding a little on top, but he has not lost one bit of his swagger."

GRAPHIC: Photos: A year after the Olympics, the lasting effects on Atlanta are short of most expectations. Centennial Olympic Park is still under construction. Janice Brown and Allie Allen, both 13, and of Athens, Ga., watched park construction. (Photographs by Alan S. Weiner for the New York Times)

HEADLINE: Policy Centers Rethink Their Images

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 19

 BODY:
The staid community of Washington "think tanks" has been trying over the last year or so to find new ways to capture the attention of a post-cold-war America, realizing that the only way they can change the world is to get somebody to listen.
The Carnegie Endowment for International Peace has hired a new president known for applying her scientific training to new, "global" issues like terrorism and the environment. And it has revamped its magazine, "Foreign Policy," to look more like a literary magazine and to grab a broader audience.. 
 Over at the Brookings Institution, the new President, Michael H. Armacost, feared that the organization was too closely associated with the Democratic Party and that people were too busy to read its scholarly research. Mr. Armacost hired a centrist Republican to direct foreign policy studies. He is known for his quick mind and media savvy and has become one of Washington's most quoted experts. At the same time, Brookings is paring down its list of fellows and asking them to write shorter research summaries, or "policy briefs," for Washington politicians and professionals.
The appointments of Jessica T. Mathews, 51, as head of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace and Richard N. Haass, 45, at Brookings, are supposed to be part of each institute's answer for a new look, and desire for new financial support.
Ms. Mathews made her mark as an innovator. A former Washington Post columnist, she turned down a top job in the Clinton Administration to become Carnegie's president. While she is well-grounded in traditional areas and has served on the board of both Carnegie and Brookings, her appointment is emblematic of the search for a new, more global rationale.
"I don't think my appointment had symbolic value to the search committee," she said in her sunny, spacious office. "But it clearly does to others," who have sent her hundreds of letters.
In part, she said, it is "a sense that I don't have a traditional foreign-policy background," with a career-long effort to try to integrate new themes like the spread of nuclear weapons, human rights and the environment and new actors into foreign policy. And in part it is her ability, like Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright, to break gender ceilings.
The changes at Brookings, which also has major divisions in economic and governmental studies, are less striking and more traditional. For the last 18 months Mr. Armacost has been engineering a quiet shake-up to make it more nonpartisan "in a way that shapes the public agenda and is useful to policy makers," he said.
"The public is looking for practical answers, not ideology," he added.
At a time when money for foreign policy is decreasing , whether in Congress or among charitable foundations, there is a new, competitive concentration on salesmanship -- getting the message pithy and quotable, for legislators and a wider, national audience.
The paradox, as Mr. Haass sees it, is that "as the old paradigms are shifting and nothing has taken their place," the study of foreign policy by outsiders should be thriving, since Government officials are generally too busy to think.
"But with the cold war over, there's less urgency, and interest in foreign policy is smaller than it's been in the last 30 or 40 years," he said.
Ms. Mathews said the main difficulty for the policy research groups, a problem Ms. Albright also faces, is that "while there is general recognition that we're the indispensable nation, the question remains, 'Indispensable for what?' "
"But the one-answer answer isn't working, and without one answer in a sound-bite society, it's hard" to articulate a rationale without the cold war's military imperative, she said.
Starting as a science adviser to Congress with a Ph.D. in molecular biology, Ms. Mathews became director of issues and research in Morris Udall's 1976 presidential campaign, and then, at 30, created the Office of Global Issues in Zbigniew Brzezinski's National Security Council under President Jimmy Carter, where Mr. Armacost and Ms. Albright also served.
Her mother, the late historian Barbara Tuchman, pushed her to write -- "she said it's a muscle you need," Ms. Mathews remembered, "and a way to learn to write is through journalism." After President Carter's defeat, she wrote editorials for The Washington Post for three years, then helped found the World Resources Institute, one of the first research institutions to focus on the environment and Government policy. When she left 11 years later, its staff had grown from 3 to 110, and taught her about institution-building, fund-raising and promoting research that affects Government policy.
She left to enter the the Clinton Administration as Deputy Under Secretary on Global Affairs, but quit in frustration after nine months. The size of the bureaucracy, its traditional training and emphasis on crisis management made it hard to concentrate on global issues.
"It's the difference between a chronic illness and a severe one," she said. "In Government, you think it's all about the cables you read, and it's hard to see that things are happening that are beyond your control."
Increasingly, she argues, key actors are nongovernmental agencies or citizens' groups like Amnesty International and international institutions like the World Bank or the United Nations.
Other institutions, like the Heritage Foundation or the Cato Institute, continue to thrive on more ideological grounds. This use of ideas as weapons crafted for political wars by "combat intellectuals" -- rather than "nonideological tools to be employed by policy makers regardless of their political affiliation" -- was the focus of a valedictory essay by Charles William Maynes, after 17 years of running Foreign Policy, Carnegie's subsidized magazine.
The magazine's first issue under a new editor, Moises Naim, has just appeared, with shorter articles, summaries of key articles in foreign and foreign-language journals, more reviews of books published abroad, a new web site, and more photographs. While Carnegie has a large endowment, raising funds is increasingly important as some traditional givers, like the Pew Charitable Trust, have stopped financing foreign-policy projects.
Ms. Mathews also wants to address "this whole question of public attention to foreign policy, of which the shrinking pool of funds is a reflection." Polls show great public interest in foreign policy, "while there's a complete disconnect between the polls and Congress," which is more isolationist. "The problem is not the general public so much but Congress," she said. "We have to really think about this."
Brookings is also thinking about where to downsize. On the Middle East or arms control, "a lot of the conceptual work has been done," Mr. Haass said. "It needs to be implemented, but that's insider work." He has encouraged some scholars to go into Government or do field work to re-energize themselves and favors shorter-term appointments.
"I see Brookings as a place where you spend part of a career," he said. "Maybe people shouldn't spend 40 years at a think tank."

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS;
Ms. Brownstein And Mr. Dennin

 BODY:
Katherine Samantha Brownstein, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Edward Brownstein of Larchmont, N.Y., is to be married today to Peter Joseph Dennin, a son of Prof. and Mrs. Joseph Dennin of Trumbull, Conn. Rabbi Stephen Klein is to perform the ceremony at Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, N.Y.
The bride, 24, is a senior associate in the Boston office of Coopers & Lybrand, the accounting firm. She graduated from Union College in Schenectady, N.Y., and received an M.B.A. degree from Boston University. Her father is a professor of psychiatry and the chairman emeritus of the psychiatry department at New York Medical College in Valhalla, N.Y. Her mother, Vivian Brownstein, retired as the chief economist at Fortune magazine in New York.
The bridegroom, 26, is a securities compliance examiner in the Boston office of the Securities and Exchange Commission. He graduated from Georgetown University. His mother, Nancy Dennin, teaches mathematics at New Canaan (Conn.) High School. His father is a professor of math and computer science at Fairfield University in Fairfield, Conn.

HEADLINE: WESTCHESTER BRIEFS

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

 BODY:

Dual Infection Possible
For the first time, researchers at the Westchester County Medical Center in Valhalla have proved that a person can become ill with Lyme disease and ehrlichiosis simultaneously. Although the possibility of a dual occurrence had been suspected by doctors for several years, it had never been documented. The findings were published in the July 3 issue of the New England Journal of Medicine. 
 There were earlier instances in which patients were believed to be infected with both tick-borne illnesses, but the diagnoses were not considered definitive because they were based on blood tests, which can only suggest and not confirm dual exposure to the diseases.
The new findings should put residents of Westchester, Rockland, Putnam, Dutchess, Ulster, Orange, Suffolk and Fairfield Counties -- where the diseases are prevalent -- on the alert, doctors said.
It will also alter the prescribed medical treatment for the illnesses. For example, Lyme disease has often been treated with amoxicillin, which is not effective against ehrlichiosis. Now doxycycline is the recommended treatment for cases of dual infection.
In related news, Gov. George E. Pataki last week vetoed a bill proposed by the Action League for Lyme, based in Chappaqua. The bill would have expanded the governing committee of the State Department of Health's Tick-Borne Disease Institute to include Lyme victims, patient advocates, doctors, local health department officials and legislators.
The Governor said the bill was not consistent with his desire to streamline government. State Assemblyman Ronald C. Tocci of New Rochelle, a sponsor of the bill, said he would work to resubmit it
 
Layoffs Imminent
About 140 workers at the White Plains-based Tambrands are facing layoffs as early as this fall as a result of the company's recent merger with Procter & Gamble.
Scott Stewart, a spokesman for Procter & Gamble in Cincinnati, said the layoffs will occur now that the merger has been approved by regulators in several countries where Tambrands conducts business. The United States Justice Department had already authorized the $1.85 billion deal.
Most of the Tambrands employees in White Plains work in sales, marketing and financial services. Tambrands produces Tampax and has two manufacturing plants in this country -- in Claremont, N.H., and Auburn, Me. The company, which employs 2,600 workers worldwide, also operates plants in Britain, Ukraine and China.
Procter & Gamble markets some 300 brands, including Tide detergent, Crest toothpaste, Pampers disposable diapers, Ivory soap, Head and Shoulders shampoo and Bounty paper towels.
Mr. Stewart said the White Plains offices on Westchester Avenue would be closed. The company occupies about 76,000 square feet in the 128,000-square-foot building and has a lease until 2001, the spokesman said.
 
No Tuition Increases
County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke, has submitted his budget for Westchester Community College, and students at the two-year college can sigh with relief.
For the first time in seven years, there is no tuition increase scheduled for the coming year for full-time students who pay $2,350 a year, said the college's president, Joseph N. Hankin.
"We don't want to decrease access in any way to the college," Dr. Hankin said.
The proposed community college budget for 1997-98 is $48.6 million, with gross capital costs of $1.7 million. For the first time in four years, the college will add 10 new positions to meet the demand for expanded campus, student and computer services.
The student body is 58 percent female, 42 percent male and from "lower socio-economic backgrounds," Dr. Hankin said. The average age of a student is 29, he said.
"Many of the students are needy," he said. "We were afraid of approaching that point of discouraging them because the tuition kept going up."
 
Settlement in Blast
A settlement of $2.25 million has been reached in lawsuits resulting from a propane truck crash on Interstate 287 in 1994.
The defendants in the suit -- Ryder Truck Rental, which owned the truck, and Paraco Gas Corporation, which hired the driver -- reached the settlement with the plaintiffs -- 15 people living within 400 feet of the blast -- in the fifth day of a trial in State Supreme Court in White Plains.
Henry Miller, a lawyer representing 14 plaintiffs, said 2 of the plaintiffs, Edward and Michelle Brunner, testified in court about how the propane tank exploded, shot 300 feet in the air like a missile and landed in their bedroom.
Twelve other lawsuits have been settled out of court, but the terms were not disclosed.
Earlier this year, Paraco was fined $1 million by a Federal judge in Federal District Court in White Plains after the company admitted to falsifying records of drivers' hours. The company violated Federal safety regulations, which mandate periods of rest for truck operators.
Last year, the National Transportation Safety Board found that the accident occurred when Peter Conway, the 23-year-old driver, fell asleep at the wheel. Mr. Conway died in the explosion.
 
Golf Course Plans
The Briarcliff Manor Planning Board has taken its first formal look at a draft environmental impact statement submitted by Donald Trump to renovate and expand the 144-acre Briar Hall Country Club. The proposal before the board is to expand the course, rebuild the clubhouse and build 87 town houses.
Lynn M. Crumb, Briarcliff Manor's manager, said that although a previous owner of the property had obtained the village's approval to build 87 residences, some neighbors were upset that the houses would be near them. The previous plans called for 12 town houses and 75 housing units in a single building. Under Mr. Trump's plans, there would be 87 town houses.
Because of the lengthy review process, Mr. Crumb estimated it would be at least six months before Mr. Trump could put a shovel in the ground.
Mr. Trump also plans to build a golf course with surrounding houses on his Seven Springs Estate, which stradles the towns of New Castle, Bedford and North Castle, and the county is planning to build a golf course -- its sixth -- in New Castle. The course would be built on 150 acres off Route 134 to be bought from I.B.M. The course, Hudson Hills, would cost about $9.7 million, County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke said.
Two public hearings were held last week on the proposal. Interested citizens who missed the hearing can still obtain a copy of the executive summary of the draft environmental impact statement by calling the county Department of Planning at 285-4400.
 
How to Ride the Ferry
The Hudson Maritime Company, which runs a ferry service from Peekskill to Bear Mountain State Park and West Point from May through October, operates only on weekends.
Ferries depart from Peekskill's Riverfront Green Dock at 10:15 A.M. and 1 P.M., with the last trip returning to Peekskill at 3:45 P.M. Round-trip fares to West Point are $14, $7 for children. Round-trip fares to Bear Mountain are $12, $6 for children. Babies and toddlers ride free.
Capt. Gregory A. Hanchrow can arrange weekday trips for groups of 15 or more.
For more information, call 348-7788 at Mr. Hanchrow's Nyack office or visit the company's Web site at www.pojonews.com/hudsonmaritime. ELSA BRENNER

HEADLINE: The Nation;
Aging Shop of Horrors: The C.I.A. Limps to 50

BYLINE: By TIM WEINER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
ON July 26, 1947, with memories of the surprise attack on Pearl Harbor still fresh and fear of a cold war rising, President Harry S. Truman signed the law that gave birth to the Central Intelligence Agency. Fifty years on, the elite C.I.A. has become a pariah in American culture, a prisoner of its public history as a spy agency.
The evil that spooks do lives after them; the good is interred by secrecy. The agency insists that it has scored dazzling successes over the decades, but prefers not to discuss them. And so people remember the Mafia hit men hired to kill Fidel Castro, the coups gone bad, the rebel groups seduced and abandoned, the drunken scoundrel Aldrich Ames. 
 Now, in sadness and anger, several of the men who led the agency through the cold war are saying that the C.I.A.'s heart itself is failing, that its clandestine service to the nation may be nearing the end of its useful life.
The agency has been on a losing streak ever since it won the cold war. Its last two directors, R. James Woolsey Jr. and John M. Deutch, blamed "the culture of the C.I.A," which in victory lost its elan. Milt Bearden, the agency's last chief of Soviet operations, said in a recent interview, "The collapse of our enemy ensured our own demise."
"The only remaining superpower doesn't have enough interest in what's going on in the world to organize and run an espionage service," said Richard M. Helms, the Director of Central Intelligence from 1966 to 1973. "We've drifted away from that as a country."
James R. Schlesinger, Mr. Helms's successor, says, "The trust that was reposed in the C.I.A. has faded." The spy service "is now so battered that its utility for espionage is subject to question."
Retired Adm. Stansfield Turner, the agency's director from 1977 to 1981, says the nation has to build a new clandestine service from the ground up, outside the C.I.A. And Duane R. Clarridge, a legendarily brash covert operator, writes in a new memoir that the C.I.A. "is finished as a really effective intelligence service."
The Central Intelligence Agency, Mr. Clarridge writes, "will be reinvented or restored to competency only after some appalling catastrophe befalls us" -- perhaps another Pearl Harbor.
The Japanese attack was predictable. But no one had pulled the facts together. The idea of the C.I.A., Mr. Helms said, "was that we've got to get an organization where analysts could look at everything from overseas, no matter how secret. The agency was created to analyze intelligence, not for covert action. It was no one's intention that the Agency should become identified with nothing but espionage." That the Central Intelligence Agency became known for spying, he said, was "an accident of history."
In 1948, the year after the C.I.A.'s founding, another new agency, the National Security Council, set up a clandestine service to fight fire with fire -- to counter what it called the "vicious covert activities of the U.S.S.R." with propaganda, economic warfare, sabotage, subversion and secret support for resistance groups. There was nowhere to hide that secret organization but the newborn C.I.A.
The C.I.A.'s charter members -- "bankers and tycoons, safecrackers and forgers, printers and playwrights, athletes and circusmen," as a future director, William J. Casey, wrote -- were a talented crew forged in the fires of World War II. New recruits came from the nation's best universities. Soon there were thousands. Their power grew with the cold war.
 
Send in the Spooks
 President Dwight D. Eisenhower told them to launch coups in Iran and Guatemala. "These succeeded," Mr. Helms said. "They attracted a lot of attention. With the attention, the C.I.A. was identified with covert action," a tool of an imperial President in imperiled times.
The agency convinced President John F. Kennedy that covert operations were a cheap alternative to sending in the marines -- then refuted the argument with the disastrous Bay of Pigs invasion in 1961.
"Public support began to erode with the Bay of Pigs," Mr. Schlesinger said. So did a measure of Presidential support. President Lyndon B. Johnson never got over discovering the Kennedy-C.I.A.-Mafia plot to kill Castro. President Richard M. Nixon railed against the agency for failing to subvert the anti-war movement at home -- which would have been illegal. "What use are they?" he once asked. "They've got 40,000 people over there reading newspapers."
Throughout the 1960's, the C.I.A. briefed Gerald R. Ford, who was then a Congressman appropriating Pentagon funds. "They had charts on the walls, they had figures," President Ford recalled in a speech last month. "And their conclusion was that in 10 years, the United States would be behind the Soviet Union in military capability, in economic growth, in the strength of our economy. It was a scary presentation.
"The facts are," Mr. Ford continued, "they were 180 degrees wrong. These were the best people we had, the C.I.A.'s so-called experts."
In 1975, as Saigon fell, the C.I.A.'s own ramparts were breached by Congressional investigators who exposed the agency's relationships with foreign governments, generals and goon squads.
The investigations "set back our liaison relationships around the world; they caused many people abroad to pull away from cooperating with the C.I.A.; and they devastated the morale of perhaps the finest group of dedicated public servants this country has," President George Bush, the agency's director in 1976, said in a written response when asked about the C.I.A.'s performance during his tenure. By then, the last of the World War II generation of spies was out the door.
President Jimmy Carter, also in a written response, said there was never a hint of impropriety at the agency under his Naval Academy classmate, Admiral Turner, who cleaned house, canceled some long-running covert operations and started few new ones. "We were aware that some of the unqualified and incompetent personnel whom he discharged were deeply resentful," Mr. Carter said, "but I fully approved."
Then in the 1980's, Mr. Casey hired 2,000 new covert operators and revived the black arts of secret war. The revival ended with the indictments of the barons of the clandestine service. And while they were shipping missiles to the contras and to Iran, Mr. Ames, their Soviet counterintelligence branch chief, was smuggling secrets to the Russians.
Since 1991, the agency has had five directors; not one has lasted as long as two years. "We're a confused group, dying for stability," the agency's inspector general, Fred Hitz, said in a May speech. With the turnover at the top, those who remain worry about the brains and bravery of the new generation.
 
Too Many Yuppies
 The spy service no longer attracts America's best and brightest, Mr. Clarridge says. "I was saddled with an overabundance of yuppie spies," he writes. "For them, the C.I.A. was just a job."
The agency's chief analyst, John Gannon, recently spoke of its "lack of expertise." And in June, the House intelligence committee reported that the agency lacks "the analytic depth, breadth and expertise to monitor political, military and economic developments worldwide."
Mr. Helms's sense that American espionage is at the end of the line may seem like an epitaph. But as his biographer, Thomas Powers, put it, intelligence services are as inevitable as taxes and telephones. A nation with an army is going to have an intelligence agency. The question is what kind.
The agency may have to go back to its beginnings if it is to have much of a future. For in the beginning, the C.I.A. was going to be a small, sharp news service delivering hot tips and cool analysis to the President's desk, not the secret weapon of American foreign policy.
To succeed, Mr. Hitz says, the agency must focus on "five or six" targets, not a dozen, as it is doing, or a hundred, as it did a decade ago. The dirty half-dozen are easy to divine: the handful of heavily armed nations that might harm the United States. Mr. Helms says there are "too many people" and too much "bloat" in the clandestine service; a far smaller organization would be far sharper.
"The goals," Mr. Hitz said in May, "remain remarkably close to President Truman's original hopes for C.I.A. in 1947": to provide the President with "timely, focused intelligence information." That calls for exceptional people devoted to anonymous Government service -- and a revival of the cold-war spirit in a new generation.
Persuading a new generation to sign up with the C.I.A. will require restoring its reputation. There may be a way to do that: telling the public exactly how the agency helped win the cold war. But the C.I.A. has sworn to carry those secrets to the grave.

CORRECTION-DATE: October 30, 1998, Friday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Sept. 29 discussed the release of 60,000 secret documents on the killing of President John F. Kennedy. Their declassification occurred over a period, leading up to the final report of a citizens' commission created by Congress six years ago to dispel lingering suspicions that the truth had been hidden.
Discussing criticism of the Warren Commission, which investigated the assassination at the time, the article said that one member, Allen W. Dulles, a former Director of Central Intelligence, had failed to tell fellow members "that Kennedy had ordered the C.I.A. to assassinate Castro." The article did not cite evidence or authority for the assertion about the President.
 Earlier articles, on July 20, 1997, and Nov. 23, 1997, also declared without qualification that Kennedy ordered Fidel Castro's assassination.
A number of prominent historians and officials with knowledge of intelligence matters in that era have asserted in interviews that President Kennedy gave such an order. But others, also close to the President, dispute their account. The Times's practice is to attribute or qualify information that it is unable to report firsthand. That should have been done in these cases.

HEADLINE: LIVES;
A Holiday in Bali

BYLINE: By REBECCA CHACE; Rebecca Chae is the author of "Chautauqua Summer: Adventures of a Late-20th-Century Vaudevillian."

 BODY:
It is a spring evening in Bali. My husband and I are seated on cushions at a low table, sipping cold mango drinks. The sound of gamelan music is drifting toward us from one of the small lighted homes that seem almost suspended in the reflection of the still water of the rice paddies that stretch out in front of us. Our 5-year-old has long since passed out on the cushions, and the waiters come and go almost silently, avoiding her sprawl, with no expression of irritation.
 
 We are sitting with a group of American and British expatriates, who are passionately discussing the need to warn other Westerners of a spiritual teacher who they think is a charlatan. Well, of course he is, I'm thinking. What better place for a guru to set up shop than Bali? I don't say that out loud, however, because most of these people came to Bali in their late teens and early 20's to pursue spiritual disciplines and have ended up staying for 20 years. Instead I change the subject and ask about education for the children. One woman tells me that she sends her boys to the international school halfway down the island. That must be a long schelp, I say. Oh, no, she responds, I have a driver.
 That, in essense, is the definition of the expatriate community we found in Bali: baby-boomers, New Agers of a sort who are nonetheless living a completely 19th-century life style. Many of them have become entrepreneurs running small export and design companies. Because they can employ help both at home and at work for next to nothing, they are free to lead a life of contemplation, pursuing the Hindu or Buddhist teachings of simplicity, karma and transcendence of the material.
 Another woman I spoke to said she had always wanted a daughter in order to name her Sinead, a Gaelic name, but had only had sons. Then she went on: "So when the boys' Ama - she's been with us forever - had a girl, we named her Sinead." I was stunned "We?" I felt as if I were talking to Scarlett O'Hara. The catch was that this was not a young girl who had been brought up in the antebellum South, but a grown woman who had adopted this way of life rather than being born into it.
 It would be easy to say that I condemned them for this, or that they were well meaning but ultimately tyrannical. My dirty little secret is that I liked these people. They were smart and interesting. But as for having servants and never having to do any errand or chore that I didn't choose to do, I have to admit that for two weeks, I loved every minute of it. I was living the life of the idle rich for less than the cost of a room at a Best Western in Nebraska.
 We don't usually live like this. Even this two-week vacation took a year and a half to prepare for, and we might never have gone except that it was in honor of a good friend's 50th birthday. Our vacations tend to be done on frequent-flier miles to visit family, and the last time I went to Europe I was sleeping in a tent and sharing a van with five other people. (And that wasn't so long ago and I wasn't that young.)
 As I lay under the shade of a thatched bungalow near the beach innorthern Bali and received a full-body massage for an hour (for the equivalent of about $4), I did feel a little guilty, and very white. That was my problem - if it was indeed ever a problem - I couldn't live like a colonial in the Dutch East Indies without my good old American liberal guilt taking over. But I kept it at bay for as long as I could, and eyed the first-class cabin hungrily as I walked my daughter up and down the aisles on our 16-hour flight home. I remembered my father telling me that my grandfather's policy was always, "If we can't go first class, Jimmy, we don't go at all." Which of course meant that they never left town. But somewhere over Hawaii I thought he had had a pretty good point.
 When the pictures from our trip were developed, and I saw snapshots of us riding through the jungle on the back of an elephant like a family of self-satisfied pashas, I thought that it had been an incredible two weeks, but I also knew that I couldn't live in the Far East as my friends do. I wouldn't be able to close my ears to the overwhelming silence ofthe "help" who are waiting, endlessly waiting, for my next need to arise. It is a world of masters and servants, and despite one's best intentions it is not really possible to mold itinto something else. I assume that one would eventually stop trying and simplly attempt to be a good master.
 But while I was on vacation I behaved no differently than my colonialist friends; after I came back to my house in the States, with the dog, the shopping and the 5-year-old all competing for my time, I couldn't help asking my husband, with more than a touch of irony: Where are all the servants?

HEADLINE: Traffic Jam

BYLINE: By Kenneth T. Jackson; Kenneth T. Jackson, who teaches history at Columbia University, is the editor of "The Encyclopedia of New York City" and the author of "Crabgrass Frontier: The Suburbanization of the United States."

 BODY:

 ASPHALT NATION
 How the Automobile Took Over America, and How We Can Take It Back.
 By Jane Holtz Kay.
 Illustrated. 418 pp. New York:
 Crown Publishers. $27.50.
 
 THE CITY AFTER
 THE AUTOMOBILE
 An Architect's Vision.
 By Moshe Safdie with Wendy Kohn.
 Illustrated. 187 pp. New York:
 A New Republic Book/Basic Books. $24. 
 Americans, as all the world realizes, are peculiar. They own more cars and, paper coffee cups in hand, drive them farther than anyone else on the planet. Their town and city centers, especially after dark, are forlorn and quiet because most families shop, work and play on the urban edges, where free parking and well-maintained roads are expected as a kind of natural right. They set their houses far apart from one another, and in the middle of lawns that by the standards of other nations are gargantuan. They regard this suburban-style, automobile-dependent environment as, if not ideal, at least the inevitable result of a free people making free choices in a free market. Why, they think, would anyone want to live in a congested neighborhood when the alternative is a suburban Shangri-La?
 Moreover, the deconcentrated pattern of the United States seems to be in accord with the technological demands of the future and their possibilities. In recent years, such prominent authors as Paul Hawken, John Naisbitt and Alvin Toffler, among others, have created almost a cottage industry out of the prediction that a new science of telecommunications will make face-to-face interaction unnecessary in the 21st century. In their scenarios, automobiles are necessary; cities are not.
 To many observers, this is a vision of hell rather than of paradise, and at least since the publication of Jane Jacobs's "Death and Life of Great American Cities" in 1961, a series of authors has excoriated the drive-in, low-density character of the United States. Jane Holtz Kay's "Asphalt Nation" falls squarely within this tradition -- although it is more passionate and unforgiving than most of its predecessors. Essentially, Kay argues that unbridled, motorized sprawl has been destructive to our communities, destructive to our environment, destructive to our economic competitiveness and destructive to our safety. And that is just for starters.
 In her book's first section, "Car Glut: A Nation in Lifelock," Kay, the architecture critic for The Nation, reports that more driving does not mean more mobility because the number and length of trips needed for everyday life are increasing; that the elderly and the young, who are unable to drive, have been transformed into virtual prisoners; that the United States gives automobiles at least seven times the subsidies it earmarks for public transportation; that improvements in emission controls have been canceled out by an increase in miles driven; that salt used on ice and snow causes trees and vegetation to wither; and that Americans are fat because they drive rather than walk.
 The problem with tires is perhaps typical. Although most of us never think about the 250 million tires we collectively discard every year, one observer says: "You can't bury 'em. You can't put 'em in the water. No one will steal them. They're just there."
 Kay's second section, "Car Tracks: The Machine That Made the Land," explains how the automobile evolved from 1908, when Henry Ford introduced the Model T amid predictions that it would reduce pollution by replacing the horse, to 1954, when the United States became a net importer of oil, to the present, when Americans collectively spend eight billion hours each year stuck in traffic. The third section, "Car Free: From Dead End to Exit," points toward a future when, Kay hopes, the front porch, the corner grocery and pedestrian-friendly streets will be the norm rather than the exception.
 To her credit, Kay recognizes that the automobile is not the only culprit. She points out, for example, that Europeans have avoided many American problems not just because of high gasoline taxes and excellent public transportation systems but also because they regard land as a scarce resource to be controlled in the public interest rather than exploited by whoever happens to own it at a particular moment. Thus, European governments have traditionally exercised stringent controls over land development, and they have operated on the theory that the preservation of farms and open space is an appropriate national goal. In Dusseldorf, Germany, possibly the richest city in the world, truck farmers tend their crops within a couple of miles of the city's skyscrapers, not because alternative land uses would not yield a higher return, but because the law prohibits the very possibility of development.
 Although "Asphalt Nation" largely succeeds in proving that it is possible to get where we are going without destroying where we live, it does not offer a systematic argument, and it does not break new conceptual or methodological ground. Essentially, Kay has taken a hundred quotations and a hundred random statistics and cobbled them together into an attractive narrative package. The result is a well-written, even dramatic, volume that may persuade many readers to hop onto the bandwagon.
 One wishes, however, that Kay had more effectively anticipated and countered the likely questions of the 40-million-member American Automobile Association and the other powerful elements of the highway lobby. What do current gasoline taxes, meager as they are, pay for? Who should pay for the construction and repair of local roads that serve residential areas? If cars are becoming cleaner and more efficient over time, why will pollution not take care of itself? Who gets the bill for the uninsured motorists who cause the innocent to live out their days in wheelchairs? Are there many instances or places where motorists subsidize the general population, as is the case in New York, with its high bridge and tunnel tolls? If so, what has been the result? Why should a driver who never uses buses or subways contribute to their support? Does not the fact that Americans have purchased 250 million vehicles constitute a kind of referendum that government officials should respect? Kay has performed an important service in putting the issue of transportation before a potentially large audience, but she has only continued the debate, not taken it to a higher level.
 "The City After the Automobile," by Moshe Safdie, with Wendy Kohn, is a briefer and less ambitious volume that picks up where Kay leaves off. Safdie is an architect best known for Habitat, an attempt to revolutionize cities that was constructed for Montreal's Expo '67 (Kohn is the author of a monograph on his work), and like Kay, he proposes stronger land-use controls to restrict development on the urban edges. He points out, for example, that shopping malls are subsidized in hidden ways with public funds. Part of his book is an analysis of what has gone wrong with large agglomerations of people in the 20th century and part of it is a review of his plans -- some realized and some not -- for rebuilding sections of places as diverse as Las Vegas, Singapore, Israel and Italy.
 Safdie's most unusual suggestion is for the introduction of rentable electric automobiles, or "utility cars." Essentially, his idea is that while we need the convenience of private motor vehicles, they should be owned in common, and used by whoever needs them at a particular moment. Rather like taxis, except that we would drive them ourselves, they would be retrievable from storage depots and would be kept by a person or a family only as long as they are needed, with billing in accordance with time and mileage.
 Another of Safdie's ideas is for a "New Cardo," or "linear center," a mile-long place of maximum interaction that would become a public arena for concentrated development. This proposal is rather fanciful and not fully discussed, but it at least has the virtue of being a potential replacement for the ubiquitous shopping mall.
 Taken together, these books deliver an important message in suggesting that the solution to congestion, to environmental pollution and to urban decay is not more cars and wider roads but more effective planning and more responsive public transportation. As Jane Holtz Kay concludes: "We are not only stuck in traffic, we are stuck in spending money that promotes more of the same. By underpricing and oversubsidizing the automobile, the highway and sprawl, we have made this life style the overwhelming option and diminished the alternatives."
