HEADLINE: At Long Last, Greece and Turkey Tiptoe Toward Reconciliation

BYLINE: By CELESTINE BOHLEN 

DATELINE: ATHENS, July 18

 BODY:
By itself, the joint communique signed by Greece and Turkey at the recent NATO summit in Madrid amounts to a series of platitudes, including promises not to use force against each other and to observe existing treaties.
But in the context of a feverish relationship that had taken a turn for the worse in recent years, such language is being read as a breakthrough of sorts. According to Greek and foreign analysts, it may even be the start of a new discussion between countries whose history of mutual hostility has been one of NATO's most troublesome problems. 
 "It is substantial progress, because it allows us to meet," Greece's Foreign Minister, Theodoros Pangalos, said in an interview here. "It is the first signal of hope."
The communique, brokered by the United States and signed July 8 by Prime Minister Costas Simitis of Greece and President Suleyman Demirel of Turkey, comes a year and a half after the two nations seemed close to war over a couple of rocky islets in the eastern Aegean Sea, a few miles from the Turkish coast.
Those islets -- known as Imia to the Greeks and Kardak to the Turks -- are still in dispute, and the list of issues that divide Greece and Turkey is as long as ever, including the divided island of Cyprus and Greece's right to extend its continental shelf 12 miles into the Aegean Sea. Behind those questions lurk enmities that date back centuries, to the days when the Ottoman Turks occupied Greece.
But the Madrid communique did succeed in blunting the issue of the 12-mile limit, which Turkey no longer regards as a possible "cause for war."
As for the age-old animosities, there are Greek officials who will now openly discuss what was once unthinkable -- namely the cultural affinities that bind Turks and Greeks, despite the history that has divided them.
"Ironically, many people feel that Greece and Turkey could have common ground, notwithstanding their historical enmity," a foreign diplomat said. "Greece has had a terrible historical experience with Turkey, but they don't have any feelings of cultural or racial superiority."
For several months, there have been hints that the overheated atmosphere surrounding the Aegean crisis was beginning to cool. In Turkey, attention has centered on a domestic political drama, which ended this month with the collapse of the Government headed by Necmettin Erbakan, leader of a pro-Islamic party. He was replaced as Prime Minister by Mesut Yilmaz, leader of a center-right party with strong secularist and pro-European traditions.
Here in Greece, Mr. Simitis, the low-key successor to the flamboyantly combative Andreas Papandreou, has given Greek foreign policy a calmer tone, with a new stress on international cooperation.
"You have a mood that is different here, and that is really important," a foreign diplomat said. "There is a resolve to solve problems."
Since the death of Mr. Papandreou a year ago and Mr. Simitis's election, the new Government has made significant progress in improving its image and its relations with neighbors and allies.
It is still negotiating with the former Yugoslav republic of Macedonia over the legal name for that country, but the nationalist fervor that once fed opposition to any sharing of the Macedonian name has virtually vanished.
"I want to get rid of this problem," Mr. Pangalos said, "because there is no substance to it."
The new tone has also spread to Greek-Turkish relations, which for Athens more than for Ankara, remains the top diplomatic priority.
A year ago, Mr. Pangalos was calling the Turks "international criminals" who lie like "fascists and Stalinists." Now, Mr. Pangalos talks of a future when, if certain conditions are met, Turkey will be "a very important partner" for Greece, and Greece will no longer provide camouflage for misgivings among other Europeans about letting Turkey into the European Union.
"There are other countries in the European Union that have other problems with Turkey and who are hiding behind my back," said Mr. Pangalos, pointing to his ample girth. "I have a big back, as you can see, but it can't cover all that crowd. I want them to come out and say what are the difficulties they have with Turkey, because they do have difficulties that are much more substantial than Greece has."
It was Mr. Pangalos who in March defended Turkey's "European vocation" after a group of European Christian Democrats issued a statement challenging the idea that a mostly Muslim country straddling the divide between Europe and Asia could be a valid candidate for membership in the European Union.
"I cannot accept this approach," Mr. Pangalos said. "Turkey is very much part of European history, and Islam is already part of Europe. The conditions for membership should be uniform, and based on whether a country meets the economic, social and political conditions required."
To its dismay, Turkey was not on the list of six countries recommended for European Union membership issued this week by the European Commission. But many analysts have concluded that in softening its position toward Greece, Turkey -- in particular the new Yilmaz Government -- has signaled a long-term diplomatic effort to win support in Europe.
Still, given the difficulties, few analysts expect quick results from the Madrid communique.
"We didn't solve any problems in Madrid," Mr. Pangalos said. "We established a framework to try to find ways to solve them. Maybe it will take 1, 2, 3 or 10 years. I don't know, but I suspect it will be a long process."

HEADLINE: Reporter's Notebook;
Republican Shows Flair for Lead Role in Inquiry

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 20

 BODY:
As he sits and gently rocks at his committee chairman's post, Fred Thompson, the movie actor who became a senator and is now chief of the inquiry into campaign abuses, seems to be polishing the role of the avuncular partisan, the country sheriff with as sharp a sense of politics as of mission.
"Well, we're going to have an opportunity to have a little bipartisanship here right now," Mr. Thompson, Republican of Tennessee, announced last week in his rich baritone, stressing the line for its irony midway through the monthlong session of initial hearings. 
 A grin creased Mr. Thompson's usual expression of gruff courtliness, in recognition that bipartisanship is about as likely as a round of moonshine-sipping at the combative hearings of the Governmental Affairs Committee.
Handicapped by sparse television coverage, the Senator has had to develop his role before the inquiry's daily attendees, who look forward to his unscripted asides. These are often provoked by his designated nemesis, Senator John Glenn of Ohio, the ranking Democrat, who is getting rave reviews from his own party for peppering the proceedings with earnestly intoned objections. ("We're not just being fair and objective about this thing, Mr. Chairman.")
But the chairman is the chief player. Mr. Thompson's allegation of a brazen and illegal Chinese plot to buy into American politics promises to carry him toward the millennial Presidential race. But it is his more impassioned ad-libs that the audience savors. In these, the Senator seems braced by the inquiry's relentlessly partisan gamesmanship, and in fervid moments, he orates in a kind of senatorial Stengelese.
"I'm sure," Mr. Thompson said in one riposte to Mr. Glenn, "we will not get diverted down rabbit trails about concocting the most elaborate and sinister possible motive and because people who wag records over to some commercial person's office to brief them on because they don't know anything that went on wrong, that we should not be allowed to make ourselves -- to avail ourselves -- of all information that is available to us. And that's what we've done."
 
Seeking Testimony of Nuns
With the hearings devoid of telegenic moments, Republicans are aching to overcome an immunity dispute with the Justice Department so they can bring before the public four Buddhist nuns connected to a temple fund-raiser that Vice President Al Gore attended last year. The event, which involved John Huang, the zealous money-raiser for President Clinton and the center of Mr. Thompson's inquiry, can only embarrass the Democrats further if the committee hears testimony from the nuns, who were listed for $5,000 party contributions despite vows of poverty.
Michael J. Madigan, the committee's chief counsel, talked tantalizingly of having already deposed one of the nuns and finding out all about the temple fund-raiser from a most convincing witness. "The little nun herself," Mr. Madigan said, yearning to put her before the panel, "she's very, uh, she's very -- she's about 4-foot-10 and about 80, 90 pounds."
Nervous laughter rippled forward as Mr. Thompson rushed to keep his counsel within the bounds of political correctness. "Be careful, Mr. Madigan," he said. "Be careful."
 
An Eye-Catching Exhibit
Even as the Republicans try to target President Clinton, a politician who has already won his last big race, the subtext of the hearings burbles with mentions of Vice President Gore, a fellow Tennessean who could conceivably face off against Mr. Thompson in the next Presidential election. Thus the gleam in some Republican eyes when Exhibit 125 was introduced.
This was a letter to the Vice President's chief of staff, Jack Quinn, from Mr. Huang in 1993, when he worked in Los Angeles for the Riady family in their Lippo empire, which has business ties to the Chinese Government. He thanked Mr. Quinn for receiving him and Shen Jueren, chairman of China Resources, the commercial wing of the Chinese Government. "Vice President Gore was just super," Mr. Huang said in his letter, referring to another meeting three days later in Los Angeles.
Committee Republicans had that to-be-continued look.
 
Gingerly Defending Huang
The hardest task for committee Democrats has been to press for weaknesses in the Republican charge that Mr. Huang was an economic spy for foreign interests yet not come off as his partisan defense lawyers. Mr. Clinton's advice to the Democratic National Committee to hire Mr. Huang as a fund-raiser is now seen as a notoriously bad recommendation -- the committee has had to return half of the $3 million he raised for the President. The Democrats would rather take Mr. Huang for a fool than a spy.
"If he was a spy, if he was compromising our national security, isn't it curious that he would not only leave a paper trail, but a paper freeway of thousands of documents?" asked Richard J. Durbin, Democrat of Illinois, citing voluminous committee exhibits.
Republicans focused suspicion on the fact that Mr. Huang, as a Commerce Department official, was in touch with the Chinese Embassy. But Mr. Durbin countered that this had been a reasonable part of Mr. Huang's department rounds and that he had openly put taxi rides to and from the embassy on his Government expense account. "This man, if he'd taken the time to read one John LeCarre book, would not have done some of the things that you're alleging he's done," Mr. Durbin said.
 
Outrage Over Absentees
For all the Democrats' gloating about the paucity of hard evidence of fresh scandal so far, there is no way they can avoid Republicans' complaints that any weakness in the hearings is rooted in the absence of crucial witnesses who richly supported Mr. Clinton's re-election and were once honored in his presence. These include Mr. Huang, who is seeking at least partial immunity from criminal prosecution; the Riadys, whose ties to Mr. Clinton go back to his days as Governor of Arkansas, and a half-dozen other big-money supporters who are reported to be in Asia and elsewhere and have shown no inclination to testify.
"If Ms. Kanchanalak and Mr. Hubbell and Mr. Middleton and a few others weren't either hiding somewhere outside this country or taking the Fifth Amendment, we might have more amplification," Senator Robert C. Smith, Republican of New Hampshire, told the Democrats, citing a few of the missing figures, Pauline Kanchanalak, Webster L. Hubbell and Mark E. Middleton.
Democrats took care to concede the point on the record. One, Senator Robert G. Torricelli of New Jersey, said: "Whatever outrage we have felt about other issues or differences does not begin to compare with our outrage with people who have escaped the subpoenas of this committee or continue to avoid participating and cooperating."
 
More Rehearsing Needed
In the inquiry spotlight, the unrehearsed words of committee members can go awry. On opening day, Senator Sam Brownback, Republican of Kansas, could be seen silently practicing some phrases and gestures of emphasis for his initial speech, which he delivered forcefully. Later, however, when questioning a witness about Mr. Huang's bonus arrangement in fund-raising for the Democrats, Mr. Brownback said, "No raise money, no get bonus." A sudden hush was discernible in parts of the audience, and just as suddenly, Mr. Brownback, wary of intimations of an ethnic slur, said, "No slight by my statement previously."

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Indonesian Balancing Act

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

DATELINE: JAKARTA, Indonesia

 BODY:
When all is said and done the Clinton foreign policy is going to be judged very heavily by how well it manages the two great historical transitions now under way: the decline of Russia and the rise of China. For now, Russia's decline is going relatively well (thanks to Boris), but the rise of China is another matter. It's critical that China's rise at the close of this century be handled better than Japan's rise at the start of this century, since Japan's emergence as a powerhouse led to three wars in Asia.
But there's no way the U.S. can manage the rise of China alone, or even with Japan. And that brings me to Indonesia. Indonesia has played one of the most important, but least understood, roles in managing China's rise. This is not only because with its 200 million people Indonesia is second only to China in weight in Southeast Asia, but also because Indonesia is the keystone of the Association of South East Asian Nations (Asean). Asean isn't NATO or the E.U., but it does a pretty fair imitation of both. 
 And Asean, which next week celebrates its 30th anniversary, would never have been created without Indonesia and without the policy President Suharto initiated when he took power from President Sukarno in 1965. Mr. Sukarno believed in an Indonesia that bullied its neighbors, sparking constant disputes. Mr. Suharto preferred to do business with them instead, while focusing on Indonesia's internal development. So he formed Asean, as an economic-trade association, comprising Indonesia, Malaysia, Singapore, the Philippines, Thailand and Brunei, and he transformed Indonesia's foreign policy from bully to gentle giant. Indonesia today has a defense budget two-thirds that of tiny Singapore.
"Ever since Asean was formed this region has entered into an unprecedented period of stability and economic growth," Indonesia's Foreign Minister, Ali Alatas, said to me. "And I think it's not too much to say that Asean was formed because of Indonesia -- because a new Government came in which renounced the earlier policy of throwing our weight around."
Asean was also a de facto security alliance, designed originally to block Communism from Hanoi. But in the last decade Asean quietly shifted from balancing North Vietnam to balancing China (and Japan). That transition was formalized last year when Vietnam -- the most powerful and historically anti-Chinese force in Southeast Asia -- was added to Asean. This year Asean is adding the remaining loose pawns on the chess board before they fall too heavily under China's sway, namely Burma, Laos and Cambodia (if it gets its house in order).
China's Asia strategy is to deal with everyone bilaterally so that China's weight can be used to maximum advantage. This is particularly true when pressing China's claims to oil fields in the South China Sea that are also claimed by Asean members. But Asean, by using solidarity as a substitute for military power, has forced China to deal with its members as a group. So when the Philippines found itself in a dispute with China over the oil-rich Mischief Reef, Asean stood behind the Philippines and swayed China into a dialogue on the issue. It helps too that Asean nations are among the biggest investors in China.
"Although strategically Asean is not a cohesive military entity, China cannot challenge any one of these states without having a problem with all of them," said Juwono Sudarsono, Indonesia's leading strategic analyst. "And, as long as China's internal economic problem is so massive, it can't just assert its military might unilaterally. It needs the good will and investment of its neighbors" -- particularly Indonesia, which controls the straits through which a growing China will soon have to import tons of oil from the Middle East.
With Asean, Japan and the U.S. Seventh Fleet each balancing China in its own way, the world stands a much better chance of seeing an emerging China that settles regional disputes through dialogue, not force.
But there's no Asean without Indonesia. The U.S. has some real problems with Indonesia today on labor and human rights. America cannot ignore Indonesia's abuses. But they also can't be the only lens through which Indonesia is judged. The best U.S. policy here would be one that carefully targets -- and when necessary sanctions -- specific Indonesian domestic abuses, while also supporting Indonesian foreign policies that have contributed so heavily to stability in this region. Without an effective Indonesia policy, the U.S. will never have an effective China policy.

HEADLINE: PRO FOOTBALL;
For Giants, Offensive Line Is Still Evolving

BYLINE: By BILL PENNINGTON 

DATELINE: ALBANY, July 20

 BODY:
One of the first things Jim Fassel did after he was hired to coach the Giants was watch a hit horror film.
It was a compilation of all the 1996 sacks and knockdowns of quarterback Dave Brown. 
 "It was brutal," Fassel said. "People have been talking to me about what I can do to make Dave a better quarterback. The biggest thing I can do is get him better protection."
So if keeping the quarterback upright is such a priority, then why is the makeup of the Giants' offensive line still a mystery?
A piece of the offensive line puzzle may fall into place Monday, when Lance Smith, an unrestricted free agent who started at left guard last season, may report to camp. People familiar with contract negotiations between Smith and the Giants said today that an understanding between them was nearly complete. Smith's arrival would hardly resolve the offensive line picture, but it would certainly give Fassel more options.
For Smith, 34, the first assignment would be winning back his starting spot. In his absence, Fassel has promoted Roman Oben, a second-year player with limited pro experience, to left tackle and moved Greg Bishop, who started at left tackle last season, back to his more natural position of left guard, where he played in 1995.
The picture will get more confused when Smith returns and Bishop begins competing simultaneously with Oben at tackle and Smith at guard.
The resolution could rest on Oben, who, except for a handful of plays, has played only on the Giants' field-goal team.
If he can do a dependable job at left tackle, then Smith, a 12-year veteran, could play guard and Bishop could back up both. If Bishop wins the spot at left guard, the Giants will be overloaded with linemen, including Rob Zatechka and Jerry Reynolds.
But starting Oben would be a big gamble for the Giants. Brown was the most-sacked quarterback in the National Football League last season, in part because Bishop -- protecting the quarterback's blind side -- was often beaten by speedy pass rushers. Can the Giants afford to place Brown's health and well-being on the limited experience of the 24-year-old Oben, who has played in two games?
 "I would be comfortable going into the season with Roman at left tackle," Fassel said. "He's looked great in camp so far."
The Giants like Oben's quick feet, an asset in pass blocking. Although he is 6 feet 4 inches and 310 pounds, he somehow appears compact and less bulky than his massive contemporaries on the offensive line. A star at Louisville, where he earned a degree in economics, Oben might have been rated a first-round pick had he been drafted after his junior season, when he excelled. Some pro scouts considered Oben's senior season disappointing.
When left tackle Jumbo Elliott left the Giants for the Jets, Oben became a natural choice to replace him.
"It's an opportunity for me," Oben said today between practice sessions on the SUNY-Albany campus. "Lance Smith is a good player, and I want to see him back.
"But I have to know that this is my chance to get better."
Oben's responsibilities may be easier than Bishop's were a year ago. Watching the Giants practice this weekend, it has become obvious that Fassel's offense plans to limit Brown's time in the pocket. Fassel relies on quick passes and short drops and, at times, he seems eager to move Brown away from potential pass-rushing pressure.
This is good news for Oben, not to mention Brown.
"Dave just can't be expected to take the pounding he has and still perform," Fassel said. "That has to change."

EXTRA POINTS
Linebacker MARCUS BUCKLEY sprained his left ankle in Sunday's afternoon practice; the rookie tight end BRANDON JESSIE partially dislocated his left shoulder, and cornerback MARC WILLIAMS strained his right hamstring. Punter BRAD MAYNARD, who sat out the morning practice with a sore left hamstring, resumed punting in the afternoon.

HEADLINE: Beijing Journal;
America the Beautiful? (A Rare Rave)

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER 

DATELINE: BEIJING, July 19

 BODY:
At a time when many of the best-selling books in China promote the idea of standing up to America or other forms of chest-thumping to herald China's rise as a great power, one author has returned from a long sojourn in the United States to testify that it is a fairly normal place, a land of great opportunity, deliciously free and full of "real people."
Qian Ning's "Studying in America" is not a sentimental paean, but an objective chronicle of the lives of Chinese students who have become a significant presence on almost every university campus in the nation that is known in Chinese as "Meiguo," or "beautiful country." 
 "My first impression when I arrived in Ann Arbor was the singing, the laughter and the smell of barbecue at parties on the campus I saw that evening," wrote Mr. Qian of his first day at the University of Michigan. It was August 1989, just weeks after he had witnessed the large pro-democracy demonstrations at Tiananmen Square and the military crackdown that led to the massacre of hundreds of unarmed students and workers by Chinese troops.
"This world in front of my eyes was so different from the world on Tiananmen Square, that it was impossible to connect them together in my mind," he continued. "But at that moment, I understood a simple thing. We Chinese -- at least the younger generation of Chinese -- can have a different kind of life, free from the repetitious political movements in the past and life-and-death struggles."
No one would call Mr. Qian a political dissident or firebrand. In simple and elegant terms, much the same as those used by Alexis de Tocqueville to describe the early United States to Europeans, the 37-year-old Mr. Qian seems to undermine the rancorous literature of Chinese nationalism.
Having left China troubled and confused eight years ago, he described the United States he found and the Chinese he encountered there. Among them was a visiting scholar who was having difficulty coping with freedom after years of regimented life in China. "Here nobody controls you, but nobody cares about you," he told Mr. Qian.
There are stories of Chinese who became millionaires in the United States but who are still haunted by the persecutions they suffered in China under Mao, and there are stories of those who failed to assimilate or struggled against the anxiety, insecurity and deprivation of an immigrant class.
One student in economics arrived from China on a one-year scholarship and described his "sense of being an elite." Initially sought out by his American colleagues to lecture on the Chinese economy at university seminars, he discovered a different side of life in a capitalist society when he had to find a way to support himself.
"When his scholarship ran out, he found out how miserable and tiny he was," Mr. Qian writes. The visiting scholar took a job in a restaurant cutting up chickens into breasts, legs and wings and "all his elite sense was lost."
Mr. Qian's book, which was published last winter, is exceptional not only because it offers millions of Chinese readers an objective antidote to the nationalistic streak that has infected Chinese literature, but also because it carries the authority of Mr. Qian's family background. He is the son of Qian Qichen, who is China's Foreign Minister and a Deputy Prime Minister.
Like many of the 250,000 students -- China's best and brightest -- who have traveled to the United States in the last two decades, the younger Mr. Qian experienced the metamorphosis of a child who grew up during China's most turbulent decade -- the 1966-76 Cultural Revolution -- only to discover a different reality outside China.
"Chinese students who went to America had simple but firm beliefs that their leaders should control the people," he said. "We thought that the values and standards in our society were only natural and absolute. It was only when we got into another society that we realized the limitation of our own ideology.
"My impression after arriving in the United States was, 'Wow, who would have thought that a man could live this way!' "
With books like "China Can Say No," and "The Demonization of China," the state-controlled publishing industry and a number of opportunistic authors, most of whom have never visited the United States, have attempted to cash in on popular sentiments and Communist Party pronouncements that the United States, Britain and the West in general are seeking to "contain" or restrain China's emergence on the world stage.
Mr. Qian's writing rejects this view of the United States in favor of a more empirical study of how Chinese students have been discovering the land they have read so much about since Deng Xiaoping, the late paramount leader of China, picked America as the country that was essential to China's modernization.
Sipping coffee in a hotel lobby in Beijing, to which he returned in 1995 to become a consultant to the American accounting firm Coopers & Lybrand, Mr. Qian explained his view of the complicated state of relations between China and the United States.
"I think that in China, as well as in America, there is a gap between what the politicians say about each others' country, and what the people think," he said. "I would have to say that when you look at a newspaper here, maybe you will find a lot of criticism of one thing or another about the West, but people here do not take it very seriously; they know this is the official culture. When you look at China -- or America -- what is more important is the real of life of the people."
Most Chinese, he said, do not share the critical view of the United States that is expounded by Communist Party propagandists. And he does not believe that Chinese and Western civilizations are fated to clash.
"I don't go along with this theory," he said. "A lot of Chinese in the United States have adapted to the American life style without much effort. I think the trouble is caused by ideology. It is not really cultures that are clashing, it is ideology that is clashing, or politics, and that is understandable."
Still, Mr. Qian says that the average Chinese has done more to try to understand the United States than the average American has done to understand China.
"We are at a different stage of development," he said, and therefore many Chinese look to the United States as a role model for China's modernization.
"Maybe we can avoid some of the mistakes that America has made, but very few Americans really get a chance to learn a lot about China," he said.
Mr. Qian returned to China flush with optimism that he can contribute to China's transformation to something better by working for its economic development.
He avoids the political implications of this goal, but the subtext of what he says is a powerful message to China's leaders that the coming generation has already rejected the ideology of their elders and that freedom, much more of it than now exists, is high on its agenda.

HEADLINE: Get Along Little Dogie #384-591E

BYLINE: By KATE MURPHY 

 BODY:
Working cattle at the Decatur County Feedyard in Oberlin, Kan., has always been a complex craft. But there was a simplicity to some jobs, like inoculations. "We used to hold them in the shoot, give them their vaccination and then kick them out," explained the head cowboy, James L. Fortin.
Today things are different. Using a large variety of electronic equipment, Mr. Fortin now takes detailed records identifying each animal and collecting data about its size and health, to determine the amount of food and medicine it needs. "They call me the ultrasound man, now," Mr. Fortin said. 
 Technology is transforming the cattle and dairy industries. Competitive pressures, high feed costs and the demand for prime, specialty beef have forced more farmers and ranchers to drive their herds into the electronic frontier.
Cowboy gear may now include electronic scanners along with the more predictable ropes, chaps and pocket knives. The scanners collect identifying data from the electronic ear tags that, when downloaded into laptop computers, automatically calls up each cow's family and medical history.
A slightly different sort of scanner is also mounted on the doors of dairy barns to read which cows come in to be milked. "The technology allows tracking," from calf to carcass, "which is the first step toward herd improvement," said David C. Warren, president of Allflex USA Inc., a privately held Dallas manufacturer of electronic animal identification devices.
None of the experts in cattlemen's professional organizations, Federal or state agencies or universities can say for sure how many of the nation's 87.8 million beef cattle and 9.3 million dairy cows are raised with electronic aids. But technology is clearly making inroads in a business whose reliance on physical skill and intuition have made it a metaphor for the American experience.
Still, whatever the folklore surrounding them, cattle are a business proposition. Tracking them through their lives to determine how to produce the food Americans want is crucial to improving profit margins. Historical information can explain why one animal in a herd fetched top dollar for its prime cuts while another ended up as ground chuck -- or why one cow yields butterfat-rich milk while another does not.
The results can mean as much as a $300 difference in the value of an animal. On average -- and the averages reflect significant annual fluctuations in price -- a single head of cattle, which usually weighs between 1,000 and 1,300 pounds, now sells for 64 cents a pound, according to Cattle Fax Inc., a private research company based in Englewood, Colo.
"There are so many things, from genetics to type of feed, that can make a difference," said Warren Weibert, owner and general manager of the Decatur County Feedyard, one of the most technologically sophisticated agricultural operations in the country.
Mr. Weibert's yard fattens 24,000 cattle for slaughter every six months. For the last three years, he has electronically tagged 15,000 to identify what factors contribute to production of the uniform, high-quality product that meat processors seek.
Raising cattle to suit the market's taste has become more crucial since Americans have become increasingly health conscious, looking askance at everything from whole milk to hamburger. But even though overall meat consumption has declined in the last decade, demand for prime grade cuts has risen.
"Cattle producers' goal nowadays is to come up with those higher grades that consumers have demonstrated they will pay higher prices for," said Chuck Lambert, chief economist with the National Cattlemen's Beef Association in Washington, D.C. The cattle industry generated $50 billion in retail sales last year.
Decatur is one of a handful of feedlots in the United States that has installed $150,000 to $250,000 systems like Amarillo, Tex.-based Micro Chemical Inc.'s Accu-Trac to electronically monitor their cattle. In fact, according to Rod Fee, the livestock editor of Successful Farming, buying such a system makes sense only if an operation's herd exceeds 15,000 head.
Central to the system are electronic ear tags that trip sensors that record how often and how much animals eat. An electronic tag cost $10; the hand-held scanners, between $3,400 and $4,000.
Veterinarians scan the tags to chronicle the immunizations and medicines they administer. Computerized scales and electronic eyes track cows' weight and height. Feedlot owners -- who buy 500-pound calves from the "cow-calf" operations and sell mature animals to the slaughterhouses -- create digitized ultrasonic images of cattle to determine leanness and marbling of their meat.
"You can imagine how helpful that can be when the price of feed hits the ceiling like it did last year," Mr. Fee said. "If the ultrasound picks up a lot of excess fat, you know that animal's getting too much feed."
Mr. Weibert said his profits rose an average $20 for each electronically monitored head last year, compared with the previous year.
In addition to helping with management decisions at the feedlot level, electronic monitoring makes it possible to inform the million or so cattle operations that supply the country's approximately 39,000 feedlots about the animals they breed. "They get back that final carcass data and can make some genetic corrections," said Walter Koers, president of Koers Turgeon Consulting Services Inc., a consulting firm in Salina, Kan.
In the past, those running the farms where calves are born and raised -- before feedlots get them -- had little idea what kind of beef their animals produced. "Getting that information is the key to breeding better animals," Mr. Koers said.
"We're moving closer to making electronic tagging a requirement because of the ability to track cows all the way back to the beginning," said William C. Wagner, who runs veterinary medicine programs at the Department of Agriculture's Cooperative Extension Service in Washington. Such records could help combat outbreaks of disease.
Electronic monitoring is already common in the $22.8 billion dairy industry. Electronic sensors are a standard feature on milking equipment. The sensor notes when tagged cows enter the milking parlor and hitch up to a machine. As the milk begins to flow, sensors on the milking machines record how much milk a cow produces, its fat content and the milk's white blood cell count -- a clue to the animal's health.
A third of all dairy farmers send this information by modem to a data base in Beltsville, Md., operated by the Department of Agriculture's Dairy Herd Improvement Association. The data are compiled and analyzed there, with the results returned to farmers.
Another sensor, implanted in a cow's hindquarters, alerts farmers when the cow allows other cows to mount her -- signaling the start of her 6- to 12-hour period of maximum fertility. Milk production is initiated by hormonal changes, so "You can't milk if you don't calf," said David Forgey, who owns and operates a 112-head dairy farm in Logansport, Ind.
For the last year, he has used Heatwatch sensors manufactured by DDx Inc. of Denver, which have improved his reproduction rate and consequent milking yield by 25 percent. The basic system costs $3,000; the sensors are $55 apiece.
The majority of the 250 or more companies creating software that run such systems are small businesses started by farmers who either gave up or had their farms foreclosed during the downturns in the volatile business.
"I got squeezed out so I got into software," said Norman Teegardin, a former grain farmer who now owns CTN Data Service Inc., which manufacturers FarmWorks livestock and crop management software in Hamilton, Ind. University based agriculture extension services also sell software like the University of Minnesota's popular DairyChamp program.
But there are no dominant players in this category yet, said Darrin Drollinger, general manager of the Agricultural Electronic Association, a Chicago-based trade group. "There are definitely no Microsofts," he said. That's because the market remains, for the most part, resistant to change, according to Bill Turner, professor of beef cattle science at Texas A & M University in College Station, Tex.
"For old boys running cows out on the range, high technology is a pickup truck," Mr. Turner said.

GRAPHIC: Photo (Allied Press)
 
Chart: "High Tech Down on the Farm"
About 4.5 million of the nation's 9.3 million dairy cows -- and their milk -- are monitored electronically, with the data analyzed by the Dairy Herd Improvement Association. Now, electronic monitoring is coming to beef cattle, as ranchers seek to improve meat quality. Here are a few examples from both.
 
Electronic Branding
A tag attached to a cow's ear identifies it throughout its life.
 
Weight
The cattle can be weighed before and after feeding, to tell if it is getting too fat or too thin.
 
Height
Sensors can be placed at barn doorways identifying the cattle by their tags and measuring their height.
 
Eating
Food in the trough can be weighed before and after feeding to track how much is consumed.
 
Slaughter
Before cattle are slaughtered, their ear tags can be scanned again. The ranchers who raised the animals can check on which animals yielded the highest quality beef.
 
Health
By scanning the ear tag on a sick cow, veterinarians can gain access to its medical history.
 
Dairy
Before dairy cows give milk, their tags can be scanned. The milk can then be analyzed; total output and nutritional content are recorded.

SECTION: Section B; Page 1; Column 2; Metropolitan Desk

HEADLINE: With Times Square Reborn, Attention Turns to Coney Island

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN 

 BODY:
Inspired by the success of efforts to redevelop Times Square, private investors and state officials are now turning their attention to another long-neglected part of New York City: Coney Island.
The efforts have gained new momentum in recent weeks because Bruce C. Ratner, a developer with a proven track record in several large projects, has shown interest in Coney Island. Mr. Ratner's most notable project so far is the Metrotech office complex, which has been credited with reviving downtown Brooklyn. 
 Coney Island, perhaps more than any other address in New York, most approaches the historical flamboyance and cachet of Times Square -- and still retains a mythic reputation as a land of roller coasters, snake handlers and other amusements. But the reality is much grimmer: The amusement area has shrunk to 3 blocks in length from 20 blocks in the 1940's, and much of the land abandoned by amusements lies vacant.
Mr. Ratner's proposal, which involves a private investment of $100 million, is to link a new multiplex theater and virtual-reality amusement park with a decade-old plan for an amateur sports center that would be built with money from state bonds.
For Mr. Ratner's proposal to go forward, he would have to acquire the land from the city, which now owns it. The plan must also pass environmental and zoning reviews, a process that could take several years. But state officials said they believed that Mr. Ratner's proposal complied with zoning rules for the Coney Island area.
Mr. Ratner has refused to comment publicly on his proposal. But Charles A. Gargano, the chairman of the Empire State Development Corporation, a major player in Times Square, said that the state was committed to redevelopment of the area and that Mr. Ratner's involvement was a major boost for these efforts. He added that he had spoken to other developers who he said also thought that such a Coney Island project would work, and that he and the Governor had had "many discussions" recently about Coney Island.
"If we can rebuild 42d Street, we can certainly rebuild Coney Island," Mr. Gargano said. "What it needs is some investment."
The current discussion is linked to the status of Sportsplex, a proposed 12,300-seat indoor athletic center that would be in the old Steeplechase Park amusement area -- once the centerpiece of Coney Island. Financing for Sportsplex is part of the current budget negotiations in Albany and would require $75 million in bonds from the state; the Legislature has failed to approve the proposal for the last two years. State officials say Mr. Ratner's project is based upon approval of Sportsplex.
Mr. Gargano said the project's prospects were sweeter this year because of Mr. Ratner's proposal and because of several other developers' interest in commercial developments to accompany the arena.
Mr. Gargano pledged state help with transportation and other infrastructure improvements, as well as aid in acquiring private land. He said Gov. George E. Pataki, who he said supports Sportsplex, is eager to prod development of Coney Island, regardless of whether Sportsplex goes ahead.
"Sportsplex would be a good part of it, but it doesn't have to be," Mr. Gargano said. "There wasn't one of those when Coney Island was booming."
Nevertheless, development efforts face many obstacles, not the least of which is that, unlike Times Square, Coney Island is far away from the main stomping grounds of tourists. Also, its main attraction in the early part of the century -- the beach -- is not the draw it once was, since automobiles have made places like Jones Beach and other spots easily accessible.
Furthermore, the current redevelopment efforts are predicated on a combined public-private effort, and the decades-long effort to improve Times Square showed how difficult these efforts can be.
Caroline Quartararo, a spokeswoman for the Empire State Development Corporation, the state economic development agency, said she believed that the project would pass environmental and zoning reviews, adding, "When the public sector gets involved, it reduces unnecessary roadblocks for the private sector."
So far, only Mr. Ratner has put forth a concrete proposal, but other developers agree the time may be right for a showy commercial development in Coney Island, particularly if it is accompanied by the sort of governmental aid Times Square received. There, the state spent $75 million, largely in condemnation proceedings, to stimulate $1.6 billion in private expenditures.
"We believe it's a ripe area for development," said Philip Wolf, who is overseeing the building of Brooklyn's first new hotel in 50 years for the Muss Development Company in the borough's downtown area. "It could be terrific."
Lewis Rudin, a leading real estate developer and chairman of the Association for a Better New York, suggested that what he termed "a modern-day entertainment center" could redirect Brooklynites' recreational patterns. "There are 2.4 million people in Brooklyn, and they don't all go to Times Square," he said. "They'll turn their cars around and head south."
The backers of Sportsplex asked Mr. Ratner to do a business analysis of the area around Sportsplex's proposed site. Mr. Gargano had suggested that such an analysis was likely to make the project more attractive to the Governor.
The developer returned with a full-scale development proposal, which foundation officials and their consultants say he has already submitted to the city.
The details of his proposal were contained in an economic analysis conducted by TAMS Consultants Inc. The proposal involves a more than 400,000-square-foot entertainment and retail complex to stretch from 15th to 19th Streets. It would include the sort of electronic games now popular in Times Square, and it would partly occupy land presently occupied by the skeleton of the Thunderbolt roller coaster, which closed in 1983. It would generate more than 1,000 construction jobs and more than 300 permanent jobs, TAMS said.
Andrew Parker, a principal of the consulting firm, said his and Mr. Ratner's own analysis assumed no subsidies, other than being given vacant land owned by the city. TAMS calculated that the project would generate $12.1 million in new annual tax revenues for the city and $9.5 million for the state after subtracting $4.8 million a year in debt service on state-backed bonds.
Mr. Ratner, a major contributor to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, has also been involved in the redevelopment of the Times Square area and developed the Atlantic Center mall project in Brooklyn.
The Sportsplex project is a 262,000-square-foot facility where 12,300 spectators could watch basketball games, track meets and other indoor athletic events.
Backers say there are only 54 public gyms in Brooklyn, a borough that is home to an estimated 600,000 amateur athletes, some of whom practice track events in school hallways. In addition, there is no athletic venue in Brooklyn with more than St. Francis University's 1,800 seats.
Because there are so few venues between Madison Square Garden and small high school gyms, school officials said Sportsplex would attract athletes from beyond Brooklyn.
"We don't see it as a Brooklyn facility; we see it as a citywide facility," said William C. Thompson, president of the Board of Education, which has pledged to pay $1 for each student using Sportsplex. Brooklyn colleges have promised $2 a user.
Sportsplex planners also hope to rent the center for events as varied as business conventions and ethnic festivals.
They have also discussed possible bookings with the Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus, the Harlem Globetrotters and organizers of professional wresting and tractor pulls and other events they see very much in the tradition of Coney Island's raucous show business heritage. They calculate that rent from such events, expected to take up only 9 percent of Sportsplex's bookings, would more than cover the center's estimated $2.5 million annual operating cost.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Philippines to Get Emergency I.M.F. Loan
In an important test of new methods to cope with instability in world financial markets, the International Monetary Fund has for the first time used emergency procedures set up after the Mexican financial crisis to arrange an urgent loan of $1 billion to the Philippines.
The move was an unusual response to the pressure placed on some other Southeast Asian economies since Thailand was forced on July 2 to devalue its currency. [Page A1.] 

New Cap Near for Outpatient Bills
Relief is in sight for elderly people who, in recent years, have been forced to pay a large and rapidly growing share of the bills for hospital outpatient services like cataract surgery, hernia operations and all sorts of diagnostic tests. The budget bill moving through Congress would impose new limits on what Medicare beneficiaries pay for such services. [A1.]
 
At the Silicon Ranch
Technology is transforming the cattle and dairy industries. Competitive pressures, high feed costs and the demand for prime, specialty beef have forced more farmers and ranchers to drive their herds into the electronic frontier. Perhaps it was inevitable when cows started appearing on those Gateway 2000 boxes. [D4.]
 
Are Papers Doing Their Jobs?
The business prospects of newspapers have improved sharply, with advertising up and newsprint costs down. But are papers fulfilling their mission to inform readers? At least four different efforts are under way to try to plumb some of the underlying problems. Iver Peterson: Publishing. [D9.]
 
Intel Settles Suit Over Chips
Intel has settled a class-action suit brought in the wake of the disclosure last year that an error in a testing process had led the company to overstate the speed of some microprocessor chips by about 10 percent. The chip maker will offer rebates on the purchase of new processors for some customers and add new language warning computer users to carefully assess comparisons of processor speed. [D6.]
 
A Loud Battle in Audio Systems
A war is under way for control of the music and the video soundtracks Americans play in their living rooms. Most people are completely unaware of the fight, or even that there's anything to fight over. But Digitial Theater Systems is mounting a nasty challenge to Dolby's primacy in the audio world. [D9.]
 
Investors Consider Coney Island
Inspired by the success of efforts to redevelop Times Square, private investors and state officials are now turning their attention to another long-neglected part of the New York City: Coney Island. The efforts have gained new momentum because Bruce C. Ratner, a developer with a track record in several large projects, has shown interest. [B1.]
 
Radio, Welcome to the Club
Even children who have yet to master their ABC's know that mouse ears mean Disney and Mickey Mouse. Now that icon of family entertainment, which has helped sell videos, magazines, television programs and films, is heading into radio, a medium that for decades has mostly tuned out listeners younger than 12. [D10.]
 
Problems Seen in Gas Tank Device
Several million cars to be sold this autumn will get a costly new pollution-control device that will make it harder to fill the gas tank at some service stations and may pose a safety risk. The new device is designed to capture the gasoline vapors that occupy a mostly empty gas tank and are usually pushed out into the air when the tank is refueled. [A15.]
 
Talking It Up, on Line
The bigger the Internet gets, the more new discussion forums seem to pop up on the World Wide Web. Taking In the Sites. [D6.]

HEADLINE: To Ease Crisis, I.M.F. Makes Philippines Emergency Loan

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 20

 BODY:
In an important test of new methods to cope with instability in world financial markets, the International Monetary Fund has for the first time used emergency procedures set up after the Mexican economic crisis to arrange a $1 billion loan to the Philippines.
The move was an unusual response to the pressure placed on some other Southeast Asian economies since Thailand was forced on July 2 to devalue its currency. On Friday, officials of the fund said today, its board approved a special loan request from Manila to help its central bank shore up the value of the Philippine peso, which was allowed to float on July 11 and has since lost 12 percent of its value. 
 Though the loan is small in comparison with an unprecedented $17.8 billion that the fund lent Mexico in February 1995, the instability of some Southeast Asian economies has been worrisome to international institutions like the I.M.F. and to the United States Government.
The Mexico crisis of 1994-95 provided further evidence to world financial authorities that global markets are tightly linked, and that instability even in smaller emerging markets can be sufficient to disrupt financial centers like those of New York and London.
During the Mexican crisis, world financial institutions were criticized for not moving fast enough. This helped lead to the establishment of emergency procedures that were put to their first test late last week.
"It's a very good thing that's happened," said C. Fred Bergsten, director of the Institute for International Economics in Washington. "This is the first sequence of financial disruptions since the Mexico crisis that has radiated out from one country to a financial contagion affecting lots of other countries. It's imperative that the I.M.F. be able to deal with these crises very fast and demonstrate that to the markets. And the Philippines deserves a lot of credit for going to the fund quickly to seek help. So both sides have learned, and hopefully this will help mitigate any spillover of the contagion."
The International Monetary Fund's board approved Manila's request to draw on $600 million from an existing loan program that was due to expire on Wednesday. It extended that loan through the end of this year, and augmented it with a further credit line of $435 million. The credit is expected to help Manila defend the peso and build up its reserves, after its central bank had spent about $1 billion trying -- and failing -- to support the currency's earlier fixed rate of exchange against the dollar, fund officials said.
Manila's request was approved within a week, an extremely quick turnaround, under the fund's Emergency Financial Mechanism set up in September 1995.
While a senior fund official said that the Philippines qualified for the new credits under normal criteria, "it was a good occasion to try out these new procedures," made easier because fund officials were already in Manila negotiating a review of the Philippines' current I.M.F. loan program. Normally, it takes the fund at least six weeks to approve a credit request, the official said.
Two years ago, at a meeting of top leaders of the Group of Seven industrial nations in Halifax, Nova Scotia, the American Secretary of the Treasury, Robert E. Rubin, persuaded representatives of other nations to set up funds within the I.M.F. for emergencies, so that loans would not be entirely dependent on American financing that would require Congressional approval.
The pressure on the Philippines, as on other fast-growing countries in Southeast Asia, was a consequence of a slowdown in exports; the strength of the dollar against the Japanese yen, which made their own currencies stronger against the yen as well, and deepening troubles in Thailand's economy. There, an overheated real estate market led banks and their customers to invest heavily in what proved to be bad projects, borrowing from Japanese and American lenders to do so.
There had been a reluctance to devalue the Thai currency, the baht, which was fixed to the dollar, because it would make those loans more expensive to repay. As a result, fund officials said, the Thais waited too long to devaluate the baht in order to make their exports more competitive.
Currency speculators, however, put pressure on the baht and finally forced Thailand to give in on July 2 and allow the currency to float. Speculators then took aim at the currencies of Malaysia, Indonesia and Singapore, as well as the Philippines, the weakest of these economies.
In return for the new credits, the Philippine Government agreed to continue to keep interest rates high, reduce inflation to 6.5 percent in 1997 from 8.4 percent last year, keep its budget deficit to 4.5 percent of the gross national product and try to pass the rest of a tax-reform package. It also pledged to tighten the exposure of banks to real estate markets, which set off the crisis in Thailand. The fund expects the Philippine economy to grow this year by 6.3 percent, up from 5.7 percent in 1996.
I.M.F. officials noted that the analogy of Southeast Asia to Mexico is not precise, and that the economies of the Southeast Asian nations -- especially Malaysia, Indonesia and Singapore -- are fundamentally sound, with strong growth. These countries, as well as Thailand, in many respects already have the kinds of dynamic economies that Mexico is trying to develop.
While Thailand does not have a loan program with the I.M.F. and says it does not want one, its Finance Minister visited Japan last week. But he did not, as expected, ask for a loan, because the Japanese are said to have made clear that no money would be forthcoming unless Thailand first approached the I.M.F.

HEADLINE: Lilco's Hard Journey

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

DATELINE: ALBANY, July 20

 BODY:
The State of New York finally agreed to a takeover of most of the Long Island Lighting Company last week, but the fate of the company may have been sealed on March 28, 1979.
On that day, the cooling systems at a nuclear power plant in Pennsylvania failed, a reactor overheated, plutonium fuel rods melted, mounting pressure threatened to burst the concrete shell and radioactive steam and water were released to prevent an explosion. The plant, Three Mile Island, became synonymous with the dangers of nuclear power. 
 The accident galvanized local opposition to the Shoreham nuclear plant, then under construction on the North Shore of Long Island, and that opposition prevented Lilco from putting the plant into service. The accident at Three Mile Island also resulted in new safety requirements for nuclear plants, pushing the cost of Shoreham sharply higher. The utility spent $5.5 billion on an investment it could not use, forcing it to buy power elsewhere, causing electric rates on the island to balloon and leaving the company staggering under its debt.
State officials have been searching for more than a decade for some way to lower Long Island's electric rates, which are more than double the national average. And for more than a decade, state officials assigned to solve the problem have concluded that the answer was a state buyout.
Indeed, despite years of pitched political battles and position reversals by key players, including Gov. George E. Pataki, the agreement approved last week by the state's Public Authorities Control Board had about it the air of inevitability.
"It had to happen," said Frank G. Zarb, until recently the chairman of Long Island Power Authority, the state agency that will effect the takeover. "It was just a matter of time."
The Power Authority plans to borrow $7.3 billion to buy Lilco's transmission and distribution system and to take over its debts. Lilco, which is merging with the Brooklyn Union Gas Company, will keep its power plants, though the power authority will have the option of buying them in a few years. The deal still must be approved by several Federal agencies.
The control board promised that rates would average at least 14 percent below current levels for the next 10 years; the administration says it will be 19 percent.
The savings would derive from three basic factors: The state agency can borrow through tax-exempt bonds, refinancing Lilco's debts at a low interest rate; the authority does not have to pay income taxes, as Lilco does, and it does not have shareholders to whom it must pay dividends.
A public buyout has been part of the Lilco debate for more than a decade, though each new set of public officials to enter the fray had to take up and discard other options before arriving at that one.
In the mid-1980's, Senators Daniel Patrick Moynihan and Alfonse M. D'Amato obtained a Long Island exemption to a Federal law that barred the use of tax-exempt bonds to refinance utility debts. In 1986, the state created the Long Island Power Authority specifically for the purpose of taking over Shoreham or other Lilco assets, or even the whole company.
"The surprise is that it took this long, and that it's a Republican governor who's doing it," said Gordian Raacke, executive director of the Citizens Advisory Panel to Lilco, which was appointed by a Federal court as part of a lawsuit against the utility in the 1980's. Mr. Raacke is critical of the deal, though not of the takeover notion in general.
The Power Authority made unsuccessful offers for the company in 1988, though they were meant primarily to prod Lilco into giving up Shoreham, which it turned over the state the next year.
"In the beginning, nobody wanted to see a friendly takeover," said Richard M. Kessel, the chairman of the Power Authority and a member of its board since it was created. "Seizing it by eminent domain, maybe. But we tried our best to look at every other alternative, and we had to conclude that this was the only way to go."
So what took so long?
"The notion that government should somehow undertake a massive thing like this turned off a lot of people," said Mr. Kessel, a Democrat. "And for years, everybody was preoccupied with closing Shoreham. But mostly, people hate the company, and that gets in the way of everything. Any solution means making a deal with the company, and the passions are so huge, it's hard to get people to understand that. It took me a long time to cross that bridge."
Mr. Zarb gave a shorter answer: "Politics."
Takeover bids under Governor Mario M. Cuomo met with stiff opposition from Republicans in the Legislature.
"The Republicans stopped it," Mr. Cuomo said. "Ask them why it didn't happen earlier."
In October 1994, locked in a desperate race for governor against Mr. Pataki, Mr. Cuomo proposed a complete takeover of Lilco. Some important details were different, but in its broad outlines, it was much the same plan that Mr. Pataki proposed two and a half years later.
But at the time, Mr. Pataki derided the idea as a cynical attempt to buy Long Island votes, and as a misguided, big-money initiative typical of the Democrats, and discarded the plan after he was elected.
Mr. Zarb, a Republican, noted wryly that, "taking over anything wasn't exactly a Republican formula."
The new Governor ousted Mr. Kessel as chairman of the Power Authority. Mr. Kessel arrived at the authority one day to find his desk cleaned out and his things piled in a corridor. Mr. Pataki proposed his own formula, to break up Lilco into several pieces and sell them off. After that plan wilted under widespread criticism, he appointed Mr. Zarb as chairman and asked him to find a better answer.
Mr. Zarb and Mr. Kessel, along with administration officials, spent a year negotiating the deal with Lilco that was announced in March. Then Mr. Zarb left the Power Authority to become president of the National Association of Securities Dealers. To replace him as chairman, Mr. Pataki appointed Mr. Kessel, the man the Governor had forced out of that post two years earlier.
"Nothing about this whole history was easy," Mr. Kessel said. "It might have been inevitable, but it was a lot of work."

HEADLINE: National News Briefs;
Private Guards Credited With Decrease in Crime

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, July 20

 BODY:
A 50 percent drop in crime in Hollywood is being attributed to a business improvement district's hiring of private security guards.
Drug-related activity, trespassing and other nuisance crimes have decreased over the past several months, business owners and the police said on Friday. 
 Aggravated assaults and vehicle break-ins were down two-thirds in the second quarter of 1997 compared with the same period last year, and robberies were down 25 percent, said Valerie Munoz, a crime analyst for the Hollywood division of the Los Angeles Police Department.
The Hollywood Business Improvement District was formed six months ago with a five-year goal of changing the area's seedy image and attracting new retail businesses and restaurants.

HEADLINE: From Rags to Riches: Versace's South Beach;
Designer Left His Stamp On Community

BYLINE: By MIREYA NAVARRO 

DATELINE: MIAMI BEACH, July 20

 BODY:
When the fashion designer Gianni Versace announced in the early 1990's his plans to demolish a boarded-up three-story hotel here to make room for his swimming pool, George T. Neary fought him. Mr. Neary, the executive director of the Miami Design Preservation League, said he was more interested in saving a building in the historic Art Deco district than gaining a celebrity for it.
But by the time Mr. Versace, who ultimately got his swimming pool, was gunned down in front of his house on Tuesday, he had won over his former opponents, restoring a former apartment building as a magnificent home that won awards and helping local preservationists successfully lobby for stronger laws to protect other buildings. 
 "We've lost a neighbor," a saddened Mr. Neary said this weekend of the enemy who became an ally.
Mr. Versace's death has brought the familiar international outcry about violence in America to this city's South Beach section, a bustling district of historic architecture, topless beaches and relentless night life that is the jewel of tourist attractions in Miami's metropolitan area.
The vision of preservationists, the growing Hispanic population of South Florida and the arrival of celebrities like Mr. Versace have helped promote the area's stunning transformation in less than two decades from a decaying area to a vibrant one. But South Beach has an aura of danger, thanks to television.
Nancy Liebman, a Miami Beach commissioner and longtime historic preservation advocate, traces South Beach's dramatic rise -- from a crime-ridden enclave best known for its poor retirees, crumbling hotels and refugees from the 1980 Cuban boatlift -- to three milestones.
The first was the inclusion of a one-square-mile district in Miami Beach's southern tip in the National Register of Historic Places in 1979, which saved South Beach's early 20th-century architecture from bulldozers. The second was the worldwide publicity generated by the Bulgarian-born artist Christo, who stayed with his staff in South Beach hotels in 1983 while wrapping a cluster of Biscayne Bay islands in pink fabric in the name of art.
Then, in the mid-1980's, the television show "Miami Vice" brought South Beach to the masses with a violent but stylish portrayal of a Miami area steeped in crime and clad in sockless loafers. The exposure helped draw fashion photographers looking for winter shooting locations to South Beach, as well as developers who restored pastel Art Deco hotels and added sidewalk cafes and television and record companies. It also attracted hordes of tourists, now the economic engine of the area.
"The place became known for the excitement," Ms. Liebman said. But after Mr. Versace, 50, was fatally shot at the gate of his South Beach estate -- the suspect is sought in four slayings elsewhere and remains at large -- the district finds itself in need of damage control.
The American press treated the Versace killing as an act aimed at a particular victim that could have happened anywhere, said Mayco Villafana, a spokesman for the Greater Miami Convention and Visitors Bureau, but the foreign news media related it to tourist killings in the Miami area in 1992 and 1993 that led to a drop in visitors.
The bureau is planning trips for journalists from Italy and other European countries to dispel fears, Mr. Villafana said.
"This was an issue of a man and not a place," Mr. Villafana insisted.
Mr. Versace found relaxation and inspiration in South Beach, his friends and acquaintances said, and he turned up the voltage on its glitter. His catalogs and advertisements featured South Beach backdrops, and he devoted one of his collections to Miami, emblazoning the city's name, 1950's Cadillacs and Art Deco hotels across $1,800 silk shirts and other clothing items that sold worldwide.
"He promoted the city in a way that had never been done," said Glenn Albin, editor in chief of Ocean Drive Magazine, a monthly here. "It was outstanding."
Mr. Versace also stimulated the local market by buying his Ocean Drive residence in 1992 and later opening a store that soon was in the company of other high-end fashion shops. And Mr. Versace impressed the preservation watchdogs in Miami Beach, a city of about 93,000 where voters recently passed a referendum calling for limits on high-rise development, with his elaborate renovation of Casa Casuarina. He bought the 1930 Mediterranean Revival-style structure for $2.9 million, then then invested millions more, building a pool and a garden. Ms. Liebman called it "the most perfect restoration in South Beach, to the last detail."
But Mr. Versace was also attracted to the more hedonistic side of South Beach, a sexy and carefree world of stretch limousines and glamorous models, of bare navels and bulging muscles in bronzed bodies and after-hours clubs. Its large gay population tends to be apolitical and incohesive. It is no coincidence, some say, that many gay men with AIDS have come to South Beach to spend their last years.
"This is a place of escape for people from all walks of life," said Eugene J. Patron, who writes about gay issues for The Miami Herald and serves on the board of the South Beach Business Guild, the gay chamber of commerce, which has 140 members.
When in town, Mr. Versace, who was gay, frequented restaurants, nightclubs and the beach within walking distance of Ocean Drive, a beachfront strip of hotels and restaurants where he owned the only house. In a growing Hispanic area and vacation hot spot for European and South American tourists, he enjoyed the international atmosphere and exhibitionism, translating his impressions into the color and vibrancy of fashion, some who knew him said.
"He saw it as a civilized bazaar," said Israel Sands, a local florist who decorated many of Mr. Versace's parties and dinners and, last week, his casket and the urn with his ashes. "People have a lot of energy and come here to express it. It stimulated him."
But it is also a transient world where someone like Andrew P. Cunanan, the 27-year-old suspected of killing the designer, could easily disappear.
Described as a gay prostitute by law-enforcement authorities, Mr. Cunanan is now believed to have stayed in a Miami Beach hotel for two months before the murder. Hotels workers have said he usually left his hotel room after 10 P.M. and would not come back until morning.
In recent years, some residents of South Beach have complained that the area may be a victim of its own success. They say the overpriced shops, scarce parking and appreciating real estate have robbed South Beach of the bohemian character given by the artists, gays and others who first moved here because of cheap housing.
And while Miami Beach police say robberies are still a worse problem than homicides, Mr. Versace's violent death has robbed many of a sense of innocence.
"You feel this overwhelming sense that the community is so shaken by this that it can't help but taint things," said Bob Guilmartin, vice president of the Florida Hotel Network, a reservations company here.

HEADLINE: America's Vital Interest in the 'New Silk Road'

BYLINE: By James A. Baker 3d; James A. Baker 3d, Secretary of State under President George Bush, is honorary chairman of the James A. Baker 3d Institute for Public Policy at Rice University.

DATELINE: HOUSTON

 BODY:
On Aug. 2, 1990, when Iraqi troops crossed the border into Kuwait, I happened to be meeting with the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, in Siberia.
The next day, he and I issued a joint statement condemning Iraq, despite the fact that the document had not been formally cleared with the Soviet President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Mr. Shevardnadze made the decision on his own because he felt it was simply the right thing to do. "When the two of us meet," he told me, "there must be results." Such personal and political courage exhibited by Mr. Gorbachev and Mr. Shevardnadze throughout this period helped write an end to the cold war. 
 Mr. Shevardnadze has been in Washington these last few days in his new role as President of Georgia. He talked to President Clinton, members of the Cabinet and business leaders about opportunities for American companies in Georgia. I hope they will listen sympathetically: Georgia needs American investment, and more important, it is in the strategic interests of the United States to build the strongest possible economic, cultural and political ties to Georgia.
Under Mr. Shevardnadze's leadership, Georgia has emerged as one of the most Western-friendly countries of the former Soviet Union, with a rapidly growing economy. Georgia's importance is its location at the nexus of Europe and Asia, with ports on the Black Sea. The country is poised to be a principal outlet for bringing the oil and gas resources of the Caspian Sea to international markets. Caspian oil may eventually be as important to the industrialized world as Middle East oil is today. Georgia's future security, therefore, is important to America's security.
Georgia sits at the Western end of what is often described as the "new silk road," the revival of historical trade routes linking China and Central Asia with Europe. In addition, Georgia's oil and gas resources will lead to the development of new road, rail and communications links. Development of this Eurasian corridor is receiving priority from a number of international organizations.
These changes have transformed the continent from the north-south character of the former Soviet Union into the east-west orientation of the new independent nations. Enders Wimbush, a leading analyst of the region, has called this change "one of the fundamental political shifts of our time, with important consequences for U.S. strategic interests from Europe to China."
Mr. Shevardnadze sees this transformation more clearly than most. He understands the cultures involved, the historical relationships, the importance of timing. He has carefully nurtured relations with his country's neighbors and actively promoted regional economic cooperation and growth to bring a new stability to the region.
American businessmen in the region speak of his ability to get things done. Some cite the way he re-opened the important rail link between Baku in Azerbaijan and the Georgian port of Batumi that had long since fallen into disuse, but now carries over a million barrels of oil a month from Kazakhstan to the West.
To me, Mr. Shevardnadze has always been more than a politician and diplomat. He has an ability to predict with great accuracy the future flow of world events.
His current visit, the first as President of his country, is important not only to Georgia but also to the United States. We can benefit from listening to this man of experience and understanding.

CORRECTION-DATE: July 26, 1997, Saturday

 An Op-Ed article last Monday by former Secretary of State James A. Mr. Baker's law firm represents an oil consortium and other companies in the region. The Times should have made those interests known to the reader.

HEADLINE: Dads' Staying Home Won't Erase Black Poverty

 BODY:

To the Editor:
I was disturbed by "A Pitiful Giant," Bob Herbert's July 18 column lambasting the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People for not making black children's "abandonment by their own fathers" the first priority at its annual convention. 
 Mr. Herbert's assertion that children who grow up in fatherless homes are more likely to be in poverty may well be true, but is the lack of fathers a cause or effect of poverty? Just having fathers live with their children will not resolve the severe problems confronting many blacks in the inner city: underfinanced, poorly managed schools and a lack of decent-paying jobs.
Will a poorly educated father unable to find a job be able to save his child from poverty, crime and unemployment just because he resides in the same home? I doubt it.
Who cares if Kweisi Mfume, the N.A.A.C.P.'s president, fathered illegitimate children in the past? At least he regrets his past and has made an effort to be a good father.
Yes, as Mr. Herbert implies, the black community -- like all communities -- needs to do some soul searching. Yes, Mr. Mfume and the association's chairwoman, Myrlie Evers-Williams, may be too quick to use vague, paranoid rhetoric. However, in a country where racism still abounds and equal opportunity is little more than an oxymoron, I hardly think flawed leadership and absentee fathers are the slavery of the late 20th century.
 
JULIE WIENER
Ann Arbor, Mich., July 18, 1997
