HEADLINE: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;
A 'Shrew' As Good As Gold

BYLINE: By BEN BRANTLEY 

DATELINE: STRATFORD, Ontario, July 18

 BODY:
And you thought it was a boy beats girl story. It's money -- not love, not the clashing of the sexes -- that makes the world go round in the Stratford Festival production of "The Taming of the Shrew." This is the not entirely unwarranted view set forth by the young director Richard Rose in his lively if overburdened interpretation of the comedy.
Reset in Little Italy in Manhattan, with a Petruchio who says (sorry Shakespeare, sorry Cole Porter) he comes "to wive it wealthily in America," the production is awash with images of people flashing bankrolls and symbols of conspicuous consumption. The show ends with a shower of what look like greenbacks falling over the newly renovated Festival Theater. And Mr. Rose has been quoted as saying that the play's title character is "a shrew because she is being treated as an economic product." 
 Actually, a preoccupation with things fiscal is understandable in anyone associated with this ever-worthy 44-year-old repertory company, which remains unmatched in North America in its ability to bring large audiences (now more than half a million people, 35 percent of them Americans) to see a Shakespeare-oriented roster of classic theater every summer. Artistic ambition may remain a cornerstone. But there is also a pervasive, slightly weary sense that what is put on the stages here must indeed be viable economic products.
Under Richard Monette, the artistic director since 1995, the festival would seem to be in the pink of health. Forty years after it replaced the giant tent under which the legendary showman Tyrone Guthrie staged the company's first productions in 1953, the Festival Theater has undergone a $10.5 million renovation (all figures in American dollars), which has been celebrated this season with events that included a visit from Queen Elizabeth II.
Its acclaimed 1995 production of "Long Day's Journey Into Night" has been turned into an equally acclaimed film. Its mounting of Christopher Plummer's one-man show "Barrymore" was transferred to an award-reaping Broadway run. And plans are being made to take two Festival Theater productions to City Center in New York annually, beginning at the end of 1998. But as in the United States, government subsidies for the arts are shrinking like cotton clothes in an overheated dryer. In the last three years, about 35 percent of the money from the Ontario Arts Council has disappeared, and overall government support is now just over 6 percent of the festival's $20 million budget. No one's making a secret of the way this necessarily shapes the company's artistic policy.
In a special festival edition of The Beacon Herald, Mr. Monette, whose tenure has been extended through 2000, comments: "These theaters were not designed to work without subsidy. Because what will happen is we will become more and more reliant on box office successes. It's already a difficult balancing act."
Accordingly, there is always at least one big, familiar musical on the schedule. (This year's is "Camelot," in a sumptuous production designed expressly by the company veteran Desmond Heeley to match the glamorously refurbished interior of the Festival Theater.) And the standing repertory of actors is flecked with stars from Canadian television, including Al Waxman, who does a creditable Willy Loman in Arthur Miller's "Death of a Salesman."
Even within productions of classics, however, the feeling of Mr. Monette's balancing act is clearly in evidence. The festival's most intriguing offerings -- a revival of Peter Shaffer's "Equus," directed by and starring Brian Bedford, and a re-creation of the company's famed 1955 production of "Oedipus Rex," modeled after Tanya Moiseiwitch's original designs and masks -- have yet to open. But four current productions ("Shrew," "Camelot," "Coriolanus" and "Salesman") offer an index of the festival's strengths and weaknesses.
All are handsomely staged, often creating a sense of lavishness from minimal means. And the general standard of acting, particularly in terms of ease with Shakespearean language, is higher than that generally found in American productions, including those of the New York Shakespeare Festival.
Yet each production gives off an aggressive air of overeagerness that sacrifices nuance for attention-getting broad strokes. The whimsy quotient of "Camelot," directed by Mr. Monette, is raised to an almost assaultive level, with the result that nearly every musical number seemed to end with the unspoken question, "Are we having fun yet?"
The domestic squabbles of "Salesman," as staged by Diana Leblanc (the director of the festival's production of "Long Day's Journey") take on an operatic intensity that nearly eclipses Mr. Waxman's touchingly straightforward portrait of a loser. And the martial sturm und drang of "Coriolanus," directed by Mr. Rose, registers as a noisy pageant of 20th-century war-is-hell images that doesn't reckon with the psychological pathology of its central characters.
Mr. Rose's "Shrew" also suffers from a surfeit of flash, but it does occasionally open a window onto new perspectives on the comedy. Petruchio (Peter Donaldson) is portrayed here as a down-at-heel Italian immigrant in the New York of the 1960's. The production's Little Italy (or Nuova Padua, as the characters, who speak Elizabethan English with thick Italian accents, call it) is a world of mercenary padrones, garishly decorative women and small-time hustlers. (When a character says, "There are good fellows in the world," it has special significance.)
The director fills the stage with a San Gennaro-like festival of tipsy ecclesiastics and musicians, actors dressed up as Manhattan tourist attractions like the Chrysler building, a creepy castleful of cartoonish Gothic servants at Petruchio's moldy estate in Italy and cardboard yellow taxis in traffic jams. It all gets out of hand finally. (The newly married Petruchio and Kate, played by Lucy Peacock, take Alitalia flights to and from Italy.) And there's the sense that the production is often running on a track that parallels rather than intersects with Shakespeare's text.
But the show convincingly illuminates the work's emphasis on materialism. And Ms. Peacock and especially Mr. Donaldson, who finds a wry, reflective strain of self-awareness in his volatile Petruchio, make an attractive case for the characters' relationship as a process of mutual education. Mr. Rose's ingenious justification of Kate's final, submissive speech should pacify even militant feminists.
It's harder to believe in the romantic triangle in "Camelot," in which King Arthur (Tom McCamus), Guenevere (Cynthia Dale) and Lancelot (Dan R. Chameroy) all register as giddy adolescents playing medieval dress-up, with an unfortunate tendency to annotate the songs' lyrics with literal-minded gestures.
In "Shrew," however, Ms. Dale does a witty take on Bianca as a spoiled Italian-American princess. The sprightly, slight-bodied Mr. McCamus, while a winning performer, is miscast both as Arthur and Coriolanus, though he does manage to hold the center of the stage with an inflexible sneer as Coriolanus. And Martha Henry, a longtime Festival Theater favorite, is truly dominating, even terrifying, as Volumnia, Coriolanus's autocratic mother.
In a testament to the opportunities for actorly stretching afforded by repertory companies, Ms. Henry also shows up as Willy Loman's drab, faithful wife, Linda, in "Salesman," although costumes aside, there's little drabness in the character here. In fact, with her deep, resonant voice and high-wattage presence, the actress brings a residual touch of Volumnia to Linda, which gives a whole new, unsettling flavor to the Loman sons' relationship with their mother.
When this Linda says, "Attention must be paid," it's a stern, booming command that you don't dare ignore. Getting people to pay attention, after all, is what Stratford specializes in.

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
The Connecting Line

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL 

 BODY:
In just one day last week three stories were reported that told of the stunning successes the Chinese Politburo has achieved in manipulating America and diminishing it as a credible political player in the Far East.
Americans can find similar stories almost every day in their press. But American journalism, like American diplomacy and politics, has failed to show the clear line that connects the stories. And historically -- meaning from tomorrow deep into the next century -- that failure can be the Politburo's biggest triumph of all. 
 One story dealt with China's plan to influence the American Presidential race and how President Clinton insisted that the agent of Beijing's chief overseas economic commercial partner be given a role in the campaign.
This agent, John Huang, received regular C.I.A. briefings. If the White House does not understand that anything interesting the C.I.A. told him found its way through his Indonesian masters to their Beijing partners, it would be obscene self-delusion amounting to dereliction of duty.
Another story was about the growing worry in Congress that U.S. intelligence has not kept track of how China's increasing military and political power affect America. The House has called for a report within a year. It appropriated $5 million to hire academics to help our multibillion-dollar intelligence machinery.
The third story told of how the dissident movement has been crushed in China. The Communists got a free hand when the Clinton Administration dropped human rights as a goal of its foreign policy. The Communists then had no worry about economic penalty for the torture and murder of Chinese guilty of trying to express themselves. So they set to work.
Just another human rights story. But the connecting line among all the successes of China is human rights. The line begins with President Clinton's decision in 1994 to renege on promises he had made to use economic pressure to help imprisoned Chinese and Tibetan dissidents.
Human rights for Chinese -- the right to speak, write and worship as they choose -- should be important in themselves to Americans. They should make us cherish and protect our own, inspire us to give a hand to those who have none.
The apologists for China sneer at all that. What are we, missionaries? They say Americans supporting human rights thirst for enemies after the Soviet breakup and select China for the role.
This is a knowing falsehood. The opposite is true. Like other police-state rulers, Chinese Communists live in fear of their people's desire for liberties. They see American democracy as the danger to the Communist Party, the inevitable enemy. They search out other dictatorships for help in damaging America.
That is why China sells nuclear technology to the likes of Iran. To weaken America -- that is the connecting line in Politburo policy.
For Mr. Clinton, the decision to betray Chinese human rights was the beginning of the line to the other accommodations and appeasements that flowed from it. Could he have brought into his campaign a man useful only because of his links with China, direct or indirect, if he were still standing up to what the Communists were doing to dissidents?
The President's men, and women, walk the line with him. For career reasons, they pretended to believe his cynical fantasy that deserting human rights would somehow make the Communists improve human rights. They said straight-faced that it would also persuade the Politburo to safeguard America's security interests -- no more sales of cruise missiles and nuclear technology to the Irans of the world.
So when American intelligence did report those sales, the Administration whined a bit but accepted Beijing's insulting answer that it knew nothing about the sales. They expected Americans to believe even pistols could be exported from China without Beijing's approval.
Only one thing prevents Beijing from fully relishing its double victory over Chinese human rights and America's claims to international moral leadership.
Beijing has not yet stamped out one human rights struggle -- the passion for freedom of worship. Yesterday the U.S. again acknowledged the persecution of Christians in China. America's Government will try to remain detached. America's people may not.

HEADLINE: France Raises Business Taxes, and Anxiety Over Euro

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN 

DATELINE: PARIS, July 21

 BODY:
France's Government raised taxes sharply for big business today after an audit showed that this year's budget deficit is running well above the target set to qualify for the European Union's planned single currency.
Dominique Strauss-Kahn, the Finance Minister, announced a 15 percent increase in taxes on large corporations and vowed that France would qualify for the euro, the common currency, "in the same conditions as our partners." 
 But with less than 18 months to go before the planned introduction of the euro, the French budget difficulties seemed certain to accentuate German anxieties. Germany is already deeply nervous about the imminent abandonment of its mark, the symbol of its postwar economic strength and stability.
The German Finance Minister, Theo Waigel, put a brave face on the French problems, declaring that Mr. Strauss-Kahn had assured him by telephone of his commitment to meeting the budget targets set for the euro. But it seemed clear from today's announcements that France's notoriously swollen public employment rolls are still far from being brought under lasting control.
The euro is much more than a financial project, in the absence of any momentum toward political union in Europe. It amounts to the cornerstone of efforts to revive European integration and so eventually to form a credible counterweight to the United States.
The French and German political investment in the plan is enormous, and their joint commitment to overcoming any last-minute hitches is considerable. But tension is mounting as the German Bundesbank, the rock on which the mark's strength has been based, grows increasingly concerned that attempts will be made to fudge economic criteria in the name of political imperatives.
Two independent auditors appointed last month by the new Socialist Prime Minister, Lionel Jospin, reported today that the French deficit for 1997 would, without corrective measures, amount to between 3.5 and 3.7 percent of gross domestic product, or total national output.
This would be well in excess of the 3 percent deficit set as a target by the Maastricht Treaty of 1992, which laid out a road map to a single European currency. These steps were supposed to insure that the euro would be backed with the same economic rigor that sustained the German mark for decades and made it the world's second-largest reserve currency, behind the dollar.
The members' 1997 deficit figures and compliance with other targets concerning inflation and the national debt are to be used by European leaders next May in choosing which countries qualify for the scheduled introduction of the euro on Jan. 1, 1999. Thus the French deficit figure for this year is critical, as a euro without its central promoters, France and Germany, is widely viewed as untenable.
Announcing measures today that he said would lower the projected 1997 deficit by $5.3 billion, Mr. Strauss-Kahn said that the corporate tax rate would be raised to 41.6 percent from 36.6 percent for companies with annual sales of over $8.3 million. The increase will apply to this year and 1998; after that, the tax will gradually be lowered again.
In addition, corporate capital gains, previously taxed at 19 percent, will be permanently taxed at the same rate as profits. Over all, these tax increases -- called the "euro surcharge" by commentators -- will bring in about two-thirds of the $5.3 billion, Mr. Strauss-Kahn said.
The remainder of the money, he said, is to be found through spending cuts, particularly in the military budget, and through a special contribution from the profitable state-owned electric utility.
The Finance Minister declined to set a specific target for the 1997 budget deficit, but he said the measures "concern 0.4 percent of gross domestic product." Thus, in the absence of further taxes or spending cuts, the French 1997 deficit seems set to total between 3.1 and 3.3 percent of total output, still above the Maastricht target.
But if some flexibility is shown to France over the criteria for qualification, it will be very difficult to deny the same treatment to Italy, Spain and Portugal, which also seem likely to come just above the 3 percent target. The inclusion of these countries, especially Italy, would deepen fears in Germany that the euro would lack credibility and so resemble the lira more than the mark. Already about two-thirds of Germans express deep doubts about the euro.
Since last August, the mark has dropped about 18 percent against the dollar, and concern has grown about what kind of currency the euro will be. It has also dropped 32 percent against sterling, which is being viewed as a haven from euro-related turbulence because Britain has indicated it will not join the euro in 1999. Recent comments from Hans Tietmeyer, the president of the Bundesbank, suggesting that the mark's fall has gone far enough have done little to stabilize it.
French businessmen reacted angrily to the tax increases, saying they were precisely what France does not need. "Raising taxes will slow growth," said Georges Jolles, the vice president of the employers' federation. "France already taxes too much, and the state spends too much."
The new 41.6 percent tax rate compares with a rate of between 25 percent and 33 percent in Britain and is also well above the American corporate tax rate. The taxes help finance France's public spending, which amounts to about 55 percent of total national output, compared with an average of 40 percent in other major industrialized countries.
Mr. Jospin, who was elected last month in a surprise Socialist victory, made clear commitments during the election campaign to maintain the size of the public sector. He criticized privatization and suggested he would create 350,000 new state jobs.
Since then, under severe budget pressure, he has retreated somewhat, but his maneuvering room in raising money needed to meet the Maastricht targets is very limited.
In this context, he opted for new corporate taxes rather than for other measures. Nevertheless, his Communist coalition partners and some Socialists are already criticizing him for making the euro a higher priority than tackling an unemployment rate of close to 13 percent.
The choice of new taxes rather than lasting cuts in public spending will only increase the Bundesbank's anxiety. In that the measures announced today are more onetime measures than real structural changes that would balance France's budget in the long term, they are unlikely to satisfy the German bankers or to ease growing concerns that the euro is destined to be weak.

PUB-DATE: July 22, 1997

SECTION: Section A; Page 18; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 448 words

HEADLINE: A Budget Deal Not Worth Saving

 BODY:
The current budget negotiations between the President and Congress are often portrayed as an epic struggle over how to cut taxes, trim spending, invest in education and balance the budget for the first time in a quarter-century. But a less flattering version would note that the roaring economy is already driving the deficit close to zero, making a final deal superfluous if not harmful. Indeed, the deficit could be eliminated quicker if the budget deal collapsed.
Some of the budget deal's potential provisions smell rancid. An unfair allocation of very steep Medicare cuts could damage urban hospitals that train doctors and care for the poor. Various proposals would create tax dodges for wealthy investors, eviscerate tax collections a decade from now, encourage colleges to raise tuition and starve nearly every discretionary spending program. No one need mourn if the members of Congress who harbor misgivings, from Senator Phil Gramm of Texas on the right to Senator Paul Wellstone of Minnesota on the left or a President pushed to his limit by excessive tax cutting for wealthy families, decide to scuttle the deal. 
 With tax revenue soaring, this year's deficit may fall below $45 billion, a pittance in a $7 trillion economy. Though the budget deal would eventually trim the deficit, it would actually slow deficit reduction next year because its tax cuts and spending hikes kick in immediately, while spending cuts are postponed. According to the Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget, a corporate-financed nonpartisan group, the budget would be balanced by 2001 if Congress merely locked current policies in place. Under the budget deal it would take one year more to achieve balance. Either way, the deficit will eventually rise again, to large numbers, early next century.
It may be asking too much for Congress, or the President, to admit publicly that the budget plan has gone off track. But the booming economy ought to change the dynamics of the negotiations, by making a final deal less important. Fratricide among Republicans after the failed coup against House Speaker Newt Gingrich could further alter the dynamics. President Clinton negotiates with a weaker Speaker, but one who can no longer afford to jeopardize his tenuous hold on conservative allies.
Mr. Clinton has vowed to reject many of the G.O.P.'s tax proposals that either open huge holes in the budget or favor the nation's wealthiest families. If he recognizes that the budget deal is at best of marginal value, he might stiffen his resolve to beat back the worst excesses of the Republican plans. If the Republicans then threaten to back out of the budget deal, so much the better.

SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1599 words

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Boeing Has Its Feet on the Ground

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT 

 BODY:
In the aerospace business, Boeing seems invincible. By placing big bets on new aircraft and paying close attention to research and engineering, it has grown to dominate its industry by a wide margin. When it has tried to diversify outside the notoriously volatile aircraft industry, though, it has a remarkable history of missing the mark.
Through the years, the Boeing Company has made everything from windmills and hydrofoils to rail cars and computer-controlled buses. In its early days, it even tried making furniture. And while most of these ventures were considered technical successes, they all drained cash until the company shut them down. 
 Now, undeterred, Boeing is breaking out into new areas again. But there is a difference this time: The company finally appears to have learned from its mistakes. In recent months, the Seattle-based Boeing has announced a number of new ventures -- such as selling corporate jets and training pilots -- that suggest that it has decided to stay close to its aerospace roots.
"Boeing has learned that if it reaches too far afield, it gets burned," said Wolfgang H. Demisch, an aerospace analyst at BT Securities. "So it is trying to somehow extend its presence by building on its existing franchises."
More is at stake than simply erasing Boeing's dubious record in sideline businesses. For one, the new ventures, if successful, can help smooth out the cyclical swings that have long buffeted Boeing's stock price and the size of its work force.
That search for balance was a big reason Boeing announced last December its intention to acquire the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, whose strength in military contracting should complement Boeing's commercial aircraft business. But that deal, scheduled to be completed early next month, has encountered sharp criticism from the European Union, which has threatened to oppose the merger tomorrow in its final ruling unless Boeing accepts severe restrictions on its operations. The Clinton Administration has signaled that it may retaliate if the European Union decides to impose stiff fines on Boeing.
For all its problems with European regulators, Boeing has another kind of problem -- the kind any company would love to have. It expects to generate such hefty profits in coming years that it will be forced to find new uses for all the cash. Yesterday, it reported second-quarter net income of $334 million on revenues of $9.29 billion. The results were short of analysts' expectations, and the stock fell $1.6875, closing at $54.375. But that is probably just a blip on the radar. And this time, Boeing is not waiting to start searching for new businesses only after aircraft orders have slumped and it is struggling to keep its workers busy.
"That is a significant difference between the past and where we are today," said Lawrence W. Clarkson, president of Boeing Enterprises, a division created in January to seek out and manage new ventures.
Boeing, for example, is now in the corporate jet business. The idea grew out of conversations between Philip M. Condit, Boeing's chairman, and John F. Welch, chairman of the General Electric Company, a big supplier of engines to Boeing as well as a big buyer of jets for its aircraft leasing division.
According to Boeing executives, Mr. Welch had already committed to buying two 737's for corporate use, but mentioned to Mr. Condit that they still lacked the range of traditional, smaller corporate jets.
Boeing then set 100 engineers to work designing a 737 with the most modern wings and bigger fuel tanks to get its range above 6,000 miles. Offered this new capability, Mr. Welch immediately switched his order to the new version and, convinced such a plane would appeal to other executives, joined Boeing as a partner to start Boeing Business Jets. The planes, at about $38 million to $40 million each, are approximately the same price as the smaller, top-of-the-line corporate jets made by Gulfstream and Bombardier.
At a news conference last year to announce the venture, Boeing officials had planned to say they expected to sell six to eight business jets a year, but Mr. Welch persuaded them to push the estimate to 10 a year. None of them were right. In the first year, Boeing has taken orders for 20 corporate jets, including one from the golfer Greg Norman, whom Boeing has signed up as a pitchman to help sell the planes.
Perhaps the strongest validation of the new market for large corporate jets came from Boeing's biggest rival, Airbus Industrie, which announced last month that it, too, would start selling a modified version of its A319 as a corporate jet.
In January, Boeing Business Jets was folded into the new Boeing Enterprises division, which has moved quickly into other ventures. In March, it joined forces with Flightsafety International, a company acquired last year by the investor Warren E. Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway Inc., to train commercial-jet pilots. And in May, Boeing Enterprises agreed to a joint venture with Aero Vodochody, a Czech manufacturer of military jet fighters.
Mr. Clarkson said Boeing Enterprises was considering a number of other businesses. One is heavy maintenance of aircraft, work that many airlines prefer to farm out to subcontractors. If it proceeds with that idea, Boeing may find itself competing against some of its airline customers. Lufthansa, for example, handles heavy maintenance for more than 100 airlines. Lufthansa said it did not see Boeing conflicting with its interests unless Boeing went after some of its maintenance clients.
Other possibilities, Boeing Enterprises executives say, include managing the installation of aircraft interiors, an increasingly complex task because of the growing sophistication of in-flight video and audio systems.
Boeing officials declined to predict how much revenue Boeing Enterprises may generate in coming years. But Nicholas Heymann, an aerospace analyst at Prudential Securities, has estimated that Boeing Enterprises could take in $5 billion by 2000, with operating profit margins of about 20 to 25 percent. He also predicted that the division would grow 8 to 10 percent a year.
Boeing officials said two overarching criteria would guide Boeing Enterprises' expansion into new areas: It must know at least something about the products and their customers.
As sensible as that strategy sounds, Boeing is nevertheless adding to the challenges it faces in coming years, particularly in trying to absorb McDonnell Douglas into its corporate culture.
"The jury is still out on whether they are overreaching themselves in other business," Mr. Demisch said. "What they are attempting is pretty ambitious."
For all the challenges of the corporate strategy, though, one thing is clear: Boeing will leave behind fewer curiosities for historians. When the aircraft industry slumped in 1918 after the end of World War I, for example, Boeing tried to augment its modest plane-building business by making flat-bottomed boats called sea sleds and furniture like dressers and phonograph cases.
Boeing had hoped to sell the boats to the Navy, but they eventually wound up in the hands of private owners who bought them at a discount. And Boeing's own employees bought much of the furniture at clearance prices. According to "Legend and Legacy," a history of Boeing by Robert J. Serling, the company sent out a notice to employees that included this sales pitch: "P.S. If you have delayed getting married on account of the high price of furniture, now is the time to get a good start."
The next big push to diversify came after World War II, when Boeing's production lines for bombers were almost shut down. It considered getting into the car and household appliance businesses, but Boeing executives determined that that would be too much of a stretch even for them. The company tried the turbine engine business instead.
In the late 1960's, when business was so slow that Boeing at one point went 18 months without getting a single aircraft order, the company branched into a wide variety of businesses. It built passenger and military hydrofoils, wind-powered turbines, public transit equipment, even police radio scramblers. At one point, Boeing was planting and selling potatoes as part of an irrigation experiment.
Boeing officials said at the time that their goal was to have a third of the company's revenue coming from nontraditional areas by 1980. "We are going to respond to social needs," a Boeing official told Time magazine in 1971. "If we do not, we will be a limited company."
But as demand picked up for planes, particularly with airline deregulation in 1978, Boeing eventually left all these businesses to focus on the products and customers it knew best. In the process, it became a far narrower company, although a far more prosperous one than if it had continued pouring money into extraneous ventures.
Since then, Boeing has gone through a fundamental change, and has come to see itself as an aerospace company, rather than a company with engineering prowess that can be applied to just about anything.
One former Boeing executive who was involved in many past diversification efforts, John H. Goldie, summed up Boeing's mistakes in "Legend and Legacy," although his words serve as a warning to all companies:
"Boeing never had a strategy to diversify in any intelligent way," Mr. Goldie said. "It gets into these things on an ad hoc basis. Somebody promotes an idea and if he's reasonably capable, it'll work. But if the guy's an idiot and doesn't do any market research, it'll be a disaster."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Lawrence W. Clarkson, president of Boeing Enterprises, on the floor of the compnay's factory in Renton, Wash., where a new business jet will be made. (Larry Davis for The New York Times)(pg. D1)
 
Chart/Diagram: "Maintaining Altitude"
Over the years, Boeing has diversified to try to protect itself against downturns in the aircraft industry. But these attempts have not been commercially successful. Now it is embarking on new ventures. This time, though, Boeing's plans, such as custom fitting 737's as corporate jets, are within its area of expertise.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bonds Quiet As Greenspan Is Awaited

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Treasury prices were little changed yesterday as investors braced for Congressional testimony from Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, as well as for the Treasury's sale of $27 billion in new debt this week.
"Greenspan is a bit of a wild card tomorrow" for the bond market, said Bill Girard, who helps manage $3 billion in fixed-income assets at Scotia Capital Markets in Toronto. 
 The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 4/32, to 101 5/32. The bond's yield, which moves the opposite direction from its price, rose to 6.54 percent, from 6.52 percent on Friday.
The Fed chairman delivers his semiannual testimony on the state of the economy to the House Banking Committee today and its Senate counterpart tomorrow. His comments often set the tone for bond trading because investors look for clues to how the Fed has read the latest economic reports.
Mr. Greenspan's comments today come just an hour after the bidding deadline for the Government's sale of $15.5 billion of two-year notes. That may prompt investors to demand higher yields on the securities, in case the central bank chief says something that roils the market.
The Government will also auction $11.5 billion in five-year notes tomorrow. Wall Street firms required to bid at Treasury debt sales often drive yields higher beforehand to stir demand from investors.
"We've got to get through Greenspan's testimony" before investors grow more bullish on bonds again, said Bill Edwards, a trader at Nikko Securities Company International. "There is going to be some anxiety until then."
Many traders expect the Treasury rally, which pushed the yield on the 30-year bond down about 60 basis points since late April, to resume after the Fed chairman completes his testimony. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
Still, traders also expect Mr. Greenspan to be circumspect in his assessment of the economy so as not to fuel optimism among investors.
"The environment he would create would stimulate the economy and that could be negative in the long run," said Tony Crescenzi, head trader at Miller Tabak Hirsch & Company. "He has to sound a little bit hawkish."
In the corporate bond market, Stater Brothers Holdings Inc., the Autotote Corporation and Safety Components International -- all rated below investment grade -- raised $200 million, taking advantage of the low borrowing rates.
The Riverwood International Corporation and several other companies are expected to sell about $3 billion of debt this week.
In the municipal market, New York City plans to sell $445 million in general obligation bonds today.
In connection with its tax-exempt issue, New York City sold $75 million in taxable floating-rate notes yesterday to European investors. The securities pay interest at a rate equal to the three-month London interbank offered rate plus 25 basis points.
The Treasury sold $23.4 billion in three-month and six-month bills at its regular weekly auction. The three-month bills were sold at an average discount rate of 5.11 percent, up from 5.05 percent last week, and the six-month bills at an average rate of 5.17 percent, up from 5.09 percent. In when-issued trading yesterday, the new two-year notes were being offered at a price to yield 6.17 percent.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 5; Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: A Pulse That Lingers

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL 

 BODY:
Inflation is dead, right? After all, despite more than six years of uninterrupted economic growth and with unemployment now near the levels last enjoyed in the 1960's and early 1970's, consumer prices have risen at a mere 1.4 percent rate so far this year. And the cost of manufactured goods is actually falling.
But don't count out the old nemesis just yet. While hardly anybody is predicting apocalypse soon, there is reason to believe that unemployment is already below the rate consistent with price stability. 
 Indeed, for all the widespread economic optimism that has helped power both the stock market and President Clinton's popularity to new highs, inflation may already be creeping through the economy on little cat's feet.
Robert Gordon, a specialist on inflation at Northwestern University, warned, for example, that wage increases are being disguised as promotions. "It will take at least a year to see it happening," he said.
Inflation's prospects are also being bolstered by the likely end to the set of conditions that have helped hold it in check, such as the low price of oil and the strong dollar, which has kept imports inexpensive.
So far, the news on the inflation front has been so good that the Federal Reserve has barely nudged short-term interest rates higher this year. Indeed, despite his reputation as a inflexible inflation fighter, Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, has been willing to hold off against considerable pressure from colleagues within the Federal Reserve to raise rates much more sharply.
But when he testifies to Congress today about the outlook for the economy and monetary policy, Mr. Greenspan may give some hints about whether he thinks this rare combination of shrinking unemployment and lower inflation can continue for much longer.
To be sure, the expansion of the 1990's is nearly as old as the 1980's boom without any of the kick-up in prices that brought the last business cycle to an end. Jobs are going begging, but wages have risen only slightly; all the statistics suggest that inflation is locked tightly in its box.
Certainly some things are different and economists have revised their estimates of how low unemployment can go without setting off a new cycle of higher wages and prices. In the early 1990's, Mr. Gordon pegged this figure at slightly more than 6 percent. Now his computer model says the so-called non-accelerating inflation rate of unemployment is around 5.3 percent -- three-tenths of 1 percent above the current rate.
Good news has many fathers. Dale Jorgenson, an economist at Harvard, noted that the average worker is older and more experienced than in the late 1980's and thus easier to integrate into a new workplace without a decline in productivity. Then, too, there are more workers "at the margin" -- everyone from retirees to welfare mothers to immigrants (legal and illegal) -- who can be coaxed into the labor market without sharply raising wages.
Rudi Dornbusch, an economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, emphasizes the diminished role of unions. "There isn't anyone around to organize the pressure for wage increases that has been traditional this late in the business cycle," he said.
All in all, William Dudley, the chief United States economist at Goldman, Sachs & Company, concluded, "We've been very lucky."
But there is a dark lining in this silver cloud. The new American jobs machine, suggested Paul Krugman, an economist at M.I.T., is built on a foundation of fear. "The success of what could be called 'the intimidation economy' depends on workers worrying more about security than wages," he argued. "Being nice to the rich hasn't made much difference to the American economy, but being beastly to the poor does seem to increase efficiency."
Other factors -- some of which may be about to run their course -- have also played a role in suppressing inflation. The prices of oil, metals and other commodities have been depressed because there is considerable slack in economic activity outside the United States. And consumers have reaped the benefits of the strong dollar, which has made imports cheaper and kept import-competing manufacturers -- notably auto makers -- from raising prices.
Add, too, the sense that business is finally reaping the productivity rewards from heavy investments in computers.
But the most frequently cited factor explaining the persistence of wage and price stability has been the insecurity of workers. While the actual impact of downsizing on job tenure is debatable, the perception of increased risk is clear.
According to the Pew Research Center in Washington, just 18 percent of workers were "very concerned" they would lose their jobs in May 1988. But in October 1995 -- deep into the current economic boom -- the comparable figure was 34 percent. And it rose yet again, to 47 percent, in March 1996. "The fear lasted, even though the economy kept getting better," explained Larry Hugick, an analyst at Princeton Survey Research, which did the polling for Pew.
All this has contributed to a giddy optimism in which the old assumptions about the lack of free lunches are being challenged. Factors ranging from globalization to outsourcing to computerized inventory control have changed the fundamentals, economists say. "Competitive processes have so intensified," argued Bruce Steinberg, chief economist at Merrill Lynch & Company, "that we're looking at a world in which deflation -- not inflation -- may be the norm."
But many other economists insist that what has dubbed "the new paradigm" is little more than sound financial management by the Federal Reserve and some good luck. The rest, they argue, is wishful thinking.
Mr. Dudley, the Goldman, Sachs economist, distinguishes between changes that have fundamentally improved the trade-off between employment and price stability, and those providing only a temporary breather. Much of the recent restraint on inflation -- the strong dollar, weak commodity prices, lower costs for health insurance -- falls in the latter category.
Why, then, hasn't the pressure shown up in the wage or inflation data? Perhaps only because the pressure builds very slowly, Mr. Gordon said. Based on the experience of the last two decades, his computer model suggests that unemployment at a full percentage point less than the sustainable rate translates into an increase in inflation each year of just four-tenths of a percentage point. So if the sustainable rate is, say, 5.5 percent -- only a half-percent above the current rate -- the impact to date could easily be lost in the numbers.
Besides, Mr. Gordon added, a hard look does offer hints of inflation ahead. While the employment cost index, the Government's most comprehensive measure of wage pressure, has not budged, other measures are beginning to rise. One reason higher wages may not yet be visible in the cost index, Mr. Gordon said, is that employers are using promotions and other rewards to satisfy key workers. "A valued secretary may become an 'executive assistant' at higher pay," he said.
Of course, the only way to know for certain whether unemployment could be driven down further without igniting prices is to try. But economists are leery. "At this point," said Barry Bosworth of the Brookings Institution, "the risks are mostly on the downside."

TYPE: Economic Analysis

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

AT&T Earnings Fall But Top Expectations
AT&T reported a 38 percent plunge in second-quarter income from continuing operations, to $959 million, which it described as its "low water mark of the year." Still, its earnings were a penny above analysts' forecasts and some saw a hint of a turnabout.
AT&T's woes have been compounded by management turmoil. Last week, its president, John R. Walter, resigned under pressure, and his lawyer met with AT&T lawyers on Friday. Mr. Walter was said to have presented a list of demands in addition to the more than $26 million he is to receive. [Page D4.] 

Dow Gains; Broader Averages Fall
Though the Dow industrials gained 16.26 points, to 7,906.72, broader market averages were lower, as investors nervously awaited the semiannual Congressional testimony of Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman. The Nasdaq fell 11.76, to 1,536.23. [D8.]
 
Treasury prices were little changed, with the yield on the 30-year bond rising slightly, to 6.54 percent from 6.52. [D18.]
 
High Price for a Virginia Bank
First Union is paying a lot -- $3.25 billion -- for Signet Banking of Richmond in a deal that has sent the shares of Signet soaring. While analysts acknowledge that First Union has been good at making acquisitions pay off, they question whether Signet was the right choice for First Union as it seeks to grow in Virginia. Market Place. [D8.]
 
Exxon Profit Above Forecasts
Exxon said its earnings rose 25 percent, more than expected, as profit margins grew in its refining and chemicals businesses. [D2.]
 
Another Texas Pacific Acquisition
Texas Pacific, an investment firm led by David Bonderman, has agreed to buy Zilog, a semiconductor maker, for $527 million. [D8.]
 
Sprint Plans $425 Million Deal
Sprint, aiming to expand into the computer-network systems management business, agreed to buy Paranet for $425 million. [D6.]
 
France Raises Business Taxes
France's Government raised taxes on big business sharply in an effort to meet the strict fiscal requirements of the plan for European currency union. But it appeared that France would still fall short, furthering German fears of a weak euro. [A3.]
 
Speculation in Asian Currencies
Currency speculation continued to take a toll on South and Southeast Asian economies, as the Indonesian rupiah tumbled and interest rates were driven up in Hong Kong and Singapore. [D15.]
 
Inflation: Down, but Maybe Not Out
Despite more than six years of uninterrupted economic growth and with unemployment now near the levels last enjoyed in the 1960's and early 1970's, consumer prices have barely budged. But don't count out that old nemesis, inflation, just yet. Economic Analysis. [A1.]
 
Microsoft Stake in Net Company
Microsoft made a minority investment in Progressive Networks to help that company develop technology for audio and video broadcasts over the Internet. [D6.]
 
Coffee Prices Drop
Coffee prices fell sharply as world inventories continue to build. Roasters are also awaiting new supplies from Brazil, which is expected to harvest its largest crop in six years. [D15.]
 
Bambi? No, Batman
The traditional family film, once a lucrative staple of Hollywood's studio system, is quietly dying as the industry feeds an increasingly restless audience with bigger stars, more provocative themes and stories with an edge unheard of even a decade ago. [C9.]
 
Big Campaign for Cigar
As the white-hot premium cigar industry enters a shakeout period, H. Upmann, Consolidated Cigar's flagship premium cigar, is beginning a multimillion-dollar ad campaign intended to make sure it emerges a winner. Advertising. [D6.]

HEADLINE: German Merger Would Create Europe's No. 2 Bank in Assets

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, July 21

 BODY:
Two big German banks announced plans today for a $10 billion merger that would create one of the biggest banks in Europe and an institution with more assets than any bank in the United States.
The merger involves the two biggest banks in Bavaria, Bayerische Vereinsbank A.G. and Bayerische Hypotheken und Wechsel Bank, and is the most dramatic move so far by European banks to shore up their strength to compete in an increasingly borderless economy. 
 Bankers and analysts have been bracing for a big wave of bank mergers in Germany for at least a year. Like several other European countries, Germany has far more banks and bank branches than it needs, analysts say. That has made it progressively harder for banks to earn respectable profits and to brace against new rivals as the drive toward European unity accelerates with the planned adoption of a single currency, starting in 1999.
Though Germany's hometown banks were once able to manage with mediocre profits or growth, they now face the prospect of growing rivalry from neighboring countries and a need for more investment capital in order to serve a broader European clientele.
The new bank would have assets of $472.4 billion, second in Europe only to Deutsche Bank A.G. in Frankfurt and considerably more than the $340 billion in assets of the Chase Manhattan Corporation, the biggest American bank. The combined company will almost certainly have significantly fewer employees, as it shuts down unneeded bank branches and reduces services within others.
Executives at Bayerische Vereinsbank said the deal had been conceived in part to emulate the success of American "supra regional" banks like Nationsbank of Charlotte, N.C., and Banc One of Columbus, Ohio, which have become powerhouses by acquiring scores of smaller institutions over the last decade and shutting down overlapping branches. The two German companies, both based in Munich, predicted that within five years the merger would save them about $600 million a year, largely by cutting back on bank branches and reducing services within branches.
"We have watched very closely what is going on in the world," said Martin Hufner, chief economist at Bayerische Vereinsbank. "It is the banks like Banc One and Nationsbank that have been the fastest growing and most profitable."
In another sign of the growing influence and emulation of American financial services here, both banks were advised by the same American investment bank, J. P. Morgan, which mapped out a complex, two-step merger. Representing both sides in a merger is illegal in the United States, but not in Germany.
The deal would have a major effect on European finance by creating a major new player virtually overnight. It could also prompt more mergers and acquisitions, particularly among smaller banks.
"Europe is overbanked, and the industry is under increasing competitive pressure," said Matthew Czepliewicz, a banking analyst at Salomon Brothers in London. "This is a sign that the banks are recognizing that and are willing to act in fairly radical ways."
The competitive pressure on banks has been particularly fierce in Germany, where there are nearly twice as many bank branches per capita as in either the United States or Britain. Germany has one bank branch for every 1,500 people, compared with one for every 2,723 in the United States and one for every 2,931 in Britain.
The weight of all that infrastructure is apparent in the profitability of the two Bavarian merger partners. Both have a return on equity of about 8 percent, in contrast to a return of 20 percent or more that has been typical of American banks, according to Piers Brown, a banking analyst at UBS Securities.
"The problem that these banks all have is that they have been consuming capital at a rate far faster than they can generate it internally, so they have had to keep going back to the markets" to raise more money, Mr. Brown said.
Indeed, even today, Bayerische Vereinsbank announced that as part of the merger it would try to raise a significant amount of money -- probably more than $1 billion -- to replenish its capital after buying 45 percent of the stock of Hypobank, as its merger partner is known.
Under the proposed merger, Bayerische Vereinsbank will first buy that 45 percent stake, valued at about $4.6 billion, in exchange for shares that it owns of the German insurance company Allianz A.G.
Bayerische Vereinsbank then plans to go back to the market and raise money to shore up its financial position. Next spring, the two banks would then merge into a single entity with new stock.
The deal values Hypobank's shares at 70.8 marks each, or $39.42, based on Allianz's closing stock price today. The value of Hypobank's shares would be above the closing price of 67 marks in Frankfurt, up 8.45 marks, and the total value of the company would be 18.2 billion marks, or $10.13 billion.
Executives at Bayerische Vereinsbank said the virtue of the complicated structure was that it would protect shareholders from seeing their shares diluted. Under this plan, they said, the fully merged company would have 20 percent fewer shares than if it had executed a more conventional merger.
The question on many minds today, however, was whether more big mergers were on the horizon. Mr. Czepliewicz of Salomon Brothers said the deal would probably not set off a frenzy of deals, though it could lead to several combinations of second-tier banks in Germany or mergers by some of the country's big state-owned banks, known as Landesbanks.
Analysts also said that Germany's two biggest banks -- Deutsche Bank and Dresdner Bank -- were strong enough to proceed on their own and were probably more interested now in foreign acquisitions.
But the announcement today did prompt speculation about Germany's fourth-largest bank, Commerzbank A.G., which would be bumped to fifth place and is widely viewed as needing a new partner of some sort.
Deutsche Bank, which started much of the talk about German bank mergers last year by acquiring a 5.2 percent stake in Bayerische Vereinsbank, said it was pleased with the planned merger. Analysts said that was probably because the merger would not strengthen the hand of Commerzbank or some other powerful Frankfurt-based institution.

HEADLINE: Stocks Mostly Fall, Though Dow Is Up

BYLINE: By SHARON R. KING 

 BODY:
Stocks ended mostly lower yesterday, as nervous investors awaited the semiannual appearance of the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, before Congress. In his two days of testimony, he will detail the central bank's outlook on the economy.
Prices were also depressed, analysts said, as stocks reeled from a hangover caused by the Dow Jones industrial average's ascent above 8,000 last week and another decline in technology issues. 
 Despite the hand wringing of investors, the Dow Jones industrial average eked out a modest gain, ending up 16.26 at 7,906.72.
But the broader market indexes all ended lower, and declining issues outnumbered advancers on the New York Stock Exchange by a margin of slightly more than 2 to 1. The technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index fell 11.76, to 1,536.23, while the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks fell 2.36 points, to 912.94.
Microsoft lost more than 3 percent, finishing at 135 15/16, down 4 9/16, as investors continued to sell in the wake of what some saw as disappointing earnings for the quarter ended June 30, announced last week.
Although the earnings were in line with expectations, Microsoft is known for returns that exceed market forecasts, said Robert Stovall, president of Stovall/Twenty-First Advisers Inc. in New York.
Intel also finished lower, off 3/4, to 85 11/16.
The Pacific Stock Exchange technology index fell 3.01 points, or almost 1 percent, to 312.14.
But for the most part yesterday, equity investors were wondering what Mr. Greenspan will say today.
Several market analysts said they did not expect the Federal Reserve chairman to roil markets, given the positive combination of moderate growth and low inflation that the economy is now experiencing. But they all said Mr. Greenspan still had the ability to surprise investors and cause selloffs, as he did in December when he suggested that the market might be exhibiting "irrational exuberance." Since then, the Dow has risen nearly 24 percent.
Given how much the stock market has risen recently, said Thom R. Brown, managing director of Rutherford, Brown & Catherwood, a Philadelphia-based investment management firm, investors are "a little bit apprehensive about what Chairman Greenspan is going to say."
But he and other analysts said that if Mr. Greenspan merely said the central bank could raise interest rates if the economy grew too fast, then investors should not panic.
Among the stocks leading the Dow higher was Eastman Kodak, which rose 1 1/4, to 67 1/2. On Friday, the chairman of Kodak, George M. C. Fisher, said that he was not a candidate for the top job at AT&T.
One of the biggest gainers on the day was Signet Banking Corporation, which jumped 13 1/2, or 37 percent, to 50 3/16. First Union Corporation agreed on Sunday to buy Signet for $3.3 billion, or 3.5 times Signet's book value. The hefty premium marks one of the most expensive bank deals in history. Shares of First Union took a hit, falling 3, to 94 7/16.

HEADLINE: John E. Hines, Episcopal Leader, Dies at 86

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON 

 BODY:
The Right Rev. John Elbridge Hines, the 22d Presiding Bishop of the Episcopal Church who guided the denomination through the social turmoil of the 1960's and helped open its clerical ranks to women and blacks, died on Saturday in Austin, Tex. He was 86 and had moved to Austin from North Carolina four years ago.
Bishop Hines had been bed-ridden and in declining health since breaking several ribs in a fall last Christmas. Associates said his condition deteriorated swiftly after a stroke in recent days. 
 His commitment to social justice prompted his elevation by the Episcopal House of Bishops to spiritual head of the church's three million members in an extraordinarily disruptive period. From 1965 to 1974, he pursued profound changes in the church's structure and its outlook.
He assumed his duties as Presiding Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Church on Jan. 1, 1965, and at 54 he was the youngest man to hold that position.
As his predecessor, the Right. Rev. Arthur Lichtenberger had done, Bishop Hines kept his church in the forefront of ecumenical and civil rights movements.
He resigned at 63 in 1974, saying he was in good health but wanted to make room for a younger leader. At the time he was still pressing the church's law-giving body to allow the ordination of women as priests and bishops, an emotional issue since the 1970 convention decreed their acceptance only as deacons.
Presiding at church headquarters in Manhattan, he served as chief executive as well as pastor of the Church of St. Peter and St. Paul in Washington and representative to other denominations and the Anglican Communion.
Managing a large staff, he was accused by critics of overlooking administrative detail as he focused on social issues. He stood for liturgical renewal, the ecumenical movement and the promotion of minority members and women in church councils.
Lending a Christian perspective to the problems of racism and poverty, he responded to the urban riots of 1967 with a plan to reorder the Episcopal Church's fiscal priorities. He advocated measures to give the poor of the ghetto financial help with no strings attached, and with it political and economic independence.
His call for social justice and self-determination inspired a General Convention Special Program. Intended to purge his church of racism, the program accomplished much in the neighborhoods it served. But it was unable to enlist the rank and file and provoked dissent, leading many congregations to withhold money, which drastically reduced the church's national budget.
Bishop Hines nevertheless broke new ground in 1971 by taking his fight against racism to South Africa. He started a divestment campaign that spread to other denominations and American public and academic institutions.
Wielding the power of shareholders at annual corporation meetings, the movement persuaded some big businesses to cut back or shed their investments in apartheid-era South Africa. Bishop Desmond Tutu of South Africa said the movement played an important role in the demise of apartheid.
Bishop Hines brought the Office of the Presiding Bishop to its highest level of centralization. Many objected, but he never wavered in his conviction that the church had to take an uncompromising stand for the poor and defenseless and serve as an inspiration for others to do so.
When he left office before the end of his term, The Christian Century said he "remained astride the bucking bronco of a polarized church during one of the most controversial decades of American history." Many blamed him for drops in church membership, but since his retirement more national and local Episcopal bodies have engaged in the kind of social outreach ministries he propagated.
Bishop Hines was born in Seneca, S.C., and excelled in academics, athletics and student leadership at the University of the South. He graduated from Virginia Theological Seminary in Alexandria and filled his first ministry at the depth of the Depression in St. Louis.
There he came under the spell of Bishop Will Scarlett, one of the Episcopal preachers of a "Social Gospel" that sought to imbue American society with Christian values.
He was sent at age 26 to Georgia, where he attacked racism while starting his lifelong defense of those who lacked political, economic, social and educational opportunities. He moved to Houston in 1941 as rector of the Church of Christ and a builder of nationally reputed institutions, including a seminary, college chaplaincies and 41 new congregations. He became Bishop of Texas in 1955, and led his diocese through a racial integration of its institutions.
In retirement, he lived for nearly 20 years in North Carolina, staying out of the spotlight but occasionally preaching, lecturing and taking part in the consecration of bishops.
He was married to Helen Orwig, with whom he had four sons and a daughter, who survive. Helen Hines died last year.

HEADLINE: Learning to Love a Disaster;
The Edsel, With All Its Quirks, Is Hailed as It Turns 40

BYLINE: By JAMES BARRON 

DATELINE: MIDDLESEX, N.J., July 19

 BODY:
Ted Girvan would not let anyone else drive his: the muffler is loose. Richard Jump worried about how much gas was left in his: the fuel gauge is broken. Bruce Paterson finally got the passenger-side door on his to stay shut: it did not close on the first try. Or the second, the third or the fourth.
"It takes a special finesse to close the door on an Edsel," Mr. Paterson said. 
 Only someone who enjoys shifting with a clunky push-button transmission would use the word "finesse" in the same sentence as "Edsel," or spend a Saturday afternoon at a picnic for a dozen hard-core members of the Garden State chapter of the Edsel Owners Club and the International Edsel Club. (Yes, there are two different organizations devoted to an automobile that has not been made for 37 years, and that became a chrome-laden dinosaur almost as soon as it rolled off the assembly line. One owner's group has scheduled its annual national convention for next week in Orlando, Fla., the other the following week in Spartanburg, S.C.)
As Edsel owners know only too well, the Edsel was a flop of such colossal proportions that its name quickly became synonymous with failure. It was not simply another road monster that hit the streets in the days of giant, gleaming tail fins and gas-guzzling engines that came in two sizes -- large and larger -- but the most spectacular failure from the Big Three automobile makers in the go-go years after World War II.
It had been introduced in 1957 with an expensive publicity campaign that included everything from full-color magazine advertisements to an hourlong television special starring Frank Sinatra, Louis Armstrong, Bing Crosby and Rosemary Clooney. Edsels, which sold for between $2,200 and $4,000 and could seat six people in near-Barcalounger comfort, were supposed to compete with General Motors's mid-priced lines.
But after being on the market for only about three years, the Edsel was dropped. America had taken a look at the oval-shaped front grille and couldn't decide: was it more like a horse collar, a fish's mouth or, as Time magazine put it, "an Oldsmobile sucking a lemon"? The country snickered and and stayed out of the showrooms; psychologists declared the Edsel emotionally displeasing. Ford, Edsel's parent company, is said to have lost at least $125 million on its ungainly offspring, named after Henry Ford's only son.
Now, though, as Edsel owners prepare to celebrate the car's 40th anniversary, they seem to be having the last laugh. They love their cars -- the 5,000 or so that are still out there somewhere. They have learned to live with the ribbing they take from friends or relatives. They even repeat Edsel jokes, like the one Mr. Jump relayed today at the picnic at Mr. Girvan's house here. "God said, 'I gave them control of the air, the sea and the land, and what did they do? The Hindenburg, the Titanic and the Edsel.' "
But their passion is so all-consuming that they do not find Edsel jokes funny, their devotion so complete that the women among them talk about painting little E's on their fingernails. They are not dismayed by headlights that flicker, engines that overheat and transmissions that have been known to shift from forward to reverse without warning, while the car is moving.
And when the Edsel name is used in the same breath as other failures, they get angry.
When Plumbing and Heating magazine referred to a newly introduced product as "the Edsel of bathroom fixtures," Mr. Paterson, who is 46 and works for a plumbing and heating contractor in Garwood, N.J., grabbed pen and paper. "I actually wrote a letter saying, 'I take offense,' " he said.
And as for a Dunkin' Donuts commercial now seen on late-night television that shows the devil in the driver's seat of an Edsel?
"We're insulted," he said.
Some automobile historians say that Edsel owners have every right to be. "We've committed greater follies than the Edsel," said Jane Holtz Kay, the author of "Asphalt Nation: How the Automobile Took Over America, and How We Can Take It Back" (Crown Publishers, 1997). The Corvair? The DeLorean?
Michael Marsden, a dean at Northern Michigan University in Marquette, goes even further, arguing that the Edsel does not deserve its besmirched reputation. "Depends on who you talk to, of course, but design-wise, it was a car ahead of its time," he said. "It had a lot of good innovations in it." Edsel owners say the forward-thinking included a speedometer that could be set to warn the driver when he was speeding and idiot lights that later replaced gauges on other cars with one- or two-word messages like "service engine" or "door ajar."
Mr. Marsden said the Edsel's real problem was bad timing. "Had it come a little bit earlier or a little bit later, the car would have been a huge success." But it was introduced in a recession. A month after dealers began selling Edsels, the Soviet Union launched the first Sputnik satellite, catching the United States unprepared in the space race. Some sociologists say that because it was a behemoth that suffered from infamously poor workmanship, the Edsel fell victim to national soul-searching that followed Sputnik.
As if that were not enough, there are Edsel owners who find bitter irony in the fact that the man they hold responsible for the Edsel's demise went on to become a principal architect of American policy in Southeast Asia during the early years of the Vietnam War. Before he went to Washington, Robert S. McNamara, who was the Secretary of Defense in the Kennedy and Johnson Administrations, had been a top executive at Ford. Edsel owners maintain that Mr. McNamara was no fan of the Edsel.
"Well, they're right," Mr. McNamara said in a telephone interview. But, he added, "Any of those who claim I irrationally caused its death had better go back and read history. There was absolutely no way it could have been saved, nor should it have been saved. It was a disaster."
Mr. Girvan is reluctant to admit it, but even he concedes that Mr. McNamara -- who shepherded the smaller Ford Falcon into being -- might have been on to something. "When you figure that the smallest Edsel engine got 8 miles per gallon," Mr. Girvan said, "that was a problem."
Other cars from the 1950's have become increasingly pricey collectors' items -- the 1953 Chevrolet Corvette and 1957 Ford Thunderbird, for example. But the Edsel, whose value as a used car in the 1960's lagged behind other cars from the 1950's, is still a relatively poor investment. "A lot of people think because you've got an Edsel, it's worth a lot of money," said Mr. Jump, a 36-year-old cook who was born 18 months after Ford stopped making Edsels. "It's still an Edsel. I call it the poor man's collector's car."
His own 1959 station wagon has had seven owners. Once it was raffled off, only to be rejected by the winner. Its next owner disconnected the battery and left it in a garage for 16 years, where Mr. Jump found it four years ago. It was his second Edsel. He already had a 1959 two-door hardtop.
"Even as a little kid, I always wanted an Edsel," he said. "For a long time my family would rib me on it, asking why I was putting all this money into this old car. I said, 'Look, I could have been an alcoholic, I could have been a gambler, I could have been into drugs. I can look at the car and know where the money's gone.' "
But on Saturday, he indulged in his Edsel obsession, trading leads on where to find windshield wiper blades, turn signals and tailpipes while Edsel club members had hamburgers and hot dogs at Mr. Girvan's house. Unlike Mr. Jump, some members were original owners. Dominick Rullo of East Brunswick, N.J., bought a 1959 convertible when it was brand new -- his car payment was $26 a month.
Four years later, he made what he still considers the big mistake: he sold it, for $200, to a cousin who junked it within six months. It took 20 years, but he finally found the blue-and-white Edsel he has now. The price: $4,500.
Mr. Girvan, who spent $1,200 to buy his car and $1,100 to have it shipped here from Champaign, Ill., has spent more than $10,000 restoring it, including a $3,000 paint job. Some Edsel parts are expensive. Mr. Girvan said that a hood ornament -- a chrome circle with an E in the center -- sold recently for $600 in Las Vegas.
To spend a couple of hours with a dozen Edsel owners is to take a crash course in automotive trivia. It is to understand why the owners of 1958 Edsels disdain the 1959's, the owners of 1959's disdain the 1958's, and the owners of the few 1960's that were manufactured have little use for the others. (All that really needs to be said is, the parts are not interchangeable.)
Edsels did not come in just any colors, they came in "president red" or "chalk pink." Mr. Girvan's hardtop, parked proudly on the lawn in front of his split-level house, is "spruce green metallic," a dark green that looks bluish from a certain angle, with "ice green" trim.
And then there is Roy Knapp's 9-passenger station wagon, with seats that seem as wide as some living-room sofas. The car, he said, is "jet stream blue" and "snow white" -- "without the dwarfs," he said, "though they could all fit in there."

U.S. Study Criticizes China On Restraining Christianity
In its report on persecution of Christian groups around the world, the State Department has criticized China for suppressing religious worship and urged President Boris Yeltsin of Russia to protect his country's newly gained religious freedom. A1 

France Raises Corporate Tax
Vowing that France would qualify for the European Monetary Union, the Socialist Government raised taxes for big businesses after an audit showed that this year's budget deficit would exceed the 3 percent of gross domestic product set as a criterion for joining the European Union's planned single currency. The increase will apply to this year and 1998, said Finance Minister Dominique Strauss-Kahn, who added that defense spending cuts would help fill the rest of the budget gap. A3
 
Ulster Leader Angry With Blair
David Trimble, leader of Northern Ireland's largest Protestant party, met with Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain, whose Government he had hours before accused of "duplicity on a massive scale." Mr. Trimble's Ulster Unionists were angry that the Irish Republican Army had not been asked to surrender "a single bullet" as a condition of participating in peace talks through their political wing, Sinn Fein. A8
 
Mir Repairs Await Next Crew
Russian space officials said the next crew on the space station Mir would "stamp their feet" on the damaged Spektr module during an exterior spacewalk in order to locate its depressurized points. They also said that Michael Foale, an American astronaut, would not take part in an internal spacewalk to reattach damaged power cables inside Spektr. A8
 
Canadian Boats Block Ferry
More than 100 Canadian fishermen concerned about salmon populations ignored a court order and refused to allow an American ferry to leave a port in British Columbia. They were protesting what they consider salmon "rustling" by Alaskan fishermen, in violation of a treaty drafted to preserve salmon stocks. A6
 
Arafat Orders Police Arrested
The Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, has ordered the arrest and investigation of several of his police officers. Israel and Washington had pressured him to take action after Israeli forces apprehended three Palestinian officers with guns and grenades preparing to attack Jewish motorists on a road in the West Bank. A6
 
186 Kurds Seek Asylum in Italy
The 186 Kurds seized by Italian police officials off the coast of Sicily have requested asylum in Italy, the police said. The Kurds, whose requests the police said would be considered after interviews, were among 350 immigrants from various Asian countries who tried to row ashore in dinghies from a Turkish ship last week. Five Turkish crew members were arrested on charges of trafficking illegal immigrants. (Reuters)

Gingrich Says He Plans To Stay Put as Speaker

Change in Drug Law Urged
Attorney General Janet Reno and General Barry R. McCaffrey, the White House's director of national drug control policy, have recommended to President Clinton that the gap between mandatory Federal sentences for possessing crack cocaine and powder cocaine be significantly narrowed. Congress first created the sentencing disparity in response to voter fears prompted by a wave of violence by dealers competing to sell crack. But critics have attacked the disparity, saying it puts far more blacks than whites behind bars for five years or longer. A1

Faster-Than-Light Experiment
A twin-photon experiment last month was the most spectacular demonstration yet of the mysterious long-range connections that exist between quantum events, which in theory can reach instantaneously from one end of the universe to the other. HEADLINE: New Jersey Daily Briefing;
Court Curbs Tax on Business

BYLINE: By TONY MARCANO 

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
In a unanimous decision, the State Supreme Court ruled yesterday that business equipment and machinery cannot be taxed by cities and towns.
The ruling stemmed from a long battle between the City of Linden and General Motors Corporation, which sued the city for what it considered high tax assessments from 1983 to 1985 on its automobile plant. The state's highest court upheld an appeals court decision that the 1992 Business Retention Act, which says that equipment necessary to operate a business is exempt from local property taxes, does not violate the State Constitution. 
 The ruling was hailed by Joan Verplanck, the president of the New Jersey Chamber of Commerce, who said it would have been "disastrous" for economic development efforts had the court struck down the Business Retention Act. Edward J. Kologi, the city attorney for Linden, declined to comment.

HEADLINE: Upstate Glass Plant Agrees To Give Up Pollution Credits

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: ALBANY, July 21

 BODY:
State and Federal environmental officials have reached a tentative agreement with a major glass manufacturer that will require the company to significantly reduce pollution at a new plant in central New York and return to the state hundreds of thousands of dollars worth of so-called pollution credits.
The settlement removes a major obstacle for the company, Guardian Industries of Auburn Hills, Mich., to open a $120 million, 250-employee glass plant next year in Geneva, about 60 miles west of Syracuse. But the agreement, which was prompted in large part by a lawsuit brought by opponents of the plant, does not resolve a debate over whether the state should be giving away pollution credits to help companies expand or open within its borders. 
 Earlier this year, the Pataki administration gave the company 150 pollution credits, worth between $150,000 and $450,000, as an incentive to build the plant in Geneva. Under the Federal Clean Air Act of 1990, manufacturing plants must acquire a certain amount of the credits from other companies before they open. Guardian was having trouble purchasing enough credits on the open market until the state stepped in and provided some of its own.
The credits are awarded to companies or government agencies that keep their pollution below Federal limits, and they can be sold or traded on the open market. The credits essentially give companies permission to pollute.
Some environmental groups and Democratic legislators contend that the state should not be giving away its credits, but retiring them permanently to reduce future pollution. Indeed, the Atlantic States Legal Foundation, a nonprofit group, said today that it was suing the state to prevent it from giving away pollution credits as an economic incentive.
Under the agreement announced today, Guardian will return 125 of the 150 pollution credits to the state, said Gary Sheffer, a spokesman for the State Department of Environmental Conservation. The state can now turn around and give those credits to other companies seeking to expand or open here. The remaining 25 credits will be held by Guardian until the Geneva plant closes, when the credits must be returned to the state. The provision effectively retires the 25 credits for the lifetime of the plant, estimated at 40 years.
The settlement also calls for Guardian to reduce its emissions of nitrogen oxide, a component of smog and possibly acid rain, by 30 percent of the amount originally authorized by the state. It will set the strictest standard for nitrogen oxide emissions by a glass plant in the country and will become a national benchmark for future emission permits, New York and Federal environmental officials said.
