HEADLINE: AT LUNCH WITH: Sheila Lukins;
Only in the Kitchen Are There No Letdowns

BYLINE: By ALEX WITCHEL 

 BODY:
SHEILA LUKINS fits best in the kitchen.
When she walks through the other rooms in her sprawling apartment at the Dakota, the ceilings are so very tall and she is so very short (five feet) you can easily imagine the place as a duplex. The formality of those rooms, despite their abundance of chintz, seems at odds with this intense, almost austere presence in black pants, white shirt and dark hair. 
 But in the kitchen, the woman who was a co-founder of the Silver Palate food shop in Manhattan, who conceived the recipes for five cookbooks that have more than 5.5 million copies in print, seems to grow. In spite of the requisite equipment -- professional grill, professional stove -- the room feels personal enough to be a teen-ager's bedroom. A picture of Elvis, a pitcher filled with sunflowers and two stuffed Campbell Kids dolls reside on the windowsill. On the counter is an array of bottles filled with olive oil, some greenish, some gold, some full, some not, clustered the way other women gather perfumes on the vanity; all at the ready, the perfect one waiting, to suit her mood. Or more important, her mouth.
"I feel so cozy in my kitchen," she says. "It's so familiar."
Cozy, however, is not the feeling Ms. Lukins exudes. It's more tense. Intense. Settled among the chintz in the living room, she shoots up when asked a simple question about why she covers the pan while frying chicken. Trekking down the hallway, she summons her assistant, Laurie Griffith, with an almost grim determination to prove, in stereo, that the chicken will not turn soggy. O.K., O.K. It was just a question.
"I take everything very seriously," Ms. Lukins says.
You would think that at 54, having established herself as a pre-eminent home chef and cookbook author (co-author of the Silver Palate books with her former partner, Julee Rosso), with her two daughters grown and happy and an apartment as big as Nebraska, she could take a little chicken in stride.
But things are not all they seem. In 1991, while Ms. Lukins was in her kitchen cooking a dinner for a charity event, she developed an excruciating headache, which caused her to lie down. She woke up in the hospital after suffering a cerebral hemorrhage so severe she was expected to die. The entire left side of her body was paralyzed and she developed an infection in her skull, which required a second operation. Finally, she landed at the Burke Rehabilitation Center in White Plains, where she spent three months relearning how to feed and dress herself.
The hemorrhage came while Ms. Lukins was in the midst of her first solo effort, "All Around the World Cookbook" (Workman, 1994), and although she could barely walk while recovering, she insisted on traveling to 33 countries to conduct research, accompanied by Ms. Griffith or her husband, Richard Lukins. She was in such bad shape that when she went to food markets in India or Morocco, she jokes, "they didn't know whether to ask me for money or give me money."
Still, she finished the book only three months past deadline. She then embarked on her newest, "U.S.A. Cookbook" (Workman, $19.95), which she describes as a celebration of American regional cooking. It was published in April, and 255,000 copies are already in print.
Yes, the story is a triumph, but at a price. Though Ms. Lukins can walk by herself now, her gait is a bit lopsided. She has not regained full use of her left hand, despite an experimental treatment at Baylor University in Houston, which fitted her for a wire-mesh glove that gives electric shocks to stimulate the nerve endings. And she and her husband have separated. Suddenly, tense makes sense.
"You ask me any question and I'll answer the way I answer," she proclaims.
Fair enough. Is it time for lunch yet?
Ms. Lukins and Ms. Griffith have prepared a gorgeous spread on the kitchen table, all from "U.S.A. Cookbook" recipes, and it tastes as good as it looks. It is almost impossible not to eat the entire plate of deviled eggs. Pulled pork in a burnished red sauce is also wonderful, served with homemade Parker House rolls, potato salad, picnic slaw and homemade bread-and-butter pickles. How Ms. Lukins stays so tiny is a mystery.
There's a smile. "Both Laurie and I taste," she says. "We don't eat that much. When I'm traveling, though, I do what it takes, and sometimes that means arches, if you know what I mean." The smile gets bigger. "They have great french fries."
She serves herself picnic slaw. Did she use a mandoline to get the vegetables so thin?
"No," she says emphatically. "I cut with a knife. I don't much go for gadgets. I have a Waring blender, coffee maker, juicer and an ice-cream maker. I'm pared down. We just test everything like crazy. I will kill myself to get a recipe right."
She will?
"Sheila is the Rodney Dangerfield of food," says Clark Wolf, a food and restaurant consultant in New York whose recipe for bruschetta is in "The New Basics Cookbook" (Workman, 1989). "She didn't get no respect. Because she and Julee wrote books that were fun and easy and accessible and sold millions of copies, all the food historians whose books sell 6,000 copies got very cranky.
"Sheila made a significant contribution for women who want to make a special meal and still be at the office at 9 the next morning. But it's taken a long time to get respect, as populist things do."
Even more populist than her books is Ms. Lukins's position as the food editor of Parade magazine, with a readership of 83 million, a job she inherited from Julia Child in 1986 and shared with Ms. Rosso until 1991. When Ms. Lukins ran a contest for best one-pot meal in 1995, she got 15,000 entries -- and tested most of them. The recipe for the winner, Wisconsin Cassoulet, which is made with maple syrup and brown sugar, is included in "U.S.A. Cookbook."
In a telephone interview, Julia Child said: "Sheila Lukins is a very, very good cook. I'm a home cook, too, so I think they're the best." While Miss Child said that she owned all of Ms. Lukins's cookbooks, she hastened to add: "I only use my own. But Sheila is right at the top of her career, a tremendous success. She should be very proud of herself."
Sheila Lukins was born in Philadelphia, grew up in Westport, Conn., and graduated from New York University with a degree in art education. When her husband's security guard business took him to London in the early 1970's, she went, too, studying at the Cordon Bleu while doing freelance graphic design for theatrical productions. The couple moved to Paris for a year, where she continued her studies.
After returning to New York, she opened the Other Woman Catering Company. Ms. Rosso, then an advertising executive, hired Ms. Lukins to cater a corporate breakfast. The two joined forces in 1977 and rented a Columbus Avenue storefront for $400 a month, and Ms. Lukins spent her days cooking Silver Palate dishes in her Dakota kitchen and running them over to the store. In 1988, the pair sold the business, which, besides the cookbooks, spawned a line of prepared foods like salad dressings and chutneys.
Last spring, Ms. Lukins signed on with United Airlines to upgrade its economy class meals, devising 17 regional entrees from her "U.S.A. Cookbook," including Shaker cranberry brisket and backyard barbecued roast beef. Robert Sobczewski, manager of on-board service for United, says: "Our food ratings are significantly up. They have exceeded our highest expectations."
What is most important to Ms. Lukins about the "U.S.A. Cookbook," she says, is that "it's about local ingredients, American ingredients." She continues: "There is no foie gras, and not a drop of lemon grass. I ate in diners and luncheonettes. When we went to Louisiana we didn't go to New Orleans. We went to Lafayette and danced with boys named Doris, eating in zydeco clubs."
For dessert, she has made chocolate pudding with homemade whipped cream. "Just a bite," she orders, knowing it will turn into more. It is spectacular.
The phone rings. It is Ms. Lukins's publicity agent, checking in. The author is on a short break from a daunting three-month book tour that is taking her everywhere, from bookstores to food fairs in 40 American cities. "Ever since I was sick, I really don't travel alone," she says. "I check into some hotels at 1 A.M. and have to get up at 4 A.M. to do a 5 A.M. TV show. I would say I need company for moral support alone, but the physicality is just impossible."
She looks out the kitchen window for a few minutes without speaking. She looks as though she might cry.
"I wrote about my illness in Parade and got letters from thousands of people who needed help," she says. "I sent a number of people to my program at Baylor. Those people are better now. I can only imagine that is why I got sick. To help other people. Why else would someone get sick at the height of their career, the height of their family? When I was in a wheelchair, one man wouldn't let me in his store. You can't imagine how lucky we are when we are whole. I was never empathic before. I am now."
But did she have to push herself quite so hard and quite so fast to finish her "All Around the World Cookbook?" Why didn't she ease up a little?
"My career has never let me down," she says softly. "It's the only thing in my life, except my children, that hasn't. Everything else has, including my health. Work is a constant. It gave me my independence back. I hated being dependent on everybody else when I was ill. I was so driven because I couldn't stand it. I used to dream I was fine, and then I'd wake up and it would be so horrible. I had such a great life, and I didn't want to get better and have a different life. I wanted not only to be alive but to have the same kind of life."
Her voice is rough. "If having a brain hemorrhage didn't kill me, then nothing will kill me," she says. "It was completely a fluke. I must have had 20 M.R.I.'s since then and they're completely normal, as if nothing had happened."
Beside being the year of her illness, 1991 was also the last time she spoke to Ms. Rosso. In a much-publicized fallout, Ms. Rosso, who moved to Michigan after the sale of the Silver Palate and started a newsletter, wrote to her subscribers that the publication was late because of Ms. Lukins's illness. Ms. Lukins was not connected to the newsletter, and when she protested, Ms. Rosso claimed that an assistant had written the comments and signed her name without her knowing it.
Ms. Lukins sighs. "It was really unfortunate for it to end so unpleasantly," she says. "It was so unnecessary, so silly. But there was no question when we did 'The New Basics' that that would be our last project together. We both wanted out of the Silver Palate, to have our own lives."
Ms. Lukins says she is not sure what her next book will be. She is still in love with her "U.S.A." food, as evidenced by an exploration of her refrigerator.
Hellman's Mayonnaise. Heinz Ketchup. A-1 sauce. Philadelphia Cream Cheese. Hershey's Chocolate Syrup.
Oh. It looks like everyone else's.
Finally, a laugh. "Mine is not a chef's book," she says. "It's a Sheila book."
 
These recipes are adapted from Sheila Lukins's "U.S.A. Cookbook."
 
All-American Deviled Eggs
Total time: 45 minutes

 6 large eggs
 1 teaspoon Dijon mustard
 1 to 2 dashes Tabasco sauce, to taste
 Salt, to taste
 1/4 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper
 1 tablespoon snipped fresh chives
 3 tablespoons mayonnaise
 Paprika, for garnish
 Whole fresh chives, for garnish.
 
 1. Rinse eggs with warm water, and place in a small saucepan. Cover with cold water, place the pan over medium-high heat and bring to a boil. Reduce heat to a simmer, and cook for exactly 13 minutes. Drain, rinse under cold water and peel. Cool in the refrigerator, loosely covered, for 15 minutes.
 2. Halve eggs lengthwise, and carefully scoop out yolks. Place yolks in a bowl, and mash with a fork. Add mustard, Tabasco, salt, pepper and snipped chives. Stir in mayonnaise.
 3. Fill each egg white with about 1 1/2 teaspoons of the egg-yolk mixture and dust the top with paprika. Arrange in a spoke design on a platter; garnish with whole chives.
 Yield: 12 halves.
 Approximate nutritional analysis per serving: 65 calories, 6 grams fat, 110 milligrams cholesterol, 60 milligrams sodium (before salting), 3 grams protein, 0 grams carbohydrate.
 
North Carolina-Style
Pulled Pork Barbecue
Total time: 4 1/2 hours
 
 5 to 6 cups barbecue sauce (recipe follows)
 2 tablespoons olive oil
 4 pounds pork butt
 8 soft rolls or slices of white bread.
 
 1. Prepare the barbecue sauce the day before cooking the meat.
 2. Preheat the oven to 275 degrees.
 3. In a large (6- to 8- quart) ovenproof casserole or flameproof roasting pan, heat oil over medium-high heat. Add meat, and brown on all sides, about 8 minutes a side. Remove meat and wipe out casserole.
 4. Place a rack in the bottom of the casserole. Put the meat on the rack, and cover with 2 1/2 cups barbecue sauce. Cover and cook for about 4 hours, basting occasionally, until the internal temperature of the thickest part of the meat reaches 150 to 180 degrees. Remove from oven, and set aside to cool.
 5. Gently heat remaining barbecue sauce. When meat is cool enough to handle, trim and discard fat. Shred meat coarsely by hand, or pull it with two forks. Put shredded meat in a large bowl, and toss with warmed sauce. Serve on rolls or slices of white bread, with coleslaw and bread-and-butter pickles on the side.
 Approximate nutritional analysis per serving: 680 calories, 25 grams fat, 110 milligrams cholesterol, 715 milligrams sodium (before salting barbecue sauce), 50 grams protein, 65 grams carbohydrate.
 
Barbecue Sauce
 Time: 3 hours, plus refrigeration

 2 28-ounce cans Italian plum tomatoes, chopped, with their juices
 1/2 cup unsulfered molasses
 1/2 cup honey
 1/4 cup tomato paste
 2 tablespoons coarsely chopped garlic
 2 bay leaves
 2 tablespoons ground cumin
 1 teaspoon cracked black pepper
 1 1/2 teaspoons crushed red pepper flakes
 4 cups water
 1 1/3 cups cider vinegar
 Salt, to taste.
 
 1. In a large heavy pot, place the tomatoes with their juices, molasses, honey, tomato paste, garlic, bay leaves, cumin, black pepper and red pepper flakes. Bring to a boil. Reduce heat and simmer, uncovered, for about 1 1/2 hours, until very thick.
 2. Add the water and vinegar, and return to a boil. Reduce heat and simmer, uncovered, for an additional 1 1/2 hours. Remove and discard bay leaves, and season with salt. Cool, cover and refrigerate overnight.
 
Double Dip of Chocolate Pudding
Total time: 30 minutes, plus chilling

 1/2 cup sugar
 3 tablespoons unsweetened cocoa powder
 2 1/2 tablespoons cornstarch
 Pinch of salt
 1 large egg plus 2 yolks
 2 cups milk
 4 ounces best-quality semisweet chocolate, chopped
 2 tablespoons unsalted butter
 1 teaspoon instant espresso powder
 1 teaspoon vanilla extract.
 
 1. Combine sugar, cocoa powder, cornstarch and salt.
 2. Whisk egg and yolks together in a small bowl. Add sugar mixture, and whisk to a smooth paste. Set aside.
 3. Scald milk in medium heavy saucepan over medium heat. Remove from heat immediately. Add 1/2 cup hot milk to egg mixture; whisk until smooth. Slowly pour this mixture back into saucepan with the hot milk. Whisk constantly until smooth.
 4. Place saucepan over medium heat, and cook, whisking constantly, until thickened, 5 to 7 minutes. Remove from heat, add chopped chocolate, butter, instant coffee and vanilla. Continue whisking until smooth.
 5. Scrape the pudding into four individual serving dishes or one bowl. Cool to room temperature, cover with plastic wrap, and refrigerate until chilled, 1 hour or more. Serve with cream, whipped or plain.
 Yield: 4 servings.
 Approximate nutritional analysis per serving: 435 calories, 25 grams fat, 190 milligrams cholesterol, 115 milligrams sodium, 10 grams protein, 55 grams carbohydrate.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Surges Against Mark As Greenspan Soothes Traders

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar surged to its highest level against the German mark in six years yesterday, buoyed by soothing remarks from Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, and a growing perception that Europe's planned single currency would be broad based and weak.
Mr. Greenspan told a House Banking subcommittee that United States growth appeared to be slowing and that he was confident of modest inflation through the end of 1997. 
 His remarks sent stock and bond prices sharply higher and lifted an already soaring dollar above the 1.82 mark threshold for the first time since August 1991.
"The risk was that Greenspan would come back and say there was a chance of increasing inflation," said Lizbeth Goldberg, assistant vice president of foreign exchange at Bayerische Hypotheken und Wechselbank. "He did not say that, the bond and stock market took off, and the dollar just followed."
In late trading in New York, the dollar rose to 1.8240 marks, up 1.5 percent from 1.7965 marks on Monday and the strongest level since July 1991. But the dollar fell to 115.15 yen, from 116.15 yen on Monday. The pound rose to $1.6790 from $1.6785.
Mr. Greenspan's remarks added additional fuel to a dollar rally against the mark, which began overseas because of mounting doubts about the strength of Europe's planned common currency, the euro.
These doubts increased on Monday, when a French budget audit showed that the country would fail to bring its budget deficit to within 3 percent of gross domestic product -- a required level for countries participating in the introduction of the euro.
Yesterday, German officials appeared to welcome French plans to increase corporate taxes and cut spending in order to get closer to the 3 percent target, while shrugging off the importance of meeting that precise level.
Without German insistence on a strict interpretation of the criteria for monetary union, many fear that a large number of countries will qualify, leading to a weak euro.
These fears were exacerbated when a Bundesbank council member, Hans-Jurgen Kobnick, told German radio yesterday that the euro could be stable even if Germany and France missed the targets.

HEADLINE: Immigration Angst

BYLINE: By Alan Wolfe; Alan Wolfe is a professor of sociology and political science at Boston University and author of the forthcoming "One Nation, After All," about middle-class morality.

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
Long before gays in the military became a political issue, Americans had adopted a "don't ask, don't tell" approach to illegal immigration. Immigrants did not tell because they did not want to be noticed. And the rest of us didn't ask because we knew the details of their passage would turn our stomachs. Some illegal immigrants would eventually realize the American dream, and then their story could be celebrated. But the American dream was not supposed to include forced labor.
The tales emerging out of New York of Mexican immigrants held in virtual bondage force us to confront realities of illegal immigration we would rather avoid. But now that we know what illegal immigration can mean, what exactly should we do? 
 Those who have always had their doubts about immigration will surely find in the news from Queens confirmation of their fears that immigrants undermine the American way of life. Ask those who hold this view what the American way of life actually means and they will often respond that it involves speaking English, working hard and believing in God. To this can be added living in freedom. That immigration has brought to our shores the kind of peonage abolished in this country long ago would seem to confirm the belief that allowing indiscriminate entry into the United States would corrupt our most fundamental values.
For defenders of immigration, by contrast, it was only a matter of time before someone, seeing the profits to be made by employing illegals as gardeners or shopping-bag packers, got the idea of making money by forcing them to peddle trinkets in the subways. To people who maintain this perspective, those who smuggled the Mexicans to New York City are different from agribusiness companies that employ illegal immigrants only in degree; both thrive by finding the cheapest workers they can. And workers cannot come cheaper than the truly desperate: deaf mutes, already cut off from the hearing world around them, condemned to obedience in a land not their own.
From this viewpoint, the lesson to be learned from Queens is that illegal immigrants are especially vulnerable to exploitation, which can be remedied only by allowing all immigrants to remain in the country legally.
Stories contrasting the wealth and opportunity of the United States with the downtrodden struggling against odds to make it here touch a nerve among Americans. Before the Mexicans there was the Golden Venture, the ship smuggling Chinese immigrants that ran aground off Queens four years ago.
But the very emotional power of these tales suggests why we should avoid drawing too many conclusions from them. Immigration policy is too important to the politics, economics and culture of the United States to be made by anecdote.
Moved by the plight of people barely capable of communicating their distress, we might decide that the nation has a humanitarian duty to help the vulnerable, especially those attracted to this country by the opportunities it offers. That would be a wrong conclusion. This was not, after all, a tale of wealthy Americans exploiting helpless immigrants, but of one group of immigrants exploiting another in a country to which neither belonged. Headlines in Mexican newspapers screamed about slavery in New York, ignoring the fact that their bosses were just as Mexican as the peons.
But even more important, sainthood is for saints, not policy makers. Just because people suffered greatly to get here, and then suffered even more after they arrived, is not by itself reason to allow them to stay. A society that extends its obligations to everyone extends them to no one. So long as some of our fellow citizens are in need -- and who can doubt that some of them are? -- they must have first claim on our conscience. Sympathy has to be rationed. As much as our hearts go out to people as vulnerable and exploited as the Mexican trinket sellers, our heads must insist that they be returned to their country.
Yet we would also be wrong to conclude from the events in Queens that we ought to be hard-nosed realists and close our borders. Immigrants have rejuvenated the American work ethic. Many of them are deeply religious, and they have re-invigorated American religious life. And they have brought vitality to many American cities. Several new American citizens were born to the deaf illegal immigrants in Queens. They may wind up being the fortunate in this unrelenting tale of misfortune.
At least in this country, conditions so alien to freedom do not survive once exposed to the light of day. Yet what happened in New York City is not a parable of evil or compassion. It is not a parable of anything. The very aspects of the story that make it newsworthy also make it atypical. We would be wise to allow the gut-wrenching emotional impact of these recent events to pass before deciding whether to tighten or further open our borders.

HEADLINE: Caterpillar Profit Advances 16% On Record Results for Quarter

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: PEORIA, Ill., July 22

 BODY:
Caterpillar Inc., the world's largest maker of tractors and construction equipment, today posted a 16 percent profit gain for the second quarter, exceeding expectations.
Caterpillar said sales and earnings in the quarter were its highest ever and forecast moderately higher results for the second half, compared with a year earlier. It said the world economic outlook continued to improve, but said it expected demand to weaken in Europe and Japan. 
 Even a forecast of moderate growth was "very extensive, very upbeat and for a second-quarter release very unusual for these guys to do," J. Blair Brumley, an analyst at Dain Bosworth Inc., said.
Earnings climbed 16 percent, to $435 million, or $1.15 a share, from $374 million, or 97 cents a share, a year earlier. The prior year's results were adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split.
The earnings surpassed analysts' expectations of $1.09 a share. But Caterpillar shares fell 56.25 cents, to $56.1875, as investors took profits following a strong run-up in the stock.
Caterpillar has been one of the best-performing stocks this year among the 30 component issues of the Dow Jones industrial average.
Revenue rose 16.5 percent, to $4.87 billion from $4.18 billion. Domestic sales climbed 20 percent, and international sales gained 14 percent.
"Their shipments continue to outpace the overall business of the industry," Lisa Shalett, an analyst with Sanford C. Bernstein, said this week. In the past, she noted, Caterpillar had cut inventories to become more attuned to industry demand.
When it reported earnings for the first quarter, in April, the company expressed concern about the dollar's strength against the yen, which raises the cost of Caterpillar's exports in terms of the Japanese currency, and the possibility that the Federal Reserve would raise interest rates again. But the dollar has cooled off against the yen, and the Fed has not tightened monetary policy since March.

HEADLINE: Madelon Talley, 65, a Pioneer On Male-Dominated Wall Street

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
Madelon DeVoe Talley, an investment manager who was one of Wall Street's first female executives, died Friday in a car accident near Wyndam, N.Y., her husband, Truman M. Talley, said. She was 65.
Despite a longtime interest in finance, Mrs. Talley did not begin her career until 1969, when she was in her late 30's and in the midst of raising three children. 
 In his book "The Go-Go Years," an account of Wall Street during the 1960's, the author John Brooks said Mrs. Talley was a "New York housewife who had tired of full-time housewifery," when she took a job as an assistant analyst at the Dreyfus Corporation.
A year later, she was named co-manager of the Dreyfus Leverage Fund, a promotion that made her the first female fund manager on Wall Street.
During her tenure at Dreyfus, which lasted until 1977, Mrs. Talley managed several funds, was a member of the firm's executive committee and earned a reputation as one of the sharper financial minds around.
During that period she also received a B.A. from Sarah Lawrence College.
"She had a lot of energy, talent and ability in the field, and did very well," said Howard Stein, the retired chairman of Dreyfus.
Mrs. Talley left Dreyfus to develop programs for the American Women's Economic Development Corporation, a joint venture of the Small Business Administration and the Commerce Department that aids women entrepreneurs.
Mrs. Talley said she took the job to hone her interest in small business rather than further an interest in business.
"Everybody in my family has started his own business," she said in a 1979 interview.
"My father-in-law started a paperback book company; my father started two businesses on Wall Street, and my grandfather started two businesses in Hoboken."
The call of the investment world was strong, however, and seven months after taking on her new position Mrs. Talley returned to it.
In February 1979 she was appointed New York State's director of the division of investments and cash management, a job that included the management of the state's $16 billion common retirement fund.
"Madelon Talley set the procedures and processes for the retirement funds, so that when the markets started to rise in 1982, when the Dow Jones industrial average was at 800, we were set," said Edward V. Regan, the former New York State Controller who hired her. "It was a very, very major contribution."
Mrs. Talley kept her Albany job until June 1982, when she left to join Rothschild Inc. as president of its asset management unit. She held the post for two years, leaving to set up a hedge investment fund for private investors.
In the last decade, Mrs. Talley devoted much of her time to writing about investing and serving on various boards.
From 1993 to 1995, she served as a governor of the National Association of Securities Dealers. In 1995, she was appointed a commissioner of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. She wrote two books and numerous articles for a variety of publications.
At the time of her death, Mrs. Talley was vice chairman of W. P. Carey & Company, a real estate concern, a member of Alliance Capital Management's International Advisory Committee and a member of the board of the Joffrey Ballet.
"She knew our business as a customer and a vendor, and she did a great job for New York State by getting the state heavily into stocks in the early 1980's, which was the right thing to do," said Dave Williams, chairman of Alliance Capital.
A lifelong resident of Manhattan, Mrs. Talley was a 10th-generation New Yorker, her forebears having emigrated from Alsace-Lorraine in the mid-17th century.
In addition to her husband, Mrs. Talley is survived by a son, MacDonald W. Talley of Pacific Grove, Calif.; two daughters, Melanie Talley Whately and Marina Talley, both of Manhattan, and a brother, Raymond F. DeVoe Jr. of Sea Girt, N.J.

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
City's Jobless Rate Reaches 10 Percent

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON 

 BODY:
New York City's unemployment rate rose to 10 percent last month, up from 9.6 percent in May, the State Department of Labor said yesterday. Not since January 1994, just after the end of a deep recession, has the seasonally adjusted jobless rate been in double digits. The statewide unemployment rate was unchanged at 6.3 percent.
The new higher jobless number for the city has become a running theme in the current economic expansion: tens of thousands of new jobs in private business have been created in the city, but even more people have come out to look for those jobs, creating greater joblessness. Meanwhile, the number of jobs in government -- a large employer especially in some neighborhoods in the city -- has continued to contract. 
 Over the last 12 months, state officials said, New York City has added more than 45,000 jobs in private business and lost about 10,000 government jobs, for a net increase of 35,000. That accounted for almost all the growth in the eight-county metropolitan region tracked by the Labor Department -- the city's five boroughs plus Westchester, Rockland and Putnam Counties. Westchester, in fact, lost jobs over the last year.
The city's unemployment rate, meanwhile, has steadily risen, from 8.7 percent in June 1996 to its new peak reached last month. The unemployment rate in Westchester, by contrast, has actually fallen -- from 4.2 percent in June 1996 on a non-seasonally-adjusted basis, to 3.4 percent last month, the state said.

HEADLINE: Business Travel;
Start-up and low-fare airlines continue to remain out of favor for corporate fliers, despite savings.

BYLINE: By Edwin McDowell 

 BODY:
AFTER the Valujet crash in the Florida Everglades in May 1996, many travelers started booking away from not only Valujet, but also many other start-up, low-fare airlines. A new survey suggests that they remain out of favor with corporate travel managers.
According to the National Business Travel Association, a survey it conducted of 565 corporate travel managers showed that only 18 percent of them considered booking employees on low-cost or start-up airlines as a way to reduce travel costs. 
 With the last-minute fares typically used by business travelers hovering near record levels, corporate travel managers are using a number of methods to reduce costs, the survey showed. More than half of the managers surveyed said they encouraged the use of Saturday night layovers to get lower fares. Other methods include routings that might include a connection instead of a direct flight, or using secondary airports near their employees' destinations.
Barry Jagoda, a spokesman for the association, said more challenges might be coming for corporate travel managers. "As Congress considers more taxes and fees, the threat of even higher business air fares has led travel managers to consider a variety of measures to reduce air fares,"
 
Organic Fare
Swissair introduced organic food last month (including organic baby food) on all flights out of Zurich and Geneva, and Ulrich Wohn, the director of marketing services, said it had been a huge success. So successful, in fact, that by the year 2000 the carrier wants 90 percent of the food and beverages it serves in economy, business and first class to be organic.
This winter, Swissair will add organic salads, next summer it will add organic appetizers and soup, and in the winter of 1998-99, snacks, deserts and cold meals will also be organic. Inspiration for serving organic food, Mr. Wohn said, "came from our best customers, those who travel most."
 
A Reassuring Voice
They may never dispel the movie or TV image of the snarling New York taxi driver, yet visitors may find it reassuring when in a cab to be reminded by Placido Domingo, Eartha Kitt and Jackie Mason to buckle one's seat belt for safety, and be sure to take one's belongings and get a receipt at the end of the ride.
The other celebrity voices, on digital chips that are in many taxis already and required to be in all 12,000 cabs by Aug. 1, are Joan Rivers, Joe Torre, Dr. Ruth Westheimer and Judd Hirsh. The voices will be rotated every four to six months, although some of the original voices will return with new messages.
 
World Corporate Games
Time is growing short for those intending to compete in the World Corporate Games but who have not yet registered. Now in their 10th year, the games will be held in Aruba from Sept. 13 through Sept. 20, and participants must be registered by Aug. 13.
Texaco and British Petroleum have signed up, but the games are essentially corporate in name only, since any individual or any organization can also compete in any of six age categories. The 21 sports include many of the usual ones, plus bocce, dominoes, six-person soccer, table tennis and that favorite spectator sport of couch potatoes and other television addicts, beach volleyball.
Information in available by telephone at 954 767-3395 or on the World Wide Web (www.arubagames.com).
 
Auto Club's New Logo
Chartered 95 years ago as the American Automobile Association, that organization will formally become AAA, effective today. To mark the occasion, the familiar logo with the three red A's surrounded by an oval will also receive its fifth face lift, the first since 1983.
The new logo, with more contemporary lettering, will also be adorned by a blue ring apparently meant to suggest motion and progress. Over the next few years it will be converted on millions of membership cards, as well as signs at participating lodgings, restaurants and attractions.
The change, the association said, better reflects AAA's growth beyond automobile services to include travel, financial and insurance services. With 40 million members, 44 percent of whom are business executives, managers, doctors, lawyers and other professionals, AAA is indeed a powerhouse. It claims to be the world's biggest seller of American Express traveler's checks ($2.4 billion worth sold in 1996), the world's biggest travel publisher (300 million copies of travel-related books and maps each year) and it says that at any one time, 24 percent of all hotel rooms nationwide are occupied by an AAA member.
Meantime, AAA is not out of the auto emergency business. Last year it charged the batteries, changed the tires and otherwise helped out 30 million stranded motorists.

HEADLINE: Robust Economy Shrinks Federal Deficit

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 22

 BODY:
The Federal budget deficit shriveled to $10.87 billion for the first nine months of the fiscal year as a vibrant economy generated a record surplus for June, the Treasury Department said today.
The monthly report bolstered the notion that the surprising vitality of the United States economy could raise enough revenue to wipe out the deficit by the end of next year. 
 In June, revenues from taxes, fees and other sources exceeded expenses by $54.52 billion, topping the previous record surplus for that month of $34.34 billion in 1996, the Treasury said. In May, the Government had a deficit of $48.49 billion.
With the Government awash in unexpected cash, the deficit through the first nine months of the 1997 fiscal year, which ends on Sept. 30, has fallen 85 percent, to $10.87 billion, from $74.02 billion at the similar point in 1996.
Many economists expect the current fiscal year to wind up with a modest budget deficit of about $50 billion, after a deficit of $106.99 billion in 1996. They expect it to fade completely by the end of next year if current policy is left unchanged by Congress and the White House.
A budget deal including tax and spending cuts could widen the deficit next year, even though it would wipe out the budget shortfall by 2002. The last time the United States posted a budget surplus was 1969.
In June, outlays were $118.84 billion, down from $142.99 billion in May but up slightly from $117.66 billion in June 1996. Revenues rose to $173.36 billion in June from $94.49 billion in May and $152 billion in June 1996.

HEADLINE: Boeing Is Said to Give In to European Demand on McDonnell Deal

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, July 22

 BODY:
Hoping to avoid a bruising trade battle, the Boeing Company apparently capitulated today to a key demand by the European Commission in a bid to win approval by the commission of Boeing's $14 billion merger with the McDonnell Douglas Corporation.
One day before the commission, which is the executive arm of the 15-nation European Union, was expected to formally reject the merger, Boeing indicated a willingness to alter or drop its use of exclusive aircraft supply contracts with major American airlines, trade officials said. 
 The move came after weeks of fruitless negotiations that had threatened to escalate into a battle between the United States and Europe over control of the worldwide commercial aircraft market. The commission's threats to reject the deal had led American officials to vow to retaliate.
The focus of the dispute has been the exclusive supply arrangements, which Boeing has struck with three United States airlines. European officials say these arrangements pose a threat to the survival of Airbus Industrie, the European consortium, based in Paris, that is rival to Boeing in the commercial aircraft market.
Until today, Boeing had appeared unwilling to alter or drop those arrangements, as the Europeans had demanded. But late in the day, Karel van Miert, the European Union's top antitrust official, indicated that Boeing had sent him a new offer, signaling a willingness to do so.
"There is certainly a very important new element this afternoon," Mr. van Miert told Bloomberg News. "It seems Boeing is now ready to scrap the exclusive contracts. We are now looking at their latest offer, and we will tell you more tomorrow."
In Washington, Clinton Administration officials confirmed Boeing's concession and expressed hope that it would produce a peaceful resolution of the conflict. President Clinton, while not mentioning any specific details, predicted that a deal could be reached. "I think there is a way to work this out," Mr. Clinton said at a White House news conference, "and I'm hopeful that by Wednesday, when the commission meets, an agreement will have been reached."
Publicly, Boeing officials remained reticent. "We think we have done everything possible to reach a resolution," said Craig Martin, a spokesman for the company in Brussels, where the commission has its headquarters. "We are sort of stuck now waiting for the vote."
The vote on Wednesday is critical because the European Union has asserted its authority to reject the merger on the ground that Boeing is a major aircraft supplier across Europe. Although it could not technically block the deal, it could make it difficult for Boeing to do business in Europe by trying to impose fines of up to 10 percent of Boeing's worldwide revenues.
In addition to the exclusive contracts, a number of other aspects of the merger have drawn the opposition of the Europeans. Though McDonnell Douglas has seen its share of the commercial aircraft market shrink to less than 10 percent -- compared with about 60 percent for Boeing and about 30 percent for Airbus -- Mr. van Miert says that McDonnell's giant military business would in effect amount to a Government subsidy for Boeing.
American officials have pointed out that several companies in the Airbus consortium themselves have substantial military contracting businesses. And Boeing has argued that its exclusive sales deals are merely a refinement of long-term contracts that have been the norm for years in the aircraft industry, and that Airbus itself has tried to negotiate such contracts.
The Federal Trade Commission, in announcing its decision recently to allow the merger, said the long-term contracts did raise concerns but did not pose a sufficient reason in themselves to block the deal.
Until today, Boeing and the European Commission had made virtually no progress toward a settlement and appeared on track for a politically loaded trade battle. But with the scheduled vote less than 24 hours away, Boeing came up with its offer and a compromise suddenly seemed more likely. "There appear to be signs that the American side is softening," Germany's Foreign Minister, Klaus Kinkel, said after a briefing by Mr. van Miert. Saying a trade war should be avoided, Mr. Kinkel added that he had spoken with Secretary of State Madeleine Albright about the Boeing case on Monday.
White House officials have spoken by telephone with European officials, and Mr. Clinton said he had tried to speak with several heads of state. Joel Klein, the new head of the antitrust division of the Justice Department, has also been working behind the scenes with the White House's National Economic Council to nudge Boeing and the Europeans closer to a peaceful resolution.
United States officials have said that even if the European Union rejected the merger, they would continue to fight for the deal. The dispute would almost certainly be taken to the World Trade Organization in Geneva, which has the authority to resolve trade disputes and strike down government actions that it decides are merely protection measures that block free trade.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Fed Chief's Remarks Spur Surge in Bonds

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Treasury prices surged yesterday and drove yields to their lowest levels in almost eight months after investors took comments from Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, to suggest that the Fed would not soon raise interest rates.
"The recent performance of the economy, characterized by strong growth and low inflation, has been exceptional -- and better than most anticipated," Mr. Greenspan said in his semiannual testimony before a House banking subcommittee on the state of the economy. 
 The price of the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond rose 1 21/32, to 102 26/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction, from the price, fell to 6.41 percent from 6.54 percent on Monday.
Bond investors regarded Mr. Greenspan's comments as a clear sign that the Fed chairman was not overly concerned inflation would quicken any time soon.
"This is a huge sigh of relief for the market," Kevin McClintock, who manages $5 billion of bonds at the Dreyfus Corporation in New York, said of the market's activity after Mr. Greenspan's testimony.
Mr. Greenspan also suggested that there might be room for the economy to grow even faster without speeding inflation -- the nemesis of bondholders, since it erodes the value of bonds' fixed payments.
"From the Federal Reserve's point of view, the faster the better," Mr. Greenspan said.
Joseph Liro, chief economist at CIBC Wood Gundy Securities, said: "There's nothing on the immediate horizon that would suggest a rate hike. If the economy behaves itself, the Fed will behave itself."
Bond prices received another lift earlier in the afternoon when the Treasury sold $15.5 billion of two-year notes at a price to yield 5.93 percent -- less than the 5.94 percent many market participants had expected.
In contrast to yesterday's rally, bond prices tumbled on Feb. 26, after Mr. Greenspan used his House testimony to suggest the central bank was poised to raise interest rates to head off inflation. A month later, Fed officials lifted the target for overnight lending, by a quarter-percentage point, to 5.5 percent.
Few expected Mr. Greenspan would issue such a blunt warning in his testimony yesterday, and he did not. Reports in recent weeks suggest that the economy has slowed since the first quarter, while inflation is running at an annual rate of just 1.4 percent, the slowest in 11 years.
"Compared to his last testimony, these comments aren't nearly as bearish," said Mark Sauvigne, a five-year-note trader at Chase Securities. "He was much more concerned about inflation then -- it's a much rosier picture this time."
Fed officials next meet to debate monetary policy on Aug. 19 and again on Sept. 30. Judging from current rates on Eurodollar futures contracts, or dollars on deposit outside the United States, few anticipate a rate shift any time soon.
The securities are among the most sensitive to changing Fed rate expectations.Yet the September three-month Eurodollar contract recently had an implied yield of 5.75 percent, the same as the rate for three-month borrowing. That suggests investors see little or no chance for higher rates before the contract expires.

HEADLINE: Questions Grow Over Haiti Peacekeepers' Role

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, July 18

 BODY:
For nearly three years, ever since 22,000 American soldiers landed here to restore then-President Jean Bertrand Aristide to power, foreign troops have been an accustomed part of the Haitian landscape.
But with the mandate of a United Nations peacekeeping force scheduled to expire at month's end, their continued presence is rapidly becoming the focus of a broad national debate. 
 Barring a veto by China or Russia, the United Nations Security Council is likely to extend the peacekeeping mission through Nov. 30. Signs of fatigue are emerging, among both Haitians, who originally welcomed the American-led intervention in September 1994, and the countries that have since backed the peacekeeping effort here.
"There is a generalized recognition that this will be the last four months of the military component of the mission," Enrique ter Horst, director of the United Nations contingent here, said in an interview. But, he added, Haiti's Government, especially its fledgling national police force, "quite clearly will continue to require technical assistance" even after the military leaves.
[Citing "daunting political and economic challenges," United Nations Secretary General Kofi Annan submitted a report on Tuesday to the Security Council recommending the four-month extension for what will now be called a "transition mission." After November, he said, it will remain vital for the international community to offer "strong support to the building of a professional police force."]
At the moment, the United Nations presence here consists of 1,300 Canadian and Pakistani soldiers and 250 police officers from several nations. The United States is not formally part of the current peacekeeping mission, but has a parallel force of about 500 soldiers that it calls a "support group." Those numbers are likely to drop only slightly when the mandate is renewed later this month, with the United States and Canada paying a larger share of the costs in order to satisfy China and Russia.
The jubilation that greeted the arrival of American troops is gone, replaced by a general indifference, a sense of disappointment or even, in some cases, outright opposition. Around the capital and in some parts of the countryside, graffiti have begun appearing on walls, proclaiming "down with the occupation" and demanding that "blan soldiers get out." The word "blan" means both "foreigner" and "white" in Haitian Creole and can have pejorative connotations.
Similar graffiti warnings were common three years ago, when a right-wing military dictatorship, which had deposed Mr. Aristide, was trying to avert the American-led intervention. This time, however, "popular organizations" on the left, most of which say they are loyal to Mr. Aristide but are not widely known, are issuing the threats. One such group has gone so far as to warn United Nations forces to stay out of its neighborhood after July 31.
Mr. Aristide, who exited the presidency last year after heavy pressure from the United States and its allies that he fulfill a pledge to do so, has muddied the issue by refusing to publicly endorse an extension of the United Nations mission. Instead, he has criticized the Government of his successor, Rene Preval, as being "indebted to imperialism" and accused the international community of trying to undermine the country's democratic forces.
"If they believe they can deplete the battery of our morale by programming hunger and a rising cost of living, they have miscalculated," Mr. Aristide said in one of several recent fiery speeches. Those arguments appear to be resonating among at least some parts of the populace.
"They have been here three years, but the economy is still a mess, and even though there are soldiers in the streets, the criminals continue to prey on us," said Hypolite Sanon, an unemployed resident of Cite Soleil, a sprawling slum on the outskirts of the capital. "If the foreigners cannot supply us with what we need, then it is best that they leave our country."
In an interview here, Mr. Preval said that though he recognizes that opposition to the United Nationspresence exists on both the right and left, he favors maintaining the mission for another four months. But he also indicated that when the next deadline comes, the "technical support" he wants could come under the auspices of other international bodies.
After November, Mr. Preval said, "one cannot exclude the possibility of bilateral assistance from the countries of the Caribbean Community," the 14-member regional group of predominantly English-speaking nations, which admitted Haiti as a member earlier this month. Jamaica in particular, he added, is a likely candidate to provide assistance in police and security matters.
The focus of much of the concern remains the Haitian National Police, which has been involved in recent incidents in which officers have used excessive force to quell demonstrations and have killed bystanders by firing wildly while trying to apprehend suspected criminals.
"For myself, it's not reasonable to ask this young and inexperienced police force suddenly to have to take over full responsibility for a safe and secure environment," said William L. Swing, the United States Ambassador here.
Beyond November, Mr. Swing added, "the responsible thing to do is ask what do Haitians want?" He added: "One needs to listen to people, take cues from the government and try to maintain some sort of international support group" that includes "a residual international security program."
But with the collapse of the United Nations-brokered accord in Cambodia and mounting concerns about the fragility of the Bosnian peace agreement, members are eager to avoid similar problems here. In addition, some countries have made it clear they are reluctant to do a job they view as primarily an American responsibility.
"Have we come to the point of diminishing returns?" one longtime United Nations official here asked. "I think locally the feeling is yes, despite their own apprehensions about the police not being up to the job."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Greenspan Eases Fears Of a Rate Increase
Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, suggested that the central bank was inclined to leave interest rates steady for the time being, but he issued a gentle warning that the current combination of steady growth, low unemployment and scant inflation would not continue indefinitely.
Mr. Greenspan's generally upbeat assessment of the economy, though laden with caveats, dispersed lingering anxieties among investors that the Fed would raise rates next month, and the stock market soared in response. [Page A1.] 

Treasury prices surged, too, sending the yield on the 30-year bond to the lowest level in almost eight months, 6.41 percent, from 6.54. [D18.]
 
Time Warner to Carry Fox Channel
The Time Warner cable system has agreed to carry Rupert Murdoch's 24-hour Fox News Channel in New York City after nearly a year of bitter legal and political battles, executives close to the negotiations said. [B1.]
 
Philip Morris Meets Expectations
Philip Morris reported a 13.3 percent earnings rise, matching forecasts. Results were strong domestically and internationally. [D2.]
 
RJR Nabisco moved into the black, rebounding from a loss a year earlier. International volume was strong, but domestic cigarette sales eroded. [D2.]
 
Restaurant Gains Help Pepsico
Pepsico matched analysts' earnings expectations, buoyed by gains in its soon-to-be-spun-off restaurant business and despite slowed growth in the Frito-Lay snack food business and sluggish beverage profits. [D4.]
 
Big Increases at Phone Companies
Bell Atlantic, Nynex and Northern Telecom all reported unexpectedly high growth in earnings from operations, thanks to wireless telephones and the Internet. [D4.]
 
5 Big Drug Makers Report Gains
SmithKline Beecham, Warner-Lambert, Schering-Plough, Bristol-Myers Squibb and American Home Products reported strong profits. But the news was overshadowed by an announcement that SmithKline would enter the lucrative but crowded market for cholesterol-lowering drugs. [D4.]
 
Texaco and Amoco Above Forecasts
Profits surpassed forecasts at Texaco and Amoco, though Texaco's operating earnings fell 5.4 percent. Amoco, citing gains in refining, had a 5 percent rise in its net income. [D5.]
 
Strong Report Lifts Disney Stock
Disney said that its earnings rose 18 percent in the latest quarter, driven in part by strong earnings at the company's theme parks. Net income was slightly above expectations, and Disney's stock rose strongly. [D7.]
 
At I.B.M., Shifts and a Promotion
I.B.M.'s chief, Louis V. Gerstner Jr., shuffled management ranks and promoted a young executive, Samuel J. Palmisano, who some think could be an heir apparent. [D5.]
 
Canadian Bank's Global Strategy
In agreeing to acquire Oppenheimer Holdings for $525 million in cash, the Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce is taking a big step toward its goal of building a worldwide securities business. Market Place. [D8.]
 
UAL Earnings Above Expectations
United Airlines' parent said that earnings before charges rose 12 percent, outpacing expectations, as international revenue was higher. .At Northwest Airlines, profit fell yet exceeded analysts' forecasts. [D5.]
 
High Growth but Low Inflation
The Chinese economy grew at a world-leading 9.5 percent in the first half of the year. Yet it confounded economists with remarkably little inflation, just 1.8 percent. [D6.]
 
Novel Approach in Strike
The United Steelworkers of America have embraced some provocative tactics in a strike against Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel, including protests against companies with which the steelmaker does business. [A15.]

HEADLINE: GREENSPAN UPBEAT BUT WITH CAVEATS

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 22

 BODY:
Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, suggested today that the central bank was inclined to leave interest rates steady for the time being, but he issued a gentle warning that today's nearly perfect combination of low unemployment and scant inflation was too good to last forever.
Mr. Greenspan's generally upbeat assessment of the economy, although laden with caveats, dispersed lingering anxieties among investors that the Federal Reserve would raise rates next month to head off any possibility of inflation infecting an expansion that has lasted more than six years. 
 Coming hours after strong earnings reports from big companies like Philip Morris, Caterpillar and Pepsico, Mr. Greenspan's comments were seen as a green light on Wall Street, which sent stock prices to new highs. [Page D1.]
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 154.93 to close at 8,061.65. The bond market also surged, pushing long-term interest rates, which move in the opposite direction of bond prices, down sharply. At the end of the day the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond yielded 6.41 percent, its lowest level in more than seven months.
"The markets reacted to the notion that there wasn't any immediate threat," said Richard D. Rippe, an economist at Prudential Securities, "either in the way Greenspan perceived the economy or in what he implied about monetary policy."
But Mr. Greenspan's comments, Mr. Rippe said, contained a "clear implication that he thinks it's more likely that they will have to tighten monetary policy in the period ahead than it is that they would ease."
Speaking before a House subcommittee, Mr. Greenspan said prices were as stable as they had been since the 1960's. And he said that after growing at a 5.9 percent annual rate in the first quarter of this year, the economy cooled off considerably in the second quarter, dispelling any immediate fears that inflationary pressures might be building.
But he said growth appeared to be accelerating again. And he said the low unemployment rate -- currently 5 percent -- meant that wages might soon begin rising more rapidly, a development that would be good news for workers but worrisome to policy makers because many economists see wage increases that outstrip productivity gains as leading to broader price inflation.
"Unless aggregate demand increases more slowly than it has in recent years -- more in line with trends in the supply of labor and productivity -- imbalances will emerge," Mr. Greenspan warned on the first of two consecutive days of testimony he will deliver to Congress on monetary policy.
"We do not know, however, at what point pressures would develop, or indeed whether the economy is already close to that point," Mr. Greenspan said. "Fortunately, the very rapid growth of demand over the winter has eased recently."
To Wall Street, what Mr. Greenspan did not say was perhaps even more important than what he did. With financial markets storming ahead even as his words were being transmitted to trading desks around the world, there was no mention of "irrational exuberance," the phrase Mr. Greenspan coined last December to describe the stock market when the Dow Jones industrial average was 1,600 points lower than it closed today.
He gave only a veiled hint that he remained worried about the recent heights scaled by the market, leaving unspoken the idea that investors might benefit from a look back into history. "With the economy performing so well for so long," Mr. Greenspan said, "financial markets have been buoyant, as memories of past business and financial cycles fade with time."
Reflecting the strong growth rate of the first quarter, Mr. Greenspan said, the Federal Reserve has increased its forecast of economic growth for the full year by a percentage point, to a range of 3 percent to 3.25 percent, up from the last forecast in February. The Fed now expects growth in 1998 to slow to 2 percent to 2.5 percent, within the range most economists believe can be sustained without igniting inflation.
Nonetheless, the new forecast projects inflation to rise from a range of 2.25 percent to 2.5 percent this year to between 2.5 percent and 3 percent next year. It assumes that this year's drops in food and energy prices will not be repeated next year.
Mr. Greenspan's testimony reflected the thinking of traditionalists within the central bank, including Laurence H. Meyer, a Federal Reserve governor appointed last year by President Clinton. They believe that low unemployment and strong growth almost inevitably results in rising wages and prices.
"I have no doubt that the current stance of policy -- characterized by a nominal Federal funds rate around 5.5 percent -- will need to be changed at some point to foster sustainable growth and low inflation," Mr. Greenspan said, adding that any such change should be seen as routine.
"For the present, as I indicated, demand growth does appear to have moderated, but whether that moderation will be sufficient to avoid putting additional pressures on resources is an open question," he said. "With considerable momentum behind the expansion and labor market utilization rates unusually high, the Federal Reserve must be alert to the possibility that additional action might be called for to forestall excessive credit creation."
But Mr. Greenspan also used his testimony to elaborate on his often-stated belief that technology, among other factors, might have helped change the economy in fundamental ways that would allow higher levels of noninflationary growth.
Although he emphasized that he remained skeptical of the idea of a "new economy," he said there was more evidence to support the notion that heavy investments by business in computers, telecommunications equipment and other technology were generating increases in productivity not fully captured in economic statistics.
"What we may be observing in the current economic environment is a number of key technologies, some even mature, finally interacting to create significant new opportunities for value creation," Mr. Greenspan said, citing such examples as the combination of lasers and fiber optic cable in transforming telecommunications and the mix of computer software and hardware that created the Internet.
'We do not now know, nor do I suspect can anyone know," he said, "whether current developments are part of a once-or-twice-in-a-century phenomenon that will carry productivity trends nationally and globally to a new, higher track, or whether we are merely observing some unusual variations within the context of an otherwise generally conventional business cycle expansion."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, told Congress that the key questions facing markets and policy makers are "what is behind the good performance of the economy and will it persist?" (Stephen Crowley/The New York Times)(pg. D20)

HEADLINE: Ruth Messinger Gets Specific

 BODY:
Ruth Messinger started her mayoral campaign in earnest yesterday with a speech on budget issues that dared to state some hard truths about the way New York City delivers its services. For the first time this year, it seemed possible that Mayor Rudolph Giuliani might have to do more in his re-election campaign than put price tags on Ms. Messinger's laundry list of worthy but costly projects.
In an address to the 14th Street-Union Square Local Development Corporation, Ms. Messinger answered those who had demanded that she explain how she would pay for the increased spending on schools and teacher salaries she has been calling for. Her proposed savings included targets seldom mentioned by Democratic or even Republican mayoral hopefuls, like the 35-hour workweek many city employees enjoy, teacher sabbaticals and "released time" that allows hundreds of workers to collect city paychecks while devoting some or all of their time to union duties. 
 Many of Ms. Messinger's other ideas for merging city agencies and for improving productivity by allowing private businesses to compete for contracts have been made before. Some proposals, like replacing police officers who do desk jobs with cheaper civilians, seem to come up on almost a weekly basis. But voters seldom get to hear a serious debate about their practicality.
Until now, Ms. Messinger seemed incapable of forcing Mr. Giuliani to defend his record as a manager. Her early speeches, which listed familiar complaints about crumbling schools and overcrowded classrooms, seemed meaningless without an explanation of where the money would come from to do more than the Mayor has done. Her suggestion that the city's teachers, police and firefighters be paid the same salaries as their suburban counterparts was unrealistic. Tactically it was an even bigger mistake, since she may have made Mr. Giuliani look like a tougher negotiator of union contracts than he has actually been.
The Giuliani campaign has violently disputed almost everything Ms. Messinger proposed, especially her claim that the ideas would save $1.1 billion a year. The Mayor also noted that her economies in the Police Department would require a smaller uniformed force. This sort of argument is healthy, and all Ms. Messinger's proposals should be debated in full. The city's unions should join in the debate too, along with the other Democratic primary candidates, Sal Albanese and Al Sharpton.
Ms. Messinger re-emphasized her commitment to activist government. But she added that 20 years in politics had taught her to value productivity too. If she can make her party, which is often captive to special interests, an advocate of government that is compassionate, fair and efficient at the same time, this campaign could be a valuable one.

HEADLINE: 5 Days in 1967 Still Shake Detroit

BYLINE: By ROBYN MEREDITH 

DATELINE: DETROIT, July 22

 BODY:
During this city's riots 30 years ago, Officer Isaiah McKinnon of the Detroit police was pulled over by an unmarked police car while driving home from a 12-hour shift spent trying to stop arsonists and looters from torching businesses and carrying off sofas, radios, even groceries.
Mr. McKinnon still had his uniform on that night and was one of the few black officers then on a police force so brutal and infected by racism that a routine raid of an after-hours club touched off the rioting. When Mr. McKinnon was approached by the two white officers who had stopped him for violating a riot curfew, he yelled that he, too, was on the police force -- to little effect. 
 "The older guy, he had his gun out and he made a racially derogatory comment to me," Mr. McKinnon said. "I could see that he was pulling the trigger. I dove back into my car as he fired, and I just floored it."
Much has changed since the night three decades ago when the white officer's shot missed Mr. McKinnon. City Hall, then run mostly by whites, is now run mostly by African-Americans. This city of almost a million people, which is 76 percent black, is the nation's largest with a black majority. More than half the members of its police force are black, and Mr. McKinnon has risen through the ranks from rookie to Chief.
But other scars from the riots remain. Hundreds of burned or looted businesses were never rebuilt. Tens of thousands of Detroiters moved to the suburbs, including many middle-class and affluent families. The city's tax base shrank and the quality of its schools declined.
City officials have found it easier to fix a police force under their control than to repair the economic wounds left by the riots.
Although public debate about the city's police force has largely disappeared, the struggle continues to rebuild what is also the nation's poorest big city.
"A lot has changed," said Detroit's Mayor, Dennis W. Archer, who is black. "The residents know and respect our officers."
But the Mayor acknowledged that other problems persisted.
"Whatever damage you inflict to your own city, it is likely to remain permanent," Mayor Archer said, "because in the very same areas where there used to be flourishing businesses, they do not exist today, and in the very same areas where there used to be dense housing units, they no longer exist today."
There were nearly four dozen riots and more than 100 smaller cases of civil unrest in the United States in 1967, but Detroit's riots were the deadliest. A Presidential commission later attributed most of the 43 deaths to police officers and National Guardsmen who, in the commission's view, had gone out of control.
The long-simmering anger of black residents at an abusive, mostly white police force erupted here in the early morning hours of July 23, 1967, and lasted five days. The flash point was a raid by white police officers on an after-hours drinking and gambling club at the corner of 12th and Clairmount Streets, in a heavily black neighborhood. By the time the smoke cleared almost a week later, 683 buildings across the city had been damaged or destroyed and tanks had rolled through the streets.
Whole blocks had gone up in flames, and the looting was so extensive that in some neighborhoods, alleys and sidewalks were lined with old sofas and armchairs that residents had cast out to make room for new furniture. Along 12th Street, smoldering piles of debris had replaced a bustling neighborhood of apartment houses, grocers, bars, a shoe store, a dry cleaner, a meat market and a bicycle shop.
Today, empty lots of thigh-high grass cover much of the area. Only one business owner at the epicenter of the riots, Carl Perry, still hangs on, operating a tiny photography studio next to a boarded-up storefront.
Mr. Perry's studio was here during the riots, too. Worried about looting, he moved all his expensive equipment into a drugstore he owned in the next block, where he served ice cream sodas to neighbors. Then a nearby grocery was torched, and the flames consumed his drugstore, destroying everything inside, including the expensive cameras and darkroom gear.
"It burned, it all burned," said Mr. Perry, who winced as he remembered the sight, even three decades later. "I didn't have one cent of insurance."
Mr. Perry, who is black, repaired store windows broken during the riots and kept his photography studio open. In the decades since, he has opened a small shop in the vacant storefront next door, and occasional customers buy soda, candy bars and potato chips there. But a grassy lot now occupies the site of his once-bustling drugstore.
Like other big cities, Detroit has never regained the prosperity it had in the mid-1960's, partly because of the riots' lingering effects and partly because of broad economic changes over which the city had no control.
For instance, jobs dwindled at the General Motors Corporation, the Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation, the Motor City's hometown employers, when the companies could not match the competition from Japanese auto makers.
But the riots exacerbated demographic shifts that had begun a decade before in many big cities. Around 1940, many Southern blacks, like various immigrant groups before them, moved to Detroit for the work in the automobile factories. The city's population at the time of the riots was one-third black, and by 1990 that percentage had grown to 76 percent.
Even before the riots, many middle-class Detroit residents, particularly whites, had begun moving to the newly built suburbs, commuting to work on the broad highways being built. But the riots turned the steady stream of people moving to the suburbs into a torrent. Businesses followed their customers. Thousands of houses were abandoned as the city's population plunged to 992,000 from 1.6 million at the time of the riots.
"We still have a huge inner-city problem in Detroit -- of housing, homelessness, joblessness, an incredibly decrepit education system, high crime rates, drug abuse, welfare dependency, teen-age pregnancy," said Representative John Conyers Jr., a Democrat who has represented Detroit since 1965.
One in 3 Detroit residents lives in poverty, compared with 1 in 13 in the city's suburbs. The median family income here was $22,566 in 1990, only three-fifths of the national median.
"All the statistics may have gotten worse in the last 30 years," Mr. Conyers said.
But there is some evidence that the city hit bottom some years ago and is beginning to turn around, particularly since the 1993 election of Mr. Archer, a pro-development Mayor who has concentrated on luring back suburban business leaders.
There are plans to build a new football stadium and a baseball stadium in the inner city, along with three casinos. G.M., the world's largest company in terms of sales, recently decided against moving out to the suburbs and bought a downtown office complex for its headquarters instead. Developers have built hundreds of new, middle-class homes in the city for the first time in decades.
Over the past 30 years, there have been a few hints of recovery near where the riots broke out. A strip mall with a supermarket, a drugstore and a bank opened with much fanfare -- and subsidies -- 15 years after the riots. A small subdivision of houses has sprung up in the last several years.
While economic progress has come slowly, the city has cleaned up its police force. In the process, the level of tension in the city has fallen sharply, civic leaders said, greatly reducing the likelihood of future explosions of violence.
The Detroit police used to be hated by large segments of the black community, and officers were viewed more as an occupying army than as keepers of the peace. Particularly notorious were what were called Big Four. These were squad cars carrying four officers, usually all white, and they inspired widespread fear.
The Big Four are remembered for their racially derogatory remarks and were widely blamed for beating up blacks who loitered on street corners or refused to obey police orders promptly.
"You might wind up with something upside your head" for not moving quickly, Mr. Archer recalled.
To be sure, some black residents maintained good relations with the police in that era. Esther Gordy Edwards, the sister of the Motown founder Berry Gordy Jr., said that when white officers were dispatched to Motown's headquarters on a residential street because of noise complaints, they often stayed to listen to recording sessions.
But many residents had very different experiences. In 1965, a then-former police commissioner warned prophetically that relations between the police and local blacks were so strained that a race riot could occur.
The old system hit its nadir during the riots, when many white officers proved too willing to shoot blacks. Police officers shot at least 20 people to death, and Army troops and National Guardsmen killed up to 10 more, according to Lyndon B. Johnson's National Advisory Commission on Civil Disorders, popularly known as the Kerner Commission. Of the 43 killed, all but 10 were black.
Even today, some black residents refer to the upheaval here 30 years ago as a rebellion against racist white authority rather than a riot. The site where the troubles began, 12th Street, was renamed Rosa Parks Boulevard in 1976, after the civil rights heroine from Montgomery, Ala., who refused to give up her bus seat to a white man and who later moved to Detroit.
But to Mr. McKinnon, the police Chief, the disturbance was a riot, and he and his predecessors have taken steps to keep anything like it from happening again. These days, there are far fewer citizen complaints, and they stem from isolated incidents, not accepted police practices.
The city's 4,072 police officers receive special training in handling riots. The city now makes elaborate preparations even for celebrations, like the Detroit Red Wings' recent victory in the Stanley Cup hockey championships. The police predict where crowds will form, map those neighborhoods using a grid system and then make each officer accountable for keeping the peace in a vicinity. Police officers face investigation if an unusual number of citizens complain about their actions, Mr. McKinnon said.
Mr. Perry, the only businessman left on the block where it all began three decades ago, remembered when that was not the case.
"We seem to be having a pretty good relationship with the police now," Mr. Perry said. "Before the riot, it was just a different day and age."
