HEADLINE: ACCORD REACHED ON TAX MEASURE, REPUBLICANS SAY

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 22

 BODY:
House and Senate Republicans said tonight that they had resolved nearly all the differences between their respective tax bills and that they would present a united front in trying to reach a deal with the Clinton Administration.
The differences between the ways the House and Senate arrived at an $85 billion tax cut were substantial and had complicated negotiations between Republican leaders and the Administration on a compromise that President Clinton would sign. 
 But in agreeing to take a single position in the talks with the White House, Republicans adopted some positions that were closer to the House bill, which Mr. Clinton had made clear was unacceptable, and away from the Senate bill, which Administration officials had said provided a reasonable starting place for negotiating a compromise.
"We had a very, very good negotiation," House Speaker Newt Gingrich told reporters after the meeting. "We're very close to getting this done."
The chairman of the Senate Budget Committee, Pete Domenici of New Mexico, said the Republicans were ready to start discussing the issues with the White House on Wednesday. "We have reached sufficient agreement among ourselves," he said.
Republican leaders did not disclose details of the deal they worked out on the House and Senate bills. But people involved in the talks said it retained a provision in the House bill that would allow investors to subtract the effects of inflation in calculating their capital gains. Mr. Clinton said such a provision would lead him to veto the bill because it would cost the Government so much in revenue in coming decades that it could send budget deficits out of control again.
The Republicans also maintained their opposition to making more low-income working families eligible for a proposed tax credit of $500 per child. Mr. Clinton has pressed the Republicans on the issue, saying families making $20,000 to $25,000 a year who already benefit from the earned income tax credit deserve the child credit as much as families making more money who do not benefit from the earned income credit.
The unified Republican plan would adopt a position on the child credit between the House bill, which the Administration considers unacceptable, and the Senate bill, which is closer to what the White House wanted.
But Republicans said they had adopted a position closer to the Senate version on credits for college tuition.
The Republicans, however, apparently left unresolved two major differences between the House and Senate bills: whether to increase taxes on cigarettes by 20 cents a pack, and how to structure an extension of a tax on airline tickets.
Republicans said they hoped to begin full-scale negotiations with the Administration on the tax bill Wednesday and to send a bill to Mr. Clinton for his signature by the time Congress recesses in early August.
Republicans said they had decided against a strategy under consideration in the last several days of passing a tax bill even if there is no agreement with the White House and sending it to President Clinton, knowing he would veto it. Instead, Republicans said, they had decided to keep negotiating with the White House even if there is no deal by the summer recess.
Republicans said they might consider sending the legislation to Mr. Clinton if negotiations resolve most, but not all, of the differences between the Republicans and the Democrats.
The tax package is a centerpiece of the balanced-budget agreement reached by Congress and the Administration this spring, and if enacted, would be the first Federal tax cut in 16 years.
White House officials had no immediate comment on the Republican plan. But they have harshly criticized both the House and Senate bills as giving too much to the wealthy at the expense of working people and putting the nation's fiscal soundness at risk in coming decades through cuts that would explode in cost over the years.
Administration officials have made clear that they believe they would have the political advantage if the Republicans sent Mr. Clinton a bill that he vetoed, even if it meant a long standoff.
In closing ranks on the tax bill, the Republicans were clearly motivated to some degree by a desire to show that they could work together in the wake of a failed effort by some conservative House Republicans to oust Newt Gingrich as Speaker.
Among the issues certain to be vigorously debated between the White House and Republicans is the size of any cut in capital gains taxes. The Treasury Department today released an analysis that it said showed how the cost of the capital-gains cut proposal in the House bill would spiral out of control after 10 years.
The Treasury study showed that the House proposal, including the provision allowing investors to subtract the effects of inflation, would cost the Government even less in the first 10 years than Congressional estimates. But the study found that the costs would escalate to $196.6 billion between 2008 and 2017.
Administration officials said the Government would be particularly hard pressed to absorb such large costs during that period, because Medicare and Social Security expenditures would be rising sharply at the same time because of the retirement of baby boomers.

HEADLINE: Excerpts From Greenspan's Report

BYLINE: By Dow Jones 

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from testimony yesterday by Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, before a House Banking subcommittee: 
 The recent performance of the economy, characterized by strong growth and low inflation, has been exceptional -- and better than most anticipated. . . .
With the economy performing so well for so long, financial markets have been buoyant, as memories of past business and financial cycles fade with time. Soaring prices in the stock market have been fueled by moderate long-term interest rates and expectations of investors that profit margins and earnings growth will hold steady, or even increase further, in a relatively stable, low-inflation environment. . . .
The key questions facing financial markets and policy makers are what is behind the good performance of the economy and will it persist. . . .
In gauging the potential for oncoming strains, it is the effective capacity of the economy to produce that is important to us. . . .
Capacity itself, however, is a complex concept, which requires a separate evaluation of its two components, capital and labor. It appears that capital, that is, plant and equipment, can adapt and expand more expeditiously than in the past to meet demands. Hence, capital capacity is now a considerably less rigid constraint than it once was. . . .
Yet despite significant increases in capital equipment in recent years, new additions to labor supply have been inadequate to meet the demand for labor. As a consequence, the recent period has been one of significant reduction in labor market slack. . . .
The rise in the average workweek since early 1996 suggests employers are having increasingly greater difficulty fitting the millions who want a job into available job slots. If the pace of job creation continues, the pressures on wages and other costs of hiring increasing numbers of such individuals could escalate more rapidly. . . .
As I noted, the recent performance of the labor markets suggests that the economy was on an unsustainable track. Unless aggregate demand increases more slowly than it has in recent years -- more in line with trends in the supply of labor and productivity -- imbalances will emerge. . . .
Fortunately, the very rapid growth of demand over the winter has eased recently. To an extent this easing seems to reflect some falloff in growth of demand for consumer durables and for inventories to a pace more in line with moderate expansion in income. But some of the recent slower growth could simply be a product of abnormal weather patterns, which contributed to a first-quarter surge in output and weakened the second quarter, in which case the underlying trend could be somewhat higher than suggested by the second-quarter data alone. Certainly, business and consumer confidence remains high and financial conditions are supportive of growth. Particularly notable is the run-up in stock market wealth, the full effects of which apparently have not been reflected in overall demand, but might yet be. . . .
I have no doubt that the current stance of policy -- characterized by a nominal Federal funds rate around 5 1/8 -- will need to be changed at some point to foster sustainable growth and low inflation. Adjustments in the policy instrument in response to new information are a necessary and, I should like to emphasize, routine aspect of responsible policy making. For the present, as I indicated, demand growth does appear to have moderated, but whether that moderation will be sufficient to avoid putting additional pressures on resources is an open question. With considerable momentum behind the expansion and labor market utilization rates unusually high, the Federal Reserve must be alert to the possibility that additional action might be called for to forestall excessive credit creation. . . .

He noted that the nominal Federal funds rate was around 5 1/2 percent, not 5 1/8 percent.

HEADLINE: Stocks Rally On Comments By Greenspan

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA 

 BODY:
Stocks soared to record levels again yesterday after Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, told investors just what they wanted to hear: There is no imminent threat of a rise in interest rates.
In his upbeat assessment of the economy before Congress, Mr. Greenspan also failed to caution investors about "irrational exuberance" or "excessive optimism" in the financial markets -- as he had in earlier comments -- choosing instead to emphasize the strength of the economy and its long-term prospects. 
 "What many investors were saying today was that Mr. Greenspan has a view that is not very different from theirs: The U.S. economy is competitive, it's generating profits and jobs, but at this point it's not generating inflation," said Abby Joseph Cohen, co-chairwoman of the investment policy committee at Goldman, Sachs & Company. And, she added, "what really drives the equity market is confidence in the durability of earnings."
After slumping for several sessions, stocks were rallying even before the Fed chairman spoke yesterday because of strong earnings performances. But Mr. Greenspan's remarks propelled share prices even higher.
The Dow Jones industrial average soared 154.93 points, or 1.96 percent, to 8,061.65, a new closing high. That gain puts the blue-chip average up 25 percent this year, or more than 1,600 points higher than it was in early December, when Mr. Greenspan first warned of the possibility of "irrational exuberance" in the stock market.
Broader measures also ended higher. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index surged 21.04 points, or 2.3 percent, to a record 933.98. And the Nasdaq composite rose 27.63 points, or 1.8 percent, to 1,563.86. In the bond market, the yield on the 30-year Treasury tumbled 13 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, to 6.41 percent, its lowest level of the year.
In effect, Mr. Greenspan's comments yesterday affirmed what many on Wall Street have been saying for some time: that the economy is in a "sweet spot," bolstered by robust economic growth, low inflation and soaring earnings. That combination, analysts said, has made stocks an increasingly attractive investment.
Indeed, Ms. Cohen said that investors and the Fed were coming to terms with a dynamic new economy, one that was being driven by a technology revolution, greater productivity and, right now, an elongated economic cycle -- what she called a "Silly Putty cycle."
"What we're talking about is a huge structural transformation of the economy," she said. "The average experiences of previous cycles don't hold. Inflation does not rise as easily and economic growth lasts longer. In other words, many of the assumptions that investors use have been torn asunder."
Indeed, such gains in productivity have spurred rising profit margins, many of which were on display yesterday. For instance, there were strong earnings reports yesterday from Walt Disney and Philip Morris, Dow component companies, as well as Warner-Lambert and RJR Nabisco Holdings.
"Today, we've gotten encouragement on all fronts," said Hugh Johnson, a market analyst at the First Albany Corporation. "It's been a very good earnings season. And then we have Greenspan's comments, and he's telling Congress: 'you really couldn't ask for a better economic backdrop.' "
Indeed, stocks were higher in early, but subdued, trading before Mr. Greenspan's testimony. The Dow was up about 55 points just before 2 P.M. Shortly thereafter, when news agencies transmitted accounts of his remarks, the financial markets rocketed higher.
"Mr. Greenspan's remarks hit the wires around 2 P.M., then the bonds jumped more than a point, the stock futures picked up and then it just ran the market," said Richard Cripps, a market analyst at Legg Mason in Baltimore. "The market seems to be in celebration rather than anticipation. We already had the Goldilocks view of the economy, and now Greenspan has given people the view that monetary policy is on hold."
With the economy in such a Goldilocks phase -- not too hot, not too cold, just right -- investors returned yesterday to many of the banking, drug and technology issues that have led the market higher this year.
Of the Dow's 30 component stocks, 28 gained yesterday, led by Du Pont, up 3 3/8 a share, to 66 3/16; Chevron, up 2 3/4, to 77 5/8, and Disney, up 2 7/16, to 77 5/8. Caterpillar lost 9/16, to 56 3/16, while Philip Morris, the Big Board's most actively traded issue, rose 2 1/8, to 42 5/8.
Among drug stocks, Warner-Lambert rose 3, to 142 1/2; in technology issues, Microsoft was the powerhouse, up 8 5/16, to 144 1/4. RJR Nabisco rose 1 1/16, to 30 7/8.
On the Big Board, advancing issues outpaced decliners, 2,094 to 842; volume was heavy at 580 million shares.
While many on Wall Street were expecting Mr. Greenspan to paint a rosy picture of the economy, many also feared that even the slightest dose of criticism yesterday might rattle the markets. But there was none of that.
Donald Fine, the chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management, said: "No one was expecting the Fed to tighten any time soon. But this removed any fear, and the market took off. After listening to his testimony, the risk of investors being wrong was greatly reduced."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
As the Dollar Keeps Rising, 'The Trend Is Your Friend'

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar reached another six-year high against the German mark yesterday and rose in most other dealings after top officials from the Bundesbank and the Federal Reserve signaled that they did not oppose the dollar's latest ascent.
Momentum from Tuesday's gains also helped carry it higher. Many traders bought dollars, fearing that they might miss a profitable opportunity. "We haven't broken out of the bullish trend," said Thomas Lapinski, chief dealer at the MTB Bank Corporation in New York. "You don't want to stand against the train coming at you. The trend is your friend." 
 The dollar reached an intraday high of 1.8325 marks, the strongest since July 1991, before settling in New York at 1.8268 marks, up from 1.8240 late Tuesday. The dollar rose to 115.65 yen from 115.15 yen. The British pound fetched $1.6804, up from $1.6790.
Traders said the dollar got an early boost from remarks by Guntram Palm, a member of the Bundesbank's policy-making council, who said that its strength against the mark does not create the risk of higher German inflation.
Although the dollar's strength could raise import prices, Mr. Palm said the effects were offset by Germany's weak economy, high unemployment and slow-growing money supply, which have discouraged spending.
His comments were widely viewed as a sign that German monetary policy makers were willing to let the mark weaken against the dollar as long as the decline is orderly. The weak mark could help stimulate German exports and help the economy grow.
Robert Fullem, a trader at NatWest Markets in New York, put it this way: "If you were a Bundesbank council member and you had a high unemployment rate and no inflation and were trying to get the economy to move forward, what are you going to do? There's no reason to have the mark strengthen."
Later, the dollar got further help from a second day of positive comments about the United States economy from Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman. He called the combination of steady growth and low inflation exceptional, with no mention of the dollar's strength as a possible risk.

HEADLINE: Concession With Little Immediate Effect

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT 

 BODY:
The Boeing Company's concession to European Union officials -- giving up exclusive 20-year contracts to supply aircraft to American, Delta and Continental airlines in return for approval of the acquisition of the McDonnell Douglas Corporation -- will have little practical effect for years to come, industry experts said yesterday.
After all, the airlines, having placed orders for the next 20 years, still want the aircraft they have ordered for the foreseeable future. And there are powerful incentives to remain with one manufacturer, including reduced training costs for pilots and mechanics, and the lower costs associated with carrying inventories of spare parts for only one brand of aircraft. 
 Boeing acceded to European demands that the exclusivity clauses be dropped so that Airbus Industrie, the European consortium that is Boeing's biggest rival, would not be frozen out of competition for new orders for so many years. However, Airbus or any other potential competitors to Boeing would have to offer strong incentives to airlines to complicate their fleets with new aircraft types.
"That will be a powerful force in deterring the airlines from making any radical changes," said Edmund S. Greenslet, an industry analyst who runs ESG Aviation Services in Ponte Verde Beach, Fla. "It's going to be a tough sell, but not an impossible sell."
But, he added, "For the next five years, even 10 years, I don't think it means anything."
Beyond that time, though, the Boeing concession appears to be a slight positive for Airbus and the airlines that signed the agreements with Boeing, and a slight negative for Boeing itself.
The airlines will continue to hold on to the steep discounts they received for new aircraft in return for wedding themselves to Boeing. At the same time, they are free to consider new offerings from other manufacturers before the end of their 20-year contracts.
"Now we get the best of both worlds," said Gordon M. Bethune, chairman of Continental Airlines.
In a news conference in Washington yesterday, Philip M. Condit, Boeing's chairman, said that Boeing had been reluctant to give up the exclusivity clauses, although he said that Boeing expected the change to have little impact on aircraft orders.
"Given this agreement, we can have, if not zero impact, then minimal impact on the bottom line," Mr. Condit said.
To the degree that removing the exclusivity clause on its contracts chips away at the competitive advantage of Boeing, the change benefits Airbus.
Airbus had feared the 20-year contracts for good reason. In practical terms, by the time an airline had moved to an all-Boeing fleet after 20 years, any airline would be reluctant to start carrying the additional costs associated with bringing in new plane types.
"Exclusive deals are not for 20 years, they are for eternity," Jean Pierson, managing director of Airbus, said at the recent air show in Paris.
Now, Airbus will at least have an opportunity to make sales pitches to top airline executives, particularly when leadership at AMR's American Airlines, Delta Air Lines and Continental changes over the next two decades.
That thinking was reflected when Airbus mounted an aggressive public relations campaign against Boeing's long-term contracts following Delta's announcement of the Boeing deal in March.
John J. Leahy, an Airbus senior vice president, contended at the time that the contracts deprived airline investors of a chance to get an even better deal in the future.
"Airline managements in the future are going to wonder what their predecessors got them into," Mr. Leahy said.

HEADLINE: New York's Prison Building Fever

 BODY:
The battle over prison construction is one of the remaining disputes holding up New York State's budget. Gov. George Pataki, trying to prove he can be tough on crime, had proposed to build 7,000 new prison beds over three years at a cost of about $635 million. Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver says only 800 new beds are necessary. For several reasons, the Speaker is more right than the Governor.
Mr. Pataki says more prison beds are needed to handle an increasing number of violent offenders. But the jail population of New York City, which supplies the majority of state prison inmates, has been declining, and 60 percent of those sent to state prisons last year had been convicted of nonviolent crimes. That would seem to justify reversing New York's expensive habit of building more and more prisons. The state could use existing cells more effectively if Mr. Pataki would push for reform of mandatory sentencing laws that force the courts to imprison many nonviolent offenders who might be handled more cheaply outside and to keep some offenders in prison much longer than necessary. 
 Mr. Silver proposes that the state build only 800 new maximum-security beds and supplement that with 800 new drug treatment beds to try to wean addicts from their habit. That targets two specific areas of need -- more space for some of the toughest inmates and treatment for those with serious drug problems.
Mr. Pataki seems more interested in grandstanding on the crime issue or satisfying upstate legislators who see prisons as economic development engines for their districts. By holding up the budget for a misguided response to crime, Mr. Pataki does the state a double disservice, harming both the budget and the criminal justice system.

HEADLINE: 3M Earnings Increase 9.7% But Fall Short of Expectations

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: ST. PAUL, July 23

 BODY:
The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company said today that earnings rose 9.7 percent in the second quarter, slightly less than analysts expected, as the strong dollar and new-product costs cut into higher sales.
The company's financial health is often considered a benchmark for the economy because of the manufacturer's large and diverse base of consumer and commercial products. 
 Net income at 3M, whose products include Post-It brand notes and Scotch brand tape, rose to $418 million, or $1.01 a share, from $381 million, or 91 cents a share, in the period a year earlier.
The per-share results fell short of the $1.03 that analysts, on average, had expected. On the New York Stock Exchange, 3M declined $1.875, to $98.4375.
Sales increased 8.4 percent, to $3.82 billion from $3.52 billion.
While sales in the United States and abroad were better than expected, rising 10 percent in this country and 15 percent internationally, the dollar's strength reduced earnings by 5 cents a share. As the dollar rises, sales denominated in other currencies produce less American currency.
International prices dropped 1 percent, and costs increased because of investments in the Pacing Plus new-products program, 3M said.
Jonathan Rosenzweig, an analyst at Salomon Brothers, said, "Revenue beat our forecasts handily due to strong international volume growth, implying the company must have had a very strong June." Operating profit margins were not as strong as expected, he said, because of the dollar's strength and the cost of the new products.
The manufacturer said both of its two major product sectors -- industrial and consumer products and life sciences -- did well.
Research and development costs increased $20 million from a year ago as 3M stepped up production of brightness-enhancement film, which is used on laptop computer screens, as well as chemicals that replace chlorofluorocarbons. Both are part of the Pacing Plus program, which speeds development of products that 3M believes have the potential for large sales and profits.
The company said it expected strong growth to continue in the second half despite the impact of currency conversions.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bond Prices Dip on Sale Of New Notes

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Treasury prices fell slightly yesterday after what traders called an expensive auction of new five-year notes.
The second day of Congressional testimony from Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, had little effect on bonds. 
 Mr. Greenspan repeated the favorable assessment of the economy and inflation that on Tuesday spurred the biggest bond rally since October. He added yesterday that long-term yields were high relative to inflation. Some investors took those comments as a sign that bonds could rally further.
Laurence H. Meyer, a Federal Reserve governor, and Alice Rivlin, the Fed vice chairwoman, also testified before Congress yesterday and gave optimistic assessments of the outlook for growth and inflation.
"Life is good right now," with moderate growth and low inflation making a good environment for bonds, said Alan Day, who manages $900 million at Stratevest Group in Burlington, Vt.
Still, the price of the benchmark 30-year bond fell 9/32, to 102 18/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 6.43 percent, from 6.41 percent on Tuesday.
Bonds gave back early gains after the Treasury sold $11.5 billion in five-year notes at a yield of 6.024 percent, below traders' expectations. That raised concern that Wall Street firms that bid on the notes might have a tough time finding buyers for the securities.
"It came too expensive," said Bill Kirby, a trader at Prudential Securities Inc., one of the 39 primary dealers required to bid at Treasury debt sales.
On Tuesday, bond prices surged after Mr. Greenspan said the economy was on an "exceptional" path of strong growth and slow inflation, easing worries about an imminent increase in interest rates. He repeated those remarks to the Senate Banking Committee yesterday, concluding his semiannual testimony to Congress.
His comments cheered investors because many were bracing for the usually cautious central banker to sound an alarm about the dangers of future inflation.
Instead, "Greenspan basically came out and said they won't be tightening in the near future," said Jim Madelmayer, a trader at Dresdner Securities Inc. "The market will continue to do better."
The Fed last raised rates in March, increasing its target for the Federal funds rate by a quarter percentage point to 5.5 percent.
Still, some investors said there was little fresh incentive to buy Treasury securities at the highest prices this year.
"A lot of good news is already priced into the market," which may curb further gains, said David Schroeder, who manages $2 billion in bonds for American Century Benham in Mountain View, Calif.
In the corporate bond market, the McDonald's Corporation, the Riverwood International Corporation and PT Polysindo EKA Perkasa, a textile company in Indonesia, sold a combined $650 million of bonds as companies rushed to take advantage of the recent rally in Treasury securities.

HEADLINE: Greenspan Silence on Stocks Speaks Volumes to Investors

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 23

 BODY:
He was concerned about the lofty level of stock prices when the Dow was at 6,400 late last year. But when Alan Greenspan assessed the economy for Congress this week, he hardly mentioned Wall Street -- never mind that stocks were bursting through 8,000.
So what changed? 
 Through his silence this week about the risks of a stock-price bubble, Mr. Greenspan may have been conceding that the market was right after all. What's more, he appeared to acknowledge that he, the all-powerful chairman of the Federal Reserve, was wrong in December when he coined the phrase "irrational exuberance" to describe investor psychology.
Certainly, investors took it that way. Stocks rallied to a high after his statements on Tuesday and rose again, though with less vigor, today, in part because Mr. Greenspan waved no red flags and characterized the economy as humming along at a near-perfect pitch.
Analyzing Mr. Greenspan's thinking from afar can be a perilous business, but many economists believe that Mr. Greenspan's concerns have been assuaged by the strong profits American businesses have enjoyed this year, making stock prices relative to earnings less inflated than they might have seemed.
Which is not to say that stock prices could not still crash, or that they are certain to go on rising. Or that Mr. Greenspan was not justified in exploring the question of how a booming market -- or a crashing one -- might affect the economy and monetary policy.
But the strong corporate earnings performance appears to meet the test that Mr. Greenspan laid out when he sought to explain his "irrational exuberance" comments during testimony in March.
"Analytically," Mr. Greenspan said at the time, "current stock-price valuations at prevailing long-term interest rates could be justified by very strong earnings growth expectations."
Since then corporate America has posted robust increases in profits, generated for the most part by solid improvements in sales and productivity rather than by financial gimmicks.
"Greenspan said earlier this year that he'd accept the view that stocks are reasonably priced if we saw that expected profits or profit margins were ultimately realized," said David Jones, an economist at Aubrey Lanston & Company in New York. "That's precisely what happened. He set up the criteria and essentially they were met."
To some extent, Mr. Greenspan may have been reticent to raise the subject again because of the storm of criticism that showered down on him after his statements in December. Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the Republican leader, asked whether the Federal Reserve's independence needed to be reviewed. Economists wondered why Mr. Greenspan, a strident free marketer, was questioning the efficiency of the financial markets. And many small investors asked what business the Fed chairman had trying to talk down the value of their portfolios.
"There's no question he was smarting from the criticism," Mr. Jones said.
But economists who follow the debates within the Federal Reserve and speak to officials there said Mr. Greenspan also seemed to change his outlook gradually during the winter and spring. They said he had asked a lot of questions about corporate profits and spent a lot of time studying reports about strong earnings and low inflation. His thinking may also have changed after the market fell by almost 10 percent in March and April and then promptly rebounded with no apparent damage to the economy, the financial system or investor confidence.
"Suddenly he was less warlike on the stock market's elevation, and even his concerns about the inflation threat seemed to become more muted this spring and summer," said Lawrence Kudlow, an economist at the American Skandia Life Assurance Corporation.
Mr. Greenspan's thinking may have been influenced by research suggesting that stock prices were not excessively high by historical standards when the climate of low inflation and steady growth were taken into account along with strong profits. Mickey D. Levy, an economist at Nationsbank in New York, developed a model -- taking account of measures of earnings growth, inflation, interest rates and stock-return volatility -- that concluded that equity valuations "are broadly consistent with the fundamentals."
Similarly, Allan H. Meltzer, an economist at Carnegie Mellon University and the American Enterprise Institute, compared valuations during periods of strong growth and low inflation with periods of slow growth and high inflation. He found that current valuations were more or less in line with those of other eras of strong growth and low inflation.
"Both the quality and the quantity of profits are increasing at a pretty steep rate," Mr. Meltzer said. "Even if profits were to level off, you wouldn't get a huge drop in the stock market."
If the outlook for corporate profits has improved, it would support the theory floated by Mr. Greenspan, most recently during his testimony this week, that big investments in technology by businesses were paying off with productivity gains. Increased productivity would not only help explain and support higher corporate profits but would also help explain why the economy has been able to grow steadily without inflation -- even though unemployment has fallen well below the levels at which rising prices have historically started to destabilize the economy.
Mr. Greenspan made clear that he was not yet ready to accept that theory in whole, and other Fed officials continued to argue that the old rules governing the relationship between inflation, unemployment and growth have not changed. But three of the Fed's key policy makers, in their own Congressional testimony today, agreed with Mr. Greenspan that the path ahead, while not without some risks, is as clear as any central banker is willing to concede.
"The economy as a whole is functioning amazingly well," said Alice M. Rivlin, the Fed's vice chairwoman.
And Laurence H. Meyer, a Fed governor, was even more upbeat. "The performance of this 'good news' economy," he said, "is enough to make you want to cheer."

HEADLINE: Maidenform's Problems Reflect Industry Pitfalls

BYLINE: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER 

 BODY:
In the world of apparel, few things are as complicated as a bra. It may have 20 pieces and come in more than a dozen sizes and colors. Fit is extremely important -- no woman is going to buy a bra and take it to her tailor to have it altered. All of this makes production a real headache.
Production, far removed from the shopper's eye, is what most likely led to the downfall of Maidenform Worldwide Inc., which filed for protection under Chapter 11 on Tuesday night, and could threaten other intimate-apparel companies that do not keep an eye on the back office. 
 Efficiency is important to all clothing makers, but it has become increasingly essential in the intimate-apparel business, where a few giants have become dominant in the last five years, playing on their sheer size to achieve economies of scale and production efficiencies.
While Maidenform was apparently doing a fine job of staying ahead in fashion trends, the company ran into serious trouble getting its products from design room to factory to retail store in a timely manner, people with knowledge of the company said, and the production problems spiraled down to the balance sheet.
"Money is made and lost in keeping your manufacturing going," said Lee Chaden, the chief executive of Sara Lee's intimates division.
The Sara Lee Corporation is the biggest player in the $10 billion domestic intimate-apparel business, with about a 29 percent market share; the Warnaco Group and the VF Corporation have about 7 percent each. The privately held, New York-based Maidenform has 3.5 percent, on sales last year of about $400 million, and dozens of smaller players pick up the rest. Victoria's Secret, a unit of Intimate Brands Inc., says it has a 10 percent share, although several other companies make its apparel.
Over the last five years, these biggest players have become more aggressive with acquisitions here and in Europe, snatching up smaller brands and gaining efficiencies along the way. VF, for example, cited intimate apparel as one of the key growth areas that contributed to its strong second-quarter earnings, which the company announced this week. VF was recently in talks to acquire Maidenform, but the negotiations collapsed.
Each company has also tried to eke out as many new fashion trends as possible in an area of apparel that is least driven by fashion. The Wonderbra, a Sara Lee product that made cleavage fashionable again, invigorated both that company and the many competitors that copied the bra in 1994 and 1995.
And sales of so-called shapewear, a relatively new product that functions more or less as a newfangled girdle, grew 12.7 percent last year.
Designer licenses for underwear lines have also become a key point of competition. Maidenform sells apparel under the Oscar de la Renta name, Warnaco has the Calvin Klein license and Sara Lee recently acquired the rights to make Ralph Lauren intimates, which are hitting the stores now.
But most important is the manufacturing of bras. According to the NPD Group, a research firm, bras accounted for $3.6 billion, or more than a third, of the intimate-apparel industry last year. And unlike other apparel, which in their simplest form can be put together with a few seams and a zipper, bras are complicated to make and their production requires careful management.
"Bras are one of the most complex pieces of apparel," said Adelle Kirk, a manager at Kurt Salmon Associates, a management consulting firm that specializes in the apparel and retail businesses. "There are lots of different styles, and each style has a dozen different sizes, and within that there are a lot of colors.
"Further, there is a lot of product engineering. You've got hooks, you've got straps, there are usually two parts to every cup and each requires a heavy amount of sewing. It is very component intensive."
To manage this complex production, bra makers have to wring the most they can out of each component -- such as getting the same type of strap or color palette to work for five different bras -- and manage their factory orders carefully.
With so many pieces involved, coordination is especially important. Order inefficiently, and factories can lie dead for long periods, only to be overwhelmed at the last minute and unable to keep up with the workload. This results in not getting the products to the store in time. Several retailers have complained over the last year that while they liked Maidenform's lines, they had trouble getting the products in time to sell.
Maidenform had caught up with the shapewear trend -- its Subtract line had about 30 percent of the shapewear business. It had a strong designer name in the Oscar de la Renta line. And few could beat the brand -- Maidenform is a household name among those old enough to have sat through at least one humiliating department store bra fitting.
But Maidenform, which like other companies in its field looked for growth through acquisitions, did not carefully manage the integration of operations when it bought 92 percent of NCC Industries, another intimate-apparel company, in 1995.
"That acquisition diverted management's attention and they were not realizing the synergistic benefits, which included cost saving in the back office and in operations," said Ted Stenger, the new president of Maidenform.
Further, the company was making up for inefficiencies by overspending, had tapped out its bank loans and was not ready to make a $4.3 million payment on senior notes that were due in September. And NCC had a shortage of materials needed to make the apparel, which slowed production and stunted distribution, causing sales to decline. NCC lost $1.3 million in the first quarter and its sales declined 46 percent.
Maidenform will now consolidate several divisions to cut costs and get better synergies.
Analysts say that because of its strong product lines and fierce brand name, Maidenform may well emerge from Chapter 11 a viable player, but only if it turns its focus on its production issues. "In the old days," said Laurence Leeds, an analyst at Buckingham Research Group, "if you did fair, you had a nice business. But now if you do fair, you go home."

HEADLINE: Boeing Concession Averts Trade War With Europe

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: BRUSSELS, July 23

 BODY:
The Boeing Company may rule the skies as the world's dominant commercial aircraft manufacturer, but it humbly gave in to the demands of European antitrust regulators and won approval today of its $14 billion merger with the McDonnell Douglas Corporation.
Boeing's last-minute concessions on Tuesday narrowly averted a trade battle between the European Union and the United States. European regulators, displaying an increased appetite for brinkmanship, were prepared to reject a merger between two companies based on American soil despite the approval of the deal by United States authorities and support from the White House. 
 European officials have argued for months that the merger poses grave threats to competition, given that Boeing already controls more than 60 percent of the global market for commercial aircraft and that its only real rival is the European consortium Airbus Industrie.
In particular, they objected to exclusive contracts Boeing had signed with three United States airlines. Today, in its key concession toward winning approval from the European Union's executive arm, the European Commission, Boeing agreed not to enforce the exclusive-supplier provisions of those deals, though analysts said that would have little effect on Boeing's bottom line.
While a trade war was avoided, experts on both sides of the Atlantic said increasing economic globalization would make further disputes like this one inevitable. Despite growing international agreement on issues like tariffs and import restrictions, as more companies with global operations seek to merge, clashes between countries with different policies for promoting competition and regulating trade are bound to recur.
"A train wreck was avoided today, but we have many more trains coming down the track," said Michael Hodges, senior lecturer in international relations at the London School of Economics. "We need a new signaling system to keep them from colliding."
The agreement reached with Boeing marked a major display of power by Europe's Minister of Competition, Karel van Miert, and a clear sign that European leaders are willing to impose their will on global companies regardless of territorial boundaries.
But such clashes can and have been started just as easily by the United States. Indeed, the Federal Trade Commission successfully insisted on several concessions on patents before allowing the recent merger between two Swiss pharmaceutical giants, Ciba-Geigy and Sandoz, to proceed.
"This was not a one-shot, one-time deal," said Joel Klein, the Assistant Attorney General for antitrust issues at the Justice Department, who was involved in negotiations over the Boeing case. "As the world becomes more globalized, these are the kinds of problems we will be seeing."
Because Mr. van Miert got almost everything he had demanded, experts said his victory was likely to make the pugnacious and savvy antitrust chief even more formidable.
"American competitive authorities didn't entirely agree with us, but we have always insisted on our point of view," Mr. van Miert said triumphantly at a news conference here today. Boeing, he added, "must have realized that unless they made major concessions, the commission would act against them."
Although the European Commission had demanded and won concessions in one other deal between two American companies, the 1995 merger between the Kimberly-Clark Corporation and Scott Paper, never before had it threatened as loudly or as often to impose billions of dollars in fines on an American company if it did not get its way.
While the Europeans could not technically have blocked the Boeing-McDonnell Douglas merger, the fines could have made it difficult for Boeing to operate in Europe.
Boeing executives and a number of American politicians had accused Mr. van Miert of merely trying to protect Airbus, which is Boeing's main rival in commercial aircraft manufacturing. And many European politicians for several months have made plain their alarms that the new merger would put Boeing permanently in control of the world market.
Mr. van Miert always denied the accusation of protectionism, arguing that he had simply applied Europe's merger regulation guidelines and sought the remedies he felt were necessary to safeguard competition. Boeing currently sells more than 60 percent of the world's commercial aircraft, while Airbus sells about 30 percent and McDonnell Douglas sells less than 10 percent.
Analysts said Boeing's concessions would probably have little effect on the company's competitive position, at least in the near term. But Richard R. Albrecht, executive vice president of Boeing's commercial airplane group, acknowledged today that his company had blinked.
"We were faced with a very difficult decision," he said. "None of the alternatives that we faced seemed attractive."
Perhaps the least attractive option for everyone was a full-blown trade war. As recently as Tuesday morning, it looked as if both sides were at an impasse and a trade war was indeed possible. But as the European Commission's scheduled vote on the issue drew near, Boeing finally folded its cards and conceded to Mr. van Miert.
Investors appeared to be relieved that an agreement was reached as shares of Boeing rose 4.7 percent, to $59.0625, up $2.6875 on the day, in trading on the New York Stock Exchange.
As part of the agreement, Boeing also said it would license some patents on commercial aircraft to rivals. And it agreed to keep what remains of McDonnell Douglas's small commercial aircraft business a legally separate entity for a number of years, so as to prevent its being used to extend Boeing's control over the market.
But the big battle was over Boeing's long-term contracts to be the exclusive supplier of aircraft to American Airlines, Delta Air Lines and Continental Airlines. Mr. van Miert insisted that the exclusivity clauses be dropped and that Boeing agree not to strike similar deals in the future.
The Clinton Administration had tried to bridge the gap several weeks ago without success. Mr. Klein said the Government was primarily concerned about promoting the continued consolidation of the military industry, in which companies have been furiously merging as a way to survive in an era of reduced Pentagon budgets for weapons.
Even as the dispute was resolved, other trans-Atlantic mergers and alliances were being weighed. The Federal Trade Commission, for instance, is investigating the competitive effect of a proposed merger between two giant British consumer product companies, Guinness P.L.C. and Grand Metropolitan P.L.C.
And most experts predict big clashes over competition policy on telecommunications, an area in which European monopolies are being opened up and American companies are intensely eager to compete.
Moreover, American and European officials do not see eye to eye on how to deal with future conflicts like the Boeing case. Mr. van Miert noted today that the European Union had proposed that countries begin discussing ways to incorporate competition policy into the structure of the World Trade Organization, the Geneva-based agency that acts as an independent court to resolve trade disputes between countries.
But American officials have been against that idea, fearing, for instance, that it might endanger American rules against foreign companies exporting products to the United States at below their real cost, a practice known as "dumping."
"Competition policy has different meanings in different countries," said Jay Ziegler, a spokesman for the United States trade representative in Washington.
"The U.S. takes a consumer's eye on how the merger will affect consumers. Other countries look at how it affects other companies."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Boeing Gives In and Wins European Approval of Deal
Boeing gave in to European regulators' demands and won approval of its merger with McDonnell Douglas. At a news conference in Washington, the chief executives of the two companies -- Philip M. Condit of Boeing, left, and Harry Stonecipher of McDonnell Douglas -- discussed the agreement.
Though Boeing's capitulation put off the threat of a trade war, experts said increasing economic globalization would make similar disputes inevitable as other multinational companies seek to merge. [Page A1.] 

Though Boeing agreed to give up arrangements making it the exclusive supplier of aircraft to three airlines -- American, Continental and Delta -- the concession will have little practical effect for years, analysts said. [D5.]
 
Oil Earnings Unexpectedly Strong
Four large energy companies -- Mobil, Chevron, Shell and Conoco -- reported strong earnings, surpassing analyst expectations, as higher refining profits offset lower crude oil and natural gas prices. [D4.]
 
Mixed Results for Airlines
Trans World Airlines, the only leading American carrier that continues to lose money, posted a bigger-than-expected loss, $12 million. US Airways's earnings rose 2 percent, but that was less than expected. Continental's profit was down 23 percent but topped forecasts. [D6.]
 
Stock Market Again Sets Records
The stock market, continuing to bask in an economy that Alan Greenspan calls exceptional, scaled new heights. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 26.71 points to close at a record 8,088.36. With technology shares mostly stronger, the Nasdaq composite rose 3.79, to 1,567.65. [D8.]
 
Treasury prices fell slightly, with the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond rising to 6.43 percent from 6.41. [D18.]
 
3M Profit Rise Is Disappointing
Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing, whose performance is often considered a benchmark for the economy because of the company's large and diverse product base, said earnings rose 9.7 percent, slightly less than expected. Its shares fell slightly on the news. [D5.]
 
Nomura Admits Payoffs to Gangster
The president of Nomura Securities acknowledged for the first time that the company had made payoffs to a racketeer, and he vowed to clean up the firm. [D8.]
 
Tarses Says She Will Stay at ABC
Jamie Tarses, the president of ABC Entertainment, said that she was staying at the network, flatly denying speculation that she was negotiating to get out of her contract or that ABC was attempting to force her out. [C16.]
 
Advantage, Union Pacific Resources
Though Pennzoil, which once courted Union Pacific Resources, is now fighting off a hostile bid from that company, Union Pacific Resources appears to be getting the upper hand in the struggle. Market Place. [D8.]
 
Swiss Bank Finds Old Accounts
Swiss Bank said that it had previously failed to report the existence of accounts worth more than $11 million that might include assets from Holocaust victims. [A10.]
 
Another Strike Against G.M.
Labor unrest continued at General Motors, as workers struck at a plant in Warren, Mich., that supplies parts for nearly all of the company's American-made vehicles. [D4.]
 
Lilly Results Match Estimates
Eli Lilly reported a net loss, reflecting a previously announced charge of $2.4 billion to write down its PCS Health Systems unit, but operating profit rose 21 percent. [D2.]

INTERNATIONAL A3-11
 
Milosevic Expands Powers As Serbia Deteriorates
Slobodan Milosevic switched jobs, becoming President of the Yugoslav federation, and stepping down as President of Serbia. He maneuvered to take the Yugoslav presidency, until now a figurehead job, because he was barred by the Constitution from serving again as President of Serbia. He promised "a peaceful, independent, just and developed country." But since the war that Mr. Milosevic presided over and that led to the breakup of Yugoslavia, the Serbian economy has declined sharply and has become largely criminalized. A3
 
After War, the Playing Field
Croatia and Serbia held their first soccer match since the war pulled them apart six years ago. It was a desultory affair. "Neither side knows how to play," complained one 17-year-old fan. A3 

Tuition for British Students
The British Government plans to impose tuition fees on all college students, effectively abandoning the country's long-held commitment to free higher education for everyone. In a nation where free education is considered a basic right, the announcement was taken as a further sign that Prime Minister Tony Blair's new Government was intent on dismantling many of the most sacred vestiges of Britain's old-style welfare state. A7
 
Irish Plan Opposed by Some
The main Protestant political parties voted to reject a proposal by the British and Irish Governments for disarming the Irish Republican Army and Protestant paramilitary groups. British and Irish officials, who expected the decision, said the setback would not kill peace negotiations, pointing out that the largest Protestant party has pledged to continue to work with the Government. A8
 
Swiss Bank Reports Mixup
As Swiss banks sought to restore credibility lost in their handling of dormant accounts thought to belong to Holocaust victims, one of the country's top banks acknowledged that it had failed to report the existence of accounts worth more than $11 million that may include Jewish assets. The admission, by the Swiss Bank Corporation in Basel, clouded an unparalleled move by the banks to publicize dormant accounts opened before the war ended. A10
 
Experts, Holocaust survivors and others studied the list of 2,000 long-dormant Swiss bank accounts made public this week and said they were angry that the banks had not done more to track down the depositors. A10
 
Weapon Cuts in Europe
The United States, Russia and 28 other nations agreed on the framework of a treaty to reduce the number of tanks and other non-nuclear weapons in Europe, especially in Central European countries of the former Warsaw Pact. The agreement would replace and expand a 1990 accord on conventional arms between NATO and nations that were then members of the Soviet bloc. A5

Clinton Aided Fund-Raising
President Clinton personally requested a list of potential contributors whom he offered to call to try to raise $1 million for the Democratic National Committee early last year, according to a White House memorandum recently turned over to Congressional investigators. Several weeks after Mr. Clinton had asked to call the donors, several people on the President's list gave $50,000 and $100,000 checks to the Democrats, according to Federal Election Commission records. Even mild cases of a common disorder of the uterine lining, endometriosis, can cause infertility in women, a study has found. But the study also found that surgery to treat endometriosis can nearly double such women's chances of getting pregnant. A13

A coalition of 68 churches, synagogues and nonprofit groups in New York City is refusing to hire welfare recipients as part of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's workfare program, denouncing the program as unjust. HEADLINE: Strike Closes Parts Factory In Job Dispute

BYLINE: By ROBYN MEREDITH 

DATELINE: WARREN, Mich., July 23

 BODY:
This has been the year of strikes at the General Motors Corporation, a series of contests pitting a union determined to keep the company from downsizing against a bloated auto maker struggling to get in shape as more and more customers buy from G.M.'s more efficient competitors.
The latest walkout came just before midnight on Tuesday here, where 2,510 workers build parts used on nearly all of the company's American-made cars and trucks. If the strike lasts more than a few days, it could shut down most of the company, resulting in tens of thousands of layoffs nationwide as other G.M. factories run out of the transmissions, wheels and other parts built here. 
 Indeed, late today General Motors notified 2,700 workers at the Flint factory, which builds Buick LeSabres and Pontiac Bonnevilles, not to report to work on Thursday.
Because of the magnitude of the impact, a settlement could come soon. People close to the negotiations said that considerable progress was made in talks today and that a deal might be reached quickly.
Members of the United Automobile Workers picketing outside the gates of the Warren Transmission Plant, a giant, red-brick factory in this suburb of Detroit, said they were determined to stay on strike until the company gave in to their demands for increased staffing.
The labor unrest here is the sixth strike this year at General Motors, and comes just five days after the end of a three-month strike at a pickup truck factory in nearby Pontiac. The company said that in the second quarter alone, strikes had cost it $490 million -- enough to build a new, state-of-the-art factory.
Reg McGhee, a spokesman for the union's national headquarters in Detroit, said the Warren strike was part of the union's effort to retain jobs.
"Manpower is a big issue there, as are health and safety," Mr. McGhee said. "It's much the same as in other negotiations by local unions."
Sean P. McAlinden, an economist at the University of Michigan, said today's strike reflected the auto maker's desire to reduce its labor force through attrition as new car and pickup truck designs require less and less labor.
"G.M. is still committed to their long-run restructuring of the corporation, which may eliminate anywhere from 50,000 to 75,000 hourly jobs," Mr. McAlinden said.
General Motors has about 220,000 hourly workers. At its peak in the early 1960's, it built three-fifths of all the automobiles sold in the United States. But its share of the market has been steadily shrinking, and last month it was down to a record low 29 percent, partly because of the strikes earlier this year.
The U.A.W. wants General Motors to hire 500 workers to fill union jobs lost to attrition as members retired from the factory here over the last several years.
"They haven't replaced a retiree in this plant in almost two years," said Bill H. Bagwell Jr., a committee member for the plant's union, Local 909. "We are hundreds of jobs short."
Other strikers said that the company was also trying to find a supplier to build the steel wheels now made by about 100 workers at the plant here, and that it planned to move other workers from a factory in Flint to Warren -- some with enough seniority to replace those here.
In addition, the union is negotiating with General Motors to fix various health and safety problems, and several strikers complained about a lack of respect for workers.
The company refused to comment on the causes of the strike.
Even if it reaches a deal here, it has more work ahead. The company is struggling to negotiate agreements with local unions at 10 more factories nearly nine months after it reached a broad agreement with the U.A.W.'s national leadership.

HEADLINE: CUNY Chancellor Followed Policy on Writing Test Requirement;
Help the Undereducated

 BODY:

To the Editor:
It is difficult to justify spending $1.1 billion a year to regain the imagined perfection of the past "when City College was viewed as the public Harvard" (news article, July 20). The City University of New York should stop competing for well-prepared students, since government aid programs insure that most bright students have access to a college education.
In contrast, there is every reason to support a public university that provides quality instruction to undereducated students and to immigrants of limited English proficiency. Many of these students will require more than a semester of remedial education. 
 At a time when the future of our economy is increasingly dependent on a college-educated work force, the failure of CUNY to articulate such a compelling mission makes it an easy target for continued budget cuts.
 
ERIC NADELSTERN
Long Island City, N.Y., July 20, 1997
 
The writer is principal of the International High School at La Guardia Community College.

HEADLINE: British Students Facing a New Test: Tuition

BYLINE: By SARAH LYALL 

DATELINE: LONDON, July 23

 BODY:
The Government announced today that for the first time, Britain plans to impose tuition fees on all college students, effectively abandoning the country's long-held commitment to free higher education for everyone.
For Americans used to paying fees for state-run schools or tuition approaching $30,000 a year at Ivy League schools, the proposal -- to charge up to $1,600 a year -- may seem laughably modest. But the plan also means students would no longer be eligible for Government grants covering room and board, and many graduates will face debts of more than $16,000. 
 In a nation where free education is considered a basic right, the announcement was taken as a further sign that Prime Minister Tony Blair's new Government is intent on dismantling many most sacred vestiges of Britain's welfare state.
"Free tuition is seen as a right," said Liz Llewellyn, a spokeswoman for the National Union of Students, which says the prospect of leaving school deeply in debt will deter many young people from attending college at all. "We've always been told that if you choose to go on with your education, the state should pay because you'll give so much back to the state by getting a better job and paying more in taxes."
The Government's plan was outlined in a speech to the House of Commons this afternoon by David Blunkett, the Secretary for Education and Employment. He said Britain's universities, which face a deficit of up to $3.2 billion in the next decade, had fallen into a financial crisis that could be addressed only by imposing fees.
Tuition at British universities is free to citizens of Britain and other European Union countries; room and board is paid for by a combination of Government grants, student loans and parental help. Postgraduate and part-time students and students from countries outside the Union already pay tuition.
Under the Government's plan, all but the poorest students would be expected to pay tuition of up to $1,600 a year, as well as several thousand dollars for room and board. Student loans, to be paid back according to income and over a number of years, would be available for both tuition and living expenses.
Some students said today that the new charges would put an almost unbearable strain on their already shaky finances. Others said that while they would benefit from the more relaxed loan repayment schedule, they felt the Government had abdicated a basic responsibility.
"The issue is whether or not it's fair for students to pay fees," said Kat Myers, 21, a student at Loughborough University in Leicestershire, who does clerical work to help meet her living expenses. "The ethos of this country has always been that it should lie with the Government."
In most other European Union countries, university costs are paid for out of taxes and governments spend a comparatively higher percentage of gross domestic product on college-level education. But not even in Germany, for instance, where there has been considerable pressure to reduce social spending, has the Government proposed to levy university fees on students.
For a number of years, Britain's universities have been warning of an impending financial crisis. While the number of students has increased drastically -- in the early 1960's, one in 20 young people in Britain was enrolled in higher education; today the figure is one in three -- Government aid to universities per student has declined.
Some colleges at Oxford and Cambridge have their own endowments and have soldiered on with relatively few problems. But other institutions have had to scrimp and save.

HEADLINE: Stocks Keep Advancing; Dow Up 26.71

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA 

 BODY:
It's the kind of summer that investors have long dreamed about.
The economy is humming along. Federal Reserve policy makers are cheering it on. And the stock market is climbing to new heights. 
 Yesterday, a day after Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, told Congress that the economy was "exceptional," investors bid prices up even more.
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 26.71 points, to a new high close of 8,088.36, while the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 2.58 points, to a record 936.56.
"Yesterday, Chairman Greenspan said some really nice things about the economy, and the Dow shot up 154 points," said Hildegard Zagorski, a market analyst at Prudential Securities. "It was a more subdued advance today, but this is still part of the ongoing bull market."
In fact, the Dow's gains have been spectacular. A year ago yesterday, the Dow stood at 5,346.55 -- its lowest point of summer 1996. Since then, the blue-chip average has soared 51.3 percent in one of the most powerful 12-month run-ups ever.
And in slightly less than seven months of this year, the Dow has nearly equaled its 26 percent climb for all of 1996. With the Dow up 25.4 percent this year, it is just 35 points shy of matching last year's advance.
Of course, the mantra heard repeatedly on Wall Street is that investors are being treated to a "just right" economy, a combination of steady growth, low inflation and rising earnings.
There is also talk about the continued strength of the dollar, a strong American economic position relative to Europe and Japan, and the undeniable power of euphoric investor sentiment.
"Clearly, sentiment is what's driving the market now, not earnings," said Gail Dudack, chief investment strategist at UBS Securities. "The trade-weighted dollar is near an eight-year high. And if the dollar's a safe haven, people want to buy more U.S. assets."
Falling interest rates in the bond market have also been a boon to stock prices. Yesterday, the benchmark 30-year Treasury rose two basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, to 6.43 percent. But since late May, the long bond has fallen sharply, down 60 basis points from 7.03 percent.
This economic brew has helped carry share prices out of a month-long slump that ended in mid-April and toward gains of nearly 27 percent.
Still, according to Jeffrey Applegate, the chief investment strategist at Lehman Brothers, this type of run-up was not at all unusual after a Fed tightening, which last occurred in late March.
"We've seen this movie five times before in the postwar period," he said. "It's the classic contraction-expansion scenario."
When the Fed tightens to slow economic growth, he said, as it did in 1962, 1966, 1984, 1987 and 1994, the market typically contracts. But in each instance Mr. Applegate cited, a year later -- after the economy retrenched -- stocks made double-digit percentage gains.
"The Fed is tightening because G.D.P. is too strong, and they want to slow it down," Mr. Applegate said. "And when the Fed achieves that goal, the bond market rallies, and stocks gain."
Yesterday, however, the gains came after a mixed bag of earnings reports, with DuPont beating expectations and Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing failed to meet them.
Shares of DuPont rose 1 7/16, to 67 5/8; shares of 3M fell 1 13/16, to 98 1/2.
Technology shares were mostly stronger yesterday, with Compaq Computer rising 6 7/8, to 138 3/8; Gateway 2000 up 3, to 44 3/4, and Dell Computer advancing 4, to 164.
Travel Services, a travel agency based in Palm Beach, Fla., was a strong initial public offering, rising nearly 60 percent from its offering price to 22 1/4 on its first day of trading.
The technology-heavy Nasdaq composite rose 3.79 points, to 1,567.65. And on the Big Board, advancing issues outpaced decliners, 1,733 to 1,167; volume was heavy, at 620.6 million shares traded, in what has become an extremely active summer.
With investors continuing to pour money into mutual funds that track the indexes, such as the S.& P. 500, and portfolio managers trying to narrow their performance gap, the market has remained unusually active, analysts said.
"There was a time when people took a vacation," said William LeFevre, an analyst at Ehrenkrantz King Nussbaum. "But now the stakes are too high. People are either delegating, or they're not going away."

HEADLINE: Nonprofit and Religious Groups Vow to Fight Workfare Program

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE

 BODY:
Denouncing workfare as morally unjust, a coalition of 68 churches, synagogues and nonprofit groups is refusing to hire welfare recipients under Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's program requiring people to work for their benefits.
Borrowing the language of abolitionism, the coalition said it wanted to use its moral stature to press New York City to treat its 38,000 workfare employees with greater dignity and to pay them far more than they now receive. 
 Beside a sign saying, "Rudy, We Will Not Be Your Slave Drivers," several clergy members and leaders of nonprofit groups said at a news conference yesterday that they would fight the program by refusing to take any workfare employees, at a time when the city hopes to place thousands of such workers with nonprofit agencies.
"This program fails miserably to meet the criteria of justice and fairness," said the Rev. Peter Laarman, the pastor at Judson Memorial Church in Greenwich Village. "We don't want to say five years from now, here was an evil system that grew up around us and we didn't resist it."
The members of the coalition include Judson Memorial Church, the Stephen Wise Free Synagogue, Congregation B'nai Jeshurun on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, the Convent Avenue Baptist Church in Harlem, the First Presbyterian Church in Brooklyn, the Legal Aid Society and St. Mark's Church-in-the-Bowery. [List, page B6.]
Mr. Giuliani defended the program yesterday as fair and effective in moving people from welfare to work, asserting that the city had cut its welfare rolls by 285,000, in part thanks to workfare.
Officials in some nonprofit groups that have used workfare employees say the workers enable them to stretch their tight budgets and provide services that they could not otherwise afford. Several officials also said their organizations gave workfare participants valuable training and supervision.
But religious leaders in the coalition likened the workfare program to slavery, saying it forces welfare recipients to work without pay and drives down other workers' wages. They also attacked workfare for forcing many recipients to quit college and having thousands of workfare employees do the work once done by higher-paid city workers.
The clergy members and leaders of nonprofit groups urged the city to pay workfare workers what they called a living wage, to provide them with job training and to insure them permanent jobs. The coalition is urging other groups not to participate in the program even as the Giuliani administration is looking to them to take more welfare recipients, as it expands its Work Experience Program from 38,000 people to an expected 100,000 in the next few years.
About 2,500 workfare participants now work for nonprofit organizations, with the rest working directly for the city, cleaning streets and parks and doing other jobs. City officials say it will be far easier to expand the program if it can place more workers in nonprofit agencies.
Gary Bretton-Granatoor, senior rabbi at the Stephen Wise Synagogue, said he viewed workfare as a moral issue and gave a sermon just before Memorial Day condemning the city's workfare program, which is by far the nation's largest.
"There's a section in Leviticus that says if somebody in your community comes under your authority and they need your help, you are not allowed to treat them as a slave," he said. "My problem with workfare is they're not getting paid for the work they're doing. They're asked to work because they're receiving benefits. They're not treated in a human way. They're not given adequate changing facilities. They're not given adequate bathroom facilities. There is no way to address their grievances. That to me is enslavement."
Mr. Laarman, who is coordinating the antiworkfare effort, said he hoped that the coalition's efforts would inspire the formation of similar groups elsewhere as the new Federal welfare law requires other cities to expand their workfare programs. The New York coalition, Mr. Laarman said, was inspired in part by a coalition of churches, synagogues, nonprofit groups and labor unions in Maryland, which persuaded that state to prohibit its communities from using workfare workers to displace government employees.
But Mr. Giuliani defended workfare at a news conference, saying: "The program is an excellent program, and it is the most realistic program you can have for a city that had over a million people on welfare."
Anthony Coles, the senior adviser to the Mayor who oversees workfare, says workfare is a transition program aimed at moving workers from welfare to work and should not be viewed as a regular job. City officials say workfare teaches welfare recipients the discipline of work and has helped make the city's streets and parks cleaner.
The city has been contacting private agencies to invite them to hire workfare participants, and leaders of the coalition said about a third of their organizations had already been approached by the city.
The Rev. Kevin Sullivan, chief operating officer of Catholic Charities for the Archdiocese of New York, said the archdiocese employed some workfare workers but nevertheless sympathized with the coalition's concerns. "We've taken a very clear position with regard to work and welfare," he said. "For us work is not a dirty word. However, we believe that to respect human dignity, work should have certain characteristics. It should be at decent wages. It should be at decent working conditions. It should not be a dead-end job. And such work should not displace current workers.
"In certain ways, the city's workfare program doesn't meet our conditions of good work, and it can hurt current workers."
Msgr. Howard Basler, director of social action at the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn, also criticized some aspects of the workfare program, although he said the diocese has more than a dozen welfare recipients working as soup kitchen aides or in rectory jobs.
"We do everything we can to make sure the workers receive training and that it is not a dead-end job," said Monsignor Basler. But he noted that the diocese could not absorb many more workers, as the city is urging, if it wants to provide them with proper training.
The executive director of one neighborhood center in Manhattan, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said she used six workfare workers to help serve and cook food for the center's senior-citizens program. Although she said she was not enthusiastic about workfare, she said the center hired the workfare participants and offered permanent jobs to them when openings developed.
"We need the extra help," she said.
The coalition members said the workfare program often employed workers in unsafe conditions and frequently did not provide them with boots or gloves for winter work or dangerous jobs. Mr. Laarman of Judson Memorial Church also said the city's program was punitive to the poor and was dragging down the pay of low-wage workers in city government and in the private sector.
"Basically, it's unjust," said the Rev. Janice Glenn, associate minister of the Convent Avenue Baptist Church. "People are being used to do work, and they're not being compensated for it."
The city established its workfare program, which focuses on welfare recipients who are adults without young children, even before the new Federal welfare law required states and cities to set up such programs. The new law will force the city to expand the effort vastly by requiring it to put many welfare recipients with children to work as well.
The Giuliani administration began placing workfare participants in jobs at nonprofit agencies three years ago, but it has stepped up those efforts in recent months under Federal pressures to expand workfare. The 2,500 workfare participants now working for nonprofit groups work in soup kitchens, day-care centers, girls' clubs, home health care and neighborhood improvement organizations.

HEADLINE: Jittery on Thailand, Asia Currencies Dip

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: JAKARTA, Indonesia, July 24

 BODY:
South Asian currencies were lower again today, on concern that amid problems at Thai banks they might become targets of new speculative attack.
"All the speculators see the baht being weak," Conny Chandra, an interbank dealer at PT Bank Tiara Asia, said, referring to the Thai currency, "and they expect the other currencies like the rupiah to be, too." 
 The baht fell for a second day, to a rate of 32.2 to the United States dollar from 31.6 on Wednesday. Thailand's banks and finance companies are faced with mounting bad loans as the country experiences its slowest economic growth in a decade.
Thai banks have started reporting their financial results for the first six months of the year, detailing how their earnings were affected by these bad loans.
Finance Minister Thanong Bidaya has said he will give details of a bailout package for financial institutions and on how to stimulate the economy in two weeks.
Thailand's problems weighed on other currencies. The Indonesian rupiah fell more than 1 percent, to a rate of 2,625 to the American dollar. Singapore's dollar fell seven-tenths of a percent, to 1.4787 to the American dollar, its lowest rate in almost three years. The Malaysian ringgit declined to as low as 2.6540 to the dollar, a drop of six-tenths of 1 percent.
Currency declines on Wednesday have prompted more businesses to buy the dollar for repayment of their dollar-denominated debts before the dollar becomes more expensive. This helped pull the Asian currencies lower today, traders said.
