HEADLINE: In Tax Talks, Officials Play Game of Cat And Mouse

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 24

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration edged toward serious give-and-take with the Republican leadership today over how to cut taxes, with the outlines of a compromise apparent to both sides but neither willing to make the first big concession.
White House officials shuttled from meeting to meeting on Capitol Hill throughout the day and into the evening, sounding out the priorities of their fellow Democrats and providing Republicans with blunt assessments of what it would take to produce a tax bill that President Clinton would be willing to sign. 
 "We have started letting them know where we are willing to compromise, and vice versa," said Senator Don Nickles of Oklahoma, the assistant Republican leader. "They're getting, I'm not going to say closer, but we have a better understanding on both sides."
Administration officials said the day's schedule amounted to no more than a "reconnoitering" mission.
"We discussed each issue, exchanged viewpoints, and that's about it," said Erskine B. Bowles, the White House chief of staff.
The effort to push the tax negotiations forward came as the Administration and Congressional leaders tried to resolve a separate dispute over the details of a bill covering reductions in Medicare spending, increased spending on children's health insurance and changes to welfare policy. Neither side reported significant progress, but each said it had emerged with a clearer understanding of the other's positions.
Republicans have been pushing hard to wrap up both the tax and spending bills in the next week and send them to President Clinton before Congress recesses on Aug. 1. But some Administration officials said they were in no particular rush to finish, a position also taken by some Senate Democrats.
The Administration and the Republicans are deeply divided over several important elements of the plan to cut taxes by $85 billion over five years. The Administration is demanding that Republicans scale back their proposed reduction in the capital gains tax, make more low-income working families eligible for a credit of $500 per child and increase tax breaks for college costs.
More generally, the Administration wants the tax plan modified to shift more benefits from the wealthy to lower and middle-income people and to limit the plan's long-term costs to head off a possible resurgence of big Federal budget deficits.
Privately, both Democrats and Republicans said they could foresee some of the likely tradeoffs. The Administration will have to grant the Republicans most if not all of the reduction they are seeking in the top rate on capital gains, from 28 percent to 20 percent, but the Republicans will have to give up their plan to allow investors to subtract the effects of inflation.
Mr. Clinton, they said, will probably win less than the $35 billion in college tax breaks he wants, but Republicans will probably have to make more lower-income families eligible for the child credit.
But there are many complex issues that remain in dispute. Although House and Senate Republicans have resolved most of their differences over how to apportion the tax cuts, they remain divided over the Senate's plan to raise the cigarette tax by 20 cents a pack and to use about half the proceeds to increase spending on children's health programs by $8 billion over five years.
House Republicans said today that they might soften their opposition to the tobacco tax, but said they would not want the proceeds to go to children's health or any other spending program. Democrats and some Senate Republicans said that removing the additional financing for children's health would seriously reduce the chances of any tax bill's winning Democratic support.
One consideration, members of both parties said, is moving the cigarette tax into the spending bill to link it more closely to the children's health issue and remove it as a point of contention in the tax bill.
Officials said the White House was unenthusiastic about the latest Republican proposal on the child credit, to allow low-income families whose income tax liability is eliminated by the earned income tax credit to "carry forward" the child credit into the future when they might have an income tax bill. The House bill would have made the child credit available only to families who have to pay Federal income taxes.
Republicans also appeared to be near a compromise among themselves on the details of a plan to extend the tax on airline tickets. Under heavy pressure from major airlines, Republicans said they are moving toward adopting a version of the tax close to that passed by the House rather than one passed by the Senate and opposed by the airlines. The plan would gradually reduce the current 10 percent tax to 7.5 percent and impose a $1 fee for each flight segment, rising eventually to $3.

HEADLINE: Khmer Rouge, With a 'Magic Trick,' May Have Made Themselves Disappear

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS 

DATELINE: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, July 24

 BODY:
In the days leading up to the Cambodian coup earlier this month, Khmer Rouge guerrillas seemed to be provoking Hun Sen, the militarily powerful Second Prime Minister, by dallying with his political rival and by taunting him in radio broadcasts from their jungle stronghold.
Their machinations may have been just the impetus he needed. After months of infighting and growing tensions, Mr. Hun Sen turned his armed forces on those of his rival coalition partner, Prince Norodom Ranariddh, and seized sole power. 
 But whatever game the Khmer Rouge were playing, they appear in the end to have lost. The coup has left them weaker and more isolated than ever. Any chance they may have had of negotiating an amnesty seems to have faded, and any alliance they may form with Prince Ranariddh's defeated soldiers will pose little threat to Mr. Hun Sen's Government.
That much now seems clear. What is less clear is just what was going on in the Khmer Rouge headquarters in Anlong Veng, and why. Five weeks after the Prince began to offer a series of sensational accounts about turmoil in the Khmer Rouge leadership, none of his reports have been confirmed.
Mr. Hun Sen has described the entire episode as a "magic trick" masterminded by the evil genius of Pol Pot, the Khmer Rouge leader. A number of foreign experts on the Khmer Rouge agree.
But there is no way to know whether Pol Pot himself was involved, or even whether he is still alive. The 69-year-old guerrilla has not been seen by foreigners since 1981.
The answers may never be known. This is a country where politics is played in the shadows, where illusion and disinformation are as much a part of politics as speeches and parliaments.
For the moment, Mr. Hun Sen holds the power in Cambodia. But his coup was only the most recent twist in a tangled history of alliances and rivalries that may not be laid to rest for years.
The latest chapter in the Cambodia drama began nearly a year ago when several Khmer Rouge commands broke with Pol Pot's hard-line leadership and defected to the Government. Both Mr. Hun Sen and Prince Ranariddh -- co-Prime Ministers with rival armies -- began lobbying vigorously for their allegiance.
In recent months, the stakes rose, with both sides reportedly sending representatives to talk with members of Pol Pot's inner circle at their northern headquarters in Anlong Veng.
In these negotiations, the Prince had an advantage over his rival: his royalist forces had been allies with the Khmer Rouge during a long civil war in the 1980's against the Vietnam-backed Communist Government of Mr. Hun Sen.
That Government had been installed in 1979 after a Vietnamese invasion put an end to the four-year rule of the Khmer Rouge during which more than a million people died. Mr. Hun Sen had himself been a Khmer Rouge cadre until he broke with Pol Pot in 1977 and fled to Vietnam.
In the three weeks leading up to the coup, the Prince increased the pressure on Mr. Hun Sen with a series of startling reports about events in Anlong Veng. He announced that the clandestine Khmer Rouge radio station was about to brodacast a pledge of allegiance to the Government.
The Prince's first report came on June 13, when he announced that Pol Pot had killed his longtime friend, the former Khmer Rouge Defense Minister, Son Sen, and run over his body with a truck. Political analysts here said they believed that Mr. Son Sen had been the figure with whom Mr. Hun Sen had been negotiating.
The Prince's reports continued: Pol Pot had fled into the jungle, sick and swinging in a hammock. Pol Pot had taken some of his supporters hostage, including another close aide, Khieu Samphan. Pol Pot had been captured by his own men and would soon be turned over for trial for crimes against humanity.
None of these reports were confirmed. Indeed, their only apparent corroboration came in Khmer Rouge radio broadcasts. These broadcasts were clearly aimed at provoking Mr. Hun Sen, whom they reviled as a puppet of Vietnam.
"It was a Khmer Rouge game through and through," said Christophe Peschoux, a scholar of Cambodian history, in describing the Prince's negotiations.
At first, Mr. Hun Sen was silent as the Prince's reports emerged. Then he began to complain that the Prince was transporting tough Khmer Rouge fighters into the capital in preparation for military action.
Then he attacked. On July 5, Mr. Hun Sen's troops began what one of his aides called a "mopping-up action," targeting the strongholds of the Prince's royalist troops on the outskirts of the city.
Lost in the din of the big guns that morning was the promised Khmer Rouge broadcast pledging allegiance to the Government -- too late to affect the course of events.
In a white paper issued three days later, Mr. Hun Sen's party said its armed attack came in response to what it called a "strategy of provocation" by the Prince. Among several actions, these were said to include both the negotiations with the Khmer Rouge and an infiltration of guerrillas into Phnom Penh.
"The military buildup and the alliance with the Khmer Rouge was virtually a declaration of war," the white paper said.
"The importance of the militarization of the Khmer Rouge and their introduction to Phnom Penh by Prince Ranariddh's military advisers cannot be minimized," it said. "For the first time since 1978, armed Khmer Rouge soldiers were present in the streets of Phnom Penh."
Western diplomats have similarly suggested that the Prince may have embarked on a tactic of provoking Mr. Hun Sen.
And Mr. Hun Sen had reason to be concerned about an emerging political alliance that could include the royalists, the Khmer Rouge and other smaller opposition groups -- a revival of the civil-war alliance of the 1980's.
But little evidence has emerged to support Mr. Hun Sen's claim that the Prince had brought Khmer Rouge fighters into the capital.
Indeed, Western experts who have analyzed the fighting on July 5 and 6 say there is stronger evidence to show that Mr. Hun Sen's forces included at least one unit of Khmer Rouge, commanded by Gen. Keo Pong, who defected with several hundred men in early 1996.
If the Khmer Rouge meant to provoke an open split between Prince Ranariddh and Mr. Hun Sen, it seems to have succeeded.
But if the guerrillas were hoping to be embraced in a new alliance, they may be out of step with history. It was the geopolitics of the cold war that provided the former alliance with its anti-Vietnamese and anti-Soviet support from the West and China as well as its sanctuary in Thailand.
The guerrillas' economic base -- an illegal gem trade -- disappeared last August with the large-scale defections of their Western commands.
And in Phnom Penh, the man in full control now is their enemy, Mr. Hun Sen. He is less likely than Prince Ranariddh to negotiate safe passage for the remaining hard-line leaders in Anlong Veng -- even if they were to hand over Pol Pot for trial.
"They are more marginalized than ever," said David Chandler, who has written widely about the movement. "They've got nobody to deal with in Phnom Penh. Their foreign patronage is all gone. They aren't going to get any deals from Hun Sen. He doesn't have to; they are no threat to him."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Thousands of Cambodians fled toward Thailand Wednesday as fighting between forces loyal to the rival Prime Ministers flared in northern areas. (Agence France-Presse); King Norodom Sihanouk; Pol Pot; Hun Sen; Prince Norodom Ranariddh
 
Chart: "Four Powerful Men, Four Decades of Battle"
The shifting alliances and enmities of the past few decades have become focused on the ambitions of four central figures: Second Prime Minister Hun Sen, who ousted his coalition partner, First Prime Minister Norodom Ranariddh, in a coup July 6; Prince Ranariddh's father, King Norodom Sihanouk, who remains in Beijing; and Pol Pot, the Khmer Rouge leader, whose shadow still darkens the nation. Here is a look back at the long intertwined paths of these four powerful men. SETH MYDANS
 
King Norodom Sihanouk, 74
After a decade in exile in China and North Korea, he accepted the titular role of constitutional King in 1993. During the recent coup he remained in Beijing.
 
Pol Pot, 69
Leader of the Khmer Rouge; possibly ailing or dead.
 
Hun Sen, 45
Supreme leader of Cambodia at the moment.
 
Prince Norodom Ranariddh, 53
The son of the King Sihanouk and formerly First Prime Minister of Cambodia, has fled the country searching for international support.
 
1953
Cambodia, under French control since 1863, gains its independence. A constitutional monarchy led by Norodom Sihanouk is established.
 
1965
Sihanouk breaks relations with the U.S., accusing it of antigovernment activity.
 
1969
The U.S. starts bombing North Vietnamese and Viet Cong in Cambodia.
 
1970
Cambodian Prime Minister Lon Nol, sup-ported by the U.S., over-throws Sihanouk while he is out of the country. Sihanouk allies with the Khmer Rouge in the resistance to Lon Nol.
 
1975
A radical Maoist group, Khmer Rouge, led by Pol Pot, seize power. Over the next four years, more than a million people are executed or die of starvation, disease or overwork.
 
1979
Vietnam invades Cambodia, overthrows Pol Pot and installs a puppet Government. A coalition of the Khmer Rouge, royalist and democratic forces launches a decade-long civil war.
 
1985
The Communist Party's Hun Sen becomes Prime Minister of the Vietnam-backed Government.
 
1991
The U.N. brokers a peace plan, the Paris Agreement, that calls for disarmament of all parties. Democratic elections are set for 1993, over Hun Sen's protests.
 
1993
Prince Norodom Ranariddh wins an election, boycotted by the Khmer Rouge and contested by Hun Sen. Prince Ranariddh is forced to share power with Hun Sen until the 1998 elections.
 
1996
Friction continues to build between the Prime Ministers and both amass troops and arms.
 
1997
With the Khmer Rouge frac-tured, Pol Pot is reportedly captured by his own men, but no evidence of this emerges. In an armed coup, Hun Sen ousts Prince Ranariddh, who is in France.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
The Dollar Rises Higher Yet; Even Swiss Franc Is No Haven

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar rose against the mark for a fourth straight day yesterday, on fresh hints that Germany would not oppose the rally and on unexpectedly weak Japanese economic news.
Demand for dollars also broadened to lower the Swiss franc, which had been less vulnerable to the dollar's latest ascent because of its perceived status as a safe haven from the uncertainties created by Europe's single-currency plans. The dollar touched a three-and-a-half-year high against the Swiss franc. 
 Stephen Jury, managing director for foreign exchange at the Union Bank of Switzerland, said that traders sold the Swiss currency "very aggressively."
The dollar reached an intraday high of 1.8387 German marks, the strongest since July 1991, before settling in New York yesterday at 1.8348 marks, up from 1.8268 late Wednesday. The dollar has gained nearly 20 percent against the mark this year. It rose to 1.5065 Swiss francs, up from 1.4861 on Wednesday; that was the highest since December 1993.
The dollar also rose against the Japanese yen, strengthening to 116.05 yen, from 115.65 on Wednesday. It gained, as well, on the British pound, which declined to $1.6745, from $1.6804 late Wednesday.
The dollar has been rallying against the mark since Monday, rising along with stocks as reports continued to show a healthy American economy, German economic weakness and a growing conviction that the European single currency would most likely be weak.
The catalyst for further dollar buying yesterday was a decision by the German central bank to leave interest rates unchanged. In addition, the Bundesbank did not hold a news conference after the meeting; in the past, such occasions have been used to express views on currency rates and interest-rate trends.
"This was seen as a sign they're not even going to try jawboning the dollar," said John McCarthy, senior vice president for foreign exchange at ING Capital Markets Inc. in New York. "That started another wave of dollar-buying against the mark."
The dollar rose against the yen after a Bank of Japan quarterly report suggested that recovery from a prolonged slump, though it was proceeding, was "unlikely to gather significant momentum."

HEADLINE: Jobless Claims at Lowest Level in Year

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 24

 BODY:
The number of Americans claiming first-time jobless benefits dropped last week to the lowest level in nearly a year, the Government reported today in the latest sign of a strong jobs market.
Weekly jobless claims fell to 299,000 in the week that ended last Saturday from a revised 341,000 the week before. That was far below the 333,000 level that economists had forecast. Much of the decrease may have been attributable to the reopening of auto plants after their annual new-model retooling and the end of auto strikes. 
 The drop pushed weekly claims to their lowest level since the week that ended on July 27, 1996, when they were 297,000.
The four-week moving average, which helps to smooth out week-to-week swings in the data, also fell. The average of claims stood at 340,750 last week, down from 349,000 the week before.
The number of people continuing to claim benefits rose slightly, to 2,302,000, in the week ended July 12, the latest week for which the data were available.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Network Speeds Tempo of Downloading Songs

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSS SORKIN 

 BODY:
In a bid to demonstrate that a cable connection can expand the use of the Internet beyond exchanging E-mail and browsing the World Wide Web, At Home Network is expected to announce a service today that will enable subscribers to download the highest-quality audio recordings within minutes.
It is the first significant move by the company, which provides Internet access on a high-speed, high-capacity cable network, since an initial public offering two weeks ago. Yesterday, its shares closed down 62.5 cents, at $20, almost double the $10.50 initial offering price. 
 Downloading high-quality audio recordings can take more than an hour over normal telephone-line connections, but it takes less than five minutes with At Home's service. However, the move toward improved audio access is raising concerns within the recording industry about increased piracy and the potential for more disputes over intellectual property rights.
One of At Home's partners in the venture is N2K Inc., a company that operates Music Boulevard, a popular Web site. As part of the agreement, N2K will provide its library of 250,000 music albums for sale to At Home subscribers, but not for downloading. For 99 cents, users will be able to download music singles, each of which takes up about 6 megabytes of computer disk space.
"The speed is the huge difference," said Larry Rosen, chairman and chief executive officer of N2K in New York. "The appetite has always been there, but you really had to be patient."
Another key difference will be the quality of sound. Now, the faster recordings are downloaded, the poorer the quality. At Home's service provides high speed and high quality.
At Home's other partners include Net Radio Network and the DJ Network, which will provide broadcasts. Both provide broadcasts on the Internet, but the quality is low. At Home Network customers will hear broadcasts with the quality of compact disk recordings.
"The quality is so poor that it's really not a good experience," Charles Moldow, vice president of media development for At Home, said of current attempts to broadcast recordings over the Internet. But with cable connections, he said, "the audio is clear."
Analysts generally applauded At Home's move.
"They have created a compelling list of stuff to do," said Emily Green, an analyst for Forrester Research in Cambridge, Mass.
For all its promise, however, the improved audio is not certain to prove profitable for At Home, which is owned by Tele-Communications Inc. and uses the networks of TCI, Comcast and Cox Enterprises.
"I don't think it will add significant equity to the company," said Michael W. Harris, president of Kinetic Strategies Inc., a company that monitors the Internet cable industry. "But it proves that they are the real deal, that all of this is not just talk."
At Home, based in Redwood City, Calif., has only 12,000 subscribers, but its potential market is much larger. At least 2.3 million homes now have cable Internet access, according to Kinetic.
Regardless of At Home's size, its service is raising concerns that piracy could become more rampant.
Mr. Rosen, N2K's top executive, has already heard from experts on the piracy issue.
"I've certainly talked to people who are concerned," he said. "There is no question that intellectual property rights become a major question in this new environment."
Hillary Rosen, president of the Recording Industry Association of America, who is unrelated to Larry Rosen, said: "I think it's scary. But we can't stop technology."
N2K, however, says its technology can help keep piracy of music singles to a minimum. It says users of the service can buy a song and play it on their computers. But unlike standard music files, the copies cannot be duplicated, and an internal encryption mechanism prevents them from being played on other computers.
"It's not like you can start a factory and crank out CD's," Larry Rosen said. "It's just not possible."

HEADLINE: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/Technology;
Toyota Ahead of Pack On Hybrid Production

BYLINE: By MICHELLE KREBS 

DATELINE: DETROIT

 BODY:
While many auto makers are working on electric vehicles and on hybrids that can run on multiple energy sources, the Toyota Motor Corporation seems most likely to become the first manufacturer to mass-produce a hybrid that delivers twice the fuel economy and one-tenth the emissions of a conventional automobile.
Toyota is planning to introduce its hybrid, a car sized between a compact Corolla and mid-size Camry, by the end of this year in Japan. 
 While purely electric cars are desirable because they produce no emissions, hybrids are appealing because they also have a gasoline engine that eliminates an electric vehicle's two chief drawbacks: a limited travel range and lengthy recharging periods. But with two power sources and high development costs, a hybrid car may ultimately cost more to buy.
Toyota's hybrid is equipped with a new, highly efficient 1.5-liter gasoline engine -- Toyota engineers say it should get 66 miles to the gallon -- and an electric motor with a high-voltage nickel-metal-hydride battery. The hybrid operates as an electric car under some conditions and uses the gasoline engine at other times to drive the wheels while also charging the battery. The idea is that the most efficient power source is always in use.
The yet-unnamed Toyota starts like an electric car and, in fact, the electric motor gets the car moving. Taking off from a stoplight, moving along at low speeds or descending a hill, the Toyota hybrid operates as an electric car. These are just the conditions that cause gasoline engines to emit relatively high levels of pollutants. As the hybrid picks up speed, the gasoline engine comes on. When decelerating before a stop, the gas engine switches off and the electric motor takes over again.
In a test drive of the hybrid, the switching back and forth between the electric motor and the gasoline engine was smooth and virtually imperceptible. Toyota engineers are working to make the switching even more transparent than it was in the prototypes recently demonstrated.
The Toyota hybrid does not require recharging, since the gasoline engine charges the battery while the car is running. Additional electricity is stored in the battery.
Toyota plans to sell at least 1,000 hybrids a year in Japan. It has no immediate plans for sales elsewhere, including the United States, although the car would meet California's strict emissions requirements.
The hybrid is part of Toyota's publicly stated strategy to establish itself as the producer of the world's safest and most environmentally friendly cars. That is a goal shared, no doubt, by other auto makers that are also developing low-emission, high-mileage vehicles with advanced safety features. Still, in an uncharacteristic move at the normally secretive company, Toyota has been showing its future technology to the press.
In addition to the hybrid, Toyota will introduce an electric RAV4 sport utility vehicle this fall in the United States and Japan. It has a range of 130 miles, made possible by nickel-metal-hydride batteries, the promising next generation of battery technology. Toyota will become the first to use these batteries, rather than the more conventional lead-acid batteries, in a production vehicle.
The battery packs are situated under the floor so that good stability and a roomy passenger cabin are maintained. The electric RAV4 is also equipped with a regenerative braking system that recaptures energy typically lost in braking. The electric RAV4 can be recharged using household current, with no need for charging stations like those required for the General Motors EV1, which is available for leasing in California and Arizona.
Toyota is also introducing what it calls its D-4 direct-injection gasoline engine. The engine operates on precise, ever-changing mixtures of fuel and air to decrease emissions and improve fuel economy.
And it has under development a fuel-cell electric car that uses an electro-chemical reaction of hydrogen, carried on board, and oxygen from the atmosphere to generate electricity that drives the motor. While other auto makers are developing no-emissions cars that use fuel cells, Toyota's uses a hydrogen-absorbing alloy in its system that makes the fuel cell more compact and better-performing.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Prices End Unchanged

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Treasury prices ended unchanged yesterday, as several large corporate issues and a dearth of economic data curbed buying.
Still, traders and analysts said they continued to be bullish on the market following this week's upbeat assessment of the economy from Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman. 
 "The bond market is going to be fine in the near term," said Anthony Karadakis, senior financial economist at First National Bank of Chicago. "I don't see anything on the radar screen to shatter" the market's economic outlook, he said.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond was unchanged at 102 17/32 , leaving its yield at 6.43 percent.
Several large corporate bond issues held Treasury prices in check, analysts said, as investors sold Treasury securities to buy the higher yielding debt.
The most notable issue yesterday was $2 billion in Yankee bonds priced by Hutchison Whampoa Finance Ltd. of Hong Kong.
The multi-part offering was Hutchison's debut in the corporate bond market and met with very strong demand from institutional investors from around the world. It was a Rule 144A offering, which meant it was placed privately with institutional investors.
It was the largest global issue of Yankee bonds -- dollar-denominated debt issued by a foreign corporation or government -- ever by a corporation, said Carlos Cordeiro, managing director at Goldman, Sachs & Company, one of the lead underwriters of the deal.
"The enthusiasm this issue met in the market really speaks to the credit and the future of Hong Kong in so much as we are just barely 30 days into the new administration," he said.
Hutchison Whampoa Finance is a unit of Hutchison Whampoa Ltd., one of Hong Kong's largest conglomerates. The parent company owns a majority stake in Hong Kong International Terminals, the world's largest privately owned container terminal operator and the largest port operator in Hong Kong.
The largest of the issue's three offerings was $750 million of 10-year bonds. The other parts consisted of $500 million in 20-year bonds, $500 million in 30-year bonds and $250 million in 40-year bonds, which can be sold back to the issuer in 12 years.
The issue was rated A3 by Moody's Investors Service and A-plus by Standard & Poor's.
Analysts have said the issue, because of its large size and structure, is likely to be used as a benchmark for future Asian offerings.
In the Treasury market, meanwhile, investors will next turn their attention to today's report on durable goods orders in June.
But that figure -- notoriously volatile -- was not expected to have much market impact. More attention will be focused on Tuesday's report on the Employment Cost Index for the second quarter of the year.
The market will also have to contend with the issue of supply next week, when the Treasury is expected to announce the size of its planned sales of new 10-year notes and 30-year bonds in August.

HEADLINE: Dow at High Again, With 8,116.93 Close

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Stock prices rose to records again yesterday, rebounding from early losses as better-than-expected earnings from companies like Digital Equipment offset concern that prices had risen too far.
"The numbers that have been coming out have been as expected or better," said Don Fredell, senior managing trader at American Express Financial Advisors, which oversees $160 billion. Among the companies that like Digital rose on favorable earnings reports were Quaker Oats, Ericsson and Airtouch Communications. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average, which was down nearly 100 points at one point, rose 28.57, to a record 8,116.93. The benchmark 30-stock average rose for a fourth straight day, and closed above 8,100 for the first time.
Portfolio managers who failed to keep up with the broad market this year jumped in to buy when prices fell, traders said. The early declines were attributed to concern that the recent rally had pushed prices higher than justified, even with an economic and business backdrop that should result in growing profits.
"You're still seeing a lot of people chasing the recent strength in the market," said Franklin Morton, director of research at Ariel Capital Management, which oversees $1.7 billion. "It's been expensive in most of these last 15 years to be on the sidelines."
Stocks were buffeted by program trading throughout the day. Seven buy programs and three sell programs hit the market, according to Birinyi Associates Inc., a market research firm in Greenwich, Conn.
The Standard & Poor's 500 index rose 3.74, to a record 940.30, and the Nasdaq composite index gained 1.48, to 1,569.13, about 11 points shy of its record from July 16.
Shares have rallied this week as the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, in testimony before Congress on Tuesday and Wednesday, said that the economy was performing exceptionally well without much inflation, suggesting that the central bank would not need to raise interest rates soon.
Digital Equipment rose 2 13/16 yesterday, to a 52-week high of 42 9/16 , after the computer maker said its fiscal fourth-quarter earnings more than doubled, beating estimates. The company also said it might buy back as many as 15 million shares, or 10 percent of its outstanding stock.
International Business Machines rose 2 11/16 , to 107 13/16 , and Dell Computer gained 6, to 170.
American depository receipts of Ericsson, the world's third-largest telecommunications equipment maker, rose 4 9/16 , to 46 5/16 , helping push the Nasdaq higher, after the company said second-quarter net income rose more than expected. Nokia A.B., the Finnish cell phone company, rose 3 13/16 , to 82 5/16 .
Airtouch Communications rose 3, to 31 1/2, after the cellular telephone service company said profit almost doubled, beating estimates.
A decline in Microsoft hurt the Nasdaq for much of the session. Microsoft fell 4 7/16 , to 138, on concern that 1998 fiscal year earnings might not rise as much as expected because the software company planned to significantly increase spending on sales and marketing.
Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing fell 2 7/8, to 95 5/8, dropping for a second day after reporting that the strong dollar and new product costs resulted in lower-than-expected earnings.
Quaker Oats rose 2, to 47 1/8, after the company reported better-than-expected earnings. Sales of inexpensive bagged cereals almost doubled.
Nellcor Puritan Bennett soared 7 5/32 , to 28 3/32 , after the medical products maker agreed to be acquired by Mallinckrodt for $1.9 billion in cash, or $28.50 a share. The price is a 36 percent premium to Wednesday's closing price for Nellcor shares. Mallinckrodt fell 1 1/2, to 38 1/4.

HEADLINE: Stadiums Aren't Saviors

 BODY:

To the Editor:
An alarming urban trend goes unchallenged in your July 23 news article about life in Detroit 30 years after its riots. If city planners are looking to new football and baseball stadiums as a solution to decades of social ills, they had better think again. Virtually no independent study has proved a link between new sports complexes and indicators of urban health like rates of unemployment, poverty and crime. 
 Such investments are more likely to drain public coffers than provide long-lasting and tangible improvements in a population's quality of life. And yet in Detroit, plans call for two costly structures -- despite the existence of Tiger Stadium, one of the country's oldest and most cherished baseball landmarks.
 
JOANNA CAGAN
NEIL DE MAUSE
Brooklyn, July 23, 1997

HEADLINE: In Ulster Drama, a U.S. Player Is Hopeful About Peace

BYLINE: By JAMES F. CLARITY 

DATELINE: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, July 24

 BODY:
Three days after the new I.R.A. cease-fire took effect, George J. Mitchell, the chairman of the Northern Ireland peace talks, sat in the unpretentious ground-floor restaurant of the Europa Hotel and assessed his three years of work toward ending sectarian warfare in this British province.
For one thing, the menu of the Europa, which claims to be the most-often-bombed hotel in Europe, no longer offers the B.L.A.S.T. sandwich, of bacon, lettuce and sliced tomato, a kind of cholesterol bomb that attacks from within. Mr. Mitchell, 63, the former Senate majority leader, opted for cottage cheese. 
 For another thing, Mr. Mitchell said, the peace effort just staggered through another obstacle on Wednesday afternoon.
A proposal by the Irish and British Governments to deal with the crucial issue of disarmament of the Irish Republican Army and Protestant paramilitary groups had been rejected because of the opposition by the three main Protestant Unionist parties. But the largest of these, the Ulster Unionist Party of David Trimble, said it would work for a compromise on the issue with the British Government when the peace talks resume on Sept. 15.
All political leaders in the North, Gerry Adams of Sinn Fein, the I.R.A. political wing; Mr. Trimble, and even the Rev. Ian Paisley, the hard-line leader of the Democratic Unionist Party, agree with Mr. Mitchell that the process will continue in one form or another in September and that, if the cease-fire holds, Sinn Fein will be in the negotiations. That, Mr. Mitchell maintains, is encouraging, and not woolly-headed optimism.
As he spoke, officials and politicians were already saying that a new structure -- keeping the parties separate but having intermediaries shuttling between them -- could be a way out of the disarmament nettle.
"There's a lot of comment, including a good bit of hyperbole," about the rejection of the plan for discussing disarmament in the September talks, Mr. Mitchell said in the interview on Wednesday night. "But if you measure the process over a longer perspective, you can see that it's moving in the right direction."
He said that, during the first I.R.A. cease-fire, from September 1994 to February 1996, there were no peace talks. "Indeed, it was the absence of such talks that they cited as a reason for breaking the cease-fire," he said. "Now you have both a cease-fire and talks occurring and the largest Unionist party saying it's committed to peace talks, even though it didn't agree with the Governments' proposal on decommissioning," as disarmament is called here.
The Unionists wanted the I.R.A. to start to disarm once the talks reconvened. The proposal they rejected on Wednesday said only that disarmament would be discussed during the talks, with no guarantee that actual disarmament would occur.
In explaining the progress and stumbling blocks on the way to peace, Mr. Mitchell said: "There's a pattern to this process you can observe if you look back over the past three years. Each step forward is usually followed by a step backward. There's excessive optimism for the steps forward and excessive pessimism for the steps backward. The important thing is to ask whether the long-term trend is in the right direction. I believe it is."
Mr. Mitchell, a Democrat from Maine, pointed out that the events of the last few days were unusual in the course of the struggle for peace in Northern Ireland. "This week is the first time in modern history that both a cease-fire, observed by both sides, and a negotiating process are in existence at the same time," he said. "So, I'm hopeful."
Mr. Adams shares such hope. He has again demonstrated that he has strong influence with the I.R.A., by persuading the military commanders to try politics again instead of violence and to trust the new British Prime Minister, Tony Blair, to get real peace negotiations going.
But Mr. Adams has had to fend off a spate of criticism from radical Republican splinter groups that say he has abandoned the ultimate goal of a united Ireland, with the predominantly Protestant North absorbed by the overwhelmingly Roman Catholic Irish Republic to the south.
Virtually no one in Northern Ireland thinks that the talks will produce a united Ireland. British and Irish policy states that there will be no change in the political status of the North without the consent of the majority, which is 57 percent Protestant.
During the last two years, before the latest cease-fire, Mr. Adams rarely mentioned a united Ireland, using circumlocution to express his views on the issue, as he did in an article he wrote two weeks ago for The Irish Times. In it he urged the Irish Government "to uphold the legitimacy of Irish unity as a policy objective."
To a charge from a Republican radical that he would in effect be approving the partition of Ireland and the union of the North with Britain in any settlement produced by the talks, Mr. Adams said in an interview, "We are going to renegotiate the union; that is a different thing entirely." The renegotiation, he said, would include enhanced civil rights for Catholics and an end to job discrimination in the province, where the percentage of unemployed Catholics is twice that of Protestants.
And he is talking publicly again about a united Ireland as a subject Sinn Fein will raise in the talks.
At the other end of the spectrum, Mr. Paisley has pronounced the peace talks dead, but in the same breath stated that he would be willing to take part in restructured talks, possibly of the shuttle-diplomacy variety.
And John Hume, the Catholic leader of the mainstream Social Democratic and Labor Party, who with Mr. Adams was author of the current peace effort, said as he has hundreds of times, "Now is the time to stop shedding our blood and start shedding our sweat."

HEADLINE: Lake Tahoe's Legendary Clarity Is Threatened

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: INCLINE VILLAGE, Nev., July 23

 BODY:
No less a cynic than Mark Twain proclaimed it "the fairest picture the whole earth affords." But these days, the crystal blue waters of Lake Tahoe are considerably less fair -- and are losing their world-famous clarity at a rate of nearly a foot and a half a year.
Twenty million visitors a year pour into the Tahoe basin, lured by the snow-capped granite crags of the Sierras that ring it and provide first-class skiing and hiking, by the gambling resorts that dot the Nevada shoreline, and by a lake so clear it looks like a 39-trillion-gallon swimming pool. They bring boats, Jet Skis and, above all, automobiles, whose exhaust contains nitrogen that winds up in the lake, fueling the growth of algae that in a generation or so could leave Tahoe a cloudy green muddle in the mountains. 
 "If we look 20 or 30 years out, we've got a really ordinary lake, unless we do something here soon," said Charles Goldman, a professor of environmental studies at the University of California at Davis who since 1959 has studied every aspect of the lake's ecosystem as director of the university's Tahoe Research Group. "Since I began studying it, the lake has changed dramatically from a classic limited nitrogen lake to one that has accumulated so much nitrogen that it is no longer a pure Western lake -- it is more like a Midwestern one."
Professor Goldman will have the chance to make that case this Friday and Saturday to President Clinton and Vice President Al Gore, who are set to tour the lake in the university's research boat as part of a two-day "Tahoe summit" featuring a half-dozen Cabinet officials and the Governors and Senators of California and Nevada.
The Administration hopes to highlight Tahoe as a "shining example" that economic development and environmental protection not only can co-exist, but must, said Katie McGinty, director of the White House office on environmental quality.
And while Ms. McGinty would not elaborate, she said the President's commitment would include new money for "bread and butter" needs like sewage treatment and repairs to flood-damaged roads, along with stepped-up cooperation among the various Federal agencies that together own and control 78 percent of the land in the greater Tahoe basin, most of it national forests.
Already, local business, political and environmental leaders realize, that "everything that happens in the Tahoe basin winds up in the lake," said Senator Harry Reid, Democrat of Nevada. That includes soil eroded by the construction of multimillion-dollar houses in this wealthy town along the Nevada shore, fertilizer from gardens and golf courses, gas and oil from Jet Skis, which dump a gallon of raw fuel into the water for every five they burn.
Altogether, Professor Goldman said, those factors are increasing the growth of algae by more than 5 percent a year, reducing visibility to around 70 feet today from about 100 feet in the early 60's. If corrective action is not taken within the next decade, he said, Tahoe will become a lake of ordinary clarity, with visibility only to about 40 feet.
Local officials say there is growing consensus that if that happens, the $1 billion annual tourist economy that depends on the pristine setting cannot continue to prosper.
"Ten or 15 years ago, there were tremendous clashes between the business interests here and the environmentalists," said Rochelle Nason, executive director of the League to Save Lake Tahoe, a 40-year-old nonprofit group "Today we're seeing a lot of common ground because local businesses realize the environment is their bread and butter."
Last month, the Tahoe Regional Planning Agency, the bi-state board established by Congress and the two states a quarter century ago to oversee development around the lake, voted to ban Jet Skis and other "personal watercraft" starting in 1999. That stand is far tougher than the Environmental Protection Agency and is one expected to be appealed by manufacturers and rental shops.
The agency has also compiled a "to do" list of reclamation projects totaling nearly $1 billion over the next decade or so that would require a mix of state, Federal, local and private money.
There are many proposals, some expensive, like rerouting the Upper Truckee River, the main stream that flows into the lake at its south end, to try to recreate the filtering effects of a marsh destroyed to build a housing development in the late 60's. Others are bound to be controversial, like erecting gates at the roads that ring the basin and then charging an entrance fee for cars.
For the moment, Cinda Pierce, who has lived in Incline Village since 1976, and seen its population triple from 9,000 and her property values increase more than sixfold, said the problems were all too obvious.
"I was out kayaking last week, and to see the algae and stuff attached to the rocks," Ms. Pierce said, her voice trailing off. "It just never used to be there."

HEADLINE: New Jersey Daily Briefing;
Good Forecast for Economy

BYLINE: By TERRY PRISTIN 

DATELINE: NEW BRUNSWICK

 BODY:
New Jersey's economy is booming, forecasters said yesterday. By the end of the year, employment in nonagricultural industries is expected to rise by 1.8 percent, creating 65,000 new jobs, according to a report released yesterday by Rutgers University. 
 Personal income is expected to jump by 5 percent, while consumer prices are expected to increase 3 percent, said Nancy Mantell, director of the Rutgers Economic Advisory Service, which issues reports on the state's economy. She attributed the good news to low inflation, low interest rates, strong corporate profits and strong consumer confidence.

HEADLINE: HOCKEY;
Rangers Add to Big Offers In the Race to Land Messier

BYLINE: By JASON DIAMOS

 BODY:
Negotiating his way brilliantly through a high-stakes poker game with his future as the pot, the Rangers' captain, Mark Messier, seems to have all the cards on his side right now. All the 36-year-old unrestricted free agent appears to be doing is playing out his hand.
At the table: the Vancouver Canucks with a three-year, $18 million offer; the defending Stanley Cup champion Detroit Red Wings and their three-year, $15 million bid; and the Rangers, who are now believed to have raised their ante to two years, $10 million, with a club option or buyout for a third year that could increase the package's value to $15 million, too. 
 The Islanders announced yesterday that they have folded from the game. The Montreal Canadiens apparently never really were in. And contrary to popular belief, the Edmonton Oilers, Messier's former team, never tendered an offer.
"Of course I'm interested," said the Oilers' president, Glen Sather, a longtime friend of Messier's. "Can I afford him? No." The Rangers, the Red Wings and the Canucks apparently can.
The play is now Messier's. But he and his father, Doug, who serves as his agent, might make the Rangers' president, Neil Smith, and the folks at Madison Square Garden sweat a little more before they make their next move.
"I spoke to Doug Messier this morning because I wanted to know if those figures were somewhat accurate," General Manager Mike Milbury of the Islanders said yesterday of the various reported offers. "He said they were."
And so Milbury bowed out.
Neither Smith, Mark Messier nor the Garden's president, Dave Checketts, was commenting publicly yesterday, one day after the Rangers significantly increased their initial offer of one year for $5 million to Messier, with less than $4 million up front. The Rangers blinked because of the Canucks' enticing bid, which became public knowledge earlier this week.
"I don't know anything and I don't want to know anything," Rangers Coach Colin Campbell said yesterday from his summer home in Ontario, adding that he last spoke with Messier at Mike Richter's wedding earlier this month. "Certainly I would like to have Mark back and Neil as general manager would love to have him come back, too. But I have respect for both sides."
Campbell is not the only coach who would love to have Messier, however.
"As a coach, I'd take him as a player," Detroit's Scotty Bowman said yesterday, mindful that the presence of the veteran center, who has six Stanley Cup rings, might make it easier for the Red Wings to win another title this season. "But I'm not involved with the economics."
That responsibility belongs to Ken Holland, who became the Detroit general manager effective last Friday. It is believed that the Red Wings will not go four years and will not match Vancouver's offer.
SLAP SHOTS
The Rangers announced yesterday that their preseason schedule will begin on Sept. 14 in Montreal. Tickets for the three preseason games at Madison Square Garden will go on sale on Aug. 13. The Rangers will open training camp on Sept. 9 in Burlington, Vt.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Asian Central Banks Seek Ways to Block Speculators

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: SHANGHAI, July 25

 BODY:
Asian central bankers, reeling from speculative attacks in the foreign-exchange market, agreed today to study ways to increase the value of their countries' currencies but stopped short of promising to intervene in the market to support the currencies.
Moreover, currency traders and economists said the heads of the 11 central banks, who held a regularly scheduled gathering of the Executives' Meeting of East Asian and Pacific Central Banks, were fighting the wrong battle because it was slowing economic growth that had eroded their countries' competitiveness in world markets and left their currencies overvalued against the dollar. 
 Traders have been betting that the Asian nations, many of whose currencies are linked to the dollar through an overt peg or a "managed float" system, cannot keep pace with the American currency given the region's higher inflation rates and swelling trade gaps.
"They can no longer believe that there's a simple way of doing things," said Kenneth Courtis, chief economist at Deutsche Bank Group Asia-Pacific. "If you're going to tie your currency to another currency, you basically have to have the same monetary policies and the same type of economic development."
Asian currencies were mixed in the foreign-exchange market after the central bankers' announcement.
The bankers said that while economic fundamentals in the region remained "sound," they had asked local officials to assist the International Monetary Fund in studying arrangements for "facilities to assist" countries whose currencies were under attack.
The statement was aimed at curbing speculation in Asian currencies by making it more expensive for investors to bet against a currency, analysts said. "What they want to do is to reintroduce two-way risk," said Callum Henderson, managing currency analyst at MMS International S.& P. Asia in Hong Kong. "At the moment, it's a one-way bet."
Within the 11-country group, five members of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations -- Thailand, the Philippines, Malaysia, Singapore and Indonesia -- also used the meeting to extend a currency-swap agreement that was established in 1977.
Thailand and Japan signed a pact last week under which Japan would come to the aid of the Thai currency, the baht, if needed. Officials declined to say at which level such help could be expected.
 
Dollar Strength Continues
(By The Associated Press) -- The dollar continued to strengthen in trading in Europe and New York yesterday, rising above 1.84 marks for the first time since July 1991.
Strong United States economic data, further doubts about the credibility of Europe's planned single currency and a French central banker's predictions of further dollar gains all combined to push the dollar up.
The dollar rose as high as 1.8403 marks, the strongest since July 1991, before settling in New York at 1.8384 marks, up from 1.8348 Thursday and up 2.5 percent for the week.
Against the yen, the dollar advanced to 117.02 yen in New York, up from 116.05 yen Thursday and the highest level since May 14. The pound fell to $1.6642 from $1.6745.

HEADLINE: Bond Prices Slide as Investors Await Data

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Treasury prices slipped yesterday as investors waited for several economic reports next week for confirmation that inflation continues to be dormant.
Data on orders for durable goods and existing-home sales were released yesterday, but neither report affected the bond market much. Instead, investors were looking ahead to the quarterly Employment Cost Index on Tuesday, followed by a first look at second-quarter gross domestic product on Thursday and July's employment results on Friday. 
 About a dozen more economic reports will also be released in one of the busiest weeks of the year.
"The numbers will be very important next week," said Ken Anderson, who helps manage $7 billion in bonds for Evergreen Asset Management Corporation in Purchase, N.Y.
The price of the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond fell 6/32 yesterday, to 102 10/32 . The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 6.45 percent, from 6.43 percent on Thursday. A week ago, it was 6.52 percent.
Many investors remain bullish after Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, suggested earlier this week that he was in no hurry to raise interest rates. In semiannual testimony before Congress, Mr. Greenspan said the economy's combination of strong growth and low inflation was exceptional.
"It's going to be hard to derail the current rally," said Vic Thompson, who manages $105 billion of fixed-income assets at Boston's State Street Global Advisers. He said that he did not expect next week's reports to deflate investor optimism and that 30-year bond yields could fall to 6.10 percent by the end of the year.
"The mood is ebullient," said Ben Mayer, who helps manage $15 billion of bonds at AMR Investments in Fort Worth. "There is definitely the momentum" for 30-year Treasury yields to fall to 6.38 percent in the next few weeks, he said.
In the corporate bond market, GCI Inc., the Standard Commercial Corporation, Digital Television Services L.L.C. and three financial companies -- Norwest Financial Inc., Western Financial Bank and GBC Bancorp -- raised a combined $790 million yesterday, adding to this week's total of at least $7 billion in new bond sales.
Companies are rushing to sell debt as Treasury bond yields, the benchmark that companies use to price their debt, are near their lowest in almost eight months and as investor demand remains robust.
"It's nice to price into a market that's favorable," said Kevin Race, chief financial officer at Homeside Lending Inc., which sold $200 million of notes on Thursday. "We wanted to take advantage of that, and that's what we've done."

HEADLINE: Beliefs

BYLINE: By Peter Steinfels 

 BODY:
The nation's most widely shared religious ritual is undoubtedly the Sunday collection. It may also be one of the most mysterious.
Why, for example, do Mormons give more than 7 percent of their income to their church, while Christian Scientists and Unitarian-Universalists give less than 1 percent? 
 Why have contributions from Protestants, particularly those in liberal denominations, steadily slumped as a percentage of disposable income? Or, to take a question that has stirred sharp debate among Roman Catholics, why have they contributed at a rate, well under 1.5 percent of their income, roughly half that of Protestants?
Everyone has a favorite theory: One is that Catholics give less because they are angry over the Pope's stand on birth control. But there has been very little hard evidence -- until now.
"Money Matters" (Westminster John Knox Press, 1997) is a landmark study by two sociologists, Dean R. Hoge of Catholic University and Patrick McNamara of the University of New Mexico; an economist, Charles Zech of Villanova, and an independent researcher and writer, Michael J. Donahue. With support from the Lilly Endowment, the four authors profiled 625 congregations representing the diversity of churches in five denominations.
Two of the denominations were conservative and evangelical: the Assemblies of God and the Southern Baptist Convention. Two were moderate to liberal: the Evangelical Lutheran Church in America and the Presbyterian Church (U.S.A.). Catholics were the fifth group.
The authors collected data from each congregation about its receipts and expenditures, membership, programs, financial decision-making process, theological orientation and approach to giving.
They also surveyed a sample of each congregation's members, getting data on age, income levels, size of contributions, church involvement and satisfaction with the pastor, the denomination and the way church money was were raised and accounted for.
They checked these 11,000 questionnaires from laity against a national telephone survey of randomly selected Catholics, Lutherans and Presbyterians conducted by the Gallup Organization. Finally, they studied 12 financially successful congregations in depth.
"Money Matters" systematically reviews more than 20 hypotheses about why church members give large or small amounts. And many of the findings are surprising. Consider several popular explanations for the lower rate of giving by Catholics:
First, it is often said that Catholics give less because their parishes are generally much larger than most Protestant congregations. But the relationship between the amount of giving and smaller congregations turns out to be slight and inconsistent. A sense of community and ownership among congregants is important, the authors conclude, "but these qualities are not necessarily limited to smaller churches."
Another theory is that Catholics give less because their parishes are not democratic. "At most, a secondary factor," the authors say. "What is crucial is trust in leadership," and democratic procedures may or may not bring that about.
Even though Assemblies of God congregations have pro forma elections, "the ministers run the churches, and everyone accepts the situation as proper," the authors report. Giving is much higher than in the more democratic Presbyterian, Lutheran and Baptist congregations.
A third theory is that Catholics give less because they are angry with the Vatican or other church leaders. "Initially, we thought that the theory might be true," the authors say, "but now we conclude that it is largely false."
Catholics are more apt to feel they have an insufficient voice in parish financial decisions, the authors report, but "in our survey, Catholics are no angrier in general than the members of the other denominations." Anger about church teaching on birth control and women's ordination is "not associated with level of giving."
Nor do Catholics give less because they are paying for children in parish schools. Catholic families with children in parish schools actually give more than other families.
"Money Matters" does find a modest and sometimes indirect support for some other hypotheses about church contributions. But the largest factors, besides having affluent families to begin with and achieving a high level of church involvement, turn on theology.
In keeping with other studies, the book shows that religious groups with an evangelical theology and with practices that set members off from the prevailing culture inspire greater financial sacrifice.
Another important factor is the theological understanding of giving itself. The Assemblies of God and many Baptists expect members to tithe, to donate from 5 percent to 10 percent of their incomes, as a fulfillment of scriptural mandates, a sign of trust in God and a way to insure divine blessing.
Other religious groups, with a great deal of variation, emphasize stewardship, the biblical concept that the world is God's and that believers are temporary users accountable for a wise management of earthly resources.
The authors of "Money Matters" distinguish both concepts from simple fund-raising as matters of spiritual discipline, not just utilitarian means to an end. They "focus on the individual's need to give, not on the church's need to receive," they write, on "giving as an aspect of spiritual life and of people's relationship to God, not as merely a matter of meeting an institutional budget."
Tithing, of course, is clear-cut and effective but, to many pastors interviewed by the authors, theologically troubling. Appeals to stewardship are vaguer and their effectiveness is harder to measure, yet they clearly increase giving if congregants are led to ponder and pledge a yearly sum or percentage of income.
Just as "Money Matters" ultimately emphasizes theology, so does a parallel study by Robert Wuthnow, the Princeton sociologist of religion.
Bearing the all-purpose title "The Crisis in the Churches" (Oxford, 1997), the book is more revealingly subtitled: "Spiritual Malaise, Fiscal Woe." Mr. Wuthnow links the churches' financial future to an even wider agenda of teaching about faith, work, money and the marketplace.
More on that in a column in August -- closer, appropriately, to Labor Day.

HEADLINE: Lowest-Caste Hindu Takes Office as India's President

BYLINE: By JOHN F. BURNS 

DATELINE: NEW DELHI, July 25

 BODY:
Half a century after Mohandas K. Gandhi led India to independence with a vision of a society that would rid itself of its ancient system of caste discrimination, a member of Hinduism's lowest caste took the oath today as the country's President and declared his elevation as proof that "the concerns of the common man" have finally taken precedence in the nation's affairs.
K. R. Narayanan, a 76-year-old former scholar, diplomat and Cabinet minister who once served as India's Ambassador to the United States, was chosen for the ceremonial post last week by an electoral college comprising all the country's federal and state lawmakers. While others have risen to be senior Cabinet ministers, top judges and high-ranking military officers, Mr. Narayanan is the first to realize Gandhi's standard of proof that India was finally resolved to stamp out the humiliations of the caste system -- the election of an untouchable as President. 
 Real power in India rests with the Prime Minister and Cabinet. But at a time when India seems destined to elect politically unstable coalition governments, some Indians believe that the President's role in choosing the Prime Minister and the Cabinet, judging who is most likely to be able to command a majority in Parliament, could see Mr. Narayanan emerge as crucially important political figure.
For the 150 million Indians who call themselves Dalits, a Hindi word meaning "the oppressed" that is now commonly used when referring to untouchables, Mr. Narayanan's story has the elements of a fable. He grew up in the southern state of Kerala in the 1930's at a time when untouchables were routinely denied the right to enter Hindu temples, draw water from wells reserved for Brahmins and other members of the higher castes, or walk along some village pathways; these restrictions still apply, even if they are unlawful, in many of India's 650,000 villages.
Because he was an outstanding student, rising from a village primary school to top academic honors at the London School of Economics, Mr. Narayanan found a way around obstacles that even today, consign many low-caste Indians to lives of social degradation. But well into adult life, he endured humiliations that would be recognizable to any untouchable, including an occasion when a university official in Kerala took exception to his wearing a silk-trimmed academic gown to classes, standard among Indian students of the time but judged unsuitable for a low-caste person who would traditionally have been restricted to scanty clothes like the loincloth that Gandhi often wore.
So today, the television images of Mr. Narayanan taking office had powerful symbolism all across India. Dressed in a cream-colored, high-buttoned suit of the kind named for Jawaharlal Nehru, the Prime Minister who approved Mr. Narayanan's entry into the Indian foreign service over the objections of high-caste officials, he rode in the gilded carriage once used by Britain's Viceroys, pulled by six gleaming horses and protected from the beating sun of the Indian summer by a red-and-gold parasol. Mounted lancers rode beside him with plumed pith helmets, and honor guards from the armed forces stood ramrod still as he passed by in review.
In his address in the ornate Central Hall of India's Parliament, Mr. Narayanan, who previously served as Vice President, began with a salute to the lawmakers who chose him in a ballot last week in which he won 95 percent of the votes, defeating the only other candidate, a former election commissioner, T. S. Seshan. Mr. Seshan, a well-known maverick, greeted his defeat with an angry outburst, telling reporters that it was "an insult" to Mr. Narayanan that the mainly upper-caste lawmakers chose him, in Mr. Seshan's words, "only because he was a Dalit."
Mr. Narayanan made it clear that he thought Mr. Seshan had gotten matters upside down.
"That the nation has found a consensus for its highest office in someone who has sprung from the grass-roots of our society and grown up in the dust and heat of this sacred land is symbolic of the fact that the concerns of the common man have now moved to the center stage of our social and political life," he said. "It is this larger significance of my election rather than any personal sense of honor that makes me rejoice on this occasion."
Mr. Narayanan went on to offer a stinging rebuke to the country's politicians, who applauded him repeatedly even as he politely condemned them.
With barely three weeks to go to the 50th anniversary of India's independence from Britain, he recalled Gandhi's ambition that a free India would "wipe every tear from every eye" by eliminating the country's ancient scourges, including poverty, disease, illiteracy and caste discrimination -- ills that are still pervasive, leaving India close to the bottom of virtually every international index of social progress. Among other things, India's official statistics say nearly 350 million of the country's 960 million people still live in deep poverty.
Gandhi, Mr. Narayanan said, described true democracy as "what promotes the welfare of the people," but the new President argued that the current generation of Indian politicians had placed personal ambition ahead of the abolition of poverty, ignorance and disease.
"Excessive obsession with the pursuit of pure politics has often overshadowed the social, economic and developmental needs of our people," he said. "Can we not sink our differences, as we have done on critical occasions in our history, and devote our undivided attention, for a time, to the development of the economy and the welfare of the people?"
But many Indian commentators shared Mr. Seshan's view that there was tokenism in Mr. Narayanan's appointment, and others said Mr. Narayanan had been co-opted by the Brahmins and other upper-caste Indians who still dominate in the country's politics, civil service and top corporations. A nephew of the new President told Outlook, a leading Indian news magazine, that Mr. Narayanan had turned his back on his caste origins, calling his uncle a "Harijan Brahmin."
But another view was that Mr. Narayanan could play a key role in encouraging lower-caste Indians to believe that there is a place for them in a caste-free society, instead of throwing in their lot with caste-based political parties that have become increasingly powerful as the Congress Party, the all-embracing vehicle of Gandhi and Nehru, has faded from its once all-conquering position.
The most powerful of these groups, the Bahujana Samaj Party, has used wily political horse-trading to gain power in Uttar Pradesh, the country's biggest state, with 140 million people. Low-caste political leaders, including Mayawati, the fiery Chief Minister of Uttar Pradesh, have dismissed Gandhi's gospel of social inclusion for untouchables as a sham.
Indian newspapers often carry accounts of upper-caste village men escaping punishment after raping untouchable women, or parading them naked along village paths, or shaving their heads, usually for some alleged transgression of caste traditions. The response of Mr. Mayawati has been to order reverse discrimination, dismissing, demoting or transferring thousands of upper-caste civil servants and replacing them with untouchables, and ordering the arrest of thousands of people for alleged caste discrimination.
The Indian Express, one of the country's most powerful newspapers, expressed the hope that Mr. Narayanan's arrival as President would quell the turn toward caste-based politics. It said in an editorial that the appointment "advertises the fact that social mobility is no mere directive principle -- it can be an actual fact."

GRAPHIC: Photo: K. R. Narayanan waved from a horse-drawn coach outside the presidential palace in New Delhi yesterday before being installed as President. (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: U.S. Links Top Bosnia Serbs to Attacks

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 25

 BODY:
The United States has concluded that senior Bosnian Serb leaders are orchestrating attacks on NATO troops and senior Administration officials said today that NATO would retaliate if the incidents continued.
The attacks have presumably come in response to the arrest of one war-crimes suspect and the killing of another. The persistence and severity of the attacks -- which American and NATO officials initially discounted as isolated incidents, often involving drunken Serbs -- have raised concerns about the security of the 30,000 NATO-led troops in Bosnia. 
 A senior Administration official in Washington said there would be "serious consequences" in the event of "even one more such action."
"We've had enough of this," the official said.
Administration officials declined to specify how NATO forces would retaliate, though one said commanders in Bosnia had virtually unlimited authority to act when faced with a threat to the NATO troops.
The first steps are likely to be diplomatic, but the officials said the next ones could include cracking down on television broadcasts the Serbs have used to incite attacks and seizing caches of weapons the Serbs were required to warehouse as part of the Dayton peace accords.
In recent days, a parade of American and European envoys has denounced the attacks and warned Bosnian Serb leaders in their stronghold, Pale, against inciting attacks.
Today's sharper warnings came after yet another attack on NATO forces. Before dawn this morning, an American soldier's car was damaged by a firebomb in Vlasenica, a village in the Serb-controlled part of Bosnia, according to a statement issued by the American military headquarters in Tuzla. No one was injured and the fire was extinguished.
While no one has been killed in the series of attacks, several troops have been injured, including a Dutch soldier who was wounded by shrapnel from a grenade attack in Kotor Varos and an American who was attacked by an unknown prowler outside his home, also in Vlasenica.
The attacks, which initially were written off as isolated incidents, began after the surprise operation by NATO forces on July 10 in which British special forces killed a Serbian official indicted for war crimes by the international tribunal in The Hague and arrested another in a separate raid.
The actions against the suspects, who had been charged in sealed indictments, reflected a new resolve by NATO to enforce the terms of the Dayton accords, including the capture of suspected war criminals.
The arrests also struck fear in the Bosnian Serbs, particularly those in Pale, the nationalist stronghold still dominated by Radovan Karadzic, the former president of the Bosnian Serbs, who himself is under indictment on war-crimes charges.
In public statements, Bosnian Serb leaders have denounced the arrests, but at the same time urged people not to retaliate. However, television and radio broadcasts have been increasingly inflammatory, and in recent days posters have appeared defending Dr. Karadzic.
At first, NATO's commanders discounted the idea that the attacks might be coordinated, and officials here in Washington, while denouncing them, played down their seriousness.
"In the last day or two, some of the people subscribing to that view have begun to change," another official said today. "This turnaround is particularly pronounced at the Pentagon."
The officials, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said there is evidence of the involvement of the Interior Minister, Dragan Kajic, who is known to follow the orders of Dr. Karadzic. Mr. Kajic was at the center of the recent power struggle among Serbian leaders, when the Bosnian Serb president, Biljana Plavsic, tried to fire him. Dr. Karadzic's supporters retaliated by expelling Mrs. Plavsic from the ruling party and demanding her resignation.
The officials said they would also hold the Bosnian political leadership responsible, including Momcilo Krajisnik, who holds the Serbian seat on the three-member presidency ruling all of Bosnia.
The officials said the attacks would not force NATO to back away from its more aggressive approach to the mission in Bosnia, including more arrests of war-crimes suspects. However, in recent days, NATO officials have indicated that more arrests are not planned for now.
Over the last few days, the American representative to the United Nations, Bill Richardson, and the American special envoy for Bosnia, Robert S. Gelbard, have traveled through the region and called for an end to the attacks.
One Administration official in Washington said NATO was stepping up its warnings to demonstrate its resolve to the Serbs.
The United States has also succeeded in forcing the International Monetary Fund to postpone for at least two months the release of $38 million in loans for Croatia.
The Administration has pressed the fund and other international financial institutions, like the World Bank, to deny Croatia assistance until President Franjo Tudjman does more to live up to the terms of the Dayton accords, including the arrests of war criminals.
The money was the second installment of a $486 million, three-year loan approved by the I.M.F. earlier this year, but the fund's directors, meeting in Washington, agreed to delay an economic review that would have freed up the money, fund and Administration officials said.

 BODY:

So use good caring skills, or NANOVOTER(TM) wanders off and you are left to the sadness of the private sector. Be wary!
