INTERNATIONAL 2-5
 
U.S. Ambassador Is an Heir Right Under Swiss Eyes
Madeleine Kunin, the Swiss-born American ambassador to Switzerland, was surprised to discover her mother's name on the list of dormant accounts she herself had cajoled Swiss bankers to publish. 1
 
A complex set of schisms has developed between parties interested in the list of dormant World War II-era accounts published by Swiss banks. Paul Volcker, head of an independent investigative commission, warned that a class action suit that claims the assets of Holocaust victims are languishing in Swiss bank vaults could impede his team's progress and snuff out vital Swiss collaboration. 5
 
U.S. Sees Bosnian Serb Scheme
Attacks on NATO troops are being orchestrated by some Bosnian Serb leaders, senior officials have concluded. The United States and NATO vowed to be resolute if "even one more such action" occurred. An American soldier's car was firebombed in Vlasenica, a village in the Serb-controlled part of Bosnia. No one was injured. 5
 
Untouchable to Lead India
K.R. Narayanan became India's first "untouchable" President. He told Parliament and the nation that his election to the post symbolized the long-awaited arrival of an era when "the concerns of the common man" had taken precedence in the nation's affairs. 3
 
New Use for Cambodian Guns
Heavily armed troops were deployed around Phnom Penh, briefed to prevent high school students from cheating on their final exams. Photocopy shops were also guarded. Teachers in Cambodia are paid around $20 a month and bribery is widespread. The Government's crackdown follows its coup weeks ago. 4
 
Housing Angers East Jerusalem
The decision by the city government of Jerusalem to allow an American Jewish financier to build Jewish housing in an Arab neighborhood of East Jerusalem caught Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu off guard. He vowed to block the plan, which enraged Palestinians. 2
 
Albright Attends Asean Talks
Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright arrived in Malaysia for meetings with the Association of Southeast Asian Nations on how Hun Sen might be persuaded to hold legitimate elections after the coup in Cambodia. Washington has suspended its aid to Cambodia for 30 days. 4
 
Strike Talks Resume in Israel
Israel's skies were quiet as flights were stopped and telephone communications were often cut by workers striking against plans to privatize Bezek, the country's telephone monopoly. After Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu called the leaders of the Histadrut labor federation "Bolshevik dinosaurs" and they accused him of acting like a "Bolshevik regime," the strike was called off and negotiations resumed. 3
 
NATIONAL 6-9
 
Ex-G.O.P. Chairmen Offer Differing Accounts of Loan
One former Republican National chairman contradicted another as Richard Richards told the Senate campaign finance inquiry that Haley Barbour had stressed an urgent need for a $2.1-million foreign loan guarantee to "free up" funds for Republican candidates in their 1994 campaign to take control of Congress. 1

Congress Adds Disability Aid
Congressional Republicans bowed to President Clinton's demands and tentatively agreed to restore disability benefits to more than half a million legal immigrants, as budget negotiators broke a week-long impasse. Republicans also agreed to extend Medicaid coverage to tens of thousands of children who will lose their disability benefits under the welfare law that President Clinton signed last August. 1

Caretaker Seeks Reward
The caretaker who stumbled on the hideout of Andrew P. Cunanan has filed a lawsuit in Dade County Circuit Court to claim a total of $65,000 in reward money that had been offered for the apprehension of Mr. Cunanan. Mr. Cunanan, who had been sought in the murder of five men, including the fashion designer, Gianni Versace, fatally shot himself on a houseboat in Miami Beach after the police were called by the caretaker. 6
 
Notoriety Follows Ex-Suspect
It has been almost a year since Richard A. Jewell was first identified by The Atlanta Journal as the focus of the Federal investigation into the July 27 bombing at Centennial Olympic Park. It has been almost nine months since the Justice Department cleared him of any involvement in the deadly attack. And yet, Mr. Jewell, 34, lives with his unwanted notoriety every day and his bitterness remains strikingly raw. 6
 
An internal Justice Department investigation into the bombing in Atlanta has concluded that a F.B.I. interview of Mr. Jewell was seriously flawed and resulted from a breakdown of communications within the law enforcement agency, Government officials said. 6
 
G.M. and Union Reach Accord
General Motors and the United Automobile Workers reached a tentative pact to end a strike at a transmission factory that had forced the company to idle six other plants. 7
 
Chrysler Seats Scrutinized
The Chrysler Corporation sent instructional videos last week to about 135,000 customers after receiving complaints that child seats built into its mini-vans malfunctioned. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration is investigating the matter. No injuries or deaths have been attributed to the seats, Chrysler and the Federal safety agency said. 7

Senate Backs Treaty Change
The Senate unanimously urged the Clinton Administration not to pursue a treaty that would limit the industrial world's emissions of greenhouse gases unless the agreement requires developing countries to control their rapidly growing emissions at the same time. 8

NEW YORK/REGION 23-27
 
Jury Finds Gigante Guilty On Racketeering Charges
Vincent Gigante, the enigmatic figure known for wearing a bathrobe and pajamas in public, was convicted of being a powerful Mafia kingpin who conspired in plots to kill other gangland figures and who ran lucrative rackets in New York. At the same time, though, the jury in Federal District Court in Brooklyn acquitted him of ordering three gangland killings and could not agree on charges that he ordered four other murders. 1

Law enforcement officials said Mr. Gigante's racketeering conviction was unlikely to immediately weaken the Genovese crime family's powerful underworld position, since his active role as boss of the gang was reduced in recent years by intense law-enforcement pressure and a heart ailment. 25

Conviction in Cosby Trial
A Federal jury in Manhattan convicted Autumn Jackson of trying to extort $40 million from Bill Cosby, the man she claimed was her father. When she is sentenced on Oct. 22, she could receive a prison term of up to 12 years for her convictions on extortion and two other charges, conspiracy and traveling across state lines to commit the offenses. Her attorney said he planned to appeal the verdict and that Ms. Jackson is also considering a paternity suit against the actor. 1

Forced Labor Inquiry Expands
Federal agents raided two houses in a small North Carolina city and found more than a dozen illegal Mexican immigrants, most of them deaf, who officials believe were coerced into peddling trinkets at local shopping centers and giving most of the proceeds to "bosses" who oversaw the operation. The United States Attorney in Greensboro, N.C., said prosecutors were exploring whether the operation in Sanford was linked to the people charged last week in New York City with holding dozens of deaf Mexican peddlers in virtual slavery. 1
 
Crime Falls in New Jersey
Overall violent crime dropped 11 percent across New Jersey last year. The decline was far greater than the 7 percent decrease in violent crimes across the nation. 23

HEADLINE: Flake May Leave the Congress For an Expanded Church Role

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS 

 BODY:
Representative Floyd H. Flake, an 11-year incumbent who also leads a sprawling congregation in Queens, said yesterday that he was considering retiring from Congress at the end of his current term to devote more attention to the church he has been pastor of for 21 years.
While Mr. Flake, a 52-year-old Democrat, said in an interview that he planned to make a decision within the next two weeks, several people who are close to him said that he had decided not to seek a seventh term in Congress, and that he would announce his decicion to his congregation next week. 
 Rumors of Mr. Flake's deliberations have traveled in political circles in Queens for several months as some thought that the Congressman might seek the position of bishop in the Allen African Methodist Episcopal Church in Jamaica, Queens. And although he declined to seek that post, that has not stopped several Democratic politicians from discussing a possible run for his seat in the 1998 Congressional elections.
The name mentioned most prominently by Queens Democrats is Gregory W. Meeks, 43, a state assemblyman with close ties to Mr. Flake who is also the chairman of the state Council of Black Elected Democrats. Another is State Assemblywoman Barbara M. Clark, 58, who has been in office since 1987 and has already begun discussing fund-raising strategies, several political officials said. Also, State Senator Alton R. Waldon Jr., 60, is said to be interested in the seat.
Archie Spigner, one of the City Council's most senior members, is also mentioned as a possible contender. Mr. Spigner yesterday described the idea of a Congressional race as "a rather stimulating concept," but declined to discuss the matter further. Mr. Meeks and Mr. Waldon were traveling yesterday and could not be reached, their staff members said. Ms. Clark did not respond to telephone messages.
Mr. Flake said he was considering leaving Congress because his duties to the Allen A.M.E. Church will expand with the opening of a $23 million, 2,500-seat cathedral. "I have a certain standard in terms of attending to my Congressional and church responsibilities," Mr. Flake said. "And I'm not certain I could really keep pace."
A Democrat who has leveraged his political power with Republicans to gain economic clout for his church in southeast Queens, Mr. Flake has developed a formidable social-service and economic empire at Allen A.M.E. that many suggest far outpaces the one established a generation earlier by Congressman Adam Clayton Powell Jr. in Harlem.
Under the pastorship of Mr. Flake, who was once a Xerox Corporation market analyst, Allen A.M.E. has established an elementary school for about 500 students, a 300-unit senior citizens complex, a bus chartering corporation and a community center that operates a health clinic and a Head Start program. The church's development corporation has also purchased commercial storefronts.
Mr. Flake said that he did not wish to discuss any potential successor. "The seat is not vacant and, God knows, it may not be," he said. The Sixth Congressional District includes most of southeastern Queens, and includes the neighborhoods of Jamaica, St. Albans, Cambria Heights, Laurelton and South Ozone Park. It also includes the western portion of the Rockaway peninsula.
The new Allen Cathedral, which will have its first worship services on Sunday, will be the second-largest predominantly African-American church in New York City, after the Concord Baptist Church in Brooklyn.
Mr. Flake is known as an independent Democrat. He has decided not to join with the Queens Democratic organization, which has endorsed the mayoral candidacy of Ruth W. Messinger, the Manhattan Borough President. Mr. Flake said yesterday that he would not make a mayoral endorsement this year. "I feel favorably disposed to the positive things that have happened to New York in the last three years," he said, adding that his words should not be construed as an endorsement of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. "But if the economy is up and crime is down, it's difficult to fight against the things you have fought for all of your life."
Mr. Flake has sometimes run into difficulties during his stewardship. In 1990, after a former church secretary's testimony to a grand jury in Brooklyn accused Mr. Flake of financial improprieties, Federal prosecutors charged the Congressman and his wife, Margarett Elaine, with not reporting $177,578 in income from the church and dodging Federal income taxes. The following year, three weeks into the trial, prosecutors, their approach derailed by an early ruling by the judge, dropped the charges against the Flakes.
But later in 1991, the Justice Department brought a civil suit against Mr. Flake, accusing him of improperly using Federal housing funds to build a portion of the church school. In a settlement in 1994, Mr. Flake and his church agreed to repay the $500,000 with interest but admitted no wrongdoing.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Representative Floyd H. Flake, at pulpit of Allen A.M.E. Church. (William Lopez/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Senate Urges U.S. to Pursue New Strategy On Emissions

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 25

 BODY:
The Senate unanimously urged the Clinton Administration today not to pursue a treaty that would limit the industrial world's emissions of greenhouse gases unless the agreement requires developing countries to control their rapidly growing emissions at the same time.
While it is not binding, the Senate resolution complicates the continuing negotiations for a new treaty to prevent global warming caused by increasing levels of carbon dioxide as people burn more fossil fuel. 
 The Senate would have to consent by a two-thirds vote to the ratification of any such treaty by the United States. The resolution criticizing the Administration's current negotiating approach passed, 95 to 0.
In the debate, many senators expressed skepticism that global warming was a serious problem or that the United States, as the leading emitter of gases like carbon dioxide that trap heat from the sun, should do more than poorer nations to reverse it.
But even those senators who favor a treaty voted for the resolution after its chief sponsor, Senator Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia, expressly endorsed the scientific consensus behind the global warming theory and signaled that less developed countries ought to be granted more flexibility in cutting emissions, as long as they accept the treaty commitments.
The final negotiations for the treaty are to be made at a meeting in Kyoto, Japan, at the end of the year.The next round of bargaining is to begin next week in Bonn. The resolution that passed the Senate today disputes a basic premise of those talks: that the first and biggest steps ought to be taken by industrial nations like the United States.
Senator Byrd, a Democrat, said the proposal offered by the Administration in the talks was "simply unacceptable." That proposal would set binding limits on emissions of heat-trapping gases by industrial nations in the medium term, while deferring the time when developing nations would have to accept similar limits.
Mr. Byrd's resolution is supported by energy producing and consuming industries, especially the coal industry, which sustains the West Virginia economy and is powerful in many other states. Industry lobbyists have argued that reducing such gases threatens their prosperity.
Andrew Card, president of the American Automobile Manufacturers Association, called the vote "a wake-up call to the Administration to adopt a more open and realistic approach to global climate negotiations."
But Tim Wirth, the Under Secretary of State for global environmental affairs, tried to put the best light on the situation, saying after the vote that "we support the thrust of the Byrd resolution," and added: "We have been further out front than any country in pressing for developing-country commitments. The U.S. is much more aggressive than anyone else, and this strengthens our hand."
Senators John Kerry of Massachusetts, a Democrat, and John H. Chafee of Rhode Island, a Republican, joined with Mr. Byrd in a carefully scripted colloquy on the floor during which they all seemed to agree that each country should make, as Senator Byrd put it, "unique and binding contributions of a pace and kind consistent with their industrialization."
Mr. Byrd added, "The developing world must agree in Kyoto to adopt some manner of binding targets and commitments which would begin during the same compliance period as the developed world, in as aggressive and effective a schedule as possible."
A scripted discussion in a Senate debate is important because it provides a legislative history intended to clarify the intention of a resolution.
Mr. Byrd also said his resolution "accepts the thesis, which is still the subject of some dispute," that global warming is a real problem.
Many scientists believe the warming of the planet could cause ocean levels to rise and would severely disrupt the earth's biological systems. Such a trend is likely, they say, because increasing levels of carbon dioxide and other gases trap heat from the sun in a process similar to what happens in a greenhouse.
In the colloquy, Mr. Kerry built support for the Administration's plan to allow developing and developed nations to trade credits with one another for reducing emissions, a plan intended to reduce the costs faced by industrial nations while decreasing the pollution generated by developing nations.
But the debate also highlighted strong feelings among some lawmakers against any treaty whatsoever. Senator Larry E. Craig, Republican of Idaho, accused President Clinton of using his "bully pulpit to terrorize the American people," and of "building a propaganda campaign" to support a new treaty.

HEADLINE: Orders in June For Durables Rose by 2.3%

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 25

 BODY:
Orders for durable goods rose 2.3 percent in June, more than expected, with half the increase coming from a flood of orders for commercial aircraft, the Commerce Department said today.
A separate report showed that home resales fell 2.6 percent in June. 
 Excluding the often-volatile category of transportation equipment, June's orders for durable goods increased eight-tenths of 1 percent.
In May, orders for durable goods, which are expensive items meant to last at least three years, fell a revised four-tenths of 1 percent. The decline had previously been reported as seven-tenths of 1 percent.
Economists caution it is difficult to discern trends from month-to-month shifts in the orders because they are heavily influenced by changes in orders for commercial jetliners and military weapons. Still, the June increase was another indication that the economy remained on a path of moderate growth, which should keep Federal Reserve policy makers from raising interest rates.
"Despite the unexpected strength of June orders, the trend in orders is not alarming," said Christopher Low, economist at HSBC Markets Inc. in New York.
During June, the Boeing Company, which is the world's largest civilian aircraft maker, received orders for 156 planes, bringing orders for the year to 224, or about $16 billion.
Excluding military hardware, orders increased 2.1 percent last month, the fifth increase in six months.
Unfilled orders, a gauge of pent-up demand, rose three-tenths of 1 percent in June on the heels of May's revised gain of one-tenth of 1 percent. Shipments, a measure of current demand, rose 1.8 percent after having fallen 1.5 percent in May.
In the report on June's home resales, the National Association of Realtors said resales fell 2.6 percent, to an annual rate of 4.14 million, the fourth decline in the last six months. Resales increased a revised 4.7 percent in May.
"While there has been a slight tapering off, the market has remained strong due to favorable economic conditions over all," the association's president, Russell Booth, said. "We expect this activity to continue with no major surges or dropoffs in the near future."
The figures represent actual closings, which lag behind contract signings by a few months. David Resler, an economist with Nomura Securities in New York, said before today's report that "these transactions would have gone to contract in March or April, just as people were getting ready to pay their taxes, not put a deposit on a house."
By region, resales fell 7.7 percent in the Northeast, to a 600,000 annual rate; were unchanged in the South, at a 1.58 million annual rate; rose nine-tenths of 1 percent in the Midwest, to a 1.08 million annual rate, and fell 6.4 percent in the West, to a 880,000 annual rate.
Home resales make up about 85 percent of all single-family home sales in the United States.

HEADLINE: A Gentler Hand at Columbia's Helm

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON 

 BODY:
In Thomas F. Frist Jr., Columbia/HCA Healthcare has the friendlier face it needs to reassure investors and perhaps strike a deal with Federal investigators.
Dr. Frist agreed to sell his Hospital Corporation of America to Richard L. Scott's company in 1993, seeing in Mr. Scott an aggressive manager better able to run the world's largest hospital chain. But as Federal investigators swarmed and allegations of wrongdoing multiplied, Dr. Frist questioned whether Mr. Scott had gone several steps too far. 
 "At any institution, there is a time for a different style to take it to the next level," Dr. Frist said yesterday, later adding, "There is a trust level that is not there."
Although Dr. Frist had offered some incentives for doctors to send their patients his way, he stopped short of Columbia/HCA's practice of making them investors in his hospitals. He is now scrapping this policy at Columbia/HCA.
And if the Hospital Corporation of America faced its share of challenges and lawsuits from aggrieved competitors and doctors, it was never confronted by Federal investigations of the nature facing Columbia/HCA.
Mr. Scott wears his intensity on his sleeve. Dr. Frist, whose brother, Bill, is a Republican Senator from Tennessee, comes across as a folksy Southerner -- Big Tommy, is his nickname.
"With Tommy, you really got the impression of a person who was comfortable in his position of authority," said Jeff Goldsmith, a hospital strategist.
Dr. Frist had urged Mr. Scott to lighten up. When the company headquarters were in Louisville, Ky., Dr. Frist successfully urged Mr. Scott to delay his 6 A.M. Monday teleconferences by an hour, complaining that the time difference forced him to stand ready at 5 A.M. in Nashville.
Unlike Mr. Scott, who is a lawyer, Dr. Frist is a doctor who made his career in the hospital business. Trained as a surgeon, Dr. Frist served as a flight surgeon in the Vietnam War but never practiced. Instead, he founded the Hospital Corporation of America with his father and another partner in 1968.
He was inspired by a fraternity brother whose father started the Holiday Inn chain, transforming an industry and bringing computerization, standardization and economies of scale. Obsessed with overcoming the stereotype of doctors as poor managers, he built and bought his way into making his company the nation's largest hospital chain by the late 1980's.
As Medicare cut payments, however, the Hospital Corporation of America and other chains fell from favor with investors. Dr. Frist and backers, including Richard Rainwater, responded by taking the company private in 1988 then public again in 1992. Mr. Rainwater, who was building his own hospital chain with Mr. Scott, was central in arranging the companies' merger in 1993.
Dr. Frist, 58, received a bachelor's degree from Vanderbilt and his M.D. from Washington University School of Medicine in St. Louis. As Columbia's vice chairman until he became chairman and chief executive yesterday, Dr. Frist is also the company's largest individual shareholder. His 14.6 million shares, or 2.2 percent of the company, were worth $524.7 million at yesterday's close.

Two Executives Are Out In Columbia/HCA Shake-Up
Richard L. Scott, left, the chairman and chief executive of the Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation, resigned amid growing criminal investigations of the giant hospital company's business practices. His lieutenant, David Vandewater, also quit. People close to Mr. Scott portrayed him as a brilliant businessman who was undone by flaws, among them an arrogance and aggressiveness that permeated the company, causing it to make enemies among competitors and Government officials alike. [Page 1.]
 
Taking the helm, Thomas F. Frist Jr. offers Columbia/HCA the friendlier face it needs to reassure investors and perhaps strike a deal with Federal investigators. [34.]
 
Sign of Moderate Growth
Orders for durable goods rose 2.3 percent in June, more than expected, with half the increase coming from commercial aircraft orders, the Commerce Department said. [34.]
 
Treasury prices slipped as investors waited for several reports next week for confirmation that inflation remains dormant. The yield on the 30-year bond rose to 6.45 percent.[36.]
 
Blue-chip stocks limped to a lower close after a spirited week. The Dow Jones industrial average ended 3.49 points lower at 8,113.44. For the week, it was up 222.98 points. [36.]

Rituxan, a biotechnology drug produced by Idec Pharmaceuticals and Genentech, would be used to treat a form of non-Hodgkin's lymphoma that is a slow-growing but fatal and incurable cancer of the immune system. [47.]

Familiar Name on Swiss Bank List
Madeleine Kunin, the United States Ambassador to Switzerland, had urged the country's embattled bankers to help the heirs of World War II victims and refugees, and particularly to publish a list of long-dormant bank accounts. Asians Look at Currency Fervor
The heads of 11 central banks in Asia agreed to study ways to increase values but did not promise to intervene against speculative attacks on their countries' currencies in the foreign-exchange market. [43.]

Gasoline and crude futures prices rose sharply amid a United Nations dispute over how much oil Iraq can sell in coming weeks. [43.]

HEADLINE: TALKS ON BUDGET YIELD AN ACCORD ON DISABILITY AID

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 25

 BODY:
Congressional Republicans bowed to President Clinton's demands today and tentatively agreed to restore disability benefits to more than half a million legal immigrants, as budget negotiators broke a weeklong impasse and began making progress on several bitterly contested issues.
The Republicans also agreed to continue Medicaid coverage for tens of thousands of children who would otherwise lose it, along with their disability benefits, under the welfare law that the President signed last August. 
 After a day of talks on Capitol Hill between senior Republicans and Administration officials, negotiators were making headway more quickly on restraining spending to balance the budget by 2002 than they were on cutting taxes. But today's progress suggested that they might reach agreement on spending and taxes alike in time for Congress to pass both bills and send them to Mr. Clinton before leaving for the summer recess next Friday.
Negotiators pared their ranks today to the most senior participants, who met in the offices of the Senate majority leader, Trent Lott, and Speaker Newt Gingrich. Aides said tonight that both sides, having adopted a get-it-done attitude, were spending less time posturing and speechifying and more time resolving specific issues.
The talks broke up shortly before 8 P.M., and Mr. Clinton's negotiating team returned to the White House to brief him. The negotiators plan to meet again at 11 A.M. on Saturday in hopes of resolving the outstanding issues.
"They're making a lot of progress on the spending side," a senior Administration official said.
But another White House official cautioned tonight, "A lot of work remains to be done."
Earlier in the day, Mr. Clinton sounded an optimistic note about the talks. "I think we're going to get this agreement," he said. But he also continued to pick apart the Republican tax-cutting plan, declaring that it fell far short of commitments to defray the cost of higher education that Congressional Republicans had made in the preliminary budget agreement.
Republicans agreed today to address two of Mr. Clinton's chief criticisms of the law overhauling the nation's welfare system, which he signed last Aug. 22. That law cut off most benefits for legal immigrants as of this fall.
Mr. Clinton criticized the law at the time for denying benefits to certain immigrants -- those legally living in the United States when he signed the bill -- if they were disabled, or became disabled later. He also said the law erred in changing the requirements for providing Supplemental Security Income to families with disabled children, so that tens of thousands of children would not qualify, and therefore also risked losing their Medicaid coverage.
Republicans agreed today to continue the disability benefits for legal immigrants and to extend Medicaid coverage for those children who lose the S.S.I. benefits.
Members of the Congressional Budget Office estimated that the agreement struck today would affect about 500,000 legal immigrants who were already disabled as of August. But it also estimated that one-third of those people could have ultimately received benefits anyway, because they would become citizens by 2000.
Congressional staff members said the changes would also help an additional 125,000 people who are estimated to become disabled in the future.
And 20,000 to 30,000 children are expected to benefit from the decision to continue Medicaid coverage.
Despite the progress on those two issues, several crucial disagreements over welfare remain, including the application of minimum-wage and other labor laws to welfare recipients in community service and workfare programs.
The principal author of the 1996 welfare law, Representative E. Clay Shaw Jr., the Florida Republican who heads the House Ways and Means Subcommittee on Human Resources, was not in the room during the negotiations. His aides said tonight that he wanted to see the entire package of welfare changes before passing judgment.
The compromise reached tonight may prove unpalatable to Republicans who considered the curtailing of benefits for immigrants an important part of the 1996 law.
Negotiating for the Republicans today, in addition to Mr. Lott and Mr. Gingrich, were Senator Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico, chairman of the Senate Budget Committee, and Representative John R. Kasich of Ohio, chairman of the House Budget Committee. The White House negotiators were Erskine B. Bowles, the chief of staff; Franklin D. Raines, the budget director; Gene Sperling, the economic policy adviser, and John Hilley, the Congressional liaison.
As the senior budget negotiators huddled, Mr. Clinton continued his drumbeat of criticism of the Republican tax-cut plan. He said it would fail to defray the costs of higher education, a goal to which Congressional Republicans agreed in the preliminary budget accord.
In a speech to elementary-school principals in northern Virginia, the President jockeyed for the political high ground by portraying himself as the guardian of fiscal discipline and the protector of the middle class.
"The tax cut has to, first of all, put middle-class families who need the relief most at the heart of its objectives," Mr. Clinton declared.
Mr. Clinton also warned that he would oppose tax cuts that would cause the budget deficit "to explode in the out years."
"We have been handicapped severely for years and years and years because we went on a binge of deficit spending in the early 80's that we couldn't break," he said.
Around the edges, other politicians tried either to speed the negotiations or to slow them.
Republicans on Capitol Hill tried to speed them. They said they feared that it would be more difficult to pass such legislation in September than now. "It would be a real loss of momentum," said the Senate majority whip, Don Nickles of Oklahoma.
Senator William V. Roth Jr., the Delaware Republican who leads the Senate Finance Committee, urged the President to release new Administration budget estimates, which are believed to show that the strong economy is shrinking the Federal deficit even more quickly than already expected.
"This is great news, and should not remain hidden," Mr. Roth said in a written statement. "A booming economy should allow us to provide a much larger tax cut for hard-working Americans."
For their part, an influential group of Senate Democrats said Mr. Clinton should be in no hurry to negotiate. Trying to stiffen Mr. Clinton's resolve and perhaps to strengthen his bargaining position, the nine Democratic members of the Senate Finance Committee called on the President to wait the Republicans out.
In a letter to Mr. Clinton, the nine Senators said: "We are troubled by the direction of the budget negotiations currently under way between the Administration and the Congress. The most recent Republican proposals on both the tax and spending bills move toward the House in many respects, which we find unacceptable."
Speaking before the negotiations were finished for tonight, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York, the committee's ranking Democrat, said that "it's not possible, nor do we think it wise," to complete work on the two bills by next Friday.
The Finance Committee Democrats are an influential group. They worked closely with the Republicans on the budget and tax bills, and if they oppose the final product there will be no chance of bipartisan support for the measures.
Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the Senate Democratic leader, echoed his colleagues' concern, saying, "I'd rather do it well than do it fast."
At the White House, Michael D. McCurry, the press secretary, said the President would be patient.
"We're not going to accept a deal just because Congress is going on recess," he said. "We'll stick around and wait to get something that the President thinks is in the best interests of the American people."
Mr. McCurry said that if necessary, the President would postpone his three-week vacation on Martha's Vineyard, planned to begin on Aug. 18, to continue negotiating.

HEADLINE: Coliseum Deal Is Governed By Financing

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY 

 BODY:
State officials acknowledged yesterday that they had tentatively recommended a winner in the yearlong competition to develop one of the most coveted pieces of Manhattan real estate -- Columbus Circle -- based less on architectural and aesthetic considerations than on financial grounds.
The officials had long maintained that they wanted buildings that would please the eyes and revive the neighborhood by replacing the dowdy New York Coliseum. But after settling on a design by Millennium Partners for an angular 64-story glass tower and connecting complex, the officials said they were most influenced by the willingness of the developer to pay for the site even if, as is very likely, the project is tied up in litigation before any ground is broken. 
 The officials said Millennium Partners had agreed to pay more than $300 million upon signing a contract for the property, lawsuits or no lawsuits. Developers generally withhold full payment until litigation is resolved, so the provision in the proposed deal with Millennium is highly unusual.
No other bidder said it would pay the full price in the face of litigation, officials involved in the selection process said.
The provision shows that the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, the state agency that owns the site, was so wounded by its last attempt to sell the Coliseum, a nine-year effort that collapsed in 1994 under the weight of several lawsuits, that it is eager to prevent it from happening again.
The provision "insures that this thing won't drag on for many years," said a senior state official, who spoke on condition of anonymity.
Officials said the aesthetics of Millennium's proposal helped its prospects, but were in the end of secondary importance. Some neighborhood groups have in fact praised the developer's design for a complex of 1.2 million square feet, which includes a convention center, a luxury hotel, condominiums, an entertainment center and a health club.
A coalition of three community boards in the area that ranked the nine original proposals for the site described the Millennium plan as among the best, though it said it had reservations about all the designs.
Millennium's lead architectural firm is James Stewart Polshek & Partners, which also designed the plan for the new planetarium at the American Museum of Natural History.
The Polshek design for the Coliseum site would create a glass presence on Columbus Circle with two towers, one 750 feet tall and the other 282 feet. A smaller glass structure framed in metal would curve along the circle and would connect the two buildings. Its roof would house a restaurant and other public spaces.
The visual focus of the design is the 750-foot tower, which has a triangular, sloping top and, while largely glass, is partly sheathed in stone toward the western side of the building.
Earlier in the consideration phase, neighborhood groups had complained that the transportation authority should have held an architectural competition.
The groups said the agency then should have chosen a design and given it to the developer that bid the highest for the site. Instead, the authority asked developers to submit plans that included designs, proposed uses and bids.
As a result, the critics say, the authority signaled more interest in financial considerations than in architectural values.
The authority did include architectural criteria in its request for bids, so many of the original proposals shared similar features.
All included at least one 750-foot tower, though the width, building material and style of the structures varied.
Some civic organizations and neighborhood groups said they disliked those proposals that included what they considered to be hulking towers, like the one designed by Robert A. M. Stern for the developer Donald J. Trump.
The transportation authority has not formally designated Millennium, and it appears that at least two development groups -- one a partnership of Bruce C. Ratner, Daniel Brodsky and Peter M. Lehrer, and the other a partnership of the Related Companies and Himmel & Company -- have a lesser chance of winning.
But both partnerships have refused to make the promise that Millennium did -- to pay for the site even if there is litigation.
Both partnerships' designs shared elements with the Millennium proposal.
The design by Cesar Pelli & Associates for the Ratner, Brodsky and Lehrer group calls for building two slim towers, one that would be 750 feet tall and another 540 feet tall, joined by a curved base that would include a Sears department store, a movie theater and an aquarium.
Skidmore, Owings & Merrill, architect for the Related Companies and Himmell & Company, proposed three towers, and instead of placing retail space on the ground floors, created an area for a 420,000-square-foot television studio.
Another proposal that is said to be in the running no longer -- Murphy/ Jahn's design for Tishman Speyer Properties -- called for two 750-foot towers, with a curved glass base similar to the Millennium design.
The news that the transportation authority has picked Millennium Partners angered the other two development teams still in the running, which protested to the authority yesterday that Millennium would not follow through with its promise to pay immediately despite litigation, state officials said.
Senior officials at the authority declined to comment, as did Christopher M. Jeffries, president of Millennium Partners.
The other two teams may now try to take their case to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who can veto the authority's choice or approve the deal.
At a news conference yesterday, he declined to say whether he would support the tentative selection of Millennium.
But he did stress that he wanted to insure that the project brought economic benefits to the neighborhood, particularly by linking the site to Lincoln Center, which is a few blocks to the northwest.
"What that means is," Mr. Giuliani said, "where do we have the best opportunity for economic development, which project aesthetically is going to be the most beautiful, and then of real importance, which project is going to allow us to tie it into the Lincoln Center community in a way that expands cultural capacity, artistic capacity, rather than having something that is aberrational."
Giuliani administration officials said that the administration liked the proposals from both Millennium and the Related Companies, though they had some problems with the one from Mr. Ratner and his partners because it included a Sears store, which the officials said might not be suitable for such a location.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Yankees Take Out Insurance in Incaviglia

BYLINE: By JACK CURRY 

 BODY:
Saying that the asking prices for power hitters have been too expensive, the Yankees went the economical route last night by signing Pete Incaviglia to a minor league contract. Incaviglia, a 33-year-old right-handed outfielder, will report to the Class AAA Columbus Clippers today in Rochester, and Manager Joe Torre said he could be promoted to the Yankees by next week.
He is not Jose Canseco or even Mike Stanley, two players the Yankees have talked about acquiring, but they believe Incaviglia might be a decent weapon against left-handed pitchers. And Incaviglia's imminent arrival could enable the Yankees to release Mark Whiten. 
 Incaviglia, who went directly from college to the majors and has never played in the minors, has a .247 career average and 206 homers in 10 seasons. He was batting .246 with 5 homers and 12 runs batted in when the Baltimore Orioles released him on Tuesday.
"We're going to give him some time to knock the rust off because he hasn't played for three weeks," General Manager Bob Watson said.
Watson emphasized that the acquisition would not prevent the Yankees from continuing to pursue a more formidable power hitter. But Incaviglia offers the Yankees insurance at a cheap price. Because the Yankees must pay him at only a prorated version of the $150,000 minimum salary, he will cost them only about $50,000. The Orioles are paying the bulk of his $650,000 salary.
"This is by no means the answer," Watson said, noting that certain players are now injured. "The answer may be lying within our own organization anyway. We've got Bernie Williams coming back. We've got Tim Raines coming back. We've got favorable reports on Darryl Strawberry, and we might see him by mid-August. All those guys don't cost anything."
With next Thursday's trade deadline looming, the chances of the Yankees obtaining a more bona fide slugger to replace the injured Cecil Fielder are dwindling. The candidates have shrunk to four or fewer because Kansas City's general manager, Herk Robinson, said yesterday that he would not deal Chili Davis.
So the Yankees opted for Incaviglia, who has played for the Rangers, Tigers, Astros, Phillies and Orioles and was Hideki Irabu's teammate with the Chiba Lotte Marines in 1995.
"We don't absolutely have to make a deal," Watson said. "We'd like to make one. We don't absolutely have to."

HEADLINE: Robust Profits Continue, and Smaller Companies Join In

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA

 BODY:
Three-fourths of the way through the second-quarter reporting season, corporate America is once again showing robust earnings.
And the winners are not just the big players. Even smaller companies are showing surprisingly strong earnings gains, creating the first signs of earnings parity since the first quarter of 1996. 
 While Wall Street analysts had been expecting a gain of about 8.9 percent from the companies that make up the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, operating profits are up about 11.5 percent from a year ago, according to I.B.E.S. International Inc. and First Call, two companies that monitor earnings reports.
Operating profits at smaller companies, such as those that constitute the Russell 2000 index, are doing even better, up about 17.5 percent from a year ago.
"This is the continuation of the powerful earnings drive that started with the first quarter of 1992," said Charles Hill, director of research at First Call in Boston. "It will be the 20th out of 22 quarters that we've seen double-digit gains in the S.& P. 500."
Such a long string of earnings gains has not been accomplished since the 1960's. But in recent weeks, anticipation of such dynamic profits has helped bolster an already buoyant stock market, one that has seen the S.& P. 500 soar 26.7 percent this year.
Indeed, of the 367 S.& P. 500 companies that have reported, 82 percent have matched or exceeded expectations, according to First Call, the same number that did so in the first quarter of the year. Since 1994, the average has been 72 percent.
Before the earnings reporting season began, however, there were some ominous signs. Warnings of profit slowdowns at companies like Intel and MCI Communications were compounded by jitters about rising wage pressures, the lack of pricing power at home and the strong dollar, which hampers sales abroad.
Those concerns caused many analysts to revise their estimates downward. But earnings have been impressive.
"A lot of the things you would be expecting at this point in the economic cycle, from pressure on margins to wage pressure, seem to be strangely absent," said Steven Leuthold, president of the Leuthold Group, a market research firm. "There's no sign yet of fading momentum. It's almost eerily good."
Among the best performers are consumer goods companies, like Kellogg, the cereal maker, with operating earnings up 62.2 percent, and the energy field, where operating earnings at Exxon, for example, rose 25.3 percent.
The technology sector has outperformed all others, with the average company up 34 percent from a year ago, according to I.B.E.S. Soaring earnings at Dell Computer, Lucent Technologies and Texas Instruments, among others, have helped push technology-laden indexes, like the Nasdaq composite, to record highs this summer.
And while the second-quarter S.& P. 500 gains are not as strong as those from the fourth quarter of 1996 (11.8 percent) or the first quarter of this year (15.1 percent), they have been solid, particularly because most of the profits were gained during a time when many thought the economy was moderating.
In the first quarter of this year, the nation's gross domestic product accelerated to an annual growth rate of 5.9 percent, creating fears of rising inflationary pressure. But many economists believe that second-quarter G.D.P. slowed to about 2 percent.
"The indications we have from company earnings suggest that business wasn't as bad as some of the G.D.P. estimates led us to believe," said Thomas McManus, an investment strategist at NatWest Securities. "More companies are doing well because they are continuing to focus on the cost line. And we're still seeing some portion of the earnings gain coming from the continuing adoption of technological innovation."
In other words, corporations are still finding ways to cut costs and increase productivity. Indeed, even blue-chip companies that reported only modest revenue gains in the second quarter found a way to show solid profit growth. Revenues at the Ford Motor Company were up about 3.3 percent, but operating income rose 43.4 percent from a year ago.
Still, there are those on Wall Street who expect earnings growth to continue to slow. For instance, Richard Bernstein, the director of quantitative research at Merrill Lynch, said that behind all the solid earnings this quarter were hints of moderation.
"If you look at the stories in the paper, you'd think we were at the beginning of a profit cycle," he said. "There are so many positive surprises. But even the positive surprises can't mask the fact that the profit cycle has resumed its deceleration."
Mr. Bernstein argues that corporations are managing their earnings better, often talking down analyst estimates. But companies that once saw a 20 or 30 percent gain are now seeing 10 or 15 percent. In the first quarter of 1995, for example, S.& P. 500 earnings rose 28 percent from a year earlier. This quarter, the gain is just over one-third of that.
Peter Jaquette, a senior economist at the WEFA Group, holds a similar view. "Profits, instead of growing 10 to 12 percent a year, are going to grow at 5 percent," he said. "This is much less than anyone is willing to mention publicly."
The reason, Mr. Jaquette said, is that corporate profits will not continue to grow at a faster pace than the economy partly because companies can no longer count on benefiting from declining interest rates, which make it less expensive to borrow money and pay off debts.
But Mr. Bernstein says a moderating economy has helped push down interest rates. And that interest rate decline has actually offset the slight slowdown in earnings. And strong earnings with low interest rates, or inflation, means that stocks are very attractive, at least for now.
"The positive impact of interest rates has offset the negative effect of slowing earnings," he said. "And remember, there are certain things that kill bull markets: one is inflation and the other is recession. And neither one is out there right now."

CORRECTION-DATE: July 29, 1997, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on Saturday about recent quarterly earnings reports included the second-quarter results of the Kellogg Company erroneously. Kellogg plans to report its results on Friday; the reference to a 62.2 percent gain applied to an estimate from analysts surveyed by First Call.

HEADLINE: Mr. Warren's Profession

BYLINE: By Alonzo L. Hamby; Alonzo L. Hamby teaches American history at Ohio University. His latest book is "Man of the People: A Biography of Harry S. Truman."

 BODY:

Chief Justice
 A Biography of Earl Warren.
 By Ed Cray.
 Illustrated. 603 pp. New York:
 Simon & Schuster. $30. 
 I MET Earl Warren years ago, and recall him as tall, genial and authoritative. Ed Cray's "Chief Justice" shows that he was not as tall as I thought (only 6 feet 1 inch), that his relaxed geniality masked an explosive personality and that, while his dedication to principle never varied, his principles were variable.
Warren was for much of his career a political type not uncommon in 20th-century America -- the dedicated prosecutor and tireless foe of crime, vice and corruption, standing for disinterested professionalism and positioning himself above partisanship. He would move out of prosecution to become a liberal governor and an ultraliberal chief justice, but the persona and the approach would remain much the same.
Born in 1891, Warren grew up in Bakersfield, Calif., the son of a Southern Pacific Railroad repairman. His Scandinavian parents passed on to him the values, if not the devout faith, of working-class Protestantism. Young Earl stayed out of trouble, worked part time after school, full time in the summers, saved his money and went off to the University of California, Berkeley, where he earned a law degree.
In 1925, after a number of public legal staff positions, Warren became District Attorney of Alameda County, where he combined dutiful Republican partisanship with an independent progressive appeal. A hard-line lawman, he rigorously enforced Prohibition and relentlessly pursued wrongdoing by prominent public officials.
Erratic at best on civil liberties, he would from time to time release grand jury transcripts to the press and authorize investigative wiretaps. He instituted surveillance on fringe groups of both the left and the right in the interest of protecting Americanism, and on two occasions he ordered the confiscation and burning of books that "allegedly defamed" William Randolph Hearst. He made few distinctions between labor thugs and the union leaders who could not be proved to have authorized their excesses. Temperamental, emotional and self-righteous, he presented an image of "biblical rectitude."
By 1938, Cray explains, Warren was the most visible local law enforcement official in the state, nationally known and patently ambitious. Having already led a successful drive to increase the power and authority of the state Attorney General, he won election to that office in 1938, taking advantage of the California cross-filing system to score victories in the Republican, Progressive and Democratic primaries.
As Attorney General, he took his crusade against criminality to the state level. He also clashed repeatedly with the liberal Democratic Governor, Culbert Olson, on a wide variety of matters, including judicial appointments that he deemed too libertarian. A vocal advocate of evacuating Japanese-Americans from the state after Pearl Harbor, he remarked that it was possible to evaluate the loyalty of an individual of "the Caucasian race," but "when we deal with the Japanese we are in an entirely different field." In 1942, he ran for governor and easily defeated Olson, whom he accused of softness toward the evacuees, criminals and Communists.
As the head of a largely Democratic state, Warren spent freely on education, highways and social services. His one major defeat was on a proposal for state health insurance. Benefiting from a nonpartisan image and a booming postwar economy, he took both the Democratic and the Republican primaries in his 1946 re-election bid, and in 1948 he was Thomas E. Dewey's Vice-Presidential running mate. (His political identity had become so ambiguous that President Harry Truman hailed him as virtually a Democrat in disguise.) In 1950, still widely popular in California, Warren rolled to a third term. Three years later, President Dwight D. Eisenhower appointed him Chief Justice of the United States.
By temperament an activist, Warren became a tribune of civil liberties and individual rights. He played a pivotal role in pulling the Supreme Court away from the judicial self-restraint that had been the reigning doctrine of liberals up till then. The Warren Court made racial desegregation the law of the land, mandated one-person-one-vote standards for most Federal and state elections, stretched the boundaries of free speech by redefining the laws of libel and obscenity, protected radicals and alleged subversives from harassment and prosecution, banned school prayer and restructured the criminal justice system in ways that worked to the advantage of the accused.
Cray, a professor of journalism at the University of Southern California, chronicles this judicial revolution admiringly, perhaps giving Warren a little too much credit for placing himself at the head of trends that were taking shape independently. What he does not do is question Warren's judicial activism. "The right thing, the fair thing determined the Chief's jurisprudence," he remarks. But earlier conservative judicial activists had struck down progressive-era and New Deal social legislation in the sincere belief that they were administering simple justice. Moreover, Warren himself, even at the zenith of his liberal phase, could be arbitrary, especially in obscenity cases.
Warren's most important intellectual antagonist, Felix Frankfurter, sensed that the courts risked their authority if they became the ultimate rulers in a democratic society, and he consistently argued that law had to be based on rules that transcended the good intentions of judges. Cray deals with Frankfurter, one of the century's pre-eminent legal thinkers, mainly as a conservative pedant, motivated by pettiness. Other critics of Warren -- including Hugo Black, Warren Burger and William Rehnquist -- fare no better.
The rest of the book is about as superficial. The author favors the three-sentence paragraph and the 12-page chapter. He relies much too heavily on oral history and personal interviews, often sources of faulty memory and hearsay. His writing is clear, but frequently careless. Every hundred pages or so, he reminds us that his subject had simple tastes, was a good husband and dutiful father, had a loyal staff and so on. But he gives us no explanation of a seething personality and a far-ranging ideological transformation.
Those readers in search of a competently told, undemanding, hagiographic story will like this book. Those who want a probing examination of a complex and important life will have to wait.

HEADLINE: The Two Faces of Mexico

BYLINE: By Sarah Kerr; Sarah Kerr writes frequently about Latin American culture and politics.

 BODY:

MEXICO
 Biography of Power: A History
 of Modern Mexico, 1810-1996.
 By Enrique Krauze.
 Translated by Hank Heifetz.
 Illustrated. 872 pp. New York:
 HarperCollins Publishers. $35. 
 Earlier this month, front pages across the United States ran photographs of Cuauhtemoc Cardenas Solorzano, the new Mayor-elect of Mexico City, abandoning his careworn opposition-leader demeanor for a giddy victor's smile. Mexico had just gone to the polls, with the spectacular result that come this December, for the first time in seven decades the country's ruling Institutional Revolutionary Party will be forced to share power. No word describes this kind of change better than "historic." Yet I suspect that few Americans will appreciate what these elections mean for Mexico's future, because few of us have even the shallowest acquaintance with its past.
Why is this so? The usual American arrogance is one obvious answer. "Mexico: Biography of Power," Enrique Krauze's history of the country since 1810, the year it began to fight for independence from Spain, suggests another. The thesis of Krauze's amazingly ambitious study is that Mexico carried into the modern era a dual Aztec-Spanish colonial legacy -- a premodern attitude toward authority that has made it, historically speaking, something of a parallel universe. "Combining two traditions of absolute power," Krauze explains, "one emanating from the gods and the other from God -- this political mestizaje conferred a unique connection with the sacred on Mexico's succession of rulers."
Mexican presidents have enjoyed a bizarre job perk: an intoxicating but temporary omnipotence that disappears as soon as their term is up. And this top-heavy power structure hasn't been entirely destructive. With a few cataclysmic exceptions, the country has been stable, immune to the Latin American plague of revolving-door military dictatorships. More often than not since independence, it has even been, on paper, an advanced constitutional democracy. But Krauze believes that until recently Mexico's politics were hobbled by a morbid fixation on the past. A parade of strongmen claimed, sometimes quite sincerely, to be carrying out the legacy of the Aztecs, or a liberal 19th-century hero, or a martyr from the revolution (1910-17). And instead of encouraging open debate, they turned Mexican politics into a kind of theater, a distracting re-enactment of old, half-true legends.
So an honest account would begin by examining the lives of these strongmen, and where necessary adjusting their reputations. Krauze deals with the basic Mexican canon of heroes and villains here. The material will be familiar to people who follow Mexico, so much so that to them this book will feel something like the newly restored print of a classic film. Certain scenes have been trimmed or slightly expanded, and the lighting has been touched up; the tinkering is subtle, but the overall effect is profoundly different from what one remembers.
Krauze takes on such sacrosanct figures as Miguel Hidalgo, whose 1810 cry of "Death to the Spaniards!" evoked the suffering of the Aztecs and roused thousands of Indians to battle; in Krauze's view this patriot priest was actually a quixotic hedonist who unthinkingly whipped up ethnic hatred. Benito Juarez, a 19th-century liberal president who is one of the most worshiped men in modern Mexican history, fares better. Yet here, too, Krauze wants to clear away the distorting fog of myth. He stresses Juarez's youthful approval of a horrifying dictator. He even suggests parallels between Juarez and a traditionally reviled president, Porfirio Diaz, a ruthless economic modernizer who rescinded freedom of the press and held on to power from 1876 to 1910. Diaz has often been seen as Juarez's evil opposite, but according to Krauze, both were stoic, inflexible men who tended to hoard power.
What other insights emerge? Beginning with the Aztec emperor Cuauhtemoc, a frightening percentage of Mexico's heroes have been murdered in the prime of life; this unbroken cycle of martyrdom has polluted the country's political rhetoric with an "esthetic of death." As for the good guys, on the rare occasions when they've reached power they've had no clue what to do.
This is especially true of the man who comes closest to being Krauze's hero, Francisco Madero. A gentle, introspective advocate of individual liberty, Madero rose to prominence in 1909 when he wrote a book urging Mexicans to dump Porfirio Diaz and demand real democracy. The book became a best seller, and Madero improbably found himself leading an insurrection. But he was a moralist, not a politician. He was obsessed with notions of duty and self-sacrifice that he'd encountered in the Bhagavad-Gita; for political strategy, he relied on Ouija-board consultations with the spirit of his dead brother Raul. Given the opportunity to steer Mexico through a peaceful reform, he wobbled and failed to assert himself. Little more than a year after Madero was elected president, a breakaway general (backed by a meddling, sinister American ambassador) had him whisked away by night and shot.
Following Madero's assassination, Mexico dissolved in a factious revolution. Krauze gives us the entertaining lowdown on a decade's worth of rebels, traitors, military masterminds and suffering saints. (There's a funny but disturbing anecdote about Pancho Villa, so charismatic that Hollywood talent scouts offered him food and uniforms in exchange for the privilege of filming battles; the action director Raoul Walsh, who was then an actor playing the role of Villa in the fictional footage, said Villa was asked to schedule big shootouts at sunup for optimal lighting.) But Krauze is really interested in the way Mexico's leaders rebuilt the country by making questionable use of themes from its past.
The 1920's witnessed a disastrous persecution of Roman Catholics, which was justified in the name of an arid 19th-century vision of secular enlightenment, but which Krauze also traces, fascinatingly, to President Plutarco Elias Calles's personal rage at being born illegitimate. The end of the 1920's saw the planting of seeds that eventually grew into the Institutional Revolutionary Party, that contradictory behemoth, with its dozens of interests competing for the favor of a paternalistic president. This party began as a logical compromise. But more and more power accrued to the president, who could surround himself with cronies and do just about anything he wanted, from breaking a strike to running up a huge national debt, all in the name of revolution.
This book displays a curious mix of influences. Krauze often writes for The New Republic and other American publications, and his quick and clear style, his journalistic delight in quirks of personality and his occasional bad habit of schematic punditry (all deftly captured here in Hank Heifetz's careful translation) will feel familiar to American readers. But he also belongs to a milieu that is less well known here: the contentious, delightful, frustrating world of Mexican letters. Allegiances and antipathies tend to be more strongly defined among Mexican intellectuals than they are in the United States. Krauze pays careful homage to his mentors. His volcanic sense of Mexican history as a series of eruptions of the past in the present draws on the historical meditations of Octavio Paz. And his attack on the pharaonic powers of the modern presidency borrows from a brilliant, cantankerous essayist named Gabriel Zaid, who has compared the PRI in its heyday to vast corporations like General Motors. (It's typical of Mexico's eccentric intellectual scene that Zaid is also a poet and a business consultant; for that matter, Krauze trained as an industrial engineer.)
I POINT out this background because Krauze has buried some polemics in his study. He justly praises a right-wing party founded in 1939, the largely Catholic National Action Party -- not for its rigidly moralistic policy positions, but for its long, persevering commitment to democracy. As for the PRI's decline, he dates the beginning of the end to the truly evil moment in 1968 when President Gustavo Diaz Ordaz ordered troops to storm a peaceful demonstration in downtown Mexico City, and hundreds of students were murdered. Krauze was a student then; he recalls this thwarted movement with deep feeling. And like a man comparing each new woman he meets with an idealized first love, he criticizes much of the post-1968 Mexican left. He takes a swipe at Carlos Fuentes for an early friendship with Castro. He faults left-leaning Mexican intellectuals for clinging to a defensive, knee-jerk suspicion of the United States. He believes that Subcommander Marcos, the charismatic, articulate guerrilla leader who claims to speak for the dispossessed Indians of Chiapas, represents more of the same old Mexican histrionics.
Some of these criticisms are fair. But one wishes that Krauze would be less circuitous, even sneaky, about these polemics. In places, his opinions seem to be conveyed in a kind of petty code; with people he dislikes, like Marcos, he has mastered the American journalist's art of sounding perfectly evenhanded while damning his adversary with scant and selective quotation. His repeated insistence that Indians in Mexico face no significant racial discrimination seems exaggerated. So, too, does his emphasis on the events of 1968. The tragedies of that year did provoke the first real mass disillusionment with the PRI, yet it has taken three decades for the party fortress to show signs of crumbling. In the interim, Mexico has suffered crisis after crisis, from debt overload to assassinations to the yet-to-be-clarified sins of President Carlos Salinas de Gortari. Compared with his nuanced grasp of Mexican history, Krauze's treatment of these spectacular recent events feels perfunctory.
On the other hand, one wants to give Krauze the benefit of the doubt. Over and over again, he asserts his desire for Mexico to open itself up to debate. From the looks of this month's elections (not to mention a newly vital Mexican press that gets livelier by the day), such openness now seems inevitable, and there's every reason to believe that when the moment comes, Krauze will enter the fray with glee, freed from his need to even old scores.
Meanwhile, this shrewd and in many ways brave book is necessary reading. With luck it will help Americans appreciate that Mexico is more than an abstract policy dilemma -- a tag-along trade partner or a border to be patrolled. Mexico has a history, and it turns out to be just as rich and as puzzling and as freighted with utopian aspirations as our own.

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT;
Cheap Las Vegas Rooms Are Harder to Find

BYLINE: By MIKE RICHARD 

 BODY:
PILOTS preparing for takeoff at McCarran International Airport in Las Vegas have been known to use this joke in their greeting to passengers: "Ladies and gentlemen, we will be circling back over the Strip on our way out of town today, so feel free to look down and wave goodbye to your money."
Gamblers used to be able to withstand modest losses, mostly because hotel and food rates were so affordable. The $4.99 buffets, 99-cent one-pound hot dogs and 75-cent shrimp cocktails are still easy to swallow in Las Vegas. But visitors who enjoy the nickel-quarter slot machines and the $3- to $5-minimum table games -- not the high rollers who have their suites discounted or provided free -- are finding that bedding down in the city of neon is becoming a more expensive proposition. 
 A check in late June at some of the better-known hotels on Las Vegas Boulevard, known as the Strip, showed an increase in the cost of the most economical standard midweek accommodations.
When the Mirage opened in November 1989, rooms could be had for $49 to $59 a night when checking in on Sunday through Thursday. As the hotel -- with its exploding volcano, art collection in the lobby, manicured tropical pool area, dolphin habitat and white tigers on display (part of the Siegfried & Roy magic show) -- garnered high ratings in national travel guides, its rates rose. A midweek stay at the 3,000-plus-room resort this month could cost $99 a night, while for late October, the price quoted by a reservation clerk was $149. "Rates can fluctuate dramatically here," said Alan Feldman, a Mirage spokesman, talking about Las Vegas in general. "It's demand. That's the easiest way to explain it."
Other Strip hotels have also raised their rates. At the Monte Carlo, a hotel toward the southern end of the Strip that opened in June 1996 and advertises its "European style, Las Vegas wild" mix of accents, the same room that cost $59 during an October 1996 midweek visit costs $89 in October 1997.
While Las Vegas travelers are accustomed to paying more for a hotel on Friday and Saturday night, when the city is jammed with people from nearby Arizona and Southern California, the surge in midweek rates is something of a jolt.
Mr. Feldman said capacity, conventions and holidays can be contributing factors in a hotel's pricing structure, adding that Las Vegas is different from other major American tourist destinations because gaming revenue is part of the economic formula.
"In May of this year," he said, talking about a shopping-center convention that took place at the Mirage, "rates changed from $139 to $89 to $59 to $199 -- all in one week."
The conventioneers, with their group advance booking, got first crack at the lower rates, and as the occupancy numbers for that week went up and down at the frequently sold-out Mirage, prices for other guests were determined. One reservation clerk likened pricing formulas for Las Vegas hotels to the airlines' economic rules -- that is, the rates tend to drop if capacity is gauged to be weak.
Because of the price fluctuation, it often comes down to when a Las Vegas trip planner calls a hotel. For example, at Treasure Island, the Mirage's sister hotel known for its pirate-ship motif, a call in early May found the best price for an October midweek stay to be $89. A call in late June requesting the same accommodations on the same dates got a rate quote of $49.
Myram Borders, news bureau chief for the Las Vegas Convention and Visitors Authority, cited figures from a survey completed by her agency in January that showed a slight rate increase for accommodations from 1995 to 1996. She said the survey took into account all of the city's 101,100 hotel and motel rooms, including establishments without casinos.
"Our statistics show the average nightly room rate was $58 for 1996, compared to $54 for 1995," she said.
Finding rooms for under $60 a night may now be a long shot at the posh hotels along the Strip, but in downtown Las Vegas, about two miles north, hotel prices have remained constant and, for the most part, inexpensive. The Four Queens ($59) and the Lady Luck ($43), two glitzy lodging staples downtown, offered economical prices for the late-October midweek stay. This Casino Center section has recently been spruced up to compete with new attractions on the Strip.
Hotel managers and tourism officials said that while the city's hotels might be slightly more expensive than in the past, Las Vegas -- with its burgeoning family-friendly attractions, indoor and outdoor entertainment, hot-but-dry weather and affordable dining -- is still a bargain compared with other popular United States cities such as San Francisco, New York and Orlando, Fla.
Mr. Feldman, who estimated that 30 million tourists visited Las Vegas last year, offered this advice: "Shop around and be flexible. If you can be flexible, you can save lots of money. You have to arrive on certain days and on certain weeks. Conventions in town play a big role in prices."

HEADLINE: DANCE VIEW;
Why They Don't Dance Much in American Films

BYLINE: By Jennifer Dunning 

 BODY:
A ROW OF TROUSERED LEGS stretches across the screen. Waiting patiently, they move very little except to shuffle a step or two forward on the unemployment line. Suddenly the droning Muzak shifts to a disco beat. One leg kicks out a little and then another, almost unconsciously. The camera pans across the men to catch one, paunchy and no longer young, slipping into a modest but confidently executed turn. Dance, it seems, can spill into the dimmest corners of everyday life.
That moment is from "The Full Monty," one of three new films in which dance transforms a variety of humdrum or difficult lives. The movie, which opens in New York on Aug. 15, tells the story of a group of laid-off steelworkers in northern England who form a Chippendale-style kick-and-strip line. In "Alive and Kicking," which opened Friday, a young modern dancer with AIDS is kept alive by his will to move. And in the recent "Shall We Dance?," a middle-aged Japanese businessman with a graying soul falls in love with a beautiful but remote young ballroom dancing teacher and is drawn inexorably into an exotic world that is forbidden territory in circumspect Japan. 
 It is unsurprising that none of the films was made in the United States. Dance has played a part in American films only fitfully since the last great movie musicals in the 1950's. Dance seldom even figures as subject matter despite its potential for the kind of visual excitement that film alone can capture. And the movie dance numbers that once expressed emotions too joyous to be put into words have now gone the way of plots about the kind of uncomplicated romance that prompted most of that joy.
"So many of today's films stress the terrors that await us," Michael Kidd, the winner of a special Academy Award for career achievement this year, said in his acceptance speech. "Perhaps this award signifies an awareness that we have been missing something, namely the vitality and joy in living that movie musicals can express in song and dance."
There are no traditional dance numbers in "The Full Monty," "Alive and Kicking" or "Shall We Dance?," and certainly none of the films is remotely related to the American movie musical. But the art form that is regularly enlisted to sell everything from the songs at the heart of music videos to the nacho chips gobbled down by the chubby little strutter in television ads for Doritos, is used similarly in these three films to express and evoke powerful, liberating emotions.
" 'Shall We Dance?' epitomizes a society of repressed emotion, and I think that to a large degree exists in our society too," said Mr. Kidd, a choreographer and director of Broadway and film musicals that include "The Band Wagon" and "Seven Brides for Seven Brothers." "Ordinarily we don't release our emotions easily. That's why we can empathize with the dance, with that exuberance."
The lives depicted in "Shall We Dance?," "The Full Monty" and "Alive and Kicking" are specific and probably, for most viewers, somewhat foreign. But there is a vicarious pleasure to seeing Mr. Sugiyama, the quiet dignified hero of "Shall We Dance?," move from ramrod stiffness and pathetic hesitancy to the point where he can sweep across a ballroom with the young teacher Mai. The wildly exuberant antics of a rock-and-roll dancer at the school, revealed eventually as his nervous fellow employee Mr. Aoki in disguise, are similarly exciting.
The men in "The Full Monty" are seen rehearsing and performing for only a few brief moments, but there is a tonic familiarity to their endearingly comic struggles to overcome their embarrassment about looks and grizzled age, their uncomfortableness about female-seeming preening, and their fear of letting go in a world that has already made sport of them. And who, facing debility or simple exhaustion, has not had the experience of finding within oneself some unsuspected brute energy for survival, as Tonio does in the British film "Alive and Kicking"?
Dance is a sensual, demanding mistress. The mates of several of these unlikely dancers become jealous. "Alive and Kicking" may paint an unlikely picture of a modern dance company but there is nothing unbelievable about the explosion of rage by Tonio's lover, Jack, a hard-drinking psychotherapist desperately fighting to continue his work with AIDS patients as funds dwindle, as Tonio talks endlessly of rehearsals for a forthcoming production.
Mr. Sugiyama's pretty young wife is convinced that her husband, suddenly absent from home for his secret ballroom lessons, is cheating on her with another woman. In "The Full Monty," David's humiliation at his failure to find a job has made him impotent. His frustration turns to mute horror when his working wife lashes out at him after finding his stripper's bikini and assuming he has been having sex with some other woman.
None of these men are the sort of characters that movie musicals featured. True, as Mr. Kidd points out, the earliest musical scripts were built around the "Cinderella" plot. "If you go back to the original, what could be bleaker?" Mr. Kidd asks, referring to the innumerable wide-eyed chorines who were the heroines of those musicals. "Go out a chorus girl, come back a star. Somehow they marry a prince, though in different guises." But Fred Astaire and Gene Kelly followed.
"Astaire wasn't a real person," Mr. Kidd says. "He was strictly a musical comedy creation. You never thought of him as the guy filling your tank at your local gas station. Which Gene Kelly was, and that contributed to the tremendous popularity of musicals. The big, enormous contribution that Gene Kelly made was making the hero a 'regular joe.' "
Mr. Sugiyama, Tonio and even Gaz, the scrappy little instigator of the "Full Monty" line, live in a much darker world than the often humdrum but basically optimistic one inhabited by Kelly's men. In his films, dance was frequently a reflection of the inherent joy of life as much as its expression. Here, dance movement is one of the very few ways that joy can be realized and find an outlet.
Today, Mr. Kidd suggests, film choreography is largely a matter of the plotting of moves in action films. "It is the same meticulous choreographic planning we used to apply to musical numbers," he says. The stylized world of the movie musical has been supplanted by that of the action film. And movie musicals, an expensive genre to start, are not likely to be made again until a musical makes more money than the disappointing box-office returns for films like "Evita" and "A Chorus Line."
But love, hope and liberating joy can still push up through the sere ground of 1990's lives. One moment in "The Full Monty" communicates that best, when Gaz persuades David to return to rehearsals. It is hard and time-consuming work at first. David has found a job, which, though meager and dispiriting, is still a job. But at last he pulls away, dashing through the door of the chill, huge superstore in which he is working as a security guard.
Out he races into the parking lot, tearing after the speeding Gaz in one wild burst of running jumps. He will dance with his friends, a petty functionary turned star for a few mad minutes. There will be no work to return to. But after this, one surmises, there may even be a prince of a job on a suddenly expansive horizon.
