HEADLINE: The View From: Elizabeth Park;
A Many-Hued Offset to the Concrete Acres of Hartford

BYLINE: By PEGGY McCARTHY 

 BODY:
THE sweat slid off Hugh Greer's face under an oppressive summer sun, but the 70-year-old man continued to bend over and pull weeds from the Medallion rose beds. Mr. Greer is a volunteer who works in Elizabeth Park in Hartford most weekdays because, he says, he wants future generations to enjoy the park he "kind of grew up in."
Elizabeth Park, 100 years old this year and on the National Register of Historic Places, is a haven where memories are made and life's milestones are recorded in photos and videotapes. In June and July, about 18 wedding parties each weekend pose for photographs there, said Donna J. Fuss, the park rosarian. 
 The park is said to have the oldest municipal rose garden in the country. In 1912, the All America Rose Selection tested roses there. And in 1990 the garden, with its arches, gazebo, and rose beds, was named the most outstanding of the 130 designated All America Rose Selection gardens in the country. There are 15,000 rose bushes in Elizabeth Park, along with perennials, annuals and rock and tulip gardens. It is listed in the Garden Archives of the Smithsonian Institution.
Since Hartford is a city where resources are stretched to meet needs like education and human services, the city relies on a group called Friends of Elizabeth Park to raise money, recruit volunteers and coordinate refurbishing projects. The city employs seven people who do everything from cleaning bathrooms to mowing the lawn's bowling greens, Ms. Fuss said.
"We all call it the jewel of the city," said Ms. Fuss, whose job is to consult on the care and purchase of roses, and to conduct tours and workshops.
The 102-acre park, with its formal gardens, greenhouses, pond and shade trees, is an escape from the concrete and traffic noise of the city. It is also a tourist attraction.
The park's history is as colorful as its roses and its existence has sometimes been fragile. Charles N. Pond, a New Haven Railroad tycoon, state treasurer and banker, willed the land to the city after prodding from the Rev. Francis Goodwin, then a Hartford park commissioner.
Mr. Pond is described as an alcoholic who often disturbed his neighbors by using his living room fireplace and backyard as a shooting gallery. He had planned that after his death his home would be turned into a refuge for alcoholics. But Mr. Goodwin, it is said, persuaded him to make a bequest of a garden park in memory of his wife, Elizabeth. Their home was torn down, but a building now being renovated for a restaurant is called the Pond House.
Over the years people used the park to picnic, sled, play sports and generally escape life's stresses.
In the 1970's, however, the city faced serious financial troubles and the rose gardens deteriorated, prompting city leaders to plan to pave them over. The gardens were saved by the establishment in 1977 of the Friends of Elizabeth Park. The organization provides trees, roses, bulbs, seeds, shrubs, supplies and equipment, and has undertaken major projects including the renovation of the Pond House. It is now planning a renovation of the park's three greenhouses.
In 1987 the group hired Ms. Fuss to be its rosarian.
On a recent afternoon, about 30 people joined a tour led by Ms. Fuss, who always wears dresses and skirts with rose designs on them, as well as earrings shaped like roses. Questions came from both knowledgeable and fledgling gardeners, stops were frequent to admire the scents and the hues -- pinks, purples, yellows and whites. Tourists with cameras wandered in search of the perfect layout.
Residents of nursing homes and the American School for the Deaf are among regular visitors to the park, as are workers taking lunch breaks and families grilling picnic dinners and tossing Frisbees.
"They come to shed the stresses of life," said the park's foreman, Paul Condon.
Maryanne Gryboski, a massage therapist from Easton, spends lunch hours in the park on the three days a week she works in Hartford. She said she enjoys the perennials, and she always checks the bed of Buckroses her family donated three years ago in memory of her parents, Albert and Mary Gryboski, who lived in New Britain and often visited the park.
Mr. Condon called the park an "urban arboretum," saying it is "all a garden to me." And he listed amenities other than flowers and trees: Nine tennis courts, one regulation Little League field, two softball fields, a picnic grove with grills and two lawn bowling greens. (The father of the volunteer, Mr. Greer, was president of the park's Lawn Bowling Association in 1924.)
The tennis courts are used yearround with participants pitching in to sweep the courts after rain. Only snow keeps the diehard players away, said Robert Petrunti, of West Hartford, one of the retirees who is a regular there. The players are retirees, teen-agers, people who are unemployed, and those who play after they get out out of work. Florence H. Filhoff, of West Hartford, said she has been playing there at least five days a week for 25 years. "This is absolutely a melting pot," she said.
Everyone who stops by the park seems to have memories connected to it, said Ms. Fuss. Her own go back to when she was pushed in a stroller by her parents. She fed ducks and learned to ice skate there, she said. As a teen-ager, she and her future husband went to concerts in the park.
Mr. Condon, who said the park was a popular sledding spot for him and his boyhood friends, said the first thing that ever attacked him was a goose from the park's pond. Mary Turner moved to Hartford seven years ago and quickly became a volunteer, working
"In the city, there is so much concrete. This is such a beautiful place to come. I want to keep it going, pass it on," Mrs. Turner said.

HEADLINE: DINING OUT;
In Italian Tradition, Classics Revitalized

BYLINE: By JOANNE STARKEY 

 BODY:
LA VIGNA has come full circle. This Greenvale veteran was part of a wave of northern Italian restaurants that swept across the North Shore more than 20 years ago. They were elegant and expensive and served the Italian-French food blend called Continental.
As times and tastes changed, so did La Vigna. Around 1990, it introduced an all-Italian menu that featured grilled and lighter fare. A year later it moved to family dining, that inflation fighter with lower prices and large platter- filling portions. 
 Today, La Vigna is much as it was 20 years ago: a traditional spot serving classic food. Spinach salad is still tossed at tableside by the captain and that old standard, roast duckling in orange sauce, is on the menu.
But La Vigna is not a tired leftover. Much of the food (especially the pastas) is exciting and the dining room has been revitalized.
Gone are the elaborate chandeliers and the formal look of yesterday, replaced by fabric-draped, modern lighting and rustic touches like brick trim, stucco ceiling and decorative strings of garlic and red peppers. Yet, the dining room is still elegant. The tables are well-spaced, the seating plush and comfortable, the noise-level conducive to conversation.
There have been changes in the kitchen as well. Last year, Gary Lanza, a Culinary Institute of America graduate who has worked at Le Bernardin in Manhattan, took over the restaurant from his father. He, along with the new executive chef, Paco Ortez, make all the restaurant's desserts, bread, pastas, sauces and mozzarella. They even cure their own prosciutto.
The made-daily, chewy rolls are noteworthy but it is the pastas that steal the show. Homemade saffron spaghetti, tossed with shrimp, asparagus, tomatoes, olive oil and lots of garlic, is a memory maker. So, too, is another unusual dish: flower-shaped pasta in a black, aged, finely minced, wild mushroom sauce. Very light gnocchi in a filet mignon sauce ignited by peppercorns keeps the winning streak going.
But other menu offerings are less consistent. A chopped salad, one evening, had no taste. Much better were the warm spinach salad (created with fanfare) and the classic Caesar. Best was the sprightly Sicilian salad that featured paper-thin slices of fennel tossed with arugula and fresh orange segments.
An impressive plate of grilled vegetables and a spirited seafood salad led the appetizers. But clams in olive oil, garlic and white wine were chewy and the broth forgetable. A special of portobello mushrooms and artichoke hearts, described as bathed in olive oil, garlic and rosemary, arrived in a dark-brown, heavy gravy. This is quite a shock for diners expecting a light vegetable opener.
A few of the entrees were marred by lack of seasoning. Two specials -- chicken breasts in Champagne sauce with asparagus and sole crowned with shrimp -- both needed a hefty addition of salt to bring them to life. Much better were tasty veal rolls filled with spinach and cheese in a rich wine sauce and moist swordfish with an olive oil, garlic and herb topping.
The prime pick from the menu is the velvety filet mignon in a creamy, brandy sauce dotted with green peppercorns. Also passing muster are the tender scaloppine piccata and chicken cutlets under a blanket of chopped salad.
Service varies. On a quiet weeknight, there were few slip-ups. But on Saturday, wine arrived without glasses, the bread basket was replaced sans additional butter and dishes were delivered auction style.
Gratis bruschetta, pizza pinwheels and an intermezzo of tangy lemon sorbet make an appearance on weeknights. On Saturday, the serving of bruschetta was hit and miss. Some tables received it; others did not.
The homemade desserts here are better than the usual Italian sweets. Best are the creamy tiramisu, the light Napoleon and the raspberry tart. The cassata cake was different on two tries: light with an airy chocolate mousse filling one time, heavy with the addition of cannoli cream another.
Although La Vigna's largely Italian and American wine list of more than 50 choices contains four or five selections that cost under $20, the average bottle is on the pricey side. (More are over $30 than under it.) A soft, jammy 1994 Caboche Chateauneuf du Pape ($31) is a medium-bodied red suitable for drinking now, while a $19 Mill Creek sauvignon blanc 1993 is a solid, subtle alternative to California chardonnays.
 
La Vigna
Good

HEADLINE: Proposing New Goals for Workfare

BYLINE: By JOHN RANDAZZO 

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS

 BODY:
TEAMS of Westchester County welfare reformers and their New York City counterparts met here recentlyto consider new goals for workfare programs, which have saved both areas more than $100 million, Mary E. Glass, the county's Commissioner of Social Services, said.
On the table for discussion are topics ranging from obtaining minimum wages for people in the workfare programs to teaching them more marketable skills like car repair, plumbing and electrical work. The county started the workfare program in 1989. It requires able-bodied home-relief recipients to spend 20 hours a week in workfare, or as it is known, Pride in Work public improvement projects, to retain their subsistence eligibility. 
 Under state law, home-relief enrollees can be ordered to help county, city, town and nonprofit organizations perform clerical, maintenance, security, painting, repair and debris removal jobs, among others. About 750 people are signed into the current workfare program.
The home-relief case load, Ms. Glass said, is "currently at its lowest in 10 years and the lower the better." Meetings with the social services staff of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani of New York City would make it even better, she said.
Mayor Giuliani, along with Gov. George E. Pataki, put workfare formulas into effect about three years ago. Both have said that it saves a lot of money..
County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke started the county's operation in 1989 as an important approach to reforming welfare. He has called it an "unqualified success."
A 48-member investigative staff of the Department of the Social Services helps. A budget of more than $2 million for workfare combats fraud by weeding out ineligible applicants, no-shows, deadbeats who hold off-the-book jobs, enrollees who ignore interview appointments and absentees without satisfactory explanations.
A report from Commissioner Glass's office shows that 21,773 were removed from the rolls beginning in 1989 with 60 percent of them not returning. It vexes officials because they do not know why they do not get back on welfare. Almost 10,000 home-relief recipients have been involved in nine years of public improvement.
The report indicates that total work hours provided to municipalities and nonprofit agencies have plunged. In 1994, 511,350 hours were logged; last year, the total sagged to 440,870 hours and will be even lower this year.
In 1989 approximately 116,000 hours of work by home-relief recipients were approved for the communities.
The social services budget of $413.5 million for 1997 allots $339 millionfor all relief, including Aid to Dependent Children, Medicaid and food stamps, with 32.7 million of it allocated for home relief. Those in favor of workfare programs cite improved municipal buildings, garages, graffiti removal, roadway improvements and help to nonprofit groups in White Plains, Yonkers, Mount Vernon, New Rochelle and 17 towns and cities.
Mr. O'Rourke in a previous interview has said: "County and local agencies ask for help because neither has the time nor the funding to undertake expensive projects like these. The able-bodied gain work experience and self-respect and improved work habits and work ethic."
At the same time, he said, people unable to work because of drug or alcohol abuse, psychiatric and other ills are scheduled for treatment. The permanently unemployable are given disability reviews for continued subsistence payments, Mr. O'Rourke added.
Even as Mr. Giuliani and Mr. Pataki were expanding workfare operations, Westchester's declining home-relief case load puzzles Dennis Packard, Deputy Commissioner of Social Services.
"People just drop in and out of the subsistence" safety net, Mr. Packard said. "There must be a hidden economy out there because we don't know where they go." Public assistance payments average about $400 a month per person, he said.
A combination of factors is driving down welfare rolls, experts say. These include an exceptionally healthy economy's job market; double-dippers on the run and a perception that welfare handouts get no respect while paying jobs do.
Workfare meetings under way here are a continuation of a strategy to sharpen workfare. Commissioner Glass has visited New York City frequently to see how its program works.
Workfare has had its detractors. Union leaders have charged that jobs will be taken from union members, a fear that has failed to materialize. Some say, Demand minimum pay for workfare people, and the Clinton Administration recently said that workfare people should get minimum pay.
Other groups condemn the program because they say it teaches few marketable skills.
Commissioner Glass said study programs at Westchester Community College that teach jobs like auto repair, carpentry, plumbing and such did not work out, explaining that a transient population is difficult to invest in for marketable skills. Of the 16 people who underwent training for the jobs at the college, only one, a woman completed it.
Many people train themselves. Herbert Thomas Payne, 33, who said he is a recovering drug addict, lives with 61 other homeless men at the nonprofit Westhab Employment Residence on Tarrytown Road here.
In January Mr. Payne joined workfare. "I give my 20 hours a week," he said, "then I go to school weekends to learn plumbing and electrical work."
Orlando Davy of Mount Vernon, who lost his job at a Wall Street brokerage house, linked up with workfare, which led to a Civil Service examination for a receptionist with the Social Services Department.
He got the job and now earns $24,500 a year. Mr. Davy seeks broader horizons now and would like a job as an eligibility examiner, at $33,815 a year. "I'd like to advance within the department," Mr. Davy said.

HEADLINE: JERSEY;
Long Hours. Low Pay. Must Like Travel.

BYLINE: By JOE SHARKEY 

 BODY:
DOWN near the tip of the Jersey shore, a young woman more accustomed to the dappled greens and pastel blues of summer at home in rural Ireland blinked into the blistering lights of the Wildwood boardwalk and tried to describe her initial impressions of America.
Those impressions thus far had consisted of Kennedy International Airport and a van ride on the Jersey Turnpike and Garden State Parkway that ended at a blazing spectacle of amusement piers hoisted on pilings over a beach that takes a quarter-mile to get to the ocean. So it was a little like asking Dorothy what she thought of Oz shortly after the house dropped and the screen went to Technicolor. Wonder and awe are reasonable responses. But a smart girl from the country also spots the pasteboard beneath the glitter and watches for unpleasant surprises down the road. 
 "It's actually unlike anything I've ever seen," Mary McCormack, 20 years old, said with amiable diplomacy from behind the counter of an ice-cream and soda stand on Morey's Pier. Behind her rose the backlit herring-boned hulk of a monster new wooden roller coaster, radiating shrieks as its cars plunged down the 100-foot drop.
This summer, Miss McCormack and three girlfriends from college in Ireland came to the United States to take summer jobs in Wildwood, where the Morey Organization, which operates the three amusement piers and other boardwalk attractions, has been hiring Irish and British kids for many years to supplement its local summer work force.
What was the most remarkable initial impression?
"Well, the way Americans eat," she said, laughing after a moment's hesitation. "Every waking hour, they're eating something else." As if on cue, a fat man in droopy shorts waddled into sight stacking French fries into his mouth, one after another, from a cardboard bucket big enough to haul coal. A woman approached the counter nibbling daintily at the apex of a pizza slice. Some kids thumped by slurping ice cream.
Her second notable impression reflects the global pandemic of American television. One night shortly after settling into a Wildwood boarding house, the Irish women heard a loud argument on the street outside. Figuring a shootout would follow, "we all four got into one bed and slept with a kitchen knife under the sheet," she said.
Miss McCormack and her friends are among several thousand foreign college students recruited for summer jobs by American amusement parks, hotels and restaurants under student-exchange programs that allow them to work here from June through mid-October. In Wildwood, which is one of the leading American employers of foreign students for summer jobs, Irish and British young men and woman have traditionally predominated. But that is changing as more summer jobs open up in the voracious American leisure industry and more foreign students learn about the demand.
"These days, with so many American companies competing with us, we're getting kids from Latvia, Belarus -- places that send me to the atlas. Last year, we had a third-year Hungarian medical student working for us -- for $5.05 an hour," said Trina McSorley, the human resources director for Morey, which has 450 foreign students among its summer work force of 1,500.
Boardwalk employers in Seaside Heights, Point Pleasant, Atlantic City and Ocean City also hire foreign students. There are several reasons for the need to go abroad: Unemployment is low. And most Jersey seashore areas are surrounded by older, affluent populations with few teen-agers -- or, as in the case of Wildwood, are far from any population center.
Many foreign college students jump at the chance to come to America and work long hours at what Jack Morey, vice president of the family-run amusement business, frankly describes as "basically low-paid jobs at the beach." Part of the allure is that after the summer season ends, the students still have a month to travel in the United States.
This year, as the Fourth of July weekend approached, the Morey company was still about 100 workers short. So, like a modern incarnation of the employment agents who worked the East River piers in the 19th century, trolling for immigrant laborers to stoke the furnaces of the Industrial Revolution, Mrs. McSorley traveled to Kennedy airport in New York. Competing with agents from other major American amusement parks, and several casinos, she met flights from Europe, touting students on a summer in Wildwood. Finally, she filled her quota.
"It's become pretty competitive," she said. "I used to be pretty open about sharing information about where we get our students. Not anymore."

HEADLINE: Torrington Twisters Get Warm Embrace

BYLINE: By DON HARRISON 

 BODY:
THE man who collects the tickets at the ballpark in Torrington is older than it is, which speaks volumes about the durability of Joseph (Lefty) Silano.
The park was donated to the city in 1918 by Frederick Fuessenich in memory of his wife, Elizabeth Blake Fuessenich. Silano had arrived on this planet on Dec. 2, 1914. 
 His passion for baseball, which he played with considerable skill in distant yesterdays at Fuessenich and elsewhere, remains unabated. He was an outfielder capable of hitting .400 in the old semi-pro Connecticut State League and, much later, an umpire for 25 summers. In the early 1950's Silano played in an exhibition game at Fuessenich against a major league all-star team that included Phil Rizzuto, Mickey Vernon and Johnny Pesky.
On a recent warm afternoon, the old outfielder and umpire was collecting the usual $2 donations from a cluster of fans. He smiled or nodded as they walked toward seats in the grandstand built into the side of what was once known as Bishops Hill. Inside, the visiting Middletown Giants were preparing for their New England Collegiate Baseball League game against the Torrington Twisters.
"This is good collegiate ball; some of these kids will get signed up for the minor leagues," Silano said. "It's really shook up the town."
Silano is vice president of the Twisters and the eldest member of the 20-person board of directors. The group, with support from Mayor Mary Jane Gryniuk and other civic leaders, made the franchise a reality within the space of three months last winter.
Torrington is the newest member of the N.E.C.B.L., a four-year-old, six-team summer league sanctioned by the N.C.A.A. and Major League Baseball. The city, in the northwest corner of the state, has embraced the Twisters with open arms and open wallets.
The Rotary Club purchased uniforms; the daily newspaper, The Register-Citizen, donated warmup jackets. A radio station, WAPJ-FM, is broadcasting most games, home and away. During the Memorial Day parade, the Twisters were a uniformed presence aboard a float.
Like its more-established counterpart, the Cape Cod League, N.E.C.B.L. has rosters filled with players drawn from colleges across the country, nearly all of whom see themselves as "pro prospects," and many of them actually are. Eleven members of the Twisters, for example, were selected in the Major League draft, either in high school or college.
Prospects may be found, perhaps in less abundance, on the league's other teams: Middletown Giants, Danbury Westerners and Eastern Tides of Willimantic in Connecticut, the Rhode Island Reds and the Central Massachusetts Collegians.
On a typical game day, three or four professional scouts -- equipped with speed guns and cynical looks -- are apt to be found at Fuessenich. They're there to study athletes playing under actual professional conditions: using wooden bats. Professional teams have become reluctant to assess talent strictly on the basis of intercollegiate or high school competition, where aluminum bats are the staple.
"They were drafting guys who couldn't hit a lick with a wooden bat," said Gregg Hunt, a business teacher at the Gilbert School in Winsted and the Twisters head coach. "With wood, you have to know where the bat head is all the time and you've got to hit a lot more with your head."
Hunt considers himself fortunate to have a lineup of players who realize the importance of bat location: Justin Sherrod, a shortstop with six home runs and a .318 batting average; Dave Benham, the catcher from Texas whose six home runs have helped generate 26 runs batted in, and Jim Deschaine, a 19-year-old native of Bristol, batting .420 as the regular second baseman. Torrington leads the league with a 20-11 record.
The Twisters are also first in attendance, averaging nearly 800 people per game at refurbished Fuessenich Park. The opening game, on May 31 against Danbury, attracted a crowd of 3,320.
"Traffic was backed up for two miles in the third inning," recalled Kirk Fredriksson, the Twisters' 32-year-old general manager.
Fredriksson, a former semi-pro player who earns his livelihood as general manager of the Sherman I.G.A. supermarket, is responsible for the team's day-to-day operations. In April he helped organize a fund-raising event, a $20-a-plate celebrity breakfast that attracted 250 people and featured Fay Vincent Jr., the former Major League Baseball commissioner, as speaker.
On the baseball side, Fredriksson did his recruiting homework, even going to Florida during the spring to sign Sherrod and two other players from Rollins College.
He didn't have to look far to find Ben Power, an outfielder-first baseman, and Scott Barnsby, a pitcher. Both are Torrington residents and Power is the son of the team president. By conservative estimate, Fredriksson devoted an average of 30 to 40 hours a week to the Twisters during the formative months and perhaps 20 to 30 hours a week now. "I'm a volunteer general manager and I love it," he said. "I wanted to bring baseball back to the community level." Patrick Power, a lawyer who serves as team president, is clear in his admiration for Fredriksson's efforts: "Kirk is 95 percent responsible for the Twisters' success."
On a warm Sunday afternoon, the game was all that a baseball purist could ask for.
Both starting pitchers, Mike Galati of Middletown and Ryan Kearney of Torrington, were exceedingly sharp; neither allowed a run through seven innings. Deschaine, the Twisters' second-baseman, provided defensive support with a back-to-the-plate catch of a Texas Leaguer and a catch of a line drive that he transformed into a double play.
Kearney, a junior and collegiate all-star at the University of Massachusetts in Lowell, had hoped to be drafted, especially after pitching in the Cape Cod League the previous summer.
"It was kind of a disappointment," said the pitcher, who leads the N.E.C.B.L. with a 0.79 earned run average. "In this league, we don't have as many big-name players as the Cape, but the competition is just as stiff."
To earn spending money, Kearney, like some of his teammates, works part-time -- in his case, in a Torrington sporting goods store.
In the bottom half of the eighth inning, the deadlock was broken by Deschaine, who walloped a Galati pitch over the left field wall for his first N.E.C.B.L. home run..
Greg Jeffries, a junior from Queens College, replaced Kearney in the ninth inning and preserved the shutout by striking out two of the four Giants he faced.
Deschaine is the son of a former athlete in Waterbury and the nephew of a man who was an outstanding basketball guard at Gonzaga University; despite his athletic genes he wasn't in the Twisters' lineup at the season's beginning. "Jim didn't figure into our plans as an everyday player at first," Hunt said, but he's made himself into a starter. He's earned it."
For Torrington it is just the beginning. Next year, the restoration of Fuessenich Park will continue with a rebuilt grandstand, new restrooms, concession stands and press box. The project carries a $550,000 price tag, nearly half of which will come from the state, but the Mayor said she believes it's worth it.
"Baseball is an economic draw for Torrington. We draw from all the surrounding towns," said Gryniuk, who is enough of a Twisters fan to throw a party for the team at her home. "Torrington is a big sports town, always has been and always will be."

HEADLINE: Water Wars Along the Shepaug River

BYLINE: By FRANCES CHAMBERLAIN 

 BODY:
WASHINGTON and Roxbury have gone to battle stations in a long-simmering dispute with their larger neighbor, Waterbury, over rights to water from the Shepaug River.
In town meetings, called within 24 hours of each other on July 17 and 18, voters in the smaller towns flocked to their respective town halls and voted unanimously to join the Shepaug River Association Inc., the Steep Rock Association and the Roxbury Land Trust in a lawsuit alleging that Waterbury has violated a 1921 agreement, resulting in environmental damage to the Shepaug River. 
 The Mayor of Waterbury, Philip Giordano, responded last week by filing an action for a declaratory judgment in Waterbury Superior Court, seeking, he said, an unbiased legal opinion concerning a contractual agreement.
"I'm disappointed that Washington and Roxbury have decided to act in an adversarial manner," Mayor Giordano said in a statement. "For over a century, Waterbury has been operating its reservoir system in a responsible and prudent manner. Waterbury cannot and will not sit idly by while others seek to dictate the water policy, needs and uses of the City of Waterbury." Mr. Giordano continued: "It's a complex issue, but if the towns file suit against us, all the matters would probably be condensed into one issue. Our seeking an unbiased opinion would have some impact."
In Washington the special town meeting drew more than 250 people. William Fairbairn, a lawyer serving as moderator, opened the meeting by saying -- tongue in cheek it seemed -- "visitors and people from other towns can't vote, unless they vote the right way." It was clear within minutes what "the right way" was. One after another, people stood and pleaded support for the litigation.
In Roxbury the next night, First Selectman Edward Went pulled out extra chairs to accommodate the crowd. As people continued to arrive, he stopped the meeting briefly, collapsed room partitions to double the space and set up even more chairs.
At both meetings, the question was whether Waterbury, by diverting water, was killing the Shepaug River. One Roxbury fisherman said he had caught his first trout in the Shepaug in 1920. "Today, it's like putting your hand in a warm bath," he said. "Fish can't live in that river."
The old agreement, signed after Waterbury purchased property at the headlands of the Shepaug, stipulated that Waterbury release 1.5 million gallons a day from the Shepaug Reservoir from early spring to fall. But the complainants charge that Waterbury is using water only from the Shepaug and Cairns Reservoirs, while three other city reservoirs sit unused -- and that it is illegally selling the Shepaug and Cairns water to other towns. Mayor Giordano's staff say the question of resale is subject to interpretation.
Residents along the Shepaug say Waterbury's 1.5 million gallon diversion each day means the river virtually dries up in the summer months, leaving fish, crayfish and other wildlife dying in hot shallow pools. The water, as well as that from the Cairns reservoir, is channeled through pipes under Bantam Lake and into Pitch Reservoir, which belongs to Waterbury.
Washington and Roxbury residents believe that Waterbury uses their water, which is on higher ground, rather than supplies from the Morris or Wigwam Reservoirs, which are lower and would require expensive pumping. The Pitch Reservoir has a relatively low capacity, and the most economical solution for the city, they say, is to channel water from the Shepaug to the Pitch, and then into the water treatment plant.
Mayor Giordano's chief of staff, William Cugno, said that although the studies may suggest the Cairns/ Shepaug route for water, "the city officials have no technical data to support this." He went on: "We have no knowledge that our three reservoirs could supply the city's water and that's what precipitated the 1921 agreement."
Mayor Giordano, now in the second year of his term, inherited the thorny problem from his predecessor, Edward Bergin, and even before inauguration was put on notice that Washington, at least, was considering suit.
"I entered my administration with a force from those other towns publishing scathing articles in newspapers," Mr. Giordano said. "It took my administration 9 or 10 months to give them a call and explain our position. "They were rather apologetic. They had acted with a vengeance without regard as to whether we were willing to sit down and discuss this. I wanted to get the technical experts together and I thought we were making some strides, but unfortunately, passion and emotion have overridden the sense of fair play."
Washington's First Selectman, Alan Chapin, said efforts to reach a solution have been going on. The Rod and Gun Club, interested in fly fishing in the river, had initially gone to the Shepaug-Bantam River Board. The Department of Environmental Protection failed to approve a proposed plan, and a few years ago a new ad hoc committee commissioned a study by the Roxbury Land Trust, the Steep Rock Association, Town of Washington, the Washington Environmental Council and the Rod and Gun Club. That report was finished in April 1994 and forwarded to then-Mayor Bergin.
He responded to Mr. Chapin by saying, "Unfortunately, to date, the results of the negotiations have not provided me with a proposal which satisfactorily balances the City's primary concern, i.e. assuring sufficient water supply for future generations, with the Town of Washington's request for a reallocation of Waterbury's water supply. Until such balance is achieved, the City will continue to abide by the 1921 written agreement between the City of Waterbury and the Town of Washington."
Although Mayor Giordano has said he was ready to discuss the issue, Mr. Chapin said that six separate meetings were canceled in 1996, and at one held in September of that year, Mr. Giordano said that the Shepaug River was a low priority.
Mayor Giordano said that he did cancel one meeting, but that others were attended by city representatives who reported back to him.
A legislative task force, established by the General Assembly, ruled in January of this year that the diversion of water was causing serious problems and urged a resolution by April 30. Mr. Chapin said that again he was unable to schedule a meeting with Mayor Giordano.
On May 20, Mayor Giordano met with community representatives to discuss his process of dealing with the task force recommendations. "We said we would study the issue and provide correspondence within six weeks, which we did," the Mayor's representative, Mr. Cugno, explained. "The city has a charter that we must follow. No single individual can make a decision concerning an issue of this importance, but apparently this wasn't convincing enough."
Mr. Chapin and John Millington, president of Steep Rock Association, met with Mayor Giordano and his staff on July 15. "I told him that he should take this seriously," Mr. Chapin said, "but I don't think he understands how people here feel about the river."
In Mayor Giordano's recent statement he noted that a lawsuit "appeared to be inevitable. Millington was quoted as saying that the members of his group were 'chomping at the bit' to bring a lawsuit. Chapin noted that members of the Shepaug River Association, Steep Rock Association and the Roxbury Land Trust had already raised the funds necessary for the lawsuit, and at their meetings, both Towns also voted to commit additional financial support for the litigation."
Notices of the impending town meetings were published, and before Washington residents gathered on July 17, Mayor Giordano had faxed a response to Mr. Chapin's office.
"We recognize that there is strong sentiment held by some parties," Mr. Giordano wrote, "that it is necessary to engage in adversarial proceedings at this time. If necessary, the City is prepared to defend its legal rights with all of its energy and resources, and is confident that it will prevail in the end . . . if we establish a firm milestone schedule to address necessary matters in an amicable fashion, we feel that we can reach a satisfactory resolution before the start of the next dry season."
Mayor Giordano also said that upon receipt of the task force report, the city had a consulting engineering firm inspect the Shepaug and Cairns dams, reviewed the reports and studies of the Shepaug River Association, discussed alternatives with a consulting engineering firm, and investigated ideas like adding flashboards to impound more water for downstream release and potential piping changes.
Edwin S. Matthews Jr., president of the Shepaug River Association, speaking at both the Washington and Roxbury meetings, said that Waterbury's other three reservoirs produced 18 million gallons of water a day, more than enough to meet the needs of the city.
"Waterbury could use their system all year and not need to use the Shepaug unless there is an extreme drought," Mr. Matthews said. The legal action, he said, is based on several principles. "If Waterbury is causing environmental damage, the burden shifts, and they must show that there's no prudent alternative to using the water of the Shepaug," he told the crowd.
The Connecticut Environmental Act reimburses court costs for citizens who file suit if charges of damaging the environment are justified, he explained. "In addition, if an upstream owner causes problems for downstream owners, it is considered a nuisance," he continued. Also, by the terms of the 1921 contract Waterbury should only be allowed to divert water for its own needs. "Middlebury and Wolcott are now getting water illegally," he charged.
One Washington resident, Philip Farmer, who spoke at Thursday's meeting, said that a member of the previous Mayor's staff had told him that the Mayor and aldermen could never reach an agreement for political reasons. That sentiment was repeated Friday night at Roxbury's meeting.
"We have nine Republicans and six Democrats," Mayor Giordano retorted. "That is an absurd statement. We're no different than any other city and ultimately it boils down to passing an issue that affects the whole city."
The Shepaug River Association, the Steep Rock Association and Roxbury Land Trust have received pledges in excess of $300,000 to cover the lawyer's estimate of $200,000 to $300,000. But, Mr. Matthews said, it was essential to the success of the lawsuit that both towns express their support for the effort.
While Washington unanimously voted to appropriate $20,000 to contribute toward litigation, Roxbury voted to appropriate $10,000, reserving $10,000 for other legal expenses. Mr. Matthews says the towns will probably not be asked to contribute financially; their official support was the key element.
Roxbury First Selectman Edward Went explained that the town's legal counsel, a Waterbury firm, felt this was the prudent course in case of disagreement with other complainants or a decision to to withdraw from the case. In both Washington and Roxbury, votes at the town meetings were unanimous in favor of the lawsuit. No objections were voiced on any aspect of it.
In response to the towns' decision to sue, Mr. Cugno said, "we want to be cautious that this is driven by logic and not emotion." Mayor Giordano himself said, "Something as grave as the Shepaug, with the complexity of knowledge required, took me a couple of months to fully grasp. Unless you're running government with puppets you wouldn't want anything less than fully informed aldermen."
But at the conclusion of Washington's hour-long special meeting, Mr. Fairbairn asked the crowd to "stand up and yell 'aye' so the Mayor can hear us in Waterbury."

HEADLINE: Fair Time, From 4-H Plain To Midway Madness

BYLINE: By JACKIE FITZPATRICK 

 BODY:
DURING the school year, Billy Linkovich, 12, of Litchfield, has homework to do and baseball to play, so he tucks in visits to his grandfather's farm in East Canaan when he can. But in the summer, with the long stretch of hazy, hot days spread out before him, Billy heads to the farm every chance he gets.
He goes to help his grandfather and to spend time with Bambi, one of his grandfather's cows. He feeds the cow, grooms and works with her, all to prepare for the 4-H fairs. Bambi's getting a little old for showing now but Billy doesn't care. "He's quite attached to that cow," said his mother, Kim Linkovich. "He's proud to show her." 
 The 4-H organization has been in Kim Linkovich's family for four generations. When her grandmother, Isabelle Carlson, was a girl, she was in the 4-H sewing club, the cooking club and the dairy club. She and her friends would meet regularly at an American Legion Hall. "We made dresses. We cooked all kinds of things," Mrs. Carlson said. "I've always loved farm life. I wouldn't live in the city if you paid me." The tradition continued with Kim Linkovich's father, Douglas Carlson, who spent his 4-H time showing cows. Kim Linkovich did a bit of both -- working with animals and sewing. "4-H is such a great thing for kids," she said, "because it instills responsibility and it gives them the opportunity to work with animals."
And to their family, there is nothing at all to match fair season, which has just begun, a time of year when they get to show the fruits of their labor, when Billy has a chance to get Bambi spiffy and show a panel of judges what she can do; fair season is also when Mrs. Carlson participates in the old-timer showmanship contest, to show she hasn't lost her touch with cattle.
The Linkoviches are hardly alone in their enthusiasm. Connecticut is steeped in agricultural fairs, from the Durham Fair and the Goshen Fair to the Terryville Country Fair, the Beacon Grange Fair and the Hillstown Grange Fair and the New London County 4-H Exposition. Agricultural fairs have become one of the most popular destinations for in-state day-trippers and one of the major draws for out-of-state visitors. Hundreds of thousands of people hop into their cars during season and head to fairgrounds. They go in search of buttered corn on the cob or homemade pie or fried dough, to see the largest tomato someone has grown, to watch the pig races, to admire the needlework exhibits, to ooooh and aaaah over the tractor pull or the woodchopping contest and to learn more about farm life.
"Most people don't live near farms anymore. They don't know where their milk comes from or what farm life is all about and this brings them back, even for a day," Mrs. Linkovich said. Robert Pellegrino, the bureau director of marketing and technology for the State Department of Agriculture, agrees. "I think people don't really know how they obtain their food. They go to a store and pick it up," he said. "This shows them and it also shows them how vital farming is in the state."
Mr. Pellegrino is quick to point out the variety in the state. "The vegetable and fruit farms are doing so well and the nursery farms are exploding," he said, and he noted that "tobacco is very big in Connecticut."
Agriculture is a $2.1 billion industry in the state, which ranks No. 1 in New England in egg production, in milk production per cow, in mushroom production and value, in tobacco production and value and in the number of horses (60,000 according to 1995 statistics.) While farming is important to the state's economy, agricultural fairs are vital to Connecticut's tourism industry. As the executive director of the Connecticut Office of Tourism, Edward Dombroskas, explained it, out-of-state visitors plan extended weekend visits tying a visit to Mystic or Essex or the shoreline with a trip to a country fair and maybe a few stops at local vineyards. "We are seeing a lot of family travel." Mr. Dombroskas said, "and people want hands-on things to do, things that adults and children can enjoy. Fairs offer that to people."
The season officially began earlier this month with the North Stonington Fair, July 10-13. M. Eugene Bromley, who has the task of coordinating the North Stonington Fair, said that children clamor to see the pigs, sheep, horses and rabbits. The adults, he said, like to see teams of oxen pulling up to 10,000 pounds. "And some folks just like taking a ride on the Ferris wheel and looking out over the town," he said.
The fair season runs through October, and among the ones next month are the Lebanon Country Fair (Aug. 8-10), the Bridgewater Country Fair (Aug. 15-17), the Brooklyn Fair (Aug. 21-24), the Chester Fair (Aug. 22-24), the Woodstock Fair (Aug. 29-Sept. 1) and the Goshen Fair (Aug. 30-Sept. 1).
In addition, there are district fairs like the Hamburg, Preston City and Orange Country fairs, as well as 4-H fairs like ones in Windham County and in Hartford County. More than 20 local fairs also take place; among these are the Victory Grange Agricultural Fair in Colebrook and the Echo Grange Fair in Mansfield.
Some fairs are meant for thousands of tourists. They have boisterous midways, musical entertainment and dozens of food vendors.
Leonard Baginski is president of the Durham Fair, which often draws more than 275,000 people over three days in September. Visitors will flock to the rides on the midway and to see the llama competition, the baking contest winners and the crafts. "We draw the young and the old because everyone loves a fair," Mr. Baginski said.
Others, like smaller 4-H fairs, are decidedly simpler. There, members show their animals and their craftwork. They participate in the farm chore contest, taking bales of hay off the back of a pickup, for example and racing with it to a drop-off point. At these fairs, the focus is on the 4-H members.
Laura Marek, an educator with the UConn Cooperative Extension Service, said there are more than 300 young people statewide who participate in 4-H and the fair is their moment to shine. "They have the chance to show off projects they have been working on all year," she said.
While young people work toward a blue or red ribbon, adults put in countless hours behind the scenes preparing for the larger agricultural fairs. Paul and Joan Ziegler have worked for years as volunteers on the Connecticut Agricultural Fair in Goshen, which is taking place this weekend. They live in Danbury and have belonged to the Redding Grange for 25 years. "It's a lot of work," Mrs. Ziegler said, but rewarding.
Each year during fair time, committee members camp out at the fairgrounds. Late at night, after the last of the lights of the fair has gone out, they gather around and talk about the day's events -- the tractor pull, the photography contest, the excitement on the midway, the weather forecast. "We just sit up a long while and talk," she said. "The work is always worthwhile. Everyone has such a good time."
April Kapusta of Milford knows well the work involved, but, like the Zieglers, she loves it. Mrs. Kapusta, along with Richard and Lucille Murray of Stamford, owns World's Best Sundaes, an ice cream concession that goes to many agricultural fairs. She and her husband, Ed Kapusta, a teacher, started the business to make money for their children's college fund. The business flourished and the two families now work from June through October. On a given three-day weekend, they make 5,000 to 6,000 ice cream sundaes. They slice up 10,000 strawberries, whip 100 gallons of cream, mix 200 gallons of hot fudge and add 60 pounds of roasted almonds. Mrs. Kapusta's son slices the strawberries and is pretty much drenched in the color red all weekend.
"It's a very big job," said Mrs. Kapusta, who is also a real estate agent. "But everyone has always had a summer job, all the nieces and nephews. It was a way to be outdoors and to be together. We travel all over from fair to fair and so do many of the vendors, so we've met wonderful, professional people. It's like a second family."
For a brochure on the state's agricultural fairs, send a self-addresssed envelope with $1 in postage to the Association of Connecticut Fairs, Post Office Box 753, Somers, Conn. 06071.

HEADLINE: Connecticut Q&A: Michael P. Peters;
Paraphrase: 'What, Me Leave Hartford?'

BYLINE: By RICHARD WEIZEL 

 BODY:
WITH his quick wit and short stocky physique, Michael P. Peters, the Mayor of Hartford, has been compared to the New York City Mayor Fiorello La Guardia -- and to comedians like Rodney Dangerfield.
In 1993 when the 48-year-old former firefighter entered politics and was elected Mayor, Mr. Peters said he had finally gotten the only job he ever really wanted. Voters in the state's capital city seconded his choice, re-electing him with more than 85 percent of the vote. 
 Mr. Peters is fond of saying that when he told his wife about his political aspirations she laughed for 20 minutes, but he says she's not laughing anymore. Neither is the Union of Retired Firefighters, which booted him out last year, even picketing his home because he successfully opposed a pension increase for them that would have included himself.
While he's been a controversial local figure as he tackled Hartford's fiscal problems, Mr. Peters has also gained some national recognition, and in his city hall office, Mr. Peters recently spoke about his tenure. Following are excerpts from that conversation.
Q. A few weeks back, after the state takeover of the school system and an announcement that the Whalers hockey team was moving out of Hartford, you were quoted as saying "It's been tough, we lost the Whalers and the Board of Education in one week." Don't both developments bode ill for your city?
A. I don't think so. Let's take the issues one by one. Let's start with the Board of Education. As everyone knows, the schools in our urban areas have been experiencing some very trying times -- not just in Hartford but in places like Trenton, New York, Los Angeles and Detroit. That's why we've been trying experimental approaches like the public/ private partnership of the schools a few years back. Even though it didn't work, I think it was worth the gamble.
Q. But that was a dismal failure; the city ended up having to buy out the company's contract to regain control of the school system. What went wrong?
A. I'll tell you what went wrong. It was just a bad marriage to start with. We felt very strongly that we needed some radical changes within our school system. Educational Alternatives Inc., the company that came in, was supported by the Board of Education and I also supported it. I thought we had to try something different. But we didn't realize the roadblocks that would be put up. People in Connecticut, like most places, are afraid of change. And that was the main problem.
Q. Why did you support Educational Alternatives?
A. Because I knew that our educational system was not working, particularly for the amount of money we were putting into it. Urban school systems in general have been trying to regain a sense of balance; we're all looking for new ways to solve some of the devastating problems like poverty, teen-age pregnancy, drug use and violent crime. I felt very strongly that we needed some kind of radical change, and I thought a public-private partnership was the answer. I was wrong. So we moved on.
Q. More recently, what about the state takeover and dissolution of the local, elected school board that was a first in Connecticut?
A. Look, one thing just about everyone in the city realizes and agrees on is that the school system has not been working to provide the best possible education for our youngsters. So we had to act. If it means calling the state in, then we did that. Most mayors would call this an embarrassment. I call this a new step, and hopefully a better step for the future of our children and our schools.
Q. What about losing all control of the school system? Isn't that a major blow?
A. No. I think what we have here is a board set up of professional people from every walk of life who understand what this school system needs. Do I think losing local control is a good thing? No, but what it says is that we're probably not electing the right people. The previous board got caught up in politics, favoritism and fiscal waste. If this new group of people appointed by the state can step in and make a difference for our children, then who can oppose that?
Q. What about the Sheff v. O'Neill desegregation case? The plaintiffs in the case are saying that there is still educational inequality and racial isolation in Hartford. They are going back to court because they say not much has happened.
A. So far, the plaintiffs are right when they say that not much has happened. I think the state legislature has to get more involved; they have to get moving on it. I think they are looking at this new state board to do something too. There are a multitude of possible remedies, including school choice, some form of desegregation, etc. But I don't think anybody wants nothing, that's not where we should be heading.
Q. As one of the 10 poorest cities in the nation and with the highest teen-age pregnancy rate and high crime rate, Hartford has a bad reputation. What would you say to the critics?
A. I would say that we are most certainly not a city on the decline. The crime rate has dropped dramatically -- about 30 percent -- and in fact is the lowest it's been in 10 years. We're linked up with the F.B.I. and the state police and because of that have been able to cut the heads off our gangs, and we're very proud of that.
Q. Whatever the perception of the city, you've managed to gain tremendous popularity. Why?
A. I think they like short fat guys. No, I think they look at my work ethic. I do work very hard. I'm the type of guy who gets into work at 7:30, 8 in the morning, and sometimes don't get home until 11 at night. I know the city like the back of my hand, having been a firefighter here for 22 years. I just think if you're honest, working hard and doing the best job you can -- people really appreciate and respect that.
Q. But the firefighters union says you're far too tough on them. Is that true?
A. I don't know. I do know that being a firefighter is a great job, a well-paying job, and when in you're in a city that is one of the poorest in the country you've got to deal with the unions and say, "Look, we can't afford to do this right now. Give us some time to get back on our feet and then we'll talk again." I think the unions have to sometimes be a little more realistic about money. They have to understand that when we can afford it, we'll take care of them.
Q. On a lighter topic, you're well known for your one-liners. Is it that being Mayor of Hartford these days requires a good sense of humor?
A. You've got to have a sense of humor to be mayor of any place, even East Cup Cake, N.J. Look, God gave me this gift of gab and sometimes I guess I'm kind of funny. Hopefully it's not insulting anyone. I have a good time with it, and I love this job and this city, so I get to be mayor and I guess a comedian at the same time.
Q. Back to the Whalers defection: what impact will that have?
A. Not much. We're not going to lose a beat because we're going to have a minor league team come in and play in the Civic Center. We may not have as many fans coming to the downtown area, but it will be a cheaper ticket and more opportunity for people who couldn't afford a Whaler ticket.
Q. But isn't the city, and for that matter, the state, going to miss having a major league franchise in Hartford?
A. Sure people are going to miss the Whalers. Am I sorry the Whalers left? Yeah. But the city of Hartford has been around for 358 years; the Whalers have been here for 22. I feel bad for the fans and players, but when you offer to build a $147 million arena and guarantee $50 million in annual revenue and they still want to leave -- then you've got to figure the gentleman who owns the team just did not want to stay here, no matter what.
Q. One of the Presidential debates was held last year in Hartford. What was it like having your city be host to such a major political event?
A. The debate was a great experience. For two weeks Hartford was a regular dateline or new item around the country, even around the world. I think the debate was also important locally. There was a definite short-term economic impact on the city -- we filled hotel rooms and saw considerably more activity in restaurants, bars and shops. And long-term, I think we generated new awareness and interest in Hartford. Many people had an old image of Hartford -- a snapshot from another time. This was our chance to update that image and I think we did it well.
Q. What about your own political future? You're up for re-election again in November. How long would you like to be Mayor, and do have any ambition to seek higher office?
A. I really don't know how long I want to be in this job. I grew up here, lived here my whole life and love being mayor. I'm just taking it one term at a time. The other day someone asked me if I wanted to run for Governor . . . and I asked them, "Of which state?" Seriously, I don't know where my future lies. Maybe some day I'll have a radio show, some people think I'd be good at that.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Michael P. Peters of Hartford. "You've got to have a sense of humor to be mayor of any place, even East Cup Cake, N.J." (The Associated Press)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

CITY: HARTFORD, CT, USA (95%); NEW YORK, NY, USA (93%); LOS ANGELES, CA, USA (79%); 

COMPANY: HARTFORD WHALERS (82%); HARTFORD WHALERS (82%);

PUB-DATE: July 27, 1997

SECTION: Section 9; Page 1; Column 2; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 2882 words

HEADLINE: Spec Houses Are Back in Season

BYLINE: By TRACIE ROZHON 

 BODY:
IN 1989, Carol Konner was burned -- and burned badly. "I lost $8 million and went broke," said Ms. Konner, a tough-talking 60-year-old developer who was a major player in the Hamptons building boom of the late 80's -- and who finally has started to build again.
Last year at this time, Ms. Konner was either planning or building four houses. This year, she is actively working on 26, including a 100-acre subdivision in Bridgehampton, L.I., called Rolling Hills. 
 Ms. Konner builds "spec" houses primarily for weekenders or summer residents, and that type of construction, in the words of a contractor in Nantucket, Mass., had been "dead, dead, dead" ever since the late 80's. Speculative construction is still dead in many parts of the Northeast, even in areas where speculative second-home construction flourished in the heyday of a decade ago. According to realtors and builders, speculative second-home building is still rare along the Connecticut shore, in Vermont, New Hampshire and Maine, in New York around Millbrook and Pawling and on much of the Jersey shore.
But with all kinds of residential construction booming in hot spots like Long Island's East End, speculative building of vacation homes has returned to the Hamptons and to a lesser extent in Nantucket, Martha's Vineyard and Cape Cod.
The rules, however, have changed; the spectrum has narrowed, for both builders and buyers. In both the Hamptons and elsewhere, speculative building has become a high-stakes game largely for professionals with proven track records. The banks are lending again to both contractors and homebuyers, but with vastly different criteria: Mortgage brokers and bankers say the banks want to see a lot more cash than they did in the past.
In the Hamptons, speculative construction for multimillion-dollar second homes has been gathering strength over the last couple of years, according to builders and brokers, and, as building permits multiply, land prices have soared, pushing prices ever higher. Right now, there are an estimated 100 spec houses under construction on Long Island's East End -- compared with close to zero five years ago.
On Nantucket, there are probably between 15 and 20 spec homes -- a far cry from the estimated 150 that were rising on the island in the middle 80's, according to real estate brokers there.
There are no statistics that separate speculative homes from the so-called custom homes, houses built to the specifications of the people who are going to live in them, and who are paying the construction bills. But in the Hamptons, there is clearly a building boom.
"Last week, I drove down Meadow Lane in Southampton," said Peter Hallock, president of Allan M. Schneider Associates, a real estate firm, "and there were probably -- I'm not exaggerating -- 150 trucks of workmen, working on new construction. And that's only one street. It's phenomenal." Both custom homes and speculative homes in the Hamptons range in price from $500,000 to over $3 million.
Melissa Cohn, a Manhattan mortgage broker who opened a branch in Water Mill at the end of May, said that last year, the company lent $5 million for new construction in the East End. So far this year, the company has lent $16 million.
In the Hamptons, people started building new houses because the price of existing houses had risen so much, according to Ms. Cohn: "Instead of paying too much for a house that isn't exactly right, they realize they can pick out the land and build what they want."
Speculative houses, she said, are perfect for the person who wants a brand new house "but can't bear living with the nightmare of construction for 12 months."
Nantucket, too, has been caught in the flurry of building. Two weeks ago, The Nantucket Inquirer and Mirror wrote that "building permits are as common as parking tickets on Main Street," and expressed concern that too much home building could overtax sewers and schools.
"There's quite a lot of spec building here, but it's different now," said Christopher C. Maury, an architect and developer involved in both designing and building several houses on Nantucket. "The market's a little out of whack now. It's a market of buyers who are cash-strong, and almost all of them are from New York, not Boston. In the 80's, there was heavy leveraging, and people were coming from everywhere. Now most are cash deals."
Curtis Barnes, president of Nantucket Real Estate, echoing the situation in the other parts of the region where speculative building is going on, said that "the day when carpenters, stone masons and local craftsmen were mortgaging their own houses to build a spec house is long gone."
"Those people lost their houses -- including their own," he said. "This time around, the banks are lending only to builders with deep pockets."
Mr. Maury said that in the 80's, the spec houses cost from $300,000 to $500,000. "Now, most are a half million to $1.5 million -- and up," he said.
ON Cape Cod, the only speculative building reported by Robert Kinlin, of Kinlin Grover Properties in Osterville, is on the highest end. "It started six to eight months ago," Mr. Kinlin said. "A builder from off the Cape came here to look at land. He bought 30 acres and spun off as a subdivision about 10 or 11 one-plus acre lots and kept a seven-acre waterfront parcel. Now he's building a 5,000-square-foot Royal Barry Wills-type design, a colonial with a pool. It's $3.2 million, and it's stunning."
That builder, John Lampe of Manchester, Mass., was "clearly the first -- and the only builder on the Cape to have a spec house for over $3 million," said the realtor.
Mr. Lampe owns a summer house in Dennis, Mass., on the Cape, and when the climate for new construction improved, he said, he started shopping for land. Speculative building, he said, "isn't that risky if you have enough capital, and you're not leveraged." He decided to trust his "gut feeling" and build a spectacular house, he said; "who knows whether it will fly?"
In the last six months, two more speculative homes were built: one in Cotuit, and then one in Osterville. Now, there is another speculative house on the golf course: a 4,500-square-foot Colonial with four bedrooms and three and a half baths -- "high ceilings, the whole nine yards," according to Mr. Kinlin. The house, on the market for $1.495 million, is a joint venture between Paul Birmingham, who owned the land, and Silvia and Silvia, a builder. Another owner/ developer, Bill Guarente, is about to break ground for a similar house, with 5,000 square feet, to be priced at $1.695 million, "and there's the likelihood that it will be a second home for somebody," Mr. Kinlin said.
On the Cape, the person who buys an expensive spec house is probably planning on retiring to it "three to six years from now," Mr. Kinlin said. "They'll probably split their time: six months here and six months on the east or west coast of Florida."
In the Hamptons, speculative building came back full force about 18 months ago, according to Frank Newbold, who heads the East Hampton branch of Sotheby International Realty -- "and it's back with a vengeance after being missing for 10 years."
Yet Mr. Newbold agrees with the other builders and brokers that the pattern of the speculative building market now is very different than it had been in the past.
"It used to be spec building dominated the middle market," he said. "There are still a few in the middle here, but we've never seen this before: spec homes over $3 million."
Mr. Newbold estimated that in the East End towns that are collectively referred to as the Hamptons -- East Hampton, Southampton, Amagansett, Bridgehampton, Sagaponack, Wainscott and Water Mill -- there are probably about 100 such speculative homes going up, (Town building departments do not separate houses built on speculation and houses built specifically for the person who will live in them.)
Spec homes are obviously a riskier proposition -- the developer is betting that he or she understands what homebuyer want -- but can also be more lucrative. In a commissioned house, the builder agrees to make only a certain percentage of the construction costs as profit; in a speculative house, only the market sets the profit limit.
"I don't have a set profit -- like 20 percent on every house," said Ms. Konner. "There are so many variables, like what you have to pay for the land. On some, I don't make even 20 percent. On others . . . " She paused. "I make a great deal more."
BOB IMMACOLATO, a Hamptons realtor, had until this year managed another person's office. He had made some money -- even though he began selling real estate just six months before the stock market collapse of October 1987.
"For six months I thought I was in heaven," he said. "Then the phone didn't ring for three years."
But largely because of the return of spec building, Mr. Immacolato decided it was time he went out on his own. "We started getting the risk-takers doing specs," he said. "One developer, Haddonfield and Associates, started with $800,000 houses four years ago, and now they won't do anything less than $2.5 million."
So this year, Mr. Immacolato bought a tiny little pale green house on the Montauk Highway in Wainscott, totally transformed it -- including a new pink bathroom -- and opened Twin Pines Realty, named after the two giant conifers that flank his office. So far he has sold two houses and one piece of land. "This is my shot at the gold ring," he said.
The most expensive, most quickly sold spec houses -- in the Hamptons, on Nantucket, and on Cape Cod -- look alike. Although developers almost always insist that every speculative house is different, in fact they share the same architectural personality.
First of all, they usually are covered with wood shingles. And they are designed to look as if they had been added on to over the years -- first the basic house, then more bedrooms, then a servant's wing, then a porch, then a country kitchen. Then, of course, there's a pool house -- also shingled, also with dormers. Then the big garage, often with a "studio" above.
"This is a Haddonfield house," said Mr. Immacolato, pulling into a 17-house subdivision called Seafields in Sagaponack, where many of the houses have water views from the second floors. "See the gambrel roof, the pillars, the shingles -- and all within walking distance to the beach."
Seafields is a good example of what is happening now. The subdivision went into foreclosure in the early 1990's before building began, and the land speculators gathered. Mr. Immacolato sold 10 of the lots, and bought one for himself.
"Construction here didn't really start until this year," he said. "They still haven't built on the one I owned." When he bought his foreclosed lot in 1992, he paid $194,000. Two and a half years later, he sold it for $268,000. Two weeks ago, the owners turned down $400,000, the realtor said.
DAVID SCHWARTZ, a partner in Haddonfield and Associates, leans against his white Land Rover up a rutted road in Southampton, at the site of his latest spec house. He is waiting for his wife, Jane, the other partner.
"Our niche is the $1.5 million to $3 million spec house," said Mr. Schwartz, 36, a dark-haired man who sold his Manhattan video services company in the late 80's and, after a stint selling pieces of the Berlin Wall, moved to the Hamptons in 1991.
"They found out the Berlin Wall had asbestos in it," he said. "We were all set -- Bloomingdale's was going to carry it. So I came out here -- and if you're in the Hamptons, you gotta be in real estate."
Of the two partners, he is the developer. "My wife's the builder; she has more patience with the crews and the customers," he said. "Once you sell somebody one of these houses, it's like you're married to them."
Ms. Schwartz, 30, arrives in her British green Range Rover, and they look over the latest plans for the 7,000-square-foot house whose concrete foundation spreads out into the distance. Mr. Schwartz looks at the plans skeptically. "So now we've got two eyebrow windows?" he asks his wife, who shrugs.
The house is another long and low extravaganza. To be sold on three and a half acres, it will sell for somewhere around $2.2 million, and is being designed by John Laffey, the same local architect Ms. Konner is using for Rolling Hills.
"See what happened," Mr. Schwartz began. "We started doing a certain house. Then people started copying us; they started to look like clones." This house will have "more of a European look; not exactly postmodern -- a lot of people use postmodern the wrong way -- it'll have a lot of windows, but it won't be exactly classical." Last Monday, the walls started rising; it will take about 10 months to finish. The Schwartzes predict it will sell long before that, judging from their record on their other 15 houses.
"In the 80's," he said. "they built glitter and glitz; white and bright and boxy -- just get it up. There were more doctors, pensioners and investors putting them up, so they leveraged. They put 10 percent down and they got a house, and they figured they'd make a bundle. People ran to the Home Depot, and if they were selling off surplus windows, they built a house around them."
Now, the amateur developers have dropped away, he said. "We're still very tied to Wall Street," he said, especially in the houses over $2 million. "We're just starting to deal with Silicon Valley."
The new customers want bigger and bigger houses. (Mr. Newbold of Sotheby's said four bedrooms was now necessary for a couple with two children, because the nanny must have a room of her own, too.) And increasingly, Ms. Schwartz said, they bring in consultants.
"The new thing is lighting consultants," she said. "You know, lighting for the pond they put in, mood lighting in the master bedroom; up until the last two or three houses we didn't hear 'boo' about lighting." One man who bought a house in the Parsonage Pond development in Sagaponack is bringing in a consultant in fiber optics. And one woman brought along a fitness consultant, to advise her architect on the design of the home gymnasium.
"It's not unusual for them to spend another $250,000 or $500,000 on the landscaping," said Ms. Schwartz.
BARBARA Kavovit, a first-time spec builder -- she has been a general contractor in New York City for years -- walked out of the pool house -- well, not the pool house yet. Like the rest of the compound on an acre a few hundred feet south of the Montauk Highway (the magic words) in East Hampton, the pool house is still just two-by-fours, plywood sheathing and a roof. But in the huge rambling two-story house frame, there is the beginning of the hundreds of feet of metal ductwork needed for the heating and cooling systems.
As Ms. Kavovit tries to talk, her workmen are hammering away on the pipe. "This is my first house," she said. "I'm starting another house in September." Ms. Kavovit bought a house for herself in Wainscott two years ago, and has subdivided the two acres to allow a second house, to be built on spec.
"There's an unbelievable housing boom for vacation houses," she said. "The baby boomers made their money, and they want to spend it. They're looking for houses with this type of price tag -- I hope to get $1.525 million for this one."
A "For Sale" sign is posted at the beginning of the driveway. Already, the shell of a house has been shown eight times in the last 10 days, she said. "Once the sheetrock goes up, people will really be able to see what it's going to look like."
As Ms. Kavovit plans her second house -- and as developers on Cape Cod and the Islands get ready to roll -- the old-timers in the Hamptons are already wondering if the spec house market may be becoming overheated again.
While they've been able to build their current projects on land they had bought cheaply in the recession or got several years ago at a modest price, both Ms. Konner and Mr. Schwartz wonder if land now has got too expensive for spec development.
And they are dealing with the possibility in different ways.
"Land prices here have tripled in three years," said Mr. Schwartz. "They've become really unreasonable -- what's on the market isn't even prime. To a user, I guess it's reasonable, but not for someone who has to make a profit, it's getting risky."
The Schwartzes will keep building in the Hamptons, they say, but they want to branch out. "We'd like to begin developing in the ski areas, in Utah," he said. "And we're exploring the Caribbean," she said.
Ms. Konner, too, is worried about soaring land prices. "I was fortunate to have picked up some distressed properties," she said. "If you stayed alive after the crash, you got a good feel and smell for land."
But land at affordable prices is getting scarce, and Ms. Konner wants to stay in what she calls the "mid range": spec houses that sell in the $500,000's and $600,000's.
"I see more and more people thinking that because the rents are so high, that they can buy a house and rent it out," she said, "and these people may end up in the same place as the folks did in the late 80's.
"Things are so high now that, having gone through the 80's, I'm hedging my bets," she said. "I think it's time to pull some money off the table."
