HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Rockefeller Center;
Hard-Pressed a Year Ago, It's Bouncing Back

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
IT has been just about a year since an investment group led by Tishman Speyer Properties and Goldman Sachs assumed control of the then-bankrupt, Rockefeller Center.
In that time, Tishman Speyer, which manages the center, has landed Christie's, the noted auction house, as a tenant, has rented over 600,000 square feet of office space and is hatching big plans for upgrading the retail space in the center. 
 The new owners are also considering converting one of the 12 buildings in the complex into an upscale hotel and are deciding whether to continue with the current operators of Radio City Music Hall and the Rainbow Room or replace them with someone else.
In addition, they are trying to make the center more of a destination by doing things like holding a Duke Ellington jazz festival on the space used as a skating rink in colder months, shifting the flower show from the spring to summer and holding a classic-car competition on Rockefeller Plaza in the fall.
"We want to keep up the standards of Rockefeller Center, but with a more dynamic pace," said Jerry I. Speyer, the president of Tishman Speyer. "We want to bring the credibility of Rockefeller Center back to where it was 10 years ago."
Rockefeller Center, of course, is the Depression-era project of John D. Rockefeller Jr., who built the complex at a time when few other buildings were being erected. Although some of the structures are, in fact, over 60 years old, current managers say upgrades have kept them competitive with newer buildings.
"It's supposedly a known fact that at Rockefeller Center the ceilings are too low and there is not enough air-conditioning or electricity to run a business," said Philip M. Waterman 3d, a director of Tishman Speyer. "But if that was true, how could NBC or Lazard Freres or The Associated Press continue to operate?"
He said that improvements in air-conditioning, which had to be retrofitted to the older buildings in the center, had permitted raising ceilings from 7 feet to almost 9 feet, giving offices an expansive, rather than closed-in feeling. Mr. Waterman, who is usually known as Tod, said Tishman Speyer had embarked on a program of pre-building office space so that it could accommodate small tenants, such as accounting or software firms, without delay and to demonstrate what can be done with the buildings.
"We spent $50 a square foot to build out the space," Mr. Waterman said. "We want to have 25,000 square feet of this kind of space in inventory at all times."
At Rockefeller Center, this amount of idle space is hardly noticed. The 12 buildings to the east of the Avenue of the Americas have a total of 5,867,491 square feet of rental space, not including the space occupied by the NBC television network, which is a separately owned condominium. Tishman Speyer executives say that 331,183 square feet, or 5.64 percent of the total, is currently not occupied.
The old Rockefeller Center also included four buildings on the west side of the Avenue of the Americas, whose addresses are 1211, 1221, 1251 and 1271. Those are now managed by the Rockefeller Group, which is the successor to the company that sold the landmarked buildings to the east to the Tishman Speyer-led investment group. The Rockefeller Group is wholly owned by the Mitsubishi Estate Company of Japan.
Rockefeller Center was largely owned by Rockefeller family interests until the mid-1980's, when it sold the public shares in a real estate investment trust that held a mortgage on the property. Mitsubishi became involved in 1989 when it invested in the Rockefeller Group, which had continued to manage the center, ultimately buying 80 percent.
With rental rates for offices slumping during the real estate recession of the early part of the decade, the mortgage payments became unsustainable and a subsidiary of the Rockefeller Group filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy on May 11, 1995. The Tishman Speyer, Goldman Sachs group reached agreement to take over the ownership later that year.
Although the two Rockefeller companies are now separated by the avenue, some entangling ties remain. One is Radio City Music Hall. Tishman Speyer executives have said they are thinking about a new operator for the theater. "We hope to have something to say soon about the Music Hall, and it should be pretty exciting," Mr. Speyer said in an interview last Monday.. Its existing lease with Radio City Productions, a subsidiary of the Rockefeller Group. expires next January.
But executives of the Rockefeller Group assert that the company retains ownership of the intellectual property associated with the Music Hall, including the Rockettes and the Christmas Show. This could make it difficult to bring in a new operator while retaining the Hall's most notable attractions.
Jonathan D. Greene, president of the Rockefeller Group's development corporation, said his company was still negotiating with the new owners about extending their tenure in the Radio City Music Hall. "We expect to negotiate a long-term occupancy lease," he said .
Tishman Speyer executives say they are still studying the feasibility of converting part or all of one of the center's office building to a hotel, to take advantage of the booming lodging business in New York.
"We are working on a concept for a very special hotel, but we don't know yet if it will work" Mr. Speyer said. "We expect to be able to say whether we are going to do it or not before the end of the year."
OTHER executives involved with Rockefeller Center say a hotel would be part of an effort to make the center an attractive destination for visitors, rather than a 9-to-5 collection of office buildings. Geoffrey P. Wharton, a managing director of Tishman Speyer, who is the day-to-day manager of the center, said his company had formed an affiliation with the Mills Company, which has been highly successful in developing entertainment-oriented shopping malls that have become leading tourist attractions.
"Those people are not in the retail business," he said. "They are in the total time-capture business. That is what we are trying to do here. We don't want people to spend 30 seconds on the skating rink and take a picture of Prometheus," he said, referring to the sculpture of the mythological figure that overlooks the rink.
"We want people to shop here, dine here and -- if we do the hotel -- stay here," Mr. Wharton said.
Hotel analysts said a luxury hotel could generate more revenue for the center's owners than office space. "If you are talking Rockefeller Center office space, the yield from a hotel could easily be higher," said James E. Fitzgerald, a hospitality consultant with KMPG Peat Marwick. "That might not be true of a newer property on Park Avenue."
The other big change expected at the center is to the retail space, which now is mainly populated with small shops catering to the tenants of the buildings. Tishman Speyer executives have made it clear that they expect to replace the shops with multilevel stores, using the below-ground concourse and the mezzanines in some buildings. They say the Christie's deal is an indication that they expect to go upscale.
"Christie's will change the retail environment at Rockefeller Center," Mr. Speyer said.
The auction house will occupy part of a parking garage that is in two buildings on 48th Street between the Avenue of the Americas and Rockefeller Plaza that will give it both storage and exhibition space. The key to the decision to locate there was the center's extensive underground loading docks, said Mary Ann Tighe, a broker with Insignia/ESG.
"Most office buildings are not equipped for intense loading and unloading," she said. But the combination of the space available in the garage and the availability of the docks make the location suitable for Christie's. "Christie's will go three stories below ground for its storage and restoration activities in addition to its showroom on the ground level and the actual auction rooms on the second floor," Ms. Tighe said. Retail analysts noted that some valuable ground-floor space in the center was occupied by relatively downscale tenants such as airline ticket offices, T-shirt shops and the Berlitz language school.
"They want to go high ticket," said Faith H. Consolo, senior managing director of Garrick-Aug Associates, a retail brokerage. "They want Armani. They'd kill for Ralph Lauren." But she said that the center's landmark status would make it difficult to make exterior changes to display new stores more effectively.
A hint of what the new Rockefeller Center retail environment will be like can be gleaned by the new Tuscan Square restaurant that is being built on 51st Street west of Fifth Avenue. The 11,700-square-foot eating establishment and store is being built on the ground floor and lower level of the building, so that passers-by at both street and the concourse levels can be enticed.
"Everything is going to go up or go down," said Richard Seligman, a senior managing director at Insignia/ESG. "You are going to see stores in the 25,000- to 35,000-square-foot range."

HEADLINE: ROAD AND RAIL;
Will Finishing a Trenton Highway Finish Riverside Life?

BYLINE: By DAVID W. CHEN 

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
People can still remember when Trenton flourished as a riverfront city, replete with canoeing clubs, bathhouses, even lifeguards who watched boys and girls dive off 10-foot-high wharfs lining the Delaware River.
Then, in the 1950's, came the construction of Route 29 in the northern section of the city, a four-lane highway that effectively cut residents off from the river. But it was never finished, petering out onto a two-lane residential road, Lamberton Street, and leaving South Trenton's Lamberton Beach area, near the site of the current Trenton Thunder baseball stadium, as the last portion of the city offering unfettered access to the river. 
 Now, there is a proposal to complete Route 29 with a four-lane highway, linking it with Route 129 in Hamilton Township and giving drivers a smoother, faster trip to Route 1 and several interstates highways as well as the stadium.
To supporters, the 1.7-mile road would alleviate the crush of truck traffic that has rumbled down Lamberton Street in recent years. It would also, they say, spur economic redevelopment near the stadium reminiscent of that around Baltimore's waterfront stadium. But to detractors, a more appropriate analogy would be the argument, decades ago, against the West Side Highway in Manhattan, which brought in cars and pollution and cut off riverfront access.
"It's the kind of thing that has been very divisive," said Tom Arkinson, a teacher who has lived in the area for more than 20 years and supports the project.
The traffic problem started in 1994, when the state finished the Trenton Complex of roads south of the city -- connecting Interstates 195 and 295 to Route 129, and building a new ramp off Route 129 onto Lamberton Street, which rejoins Route 29 to the north.
What this work did, though, was offer trucks and other vehicles a shortcut to Route 1 and to Interstate 95. From 1994 to 1996, the number of vehicles traveling Lamberton Street in a 24-hour period climbed from 19,000 to 33,000, said John Dourgarian, a spokesman for the state Department of Transportation.
Many of the row houses in the working-class neighborhood rattle with each passing truck. Foundations are loosening, residents say. Doors and windows are kept closed, even in the summer, to try to block out the noise and the dirt.
So the Department of Transportation resuscitated the Route 29 proposal, which would build a new highway about 60 feet from Lamberton Street, along the river's edge. About one-third of the $90 million highway would be a tunnel between the Riverview Cemetery and the baseball stadium at Waterfront Park. The proposal would also create a park atop the tunnel and construct stairs 30 feet down to the river -- giving better and safer access to the river than the current dash across Lamberton Street, supporters say.
"Lamberton Street was not designed for 18-wheelers, and this will get them on a highway," said Patricia Stewart, president of the South Trenton Area Residents Society, a civic association that supports the project. "And the river, as it stands, is an eyesore. It is used now by drunks and drug addicts. With the new plan, it will look something like Baltimore harbor."
The governments of Trenton and Mercer County support the project, largely because of the belief that it would complement their plans to continue redeveloping the Waterfront Park area and promoting Trenton as a tourist destination.
"It is the key to everything," said Sharon Lauchaire, a Mercer County spokesperson, about the Route 29 proposal. "We want to create a little waterfront village."
There are many, though, who oppose the project, including the New Jersey Public Interest Research Group Citizen Lobby, the Tri-State Transportation Campaign and the Rutgers Environmental Law Clinic. They argue that a better alternative would be to ban trucks from Lamberton Street.
About 250 residents recently signed a petition urging the state to drop the idea.
On a recent overcast weekday, one of the signers, Leona Joyner, who lives on Lamberton Street, showed some visitors that the riverbank -- while admittedly a bit unkempt and strewn with debris -- was in fact accessible and used by people who liked to stroll, fish, swim or just watch the ducks.
She acknowledged that some work could be done to rehabilitate the crumbling stone stairs and clean up the pebble beach. But there are still well-worn trails, and spots for bird-watchers and fishermen.
"There's something calming about the water," said Ms. Joyner, who has lived in the area since 1978. "Now, who's going to have the view if this thing is built are the motorists who drive by for two seconds."
The project still needs permits from the state Department of Environmental Protection and the Army Corps of Engineers. But if it does go forward, construction could begin in early 1998, with a completion date set for 2001.
Neljane Rizzuto, who, with her husband, Sebastian, has lived in the area since before the Depression, is bracing for the worst.
"Just knowing that the river there is such a delight," said Mrs. Rizzuto, 82, whose sons were the last lifeguards to patrol the river in the mid-1950's. "We've swum. We've had boats. It's been a major part of our lives," she said. "But if they build this highway, there will be nothing left."

HEADLINE: SPENDING IT;
Owning a Fraction of a Jet

BYLINE: By DEBRA NUSSBAUM 

 BODY:
TIRED of airport lounges and inconvenient flight schedules? Wish you could get away from the guy with the bad breath in the next seat who wants to talk?
Here is an answer, if you can afford it: Buy a piece of a jet. 
 The market for partial ownership of small jets has taken off, helped by a strong economy, increased competition and -- perhaps most important -- growing interest among wealthy individuals.
Consider the 25 or so professional golfers, including Tiger Woods and Mike Hill, who share jet ownership through Executive Jet Aviation in Montvale, N.J. Mr. Woods has a one-eighth share in a Citation 10, and Mr. Hill owns a fraction of a Citation V.
There are many others. Don Imus, the radio personality, has a share in a Gulfstream, and Pete Sampras, the tennis star, has a piece of a Hawker.
Net Jets, a fractional-ownership program started in 1986 by Richard Santulli, the chairman of Executive Jet, has attracted corporations and what the industry calls "the concept buyer," an individual who has not previously owned a plane and is most likely not a Fortune 500 executive. About 75 percent of the owners are wealthy individuals, entrepreneurs and private companies, Mr. Santulli said.
Executive Jet has more than 650 customers who own pieces of 100 planes. For $389,000, a company or individual can buy a share in a Citation V Ultra that seats seven. The customer can fly 50 hours a year for a management fee of $3,730 a month and an hourly flight rate of $1,187 -- a total of about $100,000 a year. Such prices open a market for those who cannot afford $6 million for a whole plane -- not to mention expenses for staff and fuel.
Even if you can afford a jet, share ownership lets you move up. It costs $6.8 million for a quarter share of a Gulfstream IV, which seats 13; the part-owner pays a maintenance fee of $33,960 a month and an hourly flying charge of $2,662 for about 200 hours a year. Buying the plane outright would cost about $28 million, and maintenance could easily add $1 million a year.
With fractional ownership, your plane, or one just like it, is available on four to eight hours' notice. If there is a maintenance problem, another plane is provided. A key advantage to owning a part of small jets is that they can fly to 5,500 airports in the United States; big commercial jets can reach only 500.
About 8,000 companies own most of the 11,500 business jets and turboprops in the United States. Some 800 companies and individuals are fractional owners, holding from one-sixteenth to one-half of a plane, said Jack Olcott, president of the National Business Aviation Association in Washington.
Executive Jet sells fractions of many brands of planes, including Gulfstreams. In 1995 it entered a partnership with Gulfstream Aircraft, based in Savannah, Ga.; Gulfstream Shares does the marketing and Executive Jet handles operations and scheduling. The same year, the Dallas-based Business Jetsolutions, partly owned by Bombardier Inc., the jet maker, also entered the shares market.
Another jet maker, the Raytheon Company, based in Lexington, Mass., joined the field this year by starting Raytheon Travel Air. And Lynton Group, based in Morristown, N.J., started Helishare, where clients can buy quarter shares of helicopters.
So how do you decide if you want your very own jet, or a piece of one? Here is a quick formula from Mr. Santulli: if you fly fewer than 400 hours a year, you benefit by being a part-owner instead of a full-owner.
But part is not enough for John Travolta, Jack Nicklaus and Bill Cosby. They each have a Gulfstream to call their own.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Gulfstream IV, the Mercedes of corporate jets, seats 13 people comfortably. (Norman Lono for The New York Times)

LENGTH: 1341 words

HEADLINE: BEHIND THE WHEEL/1998 Nissan Altima;
New and Improved. No Kidding.

BYLINE: By JAMES G. COBB 

 BODY:
THE vast middle of the family-car market has become a bit like Garrison Keillor's Lake Wobegon, where all the women are strong and all the men are good-looking. In this neighborhood, all the medium-sized sedans are above average.
But in an industry built on the four- or five-year product cycle, where competition is internecine and "longer, lower, wider" is still the blueprint for world domination, there is always room for improvement. Nissan North America is the latest to try to raise the bar for bread-and-butter family sedans, remaking its Altima for 1998. 
 By putting the car on sale this month, Nissan gets a jump on Honda, which will take the wraps off a new Accord in late August. Both cars come on the heels of a new Toyota Camry introduced last fall, the debut this year of General Motors offerings like the Chevrolet Malibu and Buick Century, and a recent revamping of the Ford Contour.
Mindful of the dangers of being radical in a segment as conservative as freshman Republicans -- the lukewarm response to the latest Ford Taurus is a case in point -- Nissan followed the usual playbook: take a strong-selling design, make it longer and wider and smoother, add features, cut costs and lower the price. And, of course, upgrade the all-important cup holders.
The Altima arrived as a 1993 model and found 670,000 buyers over four years, but it left plenty of room for improvement. While its drivetrain showed Nissan's knack for balancing spirited performance with economy, the body structure lacked tautness and many panels seemed tinny. The ride was a bit rough and noisy. The cabin was strikingly narrow and some appointments felt cheap. The last Altima I drove, a '97 version of the semi-sporty Altima SE, seemed overpriced at $21,517.
That car, thankfully, is now a memory. The '98 Altima, based on the same platform and the same 103.1-inch wheelbase, is 3.4 inches longer and 2 inches wider, and the distance between the opposite wheels has grown 1.6 inches. While those numbers seem small, they add up. The new car looks more substantial, feels more spacious and seems more sophisticated.
The new Altima's body is 20 percent more rigid, Nissan says, and the ride is noticeably smoother. The trunk has grown to 13.8 cubic feet, from 12.9. The car has gained 30 pounds -- not much, given the bigger size -- and is more aerodynamic.
Nissan has decided that its offerings will not be all things to all buyers. The Altima is available only with four cylinders, and the bigger Maxima only with a V6, so each car is engineered from the ground up for a particular engine. In contrast, the Accord, Contour, Malibu, Camry and Dodge Stratus, among others, can be had with either type of engine, but they usually work best with V6's.
The Altima gets along nicely, however, with a revision of Nissan's smooth 2.4-liter four cylinder. This dual-overhead-cam engine produces 150 horsepower, more than most four-banger rivals. Reducing internal friction has helped to add torque, or pulling power, at lower engine speeds. Still, the engine seems happiest when the tachometer needle is zipping around the dial.
Engine production has shifted from Mexico to a new plant in Decherd, Tenn. That change, along with greater reliance on parts made near the assembly plant in Smyrna, Tenn., means that the Altima is now a domestic car by Federal standards, with 78 percent American-made components.
The '98 Altima has four versions: the basic XE, starting at $15,460 including delivery charges; the midrange GXE, expected to account for 65 percent of sales, at $18,460; the performance-oriented SE, with a firmer suspension, at $18,960, and the leather-and-frills GLE, at $20,360. The prices have been cut -- the GXE's sticker is $1,500 lower, comparably equipped. Buyers of the old model have actually been paying about $17,000, so the asking prices have essentially been adjusted closer to the market value.
The GXE test car had a four-speed automatic transmission, an impressively smooth gearbox derived from the Maxima's. Well-suited to the peppy engine, the transmission picks its gears judiciously and engages in little of the gear-hunting that makes some cars surge and stumble in the hills and dells. The automatic is standard on the GLE and optional on the other models, on which a five-speed manual is standard.
The Altima's biggest deficiency is its steering, which is lighter and has more power assist than that of many rivals. The test car's wheel was reluctant to return to a neutral, center position after turning, forcing the driver to coax it back the final quarter-turn. While the car tracked well on curves, it showed a slight tendency to drift on the highway. On hard acceleration, it pulled to the side; this "torque steer" is fairly common with front-wheel drive, but Audi and Honda, among others, have largely tamed it.
None of this is to imply that the Altima is seriously flawed. It handles nimbly and competently, with a light-on-its-feet feel that complements the eager power train. In both city and expressway driving, the '98 compares favorably with the Camry. (If all midsize cars are equal, some -- like the Camry -- are more equal than others.)
While perhaps not as hushed as the Toyota, the Altima seems quieter than before, though there is some wind noise from the mirrors at cruising speeds.
Americans seemed to like the old Altima better than the Japanese did, so the new car was designed specifically for North America at Nissan's studios in California. A new grille with a horizontal crossbar provides the look of the Maxima, and large, canted taillights wrap into the fenders, accentuating the added width. In profile, the car looks familiar but more assertive.
And if the styling fails to break new ground, there will be no criticism of it here, not after the test model was pursued several miles up Manhattan's West Side Highway by a car-savvy young man in a Honda Civic low-rider. Alternately tailgating and pulling alongside, he repeatedly flashed thumbs-ups. I can't imagine that a Camry or a Malibu would have thrilled him so.
Inside, the Altima gets a revised dashboard, with prominent, no-nonsense gauges and big vents. The cup holders were moved off the dash, where they blocked some controls, into the center console. They have flip-up lids, and their proud fathers at Nissan brag that they will hold any cup from McDonald's. A bin under the center armrest has spaces for compact disks, cassettes and tissues. Both the glove box and the front-door pockets will hold 8-by-11-inch pads.
Such thoughtful touches do not apply to the back seat. Though comfortable and fairly spacious -- headroom is on the short side, as is par for this class -- the rear of the GXE does not provide a single storage space, map pocket, cup holder, ash tray, grab handle or armrest.
Other than that, the test car was not wanting. The popular midsize models now come with enough standard equipment that they're like Ralph's Pretty Good Grocery in Lake Wobegon: If they don't have it, you can probably get along without it.
Standard on the GXE are air-conditioning, power windows and locks, cruise control and a stereo with CD player. The test car also had a power moonroof ($849) and a convenience group ($549) including an upgraded stereo (with a rich sound and excellent controls) and keyless entry (which, unfortunately, doesn't include a trunk release).
The Altima is Nissan's anchor, and the company expects 170,000 United States sales a year, up from 148,000 last year. The car also kicks off an ambitious product-introduction drive, with a new Nissan vehicle to arrive every six months for four years.
The '98 Altima is a solid step toward buffing Nissan's image, which had been losing its sheen. While the previous Altima did not impress, I found the '98 more engaging. It may not have the polish of a four-cylinder Camry, but it is priced some $2,000 lower and is surely more entertaining to drive. And who can put a price on entertainment?
 
INSIDE TRACK: Midi-Maxima, medium cool.

HEADLINE: EARNING IT;
Talk-Show Host Puts His Mouth Where His Money Is

BYLINE: By DAVID J. MORROW 

 BODY:
THE house lights have just dimmed on the set of "Win Ben Stein's Money!" The game show's host, the tart-tongued actor Ben Stein, has settled into a soundproof booth while his opponent, a Los Angeles writer named Bob, tries to cough up correct answers to 10 obscure questions.
The stakes are unusually high. Unlike other game shows, which pay contestant winnings from sponsors' budgets, "Win Ben Stein's Money!" takes the booty out of the host's $5,000-a-show paycheck. The setup is a recipe for hostility. Just ask Bob, whom Mr. Stein has publicly dubbed "the trivia blob." 
 Earlier in the game, Bob looked unbeatable, easily defeating two other contestants for the right to face Mr. Stein in a final round. But now Bob, an ace who once racked up $200,000 in winnings on "Jeopardy," is struggling over game-show staples like "Which state first ratified the Constitution?"
Delaware.
Although it once sensed that it was about to witness a shellacking of Mr. Stein, the audience groans when he not only breezes through the questions but also comes up with miracle answers. Who among us knows that Uri and Zug are states in Switzerland?
Mr. Stein pocketed about $4,100 for his troubles, plus an undisclosed amount he receives under contract. Bob gets to keep the $1,900 he won in the two preliminary rounds. "Most everyone thought that he was going to beat me," the winner said. "But you can never tell what's going to happen on this game show."
"Win Ben Stein's Money!" has its debut at 7:30 P.M. Monday on Comedy Central, and it is bound to raise a few eyebrows. It stars Mr. Stein, who once wrote speeches for President Richard M. Nixon and is perhaps best known for his role as a pedantic teacher in the film "Ferris Bueller's Day Off" and for his stints as a Madison Avenue pitchman, notably for I.B.M., Western Union and Sterling Optical. History buffs may know him as the son of Herbert Stein, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers under Nixon; he has also been a law professor at Pepperdine University and has written Hollywood-based novels including "Dreemz" and "Her Only Sin."
Not only is the show's format unusual -- no game show has ever docked a host's pay for poor performance -- it is one of the raciest since "The Newlywed Game." Mr. Stein's sense of humor relies heavily on hemorrhoids and hickeys, and includes remarks on recently taped shows about pubic hair and abrupt hand gestures to one's boss.
To insure that Mr. Stein does not see the questions or answers before his opponents, a security guard trails him while he is on the set, said the executive producer, Andrew Golder, 36. The security is necessary to avoid any suspicion that Mr. Stein sees questions or answers in advance, as occurred in the quiz show scandal of the 1950's.
Perhaps one reason that some people in the audience root against Mr. Stein is his TV persona, that of a Newt Gingrich wannabe. "Win Ben Stein's Money!" makes political conservatism way cool. Not only does Mr. Stein, 52, wear Reagan-red Hermes ties, he has a jolly good time poking fun at nearly everybody and everything. And he can seem downright pompous, often dismissing his opponents as "rogues," "plunderers" and "anti-war radicals."
His provocative approach to conservatism won't go unnoticed by the Republican Party, which has faced some internal turmoil of late. Comedy Central says "Win Ben Stein's Money!" should deliver an audience of 25- to 49-year-olds whose incomes average some $46,000 a year.
Certainly, the game's format is ripe for a daily spat. To win Ben Stein's money, three contestants answer general trivia questions, earning $50 and up for each correct answer. The two contestants with the most of Mr. Stein's money move on to Round 2, while the loser makes a speedy exit, after returning his or her winnings to Mr. Stein.
The snarliness heightens as the game progresses. Mr. Stein turns over the host duties to Jimmy Kimmel, a sports announcer for KROQ radio in Los Angeles, and becomes a contestant. His goal is to answer as many questions correctly as possible, assuring that no money leaves his pocket.
The loser of the second round gets the bum's rush, depositing his winnings back into Mr. Stein's coffers. The winner moves on to face Mr. Stein in a final one-minute round and can pocket $5,000 if he answers more questions than his host. But Mr. Stein is hard to beat: through tapings done by mid-July, he has a record of 38 wins, 15 losses and 8 ties.
None of this is easy. Behind every off-color category is a question that would rival many on "Jeopardy." Pick, for example, "Sitting at Home, Holden My Caulfield," and you'd get this as a follow-up: "The Glass family appears in two stories in what 1961 J. D. Salinger book?"
The answer: "Franny and Zooey."
Under another category: What is the nickname of the standard computer and typewriter keyboard? (Hint: it's named for the six upper-left letter keys.)
The answer: qwerty.
"We wanted the questions to be difficult enough to make them interesting," Mr. Golder said. "People who watch the show will think it's cool knowing this kind of stuff and that being intelligent is cool."
Clearly, the show's success rests on the well-tailored shoulders of Mr. Stein, and to a degree on Mr. Kimmel. Long known for his poison pen, Mr. Stein has tangled with the likes of Joan Rivers, who sued him in 1987 over an article he wrote about her in GQ magazine. Ms. Rivers contended that conversations attributed to her never took place. The lawsuit was eventually settled out of court.
On camera, Mr. Stein shows that he still has an edge. When a contestant blurted out that there was a vaccine against syphilis, Mr. Stein roared with laughter and then said: "Well, I certainly don't think so. But if you really want to be sure, we can ask the cameramen."
Contestants appear to soak up the abuse. Anne Martel Mahoney, a creative assistant with New Line Cinema in Los Angeles, met Mr. Stein in the parking lot before the show. He wished her good luck. "I told him that we were going to kick" his backside, she said.
The slash was hardly forgotten. When Ms. Mahoney hadn't answered a question during the first few minutes of the show, Mr. Stein paused in the taping to tell her that she was there to play, too, and that she could begin any time she wanted.
"I found Ben to be absolutely charming," Ms. Mahoney said afterward. "Everyone involved with the show was very friendly. They really made it a lot of fun. I would do it again. Ben's so diligent and knows so much about everything. You want to beat him."
Mr. Stein may stimulate such feelings. Mention his name to some of his former Wall Street Journal colleagues -- he was a television columnist at the paper -- and they roll their eyes and smirk; acquaintances often describe him as a self-promoter, a term that makes the star bristle.
"What does this term, self-promoter, mean anyway?" Mr. Stein said. "I do very little self-promoting. I wanted to do this game show because I had nothing to do in the afternoon while my wife was at work and my son was at school. It's very lonely writing all day, so I decided to give this a try."
Mr. Stein taped four shows a day earlier this summer. Between each, he snoozes and listens to the original cast recording of "Hair," then changes into a new set of clothes, usually a gray or blue suit he has brought from home.
"These aren't power clothes," he said. "These are clothes for fat people." He said he and Mr. Golder had come up with a theory: "That this is the show for fat people. If you watch, the person who has the widest hips in the opening round usually always wins. I love it. I come home and I don't feel fat now that I've spent time with so many people who are heavier than I am."
So why the game show? "Let me tell you something," Mr. Stein explained during a recent dinner at Morton's in West Hollywood. "The easiest way to make money is to steal it and not pay it back. I've seen it all the time. This game show is a way to give people money."
What sounds like unvarnished capitalist talk may, in fact, not play well in some conservative circles even if the show is a hit. Although he is a vocal opponent of abortion, Mr. Stein has other, more liberal views.
"I just don't see how you can discriminate against someone just because they are gay," Mr. Stein said. "Some of my closest friends are gay, and it really makes me angry to think that they may not be treated fairly because of some silly bias. If people get a lesson about conservatives from the show, I hope they learn that we are not all what they think we are."
Madison Avenue is already betting on "Win Ben Stein's Money!" Coca-Cola, American Express, the Gap and Coors have bought space on Comedy Central's prime-time lineup and will rotate ads on the show. Microsoft and Intel are set to begin later this year.
And there's always the chance of a cult following.
Michael Jackman, a lawyer in Van Nuys, Calif., was one of only 15 people so far who walked away with $5,000 of Mr. Stein's money.
"How do I like the show? It was great," Mr. Jackman said. "I'm going to use this money to pay my student loans. Hey, Ben is a great guy. And he's real smart. So what if he didn't know what was the capital of Nebraska? Neither did I."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Anne Martel Mahoney and Steve Tuckey go for the gold of their host, right, during a taping of "Win Ben Stein's Money!" (Marissa Roth for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
Creating a Parachute For a New Solo Flier

SERIES: FRESH START -- A periodic look at the crossraods of personal finance.

BYLINE: By LAURIE J. FLYNN 

 BODY:
JANICE CROTTY hasn't got a job, but it doesn't seem to bother her.
Ms. Crotty, 31, last month gave up her $72,000-a-year position as a new-media editor at Netscape Communications to set up shop as a freelance Internet consultant. She hopes to do work for companies that are setting up their first World Wide Web sites or revamping the ones they already have. 
 And from all appearances, her timing may be just right: in Ms. Crotty's trendy San Francisco neighborhood on the south side of the city's multimedia gulch, nearly every building is home to some kind of Internet-related business.
"There's much more work out there than can be done," said Ms. Crotty, an Ohio native who likes to create collages in her spare time. She already has two clients lined up and can charge $100 an hour -- a rate that may double once she gains more experience.
This is the second attempt by Ms. Crotty, who seems born to be her own boss, at self-employment. Early last year she left her job as an editor at Gamepro magazine, a computer-game publication owned by the International Data Group, to become a freelance editor. Yet even after Netscape lured her away with what she calls a "dream job," she said she "never gave up that original vision of wanting to be independent."
In fact, her responsibilities at Netscape for Web page design and Internet business strategy "blew open my vision for what my job could be," she said. That idea, coupled with a disdain for the hourlong commute to Netscape's headquarters, she said, encouraged her to go out on her own again.
Barbara Gilliard, who owns Emeritus Investment Management, a financial planning firm in San Francisco, likes Ms. Crotty's approach. "She's not afraid," said Ms. Gilliard, who was asked by The New York Times to review Ms. Crotty's finances. "She knows she's heading down the right path and she knows she's taking some risks."
But Ms. Crotty also has much to do, Ms. Gilliard said. To start her own business, she must set priorities -- delegating bookkeeping and other tasks so she can have time to secure clients. And she should talk to a business lawyer to settle quickly legal questions like whether to incorporate.
Keeping expenses down is another important chore, Ms. Gilliard said. Ms. Crotty's goal for her first year is to match her Netscape take-home pay of $3,200 a month, and with the boom in the Web business she may well succeed. But the newly self-employed should always plan for adversity.
That is especially true for Ms. Crotty, who has few assets. While she has almost no debt aside from a $13,000 loan on a new car at 7.5 percent interest, her only nonretirement assets are a $4,000 account at a credit union, $2,500 due to her in insurance reimbursements and $2,000 owed by her clients.
Ms. Crotty has already cut her expenses considerably. A few months ago, she moved from a one-bedroom apartment in San Francisco's gentrified Noe Valley district, which she had rented with her husband until they separated in October 1995, to a 2,500-square-foot loft that she shares with two friends in the less expensive Potrero Hill neighborhood. Each roommate has her own bedroom, but the three share the rest of the loft, including a large open area where they work. Ms. Crotty's "office" consists of a desk, a computer and a phone line.
Her share of the rent is $640, compared with the $800 she spent for her Noe Valley apartment. Her other major monthly expenses are $270 for the car loan; $100 total for telephone expenses and utilities; $150 for car and renter's insurance, and $100 for health insurance. Food, including eating out, comes to about $350, for total monthly expenditures of $1,610.
To trim costs further, Ms. Crotty, who says she rarely goes to the doctor, is taking Ms. Gilliard's advice and shopping for a health insurance policy with a low premium and a high deductible. She also hopes to cut back on other spending, she said.
Ms. Gilliard recommends that Ms. Crotty have three months of living expenses in an emergency fund. If Web consultants were not in such demand, Ms. Gilliard said, a six-month cushion might be better.
SETTING out to be one's own boss brings opportunities as well as risks, however, and an often-ignored one is the chance to reinvest retirement money. Ms. Crotty has $34,000 in tax-deferred retirement accounts from her jobs at International Data Group and Netscape, and now that she is on her own she can move those funds to any of thousands of possible investments, compared with the handful of options available through typical workplace plans.
Ms. Crotty's retirement accounts include about $20,000 in I.D.G. stock and $7,000 in I.D.G.'s 401(k) plan, allocated as follows: $4,200 in the Twentieth Century Ultra fund and $1,400 each in the Aetna Small Company fund and the Neuberger & Berman Guardian fund. She also has $7,000 in Netscape's 401(k) plan, divided among three Fidelity funds: Contrafund ($4,200), Emerging Growth and Equity Income ($1,400 each).
Ms. Gilliard generally recommends that Ms. Crotty roll this $34,000 in retirement funds into a more diversified portfolio that emphasizes long-term growth. "She's so young and she wouldn't need to touch it until she was 59," Ms. Gilliard said.
The $34,000 should be transferred to four mutual funds, the planner advises. She would put 40 percent in the Dodge & Cox Stock fund, which invests in large companies like Coca-Cola and I.B.M.; 25 percent in GAM International, a foreign fund; 20 percent in Oakmark, a mid-cap fund, and 15 percent in Longleaf Partners Small Cap. Over the last three years, the average annual returns of the four funds have been impressive -- 28 percent, 20 percent, 25 percent and 21 percent, respectively.
Ms. Gilliard cautions, however, that the recent high returns reflect the bull market. She says that over the long term they will probably post lower results.
"You want to be exposed to a range of markets" to help minimize the risk, Ms. Gilliard said in explaining her fund choices. While her recommendations include funds specializing in companies of different sizes -- just as Ms. Crotty's current fund choices do -- Ms. Gilliard's funds allow for more ways to diversify the assets. The foreign fund offers one such route, but perhaps the most important is the removal of the high risk of keeping 59 percent of Ms. Crotty's retirement money in the stock of just one company, in this case I.D.G.
While many of the mutual funds in Ms. Crotty's 401(k) plans are fine investments, Ms. Gilliard's selection shows the advantage of having a wide choice: On average, her four suggested funds have better three-year performance ratings from Morningstar than do the current 401(k) funds.
Whatever her choices, Ms. Crotty should not stop adding to her retirement accounts even though she is just starting out on her own, said Dirk Gilliard, a financial planner who runs Emeritus with his mother.
Ms. Crotty has plenty of other chores as she becomes her own boss. After 20 months of separation from her husband, she and he need to get the divorce they plan, Ms. Gilliard said. Although Ms. Crotty said she and her husband had already agreed on the division of their assets, the planner said, "You should clean things up and start out fresh."
But Ms. Crotty, as a single person with no children, will be able to take it easy on some fronts, like life insurance.
Also, she should limit how much attention she pays to daily work, the planner said.
"Take time to review; don't just keep plugging along," Ms. Gilliard advised. "You need to keep yourself on track and make sure you're meeting your goals."

GRAPHIC: Photo: To cut expenses, Janice Crotty moved to a loft that she shares with two friends in San Francisco's Potrero Hill neighborhood. (Anne Dowie for The New York Times)

PUB-DATE: July 27, 1997

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 3; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 3204 words

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
A Teachers' Pet Is Facing the Hounds

BYLINE: By REED ABELSON 

 BODY:
JOHN H. BIGGS may command a $2.4 million compensation package and rule a $200 billion investment empire, but he does not think or talk the way most corporate chieftains do.
Mr. Biggs is chairman and chief executive of the Teachers Insurance and Annuity Association-College Retirement Equities Fund, the world's biggest pension system. And he remains stubbornly true to the organization's paternalistic roots. Founded 79 years ago by the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching to insure that the nation's college professors did not starve in old age, T.I.A.A.-C.R.E.F. has always sought to shield unsophisticated investors from too many choices and too much risk. 
 "My view is that we don't want anything in our menus that could really do damage to our participants," Mr. Biggs, 61, said in a recent interview in his office at the group's Manhattan headquarters. "We have never bagged them with an awful result."
The group serves some two million people, including current and retired college and university employees, as well as employees of other nonprofit groups. Ever vigilant of the long-term interests of his charges, Mr. Biggs is fighting a provision in the tax bill, now in Congress, to strip his organization of its tax-exempt status. He is doing so even though the change would give his pension fund the opportunity to branch out into new areas, like the corporate retirement market, that it had been leery of entering for fear of losing its exemption. "If the bill passes, we would roar ahead," Mr. Biggs said. "We would win the whole world -- but lose our soul."
When it comes to a possibility that makes for-profit ventures like Fidelity Investments or Merrill Lynch salivate -- the privatization of the Social Security system -- Mr. Biggs is equally boastful, and just as high-minded. "We would clean up -- there is no question we would be a popular choice" as a vendor, he said.
But the idea holds no appeal for him. His group, he said, "is not the right model" because it fails to guarantee people a fixed amount of money when they retire.
Too many people, he said, could end up like his former headmaster at a small Midwestern private school, who opted out of Social Security in the 1950's when doing so was still legal. "He became a real stock-market plunger" and lost everything at age 61, Mr. Biggs recalled. The school, its trustees and its alumni, including Mr. Biggs, supported him for the next 20 years out of their own pockets.
It is that kind of concern that Mr. Biggs took to the pension system. "T.I.A.A., conscious of its special privilege, always had a paternalistic attitude -- namely, that the purpose of setting aside money is your old-age retirement," said Paul A. Samuelson, the Nobel laureate economist, who is a former C.R.E.F. trustee.
Despite its lofty principles, the teachers' pension fund until recently displayed some of the worst traits of a virtual monopoly. For most of its history, the group lived a rarefied existence, as removed from the pressures of the marketplace as the academics it served. With few competitors, it saw little need to be responsive to its customers. Until the late 1980's, when competition from hungry mutual funds arrived, it gave them only two investment choices, fixed-income or stocks, and it made it impossible for them to take any money out of the fixed-income account until retirement.
"Paternalism was a mild word applied to us," said Mr. Biggs, an economist and actuary by training who spent nearly 20 years at the General American Life Insurance Company and headed the Centerre Trust Company before joining T.I.A.A.-C.R.E.F. as its president in 1989. He was named the organization's chairman and chief executive in 1993.
THE arrival of competitors like Fidelity Investments and the Vanguard Group, the mutual fund giants, forced the pension system kicking and screaming into the real world. Under new leadership, the behemoth began to address the lack of investment alternatives and flexibility for its participants by increasing its offerings and being more responsive. "There has been an enormous change," said Roy A. Schotland, a law professor at Georgetown University, who was among those faculty members who pushed for change.
But the group remains convinced that it knows best. Participants continue to be frustrated by a lack of choice: They are still unable to put their money in an account that buys only foreign stocks or the stocks of the fastest-growing companies. "The assumption is that you are not given a choice because you're grossly incompetent to make the choice," said Eugene Lerner, a money manager in Evanston, Ill., who keeps some retirement money at the organization from his days as a finance professor at Northwestern University.
The group's high ideals and its authoritarian temperament make it an odd success in today's freewheeling, hyper-competitive environment.
And that incongruity raises a compelling question: Is there a place for this not-for-profit throwback in a financial-services industry dominated by profit-driven companies obsessed with selling as many products as possible and getting the highest returns?
The answer seems to be yes.
First of all, T.I.A.A.-C.R.E.F. is not about to go away. Despite all the competition, Mr. Biggs remains very much a financial-services titan, in the same league as Fidelity's chairman, Edward C. Johnson 3d, or Travelers' chairman, Sanford I. Weill. His $200 billion under management makes the group the largest pension system in the world, and T.I.A.A. is the third-largest life insurance company in the United States. The group owns roughly 7,000 stocks, and its real estate holdings include the Mall of America in Bloomington, Minn., and the Seagram Building at Park Avenue and 53d Street in Manhattan. Its flagship stock account is one and a half times the size of Fidelity Magellan, the nation's largest mutual fund.
Having made substantial changes, the group has satisfied many of its critics. Just as important, however, is that a lot of people like to have somebody else decide where to invest their money for them, and they trust the teachers' retirement system to do a good job. They also like the fact that it is a nonprofit group that keeps expenses at a minimum. "Our customers believe our only purpose in being is to serve them," said Thomas W. Jones, the vice chairman, president and chief operating officer.
Some participants have developed strong ties to the organization. "T.I.A.A.-C.R.E.F. maintains what just has to be an extraordinarily enviable loyalty," said Ron Bush, a senior vice president for Access Research, a Windsor, Conn., consulting firm that specializes in the retirement market.
The organization also benefits from the tremendous confusion over the potpourri of investment choices in the marketplace. While companies typically select a single vendor for their employees' retirement plans, universities often allow just about any financial-services firm in their doors to peddle its retirement products. Employees face a dizzying array of investment options, and many have chosen the teachers' pension system for its simplicity. The group is able to hold onto assets because it remains difficult for customers to withdraw money from the traditional fixed-income account.
Moreover, fund groups have difficulty matching T.I.A.A.-C.R.E.F.'s one-on-one sessions with faculty and staff. At Stanford University, for example, employees can go to the group's nearby regional office, one of 11 around the country, for a bit of hand-holding. "It's easy for them to be a presence on campus," said James Franklin, the associate vice president for total compensation at Stanford. Other vendors presumably could open such centers, too, but it is not the way they traditionally do business.
One might think that a group with this many Ph.D.'s among its clientele would not need to offer so much instruction. But Mr. Biggs says the emphasis on education has been key to its success in fending off competition. "We do a lot of counseling," he said. "That is the future of the company. Our products may be less important; our investment performance may be less important." He hopes to capitalize on this expertise by setting up a fee-based financial planning service, for the organization's wealthier clients, as a taxable operation next year.
For all Mr. Biggs's talk about not craving the highest returns, the group's investment performance has been good enough.
Participants typically use their dollars to buy annuities, which promise either a fixed stream of income through T.I.A.A. upon retirement or, for the more adventurous, a variable stream of income whose performance depends on stocks through C.R.E.F.
Its $93 billion variable-annuity stock account, for example, invests about half of its assets in stocks tied to the Russell 3000 index, which is composed of the 3,000 largest public companies, and splits the remainder between foreign and domestic stocks that it hopes will outperform.
In the decade through June 30, the account gained an average of 13 percent a year, placing it in the top fifth of its peer group, according to Morningstar Inc., the Chicago research firm. And over the last three years, it has gained 23 percent a year, versus the 27 percent annual return of the Russell 3000. The account's international holdings help explain its lag.
The account certainly has not beaten the market, but who has? "It seems like they do an adequate job," said Robert Jennings, a finance professor at Indiana University who is also a client. "I'm not looking for the last basis point in return."
The teachers' pension system has also been able to use its tremendous size and efficient operations to keep expenses extraordinarily low. The average expense on its annuities is 0.32 percent of assets, including the cost of the insurance that is in the accounts, compared with an industry average of 2.16 percent, according to Morningstar. "It's a terrific bargain," said Mr. Schotland of Georgetown University.
But even if the pension system were to lose its tax exemption, its competitors would hardly be dancing in the street. "We don't lose business to T.I.A.A. because of its tax-exempt status," said Ellyn A. McColgan, the president of the Fidelity Investments subsidiary that is dedicated to the not-for-profit retirement market.
INDEED, after the big mutual fund groups invaded its turf in the 1980's, they discovered, much to their dismay, that the teachers' pension system could slowly transform itself by broadening its array of products and improving service.
Today, participants have a choice of 10 investment options, five of which have been introduced since 1992, including a global stock account, a growth stock account, a socially conscious stock account, a money-market account and an account consisting entirely of the Treasury's new inflation-linked bonds. It has also introduced the T.I.A.A. Real Estate Account, intended to capitalize on its long experience in the real estate market. Instead of investing in real estate investment trusts, a more standard vehicle, the account invests directly in office and residential complexes and in industrial and retail facilities.
On the service side, telephone calls are answered more promptly than they were several years ago, and transfers among accounts have been made much easier.
The group has become "a good competitor," said Ms. McColgan of Fidelity. Added William McNabb, a senior vice president at the Vanguard Group, the. "The fact is that they do a pretty good job."
The investment group, which has increased the number of participants by two-thirds since 1988, to a bit more than two million, and has nearly tripled the assets under its management to $200 billion, still controls about half the estimated not-for-profit retirement market. The second-largest private provider to this market, with about $25 billion in assets, is the Variable Annuity Life Insurance Company, a subsidiary of American General. Variable Annuity focuses largely on the secondary-school market. Fidelity, the rapidly growing No. 3, is right behind, managing about $24 billion.
KEEPING the mutual fund groups and the insurers at bay remains a tough challenge for Mr. Biggs and his colleagues. They are "fighting desperately," said Louis S. Harvey, the publisher of Variable Annuity Market News in Boston. "They are remarkable in how good they are but how slow to change," he said.
Mr. Biggs, though, says he is more worried about the competition from the state-run pension systems, whose chunk of the market is not closely tracked but is widely believed to exceed that of everyone but T.I.A.A.-C.R.E.F. And the group is clearly making headway against them. By persuading more and more states like Ohio and Kentucky to allow higher-education employees to opt out of the state systems, it has increased its share of the 3.5 million people working for colleges and universities from about 25 percent eight years ago to 40 percent today. His goal is a none-too-modest 60 percent.
His critics, of course, say Mr. Biggs's group has an unfair advantage, that it is getting a free ride from the Federal Government. Although the organization has been taxed on the portion of its business devoted to selling life and disability insurance since 1986, it still receives an exemption for its much-larger pension business. And others, including Representative Bill Archer, the Texas Republican who was the chief author of the House tax bill, say that just isn't right.
Mr. Archer's bill would force the group to pay taxes on the earnings from its retirement business, particularly on the lush income it earns from the reserves it sets aside each year to back the promises it makes under its annuity contracts.
Congress estimates that taxing the organization on the earnings from its retirement business would generate roughly $1.1 billion in revenue over 10 years. In typical horse-trading fashion, taxing T.I.A.A. remains in the bill's latest version. But to ease the pain, Congress has dropped the idea of taxing tuition aid for children of college professors and staff as well tuition-reduction plans for graduate students.
The group's competitors argue that the proposed legislation would also level the playing field.
"Our position is this: They do the same kind of business we do. We pay taxes, and they should pay taxes," said Thomas L. West Jr., president of Variable Annuity Life Insurance. Although the insurer is based in Mr. Archer's home district, Mr. West said his company was not behind the push for new tax treatment.
While Mr. Archer squares off against Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the New York Democrat and former Harvard professor who has historically been able to protect the teachers' group, participants worry about the impact of such taxes on their pension paychecks. Because all profits eventually flow back to its participants in the form of higher dividends on their annuities, "the tax exemption is worth a lot to our participants," Mr. Biggs said.
He estimated that current retirees would be hit with a decline of 3 percent to 5 percent in their monthly annuity income while future retirees could see a drop of 10 percent to 15 percent. And Mr. Biggs said that dipping into the group's $4.7 billion contingency reserves to make up the difference would be a last resort, because it might endanger the firm's high ratings from independent agencies like A. M. Best.
As he spars with his adversaries in Congress --a battle that he is so far losing -- Mr. Biggs must also contend with dissatisfaction from customers. Many participants remain frustrated at the lack of control they have over their money.
Mr. Biggs argues that the few accounts offered are true to their label. And Martin L. Liebowitz, the chief investment officer recruited two years ago from Salomon Brothers, where he headed the brokerage's research department, argues that the group's lack of choices has not hurt the participants. Those participants, he points out, include his wife. "The legacy has served a large body of T.I.A.A.-C.R.E.F. participants very, very well," he said.
Still, investors are given surprisingly little information about how they are managed. Competitors like Fidelity and Vanguard have been forced to tell their shareholders how the portfolio managers are investing their money, but the teachers' pension system remains relatively mum. "Even as well run as T.I.A.A.-C.R.E.F. is, it's not an open book," said Mr. McNabb of Vanguard.
THE C.R.E.F. stock account, for example, invests a sizable chunk of its huge assets in stocks that are hand-picked by the portfolio manager and his staff. "C.R.E.F. experts invest in companies they think will perform better than the stock market in general," explains the guide to the different accounts.
The prospectus and other literature are hardly more specific. Although the group publishes its portfolio twice a year, as required by Federal regulators, it does not routinely break out its largest holdings or divide the portfolio into different categories, like small stocks.
Virgil H. Cummings, who oversees the group's investments, offers only this description of their investment style: The team takes a "bottom-up, research-oriented" approach.
And Mr. Liebowitz acknowledged, "The approach is very eclectic."
Only this year has the group introduced a newsletter, Investment Forum, to tell the participants more about how the accounts are invested. The first issue featured the international holdings, listing the top 10 overseas investments, although not by account. That, the group says, is an indication that it is working on being more open.
The information gap makes life difficult for people with a clear idea of how they want to invest their retirement money. For example, those who want to put a specific amount in foreign stocks may be attracted to the Global Equity Account. "The trouble is, it's not a pure international fund," said John Harrigan, a professor at Hamline University in St. Paul. In fact, the main stock account is invested in more countries than the Global Equity account is, and both accounts have a big position in Worldcom Inc., a Jackson, Miss., telecommunications outfit, the group said last week.
While most participants probably do not mind the dearth of information, some do -- passionately. After one participant, Daniel R. Mandelker, a law professor at Washington University in St. Louis, could not get the answers he wanted to his questions a few years ago, he moved most of his nest egg to Vanguard.
Still, it is tough for some people to come down too hard on a venture that, for all its faults, does seem to have the best interests of its customers at heart -- and does not have to worry about enriching shareholders.
"The good news is that they don't have a lot of perverse incentives," said Donald R. Chambers, a finance professor at Lafayette College in Pennsylvania who has a retirement account with T.I.A.A.-C.R.E.F.. "The bad news is that they have no incentives." Still, he is not sure he would want the group to look more like its competitors. "There are an awful lot of lousy mutual funds out there," he said.
