HEADLINE: Political Notes;
At Times, Campaign Can Be Its Own Opponent

BYLINE: By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

 BODY:
Ruth W. Messinger went to a nut-roasting factory at Hunts Point in the Bronx the other day to draw attention to news that the city's unemployment rate had inched up to 10 percent, and to assert that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani was doing nothing about it.
So it was a bit of a surprise when Rocco Damato, the president of the A. L. Bazzini Company and the host of her daily campaign event, included the Giuliani administration in his list of government bodies that were instrumental in the company's decision to move his 100-job plant to the Bronx. He had intended to move to North Carolina. 
 "The city has put together a very, very, very aggressive package that if more people knew about, there would be dozens of Bazzinis open," Mr. Damato said as Ms. Messinger, the likely Democratic mayoral candidate, looked on wanly. "I'm saying, 'Hurray for the city, broad-based.' "
It was the kind of event that makes most political campaign managers shudder. For Ms. Messinger, it was the latest in a series of mishaps that have occurred in the three weeks since she began daily campaigning.
The day before her campaign stop at the nut factory (itself the kind of location that most campaigns rigorously avoid, because of the unkind metaphors they invite), Ms. Messinger's aides instructed reporters to contact Robert R. Kiley of the New York City Partnership and Raymond D. Horton of the Citizens Budget Commission for information on her budget plan.
But neither man had been warned that they were about to be enlisted in Ms. Messinger's campaign. And neither was particularly appreciative -- all the more so because Messinger campaign officials gave reporters the numbers of Mr. Horton's summer home and Mr. Kiley's unlisted apartment.
"I'm flabbergasted," Mr. Horton said. Mr. Kiley wouldn't talk to reporters, but issued a terse statement saying: "The campaign office of Ruth Messinger gave out my name and home number without talking to me."
Some Democrats said they were worried about indications of haplessness in Ms. Messinger's campaign. But Ms. Messinger's aides said there was nothing more at play than the growing pains of a quickly expanding organization.
"A challenger is always under examination, especially this early in a race, for mistakes," Leland T. Jones, Ms. Messinger's spokesman, said. "And I think when they make a tiny mistake sometimes, they tend to get a lot of attention."
 
New, but Familiar
Four years ago, Mr. Giuliani's campaign protested when the Metropolitan Transportation Authority used radio advertisements in which Mayor David N. Dinkins took credit for keeping fares down. The advertising campaign "undermines the integrity of the Public Campaign Finance law," Peter J. Powers, Mr. Giuliani's campaign manager, wrote in a protest to the Campaign Finance Board in 1993.
Times have changed. On Thursday, Mr. Giuliani showed up with a transportation authority camera crew at the subway stop at 53d Street and Lexington Avenue to promote the use of the Metrocard. It was the second instance in which publicly financed advertisements will allow Mr. Giuliani to promote the card and the change which now allows users a free transfer between bus and subway. In this case, Mr. Giuliani will probably share a spot in the authority's advertisements with Claire Shulman, the Queens Borough President, a popular Democrat who is considering endorsing Mr. Giuliani this fall.
What has changed since Mr. Powers wrote his letter saying such expenditures subverted the campaign finance laws, and urging the board to count them against Mr. Dinkins's campaign spending limits? The Campaign Finance Board ruled against Mr. Giuliani then, and the Mayor's aides said yesterday that he now felt entitled to do what his predecessor had done. "The guidelines that applied to the former Mayor, as established by the board, also apply to this campaign," said Sunny Mindel, the Mayor's campaign spokesman.
Randy M. Mastro, a deputy mayor, said the Mayor appeared at the invitation of the authority. He said he did not know the total cost of the advertising campaign but that it was a legitimate expenditure of public funds because it was "educational." In the ads, the Mayor instructs riders how they need to buy a Metrocard to take advantage of the new one-fare policy.
Mr. Jones, Ms. Messinger's spokesman, had a different view. "It's an extremely inappropriate use of public funds in a campaign year," he said. "He is basically ripping off taxpayers to run for re-election."
For the record: Notwithstanding Mr. Giuliani's appearance before the cameras, he neither has a Metrocard nor needs one. The Mayor, for security reasons, does not generally use the city's buses and subways.
 
Messinger Gets Funds
 Ms. Messinger received some good news last week as the Campaign Finance Board awarded her public funds matching her private funds. Ms. Messinger got a check for $1.1 million, part of $2.2 million given to 27 candidates. Mayoral candidates who apply for matching funds have to raise a minimum of $250,0000 from 1,000 city residents. Neither of Ms. Messinger's Democratic opponents, Councilman Sal F. Albanese of Brooklyn and the Rev. Al Sharpton, has reached the threshold yet.
Under the program, which is voluntary, the city matches contributions up to $1,000 from city residents. Since Mr. Giuliani does not have a primary, he did not receive a check now, but will in the general election.

HEADLINE: Clinton Vows to Double Federal Money to Preserve Lake Tahoe

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: INCLINE VILLAGE, Nev., July 26

 BODY:
From a research boat on the cobalt-blue waters of Lake Tahoe today, President Clinton watched scientists test the quality of that water and then pledged to double over the next two years the Federal investment in measures to halt the degradation of North America's largest alpine lake.
Mr. Clinton's visit to the 250-square-mile lake in the Sierra Nevada was his second event this week devoted to environmental issues. It was part of an Administration push to showcase efforts that unite environmentalists and business, in this case to insure that the lake, which straddles the California-Nevada border, will not lose its trademark clarity because of soil runoff and boat pollution feeding algae. 
 "One of the reasons I wanted to come here was not only to highlight to the nation the importance of Lake Tahoe," Mr. Clinton said, "but also to show the nation that there is a place where environmentalists and business people and ordinary citizens, where Republicans and Democrats, where tribal leaders and governmental people, where everybody is working together in common cause.
"We cannot divide our quest for prosperity from our obligation to hand nature -- God's great gift to us -- on down through the generations."
Besides riding the research boat, the President signed an executive order committing the Government to actions to save the lake and participated in two hours of discussions moderated by Vice President Al Gore. Mr. Gore, who had come to the area a day earlier, was clearly involved in one of his favorite issues and was also following Mr. Clinton's tradition of lavishing attention on causes important to California, a crucial electoral state.
"When I saw the Vice President this morning he was virtually glowing, and I knew he had been here in his element," Mr. Clinton joked to those gathered for the discussion session. "And the minute we got on the boat I got my Marine Biology 101 lecture about phosphorous, nitrogen, what does what, what does the other."
Mr. Gore himself said, "Lake Tahoe demonstrates clearly that the economy is the environment and the environment is the economy."
Celebrated by Mark Twain a century ago as "the fairest picture the whole earth affords," Lake Tahoe has been losing its legendary clarity by more than a foot a year because of local development. Scientists say that without remedial measures the lake has less than 30 years before it turns gray-green.
Twenty million visitors a year come to the Tahoe basin for skiing and hiking, for gambling and for the lake. Last month the Tahoe Regional Planning Agency, a joint California-Nevada authority that regulates regional development, voted to ban jet skis starting in 1999. The agency also has compiled a list of reclamation projects expected to cost nearly $1 billion over more than a decade. Officials are hoping that the Federal Government will pick up about $300 million of those costs.
Mr. Clinton made a down payment today, saying that over the next two years the Federal Government would spend $26.6 million on projects to preserve the region, above the $12 million a year that the Government has already been spending here.
Two of the envisioned Federal projects require action by Congress: the allocation of $7 million for a pipeline to carry waste water out of the Tahoe basin and $1.5 million to create a transit center where people would leave their cars and ride shuttle buses to reduce traffic congestion and pollution.

HEADLINE: When Healing Collides With the Drive for Profits

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON 

 BODY:
Behind the resignation on Friday of the top executive of Columbia/ HCA, the world's largest health care company, lie the same pressures to satisfy Wall Street that have confounded other for-profit hospital chains.
The executive, Richard L. Scott, has been the most visible proponent of the philosophy behind for-profit hospitals -- that healthy patients and healthy profits do not conflict. In less than a decade, he built Columbia into a $20 billion company with about 350 hospitals and hundreds of other treatment centers. 
 But Federal investigators are now asking whether the Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation achieved its profits partly through fraud -- by overstating their expenses to increase their compensation from Federal programs like Medicare, for example, and by regularly conducting unnecessary blood tests. Mr. Scott's grudging responses apparently contributed to his downfall.
In some ways, the profit-driven companies like Columbia have set higher standards in how hospitals operate, cutting costs with greater buying power and leaner bureaucracies. Many administrators at not-for-profit hospitals agree that their for-profit competitors have forced them to become far more efficient.
Some for-profit hospital companies have prospered without a hint of impropriety. But their greater challenge is generating profits in a business where the Government and private employers limit their payments and where not-for-profit competitors have joined together -- to buy supplies, for example -- to achieve the same economies of scale.
"On virtually every single study, there are no cost differences between the profits and the nonprofits," said Gerard Anderson, director of the Johns Hopkins Center for Hospital Finance and Management in Baltimore. The investor-owned chains are left in an ethical quandary, he said. "In order to generate substantial profit margins," he said, "they need to take some liberties."
Columbia is only the latest example of a for-profit hospital chain that has run into legal or financial woes in its efforts to provide shareholders with returns more common to the makers of software or soda water.
In 1993, National Medical Enterprises and its psychiatric hospitals were accused by the Government of bribing doctors for their patients, taking in patients who did not need treatment and then keeping them against their will until their insurance ran out. National Medical's successor company, renamed the Tenet Healthcare Corporation and now the nation's second-largest hospital chain, paid $379 million to settle the Federal accusations. Tenet has in recent days been negotiating to merge with Columbia.
The Humana Corporation, the most daring chain before the rise of Columbia, faced patient lawsuits and Federal and state inquiries into its pricing and billing: among other items, $7 Tylenol tablets and $5,000 in charges for an operation that cost the company about $1,200. Columbia later absorbed Humana's hospitals.
Several other hospital chains were forced into bankruptcy or mergers in the late 1980's after they built too many hospitals or failed to adapt to lower Medicare payments.
The pursuit of higher revenue has also affected not-for-profit hospitals, which make up 85 percent of the nation's total. The competitive new world of health care has led some of the most vaunted not-for-profit institutions to break the law, too. Over the last year, the Government has broadly investigated the nation's largest teaching hospitals to determine whether they have fraudulently double-billed Medicare for certain services. Already, two teaching hospitals in Pennsylvania have agreed to pay more than $40 million to settle charges of fraud.
The investor-owned chains argue that only they have the financial discipline to cut costs and raise efficiency, themes that play well in the battle against medical inflation. But charity hospitals can do as well. In Houston, Dr. Denton A. Cooley's Texas Heart Institute at St. Luke's Episcopal Hospital does heart bypasses for about a third less than most other hospitals, with healthier outcomes as well.
Some experts wonder how long Columbia can keep up its performance no matter what its tactics. The company, said Jeff Goldsmith, a health care consultant, has had to keep buying hospitals at bargain prices to maintain its profit margins and its appeal to investors. Even though the company's stock has fallen from its peak, investors still value it at about $25 billion.
But the hospital chains, including some not-for-profit groups, have a tough time squeezing higher surpluses, from their hospitals year after year. Saving money through bulk ordering of bandages is one thing, but saving through cuts in hospital staffs and procedural shortcuts has clear limits. "These institutions are vastly more complicated than any business," Mr. Goldsmith said. "You are literally custom-making a product for everyone who comes in."

GRAPHIC: Chart: "Health Care Consolidation"
When Richard L. Scott entered the hospital business in 1987, he faced a fragmented field of often-troubled competitors. Today, the greater part of the for-profit hospital world has been consolidated under his company, the Columbina/HCA Healthcare Corporation. Even the largest competitor, Tenet Healthcare, has been in merger negotiations with Columbia. The chart shows how the number of Healthcare companies has diminished through mergers since the 1980's, with Columbia/HCA totally dominating the field at the present time. (Source: American Hospital Association)

PUB-DATE: July 27, 1997

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1; Column 2; National Desk 

LENGTH: 5242 words

HEADLINE: BETWEEN BLACK AND WHITE -- A Special Report;
Questions of Race Run Deep for Foe of Preferences

BYLINE: By BARRY BEARAK 

DATELINE: SACRAMENTO, Calif.

 BODY:
By society's measure, he emerged black from the gene pool, a peculiar arithmetic that Ward Connerly insists he has never understood.
"One drop of blood does it," he said, reviewing the computation: 25 percent black plus 37.5 percent Irish plus 25 percent French plus 12.5 percent Choctaw equals 100 percent black. "I suppose I could claim to be Irish, but who wants to stand there and argue the point every time? So I'm black." 
 Cocoa-brown skin is the product of his amalgamated ancestry. And however much a hindrance the color may have been in other endeavors, it now offers him a paradoxical advantage, for Mr. Connerly has become the nation's most active opponent of racial preferences. His blackness, he agrees with some reluctance, grants many whites a kind of absolution, allowing them to protest affirmative action "without having to feel like they appear racist."
Wardell Anthony Connerly, 58, a millionaire businessman with the oratorical gallop of an evangelist, is the man who successfully led the challenge against California's racial bookkeeping, first in his position as a regent in the university system, then as head of last year's statewide ballot measure -- Proposition 209 -- that banned state and local governments from using racial and sexual preferences in hiring, contracting and college admissions.
Now Mr. Connerly has taken his crusade nationwide, pushing for similar referendums in other states and for a bill in Congress.
But while he deals boldly and directly with his cause, he has kept a psychic distance from his roots. Whatever the impact on his current beliefs, Mr. Connerly grew up in an extended family whose secrets seem to leap from the pages of Faulkner. Although his story may not suggest any new answers regarding the rights and wrongs of affirmative action, it does offer compelling insight into the difficult subject of race in America..
All his life, Mr. Connerly has mistakenly believed he was rejected by his black father. He was reared by his mother's side of the family in a milieu not uncommon to their Louisiana beginnings. Some of his relatives appraised social status by gradations of color, the lighter the better. Deep racial hurts have never been spoken of, wives to husbands, mothers to sons and daughters.
Mr. Connerly considers himself black "because blackness is an experience and others have thrust that experience upon me." He, on the other hand, claims to be not only blind to pigment but a celebrator of the continuous blending in the melting pot. "In 10 to 15 years, intermarriage will make this entire debate a moot one, anyhow, and we'll wonder why we didn't see it coming," he said.
His political efforts come at a time when the courts have already been paring the parameters of affirmative action -- and even many of its defenders believe course corrections are in order. President Clinton has labeled his own approach "mend it, don't end it."
Mr. Connerly's slogan could well be "nix it, don't fix it." He wants to set aside the bulky, contested ledger on America's racial debits and credits.
"You can't un-ring the bell on slavery," he said. "All you can do is make sure the next person who walks through the door, white or black, receives equal treatment."
Given such views, Mr. Connerly finds himself both rousingly cheered for his courage and jeered for his collaboration, a smart cookie to some, a disloyal Oreo to others. Newspaper cartoonists are fond of placing him beside allies in Klan robes. Outside of movie stars, his face has become one of the best known in California.
While most of the changes here have yet to take effect -- and others are tied up in court -- the momentousness of the upheaval is already evident: after the law school at the University of California at Berkeley was forced to stop using racial preferences, only 14 black students were selected among 792 admissions for the fall. Not one of the blacks has chosen to enroll.
"That's the bad news, yes," Mr. Connerly said. "But no one talks about the good news, that 14 black students were admissible and, if they had chosen to attend, no one would have questioned their right to be there."
He is a courtly man who speaks in gusts, airing his ideas in resonant sentences. His sport coat stays buttoned in 100-degree heat, a folded white hanky peeking from its front pocket. His body is plump, his head balding. His eyes are framed by deep bags at the bottom and bushy brows at the top. Extravagantly patriotic, he claims that each day he silently recites -- 6 or 10 times -- the Pledge of Allegiance and the opening lines of the Declaration of Independence.
By his reckoning, some form of affirmative action was justifiable in the lingering days of Jim Crow 30 years ago. But then the remedy, "like an overused antibiotic, became counterproductive." America had the contaminant of discrimination under control by the early 1980's, he has concluded.
He offered estimates. In multiethnic California, "we're at a 9 or a 10 with 10 being the best," he said.
"In other states," he said, "things are probably at a 7 or 8. I'm not sure a Mississippi is at the same point as a California."
Time is of the essence. In 30 years of affirmative action, Mr. Connerly said, blacks have paid a terrible price for preferential treatment, bartering away their self-esteem and the regard of others. "If you're lying on a gurney and a black doctor shows up, you're going to get up and crawl out," he said. Preferences "make every black doctor and lawyer live under a cloud."
As a university regent, Mr. Connerly gets sheaves of reports. One item that recently caught his eye concerned average scores on the SAT, showing that blacks whose parents earned more than $60,000 a year were outscored by whites and Asian-Americans whose families earned $20,000 or less.
"You hear that black kids need a preference because there's no one encouraging them to go to college," he said. "Well, these upper-income kids have parents who are doctors, lawyers, professors, so you can't conclude the problem is at home. I don't rule out the impact of K-through-12 education, but I think it's exaggerated. These Asian kids are going to the same schools as Latinos and blacks and outperforming them. It's time we got a handle on why middle-class black kids from the suburbs are losing out to low-income Asians from the inner city."
Mr. Connerly has read some of the literature on the subject. The answer that seems most plausible to him comes from the psychologist Claude M. Steele, who developed the idea of "stereotype vulnerability." Black students, Mr. Steele says, are overwhelmed by fear of living up to negative ideas about their race, stripping them of confidence.
"Black kids don't go into an athletic competition thinking they're going to lose," Mr. Connerly said. "They save those feelings of inferiority for the classroom. And do you know what reinforces the idea that they're inferior? Being told they need a preference to succeed."
 
His Background
Disputed Memories In Obscured Past
"If I can make it, anyone can," Mr. Connerly has repeatedly said, his customary opener to Horatio Alger-like details of a humble boyhood.
He was born on June 15, 1939, in the west Louisiana town of Leesville, about 20 miles from the Texas border. His father was part black and part Irish, his mother a medley of Choctaw, Irish and French. When Wardell, as he was then called, was only 2, his father, Roy Connerly, left. "He ran out on us," Ward Connerly said. "We never heard from him again." His mother died two years later of a brain tumor.
Wardell went to live with his widowed maternal grandmother, Mary Soniea (pronounced sun-EE-ay), a religious woman, part Irish, part Choctaw, who had freckles afloat in her reddish skin. Her husband had been Cajun, descended from the French immigrants who had settled in Louisiana. Mrs. Soniea had become the family matriarch and owner of a diner and bar on Havana Street in Leesville.
But the matter of who would rear the boy was far from settled. While the Sonieas told Wardell that his father had abandoned him and disappeared, Roy Connerly actually pursued custody zealously. To make sure the child would always stay in their family, Mrs. Soniea sent Wardell out west with her daughter and her son-in-law, Bertha and James Louis, another black man. The couple settled in a poor, primarily black section of Sacramento, Calif.
The Louises were relatively well-off, with their own home and enough money to sometimes give young Wardell a $5 bill for spending money. Mr. Louis, an unlettered man, stacked lumber for a living. He became a role model to his orphaned nephew. "Uncle James had three rules: My shoes had to be shined, the lawn had to be mowed, the car had to be clean," Mr. Connerly recalled with retroactive approval. "He taught me to have pride in myself."
Over time, most of Mary Soniea's children came to settle in Sacramento, and she eventually followed. She built a two-bedroom house for herself and her grandson. She wanted Wardell back. He moved in with her when he was 12.
"Economically, my life went from riches to rags, well, not riches, but from a middle-class life by black standards, with an allowance every Saturday, to one with a single parent who had spent every penny she had on a house and had a mortgage of $35 a month, which she couldn't always meet," Mr. Connerly said.
His description of their poverty is textured with doleful anecdotes: the many mealtimes when they had nothing to eat but sweet potatoes; the day he had to slide cardboard into his shoe to cover a hole in the sole; the time his proud grandmother had to accept money from her church's Poor Folks Fund, only to then suffer the further indignity of applying for public assistance. In every story, he portrays Mary Soniea, who died in 1977, as loving, wise and fair-minded.
But some of Mr. Connerly's relatives in Sacramento, most of them estranged, challenge these depictions of adversity. "Wardell was the little prince of the family because everyone felt sorry for him," said Elizabeth Stansberry, his cousin. "He lived in a nice, carpeted house. They always had meat. My grandmother kept tea cakes out on a platter. She bought French provincial furniture at Breuner's."
Arthur Soniea, Mr. Connerly's codgerly and irascible 75-year-old uncle, said: "That's malarkey about him stuffing paper in his shoes. Another damned lie is that sweet potatoes three times a day. He don't come around here, but if he did," Mr. Soniea said, he would haul his nephew into the woodshed .
William Lee, a newspaper publisher and close friend of Mr. Connerly's since their youth, said: "It upsets me sometimes when Ward plays to his audience. His portrayal of his childhood is very much exaggerated."
However one adds up the sweet potatoes, no one claims that Mr. Connerly grew up in velvet britches, just that his circumstances were difficult but not dire.
More intriguing, though, are recollections by neighbors and relatives of Mary Soniea as a woman with color-stratified prejudices. These memories vary in implication.
"She was well-respected and cared a lot about Ward, but part of that was to keep him away from the bad element and, to her, that more or less meant black," said Willie Hausey, who ran a neighborhood store.
Ms. Stansberry and another cousin, Grace Haynes, go much further, saying that Ward Connerly was reared by an out-and-out bigot, that their late grandmother was openly scornful of black people, including those married to five of her six children.
"Maybe that's why Ward decided to be as much of a white boy as he could," Ms. Stansberry said. "That's the way he was, you know. We'd play cowboys and Indians. He was always the cowboy and we had to turn up dead."
She said Mr. Connerly had tried to create his own past. "Isn't that what this campaign against affirmative action is all about, so Wardell can bring down black people and forget his own blackness?" she asked.
Ms. Haynes agreed with these comments, adding that her grandmother freely used racial slurs like "jigaboo" and "baboon." Other family members also recalled these verbal slights and worse.
Yvonne Soniea, Grace Haynes's elderly mother and Ward Connerly's aunt, refused several requests for an interview before finally answering some questions. Old wounds left by her mother-in-law's barbed tongue still hurt. In the telling, she broke down inconsolably. "I never wanted others in the family to know these things," she said. "These were secrets."
Her mother-in-law, Yvonne Soniea said, tried to prevent her from marrying into the family. "I'm not dark, but I'm definitely African-American," Yvonne said. "She told me I'd have black babies and she didn't want them around."
After the marriage, Yvonne said, when she did get pregnant, her mother-in-law walked out to a trash bin, contemptuously remarking, "When you have that little dark cub, you put it right here in the garbage."
Ruthless schemes were used to pry her husband away, she said; her mother-in-law encouraged him into a relationship with a white woman. This led, she said, to the couple's divorce, which lasted several months, before they remarried.
Upon hearing some of the condemnations of his beloved grandmother, Mr. Connerly grew teary-eyed and cross, dismissing them all as implausible. He mentioned family rivalries. "These people feel I've neglected them because I don't come around," he said. "My grandmother had dark skin herself."
For corroboration, Mr. Connerly suggested his 81-year-old Aunt Bertha, who did indeed back him up. "If my mother didn't like black people, why'd so many of them come to her house?" Mrs. Louis said. "Who else was there in the neighborhood but black people? The people in her church were black, some of them black as pitch."
She assessed the credibility of her kinfolk: "My brother Arthur is the biggest liar who ever lived, and those others are nothing but dogs. It's plain hatred and jealousy, I'm telling you. Wardell did eat all them sweet potatoes, and I saw that hole in his shoe myself, back in 1959, may God strike me dead."
Even excavating layers of family resentments might fail to explain such contradictions. But there are also verifiable facts buried deep down, quite intentionally hidden from a young boy.
Roy Connerly, gone from his son Ward's life for 56 years and thought most likely to be dead, is actually alive in Leesville. Unbeknown to his firstborn, he remarried, fathered two more sons and spent a lifetime in menial toil.
Ward Connerly was given the news by telephone. "I did not know," he responded sharply. "I've had no contact with him."
He paused a few seconds, then, rather formally, as if issuing a statement, said, "The fact that he's alive is news to me. It does not surprise me or delight me or disturb me. It's just news."
Moments later, his voice softened with curiosity: "He left my mother. Why didn't he ever try to reach me?"
The elder Connerly is 84 and bed-ridden, a stroke victim who suffers from crippling arthritis. With his mental faculties gone dim, he is unable to rebut the Soniea version of his marital breakup, which paints him as a carouser and a drunk and a wife-beater. It is the only account Ward Connerly has ever heard.
But Clementine Connerly, Roy's current wife, spoke up in his behalf with decidedly different particulars. "Roy was too black for the Sonieas; they was a high yellow people," said Mrs. Connerly, 62. "Grace was Roy's first wife's name. Her mother didn't want them to marry and she wouldn't stop till she busted them up.
"When Grace died, my husband went all the way to the Supreme Court in New Orleans to get custody away from Wardell's grandmother. Roy used to call him Billy Boy. Then, years later, Wardell's uncle came through here and said the boy was being raised white or Indian and he didn't want anything to do with us."
Louis Connerly, 45, a handyman and one of the two half brothers Ward has never met, said, "My father always told me it was more or less a race thing. In Louisiana, at a certain time, if you had a certain amount of white blood, you were inclined to think you were better than the next person."
He added, "My dad wanted Billy Boy. And so did my dad's mother, Fannie Connerly. You know, we all wish Wardell well. We've seen him on TV. I've got his rifle. A long time ago, my dad gave me a single shot .22. 'To my son, Billy Boy' is engraved on the stock."
Ward Connerly, hit out-of-the-blue by the details, held tightly to his bitterness toward his father. "I'm interested that he had a stroke," he said. "I've wondered about that. I've read that strokes are hereditary."
 
His Rise to Success
Moving Easily In a White World
Mr. Connerly said he can remember being called "nigger" just once while growing up. He was in the second or third grade, walking in a white neighborhood. He picked a walnut off the sidewalk. "I caught you, you little nigger, stealing my walnuts," a man shouted. Ward was rescued by his white playmate, Mildred Tittle, who said, "Don't you say that or I'll tell my father!"
Mr. Connerly has a trove of similar stories about white people who helped him, a bus driver, a store owner, teachers: "I've always been someone who people would notice and say, 'This kid is trying to make it.' "
That was certainly true in college. At Sacramento State University, where he graduated in 1962, Mr. Connerly was one of about 50 blacks on a campus of 2,000. He was elected vice president of the student body, then president. He was eagerly recruited by fraternities, pledging all-white Delta Phi Omega.
"It was very chic to have a good-looking black around," recalled Adolphus McGee, then a black football star on campus. "Ward was Joe College, Mr. Personality. Understand, those times were pre-militance, pre-dashikis."
Mr. Connerly was a Young Democrat back then. He was also the leader of the student committee against discrimination in housing. The group sent black "testers" into white neighborhoods, identifying biased landlords.
Soon after graduation, Mr. Connerly's thinking took a turn to the right. "I had always been a great believer in free enterprise," he explained. The conservative ideas of Barry Goldwater were winning him over, about the time many others were raising clenched fists in salute to black power.
"This reveling in blackness -- black is beautiful, black power, black consciousness -- just creates an invisible wall of difference that sets us apart," Mr. Connerly said. "While others are assimilating, blacks are getting further and further away from one nation indivisible.
" Black solidarity has led to a black agenda and a demand for black loyalty. If you don't believe in it, you're a sellout, an Uncle Tom, a traitor."
Two months after graduation, Mr. Connerly married Ilene Crews, a white student he had been dating for about a year. The vows were exchanged in a minister's living room before only two witnesses.
At first, neither family approved, Mr. Connerly said. He recalled that his grandmother preferred a bride of mulatto shading. "Can't you find a nice colored girl?" she asked.
Ilene's parents "had very pronounced reservations, and for a couple of years or so, they stayed in their world and we stayed in ours," Mr. Connerly said. "It's funny. The thing that makes parents the most fearful about an interracial marriage is the grandkids. What will they look like? What will they have to face? But when it happens, that's what brings you back together. They've got a grandchild and they see he's beautiful."
Even with a diploma and a dedication to free enterprise, Mr. Connerly at first did not consider a business career. He said he was "too conditioned" by his blackness.
"You had this notion back in the 60's that if you were black, and you had a college degree, you went into government," he said.
He joined the State Department of Housing and Community Development, becoming its liaison to the Legislature. There he met a political up-and-comer, Representative Pete Wilson, a man of remarkable energy who seemed to exhale ambition. Mr. Wilson recruited Mr. Connerly to a staff job on the Assembly's housing committee. A close friendship was knit.
Mr. Wilson went on to become the Mayor of San Diego, a United States Senator and then, in 1991, the Governor, while Mr. Connerly became a sought-after consultant in Sacramento, advising local governments how to comply with state land-use laws, many of which he had helped write. Some work came his way because of his blackness, as public officials tried to fulfill the mandates of affirmative action. But Mr. Connerly's success owes far more to satisfied clients and political connections.
A generous contributor to Mr. Wilson's campaigns, Mr. Connerly was offered various jobs in his friend's administration, accepting the post of regent only after being assured that it would not require much time.
Instead, the position has nearly taken over his life, filling it with new purpose while emptying it of tranquillity. Racial preferences had been of only passing interest to him before. But suddenly the subject was consuming, offending Mr. Connerly's idea of fairness. In the summer of 1994, two white parents had paid him a visit after their son was refused a spot in medical school. The father, Jerry Cook, was a statistician. His look at the admissions records led him to think his son had fallen to the bottom of a racially stacked deck.
Mr. Connerly ordered a review of university admissions data and concluded that race had assumed too important a part in the process. Blacks and Hispanic-Americans were accepted ahead of whites and Asian-Americans who had far better grades and test scores. In 1994, the average high school grade point of freshman admissions, with 4 equivalent to an A, was 3.75 for Asian-Americans, 3.69 for whites, 3.50 for Hispanic-Americans, 3.40 for Mexican-Americans (who are counted in a separate category) and 3.24 for blacks.
Racism does "not justify our government giving a preference to Jose over Chang because Susan's father discriminated against Willie's father 50 years ago," Mr. Connerly said, summing up his thoughts.
Debate began. Professors and administrators generally argued that the system of preferences was sacrosanct, defending it with the customary arguments for diversity. They often spoke in jargon, with positions that could be paradoxical.
David A. Hollinger, a history professor at the Berkeley campus and supporter of affirmative action, watched the debate with chagrin. For years, there had been "a tacit agreement not to ask hard questions" about affirmative action, Professor Hollinger said. Then, when the time came to defend it, he said, partisans were ill-prepared. Indeed, they had their own unresolved conflicts, which made their side all the more vulnerable to an attack like Mr. Connerly's.
Some believed in affirmative action to promote cultural diversity; others found absurd the assumption that culture follows blood. Some thought nonwhite skin color an inescapable burden in a biased society; others asked why the children of wealthy blacks or newly arrived immigrants were favored over the children of poor whites. Some said the program ought to be limited to black Americans burdened by the legacy of slavery; others said Hispanic-Americans should be included, pointing to the conquest of Mexico in 1848 and United States imperialism since the Monroe Doctrine.
Mr. Connerly's crusade was soon joined by Governor Wilson. Actually a longtime advocate of affirmative action, Mr. Wilson had relocated his views into the Republican mainstream just as he announced a bid for the party's Presidential nomination.
On July 21, 1995, with Mr. Wilson in rare attendance, the Board of Regents voted 14 to 10 to scrap its 30-year-old policy of preferences for minorities and women. These meetings are usually staid, but this one had protesters in full roar. Among those present was the Rev. Jesse Jackson, who would later call Mr. Connerly a "house slave" and a "puppet of the white man."
 
His Cause
Claiming Victory Over Preferences
Mr. Connerly continues to obey the three rules of his late Uncle James. His car, a Jaguar, glistens; the grounds around his home and pool are immaculate; his shoes are shined. But these tasks no longer require his own labor. His shoes are cared for by a man with a stand in the parking garage of a private club he frequents. Mr. Connerly does not know this older man's name, but he considers him "one of the brightest, best-read people I know."
And therein, Mr. Connerly said he realizes, is a dilemma.
"The reason this man shines shoes is because he's black," he said. "There's no disgrace in that, but I know that in another time and in another place, this man would not be a shoeshine man. How do we make it up to him?"
Such confounding questions played virtually no part in the debate over Proposition 209. The referendum question, carefully worded as an anti-preferences measure to guarantee civil rights, was a political brush fire with $3.6 million to burn. On Nov. 5, 1996, 15 months after the Regents' vote, Mr. Connerly gave a victory speech before an overwhelmingly white crowd, wowing them as usual with his aphoristic, all-American locutions.
Asking his audience to "indulge" him, he asked to have "a personal conversation with my fellow black Americans," although only a few were in the room. "Those who followed before you had to climb steep mountains of oppression," he lectured. "Surely, you can travel the freeways of opportunity without special consideration based on the color of your skin."
The 209 effort had been started by two white male scholars who had the opinion polls on their side and most everything else against them. To place the question on the ballot meant getting 700,000 names on petitions, a laborious process for which hired workers were paid as much as $1 a signature. By November 1995 the campaign was broke, but, after an 11-month courtship, its leaders finally persuaded Mr. Connerly to take over.
His involvement was decisive. One reason was that Mr. Connerly was able to bring in money. According to an internal campaign memorandum, Mr. Connerly had refused to come aboard "without assurances from Wilson that the initiative will succeed," which, those involved said, meant that the California Republican Party would pay the way. A second reason was that he was black. Other memorandums show that leaders of the 209 effort had a calculated preference for women and minorities in top positions.
"It was like using affirmative action to defeat affirmative action," said Joe C. Gelman, the campaign manager when Mr. Connerly was brought aboard. "We were being pretty cynical, I have to admit."
Race confronted Mr. Connerly every day on the street. Blacks rushed up to him, saying he had ruined their lives. Whites thanked him for being on their side. "I'm not on anybody's side," he would respond.
Two months after the Proposition 209 victory, on the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s birthday, Mr. Connerly announced the start of the American Civil Rights Institute, an outfit with a two-person staff that would try to kindle the brush fire beyond California. So far, only campaigns in Washington State and Houston seem to have heated up.
Mr. Connerly has also tried to enlist the Republican national leadership, urging Speaker Newt Gingrich to move on an anti-affirmative action bill. But the party is ideologically split over the issue. Besides, the matter involves not only minorities but women, and last year's elections showed that Republicans were already having enough trouble with women.
In arguing "mend it, don't end it," President Clinton has pointed out that the unemployment rate for blacks is still about double that of whites. The Hispanic rate is even higher. The average income for a college-educated Hispanic woman is less than that of a white male with only a high school diploma.
But even if this were so, Ward Connerly asked, is it right to discriminate against a white man to fix it?
Last month, Mr. Gingrich and Mr. Connerly's names were atop an article on the Op-Ed page of The New York Times, rebutting the President. The article called racial preferences "a national human catastrophe," then let fly with a volley of broadsides at "the failed Great Society," an attack that made Mr. Connerly wince.
"Gingrich's staff people wrote it, and I didn't get to see a draft until the last minute," he said, deftly accepting and deflecting responsibility. "It's under my name and I'll stand behind it, but I only got to make minor changes to the anti-liberal rhetoric. I'm no liberal, but I don't think it serves conservatives well to go on and on about the Great Society."
Mr. Connerly's private reflections are rarely as unambiguous as his public pronouncements. Before audiences, he shies away from complexities. In private, his views are more elastic.
Thinking out loud, he often twists himself into contradictions, his thoughts especially entangled when it comes to proposing remedies for large-scale discrimination. Once, he suggested class-action suits as an approach, another time "the collective nah-nah-nah of the marketplace."
Most of Mr. Connerly's arguments apply to skilled jobs where merit can be put to some measurement. But if racial disparity is shown in the hiring of unskilled workers, he said, "I'll be the first person to admit I don't know what the hell to do."
"You almost have to look at how race was taken into account" in such cases, he said. "The position I'm coming to is that it's O.K. to monitor with numbers."
But the fear of showing unbalanced numbers to government monitors has, in the past, led employers to play it safe by using preferences and quotas.
Mr. Connerly has things just about half right, said Eddie Hall, the man who shines his shoes: Hard work, not affirmative action, is the answer. But insofar as society ever becoming color-blind, "That's utopia and there's no such thing."
Mr. Hall, 72, is a man with a gray beard who looks at his buff cloths through bifocals. He has watched his own dreams diminish and then disappear. Think of it, he laughed, he once thought a poor black like himself could go to college and be a doctor.
Instead, never able to get any kind of good-paying job, he became one of those blacks who "are resigned that in the eyes of God we must work in the pit." A man of good temper, Mr. Hall thought of a wry way to explain the only affirmative action he had ever known.
Time after time, employers turned him away after they saw his black skin.
"It was a-firm-ative action," he wisecracked. "They were very firm."
Five days after learning that his father was alive, and after hard thinking about confused feelings, Ward Connerly telephoned Louisiana. "This all leaves me shaking," he said after hanging up. "I can't believe I'm using words like 'my father' and 'my brothers.' He acknowledged that he probably was not told the truth about his father's desire to rear him.
During the phone call, Mr. Connerly mostly talked to Clementine, the wife of his addled father. Then, for a short time, he said, she put the receiver up to her invalid husband's ear. Before he lapsed back into a muddle, a small spark lighted within.
"Who is this?" the old man asked.
"This is Wardell."
"Billy?"
"Yes, your son."
"Billy, when you coming back this way?"

HEADLINE: Mayor Vows to Veto Coliseum Sale, Citing Long-Term Issues

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY 

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani threatened yesterday to block a plan by a state agency to sell the New York Coliseum, one of the most valuable parcels of real estate in New York City, saying that the agency was focusing too much on immediately profiting from the project and not enough on the long-term economic benefits and architectural merits of the proposals for the site.
Mr. Giuliani, who has veto power over the project, said he would demand extensive revisions in a tentative deal between the agency and a developer before he granted his approval for any new building on the site, which anchors Columbus Circle. 
 The deal by the agency, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, is not yet final, but Mr. Giuliani said he was disturbed by the news that the authority appears to have settled upon the developer, Millennium Partners, in large part because of a highly unusual financial concession that the developer offered.
The authority had hoped to approve the sale on Wednesday, but the Mayor said he would not allow that. Mr. Giuliani's vow indicates that the long-delayed effort to revamp the Coliseum site, which has been the subject of some of the most celebrated and contentious development battles in the city's recent history, has hit another snag.
At a news conference yesterday and in an interview afterward, Mr. Giuliani lashed out at the authority and said he would set up his own panel to evaluate the esthetics and economic benefits of the designs and proposed uses offered by the five finalists in the competition held by the authority to choose a developer.
"The M.T.A. has really no concern for the future of the city," the Mayor said. "All they are concerned about is how much they make." The Mayor added, "They are going to have to make a lot of changes in order for me to be satisfied."
The dispute that arose yesterday was not really about esthetics or architectural style, because the Giuliani administration has not expressed strong opposition on those grounds to Millennium's proposal. It appears instead to stem from a disagreement over the pace of the selection process -- and what kind of buildings will be on the site.
Giuliani administration officials maintained that the Mayor had privately told the authority in recent weeks that he wanted the winning developer to build a 1,000- to 2,000-seat theater on the site that would link it to Lincoln Center, which is a few blocks to the northwest. None of the finalists have yet incorporated such a structure in their plans.
The officials said the Mayor decided to criticize the authority publicly yesterday after he began to feel that it was ignoring his request and rushing the deal.
Besides the theater, though, the officials would not say what other revisions the Mayor wanted in the proposed agreement with Millennium.
That reticence to discuss other changes suggests that the Mayor's primary goal in announcing his criticism yesterday was to counter the perception that he was allowing the project to proceed without adequate consideration for its aesthetic or civic virtues. In other words, even if he generally likes the Millennium proposal, he may not like the appearance that it is being chosen for largely financial reasons.
Asked yesterday about the Mayor's comments, Virgil Conway, the authority's chairman, said, "The Mayor's concerns have to be dealt with. But I would hope that we could do it by Wednesday." Mr. Conway added that the authority had not ignored architectural considerations in choosing a developer.
The developer that is the top pick of the authority, Millennium Partners, has proposed a glass complex for the site that would include a 64-story tower, as well as a convention center, a 1,000-room hotel, condominiums, an entertainment center and a health club.
Perhaps more important, Millennium promised the authority that it would pay more than $300 million for the property even if, as is very likely, the project is entangled in litigation. Millennium Partners was the only one of the nine bidders in the yearlong competition for the site that agreed to pay upon signing a contract, state officials said.
That provision in the deal was so important that it gave Millennium the edge even though it did not make the highest offer for the site, state officials said.
Developers usually withhold full payment on these types of projects until litigation has been resolved. Some neighborhood groups have said they will go to court to stop the project, as they did the last time the authority sought to sell the site, saying the project would be too big for the area.
"Of course that's important," Mr. Conway said of Millennium's promise. "Unconditional offers are always important. The more conditions that you attach to any real estate deal always detract from an offer." Executives at Millennium Partners declined to comment.
The Mayor's attack yesterday reflected longstanding tensions between the two sides over the sale of the site. The authority, a transportation agency that has no interest in acting as a developer, is eager to rid itself of the Coliseum and channel the proceeds from the sale to capital improvements on the subways and commuter railroads.
Officials of the city, which essentially will reap no money from the sale, are more interested in whether the project will revitalize Columbus Circle.
"The M.T.A. mistakenly believed that this was all about money," Randy Levine, the Deputy Mayor for Economic Development, Planning and Administration, said. "We told them that it was never about money, that this was about a series of things, price being only one. The most important thing is the way the project enhances the neighborhood, because New York City has to live with this for the next 50 or 100 years."

HEADLINE: Both Sides Say Accord Is Near On the Budget

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 26

 BODY:
With each side speaking encouragingly of progress, White House and Republican negotiators today made a significant push toward an agreement on tax cuts and a balanced budget.
"It's coming together," said an official involved in the budget discussions who spoke on the condition of anonymity. 
 He said the talks had progressed far beyond the rhetoric of the last few days, to the point that Congressional aides had started writing draft legislation on certain issues.
The discussions ended about 6:30 this evening after a full day, and officials said Republican and Democratic staff members would meet on Sunday to work on what they said were small issues. There were no plans for the principals to meet on Sunday.
The Clinton Administration views the negotiations on the tax cut side as a no-lose proposition. [Page 14.]
On Medicare, which is the biggest issue in the budget bill, Administration officials and Congressional leaders said the three most contentious proposals appeared to be off the table, at least temporarily.
Those proposals, approved last month by the Senate, would increase Medicare premiums for the affluent elderly, raise the eligibility age (to 67 from 65) and charge $5 a visit for home health care services.
Senators of both parties have said all three proposals are needed to help keep Medicare solvent for the baby boom generation. And President Clinton said this week that he would support a means test requiring higher premiums for beneficiaries with higher incomes.
But House members of both parties and lobbyists for the elderly have resisted the three proposals, saying they should be referred to an advisory panel that will study Medicare's long-term financial problems.
Gene Sperling, President Clinton's economic policy adviser, said late this afternoon, "A lot of issues have been narrowed on the spending side. But things will not get done tonight."
Senior leaders spent the day shuttling between a series of large meetings and smaller ones -- some on spending, others on tax cuts and still others involving just Republicans and Democrats huddling among themselves to discuss the most recent offers or counteroffers.
Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin and Erskine B. Bowles, the White House chief of staff, led the Administration's negotiating team, while the Republican side was anchored by Speaker Newt Gingrich and Senator Trent Lott, the majority leader, backed by the chairmen of their budget and tax-writing committees.
"There really are very few items that have to be resolved," Representative Bill Archer, the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, told reporters about midday. "If a couple of major items get resolved on the tax bill, the rest of it will all fall in place rapidly."
The tax question has become the linchpin in the talks and the problem in resolving it is as much philosophical as it is fiscal. A central sticking point is whether working families with incomes of $25,000 a year or less will get any benefits from the proposed tax credits for children.
The Republicans argue that many such families pay little or no income tax, so giving them the child tax credits would be a form of welfare. But Democrats counter that those same people have payroll tax deductions and need relief much more than higher income families.
A shrinking circle of negotiators was among the subtle signs today that the sides were moving toward agreement.
For example, it appeared that Mr. Archer, who has been among the most adamant Republicans in insisting on cuts in capital gains taxes and corporate taxes, might have to fight to protect his role in the final negotiating rounds. Mr. Archer's committee is responsible for all tax legislation in the House and for considerable parts of the spending deal because of its authority over Medicare.
Although he was involved when the talks resumed this morning, Mr. Archer said he did not think he would continue to be involved in the portion of the talks dealing with spending.
Asked by reporters whether he would continue to participate in the tax portion of the talks, Mr. Archer said, "We'll see."
In recent days, each side has spoken optimistically of progress in the negotiations, which are focused on cutting taxes, limiting the growth of Government and balancing the Federal budget by 2002.
"We're close to an agreement with the White House that would accomplish all those goals," Mr. Lott said today in the Republican radio address. "But you know the old saying: 'Close, but no cigar.' Any celebration at this point would definitely be premature."
At an appearance on Friday before the National Association of Elementary School Principals in Arlington, Va., President Clinton said: "I think we're going to get this agreement."
The pace of the negotiations is being driven by an effort to have both the budget and tax legislation completed before Congress leaves on Friday for its summer break.
But Democratic leaders in the House and the Senate have argued against making that a deadline.
"There is no artificial deadline," "If it takes until September to do it right, let it be September," Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the Democratic leader, said on Friday.
The two sides also resumed negotiations today on other vexing issues: welfare, estate taxes, education tax incentives, tobacco taxes and medical savings accounts.
They settled a major issue, disability benefits for legal immigrants, on Friday.
The Republicans agreed to restore disability benefits to legal immigrants who were in the country last August, when the new welfare bill was signed into law.
The Republicans also agreed to continue Medicaid coverage for tens of thousands of children who face losing it, along with disability benefits, under the new welfare law.
Entwined in the rosy talk about progress were some political barbs.
Mr. Lott complained in his radio address: "I have worked with six Administrations, both Democrats and Republicans. This one, let me tell you, is unique. Its public assertions are often fanciful; its private data are often contrived."

HEADLINE: For Deaf Peddlers, Both Opportunity And Exploitation

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN and IAN FISHER

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, July 26

 BODY:
You can buy practically anything at the wholesale stores on Los Angeles Street: smiling ceramic Buddhas, crates of heart-shaped sunglasses, countless Spanish-language videos of action movies. The deaf peddlers come mostly for key chains.
And among these deaf peddlers who come to the markets to stock up on merchandise, the Paoletti family of Mexico City distinguished itself long before it made headlines in New York. At one storefront bazaar here, the family now accused of having all but enslaved scores of deaf immigrants as street peddlers is known for having ordered its key chains by the thousands of dozens. 
 Yet if the Paolettis were remarkable figures in this silent underworld, it was mostly for the scale of their operations and the extremes to which they are said to have gone in mistreating the men and women they lured from Mexico to Queens.
Since the 1970's, researchers and social service workers say, poor immigrants have largely taken over and transformed a byzantine economy of deaf peddlers, which has its roots in places like Los Angeles Street and extends from shopping centers in Chicago to retirement villages in Florida and Texas.
[On Saturday, Federal investigators arrested two people described as the leaders of a trinket-peddling operation in Chicago similar to the one uncovered in New York last weekend. Page 26.]
But many of the peddlers and several other people who have studied their world described it as much more complex and diverse than the latest news might suggest.
For some of the young recruits, the work is simply a hard way to an honest living, a source of enough income to survive in the United States while pursuing opportunities for schooling or job-training that do not exist in countries like Cambodia or El Salvador. They may work alone or in groups, they say, but their associations are voluntary and their bosses generally fair.
For other deaf peddlers, though, there is nothing new in the stories of exploitation and abuse told by the young Mexicans who worked for the Paolettis. Separated from their families and smuggled into the United States, these immigrants have found themselves at the mercy of their own avaricious masters, "kings" who run their peddlers much as a pimp might run a stable of prostitutes.
"You know how this American dream is," said Esther Lozano, 50, a Mexican woman who was in Los Angeles visiting a family of deaf friends who sell trinkets at shopping malls. "People come here with the hope that they will be able to do what they could not do before -- people who are deaf and people who are not. But all of those people come to suffer. The deaf just suffer more."
Some students of deaf culture said the story of the Paolettis recalled nothing so much as the tale of Leon Krakover, a deaf Chicago entrepreneur who built his street-peddling empire into a corporation complete with lawyers, accountants, a staff of deaf door-to-door salesmen and an apartment hotel to house them.
Mr. Krakover's own flurry of headlines, which followed his expulsion in 1948 from the National Fraternal Society for the Deaf and a $2.5-million lawsuit that he filed in response, delineated a postwar struggle between a deaf underclass and what The Cavalier, a national deaf newspaper of the day, referred to as "the self-respecting deaf."
Members of the latter group saw the peddlers as a mendicant stain on their collective image. But even as access to better schooling and better jobs has led more and more deaf Americans to mark their distance from the ranks of the disabled, the flood of new immigrants from Latin America, Asia and Eastern Europe in the last three decades has replenished the pool of deaf people living in isolation and need.
One man, who gave his name only as Eduardo and said he was a political refugee from Guatemala, was typical of the new work force.
A thin 35-year-old who wears his hair in a short ponytail, Eduardo said he still had nightmares about his experience, and he agreed to speak to a reporter only on the condition that his last name not be printed.
He told of leaving his home in the quiet colonial town of Antigua eight years ago, after both he and his father were threatened for their activities on behalf of opposition political parties.
While living in exile in Mexico, Eduardo said, he met another deaf man in the northern industrial city of Monterrey who told him of lucrative work waiting just across the border in Texas.
Eventually, the man provided Eduardo with false identity papers and led him, along with seven deaf Mexicans, past American immigration agents at the border crossing in Laredo. But almost as soon as the group arrived at a home that the smuggler owned in Natalia, Tex., near San Antonio, Eduardo and the Mexicans were put to work in a regimen very different from what they had imagined.
"We got almost nothing to eat," Eduardo said, speaking through a sign-language interpreter at a special school he attends in Los Angeles. "We had to sell every day, from six in the morning until seven at night. The boss had a very big house, but he did not give us anything."
On Christmas night in 1989, a few visitors arrived for a party at the Natalia home. Sensing a chance to escape, Eduardo said, he hid outside the house until one of the visitors emerged, and then begged the man to take him away. The visitor agreed, but only on the condition that Eduardo trade sex for a plane ticket to Los Angeles. "They were very bad people," Eduardo, who complied, said, breaking down in tears.
Although social service agencies in the United States have expanded their services to the deaf and to immigrants, deaf immigrants are still prone to fall through the cracks.
Some of them arrive knowing only the sign languages of their native countries; some arrive without any sign language at all. Public conveniences that are taken for granted by American-born deaf people -- like telephone links that allow them to communicate by typing -- remain stubborn mysteries. Available jobs stay just out of reach.
The isolation of a life in silence is compounded for those who live in fear of the immigration authorities. Those who have left their families behind have little choice but to depend on small groups of others like themselves. And often, the king peddlers who profit from such vulnerability are deaf themselves.
"In order to recruit these people, to train them and to spread them around to work, you have to be able to sign," said Carol A. Padden, a professor at the University of California at San Diego who studies deaf culture and is deaf herself.
"You have to have an organizer, and typically, that is a deaf person."
The business itself is more intricate than it might appear from the cards that are quietly placed beside customers. Printers offer the cards with a variety of sales pitches -- from "I am deaf . .t." and "I love you" to "Please pardon my intrusion, but I am a deaf person trying to earn for college expenses."
At wholesale emporiums like the ones on Los Angeles Street, the peddlers choose items that are cheap, light and utilitarian: nail-clippers ($4 a dozen) are a favorite, as are pencils and pens (prices vary) and key chains bearing the image of the Virgin of Guadalupe, Mexico's patron saint ($4.50 a dozen for the small, $5.50 for the large). Almost always, the items sell for $1 apiece.
Most of the deaf peddlers who crowd the displays at L.A. Top Distributor, a favorite Los Angeles Street store, take their trinkets by the dozens. The salesmen there remember the Paoletti family as the deaf people who stopped shopping there several years ago, only to start calling again last year from New York with huge orders for spinning-globe key chains.
The family's most recent invoice, on Feb. 28, was for 24,000 such key chains at 11.25 cents each. At $1 each, the sales would have made the Paolettis $21,300 -- before shipping charges, subway tokens and the modest sums they apparently spent to lodge and pay their peddlers. (The police believe the shipment would have lasted less than a week.)
Sales territories also vary. Some bosses prefer airports, for the waiting travelers with disposable cash. Peddling rings have been known to fight occasionally over shopping malls they have staked out as turf. At the Los Angeles International Airport, the sales choreography can be baroque.
Maria Correa, 33, a deaf native of Mexico City who now lives in Whittier, Calif., operates independently but sometimes works with friends. She arrived at Terminal One at noon on Friday. By 3:30, she had worked her way through half of the departure lounges and was preparing to leave. There was more money to be made, she was sure, but there were also more deaf peddlers lined up behind her.
"I can't sell all day," she said. "I know there are other deaf people here trying to sell. I want to show them respect."
Ms. Correa said she knew of about 30 small rings of deaf immigrant peddlers in the Los Angeles area. Typically, she said, the bosses put up the money for the trinkets and receive about half of the take. For most of the bosses, that kind of profit margin is apparently enough; bosses as abusive as the Paolettis are relatively rare, she said.
But social service workers, researchers and some former peddlers suggested that at least some level of coercion often seemed a basic part of the arrangements.
Sally Campbell, who trains many deaf immigrants as the coordinator of Special Services at the Abram Friedman Occupational Center in Los Angeles, said some of her students had been forced by bosses to drop out of classes in English and American Sign Language when the schooling was apparently seen to have got in the way of their work.
A deaf immigrant from Mexico, Margarito Flores, 39, of Anaheim, Calif., said it was easier for other deaf immigrants to understand the hardships that went with the job.
"This is helping me and my family," Mr. Flores said through a translator. "I don't want to have to borrow money. I want to earn money. I look at this as a living."

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
How to Save on Taxes When Taking Those Stock-Market Gains

BYLINE: By JAN M. ROSEN 

 BODY:
WITH the long-booming Dow Jones industrial average now well past 8,000, many investors are sitting on gains they are reluctant to take because of the taxes they would owe. Wouldn't a money-making investment that reduced taxes, instead of adding to them, be welcome?
"Dream on," you say? Although not well-known, there is such an investment -- low-income housing. 
 When Congressional tax writers wiped out tax shelters in 1986, they created a new tax-favored investment for what is known as "affordable housing." In an effort to replace public housing projects with private sector initiatives, Congress offered tax credits -- not tax deductions -- to people who invest in housing developments that qualify.
"Affordable housing today is privately owned and managed with a profit potential," said Richard J. DeAgazio, executive vice president of Boston Capital, which offers these investments.
Through this program, Congress has authorized tax credits of $3.3 billion a year, enough to build or rehabilitate roughly 100,000 units annually. Corporations and individuals have purchased all the $33 billion in credits available since the program started, or almost one million units of low-income housing.
Corporations have received most of these credits, from firms like Arkand & Company in Seattle and the Related Companies in New York. But some syndicators offer private placements to individual investors, and one company, Boston Capital, is registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission to sell the investment to individuals publicly.
Boston Capital specializes in small garden apartment complexes in rural and suburban settings. The apartments are rented to the elderly, the disabled and people whose incomes are less than 60 percent of the average in the area. In its recently opened Tax Credit Fund IV -- Series 30, for example, the company will invest in a portfolio of 24 properties in 11 states from Maine to Oklahoma. This is a $25 million offering with an expected 12-year life span, and is being made from the firm directly (800 866-2282) and through 350 stock brokers and financial planners nationwide.
For such investments, the law sets the maximum stake for a taxpayer in the 15 percent bracket at $31,000. That sum would provide an annual tax credit of $3,750. In the top bracket of 39.6 percent, the maximum investment is $82,000, yielding an annual credit of $9,900.
Credits are more valuable than deductions because they reduce taxes dollar-for-dollar, whereas deductions reduce taxes only by the amount of the deduction times a taxpayer's marginal tax rate. For example, a $5,000 credit would be worth $5,000 to any taxpayer; a $5,000 deduction reduces taxes by $750 for taxpayers in the 15 percent bracket; $1,400 in the 28 percent bracket and $1,980 in the 39.6 percent bracket.
The low-income housing credits reduce regular income taxes, regardless of the source of income. And while they do not apply to the alternative minimum tax, people who pay this tax can carry the credits back 3 years or forward 15 years. Moreover, each year Congress has pre-funded the tax credits for 10 years, so even if Congress were to change the law, a person who has already invested would not lose the credits.
Mr. DeAgazio said his company's typical investors are in their 50's, have annual incomes of $75,000 to $200,000 and have paid off the big expenses -- mortgages and their children's education. The average holding of its 65,000 individual investors is $22,000. The minimum investment is $5,000.
But is such an investment worth it, especially since the principal will usually be invested for 12 years or so? One answer comes from Mr. DeAgazio, who calculates, based on Boston Capital offerings that have only a year or two remaining, that investors will have the equivalent of a 12 percent annual return, assuming that the housing units are sold for their original cost when the credits end, which he thinks is likely.
That is about twice the return they would receive on municipal bonds and, just as for muni bond investors, there would no tax liability. But there are no guarantees beyond the tax credits. The theoretical worst case for investors is that once the credits end, there will be no market for the properties themselves, so no capital will be returned. The best case is that the properties will all appreciate and be sold at a profit, providing investors with the credit, a return of capital and a taxable capital gain at the end.
True, because the credits are pre-funded, the investment is a predictable one. It is also counter-cyclical; if the economy were to tank, the demand for low-income housing would climb. Still, independent investment advisers express caution.
S. Timothy Kochis, partner in Kochis Fitz Tracy & Gorman, a fee-only financial consulting and investment management firm in San Francisco, said, "It is completely legitimate, completely kosher, and very low risk, but a so-so investment." The return on some placements has been equivalent to an after-tax gain of only 6 to 7 percent, he said.
Joel S. Isaacson, president of his own accounting and fee-only financial planning firm in New York, said: "We try to get clients to focus on the economics of investing, not be so tax-driven. Sometimes you're better off investing your money for return and paying the taxes." Stocks or other real estate investments, like a real estate investment trust, offer more upside potential and are more liquid, he said.
Because low-income housing is a long-term, relatively illiquid investment, investors typically put only 7 to 8 percent of their portfolios in it. Even so, in an emergency there is a secondary market for the holdings through the Chicago Partnership Board or American Partnership Services.
Mr. Kochis said one appeal, besides the tax break, is altruism. "The ethical consequences of investing are very important to some people," he said, "and this is a way to improve housing stock."

CORRECTION-DATE: September 21, 1997, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
An article on July 27 about tax credits for investments in low-income housing misstated the name and location of a company that sells such credits to corporate markets. It is the Arcand Company of Portland, Ore., not Arkand & Company of Seattle. The Portland company telephoned on Sept. 10 about the errors.

HEADLINE: FROM THE DESK OF;
A Senior Discount? I Don't Deserve It

BYLINE: By TED M. LEVINE; Ted M. Levine, age 60-plus, is the founder and chairman of Development Counsellors International in Manhattan. The firm helps cities, states and countries attract business and tourism.

 BODY:
A FEW years ago I began getting expensive gifts from people I didn't know.
A generous benefactor paid half the price of my movie theater tickets; I received discounts at hotels and motels around the country, and prestigious universities offered to teach me fascinating courses for free, or almost so. Earlier this year I purchased a round-trip ticket to Charleston, S.C., from New York City at a price 50 percent lower than the going rate. 
 In recent years, the trickle of gifts has grown to a flood of largess that I figure may be worth tens of thousands of dollars to me.
What did I do to deserve all this? Basically, I didn't die.
To be more precise, I lived long enough to qualify for a cornucopia of senior subsidies. Actually, I only had to make it to age 50. So baby boomers, now that you're starting to reach that milestone, take note: There is a 294-page directory especially for you and me titled "Unbelievably Good Deals and Great Adventures That You Absolutely Can't Get Unless You're Over 50" (Contemporary Books). The book details senior discounts offered by hotels, motels, airlines and even universities. You'll also find resorts where you can ski for half price.
"Deals" also explains why I am entitled to these things: "You deserve them, having successfully negotiated your way through life's white waters."
Well, call me a grizzled grinch but I don't buy it. I have to say that the trend toward giving goodies to golden-agers is insulting, and terrible public policy.
Some decades ago, it was different. The over-60 crowd was among America's poorest citizens. But now Social Security, pensions, financial planning and parsimony are changing that. Consider these statistics:
* In 1970, almost one-fourth of all Americans aged 65 and over were living below the poverty line, the Census showed. By 1995, that figure had plunged to 10.5 percent.
* The net worth of older Americans is pulling farther ahead of the net worth of younger people in some of their prime years of earning power. The latest figures from a survey issued every three years by the Federal Reserve showed that in 1995, the average net worth of Americans aged 65 to 74 was $331,600, compared with $308,300 in 1992. The net worth of those aged 35 to 44, meanwhile, remained virtually unchanged, at just over $144,000.
No, seniors don't need cheap movie seats or even free vacations. But I'd go a step further: Many of us don't even want them.
We not only know we own more, spend more, travel more and vote more than any other age group, but we're also proud of it. And being crudely seduced into the market with half-price off-peak train tickets or nominally discounted rental cars tends to stick in some of our collective craws.
Having grown up reading "Self-Reliance," by Ralph Waldo Emerson, I wonder what we have done to deserve all this commercial generosity. Somehow, not dying doesn't seem a sufficient justification.
Ah, but I hear a voice explaining that while carloads of senior loot may not be good public policy, it is good commercial policy. Companies are, it is argued, making billions of extra dollars by luring the over-the-hill gang to buy, buy, buy what they might not without the discount incentive.
That argument may have been true at one time, but it isn't now and it certainly won't be in the future.
The 65-plus contingent is the fastest-growing age category. Lester Thurow, the economist, has called this group the "revolutionary class" and has cited numbers to show its increasing weight: The group represented only 4 percent of the American population in 1900. Today, it's 13 percent, and by 2025, it is expected to be a stunning 20 percent. In that year, there will be an estimated 75 million people aged 65 and over. And we can expect that, having been a group of relatively high-income earners, they will remain among the richest in retirement.
IT is brainless to offer so many discounts to so many relatively wealthy people. Like other subsidies, these gifts will turn around and bite the first commercial subsidizers. Subsidies may be O.K. when offered to a few people, but anyone who starts subsidizing a large group will ultimately have to charge everyone else more. In the end, the under-65 consumer -- that is, a lot of you -- will be penalized.
Now let's get back to me. Don't I enjoy a little thrill in paying half the price of the folks on line at my local movie theater?
The answer is yes. But I'd get an even bigger thrill from letting everyone know I was paying my own way.
