HEADLINE: For Sony's Studios, A New Mood;
More Hits and Less Worry on Interference

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, July 27

 BODY:
James Marshall is, to put it mildly, a remarkable man. Using martial arts, stealth and sheer grit, he battles a planeload of terrorists, but not without a twinge of conscience. He fights for the lives of dozens of other Americans on board, including his wife and their courageous daughter. In the process, he tries to establish the United States as a bulwark of principle in a world of self-interest.
And by the way, he's the President of the United States, a man more concerned with morals than with votes. 
 Hollywood has only rarely put a positive spin on American Presidents of late, as in "Independence Day" and "The American President." But in "Air Force One," Harrison Ford portrays the President as such an earnest and unblemished paragon of virtue that the movie plays as Rambo on wings, a paean to patriotism. The United States is presented as the best hope in a dark world. Should audiences miss the point, there is even a tense moment in the movie (which brought in an estimated $37.1 million in its first weekend), when the President must guess which wires to connect in a control panel and remarks that the red, white and blue ones must never be crossed.
Historically, Hollywood has not been shy about wrapping itself in the flag when that suited its purposes, but what's noteworthy here is that the studio is Columbia Pictures, owned by Sony, the giant Japanese company.
In 1989, when the Sony Corporation acquired Columbia for $3.5 billion, followed by Matsushita's acquisition of MCA and Universal Pictures for $6.1 billion a few months later, it caused a wave of fear. Some Americans warned that the Japanese companies, battering their American competitors in the trade wars, would now subvert the content of movies. It seemed that an economic battle had turned into a battle for America's cultural soul. A cover article in Newsweek proclaimed, "Japan Invades Hollywood."
There was even concern that the vast movie library owned by the studio would be misused in Japanese hands. "Who protects the interests of the people of the United States when it comes to these motion pictures?" George Stevens Jr., the head of the American Film Institute, asked in Congressional testimony at that time. "How will future generations judge us if we allow these expressions of the American spirit to be lost to us?"
That seems a long time ago. The Japanese economy is struggling today with a recession that began in 1990, while the American economy is soaring. Numerous Japanese companies have lost billions of dollars on ill-considered purchases of American real estate and American companies, including Sony, which has only recently began to recover from its own losses. The cultural heart of the United States appears to be beating strongly.
If anything, the fears today in Hollywood concern China, which owns no studios but has objected strongly to the content of two coming films on Tibet, a country forcibly annexed by Beijing. There are "Seven Years in Tibet," produced by Sony's Tri-Star studio, and Disney's "Kundun." The worry is that studios may be pressured into censoring films that are perceived as critical of China to insure future access to the Chinese market.
"We have always feared foreign influence in ways that were mostly overstated," said Jeffrey Garten, the dean of the Yale School of Management and a former senior Commerce Department official involved in trade issues with Japan. "In the 1970's we thought Arab money would take over the U.S. And then it was Japan. Now we're worried about Chinese influence."
He added: "The real irony is that it's American culture dominating everyone else. We've been looking through the wrong end of the telescope."
"Air Force One" is just a thriller (directed, as it happens, by Wolfgang Petersen, a German), but it reinforces the view that what Sony wants more than anything, after suffering billions of dollars in losses on its movie studio acquisition, is a profit, not control over the content of movies. Mr. Stevens now says in addition that Sony has probably done a better job preserving its American film classics than American-owned studios.
"Obviously, our strategic and financial interests are mutual, but all creative decisions are exclusively local," insisted John Calley, the president of Sony Pictures Entertainment, the studio unit that oversees Columbia and Tri-Star. "We're accountable for all decisions about movie selection and production, as we should be." Yuki Nozoe, an executive vice president at Sony Pictures Entertainment and the sole Japanese executive on the studio lot, added, "We usually talk only about how we can do business from their creative ideas, consumer tie-ins and marketing."
Nobuyuki Idei, the tough-minded, hands-on president of the Sony Corporation, was in town two weeks ago for a series of meetings and viewed for the first time Columbia's current hit movie, "Men in Black." Several people recalled that afterward he quickly asked one thing, "Will it make money?"
That concern is understandable, considering that Sony's flier in the entertainment business cost it perhaps $8 billion and no small amount of embarrassment. After acquiring Columbia and Tri-Star, Sony went on to spend more than $700 million to bring in Jon Peters and Peter Guber to run the studios. The two producers, who had made films like "Batman" for Warner Brothers, already had a reputation in Hollywood for spending freely. The studio unit's revenues declined steadily through the fiscal year ending March 31, 1996, and Sony took a $3.2 billion loss in 1994.
 
Rebounding To a Record Year
Making things worse, the new management team , Alan J. Levine and Mark Canton, was also regarded as ineffectual. They, too, were forced out late last year, to be replaced by Mr. Calley; Lucy Fisher, the vice chairwoman of Columbia Tri-Star Motion Pictures, and Gareth Wigan, co-vice chairman.
But the studios began to rebound strongly last year, and in 1997 they are experiencing a record year. "Jerry Maguire," "Men in Black," "My Best Friend's Wedding" and now "Air Force One" are doing exceptionally well at the box office. These films were all developed by Mr. Levine and Mr. Canton, the discredited management team. And Sony is now seen not as a company bent on controlling its studios' output, but as a struggling Hollywood newcomer eager for little more than stability and a profit.
"I never took all that talk about the Japanese seriously," said Rupert Murdoch, the chairman of the News Corporation, the Australian company that owns the 20th Century Fox studio. "I always thought that if they had been so foolish as to try and control the movies, the public would have destroyed them."
He added: "If anything, the subversive films, the films questioning American values, American traditions, have all come from Americans. This is all really a non-issue."
Tom Pollock, who had been head of Universal Studios when Matsushita bought MCA, said: "Let's be honest, most of those fears at that time, they were more about racism than anything else. What we learned is that the same people are making movies that made them before. Hollywood is a culture that deals with itself. Japanese ownership didn't change that."
In fact, there have been changes in ownership. After suffering through poor returns and conflict with the American management of MCA, Matsushita sold 80 percent of its shareholding to Seagram two years ago. Sony has held talks on several occasions in an effort to sell all or part of its studios. Sony insists that the studios are not on the block now, and they are enjoying their most profitable year ever.
Mr. Pollock and executives at Sony's studios said that their Japanese owners had never vetted scripts or insisted on reviewing the contents of movies. Nevertheless, there have been several instances when there were fears about interference from Tokyo. Universal Pictures made a 1991 film, "Mr. Baseball," about an American baseball player who collides with Japanese culture when he goes to play in Japan. Two jokes that referred to World War II were eliminated, and the script became less irreverent about Japanese culture. But Mr. Pollock said the changes were simply an effort to make a lackluster film better.
 
War Remains A Sensitive Subject
In another example, "Hell Camp," a Columbia Pictures comedy about an American sumo wrestler in Japan, was killed at the last minute. At the time, executives said the problem was with the Sumo Association in Japan, which refused to cooperate with the project. Mike Medavoy, who was then the head of the studio, said that Sony had tried to help gain clearance but failed, and he said there was no censorship at all.
A particularly sensitive subject is still World War II, which some thought might be a test of the Japanese studio owners. Mr. Medavoy said he is currently producing "The Thin Red Line," the second film to be made from the James Jones novel about the American defeat of Japan at Guadalcanal. The executive producer, interestingly, is George Stevens. Mr. Medavoy said he had taken the project to Sony, which passed, and he had then taken it to Fox, which agreed to do the movie.
Asked if Japanese sensitivities were involved, he said: "Not at all. This was purely commercial. I know that if they thought it would have made money, they would have done it. I was more enthusiastic about it than they were, and that's what this business is all about."

HEADLINE: Compaq Retains Lead as PC Sales Soar

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: SAN JOSE, Calif., July 27

 BODY:
The personal computer market continued to grow robustly in the second quarter, with double-digit increases in sales domestically and worldwide, according to two research groups.
The groups reporting, Dataquest Inc. and the International Data Corporation, said today that the Compaq Computer Corporation had strengthened its position as the No. 1 supplier worldwide, while Hewlett-Packard, at No. 3, and Dell Computer, which was No. 4, had particularly strong gains in sales. 
 International Data reported that worldwide PC shipments totaled 18.2 million in the April-through-June period, up 15 percent from the corresponding period last year. Shipments in the United States totaled 7.2 million, up 19 percent.
Dataquest said that second-quarter global shipments reached 18.9 million, up 17 percent from a year earlier, and that shipments in the United States came to 7 million, an increase of 21.9 percent.
Both reports said that Compaq's worldwide shipments jumped 42 percent in the April-June quarter, giving it a market share of nearly 12 percent. I.B.M. retained its No. 2 worldwide ranking, seeing shipments rise 20 percent, the reports said.
International Data reported that Hewlett-Packard's shipments vaulted by 48 percent; Dataquest reported a 58.4 percent increase worldwide. Dell, the largest direct seller of computers in the United States, saw its global shipments rise by 61.4 percent, according to Dataquest, and 52 percent, according to International Data.
"They're going like a freight train out of control these days, which is good," John Brown, an International Data analyst in Mountain View, Calif., said of Dell. "They're giving notice to the guys above."
But the "guys above," challenged by Dell's lower prices, are responding with their own price cuts. While that is good news for consumers and businesses, it could lead to severe pressure on smaller companies, said Scott Miller, a Dataquest analyst.
Such companies may be forced to insure sales by cutting prices and sacrificing profit. If they do not or cannot do that, they will probably see their share of the market erode, Mr. Miller said.
Completing the top five in terms of worldwide shipments was Packard Bell-NEC, which Dataquest said had 1.7 percent fewer shipments in the second quarter than a year earlier. International Data said Packard Bell-NEC's shipments rose 5 percent. While No. 5 on the global list, Packard Bell-NEC is No. 2 behind Compaq in the United States. Dell, International Business Machines and Hewlett-Packard follow in domestic ranking.
Neither Dataquest nor International Data rank personal computer makers beyond the top five. Apple Computer, which is struggling to recover from financial losses and declining market share, slipped from the top five earlier this year.
Mr. Brown said that while Apple's shipments rose 16 percent from the first quarter, they fell 21 percent from the second quarter of last year. The company's market share was 3.8 percent in the latest period.

HEADLINE: Asians Are Cool to Albright on Cambodians and Burmese

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER

DATELINE: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, July 27

 BODY:
Japan today rebuffed American requests to use aid to put pressure on Cambodia to hold free and fair elections, while the leaders of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations listened noncommitally as Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright urged them to work for democratic change in Myanmar.
Ms. Albright came face to face today with the polite indirection of Asia and of the nine-member Asean, which values collegiality and consensus above all virtues. Asean officials almost never "tell it like it is," which Ms. Albright has promised will be her trademark. 
 Ms. Albright's admonitions to Asean about its responsibilities in Myanmar, Cambodia and North Korea, where the United States wants the organization to contribute $10 million a year to promote nuclear nonproliferation, were predictable, an Asean diplomat said today. "We expected something of a lecture, and that's what we heard," he said.
But Ms. Albright has also heard some lecturing in return, in particular from the Malaysian Prime Minister, Mahathir Mohamad, who is known for his resentment of what he considers Western arrogance.
In a meeting with Asean and its partners, Ms. Albright objected to the picture of affairs in Myanmar, formerly Burma, painted by its Foreign Minister, U Ohn Gyaw. She described the Burmese military as drug traffickers and thugs.
Now that Asean has welcomed Myanmar to its fold over American objections, Ms. Albright said, the organization has a greater responsibility to promote democratic change there. "We must insist that we work together to promote conditions that will lead toward true democracy," she said of Myanmar.
She urged the nations of Asean to meet with the leader of the Burmese democracy movement, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi. Her National League for Democracy won 1990 elections before the military seized power and put her under house arrest.
Asked for Asean's reaction, Foreign Minister Abdullah Ahmad Badawi of the host country, Malaysia, said mildly, "It is for Asean to decide later what we will do, and we will bear in mind the views of Ms. Albright and others."
Rather than isolating Myanmar, Asean would continue its policy of "constructive engagement" with the military there, he said. He smiled and added, "But it is factually correct that the Burmese are not taking big steps forward."
Asean comprises Brunei, Myanmar, Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, Singapore, Thailand, Vietnam and Laos.
On Cambodia, neither Asean nor Japan was willing to hold back the bulk of their aid to press Hun Sen, the former co-Prime Minister who took power this month by defeating the forces of his rival, to keep his promises for free and fair elections, as the United States, the European Union and Australia are willing to do.
"We believe it useful to coalesce around the question of aid to influence Cambodia, but Japan and Asean have a different view," the State Department spokesman, Nicholas Burns, said after Ms. Albright's meeting with the Japanese Foreign Minister, Yukihiko Ikeda.
Half of Cambodia's budget is foreign aid, and Japan's $153 million a year represents half of that. Japan says it has four conditions for continuing aid: respect for human rights, maintenance of constitutional government, respect for the 1991 Paris accords that led to the 1993 elections, and free and fair elections in May for a new government.
While those conditions are not now being met, Mr. Hun Sen has promised to meet them, and that is sufficient, said Mr. Ikeda's spokesman, Nobuaki Tanaka. "There is a commitment -- that we respect."
Mr. Mahathir, the Malaysian Prime Minister, while polite to Ms. Albright in person, has been making some of the choice anti-American statements that keep him so popular in the developing world.
In a speech to Asean, Mr. Mahathir, whose country was once a British colony, spoke of the need for unity and said: "We suffered in a bipolar world. We know now that a unipolar world is no better."
He criticized what he sees as an American assumption that Asia needs its protection, first during the Vietnam War, and today from other Eastern countries like China.
He has also found a scapegoat in America for Southeast Asia's recent economic crisis, which has driven down the value of regional currencies. He contended that the crisis was a result of "a well-planned effort to undermine the economies of all the Asean countries by destabilizing their currencies."
The evil genius behind the plan, he has said repeatedly, is George Soros, the American financier and philanthropist who promotes human rights and democratization all over the world, including in Myanmar. Mr. Soros, Mr. Mahathir charges, has attacked Asean currencies "to block Myanmar's admission into Asean." The result, Mr. Mahathir says, is further suffering of the region's poor.
Mr. Soros and the manager of his currency funds have denied any effort to destabilize Asean or to punish it for admitting Myanmar.
"George Soros is an honorable person and has done a lot of good in the world," Mr. Burns told Malaysian Television. "Currency crises are common, and all is fair in international finance."

HEADLINE: White House Says Iran Pipeline Won't Violate Sanctions Act

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 27

 BODY:
Despite a new law meant to discourage foreign investment in Iran's oil and gas industry, the Clinton Administration has decided not to object to a $1.6 billion project to build a natural gas pipeline through Iran, Administration officials said today.
The officials insisted, however, that the Administration's tacit approval of the project did not reflect any easing of its longstanding efforts to isolate Iran economically and diplomatically. 
 Instead, they said, the Administration has signaled that it would not oppose the project since the pipeline's primary beneficiaries would be the two countries on either end of it -- Turkmenistan and Turkey -- and not Iran.
The pipeline, stretching some 2,000 miles from Turkmenistan, through Iran and into Turkey and perhaps beyond to Europe, would cost $1.6 billion and could eventually carry 30 billion cubic meters of natural gas to energy-short Turkey.
The officials, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the project, as now structured, would not violate the Iran-Libya Sanctions Act of 1996. That law, sponsored by Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York, gives the President the power to impose sanctions on foreign companies that invest $40 million or more a year in the oil or gas industries in Iran or Libya.
Even though the pipeline would pass through Iran and the Islamic Government in Teheran would stand to profit by charging transit fees, the Administration has concluded that the project would not constitute an investment in Iran's industry and that therefore it would not provoke sanctions under the act.
The Administration's decision, which was first reported today in The Washington Post, raised immediate concerns in Congress that the project would allow Iran to profit on an international energy deal in spite of the spirit, if not the letter, of the new law.
"I have some very real reservations," Senator D'Amato said today in a statement released by his office in New York City. "It will enable a Government which is still exporting terrorism to have the resources with which they can continue that practice."
The White House, anticipating intense questions surrounding the project, reiterated the United States' firm opposition to Iran. "There's been no change in policy or any signal regarding that policy," a White House spokeswoman, Anne R. Luzzatto, said today. "It is U.S. law and U.S. policy to seek to deny Iran the resources it needs to pursue terrorism and weapons of mass destruction."
Also, the officials who spoke on condition of anonymity emphasized that they still hoped to persuade Turkey and Turkmenistan to find an alternate route that would bypass Iran, perhaps even under the Caspian Sea.
One Administration official noted that from the perspective of the United States, this project was preferable to the one announced last year by Necmettin Erbakan, who was then Prime Minister of Turkey and the country's first ruler from a pro-Islamic party. Under that deal, now apparently moot, Turkey had agreed to purchase $23 billion of Iran's natural gas.
That project would have directly benefited Iran and could have triggered sanctions against Turkey, a close American ally and a member of NATO.
In the months after Mr. Erbakan signed that deal, the United States repeatedly raised its objections in talks with the Turks, explaining that Turkey would face sanctions if it went ahead. "We did not want to see an ally sanctioned," a senior Administration official said.
In May, Turkey signed an agreement to buy Turkmenistan's natural gas instead. The new project reflected a "significant evolution" from the original deal, the official said, allowing Turkey to buy gas while largely shutting out Iran.
One official said Iran stood to lose the most under the new arrangement since it would not be able to sell its gas to Turkey as originally proposed. "We see this as a powerful reaffirmation of our relationship with Turkey and not as a signal to the Iranians," the official said. "If this benefits anyone, it's the Turks."
The project could also help advance other American interests in the region.
Turkmenistan has the world's third-largest reserves of natural gas. Its market has long been in Russia to the north, but the United States hopes to help develop other outlets for the oil and gas reserves in Turkmenistan and the other Central Asian republics. Iran's strategic location between the Persian Gulf and the Caspian Sea has created an obstacle to that policy.
Although planning for the project remains in the earliest stages, it would conceivably involve a consortium of international energy concerns, led by Turkey's state-owned oil and gas pipeline company, Botas.
One official said the project could still violate the new law, if, for example, an international company contracted to build a significant part of the 788 miles of pipeline through Iran.
Ms. Luzzatto, the White House spokeswoman, said the Administration would continue to enforce the new law, monitoring "this and other deals" that could benefit Iran.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
G.O.P.-M.I.A.

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Watching Jesse Helms, the Republican boss of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, tear apart the nomination as ambassador to Mexico of William Weld, the Republican Governor of Massachusetts, it occurred to me: What ever happened to Republican foreign policy?
Do those three words -- "Republican foreign policy" -- have any meaning anymore? Talking to Republicans, the answer is increasingly "No." There is no reasonably unified Republican view on any major foreign issue, be it trade, NATO or China. "We simply have not come up with a coherent foreign policy of our own," says Senator John McCain, one of the few serious defense thinkers left in his party's leadership. 
 Who killed Republican foreign policy? In part it was the collapse of the Soviet threat, which had been the keystone of Republican national security thinking. But President Clinton has also done to Republicans on foreign policy what he did to them on domestic policy: He occupied all the middle ground -- on trade, on NATO, on China and on intervention generally -- so that, as one Administration official put it, "Republicans either have to become Clintonites on foreign policy or become crazies. It's totally disoriented them."
Indeed, Pat Buchanan, with his far-out isolationist protectionism is the only Republican leader with his own vision. As a result, some young conservative thinkers are trying to fill the void. One school is neo-Reaganism, represented by Bill Kristol and Bob Kagan of the conservative Weekly Standard. K. & K. advocate an expansive, large notion of U.S. leadership, which Mr. Kristol unabashedly describes as "enlightened imperialism without the empire." Their view is that America is the only superpower and it should act like it -- not just defending its own vital interest, not just reacting to others, but using its influence and military weight to vigorously and, when necessary, unilaterally promote human rights and American values from Bosnia to Beijing. They advocate a particularly tough line on China, arguing that it is the biggest moral and strategic threat to the U.S. "We are assertive Reaganites," says Mr. Kristol (but without a Reagan or a Teddy Roosevelt to carry their banner).
Countering this approach is a thoughtful new book by former Bush adviser Richard Haass, entitled "The Reluctant Sheriff," which embodies "neo-Bushism." Mr. Haass is also for engagement, but believes the U.S. doesn't have the resources or public support for the unilateral, size-large leadership of the Kagan-Kristol view. He argues that the U.S. must lead by building coalitions of countries or institutions that would concentrate on doing two big jobs -- preventing aggression between nations and promoting free trade among nations. "If we can just get those two things right, we will have a solid foundation for peace and prosperity," said Mr. Haass.
"Kagan and Kristol argue that the purpose of U.S. foreign policy should be to maintain U.S. hegemony," said Mr. Haass. "They want to prevent the rise of competitors. That is both impossible and unwise. We should be aiming to co-opt competitors and, where possible, transform them. Our goal should be to build a world to our liking that we can sustain at a reduced cost." Mr. Haass insists economic engagement is the best way to change China and that the neocons are "wrong and shortsighted" by trying to isolate Beijing, which will neither produce human rights there nor protect U.S. strategic interests.
So Republicans have two foreign policy visions and no leader and the Democrats have a leader but no particular vision. With the world so peaceful, does it matter that the Republicans can't mount a unified, coherent critique? I think so. There are some huge issues to be decided this year -- Bosnia, NATO, China -- and the Clinton team's sloppiness in dealing with these issues up to now is due partly to the fact that all the Republicans have mustered is drive-by foreign policy: drive by the White House, shout something, then drive off.
"There has to be a vigorous debate and illumination of issues," argued Senator McCain. "Because without that the American people are uninformed and uninterested. Look what's happened in Haiti. It's terrible. We had 20,000 troops there for two years and spent $2 billion. And it's all coming apart now. But nobody gives a darn, and how do you keep the Administration honest if nobody cares?"

HEADLINE: As Cathedral Opens, Preacher-Politician Looks Ahead

BYLINE: By NORIMITSU ONISHI

 BODY:
A few hours after attending services early yesterday morning, Charlene Simpson was so overwhelmed by the opening of New York City's newest cathedral that she returned to worship at the day's third and final service. For Mrs. Simpson, the new $23 million Cathedral of the Allen African Methodist Episcopal Church in Jamaica, Queens, was the crowning achievement in the church's efforts to rebuild what is still one of the borough's poorest corners.
And, Mrs. Simpson said, without its pastor, the Rev. Floyd H. Flake, who has been the area's United States Representative since 1986, the neighborhood would have been "a disaster." 
 "It would have been like the Wild West," said Mrs. Simpson, 50, a bank manager who has lived in nearby St. Albans for 31 years. "We wouldn't have had a leader."
The talk of Jamaica yesterday centered around the long-anticipated opening of the cathedral, a soaring modern structure on Merrick Boulevard and 110th Avenue, by the most powerful church in the predominantly black section of southeast Queens. But given Mr. Flake's dual role as preacher and politician, some parishioners predictably wondered whether the opening would lead to another change.
After months of rumors that he might not seek a seventh term in Congress, Mr. Flake, 52, said last week that he might retire from politics to focus on the growing Allen A.M.E. Church, where he has been pastor for 21 years. Yesterday, Mr. Flake said that he had not made up his mind but would announce his decision to his congregants next Sunday.
"They will be the first to know what my plans are," he said after the end of the third service yesterday.
Several members said they were torn by their desire to have Mr. Flake exercise more direct authority over their church in Queens, and the knowledge that the area had greatly benefited from the Congressman's success in channeling dollars from Washington.
Selena Turner, 33, an account executive at an insurance company, said she had noticed many improvements to the district since she had moved to the area six years ago. They included dozens of two-family homes that the church's real estate arm helped build a few years ago with city and state housing dollars near Linden and Guy R. Brewer Boulevards.
"I remember it was just dirt there, and now there are homes," said Ms. Turner, who was standing in line for the beginning of the morning's third service with her twin 5-year-old nephew and niece, Jarese and Jonice Johnson. "It's the same with this new church."
"I feel he should do what God leads him to do," Ms. Turner said about Mr. Flake's coming announcement.
Although some of Mr. Flake's critics have said that he has not secured the same level of public and private investment for his entire district, the development around the Congressman's neighborhood, near the intersection of Merrick and Linden, is hard to miss: a 300-unit apartment complex for the elderly built with Federal housing loans, the Allen Christian School, hundreds of houses built with the help of Fannie Mae loans.
Mr. Flake, who used his friendships with powerful Republicans to gain economic clout for his district, pointed out yesterday that the Federal Drug Administration and Federal Aviation Administration were building offices in his district.
"This is the only Congressional district in the city where you have any Federal building being built," he said. "At the same time, I've been able to get this church built."
Mr. Flake said the 93,000-square-foot complex, with an 84-foot-high stone steeple, will be paid for with money raised by the 8,600-member congregation. "This is going to have to be the wave of the future if we're actually going to turn these urban communities around," he said. "People who live in them will have to understand that you have to invest in them."
The new Allen Cathedral, with 2,500 seats the largest church structure to be built in New York City since 1954, is now the second largest black church in New York, after the Concord Baptist Church in Brooklyn, which seats 2,800. Finishing touches are still being made to the cathedral's offices, and the windows are yet to be installed.
Against the backdrop of a 100-member choir, Mr. Flake told his congregants that they had more work ahead, including obtaining and renovating a boarded-up, two-story commercial strip across the street from the new church. But yesterday, the pastor turned most of his attention to the cathedral and at least some attention to the issue of paying off $23 million in construction costs.
Mr. Flake reminded churchgoers that they had worshiped for 14 years in the Allen School's auditorium, sitting on uncomfortable blue chairs.
"You asked me, 'When are we going to fix them?' " he said. "Why would we fix something we were not going to be using permanently. And we didn't want you to be too comfortable. You'd still want to be sitting over there.
"But this morning, we're here. And we're sitting on cushioned pews. Cushioned pews. We're walking on nice carpet, plush. Everything's beautiful. Look at the woodwork. And look at the redwood ceiling all the way from Canada. Amen. We're ready for the future."
"I ask you," Mr. Flake added, "touch that pew again. It's an unpaid-for pew." It was a masterly segue that drew both laughs and dollar bills.

SECTION: Section B; Page 1; Column 5; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 1748 words

HEADLINE: After Quiet Success, Columbia's President Faces Din of Protest;
Conflict Over a Dean's Dismissal Puts George Rupp In the Spotlight

BYLINE: By BRUCE WEBER

 BODY:
The conflict of hubris versus humility surfaces in George E. Rupp when he summarizes his professional life.
"I build institutions," he said in a recent interview. Then, as if that sounded brash, he shrugged and undercut himself. "It's what I do for a living, for better or worse." 
 Four years ago this month, Mr. Rupp took over as president of Columbia University. He had spent eight well-regarded years as president of Rice University in Houston, but he arrived here an unknown. And, truth be told, he still is, despite ample successes at Columbia -- a $650 million building program, a two-thirds boost in undergraduate applications and an increase of more than $1 billion in the endowment.
On campus, the prevailing view of Mr. Rupp is that he can do the job, but it is as if he does not believe it himself. He just cannot seem to sell the job he is doing. That may be why his first prominent misstep attracted more attention than all his achievements put together.
On June 30, Mr. Rupp dismissed the popular dean of Columbia College, the university's undergraduate school. The uproar among professors, students and alumni -- who saw the dean, Austin E. Quigley, as their advocate in the Byzantine game of institutional politics -- was immediate. Three days later, Mr. Rupp reinstated him.
"It makes me look like I caved," he said in an interview in his office, though he insisted it was not so. With tie loosened and sleeves rolled, he looked exasperated with the whole thing.
The reversal has left the president appearing at worst spineless, at best mystifying. Many at Columbia are befuddled by his combination of aggressive tactics and unimposing personality. "This is a black mark that's very public for a man who didn't have one," said Donald C. Hood, a professor of psychology. "If you were to ask should George Rupp continue as president, I would say yes. But when I heard about Austin, I thought I'd heard everything. This was a really stupid move."
A Presbyterian minister, slightly built and unprepossessing, Mr. Rupp, 54, comes off more as a God-fearing Little League coach than a chief executive. And though his vision of Columbia as a forward-looking and cogently organized institution is ambitious and, many faculty members say, sound, he is apparently not the kind of leader people like to be pushed by. He does not work a room well. He is energetic but not energizing.
That is true, said Joan W. Konner, the departing dean of the Graduate School of Journalism, but perhaps that is not the central point. "I don't know that there has been much discussion of his values," she said. "He is out to change our style and nature." Columbia, she said, has had factions that contribute to an intramurally competitive and even backbiting atmosphere. She said: "Columbia has an ingrained set of values. 'We're the toughest. We're the smartest.' And it's not such a great set of values. George is more community oriented."
That is why people are often surprised by the list of Mr. Rupp's accomplishments since taking office in 1993, which includes the initiation of ambitious projects like a long-needed renovation of Butler Library, the construction of a $70 million student center, and, more modestly, the improvement of the food in the undergraduate dining hall. He had the dormitories wired for Internet access and streamlined the student billing process; as a result, more people are paying their tuition on time.
"The most striking characteristic of President Rupp's term is the long-overdue overhaul of the nonacademic side of the university," said David J. Helfand, chairman of the astronomy department. "That's not trivial. To try and hire someone from a secretary to a senior researcher, it used to be a nightmare."
In addition to the increase in applications, the rate of admission, 30 percent in 1993, decreased to 17 percent for this fall's entering class. It is more selective than it used to be. Riding the strong economy, Mr. Rupp oversaw an increase in donations from $116 million the year before he arrived to more than $200 million this year, and raised the endowment from $1.8 billion in 1993 to an estimated $3 billion as of June 30.
Even Mr. Rupp's detractors give him credit for his deft handling of an incident last year when 100 students occupied Hamilton Hall, the main college building, demanding the creation of an ethnic studies curriculum, which he brought to an end sternly but with peaceful negotiations.
"I have not seen a president deal with a student disturbance more effectively," said Professor Hood, who has been at Columbia since 1969. "He did not give away any power of the curriculum, he didn't grant any amnesty, but they still worked it out, and we had a peaceful graduation."
When Mr. Rupp arrived from Rice, which has 4,200 students, he stepped in magnitude of responsibility. Columbia, with an annual budget of $1.2 billion, has 15 schools and 70 academic departments and divisions, in which it offers 6,000 courses to 20,000 students. It is the third largest private employer in the city.
Mr. Rupp did not appear to be cowed. He made an immediate impression by cleaning house even before he arrived, replacing three deans, including Jack Greenberg, the former director of the N.A.A.C.P. Legal Defense and Educational Fund and dean of Columbia College.
He has replaced much of the university's senior administration. Many people praise his hirings, among them those of David Cohen, formerly the provost of Northwestern University, now the vice president of the Arts and Sciences Division, and Emily S. Lloyd, the former City Sanitation Commissioner who is the chief operating officer. But others lament those who have fallen by the wayside, including Lance Liebman, dean of the School of Law, and John G. Ruggie, dean of the School of International and Public Affairs.
From the outset, Mr. Rupp said he would exploit what he sees as Columbia's chief assets: its New York City location, renowned faculty and international reputation. But most of all, he has focused on reining in an institution that had become so diverse as to be nearly unrecognizable as a whole. He consolidated disparate resources, linking the economics and business faculties, for example.
But nothing has been so central to his vision as the augmentation of Columbia College, the undergraduate school.
Columbia is largely a research institution, but its ratio of undergraduates to graduate students is uncommonly small. That is a problem, not least because Ph.D. students frequently need subsidies, while the tuition-paying undergraduates provide revenue.
Undergraduate alumni tend to be the most generous donors. But Columbia has the smallest undergraduate school in the Ivy League, and ranks near the bottom in percentage of alumni who contribute. Columbia College has enlarged its student body from 2,950 in the mid-80's to 3,600 today. By 2000, the enrollment will top 4,000. But more students mean more services and more teachers.
That is at the heart of the Quigley incident, in which Mr. Rupp seems to have erred, either by reversing himself or by dismissing Mr. Quigley in the first place.
This is how it played out: in the debate over the allotment of resources to Columbia College, Mr. Quigley, an English professor who was promoted from the faculty and was a favorite of students, found himself on the opposite side from Mr. Cohen, the new vice president for arts and sciences to whom he reports. Mr. Rupp eventually sided with Mr. Cohen.
Their disagreements were over the apportioning of teaching responsibilities between undergraduate and graduate schools and how quickly Columbia should expand its recruitment. But the underlying tension was financial.
The Arts and Sciences Division, which encompasses five schools, including Columbia College, has been running at a deficit, but the college itself has not. Mr. Cohen and Mr. Quigley were fighting over resources. Shortly after Mr. Cohen wrote a negative evaluation of Mr. Quigley, Mr. Rupp dismissed him.
"Where are the resources going?" asked Michael Rosenberg, a professor of English. "That's one of the issues Austin was fighting over. My concern is, if you have a larger college and don't make it a better college, what have you got?"
Mr. Rupp acknowledged "there have been tensions." When the tensions turned counterproductive, he said, he dismissed Mr. Quigley.
"George has to back his people," one dean said, speaking on condition of anonymity, "and Cohen is his people. I really think he just didn't know the whole score. The deans are too important, too visible. They usually have a constituency. George just didn't do his homework in taking a very big step."
As the news spread, letters and phone calls of protest poured into the president's office. Mr. Quigley had been dismissed on a Monday; on Wednesday, Mr. Rupp was visited by four influential Columbians, who asked Mr. Rupp to reconsider, including Philip Milstein, a trustee, and Carlos R. Munoz, president of the Columbia College Alumni Association. The same day, 25 members of the alumni association came to his office and, in a meeting that grew heated, made the same request.
What changed Mr. Rupp's mind is unclear. He says it was partly their fervor. Insisting there was no financial pressure brought to bear, he added, "Not one of them said, 'I'll withdraw my gifts.' "
But Mr. Munoz, an executive vice president of Dime Savings Bank of New York, saw it differently.
"There were people who were giving a lot of money who were upset," he said, "and certainly there was an implied threat."
Mr. Rupp recently lamented that the incident became public. He had been negotiating a rapprochement with Mr. Quigley, he said, when news of the dismissal spread.
"I'm an impatient person," he said. "Austin and I have disagreements about the pace of some changes. But we work well together. We have a congruent view of what we're doing. We had a little bit of a tiff and we worked it out."
The Board of Trustees remains supportive of the president, say its two vice chairmen, Lionel I. Pincus and Jerry I. Speyer. But the reversal has left many Columbians wondering who is really in charge. They remain as split on Mr. Rupp's character as he seems to be himself.
Mr. Quigley, perhaps, deserves the last word, and he delivered his judgment, deftly spun. "He's a strong and forceful leader," he said, "who is not afraid to change direction when he feels circumstances warrant."

HEADLINE: New York Should Ban All Crowded Housing

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Alan Wolfe's appeal to reason on the issue of illegal immigration (Op-Ed, July 23) ignores the fact that immigrants are attracted to this country because low-paying jobs are readily available. Their labor thus underwrites the high living standards of the rest of the population. Immigration policy aggressively targets them instead of their employers. This drives their wages down even further. 
 The recent plight of the Mexican deaf-mutes in New York City might not be a parable, as Mr. Wolfe asserts, but it is a clear example of the working conditions and marginalization prompted by immigration policies that fail to address the economic mechanisms behind the phenomenon.
 
PABLO PICCATO
New York, July 25, 1997

HEADLINE: Workfare Must Train Participants for Real Jobs;
No Job Is Not an Option

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "Nonprofit and Religious Groups Vow to Fight Workfare Program" (front page, July 24): 
 As a hospital social worker with five years' experience with the homeless and unemployed, I have concluded that if an able-bodied adult without small children cannot find any work after a number of years, to continue to provide such services for an indefinite period of time is a disservice to the recipient because all of life's needs are provided for, without effort. Most of the clients I have seen don't work because they don't have to.
Protesting New York City's workfare program with a sign that says "Rudy, We Will Not Be Your Slave Drivers," in effect calling Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani a slave master, will only inhibit change in our welfare system, one that has been waiting for some fine-tuning for two decades.
 
DAVID E. BERGSTEIN
New York, July 25, 1997

HEADLINE: Web Advertising Beyond Banners

BYLINE: By Nzong Xiong

 BODY:
As Internet users cruise around the World Wide Web, advertisments of all types line the roadside -- ads that are the functional equivalent of storefronts, with the merchants eager to lure people in to sample their goods. But luring is harder in a world without window displays.
 Advertisers started out in 1994 using simple banner ads, like roadside billboards. But advertisers were not totally satisfied with the banner and began looking for other models. "They haven't figured what ad form will be most effective and what should be in the ad," said Bill Doyle, senior analyst at Forrester Research in Cambridge, Mass. "So advertisers are playing with all the levers right now." 
 And what have they found so far? Animated type, animated images, interactive trivia, banners that scroll along with news headlines in on-screen tickers, five-second pop-up windows and more. Last year, advertisers, particularly technology and business and financial services companies, spent $301 million advertising on the Internet, according to Marc Johnson, an on-line advertising analyst at Jupiter Communications in New York. In the first quarter of 1997 alone, $133 million was spent, he said.
Here are just some of the models out there already on the Internet. Nzong Xiong

GRAPHIC: Chart:
 
POP-UP WINDOWS
Pop-up windows appear for five seconds when a user opens the page. The advertiser's banner remains at the top of the page after the window disappears.
 
Who clicks?
10 percent to 13 percent of visitors to a site click on this type of ad.
 
Leading advertiser
Procter & Gamble
 
Sales Pitch
"The five-second window is our most intrusive ad model to date," said Sarah Chubb, director of Conde Net, a division of Advance Publications' Conde Nast. It works for advertisers because the user can't help but notice it."
 
ROADBLOCKS
Users must pass though a full-screen ad to reach the game they want to play. Sometimes, the advertisers offer prizes to winners.
 
Who clicks?
11 percent of visitors to a site
 
Leading advertiser
Sega Soft, an on-line video game site
 
Sales Pitch
"It creates a very high impact with the user," said Geoff Judge, executive vice president for Riddler.com, a game and entertainment site owned by Interactive Imaginations in New York. "You can get across a very powerful message to the user. It also delivers high click-through for advertisers."
 
TICKERS
Users see a banner between a moving stream of headlines.
 
Who clicks?
Not available yet
 
Leading advertisers
Digital Equipment, Infospace, and Cybermax Computer
 
Sales Pitch
"We are delivering updated headlines to subscribed channels," said Paul Fusco, president and chief executive of Desktop News in New York. "When users click to that headline, it launches users to that specific site."
 
INTERMERCIALS
Users see 30-second animated commericals.
 
Who clicks?
2 percent to 4 percent of visitors to a site
 
Leading advertisers
I.B.M., Fidelity Investments, and MCI Communications
 
Sales pitch
"They are so powerful because they can encourage action from your immediate prospects and also use powerful images and information to cultivate future costumers," said Anna Zornosa, senior vice president at Pointcast in Sunnyvale, Calif.
 
INCENTIVES
Web site developers are invited to put merchant logos on their pages free of charge as a way to direct traffic to a merchant's goods. If developers are able to direct traffic there and visitors make purchases, developers receive 5 percent of the sales in cash or prizes.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; Metropolitan Desk

HEADLINE: Mexicans in New York Search for a Toehold on a Crowded Ladder

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ

 BODY:
The Irish who moved to Mott Haven in the 1860's searching for jobs are long gone, but the memory lingers at St. Jerome's Roman Catholic Church. The altar and sanctuary walls -- in marble of green, white and orange-yellow -- are a sly echo of the Irish colors. Above, huge stained-glass windows depict Bible scenes, like Jesus feeding the multitudes.
"They told stories in pictures," said the Rev. John Grange, who grew up in the neighborhood and is now the church's pastor. "People didn't know how to read." 
 Now a new generation is looking heavenward to learn the old stories. They come from Mexico, crowded into the red brick apartments that face the church on East 138th Street in the Bronx, where stores that sell tacos, tortillas and chiles have opened in recent years. In the evening, they turn the church's asphalt parking lot into a plaza where children play soccer while their parents lean against a chain-link fence to chat and rest after a day spent working as dishwashers, cooks and janitors.
As the newest arrivals in a city whose economy and neighborhoods are renewed each generation by waves of new arrivals, the Mexicans are at the bottom of the ladder in community influence, living conditions and earning power. The plight of 57 deaf Mexicans held in servitude in Queens while they sold trinkets in the subway trains was an extreme. But the everyday hardships of such an existence -- from shoddy housing to poor pay -- struck a common chord among the masses of their countrymen for whom such indignities are accepted as the unofficial price of undocumented life.
Tuesday night, two dozen men and women held hands in prayer before meeting at St. Jerome's to discuss the deaf Mexicans. Dora Madrigal and her friends had at one time or another silently suffered at the hands of landlords, employers and thugs, she said, a fear born of being in the country illegally. But the deaf Mexicans finally went to the police when their situation became unbearable.
"They have been an example to us," said Miss Madrigal, who became a citizen last week. "Those who could not speak, complained. What happens to those of us who can speak, but don't?"
They stay in New York and work, joining the estimated 200,000 Mexicans in the city who are trying to survive in a land that for them holds the promise of a better life as it did for the Irish, Italian and Jewish immigrants before them.
Too new to have become hyphenated Americans or fearful because of their undocumented status, they have yet to form the kinds of local associations that unite them and advocate for better jobs and housing. Nor have they sought the help of older Mexican-American advocacy groups that, while active on a national level, have yet to make major inroads into New York out of deference to established Puerto Rican and Dominican organizations.
Instead, they have carved out niches in the city, and more recently moved beyond, to upstate New York and New Jersey, enduring indignities in the hope that hard work will prove redemptive. But changes in the city's labor market have led to many Mexicans, unlike their predecessors, being clustered in low-paying jobs in restaurants, delis and sweatshops that could thwart their progress into the middle class.
"For the people coming in now, their chances to move up through nonskilled work or on-the-job training are more circumscribed," said Robert Smith, a professor of sociology at Barnard College who has studied the city's Mexican community. "Not only because the manufacturing jobs have left the city, but because there has been such a huge surge in immigration to New York there are a lot of other people before them in line to take those jobs."
 
A Trickle in the 40's, A Flow in the 80's
Mr. Smith's research has traced the Mexican immigration to New York to the early 1940's when two men from the state of Puebla arrived looking for work almost by accident. As word spread of their good fortune, others followed. Their numbers were fueled in the 1980's by Mexico's economic crisis, which hit Puebla especially hard, and now Poblanos account for about half of the Mexican immigrant population.
Mexican immigration boomed later in the decade when an amnesty resulted in formerly illegal residents sending for their families.
Mr. Smith said that he did not expect the North American Free Trade Agreement to generate enough manufacturing jobs in Mexico to offset the current migration. If anything, he said, he was seeing new immigrants coming from areas that had not previously sent large numbers of people.
"I don't think that Nafta will do anything to stop this," he said. "As you industrialize, you need less people to do the work. Also, investment will not be in places that have poor resources, the places that people are leaving. If it does anything, in the medium term, it will make it worse."
Jorge did not need to understand treaties to realize that his family would never escape poverty in Oaxaca as long as he made $3 a day at his construction job. "You cannot do anything with that," said Jorge, who refused to use his last name because he has been living illegally in New York since arriving four years ago. "You cannot eat."
It took him three months to find a job in a factory painting clothing for $3 an hour, he said. Although he had neither documents nor a command of English, it was not a problem.
"Where I worked, everybody spoke Spanish," he said. "Even the Jews spoke Spanish."
He now makes salads in a Manhattan restaurant, and the $6 an hour he is paid has helped buoy his family back home.
"It was definitely worth coming here," he said. "I have a house in Mexico. My family is better off. I'm not ready to leave New York. I like it."
 
In Land of Plenty, Not Enough for Some
But others are not so sure. The legions of immigrants who troop through the subways selling candy and their above-ground compatriots who sell fruits and flowers from carts complain that they are harassed by the police, overcharged by suppliers and assaulted by thugs. Some had tried to get licenses from the city, but the number is capped.
Jose Ramos, whose worn face belied his 38 years, had sold only two bouquets of red, white and blue carnations by 5 o'clock Monday afternoon. A customer handed him a ten-dollar bill and he had to scurry over to a coconut-ice vendor for change.
"One never comes here seeing the reality, so you think it's easy," said Mr. Ramos, a former farm worker who arrived in New York a year ago. "The people who come here see there is no work, so they take what they can, they take whatever they're paid. You sell all day and make $10, how can you survive? You can't."
Yet they manage by crowding into apartments where each room houses a family or in crumbling basements where they sleep in shifts. Many immigrants said that while competition for jobs was already fierce, they were increasingly worried about how tighter immigration laws would affect them. One reason New York had become a preferred destination was that its immigration authorities were seldom seen as a threat.
The recent Federal court decision that overturned the city's policy of not disclosing immigration status when residents sought services has also increased the fear and uncertainty. Ilze Betins, a social worker who directs El Faro Beacon Youth and Family Services in Spanish Harlem, said that many of her Mexican clients were already so fearful that they almost never gave out information like addresses and telephone numbers.
Eddie Baca, the executive director of the Local Development Corporation del Barrio, said that while the intent of the new policies was to root out illegal immigrants, they would accomplish the opposite. The need to make a dollar and the appetite of employers for cheap labor are too great, he said.
"It's a pipe dream," said Mr. Baca, who is of Mexican descent. "They're not going to leave."
Faced with a growing Mexican community in the city and what they perceive as a hostile political climate toward immigrants nationally, some of the more established Mexican-American organizations are considering expanding in New York.
The National Council of La Raza, which began as a Chicano advocacy group but increasingly has taken a pan-Hispanic approach, has been working with some New York nonprofit groups to reach out to the new immigrants, who themselves may be unfamiliar with what help is available.
"We are going to have to try and speed up the timetable a bit," said Charles Kamasaki, a senior vice president. "That's true with any group coming from a more authoritarian system where there is not a tradition of nonprofit organizations. It takes a while, at least a generation."
 
Looking to the Church For Comfort and Unity
Many immigrants said that apart from the soccer leagues started by the Mexican Consulate in the city, they seldom had contact with consular officials, whom they described as too bureaucratic and insufficiently involved in the communities. But many have turned to local churches for help with everything from housing to jobs.
Five years ago, hardly anyone attended the Mass on the Feast of Our Lady of Guadalupe. Now the December celebration of Mexico's Madonna attracts 1,000 worshipers, families with children who cram the church for a mariachi Mass.
"There's really no difference between them and the Irish," said Father Grange. "They eat rice and we ate potatoes. But the church is still important. You respect your parents and you try to study."
They are hard workers, he said, whose desire to earn a living had left them vulnerable to accepting starvation wages. In response, Father Grange started a cleaning service which now employs 100 Mexicans who make $10 an hour. Other parishioners have formed a savings group where they contribute $200 a month. Now they intend to pool their money in a health care cooperative.
"We're organizing as a group to have some unity," said Lucia Sanchez, a longtime parishioner. "Too often what happens happens, and everybody curses their luck. There has always been discrimination, but not like now. People don't want Mexicans. They don't respect Mexicans."
In Brooklyn, Fabiola Villagomez feels a bit cursed herself. She had told her dying uncle she would stay in Puebla and finish nursing school. She promised not to marry Gustavo, the country boy she had met while caring for her uncle. But Gustavo charmed her into breaking her blood vows to utter the vows of matrimony.
She lives in Bushwick with her husband in a room they rent in another Mexican family's apartment. He works in a clothing factory, saving for the house he is building back in Mexico. She stays at home, bored, wondering why she ever came to New York City in 1995 with no documents and no diploma. Her only job was a few months in a paper factory where she said she made $50 a week.
She stood in the shadow of the elevated train on Broadway, saddened by the recollection of her act of betrayal. She wore a New York City T-shirt, emblazoned with images of the Statue of Liberty, the World Trade Center towers and the masks of comedy and tragedy. Those, too, seemed like broken promises.
"I had imagined this city to be a palace, something beautiful," she said. "Not so much cruelty, racism or the ugly things in this country."
Still, some days she walks into Woodhull Hospital, if only to keep alive a stubborn hope.
"I go in just to watch the nurses and the patients," she said. "I close my eyes and imagine myself giving injections."

HEADLINE: Clinton Golfs And Attends Fund-Raiser In California

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, July 27

 BODY:
As negotiators in Washington worked to strike an agreement on budget and tax-cut legislation, President Clinton played golf today at a Los Angeles country club before raising money for Democrats who are seeking to regain control of the House of Representatives next year.
Halfway through a three-day trip that included an announcement of Federal assistance for Lake Tahoe on Saturday and a planned appearance before the National Governors Association in Las Vegas, Nev., on Monday, Mr. Clinton was the main draw at a fund-raising dinner here for Democratic candidates. 
 The President told a crowd sprinkled with celebrities such as Nancy Sinatra and Morgan Fairchild that a budget agreement could be near.
"This is a very good budget if we can resolve the remaining problems," Mr. Clinton said. "There is a tax cut in it. The tax cut ought to be fair to working families, it ought to put a primary emphasis on education, it ought to help the economy grow and it shouldn't explode in the later years so that we go right back to the deficits we just worked ourselves out of."
He appealed to his party to stand by his side. "I want us to make this balanced budget agreement tomorrow that I hope 90 percent plus of the Democrats will vote for."
The $5,000 a couple gathering raised more than $600,000. Democrats said a small portion of the money that was being raised was so-called "soft money,"the kind of unrestricted financing that President Clinton had called on Congress to ban as part of legislation to overhaul the campaign finance system.
Mr. Clinton's aides were unapologetic about the President's continuing efforts to bring in such donations for the Democrats who are gearing up for the midterm elections in 1998.
"We are playing by the current rules," said Joe Lockhart, a White House spokesman. "We have no intention of unilaterally disarming."
Mr. Lockhart today also brushed off a call on the NBC news program "Meet the Press" by Senator Trent Lott, the majority leader, for Mr. Clinton to become directly involved in the budget and tax-cut negotations taking place in Washington. Mr. Lockhart said the President had made his position clear on the crucial issues and had "absolute confidence" in the Administration officials who are bargaining on his behalf.
"If at an appropriate time he needs to become involved personally, he'll do that," Mr. Lockhart said.
As his aides manuevered back in Washington, the President spent most of his time in Los Angeles on Saturday night and on Sunday socializing with some of his party's most devoted donors.
On his way to California on Saturday aboard Air Force One, Mr. Clinton was already in a Hollywood mood, joking with reporters about the movie thriller 'Air Force One." He said his own plane was not quite as elaborate as the movie version. "As far as I know there is no escape pod," he said, "and I don't think we have quite the arsenal on there, and there's no back door."
Soon after landing here, Mr. Clinton went to Beverly Hills where he had dinner at the home of Lew R. Wasserman, the former chairman of MCA. A year ago, during the Presidential campaign, Mr. Wasserman held a $1 million fund-raising event for Mr. Clinton at his home with a star-studded guest list that included Neil Simon, Tom Cruise, Nicole Kidman, Geena Davis and Barbra Streisand.
This time, however, the President's aides said the gathering had nothing to do with raising money. Ms. Streisand was there again with her escort, the actor James Brolin. Also joining the President were Michael D. Eisner, the chairman of Walt Disney Company; Jack Valente, the president of the Motion Picture Association; Bud Yorkin, the television and film producer, and former Secretary of State Warren Christopher.
This morning, Mr. Clinton was out early for breakfast at the Santa Monica beach house of supermarket executive Ron Burkle. The President waved for a moment from a second-floor balcony to joggers, bicyclists and skaters who crowded an oceanside path below. Mr. Burkle, who has played host to several large fund-raising events for Mr. Clinton, was a vice chairmen of the President's second inauguration.
Not one to waste glorious golfing weather, Mr. Clinton then went to the Hillcrest Country Club with a golfing entourage of nine. The President teed off in a foursome that included Mayor Richard Riordan of Los Angeles, a Republican.

HEADLINE: Major Budget Issues Settled, Gingrich Says

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 27

 BODY:
Speaker Newt Gingrich said tonight that Congressional Republicans and the Administration had settled all but "maybe three tiny issues" in their negotiations over tax cuts and a balanced budget and that he intended to introduce legislation by Monday night.
But a White House spokesman traveling with President Clinton in California disputed that assessment, saying that there were still "significant issues" to be resolved. Even some senior Republican aides involved in the negotiations were much more cautious than Mr. Gingrich. They said that a deal was indeed very close but some tough issues still had to be worked out and that the Speaker might have been trying to pressure Mr. Clinton. 
 "I think we have an agreement, but it's never done until it's done," Mr. Gingrich told reporters this evening before sitting down with Senator Trent Lott, the majority leader, and other Republican leaders at a meeting in his office.
He said only three small issues -- one on taxes and two on spending -- stood between a final deal, although he declined to give details.
But the White House spokesman traveling with President Clinton said in Los Angeles that Mr. Gingrich was premature in his observations.
"There are still significant issues to be worked out and until they're worked out, we don't have a deal," said the spokesman, Joe Lockhart.
Mr. Gingrich seemed undaunted by the Administration's response. As he left the meeting about 9:15 P.M., he said again that "no significant issues" remained to be negotiated.
"We're doing fine," he said "and basically we'll file the bill by tomorrow."
Another Republican aide involved in the discussions said party leaders had spent the day advising certain rank-in-file members, especially some of the hard-line conservatives, on the progress of the talks and had received favorable responses. The aide said Mr. Gingrich wanted to push legislation through the House as quickly as possible before it could be picked apart.
The conflicting signals on just where the negotiations stood came at the end of a day where there were much more concrete signs of progress in the talks.
The negotiators have kept an unusually tight lid on their discussions. But senior Republican aides who have been involved in the talks revealed a few of the details.
They said the two sides had compromised on what had been the major sticking point, a proposed $500-a-child tax credit.
The White House reportedly agreed that the tax credit would cover teen-agers as well as younger children and that families making more than $60,000 would receive the full credit. The Republicans, in turn, yielded to an Administration demand that low-income families with little or no income tax burden be allowed to receive the per-child tax credit based on the family's payroll tax.
Mr. Clinton wanted the $500 tax credit to apply to working families that made as little as $18,000 a year and who paid no income tax but owe payroll taxes for Social Security and Medicare. He said the tax credit should be phased our for families making $60,000 to $75,000 a year through 2000. After that, the Administration had proposed that the phase-out would range apply to families making $80,000 to $100,000.
Republicans had argued against giving the tax credit to working families that paid little or nor income taxes, saying that would be a form of welfare. In their original proposal, the tax credit would be phased out at $75,000 in family income.
Aides said this evening that they were still working out the details of the compromise plan.
Republicans and the White also agreed to reduce the capital gains tax to 20 percent from 28 percent, the aides said. But the Republicans backed down from their demand that investors not be taxed on investment profits that result from inflation, so-called indexing.
And it seemed certain that the tax bill will contain an increase on cigarette taxes -- to 44 cents a pack, from 24 cents -- and that most, if not all of it, would go toward health care for uninsured children.
Even before Mr. Gingrich's rosy comments tonight, Republicans had given clear signals of movement.
Senator Pete V. Domenici conceded earlier in the day on the CBS News program "Face the Nation," that "it seems to me that we're going to have some cigarette tax."
Mr. Lott also hinted at the cigarette tax increase in his appearance on the NBC News program "Meet the Press."
But neither Mr. Domenici nor Mr. Lott would say whether the billions in revenue from such a tax increase would be used solely to provide health coverage for uninsured children from low-income families as the Administration had insisted.
And Representative Dick Armey, the House majority leader and Mr. Gingrich's second-in-command, had confirmed that negotiators were nearing an agreement on the child tax credit.
"We're trying to fit the President's detail into our principles and it's a very difficult fit to be made," Mr. Armey said on the ABC News program "This Week," "but we can get there."
Republicans hope to reach an agreement and approve a tax cut and balanced budget legislation before Friday, when Congress is due to begin a monthlong recess. The Republicans want to be able to go home to tell voters that they had succeeded on two of their biggest goals.
But Democratic leaders in the Senate and the House, and all nine Democrats on the tax-writing Senate Finance Committee, urged Mr. Clinton on Friday to extend the negotiations until September if necessary to win concessions from the Republicans.
Each side has spent the last few days posturing. Mr. Lott also used his television appearance to try to turn up the political pressure on Mr. Clinton, urging him to get directly involved in the negotiations on tax cuts and a balanced budget "to make it happen."
"I think right now what we need is the President to engage some," Mr. Lott said. "He's got to be prepared to make some concessions to get some."
Mr. Clinton, Mr. Lott and Mr. Gingrich were directly involved in reaching the broad deal for the tax cuts and for balancing the budget by 2002. But Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin and Erskine B. Bowles, the White House chief of staff have been in the current talks.
Although the President began a three-day trip to the West on Friday, he has been kept up to date on the negotiations, aides said.
"We are there speaking for the President, with specific instructions from him," Gene Sperling, Mr. Clinton's economic policy adviser, said on the CNN program "Late Edition."

HEADLINE: Reporter's Notebook;
Defense Lawyer Weighs Paternity Suit in Cosby Extortion Case

BYLINE: By BENJAMIN WEISER

 BODY:
What is next for Autumn Jackson? After her conviction Friday in a scheme to extort $40 million from Bill Cosby by threatening to sell a story that she was his daughter, her lawyer, Robert M. Baum, stood outside the Federal Courthouse in Manhattan and discussed her options, which include a paternity suit.
With Ms. Jackson facing as many as 12 years in prison, Mr. Baum said he would ask Judge Barbara S. Jones to consider the unusual circumstances of the case and not incarcerate his 22-year-old client. He said he would also appeal her conviction. 
 A paternity suit, Mr. Baum said by telephone yesterday, could compel Mr. Cosby to take a blood test and allow Ms. Jackson to prove whether she is his daughter.
But even if the judge allows a paternity suit to go forward -- most are filed on behalf of minors -- the strategy carries a big risk.
Suppose the suit established that Mr. Cosby was not her father. That would end a mystery that seemed to cause some opinions of Ms. Jackson to be more favorable. During her trial, some columnists portrayed Ms. Jackson sympathetically and criticized Mr. Cosby for not living up to parental obligations. Some sympathy might remain, but only for a young woman whose mother misled her from the age of 5, telling her that she was the actor's daughter.
One of Mr. Cosby's lawyers, Andrew Schau, said yesterday that Mr. Cosby has been willing to take a paternity test -- but only if the man listed on Ms. Jackson's birth certificate as her father, Jerald Jackson, takes one first -- and fails.
Mr. Baum, meanwhile, acknowledged the strategy carried some risk. "But Autumn would like to know, as she has always wanted to know, and establish her legitimacy."
 
The Extortion Paradox
At one point during closing arguments, Mr. Baum told the jury: "Autumn Jackson had a right to sell her story. Autumn Jackson had a right to ask her father to negotiate a settlement of her rights. "Two rights don't make a wrong," he added.
But prosecutors say that two rights do make a wrong, when they constitute a threat to harm someone's reputation, accompanied by a demand for money. The disagreement highlights an age-old legal debate about what one lawyer calls the paradox of extortion and blackmail (the terms are often used interchangeably).
"The reason blackmail has exerted fascination for scholars is that it's a profoundly mysterious offense," said Leo Katz, professor at the University of Pennsylvania Law School and author of the book, "Ill-Gotten Gains: Evasion, Blackmail, Fraud, and Kindred Puzzles of the Law."
"What makes it mysterious is that you are threatening to do something which you are perfectly entitled to do, and you are asking for a benefit in return for not doing it," he said.
James Lindgren, a law professor at Northwestern University who has written extensively on blackmail and extortion, said: "It's hard to see when you're doing things that individually are not wrong. It's not wrong to go to the tabloids, not wrong to make public claims about someone being your father, not wrong to ask for money.
"What's wrong," he said, "is when you use the explicit leverage of public disgrace to get what you want."
Some economists and lawyers have debated why blackmail and extortion are crimes in the first place. Paul Shechtman, a former top Federal prosecutor in Manhattan who performed an economic analysis of blackmail with Douglas H. Ginsburg, now a Federal Court of Appeals judge, found an economic rationale for keeping it a crime. Legalizing blackmail, he said, would spawn an entire industry that would dredge up secrets to conceal again for a price.
"As a general matter, it's not in anybody's economic interest to have people dig up dirt and rebury it," Mr. Shechtman said.
In any case, the extortion and blackmail riddle has not given prosecutors much pause. "Prosecutors have been prosecuting, blissfully ignorant of the debate," Mr. Shechtman said. And they have been winning convictions as well.
 
Not on the Court's TV
So why didn't the jury ever see "Down on the Farm With Chocolate Chips and the Prairie Dog Club"?
That was the children's television program that Ms. Jackson and her co-defendant, Jose Medina, claimed to be developing when the Government charged them with extortion.
"The story is about an angel, who is both a scarecrow and Indian medicine man, and his three child angel companions," Ms. Jackson wrote in a document introduced as evidence.
But when Mr. Medina's lawyer, Neil B. Checkman, hoping to show that Mr. Medina had been involved in a legitimate venture, told Judge Jones in her robing room that he wanted to play snippets from "Down on the Farm," maybe 15 minutes in all, she did not seem too enthusiastic about premiering the show in court.
"Fifteen minutes actually sounds like a lot of time to me," the judge said. "Is there any way to cut it back a little bit?"
Mr. Checkman discussed his plans further, joking, "We are not going to charge admission to this."
But last Monday, he said that he would not show the video, only introduce the script.
Would he be reading it to the jurors? Judge Jones asked.
Mr. Checkman said he would not, "though after the trial is over," he added, "they are welcome to a reenactment."
"We are on the same wavelength," the judge said, ending the matter.
