HEADLINE: At CUNY, a Debate on Grade Inflation

BYLINE: By KAREN W. ARENSON

 BODY:
How many A's and B's should a college give? And how many students should graduate with honors?
At the City University of New York, about half the course grades given are A's and B's. To Herman Badillo, vice chairman of the board of trustees, that is too many. 
 In calling for higher standards at the campuses, Mr. Badillo has repeatedly said that professors are cheapening the university by grading too leniently and granting too many honors. And he has accused the outgoing Chancellor, W. Ann Reynolds, of tolerating grade inflation. Dr. Reynolds announced July 17 that she was resigning after months of such criticism to become President of the University of Alabama's Birmingham campus.
"In the entire university, more than half of the students get A's and B's," Mr. Badillo said recently. "This is a disgrace."
He said he was also dismayed that more than half the graduates at Brooklyn College, a four-year college in the university, take honors. That suggests, he said, that "the students at Brooklyn College are the most brilliant in the country, and I don't believe it."
But to some CUNY faculty members, Mr. Badillo's charges amount to a gratuitous attack.
"The charge of grade inflation is absurd," said Bill Crain, a psychology professor at City College, speaking at a news conference in front of City Hall last week. "The charge is really distorted and wrong, and is politically motivated. City University has always graded much tougher than other public universities, and certainly than private universities and colleges in the United States."
Both sides agree on the data. At all but one of the university's four-year colleges, between 40 and 60 percent of the course grades given in the fall semester of 1995 were A's or B's, and at City, Hunter, Lehman and Queens, the rate was between 50 and 60 percent. The highest rate was at Lehman, 59 percent. The rate at Medgar Evers was the lowest, 33 percent.
At the university's six community colleges, the rate was somewhat lower; the proportion of A's or B's in course grades in the fall of 1995 ranged from 40 percent at Queensborough to 51 percent at La Guardia.
But here Mr. Badillo and his critics part company. Mr. Badillo says that those figures are simply too high, and that they put the graduates at a disadvantage. "It undermines the value of the diploma," he said. "Anyone who says this is not happening is in a very serious state of denial."
He said that he believed standards had been lowered because so many of the university's students are members of minorities -- about 55 percent are either African-American or Hispanic. "The politically correct thing is to say the bar should be lowered and that standards should be lowered for blacks and Latinos," Mr. Badillo said. "As a Puerto Rican, I resent that. I competed with other students and still came out on top."
But some City University professors say Mr. Badillo and other trustees and politicians are focusing only on students with the greatest problems, not the top students.
"My classes are superb," said Ed Kent, a philosophy professor at Brooklyn College. "The new waves of immigrants have stronger early educations than the typical American high school student," he said. "They just need to catch up with expanding their vocabularies in English."
Dean Savage, a sociology professor at Queens College, said an independent measure of the quality of City University students was the number who pursued graduate degrees. He said the proportion of graduates from Brooklyn, City, Hunter and Queens who earned Ph.D.'s between 1989 and 1993 was greater than the 3.4 percent national average.
And he and other university professors said their standards were neither lower than those at other colleges nor lower than they were in the past. They pointed to figures from a study of 21,000 student transcripts by the United States Department of Education, which showed that 59 percent of all course grades given to undergraduate students at four-year colleges were A's or B's.
"CUNY's grading sounds about the same," said Clifford Adelman, the senior research analyst at the Department of Education who headed the study. He said that grade point averages at very selective colleges, like the Ivy League, tended to be even higher than those at public universities.
Some City University professors also said there had been little change in their grading systems since World War II. Although there is no centralized data going back that far, grades at one university college, Queens, show only a tiny increase over 50 years, from 2.6 in 1946 to 2.7 today. Like many American colleges, Queens saw a rise in grades in the late 1960's -- its average grade point average climbed to 3.3 in 1970. But then, as on other campuses, grades fell back. Its average grade point average has been roughly constant at about 2.7 since 1980.
A spot check of other public university systems found 2.7 to be below some other major public universities. At the University of Florida, for example, the average grade point average was 3.0 in 1995. At the University of Virginia, it was 3.1 last year. And at the University of Michigan, it was 3.1 in the winter of 1997 and 3.0 in the fall quarter of 1996.
Of course, none of those figures are true measures. Grade inflation is difficult to judge, particularly because it is harder to determine whether classes are graded tougher now than in another period.
As for honors, Brooklyn College does give honors diplomas to students with lower averages than many other colleges, including most other City University colleges. Brooklyn's grade distribution is slightly lower than some of the other colleges -- about 50 percent of its students have A or B averages. But it requires only a 3.0 average for a cum laude degree, the same standard it has used since it was founded in 1930. The university's other four-year colleges set higher minimums, ranging from 3.2 at Baruch, City and John Jay, to 3.5 at Queens.

HEADLINE: NEW YORK ACCORD ON HOSPITALS AID SETS OFF DEBATE

BYLINE: By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ

DATELINE: ALBANY, July 27

 BODY:
New York's aging, ailing hospitals, buffeted by market competition and bracing for an overhaul of Medicaid, have been thrown a lifeline: $1.25 billion in Federal aid over five years to reinvent themselves for the age of managed care.
The money is part of an agreement reached by the Clinton and Pataki administrations last week that for the first time would require most of New York's 3.1 million Medicaid recipients to enroll in health maintenance organizations. The organizations seek to hold down costs by focusing on preventive medicine and limiting access to such things as costly emergency room visits and lengthy hospital stays. 
 Supporters of the aid package say it will offer crucial support to public and nonprofit hospitals, many of them in New York City's poorer neighborhoods, as they struggle to compete and cut costs by establishing networks of neighborhood clinics, retraining workers to provide outpatient services and setting up managed care plans.
Many of these hospitals already face financial crisis, caught between increasingly powerful health maintenance organizations that demand reduced rates for their private paying customers, and state and Federal officials who want to balance their budgets by cutting billions of dollars in hospital payments.
But critics of the deal, particularly health care analysts, say it is a wasteful taxpayer bailout of an inefficient system that has stubbornly refused to adapt to changes in the marketplace.
They say that the money, like subsidies to other struggling industries, from tobacco farming to military contracting, could help keep health care costs artificially high. And they question why it was given exclusively to hospitals and not to the scores of nonprofit community clinics that have become the main providers of primary medical care in many of the state's poorest communities.
"The Government is helping these hospitals adapt, which is really not the responsibility of the Government," said Kenneth S. Abramowitz, a health care analyst at the Sanford C. Bernstein & Company securities firm. "These organizations should have adapted on their own. This just prolongs the agony."
But as is the case with most government subsidies, politics played an important role in guaranteeing this one. Both President Clinton, a Democrat, and Gov. George E. Pataki, a Republican, had been under intense pressure from powerful union leaders and local politicians who rely on the hospitals not only to provide medical care but also to pump jobs and money into many neighborhoods in New York, particularly poorer ones.
"The question is, does this money just subsidize an inefficient system," said Andrew Rein, a research associate for the Citizen's Budget Commission, a budget watchdog group financed by private businesses, "or will it truly help provide a smooth transition for these hospitals to provide care for the poor?"
President Clinton has already approved plans by 13 states to force Medicaid recipients into managed care. But New York's plan stands out because it includes the grants to about 80 public and nonprofit hospitals across the state. The money is given to hospitals that meet two criteria: admissions totaling 5,000 or more annually, with at least 20 percent of that figure including people who are uninsured or on Medicaid.
Federal and state officials insist that New York is not being given a handout, because the $1.25 billion aid package represents money that the Federal Government will save as a result of the state's Medicaid patients moving into managed care.
Many health care experts, union leaders and politicians contend that New York's hospitals need the money, perhaps more than most other hospitals, because they have had a harder time coping with the changes that have transformed the nation's medical industry in recent years.
For one thing, they say, New York's hospitals are financially among the nation's weakest, because they have high debt and low profit margins. Also, the hospitals have for years relied on government insurers to underwrite charity care and pay for the costly, unprofitable emergency room care they provide to patients who do not have private doctors. Last year, hospitals in New York spent about $1.5 billion to care for uninsured people, particularly in poor neighborhoods, according to the Greater New York Hospital Association.
The experts say that the state's hospitals also face a sudden pressure that hospitals elsewhere do not face now: Lawmakers in Albany agreed last year to abolish the state's decades-old policy of setting rates that hospitals can charge. That allowed insurance companies for the first time to negotiate their fees with hospitals, a right that only managed care companies had up to that point, initiating a new era of fierce competition in the hospital industry.
Experts say that the demands on New York's hospitals, particularly those with high numbers of poor patients, will only deepen as a result of last week's decision by the Federal Government to stop the practice of generally paying hospitals for each procedure they perform on Medicaid recipients. Instead, the hospitals will get a set fee for each Medicaid recipient enrolled in a managed care plan, no matter what their ailment or where they are treated.
The proponents of the aid package also maintain that helping hospitals is essential to the state's effort to place most of its 3.1 million Medicaid recipients into H.M.O.'s. That plan will fail, they say, unless the hospitals play a larger role in running primary care clinics and other outpatient services that are essential to any managed care system.
"The biggest question is, are the hospitals ready to absorb the shell shock you incur when you go into a competitive environment?" Kenneth E. Raske, the president of the Greater New York Hospital Association, said. "The money will help hospitals cope with the changes."
New York's medical industry, more than most others, heavily depends on hospitals to deliver care, with its admission rate at 131 for every 1,000 people treated. By contrast, in California, a state widely regarded as a pioneer in managed care, the admission rate is 94 for every 1,000 people treated, according to the American Hospital Association's 1995 Annual Survey of Hospitals. New York also has longer hospital stays, an average of nine days for each person, compared with five days for each person in California.
Those figures mean that the average number of days in the hospital for every 1,000 New Yorkers is 1,179, compared with 470 days for every 1,000 Californians. Some experts believe the difference is explained by the fact that doctors in New York tend to admit patients to hospitals to diagnose potentially grave illnesses, whereas their counterparts in California tend to use outpatient centers.
"We need to invest in building more capacity" in the area of primary care, said Jeffrey Sachs, a health care adviser for 1199, the National Health and Human Service Employees Union, which lobbied for aid to hospitals. "The money will help to build the facilities that will hopefully attract the physicians into inner-city communities."
But critics of the deal contend that a pattern of handouts to the state's largest industry is already beginning to emerge. For example, they point to the recent decision by the Federal Government to make special payments to hospitals that agree to train fewer doctors. They describe that deal as a subsidy to an industry with powerful political ties at a time when hospitals elsewhere are struggling to hold down costs.
The objection to the latest aid package stems largely from the fact that New York already has a glut of hospital beds that are going unused. The critics maintain that allowing a few hospitals to close would yield much-needed savings in the industry by eliminating fixed costs like the maintenance of aging buildings, among other things.
Jeff Goldsmith, a health care analyst with Health Futures Inc. in Charlotte, Va., contends that hospital closings will free money that can be invested in building primary care networks. That is why he questions the decision to pump yet more public money into hospitals that are already too dependent on such financing. "I think this is a questionable investment of public money," he said. "This is like crops support."
But Kenneth E. Thorpe, the director of the Institute for Health Services Research at Tulane University Medical Center, says things are not that simple. He agrees that a few hospital closings would be far more cost-effective than the alternative now being pursued: helping the industry as a whole scale back the number of unneeded beds it has accumulated.
But Mr. Thorpe also acknowledges that there is a risk to allowing the free market alone to determine the fate of New York's hospitals at this stage: Struggling hospitals in low-income neighborhoods would probably be the first to close, meaning that the poorest New Yorkers would be left with little or no medical care.
That is the concern that drove many officials to push the Federal Government to provide the aid package to New York's hospitals.
The debate over the aid package has centered on another important question: Why did the deal not include money for community health clinics that for years played important roles in poor neighborhoods by building networks of primary care physicians when others would not? Would it not make sense, critics ask, to infuse these clinics with money to modernize and expand, particularly since they have often done a better job than hospitals in delivering basic care? Beyond that, they ask, why allow hospitals to build new clinics, as some have suggested, when these others already exist?
The money is particularly important for the roughly 80 clinics across New York State because about 50 percent of their patients are Medicaid recipients, according to the Community Health Care Association of New York State, a group that represents the clinics.
For their part, the administrations of both Governor Pataki and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said they would like to see some of the money used to help clinics do things like hire more doctors and expand their buildings.
In fact, Dr. Rosa M. Gil, the director for Health Services in the Giuliani administration, says that much of the $500 million the city will receive for its hospitals will be spent on expanding existing community health clinics, not building new ones. "We believe the funding should be to enhance what we have, not to build new clinics," she said. "The last resort will be to create new clinics."

HEADLINE: Workfare Must Train Participants for Real Jobs;
Workfare's Dark Side

 BODY:

To the Editor:
We would like to clarify one crucial issue raised by your July 24 front-page article on the campaign to protest New York City's workfare program. 
 The article referred to "workfare employees." The city vigorously insists that workfare workers are not employees and, therefore, do not qualify for laws guaranteeing payment of prevailing wages, the right to organize, or health and safety protections. Workfare workers are also not eligible for overtime, promotion, the earned income tax credit, unemployment insurance or Social Security.
The city wants to have it both ways. First, it points to valuable services provided by workfare workers, for which the city would otherwise have to hire regular employees. Then, it turns around and claims that workfare is just a transitional training program.
 
HEIDI DOROW
PETER LAARMAN
New York, July 24, 1997
 
The writers are, respectively, director of the Urban Justice Center's Organizing Project and senior minister at Judson Memorial Church.

HEADLINE: Mayor's Coliseum Plan Threatens Lincoln Center Expansion

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HALBFINGER

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's sudden call for a large theater to be built as part of the redevelopment of the New York Coliseum has called into question Lincoln Center's own plan to build another theater four blocks away.
A Lincoln Center official said yesterday that there was no room for two theaters so close to each other. 
 In threatening on Saturday to veto the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's leading choice of a developer for the Coliseum site, Mayor Giuliani said he felt it was "enormously important" that the project be redesigned to include a theater of 1,000 to 2,000 seats, for jazz, opera or Broadway performances.
But officials at Lincoln Center have been negotiating for months to build an intimate theater at Broadway and 64th Street to complement the 3,000-seat New York State Theater and the 3,800-seat Metropolitan Opera. And as one executive at Lincoln Center said of the Mayor's preference, "We're not interested in two theaters."
Mr. Giuliani's aides said yesterday that adding a theater to the Coliseum site at Columbus Circle was likely to lower the price a developer would pay the Metropolitan Transportation Authority for the property, because a theater would have to replace a commercial tenant that could afford a higher rent.
Neither Millenium Partners, the authority's leading choice to redevelop the site, nor the four other finalists have yet incorporated a theater in their plans.
Lincoln Center, meanwhile, has been negotiating since the beginning of the year with Millenium on a different project, at 1926 Broadway, where the company offered to build a multipurpose theater of up to 1,200 seats as part of a high-rise building with retail stores and apartments.
Lincoln Center was to have depended largely on the city to pay for that theater, officials said. About 40 percent of the cost would have come from the city's Trust for Cultural Resources, which would have issued bonds to be paid off with the additional tax revenue generated by the rest of Millennium's project. In addition, 20 percent would have come from the city's capital budget.
Aides to the Mayor said the project directly opposite Lincoln Center's fountain plaza had encountered problems with zoning and had apparently stalled.
Regardless, an executive at a Lincoln Center organization, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said that the city's control of financing gave the Mayor nearly total control over a new theater site.
Executives at the transportation authority and Millennium did not return telephone calls yesterday seeking comment. Nathan Leventhal, the president of Lincoln Center, declined to comment.
Randy Levine, the Deputy Mayor for Economic Development, Planning and Administration, said Mr. Giuliani's desire for a theater on Columbus Circle should not surprise the would-be developers. "The Mayor's been talking about it for months," he said. "The developers knew about it, the M.T.A. knew about it. It's been no secret."
One city official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said that building a theater at the Coliseum site could cost $15 million, compared to a total cost for the project of around $300 million. "If I were the developer, I'd ask the M.T.A. to give them that much off the purchase price," the official said. "Wouldn't you?"
Mayor Giuliani had long wanted some cultural or public use to be incorporated into the Coliseum site, such as additional ballroom space for conventions, or the Manhattan outpost of an institution like the Brooklyn Museum, said John S. Dyson, chair of the Mayor's Council of Economic Advisers and a city representative on the authority board.
The Mayor, an opera enthusiast, began pushing for a new theater at the Coliseum after Mr. Leventhal and Beverly Sills, the chairwoman of Lincoln Center's board of directors, met with him to discuss the center's need for space, Mr. Dyson said.
One of the most likely tenants of any new theater is the Jazz at Lincoln Center program, whose artistic director, Wynton Marsalis, has yet to find it a permanent home. The Metropolitan Opera has conducted an on-again, off-again search for a performance space more suitable than the Met for light opera. And Christyne Lategano, the Mayor's director of communications, said Broadway producers had also expressed interest in another large theater. Most Broadway houses seat between 600 and 1,000 people.
"The people at Lincoln Center may well prefer to be on Central Park West or Broadway," Mr. Dyson said. "But in truth, this is going to be a wonderful destination."

CORRECTION-DATE: July 29, 1997, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's call for a new theater on the site of the New York Coliseum paraphrased the reaction of a Lincoln Center official incorrectly. The official, who spoke on the condition that he would not be named, said that Lincoln Center, which has been seeking to build a theater of its own at Broadway and 64th Street, did not need two new theaters for itself. He did not say that the area could not accommodate two new theaters.
In addition, the phrasing of the headline exceeded the scope of the article. The Mayor's proposed theater at the Coliseum could be incorporated into the Lincoln Center expansion; it would not threaten the expansion. Further developments in the situation are reported today on page B3.

HEADLINE: Jewish Voyagers to the New World Emerging From History's Mists

BYLINE: By ANDREE BROOKS 

 BODY:
AN enduring image of the earliest Europeans to arrive in the New World, with help from Hollywood, is an overdressed Conquistador, crucifix or sword held high, spreading salvation among the indigenous population.
That concept is now undergoing re-evaluation. For hidden under his breastplate, in spirit if not in fact, may well have been a Star of David; the crucifix more protective cover than symbol of a crusading zeal. 
 For the Jews were far more significant in the earliest exploration, settlement and development of the Caribbean and South America than has previously been acknowledged.
Why and how this happened and why it has received scant attention was the theme of a recent conference at the John Carter Brown Library at Brown University. Called "The Jews and the Expansion of Europe to the West," it brought together about 30 scholars from as far afield as Brazil and Holland and disciplines from economic history to anthropology.
The main organizers were the library and the Touro National Heritage Trust, an affiliate of the Touro Synagogue in Newport, R.I.
The chief reason for years of oversight, scholars agreed, had to do with definition: virtually all Jews playing a significant role in the earliest development of the New World were involuntary converts, known interchangeably as New Christians, Conversos or Marranos. They had been coerced into conversion in the bloody period of persecution and elimination of Judaism in Spain and Portugal at the close of the 15th century.
No wonder the bright prospects of a newly discovered faraway land an ocean away from persecution and filled with untold riches provoked a heavy wave of Jewish migration. The trade potential was especially appealing to these Iberian or Sephardic Jews, expert international traders since the Middle Ages, when they had been a significant presence throughout the Mediterranean.
Conference presentations were dotted with colorful stories. Consider that of the covert Jewish Conquistador Alonso de Avila. He first enlists in the army of Hernando Cortes -- as a bookkeeper. In appreciation for accounting services rendered, he is then made the first mayor of the newly created city of Veracruz. But the glory is fleeting. He is arrested as a relapsed Jew by the Mexican Inquisition, accused of keeping a crucifix under his writing table and stepping on it -- a common but spurious charge, said Dr. Eva Alexandra Uchmany of the Universidad Nacional in Mexico, who told the story.
Other Iberian Inquisition practices gave these migrations a further boost. Dr. Geraldo Pieroni, professor of history at the University of Brasilia, told how deportation to Brazil was a customary sentence meted out by the Portuguese Inquisition in the 16th, 17th and 18th centuries.
Dr. Anita Novinsky, a professor of history at the University of San Paulo, estimated that in the region around Rio de Janeiro and the state of Bahia, New Christians constituted 20 percent of the European population by the 17th and 18th centuries; the number rose to50 percent in the Paraiba region near Recife, the core of the lucrative sugar trade.
Today, she said, so many Brazilians are eager to retrace their family lineages that organizations are forming for people who believe they come from New Christian stock and want to reclaim their Jewish ancestry. It is known in Spanish as "la sangre llama" (the blood is calling), said Mordechai Arbell, a former Israeli ambassador to Colombia, Panama and Haiti, and a specialist on Caribbean Jewry. The first 23 Jews to arrive in New York Harbor, in September 1654, scholars noted, were Brazilians descended from New Christians who returned to Judaism.
By the early 18th century, half the European population of Suriname, then a territory of the Netherlands, was Jewish, reported Dr. Wim Klooster, a Dutch historian. In Suriname, they could come out of the religious closet, having won freedom of worship under the more tolerant Dutch. They were considered so important to the economic well-being of Suriname that they were given the right "to labor on Sundays." A thriving agricultural village on the Suriname River in the early 1700's was called Joden Savanne (Jewish Savannah).
In Dutch Curacao, Jewish importance to the commercial viability of the settlement was deemed sufficient to allow Jewish schools to stay open on Sunday. Jewish ships plying the Atlantic carried such names as the Mazel Tov or Bekeerde Jood (converted Jew), Dr. Klooster said.
The researchers said Jewish success resulted mainly from tight family networks, which created what were essentially international corporations. These emerged as other family members, also under constant jeopardy from Inquisition spies, sought refuge in the more tolerant societies of Amsterdam, western France and London.
From there they could provide the reliable shipping, credit and trading links for a nascent commerce coping with risky voyages over thousands of windswept miles and prey to dishonest captains and sneak attacks by warring nations and pirates. The family networks also kept members accountable to one another.
"Those who could minimize risk were destined to become the most successful players," said Dr. John J. McCusker, a professor of economics at Trinity University in San Antonio.
Dr. Silvia Marzagalli, a French maritime historian from the University of Bordeaux, told how youthful family members would first be sent to Amsterdam for a commercial education and then on to the Caribbean to serve as company agents. Marriages were arranged with an eye toward expanding the network.
These settlers all still spoke a common language -- either Judeo-Spanish, also known as Ladino, or Portuguese. This seamlessly knit openly practicing Jews and their New Christian relatives in British, Dutch, French, Spanish and Portuguese-speaking domains.
One measure of their success, scholars noted, was constant accusations of unfair competition and of practicing black arts through the use of secret signs and symbols; Judeo-Spanish was often written using Hebrew characters. Another was the arrival of the Inquisition in the New World. "A Castillian of pure stock has not a ghost of a show against these Portuguese," one participant testified in a Peruvian Inquisition trial, according to Dr. Irene Silverblatt, a cultural anthropologist at Duke University.
On one occasion in the 1600's, Lima was plunged into economic chaos after the mass arrest and execution of the city's leading merchants, all of them New Christians, she said.
In the final analysis, despite the economic success of these New Christians, they lost out in the larger historical sweepstakes; they were scorned by Old Christian society and, for the most part, overlooked by Jewish history.

HEADLINE: Observer;
Another Loophole Bonanza

BYLINE: By RUSSELL BAKER 

 BODY:
They call it a tax cut. Don't believe it. What's really happening is the construction of 10,000 new loopholes in a tax law already packed with special breaks for favored groups.
The new loopholes will compound the complexity of a tax code already more complicated than a barrel of snakes. 
 A tax cut is when they say, "Ah, you lucky Americans, we're reducing the rate on everybody's taxes." The bill being cooked up in Washington does not say that. It does not cut rates across the board. The cuts are for preferred customers only.
All we're talking about is a writhing mass of loopholes meant to pay off political debts and court various voter blocs.
Is my forecast of 10,000 new loopholes excessive? True, I made it up without help from my economists. I don't have any economists.
I mean no slander against economists when pointing out that theirs is an uncertain trade. Even the great Greenspan (Alan, chairman of the Federal Reserve), who has access to the best economists the world has to offer -- even the great Greenspan didn't know that the big bull market was going to go on forever.
And so a few months back he tried to cool everybody off, only to find, as of yesterday, that the big bull market is indeed going to go on forever.
Unless, of course, it doesn't. Often in economics, things that ought to go on forever, such as stock market hounds getting fatter by the day, stop going on forever. Afterward, economists tell you why; for predicting, though, they are not that great.
What effect the new tax-loophole bill might have on anything depends on which side's economists you believe, but there are so many differing economists' forecasts that all you can get from reading them is a headache.
Why get a headache?
I make up my own statistics using hard-gained experience, folk wisdom and wild guesses, then discount for the virtual certainty that nothing will ever turn out the way you think it will.
And so when I say the new loophole bill will create 10,000 new loopholes, I say it not with the economist's respect for statistical data, but with the reasonable certainty of a man who has watched tax laws come and tax laws go for nigh on half a century.
That experience leaves me persuaded that when 50,000 corporation tax lawyers and 50,000 corporation tax accountants sink their teeth into a nice juicy new tax bill they can always find at least 10,000 new loopholes.
Much of the fanciest mental produce of the Ivy League law schools devotes its life to uncovering tax dodges hiding in the latest tax laws. The most brilliant accounting graduates of our great schools of business and finance are on the job in behalf of organizations that pay extremely well for experts who can ferret out hidden tax-law goodies.
Ten thousand loopholes? It is almost as certain as a sun rising in the east tomorrow.
Much publicity has attached to the gross favors being done for the uptown swells in the loophole bill, but fatties are not its only beneficiaries.
Do you have children? Tough bun if you don't, because a new $500-a-kid tax credit is yours only if you do. This scheme evokes a macabre memory of Nazi Germany, which used government incentives to raise the birth rate. If you want a tax cut, procreate.
A loophole to encourage parents to send the kids to college? Surely the colleges, whose prices rise with the speed of Jack's beanstalk, will lose no time lapping up the benefits of this one.
We probably deserve absurdities like this loophole bill for our hatred of real tax reform. With the widening gap between haves and have-nots, sensible policy might be to cut the rates for the lower income brackets and raise them for the uppers.
A monstrous thing to say, isn't it? I can't believe I said it. What am I, O merciless mouthpieces of Talk Radio World? A liberal, elitist, big-taxer, tax-and-spend Ivory Tower resident? Oh, shame!
Yet in the 1950's rates in the upper brackets rose to over 90 percent, and it was the golden age of the American economy.

HEADLINE: A Dynamic Farewell From a Longtime Rights Leader

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK 

DATELINE: ATLANTA, July 28

 BODY:
He preached and beseeched. He bounced and denounced.
And by the time the Rev. Joseph E. Lowery completed his rhyming, rollicking farewell address as president of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference today, a capacity crowd at the historic Ebenezer Baptist Church had been reminded why Mr. Lowery, a Methodist preacher, is considered one of the civil rights movement's most powerful -- and colorful -- orators and spokesmen. 
 In his 40 years with the conference, the group he helped found with his two predecessors, the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and the Rev. Ralph D. Abernathy, Mr. Lowery has thrived as the master of the bon mot. He has battled segregation and discrimination not only with his actions but also with his carefully crafted words.
Mr. Lowery's eyes twinkled impishly today as he, at 75, delivered one witticism after another, always in the singular cadence and idiom of the black church that nurtured him and his movement.
Speaking of the need for black Americans to free themselves from self-hatred and substance abuse, for instance, he offered this Loweryism: "If you can take care of the internal, you can easily take care of the external. Then you can avoid the infernal and latch on to the eternal."
And in defending affirmative action, the cause with which he is most identified these days, he said: "When the government, by public policy, kept you out, the government has a responsibility, by public policy, to bring you in. And it needs to be just as intentional about including you as it was about excluding you."
As president of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference for 20 years, Mr. Lowery has preserved and refocused an organization that grew out of segregationist times that no longer exist. Without Jim Crow as a catalyst for action, he has turned the group's attention to economic issues like affirmative action and minority business development, as well as fighting the explosion of violent crime and AIDS among blacks.
To honor his 40-year career with the organization, the conference has dedicated its annual convention here this week to paying tribute. It did so at a gala on Sunday night that featured a videotaped message from President Clinton, as well as speeches by movement like Coretta Scott King and Andrew J. Young.
Mrs. King, the widow of Dr. King, called Mr. Lowery "a history maker and a soul shaker."
Mr. Young, a former mayor of Atlanta and United States representative at the United Nations, said Mr. Lowery had "kept the torch aglow."
The Rev. Jesse Jackson called Mr. Lowery "an enduring figure" who has been underappreciated. In an apparent reference to Dr. King, Mr. Jackson said there had been "so much focus on the work of Moses as the leader who first broke the line that there was not ever adequate appreciation for Joshua, who organized the subsequent battles."
The primary sponsor of the tribute dinner was Shoney's, the restaurant chain that was sued for racial discrimination in the early 1990's and then signed financial covenants with the conference under pressure from Mr. Lowery. The agreements call on the company to spend nearly $200 million on promoting minority employment and business development.
Mr. Lowery's retirement signals a generational transition for the organization and, by extension, for the civil rights movement as a whole. After his departure, the group will no longer be led by one of the Alabama preachers who came together to fight for the desegregation of buses in Montgomery, and then of public accommodations and polling places around the South.
Indeed, the organization seems stymied, at least for now, in searching for a successor. After Mr. Lowery spoke, board officials announced that he had agreed to stay on for 90 days as the search continues.
The group had been scheduled to elect a successor on Wednesday.
Among those who have interviewed for the job, said several officials, are Dr. King's son Martin Luther King 3d, a former county commissioner in Atlanta; Dr. Abernathy's son Ralph David Abernathy 3d, a Georgia state senator; Walter E. Fauntroy, a board member and a former Congressional delegate from the District of Columbia, and Earl T. Shinhoster, a former director of the Atlanta regional office of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.
Mr. Lowery said he did not plan to retire from the movement, just the burdens of running the conference.
"I'll be raising hell without having to raise the budget," he said.
The annual budget of $2.5 million supports a staff of about 35 people and 300 chapters and affiliates. In recent years, the organization has been active in bringing attention to the burning of black churches in the South, to negotiating minority business development covenants with Shoney's and the Publix supermarket chain and to starting a gun buy-back program.
Mr. Lowery urged members to "move from the back court of too little action to the front court of a new era of activism."
And he did not let Mr. Clinton's praise prevent him from taking a swipe at the President. After praising Mr. Clinton's eloquence on racial issues -- "the boy can tell a story," Mr. Lowery said -- he chastised the President for a lack of follow-up.
"He quits right after the opening hymn," Mr. Lowery said, "and never makes it to the benediction."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Optimism on Report Today Lifts Bonds

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Treasury prices surged yesterday, bolstered by optimism that today's Employment Cost Index report would show that labor costs remained subdued.
"There's some anticipation that the number tomorrow will be a good one" for bonds, said William Gross, who oversees $90 billion of bonds at the Pacific Investment Management Company in Newport Beach, Calif. 
 The price of the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond rose 21/32, to 102 31/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 6.40 percent, from 6.45 percent on Friday.
Bond prices were also supported yesterday by a stronger dollar, which makes bonds more attractive to foreign investors.
And bonds received a further boost late in the day after the Treasury estimated that it would borrow $10 billion in the financial markets during the current quarter, less than previously estimated, because of strong tax receipts. It also said it retired a record $71.5 billion of debt in the second quarter.
The moves might make existing bonds more valuable, by shrinking the pool of available debt, traders said.
The Treasury announcement was a prelude to tomorrow's quarterly financing news conference, at which Treasury officials will disclose their plans for next week's sale of 3-year notes, 10-year notes and 30-year bonds. Those securities will make up a major portion of Treasury borrowing for the quarter.
At yesterday's regular weekly auction of new three-month and six-month bills, the Treasury sold $11.59 billion in three-month bills at an average discount rate of 5.12 percent, up from 5.11 percent last week. The Treasury also sold $12.14 billion in six-month bills at an average rate of 5.15 percent, down from 5.17 percent.
Today's Employment Cost Index report kicks off a busy week for economic releases. It will be followed by second-quarter gross domestic product on Thursday and the July jobs report Friday, as well as reports on manufacturing, housing and consumer confidence.
Economists forecast a rise of eight-tenths of 1 percent in the Employment Cost Index, compared with an increase of six-tenths of 1 percent in the previous quarter.
Bonds rallied the last time the report was released, on April 29, when it showed labor costs rose less than expected in the first quarter. Rising wages are viewed as a precursor of inflation, which eats away at bonds' fixed payments.
Much of the optimism among bond investors comes from the upbeat appraisal of the economy from Alan Greenspand, the Federal Reserve chairman, during two days of testimony to Congress last week. He called the economy's mix of strong growth and low inflation "exceptional."
Following are the results of the Treasury's auction of three-month and six-month bills:
